review: Despite the bad reviews, Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom is a movie that if it is worth seeing, it may not be the best of the saga, but I would not classify it as the worst either, since, to tell the truth, I think it is the best sequel to Jurassic Park ever made (my favoritism for TLW aside), it's even better than Jurassic World! Here are my reasons: - Memorable and well developed characters. - An original and well-executed story. - A soundtrack that was only surpassed! like photography, it's the best! The original essence of the first movies is back! and the CGI is great! It is very well worked, you can see the dedication with which it was made. - Finally, we cannot forget that we will open the doors for what is to come in 2022 in Jurassic World: Dominion! In conclusion I must say that although most of them are negative reviews, the important thing is that you give your own opinion, so I ask you to give it a chance, it may not be among your favorites but I assure you that it will make you have a very good time. a while.

review: one the best movies for kids

Based on the fairy tale "The Snow Queen" by Hans Christian Anderson and is a project in the works since the beginnings of Disney. This is hands down one of the best musicals Disney has created. This starts with the amazing work of Robert Lopez and Kristen Anderson-Lopez who were the song composers for this film and Christophe Beck who was the score composer. The score wonderfully sets the backdrop and the songs are all memorable and work so well with the themes and character arcs. The casting is also perfect as all the main character voice actors have experience performing on Broadway. The work on the animation is also well done with great particle effects for the snow and noticeable improvements on human hair. I understand the oversaturation of this film in pop culture, however I fully believe it is well deserved. This was the highest grossing animated movie of all time until The Lion King remake and this movie's sequel overtook it in 2019 . An absolute must watch!

review_date: 'Frozen' is Disney's newest phenomenon, and rightfully so. The incredible plot with uniquely created and voiced characters combined with some of the best musical numbers we've seen from Disney are some clear signs that this film deserves all the success that is coming its way. Its refreshing to see a princess, or queen, who doesn't need a prince charming to help her through her journey. The twists are turns of the plot make this movie accessible for any audience. It is truly one of the greats.
review: SHOW MORE

The animated film "Frozen" was created thanks to the wonderful people Chris Buck, Jennifer Lee. The first part was released in 2013 and made a splash. 3 Speaking of the plot, it is quite heavy even for an adult, because even my parents were touched by the plot. The drawing itself is at a height, everything is very clear and every detail is drawn, which pleases the eyes. One of the most important things is that even though it is a cartoon, but all the emotions are perfectly conveyed and touch the soul. Thanks again to the smallest details, you can very well understand each character, well, except for Prince Hans( my most hated character). Of course, the cartoon has a sequel, this is its second part, but the first one will always remain in my heart. Although, I don't mind the third part) so "Frozen" is the best animated film I've ever seen. Personally, I review it every time, as if I'm watching it for the first time ( but honestly Ive already watched it 10 times). I wont get tired of saying that this is my favorite cartoon! ^-^

This was the first movie I ever saw in the theatres as a child. Seriously, if you are looking for a funny family friendly movie, I would recommend this one. It really differs from your average Disney movie as it isn't based on "true love kiss" and "boys" and "I need a prince to rule." The characters are hilarious and make you smile. But if you are watching with kids you will probably be hearing "Let it go!" for weeks on end. Even as a teenager now, my little sister puts it on and I sit with her and actually enjoy most of it. As a young child, I literally spammed let it go everywhere I went (looking back I am shocked by how my family didn't go crazy!) If you are looking for a family movie, this one is great as long as you don't mind the potential of a Frozen-obsessed daughter. The plot is a literal rollercoaster and enjoyable. review: A live action remake of the 1991 animated film of the same name. There are some big names in this film: Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Ewan McGregor as Lumiere, Ian McKellen as Cogsworth, etc. They all do a great job with what they are given, except for the music. With the exception of "Gaston", all the songs in this film feel unemotional and over processed. Some of this, I feel, is due to the fact that there is limited musical theater experience with the actors chosen for this film. Ewan McGreagor is good, but he can't hold a candle (pun intended) to Jerry Orbach's many years of musical acting experience. The CGI for the Beast's face was lacking and I'm sure it hid a great facial performance from Stevens. There were a couple of scenes where Watson felt like a stick saying, or singing, lines. The added material didn't feel necessary to the story, though some of the plot holes from the original film were plugged. Nostalgia fueled the success of this film and maybe that will be enough for you to enjoy it as well.

review: I really love the moral behind "Beauty and the Beast", and it's the only Disney romance which still gets me. It's an important lesson about the ideas behind the curse of Beauty. In my mythological soup, this stands for The Judgment of Paris, where Aphrodite was chosen as the fairest (Athena DID NOT like this) because of her ability to provide a beautiful wife for the shepherd prince. The Beast becomes a Beast in mind because he has objectified his kingdom through beauty. Beast is a stand-in for Mercury, and/or Dionysus, and that's why the beautiful Athena-like witch shows up in ugly drag to test his hospitality. When he turns the witch away based on exterior appearances, not recognizing the beauty of her wisdom, she curses his kingdom to be physical objects until Beauty reappears. Then it's up to Beauty to reverse the curse through her wisdom, by seeing past the objectification of the Beast as a horrible animal to locked up in a mansion with his material things. It's important here that Belle is the hero. The Beast can't fix himself, he's the victim, and only someone who reads books and doesn't just stare at the covers can put it all together before the rose loses her last petal...

Incredibles 2 is a serviceable enough sequel to a superior predecessor. The plot is expectedly fun, if not thoroughly predictable. The animation and voice work shine, but the exhaustingly toxic family dynamics often wear thin quickly. If it wasn't for the thoroughly engaging action, Incredibles 2 might be worth skipping just to spare yourself the misery of observing this decidedly abrasive family in their natural, joyless habitat.

I was so pumped to watch this when it came out in theatres. Storyline was predictable, the tension with the family dynamics made this uncomfortable to watch. I understand they were trying to show relatability, but it could have been done differently. Storyline itself was very dull. Emotional maturity of Bob Parr‚Äî eeehhh.. Best parts of the movie were indeed the raccoon, Jack-Jack, and scenes with Edna Mode. During the latter parts of the movie, I literally just wanted it to end. Three years (2015-2018) of waiting for this movie, walked out extremely disappointed. Watched it for the second time last night, no, just an absolute no. I understand the animation was smoother. But certain scenes were "cut" too sharply. The ending of Edna Mode's scene was abrupt, cant quite describe it. If you watch it at that point, you'll understand. So sad. There was so much potential. It felt rushed "heregivemeyourmoneyandwatchthis" Just slapped together, in hopes of it being a success. It was far from being a success. :(
The film's basically Ghostbusters II. And overtime, I feel like the sequel gets a little worse with each viewing, while the original gets better and better.

Ok, so this movie is pretty good, and has all the good stuff from the original movie, but it has a few too many problems that prevent it from being as good as the first movie. First, all the things that I thought were basically spectacular. All the stuff that involves them actually being superheros is really good, not better then what was in the first, but still really good. Next is the animation, which feels very different then all the others. This feels like it's stylized for the 1950s, which the film takes place. Some people can find that distracting, but I didn't. Also, all the new characters are either good or funny, except for one thing, but I'll save that for a little later. Now, let's talk about all the things that this movie just didn't do well enough in, which keeps it from being as good as the original. The main thing is really the characters that are brought back. Except for Elastagirl, Frozone, and Jack-Jack, all the old characters feel significant weaker. I don't want to say this, but the worse character in this movie by far is Mr Incredible. He is either acting completely crazy, completely mean or ignorant, or is not really blaming himself for everything that is going wrong with the family. I'm sorry, that's a huge problem that you can't fix with just one scene. Violet and Dash seem weaker too, but I was able to look past them. I, however, cannot look past Mr Incredible. Also, another big problem is the stupid twist villain. I know Pixar has done them before, but only one of them was actually bad (Miles Axelrod from Cars 2 ring a bell for anyone?). That is‚Ä¶until the Screenslaver shows up. This was the first time I was able actually to predict the twist villain in a Pixar movie, which made it super boring. It's also really hard when the last villain in this franchise, Syndrome, is the best Pixar villain ever. So, with all of that said, I still think this a good film that everyone should watch. All the superhero stuff (besides the villain), is still spectacular, you're just gonna have to sit through a bunch of the family stuff that isn't as strong. I think that's the biggest difference between this movie and the original. "The Incredibles" is a family and character study first, and a superhero movie second. "Incredibles 2", however, is a superhero film first, and a family film second. If you don't mind the change, then you'll think this movie is great! If not, like me, you'll only think the movie is pretty good, almost great. But hey, why listen to me? Go to Disney+ and watch this almost "Incredible" movie!

This movie is nothing that lives up to where The Incredibles 1 was going. All those years since the first film! Screenslaver's character was too obvious. The only fun part of the Incredibles 2 is the raccoon vs Jack Jack scene.

Super interesting story that introduces many plot lines without feeling too messy, and the visuals are insane

I really don't like the fact that its name doesn't have The before it. Like, why? Now the two movies won't be next to each other whenever they are alphabetically arranged. But anyway, that's just a minor inconvenience. I hope that's the only problem I have with this movie, other than probably the fact that it's nowhere as memorable as the first movie. While The Incredibles is something of a pop culture icon this movie is, well, let's just say we'd have never learnt about it if it wasn't advertised so much. Incredibles 2 starts off from the part where the prequel left. And it finally answers the question of what happened in the fight between the Parr family and the Moleman - It... Happened. The only thing that came out of it was that Violet's BF learnt about her identity, which was later wiped out (or so I remember, I don't even think this movie was memorable enough. I'm remembering all the scenes as I'm writing this). So now Helen is out on another adventure, leaving Bob with the kids. And he's terrible at handling them. It was a very funny scene, seeing him struggle everyday trying to help Dash with his homework and Jack Jack in changing his diapers. The family moves into a new home which is way better than their previous one. Dash and Violet discover Bob's car and they bring it home. Then something something Helen finds out the guy who she's working with has a sister who is her costume designer, and she's secretly evil. And now it's up to the kids to save the day with all the superpowers and plot armours. See this is exactly the problem of this movie. It is super predictable, although that's not a bad thing since the way those scenes are executed make it very satisfactory to watch. The animation of this movie is probably the best thing about it. It is one of the only things which has improved drastically since the first movie. The Incredibles, you might remember, was very cool. But I just wrote a review of it yesterday and it was then that I realised the quality of that movie has aged terribly. In terms of polygon count this one takes the win. However, I also mentioned in that review that the thing which makes The Incredibles so much fun to watch is that it feels like a videogame, something similar to Sonic the Hedgehog or Spider-Man for PS4. That's not something I could say about this movie. Incredibles 2 isn't one of the movies Pixar is known for making. It's something of a sequel that can only satisfy you that the fight in the end of the first movie didn't end on a suspenseful note. It is a one-time watch for the fans of the first movie, although the kids might like it since the movie seemed to be more oriented towards them.

(SPOILERS) Honestly I am almost tempted to say I like Incredibles 2 better that the original. The characters are great as always and there is some real character development the music is spot on and I really enjoyed the moments between Bob and his kids and the awesome action sequences between Helen her self. I honestly have a blast watching this sequel, however the only problem that I have with this movie is the villain Evilen Deavor. On the one hand her character is really great. She and her brother Winston Deavor have interesting and intense back stories and have good moments with each other, however the movie kinda drags just a tad because there really trying to hide the fact that one of them is the main villain. Another thing is that Evilen's plan can kinda get confusing at times. However that doesn't mean that it takes away from the movie itself though. There is this seen with the Screen Slayer a villain that Evilen herself created and has some of coolest moments in the movie. However going into that seen though there are flashing lights so you have been warned. That scene was pretty thrilling and even haunting. However the best action scene in the entire movie was the opening which was just straight awesome and so satisfying. Incredibles 2 might have a few problems with its villain but as an overall movie it is still pretty incredible. 9.8/10

Honestly the best animated sequel Pixar or Disney has ever made. I like how we pick up right where the original left off. It stayed true to the original characters as well as the style. It was just more refined and made it more entertaining to watch. Of course it's not the original but it took a well known story and added onto it perfectly. I enjoy how it focused on Elastagirl and really showed how before becoming a house wife she was a force to be reckoned with. I think the villain was very unique and there was a good twist added in. Th animation was really smooth and all the original actors came back which made it more fun for the audience because you can see how much they actually enjoy playing these characters. All in all the perfect sequel!

review: The Fate of the Furious continues the downhill spiral of mediocrity that is the fast and furious franchise. Once a fairly ok but fun series of movies about street racing and fighting organized crime has now become a multi million dollar franchise about extraordinary heist crime action that defies the laws of physics, stupid characters, plot devices that make no sense, and just simple stupidity. Previous movies are fun enough to watch including this one but it does not make it good. In this one Dominic Toretto played by Vin Diesel betrays his team of street racers turned into international crime fighters with nice cars. The story is completely ludicrous although it tries to make some sense but in the end is just dumb. The villain played by Charlize Teron is badass and formidable as Teron brings her incredible presence that she carries into every movie yet the character motives are questionable and flat out cartoony. The only fun thing here is The Rocks and Jason Stahams chemistry which is hilarious and great which led to the spin off Hobbs and Shaw. Otherwise the rest is a bunch of explosions and impossible action pieces in a movie universe that is supposed to be realistic and is now trying to mimic superhero movies. This franchise is losing steam.
rt_name: The Fate of the Furious - Movie Reviews

review: Ok so for F10, we should have an actual car race, which is what this movie series should be about. AHAHAHAHAHA, car race? What do we look like, idiot? That's the dumbest thing to have in a FF movie. Rewatch this before seeing F9 tomorrow. Not gonna bother talking about the story, cliche dialogues, villain that only say stuff slowly and slam the keyboard, or family stuff, because that is just a vehicle for the movie to exist, so that they can lay waste to as many cars as possible. It is important that after watching too many movies, you just gotta turn your brain off and enjoy a dumb movie. And the later installments of this franchise is just what I need. Watching so many cars getting destroyed and blown up was crazy fun. The best scene was for sure the remote car control scene. It was ridiculous in all the entertaining way. Dwayne as Hobbs and Jason as Shaw were great as usual. I like both of them, and Dwayne displaying his alpha body was just great. Just watch these movies with the right mindset and expectation and you will get the most fun out of them. 7.5/10

review: Another entry in the successful F&F franchise. Overall the movie does not impress. Charlize Theron, Jason Statham and Dwayne Johnson performance save the movie, which suffers from the presence of an overly cheesy Vin Diesel. The first part of the movie was enjoyable and fun, but Gary Gray tends to drag it a little too much towards the end. It is obvious what was gonna happen and, honestly, I expected more fireworks and CGI magic. I'd recommend it to long-time F&F fans and people who like a good laugh at unrealistic action scene, but the fifth and the sixth chapters were more enjoyable and action packed. Looking forward to watch the next adventures of Toretto and co.
rt_name: The Fate of the Furious - Movie Reviews

review: Loved it! Way better in my opinion than the 7th one, which was not very good due to the action filming from James Wan and putting characters like Mia way off to the side. I watched the extended edition of this film, which in my opinion was perfect (you can rent it for the same price on Amazon). The humor and action were really good in this movie, and I loved some of the twists and turns in this movie. While it could've been generic, as suggested by some of the trailers, this movie constantly stays unique IMO. While it is VERY over-the-top, it didn't feel nearly as stupid (in a bad way) as the last one. With great action, humor, and emotion, this film is one of the best in the franchise in my opinion.
rt_name: The Fate of the Furious - Movie Reviews

review: Another solid entry in the Fast & Furious franchise which improves upon the scattered story of the previous film. Paul Walker's absence is felt throughout, but thankfully this isn't a major plot point and doesn't hold the film back from having fun. I appreciated that the writers took this film in a slightly (really very slightly) different direction by having some betrayal within the group. Dwayne Johnson finally feels utilized in this entry with far more screen time and humor than in predecessors. The physics in this one are outrageously unbelievable as always, but the stunts and set pieces are impressive. I was hesitant about Shaw's redemption arc at first, but it proved to be quite satisfying and effective. While it doesn't break any new ground, it heads in the direction of a few new ideas, giving it enough life to keep me entertained.

review: It's Raining Cars, Hallelujah! I'm not sure the cast know what's going on in this too fast, frequently furious caper, despite the remarkable amount of exposition in the dialogue of the 11th highest grossing film of all time. The upside-down faces of Vin Diesel, The Rock and Statham - all beard, no hair - merge into one as we are confronted with kidnappings, jailbreaks, Helen Mirren, Charlize Theron and nuclear footballs for some reason. Again, though, the cars are great (good to see a British Racing Green F Type for Statham), things go bang and driving really really fast as a gang can indeed save the world. You feel the writers may have just gone a little easier on the Nitrous Oxide.

review: While the movie certainly delivers on all of the usual high octane action that we have been accustomed to, it is also much more preachy and self-righteous then the other installments. While there are a lot of cars and crashes in the movie, there are so many that the overload turns what used to be a fun novelty into just so much white noise. While there are a lot of car races and chases, there are so many that it is like watching a video of someone playing a racing video game. If there is one word to describe this movie, it is overcompensation.

review: I know this movie doesn't get the same level of love as some of the more popular MCU films. It works for me...and maybe that's because I am a fan of Shane Black movies (okay...SOME Shane Black movies - Kiss Kiss Bang Bang and The Other Guys are brilliant, The Predator not so much). Some people complain Tony is not in a suit enough and sure, but isn't that kind of the point? It's forcing him to be a hero without being able to always depend on his tech, and there are still more suits in this movie than the others. One minor critique - in the voice over he definitely sounds more like Harry from KKBB than Tony.

A weak film with a forgettable and underused villain, as well as a twist that ruins the whole movie. The ending of "Iron Man 3" is also very confusing and doesn't make sense, especially when compared to other installments later on. The action is done well, however, and the humor is still done well. The stakes are higher, and the film feels more intense than the previous two, however, the ruined potential for the villain brings this movie down significantly.

Iron Man 3 was such a joy to watch as there were so many great moments throughout the film. The script is solid and doesn't shy away from any aspects, which leads to a great viewing experience. The main villain of the movie is rooted, and his motives are clear. Is he the best villain? No, but he gets the job done. The character arcs in this film are so much better here than in the second installment. Tony grew as a person and was able to become a better person overall. If I had to nitpick the script, I think I would have toned down the political tones a bit. It began to be a lot at times which I think was unnecessary. Another thing was that it felt a bit predictable at times. Using the shady businessman for the third time in a row does get a bit repetitive. Shane Black does a stellar job directing this installment and is on par with Favreau's work on the first film. There were plenty of scenes that felt inventive and unique, making the film have very few dull moments. Even with the more serious scenes, it still had the emotion it needed to be entertaining. To accompany Black's directing is some solid cinematography from John Toll. There are a lot of shots that look very nice and have some significant elements to them. Sadly, those two aspects get brought down by the harsh editing in the film. The action sequences have too many cuts leaving the scenes to feel rushed and messy. There are even a few scenes where some cuts don't match up with the shot before. The score does make up for this as it keeps the energy up in some of the scenes. Composer Brian Tyler created this bombastic score that impacted the film profoundly. The production and set design are also very attractively done. Many visually appealing locations complimented Shane Black's vision quite nicely. The cast also does a fabulous job here with stand-outs all around. Like always, Robert Downey Jr. shines on screen. This performance is the most human he has felt in any of the three Iron Man movies as he and Black translated what was on the script to the screen very nicely. Gwyneth Paltrow continues to do great in the role of Pepper Potts. Although, her performance in Iron Man 2 is still the best out of the three movies. Ben Kingsley is outstanding here and created a lot of entertaining moments in the film. I can see why some people do not like his performance, but I thought he was a lot of fun. Guy Pearce is also a solid addition to the cast. His acting seems bland at times, and it does not help that his character is somewhat the same as the other two films in the franchise. Supporting cast members like Ty Simpkins, Rebecca Hall, and Don Cheadle are fantastic in the movie. Overall, Iron Man 3 is an action-packed blockbuster that is so enjoyable to watch. The film does have a few blemishes in the script and editing department. Yet, the entertainment factor helps hide it at times. An exceptional cast, an outstanding score, and marvelous directing make Iron Man 3 a stand-out film in Marvel's cinema catalog. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

I go to see a super hero movie to see a hero being super, not spending virtually the entire film dealing with PTSD. The villain is generic and forgettable, and the twist is rather insulting, especially to hardcore fans. The suit that makes Iron Man who he is comes off nigh-indestructible in every other Marvel film, now the thing just flies to pieces if he gets hit just a little too hard? And he spends less than a quarter of the movie in it. Wow, how inspiring. I get that they were trying to go for 'Iron Man is the MAN, not the armour', but it just falls apart. Just like his suit.

Iron Man 3 is an average popcorn superhero film saved by Downey Jr. in the lead role. His smarmy yet lovable Iron Man is always a sight to behold. The action alternates between a decent showcase of big-budget CGI and illogical messiness. Paltrow and Downey work well together and Don Cheadle and Paul Bettany (voice) seem to have fun. Simpkins is a rare likable child star, but the positives end there for the supporting cast. Guy Pearce brings all of the campiness and not much else for a villain. Ben Kingsley is very welcome in another villainous role but does little to justify his inclusion apart from a bit of hit and miss comic relief. The comic relief in general does not completely miss, but could be stronger and telegraphs much of its humour in advance. Rebecca Hall did alright, though it's another case of her not quite bedding into admittedly daft proceedings as with Transcendence. Iron Man 3 is above all light-hearted fun, and this covers its faults without coming close to setting the world alight.

Honestly it's difficult to choose which is the most deranged film I've seen this week, Being John Malkovich or Minions. Minions does feature a 'hypno-hat' which enables the wearer to hypnotise whoever is in front of them and take control of what they're doing. So there is a slight link between the two films there. I've only seen the first two Despicable Me films (2010/2013) and they're pretty decent; nothing groundbreaking but a nice idea played out well. Minions is arguably the most inevitable spin off movie in film history, and unsurprisingly there's a sequel due next year. The sensible route seemed to be using the film to tell a minion origin story, and the opening sequence that explains the minions route through the earth's timeline is good fun, telling us how they've always wanted to serve some terrible evil master. We know where the film will probably end, and sure enough, it does, but it's produced well enough to hold the attention span of children and adults alike, even pre-schoolers will preoccupied for ninety minutes (mine certainly was). It's also absolutely bonkers, and I think to make this work the producers had to double down on the madness (or double up if you will) which is exactly what they have done. A lot of it is set in London, and there's plenty of shots of people drinking tea, as well as an extended cameo from an animated Queen Elizabeth II. But I understand that this description might not sound anywhere near as insane as a Charlie Kauffman film.

I had watched Despicable Me just to understand the memes and to get within the lines of the pop culture. I never understood the deal with the Facebook memes which have pictures of Minions in them and have quotes written next to them. So I used to think Minions always speak out funny one liners for the audience to have a quick laugh at. After watching Despicable Me I realised this was nothing but cheap publicity, but then I decided to watch the whole franchise anyway, and so here we are. After having watched the original trilogy, this one feels a step back, but that doesn't mean it isn't entertaining enough. Minions is a spin-off to the Despicable Me franchise (the name of the franchise is Despicable Me or Minions, I will never know). This tells the story of how the Minions found Gru and became his, well, minions. In the beginning the Minions were only wild animals who used to serve whoever was evil. They move on from one master to another, until they have none left. And that's when three Minions set out on an adventure - Bob, Kevin and Stuart (isn't it funny that they have English names even though they were born before humans existed?). The franchise has a really good animation style. It looks cute enough to be memorable, especially seeing the Minions take part in activities in the things they see for the first time. Even the action scenes of these movies are incredible. Scarlet Overkill being shown as a total badass and then getting her comeuppance made this movie so much fun to watch. Queen Elizabeth's mockery was also very funny, especially the part where one of the Minions tries to pull the sword out of the stone. The ending with Gru was also very unexpected and gave the movie a happy (?) ending. What this movie lacks in, however, is the storytelling. This is not a good movie, but rather a good "enough" movie. There's nothing in this which you haven't seen before. The plot is mostly predictable, many parts are very annoying to watch, especially Scarlet being a generic female villain who always wins with martial arts. Other than Queen Elizabeth and Herb there weren't any memorable characters. Herb was memorable and still I forgot his name. Minions is one of those movies I can imagine kids going crazy over, since the movie is targeted only for them. If you're an adult you will find this movie very childish. It's not like the Despicable Me trilogy which is fun for the whole family. It has just selected all the things which made the franchise marketable and went all out in showing them here, namely, Minions.

review: While fans like to see heroes fight each other so they can brag about their favorite hero being better than someone else's favorite hero, I'm no fan of heroes fighting each other‚Äîespecially serious fights. There are non-meaningful fights, like Bucky vs Black Panther, or even the airport scene in this film. But the final fight here between Cap & Iron Man is a meaningful fight‚Äîand simply sad, especially as Baron Zemo watches from a distance with pleasure. I'd much rather see villains fight against each other (Doctor Doom vs Magneto vs Ultron vs Loki vs Thanos vs Carnage, anyone?). What was cool was introducing Spider-Man and Black Panther, and going deeper into Vision & Wanda's relationship. The plot was generally fine (even if you were semi-familiar with the comics version of the plot) but the circumstances causing the final fight seemed contrived. I'm probably in the minority but this was a mostly downer movie. The only uplifting moment was discovering the other super-soldiers were dead.

review: A nice change of pace in the MCU, "Captain America: Civil War" brings along some new touching elements and some mature themes that help elevate it above the standard Marvel movie. The action is done fine, the CGI is good, and the villain was creatively written. However, where this movie lacks is in the motivations where both the heroes and the villain to do what they do, and I think that if they had held off on the idea, it could've been more grand. However, this film is still good, and the themes it touches upon are definitely something different, but in a good way.

review: Civil War has all the MCU production qualities and action scenes you would want from a Marvel flick, but also has quiet(er) moments when the characters philosophize and argue amongst themselves. I really enjoyed this in Age of Ultron, and to SOME degree here, but the talking here seems artificial to promote the highlight of this film where each side poses before fighting the other side. The disagreement over the Sokovia Accords seemed just dumb, and both Tony and Steve seemed like they were on the flip side of where they should be. Really? Tony is going to not go save someone when a bureaucrat in Belgium tells him not to? I get character growth and guilt and all, but please. And the fight scenes, while visually appealing, were just stupid. Bat each other around no problem until someone gets hurt, then everyone is like 'OMG dramatic moment'???? Are we five and on a playground?
rt_name: Captain America: Civil War - Movie Reviews

review: Captain America: Civil War consolidated itself as my favourite MCU film alongside Black Panther. Steve Rogers and Tony Stark disagree with each other about something. Although Steve is the protagonist, Tony's point of view is also explored, developed and comprehensible. That makes the movie almost impartial, which was a super-intelligent idea because everybody could be a villain. The action sequences are spectacular and the introduction to new characters added to the development of existent and returning ones are perfect. Tom Holland (Peter Parker/Spider-Man) and Chadwick Boseman (King T'Challa/Black Panther) are two of the best characters of this universe. And the comical timing is superb, possibly the best of the whole MCU. Credits to Holland and Paul Rudd. The story is complex and incredibly written, turning this film into Marvel's bravest and most human one. Simply lovely.

Aquaman is a broodish, miserable entry in DC's catalog. It's overlong, overstuffed, filled with poor acting, silly dialogue, features two leads who share about as much chemistry as water and oil, but worst of all, it's simply no fun. Furthermore, like every major studio release these days, this is yet another film that ends with a giant Lord of the Rings-esque CGI battle that never wants to end.
Just a generic superhero movie with a lot of cheesy special effects. It passed the time.

DC Comics movies have begun to take a turn into being enjoyable, where before the only tolerable films featured Batman, here we get the origin of Aquaman, played by Jason Momoa, who is trying to prevent a conflict between the ocean world and the land dwellers. Pretty great cast with Patrick Wilson, Amber Heard, Dolph Lundgren, Willem Dafoe and Nicole Kidman. Probably ranks up there with Black Panther for most colourful movies. A little longer than it needs to be, but a decent movie for a character that no one used to care about.

This film would be what I consider the fromage of the DCEU, however it somehow works. Though the acting isn't great by any means, and the story is kind of generic, Aquaman is selling what is literally says on the tin; a bro-ish superhero, with fish-powers, must save the World from his evil brother, whose powers are similar to his. Aquaman isn't my favourite character by far in the cinematic universe, but he does stay true to his portrayal in the comics, unkempt and brooding with a few quips here and there. I liked him far more in a solo film than I did in Justice League, as it seemed too many of the team had similar attributes and he just didn't stand out. Black Manta, being one of my favourite comic book villains, was also excellently portrayed by Yahya Abdul-Manteen II. Aquaman works better than the previous films because it doesn't need a lot of exposition and time to get to the root of the story.

Loved it! Saw it in each local theater as well as 3D. Luscious visuals, incredible special effects world, great supporting cast including Oscar winners Kidman and Defoe with many stellar performances. Biggest drawback was the female lead did not have the chops to keep up with Momoa nor the chemistry to hold the position of female lead and love interest! She was barely tolerable and that God-awful red wig... At least director Wan did not have her use a hideous British accent like in the Snyder cut of Justice League. Her poor acting and general vibe left a bad taste in otherwise great movies. But I digress, this is an Aquaman review. Aquaman is an over the top character that is bigger than life. Momoa takes a character that was made fun of for many years and makes him cool. He makes this superhero someone you want to hang out with, without needing to use his powers. Wan did a nice job showing Curry's early life and showed how he became the person we are following now. Long live Aquaman! Please give him a love interest worthy of the King of Atlantis!

Aquaman is one of my favorite films from James Wan and shows that the director is capable of handling multiple genres. Aquaman may not be the best movie we've seen in the DCEU, but it's by far the most fun and entertaining and has the most rewatch value. The visuals are phenomenal, the fight sequences are fantastic and the premise is pretty good too. The acting supplements all this really well; all the big actors do great jobs with their roles and Jason Momoa is a surprisingly good casting choice for Arthur Curry. This movie is a solid origin story for Aquaman that I only wish we'd had before the Justice League disaster so we could've had context for character upon seeing him in a big group setting, although the movie does play off of Curry's appearance in Justice League nicely. Patrick Wilson is a very welcome face in this movie for me and fans of the Insidious and Conjuring franchises and marks his 5th collaboration (I believe) with Wan. Wilson shows how good of an actor he is in this movie. I appreciate how this movie made good use of all it's big-name and A-list actors; it didn't squander any of them and gave an actor we haven't seen too much of before the film the spotlight a few times. I do wanna reiterate a point I made earlier now about the movie being fun. Aquaman struck a very different tone and mood than pretty much every other film in the DCEU; the other movies have been very serious or comedic, but haven't been so in ways that make them truly entertaining. Aquaman has a very different vibe from the rest of the DCEU, and it's a breath of fresh air. Aquaman wants to be a fun movie and succeeds in doing so, and it's a movie I could watch 5 or more times and still be entertained by, a luxury I don't personally have with any other film in the DCEU. All that said, Aquaman isn't a perfect movie, and it's biggest fault for me is the dialogue. It's really cheesy, cringey and corny at times and without the great performances from the actors some scenes would be really awkward, stupid and unwatchable. Some the actors, especially Patrick Wilson, have to be on their A-game to keep a straight face while they say their lines due to how ridiculous the dialogue is at times. Honestly, if the dialogue had been better, this movie probably would've been a perfect 10 for me since everything else about the movie works really well; the dialogue is something I hope they work on and refine in the sequel, which according to Wan started filming recently. Overall, Aquaman may not be perfect or the best movie in the DCEU but it's a fun, entertaining and action-packed movie and has some of the best rewatch value of the whole DCEU.
Not on par with the quality of entertainment that Marvel movies are at. I think it could have been a lot better if they had edited it down to 90 or 100 minutes.

review: Probably my favorite movie of all time, The Return of the King is an outstanding climax to one of, if not, the greatest trilogy of all time. I still binge watch the trilogy every few months and was fortunate to have the Lord of the Rings around when I was growing up. While many don't believe the final chapter is the best of the three, I have never felt as personally attached to a cast and movie than I was/am with Return of the King. The infamous Minas Tirith battle scene, the heroics at the Black Gate, Arogorn's speech, the brotherhood between Legolas and Gimli, the corruption of Frodo by the Ring... it's just cinematic perfection and there may never be a movie series to rival LOTR, particularly not in the fantasy genre. Whether you've read the books or not, anyone who enjoys fantasy should watch this trilogy at least once in their lifetime.

review: Lord of the Rings ‚Äì The return of the King Review One word, Perfection. From the details of each scene of this movie, from lighting to the green screen production making it realistic, from acting, this was one of the best series of movies and yet one of the best endings to a movie sequel. The music choices which each scene added so much to the way those parts felt. Everything flowed so naturally and so perfectly. Almost as if it was just a piece of cake to create this movie which was obviously not true. The acting is phenomenal. The director literally directed this movie to a legit PERFECTION. Knowing how to create the emotion for the actors on the right moments. The screen editors did a perfect flow to each scene. From romance, to horror, to action, every cut of this film was perfectly made to make you have this feeling to it. The wardrobe was correctly done to fit every characters character. Nothing was overdone or underdone. This is by far one of my favorite movie sequels. A movie where it would make you want to watch over and over again.

review: This movie is obviously fantastic regardless, but I am quite surprised it's the highest rated of the trilogy. It adapts by far the worst source material of the three and really pays the price for it with one of the worst cases of deus ex machina in movie history (the ghosts); the director thankfully chose to excise the worst chapter of writing Tolkien ever produced, that being the Hobbits returning to the Shire to find that Saruman has taken it over, but a lot of the buildup to Frodo's eventual character-ruining refusal to destroy the ring was internal and wasn't conveyed in the movie. We are instead left with a protagonist (who had already become worthless halfway through the second movie) making a heel turn long after all respect for him had been lost. I think a few of the Oscar wins this received was based on accrued appreciation for the trilogy as a whole and a lack of significant competition in '03. There was still plenty to enjoy here, especially the epilogue, and making this movie at all was a tremendous achievement by the filmmakers.

It provides the viewers with a satisfying and bitter sweet ending. Combine all these elements together, and you've an extremely rewatchable film. The fact that it only gets 86% on the audience score is criminal.

review: The writing is inferior to the book by orders of magnitude. Too much is left out and the alterations made by the screenwriters are all detrimental to the story. review: This is my third and final review of the trilogy. In the first movie's review I called it an RPG game and mentioned on how the world building was done adn how great the visuals were. In the second review I said it was like watching a book come to life and talked about the character development and philosophy/message the movie gave. In this third review I have called it an art and here I will talk about the story and why it will be remembered not just as a masterpiece, but also as a legacy. Keep in mind that all the reviews have been written separately but all of them imply to all three movies. The Lord of the Rings is one long story that has been divided equally among three movies. Because of this there is virtually no major difference between the them, and all the three movies have received almost the same ratings. Normally in trilogies the stories do not directly pick up from where the last one left but rather these are three different stories, because of which it is possible to have two great movies and one movie which does not live up to them (Sam Raimi's Spider-Man, Christopher Nolan's Batman, the original Star Wars trilogy, Godfather etc), or there is one great movie while the other two don't live up to that (Zack Snyder's Superman, Star Wars prequel and sequel trilogies, Jurassic Park etc). Here the risk was much bigger. Since there is just one story, either the entire trilogy would have been good or the entire trilogy would have been bad. This is why the movies were so long. The story is set in a fantasy world and not everyone has read the original books by JRR Tolkien. So Peter Jackson had to elaborate every minor detail. There should have been no questions left. The audience should've had a clear idea of what they were watching. Normally such things are only possible in TV shows which are book adaptations like Game of Thrones or The Man in the High Castle since they have enough time in their hands to explain everything. This, however, was a movie series. This is the reason why the runtime is so long. The total runtime of the trilogy is 10+ hours, and 12+ hours if you watch the extended cut. Another major problem that could have plagued this movie, if it wasn't addressed, was the number of characters and the fact that all of them were in different places doing different things. There were some minor characters right in the beginning of the story and some in the middle. All of them had to be humanised, something which is possible only if we get to know more about them. Because of this the story is moved forward such that we are made to care about all of the people. While we ask what happened to Gimli and Legolas in the battle, we are also worried that Frodo has been tricked by Gollum and is about to be eaten by a giant spider. The direction does not shift in the bias of any of the characters, otherwise the ones the audience cares about would have been left behind. People often make fun of the half-hour long epilogue shown in the end of The Return of the King, but imagine if it was not there. So many characters would have received vague endings. This was meant to assure that all the good characters got good endings and the bad guys got bad endings. I'd also take a moment to talk about Gimli and Legolas' relation. In the beginning they both hated each other but later on they grow to become friends. This is another great message that the movie sends us. In my previous review of philosophy I didn't mention it because it was seen in this movie. It talks about how we hate some people based on their appearance, their beliefs, their way of life. But we end up becoming friends with those same people once we actually interact with them. People were never meant to hate each other. This is something we are taught to do. This is also seen when Aragorn unleases the Army of the Dead. They never wanted to work with the living because of their hatred, but when one of them came forward and made the request, they gave in. It is these small moments that show the humanity in all the characters. And finally, what makes it a legacy? Today everyone knows about The Lord of the Rings. Gandalf is the first thing someone imagines when they hear the word "wizard", in spite of there being a more popular book adaptation movie franchise which is literally about wizards. So many RPG games have their stories set in the manner of "some characters with different abilities go out on a dangerous yet exotic adventure". Elijah Wood has become world famous for his role as Frodo Baggins. Gollum, in spite of being the same annoying character found in all fantasy movies, is more popular than Jar Jar or Dobby. All of this is possible because of the way the story unfolds. Everyone who was evil was simply so because of the circumstances, and those who were good were because of how much the story emphasised on their actions. This coupled with great direction and a good world building made it so popular. The Lord of the Rings is one of the era defining movies of our times. It looks like a painting brought to life, one that we used to look at in fairy tales and nursery rhymes. It is the first thing that comes to someone's mind when they think of a fantasy adventure set in the medieval era. The patience of the creators and the fans is what made this trilogy so powerful. I really hope we get to see more such adaptations of books that we haven't heard about. This one has made a benchmark that will be hard to reach in the near future unless a miracle happens.
mojo_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
rt_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King - Movie Reviews

review: Lord of the Rings: Return of the King is the best ending imaginable to this incredible trilogy. The characters continue to shine, most notably Frodo, Sam, Merry, Pippin, Gandalf and Aragorn in this movie. With the Battle of Helm's Deep won and Saruman dead, the stage is set for the final battle in this epic saga. Upon finding that Sauron plans to strike the city of Minas Tirith, the heart of Gondor, Gandalf and Pippin ride to the city only to find Denethor, a madman in control of the city who is totally unfit to be the Steward. Eventually, the forces of Gondor, Rohan, Eriador and Mordor all coincide at Minas Tirith for the largest and in my opinion, best battle not only in this saga, but in all of cinematic history. Every scene in this movie holds weight to it, it is my favourite in the trilogy and seeing Aragorn finally take his place becoming King of the Reunited Kingdom always brings a tear to my black heart. This movie, like every other in the trilogy is flawless and I will rewatch these movies until the day I die.
mojo_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King

review: Surprisingly good. I was really disappointed when I saw Homecoming. It just didn't feel like a Spiderman movie and was a bit on the lackluster side. I had certain expectations and I suppose Homecoming helped me know what to expect from its sequel. With that in mind I really had a good time with this film. Its a fun small neighborhood film with a really good villain. They nailed Mysterio in the film. I loved how they portrayed his character and I loved his costume. I was surprised just how close they got to the comics with it. I am glad the days of trying to subdue or gritt-ify superhero costumes are somewhat over (still holding out for Wolverine to get his comic book costume). Ideas of certain superheroes are kind of goofy and so are the costumes. It's part of the fun. Certainly adapt so it doesn't look super goofy but don't destroy either. Overall I would recommend giving it a watch. Holland still isn't my ideal Spiderman, nor is his world, but I enjoy it for what it is. And I am so glad they got rid of Spiderman's AI voice. Helps him feel less like Iron Man lite and more like Spiderman.

review: The potential of this film was destroyed, the villain was literally just another Iron Man villain, and the CGI was overdone to the point of sickness. "Spiderman: Far From Home" was just a disappointment when compared to the other Spiderman films throughout the years, and is, in my opinion, one of the lower ones. The humor is still good enough, the action is done well, and Holland continues to play his role marvelously. However, despite the positive things I have to say about this film, there was still enough yuck to bog this down, and especially when compared to "Spiderman: Homecoming," this film doesn't even compare.

review: I have a lot to say. I am a huge Spider Fan a Huge MCU fan. The number of people that know Peter Secret identity is Outrageously high so it doesn't feel like watching a spider man story. The Whole Teenage movie Recipe Clich√©. The Character Dialogue try to copy the one from the early marvel Iron man movie.. and fail because they have nothing to say to each other. The Teacher is the best part of the movie. The pitch meeting for this movie should have been very differently .. You think Peter can go back to a normal life after the event of Infinity War.. I know marvel wants to Elongate the story but darn it felt wrong. You know from the beginning who Misterio is.. So nothing is a surprise .. Kinda dum that Sony want to make a Misterio movie since sooo long. He's really not an interesting character. At least he was well played. Again to many love scene and goofy scene. We will we ever have a spider man movie without love scene that never ends ..i rather watch a 45 minute movie that is good than 2h movie that just pointless boring story with multiple plot hole just to insert character that you really don't care about. Fake Fury team look like the Nebucad Nezar team from Matrix and they are super Cringe .. Movie is dull make no sense . Do you really think the Skrull can be this Dum. Its like if Peter did not learn anything from all his adventure in the past few years. He has 0 sense of responsibility . Homecoming was the best Spiderman movie.. why did it turn this way Why did Peter gave Edith to Misterio ,,, And the END with J Jonas Alex Jones Jameson is simply ridiculous it made me lost all interest in the continuity because we all know what comes next.. Just like in the Infinity Saga (2012-13) in the comics. that will keep going on with dr strange / Happy Plus Aunt may = Cringe I seem to be alone to think that this was a bad representation of who Peter Parker is. But i own 9000+ comic book and I'm not living in USA so what do i know This is my least favorite MCU movie and i am serious. I gave one star for acting and cast because it was a good cast . and another star for the score BGM and FX. The three missing star are Story/Plot hole , General Entertainment, Personal overall Feeling about the movie.

review: Compared to this movie, Spider-Man: Homecoming is on another level. Far From Home is in general a decent film, but the two most important parts are bad-written: the protagonist and the villain. Tom Holland's Peter Parker involuted, becoming an idiot teenager who wants to run away from his responsibilities to conquer the girl he likes. Where is the guy who wants to prove himself? The guy who wants to be more than the neighbourhood friend? And Mysterio's plan and motivations don't make any sense. Luckily, he's imposing and Jake Gyllenhall is a stunning actor. The humour is more basic and less intelligent, but almost as efficient as Homecoming. And what elevates the level of this film is the third act, which is for sure one of the best acts in the whole MCU. The visual effects are amazing (by the way, the movie plays with them smartly) and the final fight is MCU's best individual fight (only one hero against the villain). Tom Holland and Zendaya's romance may seem forced, but it makes sense, they have chemistry and fortunately, the script kept MJ's cynical personality. No other character but Peter has been distorted. Oh, and I loved the mid-credits scene, it's possibly Marvel's best cliffhanger.

review: One of the best Transformers movie, if not the best, and maybe even one of the best movies of all time! I was 8 years old when I first saw this in 2011, and it brought back a lot of memories. I am a huge Transformers fan and I recall a lot of details from this film. I remember the toys and the memories I had with others. I still enjoy the other films, but this is one that stands out the most and I will never forget it. It astounds me much more that it is one of the highest-grossing films of all time, with making almost 1.2 billion dollars in the box office despite a "low" budget of 195 million dollars. I had no idea what to expect after Revenge of the Fallen, but this caught me completely off guard. Everything in Dark of the Moon is out of this world, the characters, the musical score, the story, the mystery, the action, the intensity, everything compelled me. You need to see this movie and when you do you'll find out something that you definitely never saw coming, I know I never did.

review: You know many praise this bond outing but I really could not get into it. Yes it had good action, and was exciting at times... But it was somewhat bland. But who am I kidding sky fall is another bond master piece... to some people....

What really struck me on this viewing is how much this made me think of The Dark Knight. There were just a lot of overlap in themes and a similarly ahead of the game villain...and not to say this movie is at all duplicative of The Dark Knight just that they're both great. And a fitting farewell to Judi Dench. But...the CGI is really not great on this. At first I thought it was due to streaming in my previous watch but its still there on the Blu-Ray. Update...I'm torn on ranking this one. I know some (such as The Big Picture crew) look to this as the best Bond film, other (James Bonding) seemed to have more critiques. I think it's good but I ultimately prefer Casino Royale....I think I'm going to give Connery some breathing room here and bump this down to under From Russia With Love.

Bond villain Raoul Silva's plan is laughable, Bond's treatment of former sex slave S√©v√©rine is unforgivable, and the film simply forgets to explain the cliffhanger set in the pre-credit scene. Suspension of disbelief has limits.

"Skyfall" sees Daniel Craig reprise his role as Bond for an extremely enjoyable film that has arguably the best villain in the Craig-Bond universe. The title sequence is also the best, with an extremely memorable opening that sets the tone for the whole film. The last act feels too goofy, though it still remains enjoyable to watch.
Skyfall is the darkest Bond we've seen, with it almost looking like a thriller at times. Wonderful cinematography, narrative and Craig at his intense best. This is a Bond for old and new fans.

"Believable" isn't the first word that comes to mind when someone mentions James Bond. But c'mon. With the world's crime fighting manpower and technology at your disposal, why run off to Scotland by yourselves in a car just to reenact Home Alone? Someone was under a deadline and started studying too late. And why is Silva homosexual for about 45-seconds? Walter Sobchak said it best, "Has the whole world gone crazy? Am I the only one who gives a s--t about the rules?"

Ah yes The Dark Knight one that turns into Home Alone. It's got a sprinkle of mission impossible too, but it's more known for being The Dark Knight that turns into Home Alone. All the The Dark Knight stuff are great. I am a huge Batman fan and absolutely hate Joker especially his oversaturation in the DC universe, but in this he actually works as the main villain. The score, directing, and cinematography are all fantastic. Deakins did unnecessarily use yellow more than need, but fantastic otherwise. It's when the film turns into Home Alone that I have trouble suspending my disbelief. Silva exposed all double-0 agents, but 007 because he was presumed dead, But MI6 have only 9 field agents? Where are the single-0s? If there were ever a time bond would NEED to work with someone else it would at the Skyfall property. Some snipers in the off distance trees, some in the house, another in the DB5 (that unfortunately was destroyed... again. I hate when movies think it's ok to destroy timeless cars). Some other times in other Bond movies I think "maybe this would have been better with another double-0 by his side, perhaps not". In this one I'm thinking "bring in the cavalry". Yes, I get it, they can't trust anyone especially how M's bodyguard of 15 years tried to kill her in Quantum of Solace, but then why trust Bond? He was presumed dead for how long, not know how much he's changed or feels betrayed still about her practically shooting him and doesn't know how much Silva's word affected him AND even acknowledges how little she knows if Bond is being influenced by Silva by abruptly feeling the need to stop and explain her actions involving Silva. I am also not really a fan of the film constantly asking the audience if the franchise is relevant, particularly M's scenes in the courts. Every single EON productions James Bond film, all 25 of them, have made money, even with new actors in the protagonist role where customers are not used to the new shoes yet, those sometimes make even more than the last one of the previous actor. Skyfall itself grossed over a billion dollars in 2012. So to answer the redundant question, yes, it's relevant. There also are some weird plot holes involving Silva. How exactly did he know the train was going to come through the wall when it did or how did he plan to kill M years in advance when the hearing was only set up 3 days beforehand. However, this and Casino Royale (2006) are the only Bond films where James gets character development, so that is a plus. I'm torn. Not a fan of those to particular writing things, the Home Alone part being a bigger deal for me really, but man, even though I spent like a sentence or two on the positives, they do really boost up the overall quality. The cold open, the fight against the sniper in the skyscraper, and the subway (tube) foot chase are some of the best action set pieces in Hollywood history. The tense gripping atmosphere of the mystery behind who is is hacking in MI6 before the villain is revealed is absolutely expert filmmaking. I do really think the positives outweigh the negatives here.

Skyfall, directed by Sam Mendes is a masterpiece. Being Daniel Craig's third entry into the series, Skyfall honestly blew my mind. Everything about this movie is brilliant, the action, the performances and the ending is gut wrenching and powerful. Silva is my favourite Bond villain of all time and he is such a well written character and well acted by Javier Bardem, he is just so memorable and he steals every scene he is in, yes, even the ones with Judy Dench. Overall, Skyfall is one of the best entries in the Bond series and nothing can ruin it for me.

Daniel Craig's best performance yet as our most meaningfull James Bond to ever grace the silver screen.

An extraordinary entry in the Bond franchise. It has a darker and more serious tone than other films. Daniel Craig is wonderful again as Bond. Javier Bardem plays an excellent and magnetic villain. The cinematography here felt much more memorable here than in other Bond films; just incredible. Adele's 'Skyfall' song is contender for best Bond song ever (deservedly winning the Oscar for Best Original Song). For me, Casino Royale is just slightly above Skyfall, but its a damn good movie.

Skyfall is an incredible movie with many astonishing aspects that make this film feel like a genuine spy thriller. Sam Mendes does a magnificent job directing this movie, as he creates this obscure yet exciting tone throughout the whole screen duration. The solid script helps support Mendes' vision with a prominent central story. Skyfall nailed down the story perfectly, as this is the first Daniel Craig Bond movie to feel like the world of a spy. Both Casino Royale and Quantum of Solace struggled to capture the elements of a James Bond. However, the screenwriters perfected it here in this movie. Having the central storyline being an attack on MI6 while mixing in some of the personal elements of the characters is excellent for this franchise. Where the script falls flat was the misuse of the Bond girl. The poor treatment of S√©v√©rine is very noticeable throughout the film and makes Skyfall suffer significantly. It is not necessarily wrong to not have a Bond girl, but to have one and completely butcher her character arc is wrong. Skyfall is visually stunning, with the exquisite cinematography stealing the spotlight at times. Roger Deakins does an extraordinary job here as the director of photography. Many shots were remarkable and captured the worldbuilding exquisitely. The editing is also the most potent of the first three installments. There are a few scenes with slightly choppy editing, but it is not as detrimental as the first two films. The score is also very compelling as it elevates a lot of the scenes. Thomas Newman knows how and when to make the music match sonically with what is on screen. The cast of Skyfall is strong, with a lot of great performances all around. Daniel Craig is smooth and has a lot of fun quips that make this movie special. While he may be exceptional in the role, his performance in Casino Royale edges his performance here just by a bit. Javier Bardem is phenomenal in this film and had the best performance out of everyone. The emotion Bardem put into creating Silva was comprehensive, and Bardem never overacts in any of his scenes. Naomie Harris and Ben Whishaw are both prominent in their respective roles. They each stand out in all the sequences their characters are present in. Lastly, there is Judi Dench, who knocks it out of the park. It is Dench's most excellent performance in all the Bond films, as we really get to spend time with the character and not just see her tell people to eliminate the enemies. Dench still keeps that aspect alive in her performance, as it is an influential aspect of M's character arc. However, it never becomes too over-the-top. Skyfall is the complete embodiment of James Bond as the film holds every aspect a spy thriller needs to be a great film. The story is easy to follow yet has this slight complexity to it that still makes it shocking. The cast is perfect, with no bad actors bringing down the film. What does bring down the film is a messy subplot that looms its gloomy shadow over the film. If it were not for that terrible treatment of S√©v√©rine, the film would have been perfect. I am a bit surprised by the current audience score.

This one if probably my favourite out of all of Craigs Bind films. Not only does it have probably the best bond themes to date, but the story, action and feel of bond is just perfect in this. I really like how suspenseful and thrilling it went. Never was boring, kept me entertained all the way through. Definitely worth a watch.

The Dark Knight of the Craig Bond films. Sam Mendes and Roger Deakins offer by far the best cinematography for a Bond film. You like that shot of the burning city in 1917? They got you covered with Bond's family estate. You like that shot in Shang-Chi of them fighting against the backdrop of neon advertisement billboard? They got you covered. Like the meditative wide shots of the landscapes in 2049? Oh do they have you covered in Macau. Like Adele? Covered. This film challenges Bond in a way no other film has. He's weary, battered, and no longer as fit for superspy espionage as he was in his earlier years. But the one woman who has been a constant in his hectic life, his boss and surrogate mother figure, and the person who gave the "take-the-shot" order than made Bond end up in the drink, Judi Dench's M is at risk. The best bond villain to date, Javier Bardem's Anderson Silva, is not trying to take over the world. He's got a personal vendetta against the one person Bond has any real attachment to. What's more, he's a dark mirror to Bond. A former 00 and M's previous favorite, Silva was the Bond before Bond who also suffered from "mother's" decision to prioritize the mission over the agent. He's not only a formidable foe for Bond, but he's an effective foil. This is also the best fusion of the modern, gritty, grounded Bond and the gadget-laden, seductive, classy elements of early Bond. It pays homage to hallmarks of the olden days (Moneypenny, Q, etc.) yet breaks new ground (we visit Bond's home, we change M's, etc.) This is truly prestige bond. Doesn't get better.

review_date: 4.0/5.0 Excellent. Almost a Masterpiece. Casino Royale is a little more engaging.
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

Skyfall is the best movie in the Daniel Craig franchise and a great movie over all masterfully directed by Sam Mendes of American Beauty. Skyfall brings the stakes higher as everything seems to be collapsing hence the title. In here Daniel Craig continues to shine as James Bond and here is directly paired with Judy Dench as M as M16 is attacked by a powerful villain. The chemistry between the two is wonderful almost as a mother and son relationship and Craig faces his most challenging antagonist until this point Silva played by academy award winner and spanish actor Javier Bardem. Bardem kills this performance and brings a similar aurora to that he brought to No Country for Old Men. Bardem is psychotic, mild mannered, and out for revenge in one of his most iconic roles. Lots of great action here as always but is the drama between the characters and the great relationship between M and Bond that makes this movie so incredible to watch with a climax that keeps on the edge. With Adele singing in the intro, great direction by Mendez, a great script, and an incredible performance by Javier this movie is almost a masterpiece.

Transformers age of Extinction is a 3 hour extravaganza of seizure inducing special effects, cringeworthy humour that thinks it's hilarious when it's really not and characters who grate on your nerves because they cannot stop screaming, when you think the movie is about to end it will just go on for another 45 minutes, the pacing is atrocious, this movie kept going and going and going and going and going and by the time I'm the movie ended, your legs have already fallen asleep, Transformers 4 could be a fun guilty pleasure movie if it didn't go on for so long

review: Looking at the poster and trailer of this movie I was thinking this might be something really good. I had recently watched the first three movies of this franchise and I really liked the whole concept of Transformers; just seeing them do something on the big screen is enough to get my attention. So when I heard that this is the worst movie of the franchise, the robot dinosaur poster refused to let me believe that. How can a movie with such a good CGI possibly be bad? And when I watched it... I now apologise to all those people I didn't trust. I'm really sorry. The problem with this movie is that it has humans. I know, Transformers are all about Autobots and humans interacting and coming together to beat Decepticons, but the humans in this movie are terrible. I forgave Dark of the Moon since it was Sam Witwicky, the same guy we had previously seen in two prequels. But this time, it's the new guy. I don't even remember his name, so let's just call him Mark Wahlberg. Mark is such a two dimensional character. He loves mechanical engineering and hates anyone approaching his daughter. Yes, that's his entire personality. So when Optimus Prime ends up coming to his lab, they bond together. The premise of this movie is all wrong. The Autobots are now considered criminal in this world because of the destruction that happened in the previous movie. Like, what? Dude, even the army was doing destruction in the previous movie if that's supposed to be a real reason. Also everyone saw the Autobots fight the Decepticons in the epic climax moment. And it's not like there's some communication gap between the Autobots and the humans, since Optimus Prime literally lived with the military. So if there's any problem at all, they can just talk about it. So anyway Optimus helps Mark, his daughter and her boyfriend escape from there, and they team up with Hound and some other Transformers (I don't even remember the names at this point, because they don't give a reason to do so). Together they go to The Lost World where Optimus fights the robot T-Rex for which I watched this movie in the first place. First of all, the T-Rex is like, five times bigger than Optimus Prime. For comparison, just try fighting an elephant with your bare hands (except that elephants are herbivores and won't attack you unprovoked). And after the beating that T-Rex becomes friends with Optimus because it's a Michael Bay movie. So then there's the epic showdown battle between Mark and some bad guys. I was doing my college project on my laptop and this movie was running on my phone's Prime Video, so I used to only look at the movie whenever something interesting would be happening, otherwise I'd just keep doing my work. I don't think I looked at the screen more than 3-4 times throughout the work. This is the reason why I can guarantee you that it's a boring movie. I don't remember most of it. Transformers: Age of Extinction is the movie that taught me that Transformers could be bad too. Earlier I used to see Screen Rant articles which said that after a time the movies went repetitive with the CGI fighting and explosions, so I didn't understand what's bad about it since that's literally what I watch them for. But it turns out the reason why I hate it is the other way round. The big, cool robots have now turned into parodies of themselves and the humans are no longer even close to being interesting. I'd say if you haven't begun watching this franchise, just watch the first three and then jump straight to Bumblebee. That would save a lot of time and inner peace.
rt_name: Transformers: Age of Extinction - Movie Reviews

review: With plenty of deaths and dangers, this film takes on a more somber tone. But, in true Transformers fashion, it has its share of hilarious moments. It has great action sequences, heartwarming and truly epic moments, as well as some fresh new faces. No matter how much I shall miss the old, like much in this movie, times change, just like much in this movie. I like how they started exploring the history in this film, I feel like it adds to the story. I also like the new characters, they feel realistic. There is the father and new protagonist, Cade Yeager, who is trying to support his family, his daughter who is worried about both her father and her future, as well as having some fun, and her fun carefree man, who can be just as serious. The new Transformers are fun as well, whether it be the snarky Crosshairs, the serious Drift, or the violence loving Hound. This movie is a new start, and a good one at that. It, like the others, is underappreciated. I adore this film, and I hope that others will appreciate it as much as I do, as it is a masterpiece of its own type.

review: This movie is better than ROTF but not as good as any other Transformers movie. It's still a very good and entertaining movie, but it lacks in some parts. The score once again is very amazing. It makes a good moment into a nearly perfect moment. The story is not complicated and if anything its too basic. The action like every Transformers movie is GREAT. It also is probably the most kid friendly Transformers movie out of all of them. This or TLK. The humans aside from Cade are pretty bland and just, "Eh." Lockdown is great though. He might be better than Megatron. He is very powerful and pretty cool looking. Some of the shots in this movie are insane. But another problem is how long this movie is. I feel like it could have been done in a one hour and forty five minutes movie. Like every other Transformers movie its pretty stupid. The dinobots were pretty cool. but they could have come sooner. Lockdowns ship is very cool. Crosshairs, Drift, and Hound are all ok additions to the cast. They kill off an important Transformer in the beginning which sucked. It helps show how powerful Lockdown is though. This movie is like a cake. You eat it and it tastes pretty good. You think to yourself that you would it the cake again in like half a year. You do and it tastes just as good. You eat every half a year and like it each time. But it's not a cake you wait a week after eating and then go eat it again. I say you should see this. 7.5/10 3.5/5 and 75/100

review: 2021 Nolan has spoken openly about the fact that Rises was strongly influenced by French revolutionary literature, because that's what audiences wanted from their superhero movies. Despite these unconventional influences, The Dark Knight Rises is a masterpiece‚Äîa compelling portrait of a decadent society in a time of crisis. The film was released in 2012, against the backdrop of the Great Recession and the subsequent Occupy Wall Street movement. However, Rises is not bound by its French Revolutionary influences nor its Obama-era release date. The most prescient film of the trilogy, Rises plays like a foreboding warning of things to come
