review: Good fun fantasy film for all ages. A lively live-action re-telling of Alice in Wonderful with a compelling cast.

This film is an amalgamation of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass by Lewis Carroll with a tiny bit of the 1951 Disney film thrown into the filter of Tim Burton's direction. While I was excited to see Burton's version of Wonderland, the movie changed so much of the characters from the source material that it was not a movie about Wonderland. So much so that they changed the name of Wonderland to Underland. This film looks terrific, from the costumes Alice wears to the CGI. I also enjoy the story arc of Alice and the new character of Bayard. The rest of the characters are reduced to delivering exposition or short gags. If you would like to see a totally unique version of Lewis Carroll's works then check this movie out, otherwise skip it.

This movie was visually entertaining but that was it for me. Just a lot of the same tired old hollywood tropes. The storyline didn't really make sense and so many lines that attempted to be heartfelt made me cringe. Although it attempted to be a feminist piece the narrative is so unbelievable in terms of gender norms of the period that this fantasy take feels like a mocking joke. I guess a period piece loosely based on Alice in Wonderland is another great excuse to employ an all-white cast and another skinny blond lead. Overall a shallow shiny package that failed to present anything genuinely meaningful or thought-provoking.

First off, I want to state how boring this movie is. It has serious pacing issues with it moving so slow. Some of the scenes were stretched out for too long and include unnecessary dialogue and weird visual elements. For instance, the Futterwacken scene at the end of the movie is not funny and wastes time. I appreciate the call back to the actual book, but it's just not amusing to watch. This wasted time could have easily been put to good use in the final battle scene which is so anti-climatic. It's such a shame that we went on such a long journey through Wonderland just for the final battle to be only around 10 minutes with 2-3 minutes of that being the Jabberwocky battle. The story is also very poorly written. It all just falls apart after Alice makes her way into the Red Queen's castle. The whole "Um" bit is not funny whatsoever and is stretched out way too long. I know that Alice has grown and that whole aspect does make some sense. However, the Knaves of Hearts not noticing it sooner or pointing it out sooner made no sense and felt like just a lazy way to create the heist scene. A lot of the Red Queen's story is very poorly written which is such a shame because Helena Bonham Carter does a good job in the role. Speaking of the cast, it's a mixed bag. The voice cast does a nice job, but the on-screen talent is a little off. Both Johnny Depp and Mia Wasikowska have some nice moments, but their line delivery is off most of the time. As I said before, Helena Bonham Carter does a nice job as the Red Queen. Crispin Glover and Anne Hathaway do a decent job, but their roles feel more like parodies of the characters rather than them actually embodying the roles they were placed in. The world around these characters is really bad. The visuals are so bland and dark that it doesn't even feel like Wonderland. I get why Tim Burton would have made that choice as their lives are all kind of miserable at the moment, but even the flashback scenes look dull and unimaginative. I would have loved to have seen some more color pop off the screen when Alice defeated the Jabberwocky. I think it would have made the film's final scenes in Wonderland be more at a decent level rather than just outright bad. Overall, this film is just a big mess with poor editing, a below-average story, and a cast that doesn't quite shine. Tim Burton doesn't do anything outstanding and just feels like lazy directing and storytelling. When Tim Burton said he had never felt any emotional tie-in to the book, that should've been some major red flags that this film would not be good in any shape or form. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

Not a very good film, but let's use this as a platform to talk about Mercury Poisoning, shall we?* The term "Mad as a Hatter" came from a time when Mercury was used in the hat making process and people started going mad. What are common traits of Mercury Poisoning? Depression. Anxiety. Clumsiness. Hallucinations. Who was Mercury in mythology? The God of Thieves, and a messenger to Gods. What does Mercury hold in his hand? That is the Caduceus. That is Kundalini. That is the ancient brother-sister duo battling themselves; Fuxi and Nuwa. If we are all sitting at the table of the Mad Hatter, we are bound to have consumed his poison. So, when trying on different brands of hat, do remember the attached anxiety and depression is not hallucinated, but the preoccupation of all things related to Mercury... *Please consult Jeremy Piven for further research in these matters.
I liked this a lot more than I expected too. Mainly because of Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter but the movie had a wonderful charm as a whole.

The story gathers more elements in this sequel which revamps the experience, and the nostalgia of seeing the classic characters in live-action makes for a great watching experience.

Famouse world classic story of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland being filmed again in Dark and Gothic theme named Alice in Wonderland. The plot is drastically changed from the original book, but it still have charm and uniqueness of story. Alice the protagonist of the story have grown up to a woman and forgotten Wonderland, she was expected to be someone she's not and still can't find her way. She is brought to Wonderland again by white rabbit according to the prophecy that ‚ÄòAlice' will slay Jabberwocky save but there's a question that ‚ÄòIs she the right Alice, the same one in the prophecy' and Alice also doubt that. Life of Alice is not smooth and Wonderland become a place full of danger but that's what make this movie interesting. Some characters are threaten, kidnapped, prisoned, and nearly executed but it's still in safe zone that people every age can watch together. In climax, Alice enter the war and slay Jabberwocky, fighting scene is not exciting and quite predictable for fantasy adventure movie with no fight experience woman protagonist but the war end beautifully. When back to her world, she returns as an elegant, brave and confident woman who walk in her own way. The background is mysterious but powerful and beautiful. Most characters are mystery and have their own charm, and I wish there's continue seasons.

Enjoyably mad. Tim Burton's fingerprints are all over this.

Despite how serene the lead actress is and how competent the CGI is constructed, this might be one of the most unpleasant looking movies I have ever seen. Yes, it's Tim Burton so it's meant to be at least semi-repellent visually, but Tim Burton also relies almost entirely on his visual aesthetic, which makes this unpleasant aspect of the movie the central focus. What's unfortunate is that this was originally sold to many audiences as an Adaptation of the American McGee version, which already looks like a Tim Burton version, just better, with far, far better writing, so this would've been better. Instead, we're left with the kind of poor-to-abysmal quality script that seems to accompany most Tim Burton films, not only giving us wonky and sometimes incoherent storytelling, but even manages to mold the movie with almost every current-day Cinematic Fantasy Cliche, resulting in an Army vs Army battle with Alice as some kind of makeshift Valkyrie with a magic sword. There is good to be found -- Burton's usual use of slightly over-the-top performances complements this world as it's over the top in itself, Elfman turns in a surprisingly pleasant and epic score (considering all of his past scores for Burton films have just been off-key strings to make you feel icky and uncomfortable), and the art, while inherently repellent, is actually of solid quality for the most part; like, if I saw many of these on some place like DeviantArt I would think "That's pretty interesting" - the problem is that the movie never stops with it. It was a miscalculation to have the Evil Queen get so much screen-time as she is far and away the most visually unpleasant aspect of the movie, and the fact that the movie was made during the 3D boom means that she is commonly in ultra-closeup. And frankly, it just feels like Tim Burton isn't fitted to make a movie that is >90% CGI - he does have some talent with the tangible, physical world, and this movie makes me feel happy that he has opted to stay away from this kind of filmmaking since.

I went into this film without high expectations. I saw so many ways it could go wrong, and many of Burton's more recent films have left me feeling somewhat indifferent. However, all my fears were for naught. I adored the film, without reservation. Indeed, this is not only one of Burton's best films, it is probably the best screen adaptation of Lewis Carroll ever (with the possible exception of Jan Svankmajer's Neco z Alenky from 1988). It isn't often that a film ends and I immediately want to see it again, but that's how Burton's Alice in Wonderland affected me. The cast is flawless, top to bottom. The film's vision comes the closest anyone has come to capturing the frenetic, nonsensical impossibility of Wonderland (and I loved the whole "Underland" thing). I'm hearing all sorts of bizarre negative criticisms, though none with merit. This is a bold and triumphant film, one that finally addresses, without holding back, the darkness and complexity and maturity of Carroll's writing. I will add that I saw it in 2-D, and was pleased that Burton avoided letting the 3-D thing ruin the movie, as is so often the case with that sadly popular gimmick. The film is a giddy, hallucinatory, unrelenting dance of shadow and light, hilarious and heartbreaking, brash and underscored, possessed of all the marvelously contradictory oppositions that characterize the source material. For the first time, I think, it felt as though Alice were truly an integral part of the landscape, and not just some baffled Victorian tourist passing through. And the climactic battle with the Jabberwocky...just wow. I cannot recommend this film strongly enough. (--Caitl√≠n R. Kiernan)

It's painfully incoherent and relies too much on CGI, but ALICE IN WONDERLAND is remarkably unforgettable. Both Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter have determinedly wacky performances that charm rather than induce cringes. I think Tim Burton was born to direct this film, despite his general disregard for plot.

Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin work well together and the supportive cast is memorable in their own ways. This film is well put together, a new gem in Disney animation and a must watch.

This type of world building with character driven story is something you'd expect from Pixar at their brilliant best, but Zootropolis is Disney Animation's doing. The story itself is progressive in its outlook, a female bunny achieves her dream of becoming the first rabbit to become a police officer, but faces prejudice in every aspect of the job. Zootropolis has an excellent message at its heart, but it's also cleverly written and amusing, perfect to keep the kids (and adults) occupied during this summer holiday afternoon.

Summary: Judy Hopps dreams of leaving Bunnyburrow and becoming Zootopia's first rabbit police officer. Her first day on the job, she gets stuck with parking duty and gets duped by a sly fox. Thanks to Disney+ and an unlimited number of Disney movies at my fingertips, I was finally able to enjoy Zootopia last night. It was surprisingly a very adult-centric movie and for a while I even forgot I was watching a Disney cartoon. The animals portrayed had very emotional, real world human problems to overcome and guaranteed anyone who watched this movie can relate to one of them. Personally...I relate to the sloths. But on a more serious note, I am very pleased to have found out that a sequel will be released later in 2021 because these characters are just too good to be one and done then forgotten about.
Zootopia is a utopia of imagination, every scene filled a flurry of cleverness and cuteness.

This review contains spoilers. Zootopia is one of the most loved animated films of recent years and considered by many to be a masterpiece. I am included among them. I've seen it at least 5 times, but each time it remains a perfectly aimed film. The animations are spectacular and from 10 and praise: the hairs are treated in detail and the areas of the city are memorable. Even in the characters sector we only have iconic characters: Nick is my favorite, well characterized and with a poignant background. Judy is a great protagonist and with a beautiful story arc. The sheep is a nice twist villain that the first time I wouldn't have bet a cent on her, and good motivation too. The story is deeply inspired, unpredictable and manages to entertain. The jokes are genuine and very funny. Zootopia is a great film that makes perfection its philosophy: there is nothing negative to mention and I'm really trying to find something! With photorealistic animations, fantastic script and well-made characters, Zootopia is a must see.

Probably one of the greatest movies Disney has ever made. There is something about Zootopia that makes me genuinely happy. Every time I sit down to re-watch this movie, I cannot help but get one fat smile on my face. My serotonin levels go through the roof whenever I watch the movie. Make no mistake, I LOVE this movie. This movie has everything I could ever want out of an animated feature. Intriguing story that keeps you invested all through out. The characters themselves are extremely fun and loveable. The main protagonist, Judy Hopps, is the type of person you would want to be friends with no matter what. Overall 10 outta 10, undeniably kino.

The story is indeed well-told and the animation is extremely good, far outstripping Moana from 8 months later, but the voice acting is only good, not great, there are no songs to be had and there's nothing to really latch onto as a favorite or memorable thing from the movie as they put a ton of effort into being well-rounded. There's a modicum of comedy, a dose of mystery and an underdog component but no facet of the movie is fantastic. I'm glad that I watched this as I'd heard of characters from the movie outside of it, but it's an otherwise-unmemorable police procedural with a rather plaudit-seeking morality angle.

review: Beautifully realized and with a strong score the movie has some things in its favor. The story is relatively barebones though, which isn't too surprising considering the limited source material adapted. This does hurt a little considering we spend so much time with such limited character work. The movie's biggest weakness is its toothless action. Despite how much time is spent on action scenes they accomplish very little narratively. While the action is technically well choreographed it is also so unrealistic that you lose any sense of danger after a while because none of the main characters really get hurt. All in all the movie is somewhat enjoyable despite its flaws yet people looking for a new Lord of the Rings are in for a big disappointment.

review: I was very excited to go see this in theaters when it first came out, but I actually dozed off in the theater when they were trying to cross the mountain and my enjoyment of the entire trilogy never truly recovered. I rewatched it with my wife and managed to enjoy it, but the decision to shoot in 48fps was even more jarring at home since we watched it only a couple days after finishing the LOTR trilogy. I actually loved the changes Peter made to flesh out the story into a trilogy; it did cause the runtime to bloat more than seemed necessary, but The Hobbit is actually one of the worst-written books I have ever read in my life and I've held that opinion since the first time I read it at age 12. If I hadn't read it myself I would have never believed that anyone, let alone a vaunted GOAT writer like Tolkien, had ever written a book whose entire purpose is building toward the excitement of the Dwarves' showdown with the dragon at the end, only to hastily cram in a different character in a single chapter and have him be the one to kill the dragon. My hatred of Bard the Bowman has colored my entire life since then, as I have a heightened sensitivity to perceived deus ex machina and I dislike Luke Evans as an actor because he played him. The only other gripe I have here is that Thorin was portrayed as rude, entitled and aggressive from the very beginning here, making his eventual heel turn completely unsurprising and his redemption arc ineffective at making me like the guy. Fuck Thorin. And Bard.

review: Visually, Peter Jackson's first instalment in The Hobbit trilogy is stunning. Almost every scene reveals new natural (or unnatural) delights. Martin Freeman is charming as the out-of-his-depth Mr Bilbo Baggins while Sir Ian sparkles as a less burdened, cheekier Gandalf. Devoted fans of the book will not enjoy the departures and inclusions, but for movie fans who did not ingest JRR Tolkien's dense and sometimes slow-moving children's story in their pre-teenage years, this film version will entertain more than adequately for its entire (long) length.
rt_name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey - Movie Reviews

review: A solid prequel to Lord of the Rings. It's nowhere near as good but that doesn't mean it's bad and expecting a movie as good as LOTR is basically you setting yourself up for disappointment. Every actor is amazing, especially Ian McKellen, Andy Serkis and I prefer Martin Freeman's Bilbo Baggin over Elijah Wood's Frodo Baggins. It has some well-choreographed action that makes creative use of the environment, it's visually dazzling and I know people have a problem with the overuse of CGI in these movies but this movie is innocent in that complaint and it's great seeing old locations like Rivendell and new locations as well as new creatures like goblins and it was a joy being back in middle earth, which is what I wanted. It can be funny and supenseful and a lot of amazing character moments like when Bilbo rescues Thorin and Howard Shore delivers an excellent score again. There's a lot of filler like the stuff with trolls and stone giants and it does drag in lots of places. There's no need for this to be nearly 3 hours long and it also lacks the suspense and stakes of the original series we're not 100% invested in the dwarves's journey as the consequences of failing won't be big. Plus, it has some tonal inconsistencies and a lot of moments where apparently physics doesn't exist but regardless, it's an enjoyable time and I'd definitely rewatch it.

review: It is REALLY HARD to follow Lord of the Rings, and I think that is this film's major flaw. Yes, it is spectacular. Yes, it does a great job with world building and cinematography. Even the acting and plot is well done. But the fatal flaw here is it is trying to set up something that has already happened (Star Wars prequels, anyone?) LoTR was an expansive world-ending extravaganza, whereas the Hobbit (at least the book) was supposed to be one quiet hobbit's experience with the outside world. The movie flips that all around and makes the Hobbit quite a big more expansive (and longer) than maybe it should have been. Doing this movie first, and scoping it (for die hard fans) probably would have helped. But still an excellent film.

review: I liked this movie, but it had some serious flaws. It is by far the worst of the Harry Potter movies. The movie hardcore focuses on worldbuilding for the next movies. The main plot of the movie does not get introduced until well into the movie, and even then the main plot doesn't get much screen time at all. It's interesting to see the characters behave in the situations they are put in, but not as interesting as if these situations actually had some relevance to the plot. I feel like if this movie was released in modern times, it would not have had any sequels, much like many other movies that focused too much on setting up a sequel and forgot to be a good movie itself. All that having been said (or typed?), I would still say this was an okay movie - it was very charming and it's an even better watch when you know what the future holds.

review: You probably couldn't have hoped for a better film to introduce the movie franchise than what you get with Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (aka Philosopher's Stone). Magical sets, a magical score, a perfect cast, a great script and great directing all worked to bring to life Jk Rowling's seminal work. This a clearly a big budget film, and the quality shows through in all areas. Daniel Radcliffe was a good choice to play Harry Potter, and thankfully his acting shortcomings are not as obvious in the first couple of films as they were in some of the later instalments. The Sorcerer's Stone is great filmmaking and great entertainment, easily enjoyed by anyone who hasn't read the books. It is also faithful enough to the content of the books to easily please most avid Harry Potter readers.
mojo_name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
rt_name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone - Movie Reviews

review: "Hary Potter" is the beginning of everything, the beginning of a saga that would become one of the greatest anthologies of cinema that garners many merits, being a good adaptation of the book, a remarkable creation of characters, costumes and aesthetics, the last being its greatest merit. The script adapted by Steve Kloves manages to synthesize the most important elements of the book, of course, the book is more tense and complete, but steve manages to bring the spirit to the screen just like its director, Chris Columbus, who gives a really magical touch to the film, whether in its details, in its dark photography, the magical elements in the compositions of gothic and bizarre backdrops to even its perfect soundtrack, adding that to a great cast that perfectly matches its characters, the biggest merit here is the feeling that we are watching something really wizard, the displacement with reality is very well constructed. Far from being perfect but extremely competent, "Hary Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" sums up the books well, has great characters, although not yet performative, has a beautiful direction, good effects for the time and a timeless art direction. Grade 8/10

review: Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone is the first film of this universe that the truth started in a very good way, although it is not 100% faithful to the book but is still more faithful than the other films, the evolution of Harry as a character is very Well built but I saw it as a magical version of Cinderella, from the minute we see Harry you automatically fall in love with him and it is what a movie has to do automatically with its main character that audiences connect with the main characters, With another character we became fond of was Hadrid, a character who acted as a father to Harry, went to rescue him when he was attacked by Voldemort and when he needed someone's help, the truth was he was a very good character in the plot, Ron is a character that you connect with him comes from a family with not many luxuries and that makes you love the character since he has goodness in his heart and when he meets Harry we can see the great connection in his love Istad, Hermione is a character that maybe you could see known in real life the girl in a great charisma, intelligent, kind, everything that maybe you could have come across in real life, but what we all wanted from this movie it was to see Hogwarts the great school of magic and wizardry the achievement they made so that people will fall in love with this school is a great achievement everything we wanted to see in this school we saw the classes and everything a student wants to live in It is here, the CGI is very well achieved or well it has not aged in a very good way but it is well achieved, the soundtrack is good and when you listen to it it makes you quickly remember Harry Potter, although in this movie we do not see Voldemort or well "He who should not be named" is a character that although we do not see him 100%, the magnitude of this villain and his intentions are still felt, in conclusion Harry Potter is a great franchise that started in a very good way

review: A well-made film that is also quite a bit of fun. The main critiques against it are more some of the inherent things in the storyline that I'm sure had little to do with the filmmakers and more with J.K. Rowling. For example, (I'll explain this as vaguely and spoiler-free as I can while still trying to make my point) throughout the film, the kids at Hogwarts are given strict rules to follow, lest they get expelled for breaking them. Well, several rules get broken and there are no consequences--in some instances it is even met with REWARD. Fairness is replaced with favoritism.

review: WINGARDIUM LEVIOSA! Since the whole Harry Potter movie series got added to HBO Max for a limited time, I'm going to watch all of them, and this is the first one. This was an enjoyable introduction into the magical universe. The script used the long run-time well and showed many creative ideas that had me smiling and amazed. The CGI was a bit not smooth at times, but it was still good considering the technology at the time. The main trio was also introduced, and their dynamic was also entertaining. I especially liked Emma Watson's character the most. She was clever, talkative, and quirky. And because of her confidence she didn't get too many friends, which was sad, but she's in the trio now. Since I enjoyed the magical world a lot, I honestly didn't care much about the main story of this movie. Even though there's a twist that was unexpected, I still didn't feel much about it. This movie's primary objective was clearly to introduce Harry Potter and the world he just stepped into, so the main story wasn't focused on as much. Overall, an entertaining and fun movie. Go Gryffindor! 7.5/10

It's an emotional roller coaster and prepares the setup for an incredible ending. This film is still a must see affair for all those watching Potter - and it's best to play very close attention, you'll have nearly zero questions at the end of the series. Fantastic film in an all time great series

review: One of my favorite movies is Harry Potter. This is a whole series of films directed by Chris Columbus. The first film was released in 2001 in the UK. The films are based on books by Joan Rowling. The story tells the story of an orphan boy living with his uncle and aunt. On his 11th birthday, Harry suddenly learns that he owns magic and goes to Hogwarts. There he meets Hermione Ron, and the main events of the films take place with them. The scenery of the film simply fascinates with its beauty, delightful landscapes, flying on brooms, everything immerses you in this magical world. I really like these movies and I advise all people of all ages to watch them.

review: Though it can't avoid an element of place-setting as the over-long book is split over two films, this is less drawn out than I remember. The camping scenes are needlessly long, but the wartime, almost apocalyptic atmosphere is brilliantly constructed; the dread hanging over the central characters and ever-encroaching darkness is palpable; I found the litany of names of missing wizards on the radio especially effective. The influence of Tolkein is strong here also in terms of plot, themes and world-building.

review: DOBBYYYY!! Last movie, they still said his name, now, he became you-know-who again. That's how much danger Harry and his friends were in. The opening scene of this movie was the best so far. The long chase through the Muggle's world was fast and riveting. The camera angles were creative with many cuts. They were a little bit disorienting, but still entertaining. What I liked the most was in this one, the trio spent most of their time together. Everywhere they went, the dark order was there and ready to ambush them. Even worse, the danger was so great that it affected the friendship. Also the romance, not as big of a part in this one, was still there. I enjoyed the focus on the trio quite a bit. In addition to the trio trying to run away from the dark order, they learned more about the history of you-know-who, as well as other important characters. There was a lot of mystery being explored, and it got me invested throughout the runtime. Overall, a dark and grim continuation of the story that is nearly coming to an end. Fight on Gryffindor! 9/10

review: While still great, this was the least-best movie of the series for me. Not only was it by far the least-entertaining, the section of the book this covers was rather poorly written, and them splitting it in two left far too much time for scenes that weren't as good as the second-act scenes of the rest of the series had been. Without the structure of Hogwarts a lot of the scenes felt written for the sole purpose of tying up character arcs -- it would've been illogical to hold a big wedding when there were practically still warm corpses laying about and it didn't make sense for Voldemort not to be in Malfoy Manor or quickly summoned there when they identified Harry's friends. That scene and the finding of Gryffindor's sword felt like deus ex machina in that their way out of the mess was far too convenient and unlikely. Dumbledore obfuscating the clues Harry would use to locate Horcruxes to the point he risks them not being found at all doesn't withstand scrutiny either; obviously he needed to keep the information secure, but he would've thought of a more practical way... in the very first movie he bewitched a mirror so that only a person with good intentions would get the stone by looking at it, for example. Nearly all the character development in this half is dark & they spent a little too much time visually flirting with ruining Ron & Hermione's budding romance. Also, they could've chosen a more cinematic way to interpret the book stranding the trio in the woods multiple times and the film score was unmemorable, though not as poorly done as HP5's. They at least did a good job setting up the finale by getting all of the boring parts out of the way, and I cannot dislike any movie with this much emotional investment, no matter how poorly it pays off in this particular instance.

review: So...I'd still say that the first half of the Deathly Hallows book is better than this movie. This probably has to be the darkest of all of the Harry Potter movies, but I would still recommend this movie to any Harry Potter fan out there who would want to watch the movies. It's not exactly perfect, but it is a good build-up to Part 2, and I'd still recommend Part 2 over this one any day. My overall opinion: 8/10.

review: Two films for one book: it was the precedent Hollywood needed to start doing it and everyone involved in this decision sucks. Putting that aside, this film does justice to the franchise, it's not boring at all; if anything, it has too much going on - but in a good way. It's nice to see a film that doesn't happen in Hogwarts, it's not about the school year at all and they're clearly preparing for war - that thought stops you from blinking all the way through the film.

review: Well here we are... at the end of it all. I would like to first point out that the first 45 minutes of this film are a 10/10. They are truly some of the best minutes you'll watch in this entire saga. Now with all of that out of the way, I'm going to say what's on my heart. THE REST OF THE MOVIE IS BORING! Like wtf happened to the pacing? It's like it just gave up. One minute you're riding on the back of a dragon and then the next you're listening to someone talk about someone... talk about someone. This movie had a lot of great things going for it and then waste it as soon as they get out of act 1. And don't even get me started on the whole conflict between Harry, Hermoine and Ron. It feels so useless and unearned. It's literally a conflict for the sake of conflict. It isn't growth for anyone and it's on the boarders of character assassination for Ron. Like when they aren't all acting like assholes, the movie is actually able to move forward. The plot begins to progress and everything feels right again. But damn it if that feeling doesn't take a long time to appear. But yeah, as you can probably tell, that "conflict" is my biggest problem with the story. Well, that and pacing, but at least that doesn't make you gag. Other than those two things, the movie actually quite good. It's what I wanted in teh Half-Blood Prince that I didn't get. I definitely think if stopped watching it after HBP (like I almost did) then you should reconsider. This installment is well worth your time.

But rather than that, well, this movie is a good to see and a good HP sequel! It may not satisfied TRUE HP fans but can at least content them to the Second Part in the Deathly Hallows! Part 1 of the end is a fine, boring movie to see!

review: A boy raised by wolves takes a walk through the jungle and happens upon animals with differing opinions on his well being. To the film's credit, it is wonderful to look at. Knowing that the only real thing we are looking at is Neel Sethi, who plays Mowgli, is truly a wonder for the time. All the animal characters look photo realistic. Casting Bill Murray as Baloo was a terrific idea. Ben Kingsley is great as Bagheera, Idris Elba plays a menacing Shere Khan and I love Scarlett Johansson's take on Kaa. Now here is the problem: they tried to keep the musical aspect of the original animated feature. I love the music from the original, I believe the music made that movie great. But here it is gutted from its intended purpose and is only included for nostalgic reasons. Scarlett Johansson's version of "Trust In Me" is great, but they only used it during the end credits because they needed her character to be an exposition dump. That is a terrible use of Johansson's talent and the money they spent for her studio time to voice Kaa. I could rant about this film for quite awhile, but to sum up I think this film is only worth a watch if you're interested in the technical animation achievement that it represents.

The first of many Disney live action remakes this is by far the most original huge props to Jon Faverau for adding in several new scenes and not just doing A shot for shot remake the animals are beautifully rendered accompanied by a strong voice cast Idris Elba is very menacing as shere Kahn the tiger I like how they made king Louie more sinsister. jungle book has always been one of my all time favorites and this film does it justice
Such wonderful CGI, just a visually stunning and magical film. It also captured the heart of the story, and yet made it even better.

As a fan of the original, it's too easy to dislike any retreads. This one is decent though. It has charm and it's very impressive visually. You could always nitpick these kinds of movies. And of course, it doesn't NEED to exist because the original is still great. But it's fun enough. I'm looking forward to the sequel.

review_date: Directed by Jon Favreau, starring Neel Sethi & Bill Murray. When a reimagining outshines a classic. Disney has remade its classic Jungle Book (1967) and turned it into a visual feast for the eyes. This movies special effects are so realistic, it‚Äôs hard to believe that nothing was shot on a set and it was all computer generated. The cast is complied of Hollywood‚Äôs finest actors and actresses, all lending their voices to these beautifully rendered computer generated animals. This film in my opinion delivers more emotion than the cartoon and also I think is a better movie than the original as well. This movie would suffer completely if the animals didn‚Äôt breathe and come to life the way they do. If you are a fan of the original or just a fan of Disney in general this should be at the top of your list to experience.

The Jungle Book was my favorite Disney movie growing up, and they hit this remake out of the park. Slightly more sinister than the animated version, this takes everything the original did great and expands on it. I may give this 5 stars after a later rewatch.

An eye-popping and visually dazzling masterpiece, combined with Favreau's direction, Marks' script, the performances of the cast, Debney's score, Pope's cinematography, Livolsi and Gerstel's editing, Glass's production design, Serino's set decoration, Shannon's costume design, action sequences and visual effects, The Jungle Book outdoes its animated counterpart in every part of film-making whilst pushing forward the boundaries of visual effects!!!

Really good watch, would watch again, and can recommend. I'll honestly go as far as to recommend this over the original 1967 version. I don't think is quite as charming as the original, and it has a very different animation style, both with great quality of detail in it. From the individual strains of fur, to the types of animals included (I've done so much research on Indian wildlife today), you can really see the details of the cg effects. Just watch the end credit sequence alone, and it'll prove it. There are 3 huge improvements to this versus others: Sher Khan's face, King Louie, and the intensity of the animal fight scenes. The movie isn't free of problems: I imagine someone will have issues with talking animals vs non-talking animals, that he'd have to learn the language (so how would he ever understand Sher Khan or Baloo?). If anything, I think the writing took a hit. Where the original had a subtle but strong fables sequencing to it (sort of modular moral stories with shifting focus on characters), this is structured much closer to how many video game stories are structured, serialized chapters with some level of power creep and shifting focus of environment and goals but all focused on Mowgli. And I don't think the writing is bad, but this Jungle kid (never actually reveals his backstory, somewhat of a relief honestly) is performing clean engineering using vines and pulleys and armor (that wouldn't work) with calculated positioning. I understand that some people just have talent for some things, but I had to question whether or not I could do the same thing. I could, but I'd have to do it different ways. And in all fairness some of the stupid /inconsistent things he gets up too, even though he's a "take charge" Mowgli in this version really got to me: I was literally cheering for Sher Khan at certain points. Ultimately I had a good time with it, and I think most people and possibly their pets will too (my cats were interested for a while).

The Jungle Book is an exceptionally visually-stunning film with all the CGI looking flawless and the characters from the original being brought to life in a realistic, yet vivid way. It changes enough from the first Jungle Book to have it's own sense of originality but is still loyal enough to please huge fans of the 1968 film. The voice cast is incredible, who bring plenty of charisma and energy to their roles, with the standouts being Bill Murray as Baloo and Idris Elba as Shere Kha. Neel Sethi, is also great, bringing Mowgli to life in this film. The only problems are its lack of originality (being a remake, and all) and the songs from the original feeling wasted.

review: I wasn't expecting much from a reboot/sequel to a beloved 90s movie. I liked Jumanji when it came out in 1995 so, you can imagine my hesitation when I heard about this film. Expectations went up upon hearing Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson was going to be the lead. I love me some Dwayne Johnson man! This movie is an absolute blast to watch. It is entertainment first and foremost and yet it does add some much-needed characterization to some of these kids. I will admit that I wasn't a huge fan of the extreme stereotyped version of the kids at the beginning but, once the movie got going I understood why they did that. Overall, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a extremely fun movie that you can watch over and over again. It pairs well with movies like The Mummy from 1999.
rt_name: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle - Movie Reviews

review: As a long time fan of the original Jumanji film, it was a pleasant surprise to find out how good this one ended up being. Honoring the original, but putting a modern spin on it, and going inside Jumanji instead of taking it to the real world, really gave the story a new perspective. The chemistry between Johnson and Hart is always amusing, but the whole cast worked really well together, providing a lot of laughs throughout the movie.
rt_name: Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle - Movie Reviews

review: A short but sweet coming of age movie. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a solid action movie that plays it safe which is both its biggest strength and weakness. Most stuff in here is solid but nothing special, that being said, the cast is one of the best ensembles of A-list actors I've ever seen. From Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson to Karen Gillian to Kevin Hart and even Jack Black, every actor is a recognizable face and delivers on a phenomenal performance. Their chemistry is nothing to scoff at either as they all seem like high school students who only recently got to know one another. The special effects are also top-notch with some of the most gorgeous landscapes, intricate designs that translate beautifully into a 3D environment and some entrancing particle effects. One thing I don't like is the pacing, it felt like they had an actual plan for it but it fails miserably. The story structure is supposed to represent an action videogame but it just doesn't work on film in the slightest. The slower-paced, more emotionally driven scenes feel rushed and the action sequences feel rushed. Another thing this movie kinda misses the mark on is the tension. They wrote themselves into a corner with the life system they wrote so to get out of it, they just start taking them away for the sole of comic relief and having dire stakes. These things could've definitely benefitted from a revision or two. On the contrary, the soundtrack is an absolute blast! From the orchestral themes to the licensed songs, they're all excellent. It would've been a crime if they made a movie called "Welcome to the Jungle" and not have the infamous Guns 'n Roses in it! In conclusion, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a rock-hard adventure that makes for an exhilarating thrill ride from beginning to end!

review: Jumanji: The Call of the Jungle is an excellent film directed by Jake Kasdan, which was released on December 21, 2017. This is an adventure comedy about how four teenagers got into a computer game. The plot is both exciting and frightening. As punishment, the four teenagers were left to clean up the school basement on a day off. They discover an old prefix and decide to launch the game "Jumanji". After selecting avatars and starting the game, all four are drawn into the game. The guys find themselves inside the fictional world of "Jumanji" - in a jungle full of fantastic animals and traps. Each of the teenagers turns into their own avatar. They will have to pass all the tests and reach the end to return to the real world. However, they are not playing this game, but "Jumanji" is playing with them. The actors ' acting is just great. Dwayne Johnson, Kevin Hart, Jack Black, Karen Gillan - the main characters of this film. They played their roles very plausibly. Special effects at the highest level. Overall, "Jumanji: The Call of the Jungle" is one of the best movies I've watched. Running time: 1 hour 51 minutes, this is a very interesting and intriguing film. I advise everyone to watch this movie.

review_date: An epic finale to the Journey of Bilbo Baggins and the Dwarves. Though the trilogy as a whole comes across as more cartoonish and slightly less inspired than LOTR. (the CGI appears more fake this time around) The trilogy finishes strong because we get a good build up with character development, and then the last 40 mins delivers with the titular Battle. The heroes took the mountain back from Smaug, but now they all have to deal with A mob of angry fishermen and elves and to make things worse, Azog and his Orc army attack them all with giant worms! also Richard Armitage did a great job with Thorin and portraying Thorin‚Äôs growing Lust for Riches (Dragon sickness) This is also the final performance of the Great Christopher Lee (RIP) reprising his role as The Villianous Saruman the White

review: The director did enough in the first two movies to soften the potential movie-ruining plot developments that were bound to happen in this one that I ended up enjoying it more than it truly deserved out of sheer relief. Thorin's heel turn was easier to swallow when he had been an asshole the entire trilogy and ceding the dragon kill to a random town citizen was mostly fine since he put in a lot of work fleshing out Bard's character in the second movie. With those issues overcome, what we're left with are numerous lengthy battle scenes, which P-Jackson has always done well. I liked every bit of the war parts and the ice battle was pretty good, though it didn't seem logical for Azog to go into the fight of his life using the flail weapon he'd never really used before as it ended up being his downfall. My wife was particularly touched by the Kili-Elf romance subplot!

review: Lets be honest, the Jackson films don't hold a candle to the elegance and evocation of Tolkien's masterpiece. It seems as though Jackson and is writing staff subconsciously knew they lacked the artistic ability tp produce a faithful screen adaptation to the original work. So they didn't try. Instead, they churned out another silly, superficial franchise mcmovie cash grab leveraging JRRT's name. I hope someday talented filmmakers will come along to do the books justice. Until then, I will repeat what others have already said: just read the books. Green screens and cgi will never match the power and subtlety of Tolkien's pen.

review: For the LGBT viewers: The Hobbit is not necessarily classified as an LGBT film. It's no Call Me By Your Name or A Portrait of a Lady on Fire, but if you love fantasy and can tolerate queer coded characters and plot lines, the Hobbit is definitely for you. The journey of the relationship between Bilbo Baggins and Thorin Oakenshield is definitely one for the gay history books. Throughout the whole series, Bilbo and Thorin's relationship strengthens and deepens, and reaches a height in this last movie. In my opinion, though the battles and fantastical plot lines spark much excitement through the films, the real magic is between the characters throughout the franchise. You get the best of both worlds; a great fantasy plot, with queer relationships with depth and growth. Queer viewers rarely get both of those things, so the Hobbit is extremely rare in that respect. The Hobbit makes it clear that romance is not all about kissing, and that queerness travels between worlds. Enjoy!

review: Exactly what it says on the tin - to a fault. Don't get me wrong, I like it. However, towards the end 'The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies' definitely begins to drag quite heavily - the impact of what eventually happens did not, to be honest, hit as strongly as it could've/should've. The pure action is good, but there's not much to remember about everything else. None of the characters, with the exception of Richard Armitage (Thorin) and Luke Evans (Bard) I guess, stand out amidst the wall-to-wall battle. Martin Freeman (Bilb), Ian McKellen (Gandalf) & Co. are are of little importance really, which is a shame. 'The Hobbit' series, unfortunately, gets inferior as it goes by. Loved the first film, enjoyed the second but this third installment - while passable - leaves me with a feeling of wanting something else from it. Happy to have watched them though, I'd still recommend them for sure.

review: The threequel in the Pirates franchise pits Jack Sparrow, Barbossa and the rest of the worlds' pirates against Lord Beckett, Davy Jones, the British Empire and the East India Trading Company in a final showdown. Once again Johnny Depp, Geoffrey Rush, Bill Nighy deliver outstanding performances. Tom Hollander as Cutler Beckett also deserves props, as does Keira Knightley who was allowed to shine more in this film. The final action sequence, while long, does provide excellent action and a very satisfying ending for all the characters. The special effects were well done and hold up to age well. I appreciate the world building that takes place in this film, but it does add length to the movie that might not have been necessary. This film is a fun summer blockbuster that I think is worth your time.

review: Merely worthy of its borrowed title. To me is the weakest of all five films. Depp's acting and the cameo by Keith Richards is all there is behind my two stars rating. Less action then it the first film, intertwined plots that solve themself without proper explanations, the pace is slow and uninspired, the original signature soundtrack is almost inexistent (oh you kept it all for then end credits? Damn!), and to release it one year after the second one is a marketing shame. I am planning on buying the whole saga on bluray, but for now I saw the first on vhs and then the third on dvd and I had a very hard time believing it was a sequel to the excellent, enjoyable flick that is The Curse of the Black Pearl. No wonder they changed director after At World's End...

review: I don't understand why people hate this movie. To me, it's a satisfying end to the trilogy and an improvement over Dead Man's Chest. Visual effects: Fantastic. Musical score: Absolutely remarkable. Final battle: Epic. Jack Sparrow and Johnny Depp: Just as awesome as ever with an interesting character battle in his mind. Humor: Hilarious. Elizabeth: A badass, portrayed beautifully by Keira Knightley. Barbossa: An extremely welcome addition. Davy Jones: A more interesting villain. Worldbuilding: Really interesting and creative. Story: A good follow up to Dead Man's Chest and I love the scale of the movie and I don't get why people say it's convolutef or confusing. It makes perfect pense and the movie really feels epic. Emotional weight: It lands with many deaths and a heartwarming finale for Elizabeth and Will. Beckett: More of a threat. Shch an underrated villain. Creativity: Through the roof. Entertaining: Definitely. There's a lot to like in this movie but there's also stuff I disliked. Length: Too long. Did not need to be 168 minutes long. Orlando Boom: Generally stiff performance and I'm not a fan of how Willmwas written. Pacing: not very good. It needed more action in the middle and as much as I love Davy Jones, he's kind of underutilized in the first two acts but overall, it's an epic end to a great trilogy.

review: The best Pirates movie in the entire franchise. The last two movies have been building up to this epic finale of Elizabeth's and Will's story. It is truly a masterpiece and has the best opening sequence of any film. It sets the tone for the rest of the movie by being darker than the previous two. It is my favorite movie of the franchise when I was younger and I am not disappointed. The pacing is really good, never too fast or slow, you can pick up on all of the information they give you. The 2 and a half hour run time didn't feel long or lacking at all. For the time the CGI was really good and now 14 years later it holds up pretty well. This movie left me fulfilled and wishing I could be a pirate.

review: Yep, this is definitely a rotten movie. Too complicated, over-stuffed, too many characters... in general, it's a complete mess. It has an excessive length and it feels like the director didn't want to make any more POTC movies and just tossed in the characters and a poorly written script. The action scenes are... okay, I guess, but who cares about the action sequences if the plot sucks? If I would have to describe this movie in a few words only, I would say this: "Almost three hours of crazy pirate-characters in a bad story full with inconsistencies and things that don't make any sense."

review: This was certainly better than the first movie, and it managed that despite my two least-favorite characters getting most of the screentime (Bard and Thorin). The addition of Legolas & Tauriel was a perfect touch and the two main Orcs had excellent CGI & voice actors. I would've preferred they used their decision to take creative liberties to expand Beorn's role as he's probably the most enigmatic character from the book. It was hard to get excited about the dwarves fighting the dragon at the end because it was pretty clear Peter couldn't stray so far from the source as to let them actually win, so it came off exactly like the contrived cliffhanger that it was.

review: 87/100. With a quicker and in my opinion, better pace than the first movie, it feels like ‚ÄòThe Desolation of Smaug' is a non-stop action/adventure movie. Thorin, Bilbo, and Gandalf continue to have great character development throughout this movie and the return of Legolas from the original trilogy adds a great callback. Finally, the effects and use of Smaug in this movie is something that surprised me with how well it was done. As soon as Bilbo enters the mountain and encounters Smaug, the movie did a great job of setting the tone and suspense to the point where viewers could feel the tension. If you are a fan of the original Lord of the Rings movies as well as ‚ÄòThe Hobbit' books, ‚ÄòThe Desolation of Smaug' is a must see.

What it does have is Legolas, Kate from Lost, Ronan the Accuser, Dr. Strange and Trevor Beaumont. And a massive red dragon with a superb monster design.

review: An improvement over the first movie. It's much better paced with barely any boring moments, better choreographed action sequences especially the barrel sequences, it was cool seeing the ring having an influence on Bilbo and he once again has many great moments, Benedict Cumberbatch was an amazing Smaug (and that CGI is remarkable) and the scenes with him and Bilbo were so suspenseful, we got to see brand new locations in this movie, Tauriel was pretty awesome and once again, it absorbs you into the story of Middle Earth with great character moments and the stakes and suspense are higher and you feel that throughout the movie, this time for the actual world as we see Sauron's forces gathering and Suaron himself. Not to mention it's visually stunning. It's not perfect though. The romance with Tauriel and Killi is so forced and just weird (an elf and a dwarf?), it was annoying that we did not get to see much Gandalf and it's really convenient that Tauriel and Legolas arrived at LakeTown at the perfect time. Most of the dwarves are still forgettable The weakest part is the cliffhanger and it's not an Empire Strikes Back or Infinity War cliffhanger where it still felt like a complete story. It's not a satisfying ending and not a complete ending but it's still a great movie overall and definitely an improvement over the first.
mojo_name: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug
rt_name: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Movie Reviews

review: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug, is an improvement from an Unexpected Journey but only by a smidge. While an Unexpected Journey suffered from a slow pace, that had an uneven tone, this movie thrives off of the faster pacing, and better mixing of tone. The only downgrade is the script which does go down in quality in favor of the faster pacing and more thrilling sequences. As a sequel it does its job exceptionally well, building up characters, and raising the stakes. Only if this movie had a sharper script, I think this could have been an amazing watch. So 7/10, an improvement that surprised me.

review: Still very good, but I found 'The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug' to be a step below the preceding 2012 release. The conclusion is what affects it the most, in my opinion. It isn't anything bad, but it goes on for too long - yet the ending itself comes out of nowhere a little. It's iffily crafted, with the entertainment value not enough to cover it up. Again, nothing anywhere near terrible... just not as great as I wanted/expected. I also kinda wanted more scenes with Martin Freeman (Bilbo) across the midway point. I like the focus on Richard Armitage (Thorin) & Co. but I felt there needed to be more with the lead - and with Ian McKellen (Gandalf), for that matter. I've led with my negatives first, but I have many positives too. I enjoyed the scenes in Esgaroth with Luke Evans (Bard), all of the stuff there looks awesome. The character of Tauriel, played by Evangeline Lilly, is cool. Orlando Bloom (Legolas) remains fun to watch. Everything else, including the score, is very nicely done - as anticipated. Love the end credits song ("I See Fire") by Ed Sheeran, by the way. Not quite as grand and great as "May It Be" from LOTR, but it's pretty close!
mojo_name: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug

review: The strengths of the first movie didn't necessarily carry over to this one, but it was still fantastic in its own right with its own set of attributes that made it so. Most notable by far were the film score, arguably the most memorable of the three movies, followed by the introduction of Gollum and the revolutionary CGI quality that came with him. The flaws in this one have the benefit of being made much worse by their expansion in the third movie, that being the deus ex machina and Frodo's transformation into a burdensome wuss, and even those could be considered more a gripe with the source material than the actual filmmakers. The final battle is truly something to behold here, both for its obvious high quality and for the endless series of LOTR videogames with levels based on it.

review: [‚≠êÔ∏è89%] The second movie in the Lord of the Rings franchise, The Two Towers (2002) maintains the same quality as its predecessor as well as expanding upon it in other places such as the world and creatures. As the Fellowship is broken, the remaining former members are separated into smaller groups which actually allows for some development for characters, whether they are important like Aragorn or more of a side character like Pippin. The Two Towers (2002) actually offers a lot more greater things than The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) with diving deeper into themes about the hypnosis the Ring provides as well as some huge scale battles, however the pace is a lot slower and more dialogue heavy than its predecessor, which at points can be really long to sit through. Other than it's slower pace, The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002) provides yet another fantastic addition to the trilogy.

review: The Lord of the Rings is one long story divided among three movies, which is the reason why it is hard to review this movie in itself. I have already written a review for The Fellowship of the Ring, in which I talked about how awesome the visuals of the story are, the philosophy behind the ring and the pop culture icon that it became. That is why I won't talk about those things in this review. Rather I will talk about the characters of the movie and why it has such a huge impact in the pop culture in spite of being nearly 20 years old book adaptation. Percy Jackson has done a really great job. The story picks up from the part where Gandalf was attacked, except this time it happens from the other point of view. This not only helps the viewer remember an incident that was important from the previous movie, but also makes it interesting by not showing the exact same shots again. While previously we believed Gandalf to be just a weak old man, over here he turned out to be a strong wizard. This is the reason why it paid off to see him return as Gandalf the White. The thing I really like aobut Gandalf is that he is a perfect balance of powerful and emotional character. In one moment he is being spun around by Saruman where he is crying like a frail old man, and in the very next scene he is fighting a fire dragon. In the first movie he scared Bilbo for a second by threatening him with magic if he dared to wear the ring, but immediately after he joined the Hobbits in the party. This is the trait which adds character depth to him, preventing him from being a two dimensional person. This way we get to see him from multiple perspectives. The second character I'd talk about here would be Gollum. The first time I saw him I thought he's just another one of those cringy skinny characters every fantasy movie needs to have (Jar Jar from Star Wars prequels, Dobby from Harry Potter etc). But he's very different. Earlier he was just a normal person like the rest of us. However, it was the temptation of the ring that completely ruined him, not just emotionally but physically too. Now in spite of his immortality he wastes himself searching for an addiction he has never been able to get away from. This is the reason why in spite of not actually wanting to hurt Frodo, he is unable to convince himself that what he is doing is actually wrong. This message is very clear in the scene where he is talking to himself. Speaking of the scene where Gollum talks to himself, that scene is one of the many scenes which is able to show the emotions that the characters wanted to express. This is something that can be done only by a good cinematography, which is something Peter Jackson was able to handle. Even though that scene is ridiculed, the point behind the scene was to show how Gollum was feeling while planning to kill Frodo and not how he was actually looking like. There have been plenty of scenes where the characters have conversations, but I don't want to spoil the movie for you. And that scene was interrupted by Sam, who is the next character I'd speak about. Sam is Frodo's best friend and he can go to any limits to make sure Frodo is safe. He is absolutely pure of mind, which was shown in the first movie when he stopped Frodo from wearing the ring. Sam had heard that Gollum wanted to kill Frodo and even though Gollum was the only one character who could actually help them reach the Mountain of Doom, Sam was ready to take the risk even if it meant having to get lost. Frodo didn't trust him or rather should I say, didn't WANT to trust him. And in spite of being abandoned by his best friend, Sam never wasted any time to get back to saving Frodo. The movie also has many battle scenes, cool CGI, shows the Fellowship of the Ring fight alongside other kingdoms while Gandalf is not there to protect them. The action, the comic timings, the CGI, the acting, everything about this movie is absolutely great. The only mistake I made watching this was that I watched the theatrical cut of this movie. Because of this I missed a very important (and cool) scene from the story, which I was thinking would be answered in Return of the King. It has something to do with Saruman. So don't make that mistake. I'd say you should watch the long one, no matter how much more you have to watch. The Two Towers is the most underrated movie of the trilogy and I really wish it was talked about more. Only those people know about it who have watched the trilogy. That doesn't mean it's bad. That just means this trilogy should be watched more. Since The Fellowship of the Ring is the beginning of the adventures and The Return of the King is the conclusion, The Two Towers never gets any appreciation as it is sandwiched between the two. But in reality it is the movie which bridges the two. It is an essential part of the movie since this is where the maximum amount of character development takes place.
mojo_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
rt_name: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers - Movie Reviews

review: Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers is a masterpiece. The Two Towers continues the story of the Fellowship as they travel through the lands of Rohan and the country of Gondor to get to Mordor to destroy the Ring of Power. Gollum is an amazing character and getting to see both sides of him added so much more depth to his character. The Uruk-Hai are menacing in this movie along with Saruman, he actually feels like a real threat along with his foot soldiers and you get the sense that anyone can die in all 3 of these movies, with the stakes being set at the end of Fellowship. But the bar is raised as King Theoden and the people of Rohan retreat to Helm's Deep where they fight what is undeniably one of the greatest battles in cinematic history. I could go about this movie for days, but you get the point. I love it, and I always will.

review: (Extended edition) This one is always better than I remember it being. Definitely the black sheep of the trilogy. The extended cut isn't as good as Fellowship's in my opinion as there are too many extraneous scenes in this cut that only serve to stifle the pacing. The worst offenders are the additional scenes of Merry & Pippin which were already the slowest parts of the theatrical cut. In this cut we get entire scenes that are utterly pointless and barely add anything, as well as some more comedically focussed scenes that seem awkward and out of place in the overall film. There are other scenes that help flesh out and develop characters which I feel should have been included in the theatrical version. For example, we get a much better explanation of Aragorn's lineage and history in this cut which is very important given the key role he plays in the plot of The Return of the King. Overall, I feel the theatrical cut of this film is the superior, especially for a more casual viewer. It may gloss over some aspects, but the pacing is much better. I think I'll continue watching the extended cut though, purely because it has more content.

review: Yet another great Harry Potter movie! This movie felt very raw, especially at the beginning, which is a good thing - it makes the movie feel so much more realistic. This is the first movie to feel so raw, and the later ones embrace this idea a lot more. It's a pretty difficult feat to have a good character that everyone genuinely hates, not for being a badly written character, but because of how well she is written, and Umbridge was done perfectly - I'd say Umbridge is the best example of a well-written character made for everyone to genuinely loathe. All that aside, the Order was really cool, and while I wish we spent more time with the order and getting to know them, it was a great movie as always and leaves you wanting more!

review: EXPECTO PATRONUM!! And the looming danger continued to haunt Harry Potter. This time, the school got ransacked by the Ministry of Magic, and the students weren't allowed to practice magic. I knew that after the fourth one, this movie series would get more interesting and investing. And I was right. Now, Harry Potter got into deeper danger as his mentality started to decay as the movie went on. The school ransacking plot was pretty alright. It did make me want to see Harry Potter and his squad succeed and bring down the faculties. Most importantly, I appreciated that Harry was able to bond more with the other students, not just with the trio. They used a lot more magic, which was always fun to see. The best part of the movie was near the end, it was the first time that we saw a full-out battle between the wizards. The atmosphere was intense, and I enjoyed the lot of it. Overall, another thoroughly fun display of wizardry. Hope that it would continue to get better. 9/10

review: I found it very difficult to separate this viewing experience from reading the source material -- they had so much plot to condense that it ends up being nearly all that we're left with. There's a distinct lack of joy de vivre as it's a rather solemn, darkly-toned book and they minimized parts in the movie that were bright points in the novel, like excising Quidditch and spending very little time at Grimmauld place. The composer basically just being some guy the director knew was a shockingly poor decision as he was clearly unprepared for so important a movie, producing the worst film score in the entire franchise. The acting from Imelda and Bonham Carter was very impressive but particularly with the former it wasn't so magnificent that it had me enjoying scenes with her character in them; my nostalgia for this series is rooted in the very first movie where there's a thick air of whimsy and wonder, and thus I generally dislike most of the deviations from that atmosphere, with Umbridge being the prime example. The third act of this is still a sight to behold and the whole thing is thoroughly enjoyable to watch, but for me this rates among the bottom of the franchise in terms of entertainment value.
mojo_name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

review: I'm a casual Harry Potter fan that loves watching the movies, playing the games and reading the books. By far this fifth instalment is the weakest out of the bunch and I know that a lot of content from the original was cut out. Some of my biggest issues with the film are the first and second parts that drag, the characters actually getting annoying and the overall theme of the film not making sense. However, the last third of the film gets much better as the character dynamics have more development and the climatic wizard duel was really well done which saves this film a lot. Overall it is an okay film but by far the weakest out of the Harry Potter film series, and the book was much better than the film.

review: Order of the Phoenix makes a big jump forward in terms of increasing the stakes and taking the story into darker, more serious territory. Whereas Goblet of Fire primarily focused on the school experience of Hogwarts- this one makes it clear that the focus is more on the beginnings of the wizarding war. This movie is great because the consequences are real and lasting- unlike most of the previous Potter stories where all of our main characters emerge unscathed. The adult characters play a much larger role- Gary Oldman as Sirius Black is a standout performance, and the younger cast are now closer to being adults than children. The themes are also maturing, touching on politics with the failures and corruption in the ministry. Poor leadership, abuse of authority, and the necessity of a questioning, rebellious spirit is a strong thread throughout the entire movie. The last 30 minutes of this movie have some of the high points in the entire HP franchise. The fights between the Order & Death eaters are exciting and tense. The battle between Voldemort and Dumbledore is the best one on one fight in the entire series.

Finding nemo is a great movie from my child hood. I recently rewatched it and saw how much is has related to family life and single fathers. It also plays a role in showing step families with dory too. Overall a great movie with good lessons in it.

A classic Disney movie that is worth the watch. This movie is child friendly with slight hidden adult humor. Finding Nemo focuses on a lost son with an overprotective single father. It shows that having helicopter parents can lead to defiant kids. The is a must see for parents and children with a take home message to not be defiant and not to have over protective parents. Not only is the movie sentimental and emotion, it is funny and will have you quoting the film for the rest of the week.

A young clownfish named Nemo is taken by humans and his father, Marlin, transferces the ocean to find him, with a little help from a regal blue tang named Dory. This is a great film! The first two scenes do a great job to endear you to both Marlin and Nemo. Dory is instantly likable and relatable. As Marlin goes on his journey and develops his character, the characters he meets are all memorable and iconic. The aquarium crew are all memorable as well. The animation is top notch and really captures the underwater environment in a believable way. Ellen DeGeneres stands out in the voice acting department, by creating a unique and memorable character in Dory. One of the best films Pixar has done, highly recommended!
An absolute classic of my childhood

My earliest memory is when I was 2 years old watching this at a drive-in theater. Movies matter to me a lot.

I was in kindergarten when this movie came out. I never watched it because everyone else was watching it. I have come up with the concept of normie long before it was created. Other than that it was also because I came from a very conservative family. I was not allowed to watch movies in theatre, especially not a Hollywood one. So as all the kids used to talk about it I grew into hating it. And when this movie came on TV I only watched it with a critical point of view. It was only years after when I watched it and truly appreciated it. Finding Nemo is a very colourful movie filled with many sea creatures. It is an excellent movie that can teach children about the different types of marine life. I have heard about how everyone started hunting for clownfish after this movie came up. Although this is a bit sad and very cruel thing to do it also shows the impact that this movie was able to create and how much people enjoyed watching it. The fishes were shown in a very cute manner, especially the pufferfish. The only problem I have with this movie is the lack of a story. It's just a fish going from point A to point B. Although this does make for a good story since it helps in character development and world building, but these things should not be done while completely sacrificing a good story. I think I really like this movie and I will watch that once again to truly appreciate it.

review: Although the adaptation lacks many good scenes explained in the book, clearly speaking of the movie it is a good movie, interesting and intense scenes and a good connection to the story. Something I don't like is the color mode that the whole movie has, it makes it look strange. Rupper and Daniel's performance looks very strange, I don't remember if it was like that in the book but it doesn't look good in my opinion. Finally, it is a very interesting story since we know a lot about the background of the story and if it is not the first time you see the saga, there are things that make a lot of sense. It's an interesting movie for an afternoon, only if you've already seen the saga not as an independent Harry Potter movie.

review: A movie that when compared to it's source material, is pathetic on all grounds, but even on it's own legs, refuses to stand. The story takes away a large percentage of what made the novel so interesting, in order to shoehorn in a bloat to the romance plot-line between Harry and Ginny. However, even with this change, said romance is abysmal, and considering it's the main focus of the movie, there's bound to be issues. With color pallets seem to swap with every scene, a cast of characters with some of the most annoying performances in the series, this movie falls flat on its face. This is incredibly ironic considering that the director previously did Order of the Phoenix, and then went on to film both Deathly Hallows parts, and both Fantastic Beasts movies, all of which were great.

review: Harry Potter is one of the few franchises that almost feels like each movie is better than the previous one. This one is one of my favourites. I don't think I can say any negative thing about this movie - everything was so well executed, except of course for not including Tom Riddle's other Pensieve memories. As always, I love the twists at the end, and I also love that there's just enough details left in the movie to piece together the big twist in Deathly Hallows about Snape.
