review: This is my least favorite of the movies. Both because it is unfaithful to the book and just because its a bad movie. Now I'll admit, if I hadn't read the books first, I might not have hated it as much. But even by itself: its not a good movie. I first want to disclaim: I understand the filmmakers have to cut out stuff to make the movie. My favorite book of the series is Order of the Phoenix and thats a damn good movie as well, event though they did cut out a ton of stuff. Why? They knew what to cut and what to focus on. That isn't the case here. Firstly, Voldemort's backstory is one of the best parts of the entire series. The detail, the buildup and the rhyming between the young boy in the orphanage, the charming student, and the terrifying Dark Lord is brilliant. So what do they do? Cut out all of the memories of his past except the orphanage one. I can understand cutting some of the stuff but at least give us the Gaunt memories. That is crucial to the story of Voldemort and his Horcruxes. But nope. All that great stuff is cut out in exchange for completely unnecessary and downright cringeworthy stuff (I'll get to this later. Secondly, the freaking Half-Blood Prince? Y'know the title of this damn movie? He's basically an afterthought. How many times is the Half-Blood Prince ever brought up in the movie? Barely, and even when he is, he barely factors into the story and Harry doesnt develop any sort of connection with him. The reveal that its Snape is completely tacked on in the movie unlike the book where it was a gut punch. In the book, Harry starts to relate to the Prince, even seeing him as a friend, and defending him against Hermione's suspicions. He helped Harry through the entire thing and is what gave Harry the knowledge to save Ron's life. And then it turns out that the Prince was actually the man who he hated, that sold out his parents and got them murdered (another important thing cut from the movie), in Harry's eyes, got Sirius killed, and now murdered the greatest man he ever knew. But in the movie, its just like, oh wait, is that supposed to be important? Lets add that in here even though the Prince isn't important for 90% of the movie. I swear, it feels lie this movie was just in its own land and then at the end they realized "oh wait we want to make a ton of money off the next movie so we have to set that up." Thirdly, Harry and Dumbledore's relationship. Both actors gave a fantastic performance. Hell in this movie, all of them did. Its the writing thats on the wall here. Dumbledore feels more like a plot device than a character. In the book, we see Harry and Dumbledore's relationship strengthening following the conversation at the end of the 5th book where all the feelings were let out. Dumbledore basically replaces Sirius as his guardians and we really get to see how close they are especially with Harry telling the Minister of Magic he was "Dumbledore's man through and through." But we dont get to any of that here. Nope, instead we get a cringy romance drama. Now, you might be noticing a core problem with these issues: cut out in exchange for nonsense. The stuff above is what should've been in the movie and half the stuff in the movie should've been cut out. Instead of delving into Voldemort's backstory, and advancing the character of Snape, they decided to make this movie a romance drama. Its all over the place. They also added in completely out of nowhere scenes like the Burrow burning which should've been serious but had no consequences... because it wasn't in the book at all and they realized they had to set up the seventh chapter. Thats a good chunk of screen time. Cut out all the unnecessary teenager drama, for God's sake. Was there drama in the book? Absolutely. But it was the subplot not the main plot. And it was handled a lot more seriously and/or better than it was in the movie. The drama serves the story, not the other way around, which is what the movie did. And thats the main problem with this movie. It focuses on the wrong stuff. All the melodrama, that sound be the stuff brought up here and there rather than being the main plot, the Half-Blood Prince and Voldemort's origins should be the main story. The screenwriters had this completely backwards. Yes, they would have to cut some of the good drama from the book... but thats okay. Like I said, I get that they have to cut stuff. They just cut the wrong stuff. But even then, if they handled the stuff they wanted to focus on well, I could call it a day and say its disappointing but overall a good movie. But they didnt. They even failed on all the drama they wanted to get across. If you want to make feelings and conflicts of interest the main story, at least do it well. But they even failed at that. Thee biggest example of this is Ginny and Ron. Now its pretty clear David Yates was someone who shipped Harry and Hermione from both the 6th and 7th movies. That doesnt mean you ruin other characters to get that done. I do think overall they did Ron worse than Ginny, but thats more in the 7th one. In this movie, it was Ginny that was ruined. In the books, Ginny was a sassy, confident, powerful girl who could stand up for herself and had a lot of nerve. Harry's feelings for her are built up throughout most of the book. Starting with a brief mention on the Hogwarts Express when he's unhappy that Ginny is sitting with Dean alone on the train and kicking off the plot with the scene after Quidditch practice. The drama between all the characters is very well handled in the book. In one scene, Rowling sets up grudges and building anxiety that really develop the main characters for the rest of the book. I'm of course talking about the scene where Ron and Harry run into Ginny and Dean kissing, which is where Ron's inner self-hate and jealousy as well as his insecurities are triggered by his younger sister and he finds out about Krum & Hermione, which sets up his story for the book, as well as the first time Harry realizes he likes Ginny. Unlike in the movie, they do care about Ron in the book, and Harry's inner conflict is between his feelings for Ginny and how his best friend would react if he was in Dean's place that day. Harry's feelings keep building, and later in the book, they start dropping hints that Ginny likes him as well. Ron also has a great journey where his core problem is observed: lack of self-confidence. Finding out about Hermione and Krum only made him hate himself worse, and when the Quidditch match came around and he won, he finally for the first time in his life could be proud of himself. Especially when he found out that he did it all himself, there was no Felix Felicis in his drink. He became confident, and that caused him to start becoming a jerk. Take somebody who has lacked power all their life, hated themselves for their weakness, and felt every time they were bullied, it was deserved because of weakness. And if you give them power, you'll create a greater monster than you ever could've imagined. Power in this case is self-confidence. His entire life, Ron's been overshadowed by his brothers, teased for his poorness, living in the shadow of his best friend, and now for the first time in his life, he's the one with all the attention, everyone loves him, he gets a self-confidence boost and THATS what causes him to be so horrible to Hermione. It takes a near death experience to break him out of this arrogant streak and ultimately, he becomes better as a person because of the experience. Both of these journeys come to a climax in this passage: "We won!!" yelled Ron, bounding into sight and brandishing the Silver Cup at Harry. "We won! Four Hundred and Fifty to a Hundred and Forty! We won!" Harry looked around; there was Ginny running towards him; she had a hard blazing look on her face as she threw her arms around him. And without thinking, without planning, without worrying about the fact that fifty people were watching, Harry kissed her. After several long moments ‚Äî or it might have been half an hour ‚Äî or possibly several sunlit days ‚Äî they broke apart. The room had gone very quiet. Then several people wolf whistled and there was an outbreak of nervous giggling. Harry looked over the top of Ginny's head to see Dean Thomas holding a shattered glass in his hand and Romilda Vane looking as though she might throw something. Hermione was beaming, but Harry's eyes sought Ron. At last he found him, still clutching the cup and wearing an expression appropriate to having been clubbed over the head. For a fraction of a second they looked at each other, then Ron gave a tiny jerk of the head that Harry understood to mean, "well ‚Äî if you must." This is the culmination of both their journeys. Harry finally acts on his feelings and Ron, who would've been angry if this happened at the beginning, after everything he's gone through, gives Harry his approval. THATS how you do drama well. And here's where I talk about why its just a bad movie. Instead of following the wonderful example set by the book, the writers of the movie decided to rush the relationships, remove any inch of explanation of Ron's inner journey and just have him be a terrible person in general that the perfect Hermione forgives immediately, and completely butchers Ginny's character. Ginny is for some reason in the movie still a shy little girl with a crush on Harry not having ever developed since the second book. The relationship between Harry and Ginny is rushed, and has some of the most cringeworthy scenes in any movie. The shoelace scene for one or pretty much any interaction they have. Its unwatchable. They rush the journey to get there, and do nothing afterwards. Seriously, there's nothing between them getting together and the end of the movie. All the added stuff with McLaggen & Hermione was pointless and stupid. I was actually okay with the Lavender stuff because Ron & Lavender were supposed to be portrayed as toxic. But I think they over exaggerated some of the scenes. In addition, if you need any more evidence, the moviemakers hate Ron, they gave his two best moments to Hermione. When he gives Harry his approval, and when he tells him they're coming with him wherever he's going to find the Horcruxes. Other things I didnt like: Dumbledore's funeral was not as impactful as it should've been. They did do something creative but they failed to describe how much Dumbledore meant to Harry and what it meant for Harry and the Wizarding World now that he was gone. They also cut out the fantastic scene where Harry is forced to push Ginny away from getting close to him, but at that point, they buried ship that so far there wouldnt have been any point. But two things they should've definitely kept: One, The Battle of the Hogwarts. The first one to be specific. In the book, when Harry ran down the Astronomy tower, cursing Death Eaters after Dumbledores death, he ran into a massive battle between the Death Eaters and the combined forces of Dumbledores Army and the Order of the Phoenix. Every character has a role, and afterwards, all the threads of the magnificent conspiracy by Malfoy and the Death Eaters are revealed, brilliantly tying up every plot point in the book. The Battle would've been so cool to see. Instead... we get nothing except Bellatrix laughing maniacally (I do have to say though, Bellatrix's actress is freaking fantastic, she has so much fun in the role and plays the woman that enjoys being evil so well that I understand them adding her into scenes she wasn't originally in and have no complaints there). Additionally, I hated how Harry kind of liked the fame he got in this movie. That is quintessentially against Harry's character. He HATES being famous, he hates being swarmed by people wanting to get near him all the time. Thats why its so meaningful when he uses that on Slughorn. Thats the only time he ever uses fame to his advantage, and he did it so that his mothers sacrifice wasnt in vain. But in the movie, he kinda likes being famous. The biggest example of this is when Hermione is trying to protect him from people trying to slip him love potions and tells him "they only care about you know because you're the Chosen One." And Harry says "But I am the Chosen One." That too, very pompously. That isn't Harry, its James. Harry would never say that. The real Harry would've been annoyed that Hermione didnt do more to stop the potions from being snuck and Hermione would never have needed to tell him that Harry wouldve either said or thought that himself. Oh wait, hold on. That is what happened in the book. They also completely cut Tonks from the movie, which was kinda annoying. Finally, Sirius's death had practically no repercussions. In the book, Harry is heavily hit by Sirius's death and spends all summer alone and refusing to eat, barely talking to anyone. So much of the first act includes the impact of losing his godfather on Harry. But in the movie, its almost as if Sirius's death never happened. He was there and now he's not. This movie is a dumpster fire. I didnt like the Goblet of Fire movie but at least they did the Graveyard Scene, the most important part of the movie right. It was so well adapted and shot faithfully to the epicness of the original scene that it nearly made me forgive them for completely dropping the ball on the Barty Crouch twist and a lot of other parts of the movie. At least the Goblet of Fire got the characters right, and while I dont think they did a good job with the mystery at all and ruined one of the best twists in the series, they knew what to cut for the most part and didnt sideline the main plot of the book. This movie fails to meet the very low standard of that movie. It hits very few good beats, fails with 3/4 of the main plots of the book, treats the darkest chapter of the series like a complete romantic comedy, and inserts stupid scenes that were never in the book which were either out of character, cringeworthy, or unnecessary with no repercussions. However, there are a few redeeming factors. Firstly, the acting. But sadly, not even great acting can save a bad script. Secondly, the plot with Malfoy was very well done and easily the best part of the movie. Thirdly, the effects are fantastic. And finally, they at least did the cave scene well.

review: Genuine and well-staged darkness and visual spectacle can't make up for a baggy running time - the whole film could be 45 or so minutes shorter and sacrifice little in terms of plot or character. The love sub-plots feel like they get in the way; the first hour or so could be half that length; the rest of the film is only marginally less over-long. The strengths are real and effective, but it's hard not to think it could have been more so with more discipline.

review: I'd still recommend the Half-Blood Prince book over the movie. This used to be my least favorite in the movie franchise (until watching Chamber of Secrets again), but this movie has the most amount of problems out of them all. mojo_name: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
rt_name: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince - Movie Reviews

review: This is the best movie of the franchise. I don't have as much nostalgia for it as I do some of the others but it's inarguably the most complete movie of the lot, with absolutely perfect pacing (allusions toward the cabinet-related finale sprinkled in from near the very beginning), highly likeable new characters, a series-best level of comedy and a heavy focus on the three best side characters of the series with Snape & Dumbledore's parts expanded and Draco suddenly made at least 4x cooler than he was in the previous movies. Rickman, he of the dulcet intonations, is at his absolute peak with this one. They brought back Quidditch when it'd been sorely lacking from the previous two movies and they kept a healthy running time that allowed important scenes to breathe and be taken in by the audience. Most surprising of all was that the same man who'd put forth the worst film score of the franchise with HP5 returned and gave us a score that I felt was arguably on par or even superior to Williams's score for HP1; it was heavily bolstered by his use of Williams's themes, of course, but Hooper's felt more distinctive and it seemed to better match the atmosphere of each scene. My sole knock is that I wasn't quite as impressed by the cinematography as AMPAS was; I'm not a big fan of tinting an entire scene one color or the other and they do a ton of that here. This was otherwise absolutely perfect to me -- woohoo!

review: Years ago I watched the Harry Potter movies as they came out. I had read the books and thought my disappointment with the movies was because there'd just be no way for a movie to live up to the books. Now I'm in the process of reading the books to my own children. They also want to see the movies, and so I'm treating myself to another round of the Harry Potter series to get a better handle on they will be able to handle the visual re-imagining of the story. I realise I can now better summarise why I think the movies fail. Although in this instance I'm talking about the Half-Blood Prince, the main problem seems to more or less affect all the movies. The heart of the matter is poor adaptation and screenwriting. Instead of wholesome stories, the movies feel like quick visual summaries of events that take place in the books on fast-forward. The Half-Blood Prince rockets along from one location and key event to the next without providing the due context for what is taking place. It's as if the writers of the movie knew that people would fill in what was missing from their memory of the book ...but that's not how a movie is supposed to work! A movie is supposed be able to stand on its own. It really is an art form to be able to condense a large story into one and a half-hours or maybe two. At two hours and thirty minutes, this monster still somehow feels poorly paced and rushed. The movie is like a malnourished overweight person. Plenty of mass, but little substance. That's probably the best way to describe it. Should have been a TV-series. That way the story could have had some room to breathe.

As a kid I hated Shrek. But after seeing it for the first time a few years ago, I decided that I really liked Shrek. I had to go on a vacation soon after finishing the first movie, so right after coming back I proceeded to watch the next one. And I think it's probably because of the trip or something, but I actually liked Shrek 2 more. There are many reasons why I feel this one is clearly superior to the first one, and why this is my favourite sequel among any movie (other than Lord of the Rings and The Dark Knight trilogies of course). The movie begins with the part where Shrek 1 ended. Shrek and Fiona are happily married and live their ogre lives in peace. The reason why this movie works so well is because unlike regular sequels, this one actually expanded on what could happen in future. If this was a conventional sequel it would have shown that Lord Farquaad has come back somehow and now he has joined forces with some other villain to beat them. Also some random characters would have been introduced while others would have been killed. The movie simply begins with the feeling of an adventure. Shrek, Donkey and Fiona going to Far, Far Away to meet Fiona's parents who have never seen her in the last 20 years, that's a perfect story. Remember how we thought about Shrek and Fiona before the first movie? We changed our minds for the better after we watched the movie and learnt a lesson. Fiona's parents, however, have still not seen that happen. And this is something Fairy Godmother and Prince Charming take the advantage of. The reason why this movie worked but the next two didn't was because this movie never dragged any concept. Shrek and the fairy tale characters became friends, Shrek and Donkey saved Fiona, they fell in love and married. Period. This was never 'revised' upon. Rather either the consequences of those actions or the other aspects of life were shown. Every scene looked interesting for some reason. It's almost like the creators poured all their love in every scene. No scene feels like they were just trying to get over it. Every moment is cherished: Fiona crying, Shrek meeting Puss, Shrek's friends watching TV - everything is memorable. Shrek 2 is how a sequel should be. It should give us exactly what we wish to know. It does not force any character, it does not force any scene. Everything that is introduced in this movie, every joke that takes place happens within the audience's interest. I really wish if a new Shrek movie is made, they make it like this. Shrek is meant to be something that is remembered for all time, not a meme. It's one of the most iconic 3D animated movies I've ever seen.
Fairy Godmother's rendition of "Holding out for a Hero" is a cinematic masterpiece that gives me an unparalleled level of serotonin.
A brilliant film and a perfect sequel, I can't say much else than go watch it

Lesson. Story. Action scenes. Emotion Climax. Drama. High stakes. and so on. In short this movie is everything you can ask for and more, and that is without mentioning the perfect "Holding Out For A Hero" scene. On an objective Dreamworks ranking, this would be number 2 (Behind "The Prince Of Egypt").

The story of Freddie Mercury is a tragic and hard-edged story about a immigrant gay man who did drugs and died of AIDS. The way this movie tells this story comes off as hollow and sanitised, there is so much inaccurate stuff in this movie like the fact that Queen broke up as a band because they were upset that Freddie Mercury got a deal for a solo album which upsets the band in the movie which never happened in real life because Roger Taylor released a solo album in the late 70s early 80s and in the movie Freddie Mercury tells the band he has AIDS a week before Live Aid in 1985 although he wasn't diagnosed until 1987. This is not the worst movie I have ever seen in my life but it's not exactly the greatest either

An enjoyable film but one that never feels like it truly knows what it wants to be. Is it trying to make us marvel at the creative talents of Mercury, or feel unsettled and sad at his elusive, lonely personal life? Are we supposed to feel sympathy with the band who need to comply with his antics? Or take inspiration for how energised and on-board they are with his creative direction? The film flirts with the underlying tragedy of his private life and the illness that inevitably claims his life, but keeps it at arm's length to prevent the audience from getting sad when there's rock music to enjoy. So it's a good film but not an excellent one. Rami Malek is astonishing though, without question.

It isn't terrible, I guess. I like Queen's music. Why does this movie have auto tune and lip syncing over the original recordings and not new recordings by Rami Malek unlike Taron Edgerton in Rocketman. I think it is really funny that the members of Queen get mad because they have to lip sync on tv but then they lip synced all the singing in this movie. The editing in this movie is terrible. How did this movie win an Oscar for best editing? I do not understand. They always say that Freddie is drunk or high but they never show him getting drunk or high, unlike Rocketman. The best way to describe it is that this movie is very sanitized and safe. The movie doesn't go into the real side of Freddie at all. The movie is also not factually accurate. Freddie got diagnosed with AIDS in 1987 but in the movie he gets diagnosed before the Live Aid concert which was in 1985. Rami Malek's performance is pretty good though. I liked the lawyer/manager character. The music is great but that has nothing to do with this movie. I do really like the Live Aid scenes though. The Live Aid scenes are definitely the best part of the movie hands down. I just find the Live Aid concert really cool and fascinating. I also believe Live Aid was probably the best concert ever. The story, being a true story is pretty interesting so I liked the story told in the movie. In conclusion, John Reid is a terrible person, lip syncing is bad, this movie is disappointing and mediocre but not the worst movie ever by any means and Rocketman is way better. I will say Rocketman is so much better, it's not even a competition. Bohemian Rhapsody wishes it was even near as good as Rocketman.

sin duda esta pel√≠cula logra un magnifico documental de la vida de Freddie Mercury. lo que mas resalta de esta pel√≠cula es la magnifica interpretaci√≥n de Rami Malek, quien en varios puntos de la trama te hace sentir como si fuera un documental actuado por Freddie Mercury. tambi√©n lo que cabe mencionar de esta pel√≠cula es el gran elenco que tiene. todos hacen una actuaci√≥n magnifica que te hacen sentir que es una pel√≠cula hecha con los propios personajes a lo que interpretan, y a mi gusto muy pocas pel√≠culas logran eso. si tengo que decir algo que no me gusto son los hoyos en la trama de la misma que te hacen sentir de que te estas perdiendo de algo. pero les tengo que aplaudir en hacer una pel√≠cula para los fans de la banda y no en un p√∫blico en general, que ah√≠ es donde se estancan muchas de las cintas de la misma trama que esta.

Perhaps it was necessary to deepen more about the problems that Freddie Mercury went through with his addictions and sexual issues that led to his death, but Bohemian Rhapsody is still a great and exciting biographical film that, we must admit, was directed more for the audience and that is why it was a box office success but the criticism was not so positive (although it deserves to be fresh). Compare it with Rocketman and you will see the difference between one with the other, but that Oscar for Rami Malek cannot be taken away by anyone.

Good, but not great. A bit disappointed with the way it ended, leaving out the last five years before Mercury's death in 1991. Scene with "Who Wants to Live Forever" is haunting, and the re-creation of Live Aid is superb.

A biopic is a film meant to dramatize a non-functional person's life. Some creative license is used to provide exposition. Maybe some scenes are created to move the story along. This is not a biopic. Most of the movie is simply invented by the writers and director. For example, Freddie didn't meet the other band members behind a van after their show; they were already roommates. There was no backlash against the Bohemian Rhapsody song; everyone loved it at the start. The band wasn't inspired to perform at Live Aid by Freddie's courage in the face of AIDS; he wasn't diagnosed with that until two years after that show. The movie at all times is heading towards that Live Aid performance, which was recreated shot for shot with the original footage. This begs the question: why recreate what Queen did in 1985 with actors when you literally have the original footage?

The effects are top tier adding to a rich aesthetic of well crafted production and art direction that makes you feel like you are in that universe. The technical MVP goes to Howard Shore and his iconic score.

review: [‚≠êÔ∏è97%] When the genre fantasy is mentioned, The Lord of the Rings is the first thought that comes to many peoples minds as it captures all the desired qualities required to be considered in that genre. The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) starts off the viewers experience with this trilogy in an absolutely outstanding way, leading from place to place, introducing things for the first time to the viewer along with the characters and never once failing to entertain. The reason for The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) being so engaging is that it follows such an engaging story with well developed characters, who all get their individual moments or in a group dynamic. Despite this films (and it's sequels) famous lengthy-runtime, it isn't felt compared to other movies as they provide a reason for using such length in executing engaging dialogue and a well thought-out story.

review: This is my favorite movie of the series by quite a wide margin. They did an impeccable job introducing audiences to the source material and inserting enough climactic events in the second and third acts that it didn't feel like a stretched-out origin story at any moment. Every pleasing visual & musical detail was at its freshest, there are not so many jarring uses of deus ex machina and Frodo hasn't yet been reduced to a worthless obstacle that Sam must overcome. The entire trilogy is awesome as a whole, but this section of it shines brighter than the rest for me.

review: Peter jackson is one of the best directors in terms of good budget use, the director probably learned that in his early career directing great trahs movies, and in "The Lord of the Rings" it's no different, peter makes a film of almost 4 hours grand, with impeccable costumes and makeup, great visual effects for the time and a wide range of magnificent backdrops and screen compositions, by comparison, the same year also came out Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone which cost 38 million more, although "The Lord of the Rings" seems much more expensive. I didn't read the classic JRR Tolkien book to know how it was transposed to the screen, but even with a long film time, we have zero waste, we have a story that constantly grows, full of arcs and a past that transports mythology, all of this combined with a classic and very well constructed hero arc that unfolds in a great intro drama, the film has four acts and a short last act that already leaves a plot for the sequel. The entire art direction of the film is exquisite, the feature film, which is already over 20 years old, leaves some special effects dated, it's true, but at the time it was very surprising and still convinces today, especially in its costumes and makeup, which are still great today. , photography and the use of the green background still work reasonably well, and the soundtrack is a show on its own, showing the inner emotion of each nucleus through its melodies. Peter Jackson works well not only the visual and script factor, but also works the small layers, such as obsession, fear and overcoming, and also knew how to squeeze the most out of his cast of actors, taking magnificent performances, such as de Ian McKellen for example. The film is very well worked in its most diverse layers, every shot is very well executed and formidable, the weakest point perhaps is the lack of coherence, violence and the sobriety tone of the work, which changes its state of mind constantly, but these are details that do not bother this work at all, which amuses, entertains and enchants to this day. GRADE 8.5/10

Hasn't that already happened I hear you ask. Well, yes, and here's the proof; Peter Jackson's first instalment of his staggering trilogy, and arguably the best of the three (although my opinion on that changes daily). So, why not ignore what's happening in New Zealand at the moment, whether the results are good or not, and just enjoy Jackson's mind boggling achievement from the start.

review: Well... I'm afraid that this movie is by far the most disappointing film that I've ever sat down to watch. I came in with the greatest of expectations, as I've seen countless amazing reviews, articles, and even been directly told of the praise that this movie "deserves". How it's "better than the book", "truly riveting", "the greatest action movie to date", and so on. However, I simply cannot agree with any of those claims. I think Peter cheapened much of the story, even beyond that of what's expected from compressing 423 pages down to 178 minutes worth of film *I watched the theatrical version*. Since this review is already getting very long I'm going to list out the changes that Peter made that I think were for the worse. -Merry was re-written to become a Pippin part 2, which is especially terrible since in the original story they were quite different. Merry starts out responsible and leader-like then has to deal with feelings of loneliness and usefulness. While Pippin starts out naive and mistake-ridden then learns to become responsible and valiant. -Elrond and Galadriel are very dislikeable. I could smell their superiority complex through my screen. -Gandalfs already 'not perfectly' written pre-fellowship journey becomes even worse. Like why go to Saruman before safely escorting the Hobbit to Rivendell? Why not go help the Hobbit directly after getting to Rivendell? What happened to the letter? -Aragorn and Gandalfs relationship is too mysterious. You don't see them interact with each other much, Gandalfs speaks of no importance with Aragon, and all that makes Aragorn's presence at the prancing pony even more convenient. Furthermore, why weren't the Hobbits more suspicious of him when they met? -Nazgul nerfed? Why was Aragorn able to solo 5 of the Nazgul with nothing but a sword and torch? In the book, they quickly fled because they thought that Frodo had no chance at surviving the wound, but in the movie, they stayed to fight with Aragorn for a bit before getting chased out because Aragorn was destroying them. -The Gandalf v Saruman fight was maybe the worst fight scene I've ever seen from such a big movie. Force pushing each other around with sticks, how exciting. -Elves were just cringy, with the blurring filter and ugly language, it was just too much. -Legolas, Gimli, and Boromir were less explained. In the books Legolas comes to tell about Golums escape, Gimli comes to discuss Saurons offer to the Dwarves on the lonely mountain, and Boromir comes to find counsel on his and Faramir's dreams. But in the movie, they are just there because they are important figures in their kingdoms. Although I have plenty of gripes with the movie I think it still did a fine job. I thought the production quality was outstanding, even for 2021's standards. I also like that Arwen became more prevalent in the story, although her being the one sent to help Aragorn and the Hobbits makes no sense but exploring her and Aragorn's relationship early on was a definite plus to the story. So overall I don't think it's bad but it stacks nowhere near the original story and I can't believe that anyone can say otherwise, but I seem to be in the minority so maybe I'm just wrong.

review: There are a lot of neat concepts on display in this movie, and as such, it's a real shame that more aren't done with them. This movie is 157 minutes long, and only the last 10 minutes actually amounted to anything. The rest of it is a self-contained story that has very little in the ways of actual plot, and the big reveal at the end ultimately negates half of what came before, as it turns out that a good chunk of it was a ruse (but not in the ultra-satisfying way as something like Hot Fuzz or the first Saw). Throw in the fact that the movie is also darker and murkier than the other entries, before and since, and the very mediocre performance by Robert Pattinson (already one of the most over-valued people in the industry). The mystery element involving David Tennant's character, Harry Crouch Junior, is really the only thing of real interest beyond the end, but it never actually amounts to anything either, as the audience already knows that he's evil, and once he's found out, his story ends literally seconds later.. All in all, the movie isn't 'bad' by any means - it's just almost entirely meaningless in the grand scheme of things, and honestly, it's just self-indulgence that this movie was a solid hour longer than it needed to be.

review: Imperio‚Ä¶ Crucio‚Ä¶ Avada Kadavra‚Ä¶ now time to go to Azkaban. So there's more than one wizard school. The plot is about the Triwizard tournament, where each school's representative battled for the glory. But somehow Potter was chosen as the fourth contestant, and we have ourselves a fun and intense story. I was surprised and happy that I wasn't bored through another two and a half hours of this franchise. This is the first one that kept my interest throughout. Again, there were more unique wizard stuff that further expanded the universe. This was always fun to watch, and this movie still kept that tradition going. The first half actually was teen drama where the students went to a ball. The romance was more prominent, and even became naughty in some scenes. What drove the plot was the tournament, and the looming danger that hid beneath it throughout the runtime. When the imminent doom hit at around the last round of the tournament, the movie became vastly more intense. For the first time, I felt that Harry's life was in actual danger. As for problems, the runtime was still a tad bit long. Also, some of the rounds in the tournament were pretty weak an could have been more fun. Overall, this movie is where the main story actually starts. 9/10

review: Newell did more things right here than Cuaron did with the third movie and it's not even close. He makes the most out of the lengthy runtime here by excising a lot of the subplots in the novel in an extremely successful way as it allowed more time to be spent on the climactic finale than had been allotted in any of the previous 3 movies. There was more interaction between the characters and a highly appreciable increase in comedy. The actors had grown up quite a lot and were doing better in each iteration at showing their acting range, with Hermione a particular highlight in this one. Doyle acquitted himself remarkably well, with his film score on par with Williams's previous three and the CGI had improved drastically even with only a year's time passing. Best of all was the source material itself as the underdog sports genre is probably my #1 favorite and the finale here is probably the best in the entire series, both the graveyard part and the quasi-epilogue reveal. I think Cuaron misunderstood the intended audience for these as his priorities seemed rooted solely in quality filmmaking instead of entertaining a mostly-teenaged audience, a concept Newell is apparently an expert at. The only criticism I have is that I think they could've found a few minutes to devote to the Quidditch World Cup instead of skipping the entire thing as that was one of the best chapters in the book!

review: The non-so magical review from a muggle. Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is a fantasy/adventure film directed by Mike Newell. It is based on J.K.Rowling's novel which was written in 2000 and carries the same name as the novel. It was released on November 23, 2005. It is as well the fourth part in the Harry Potter film series. Last Christmas, I saw this film and it was definitely one to remember. Just like past Harry Potter films this one didn't fail to amuse me. You could tell that this was filmed on a big-budget compared to the previous films of the series. To my mind I think this one offers a lot more than fantasy or adventure, it also gives you a lot of headspace to imagination. This piece of art surely left me astonished and filled with questions, wanting to watch the next part. As for the plot of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, it includes the three main characters to be grown up, as they enter their fourth year of the School of Wizardry and Witchcraft: Hogwarts. It holds a fair amount of violence, since Harry Potter, the main character has to enter the prestigious Triwizard Tournament as a minor and face some dreadful challenges along the way of becoming a champion. Throughout the film, new characters came to light. Some added a romantic aspect to the film, whereas others did not. For the 14-year-old Harry Potter, he endures pressure a normal teenager cannot handle to confront his biggest nightmare. With the help of his dearest friends, Hermione and Ron, he doesn't fail to succeed in the period of the tournament. After all, this is the year students prepare for the Yule Ball and dare to ask female students as their date to the ball. Yet, the charming part of the film quickly ends there, as Harry Potter will live up to his title as ‚ÄòThe Boy Who Lived'. The Harry Potter series is known to leave every person astounded who is into fiction and/or fantasy. As for me, it was always a surprising experience watching through these films, as you notice the characters growing up from a young child to an adult. There is no doubt that J.K. Rowling is by far one of the most influential writers in our century. Not only, did she write several successful books but stands as a role model for young children and women. With the apparent cliffhanger at the end of the first film, it will leave you wanting more and you will end up watching the next films that follows up on the previous one. Personally, I am a lover of anything fictional, which is obvious why I am a fan of Harry Potter. Behind the success of these series, I suppose that watchers admire the films as they are not predicable as much as you think it would be. For instance, in this film, it gets quite dark quickly once you watch Harry get involved into life-or-death situations. Another example, is that Harry experiences tons of emotions in this film. As he goes through happy moments with his friends, he goes through the same amount of unknown moments and feelings. However, I must say that this is perhaps the most significant Harry Potter film so far. Mainly because, while I was watching this part of the series it felt like a mix of genres. Also, another example to why this film doesn't have a sole boring moment since it will keep introducing new characters throughout. For the Triwizard Tournament I mentioned earlier, there will be a ton of new, yet interesting characters added who bring a value to these films, which also was an enjoyable aspect. Lastly, this film was not excessively long but definitely long enough to tell the story. But there is one negative detail, that the films don't fully cover every single detail like the books do. So if you want to have a full understanding experience, I suggest you to also read the books so that you don't miss out on other details. Clearly, this masterpiece will be a hard one to forget, as it will stick to you for a longer time. It is not something that you will be able to forget soon, as it so famous. I would recommend this film to anyone who might be interest in fantasy and fictional characters. Furthermore, it is important to watch them in chronological order, since every film leaves a cliffhanger at the end which follows up on the next one. Lastly, I hope you get lost into the imagination of the magical world of Harry Potter, just like I did.

review: Summary: This movie marks an important cornerstone in the development of the Harry Potter universe with the return of the Dark Lord Voldemort. It is set in Hogwarts during the fourth year of school, when the Triwizard Tournament takes place. It is a traditionally a competition between the three prominent schools of magic including Hogwarts, Durmstrang and Beauxbatons. Prior to the competition, the Goblet of Fire selects three students from each school to participate in the contest. Harry is unexpectedly selected and forced to enter the competition by the Goblet of Fire with three other students even though he never put his in the cup and he is also underage. Later, it is found out that one of the Voldemort's underlings cast an advanced spell on the Goblet to deceive it of Harry's age. During the first three rounds of the contest, Harry and the other students have to complete many difficult tasks such as rescuing underwater and fighting dragons. The climax of this movie comes when the four students compete to get out of the maze, the last round of the contest. However, Voldemort, still in his feeble from between dead and alive, and his underlings are in there waiting for the four, eventually killing Cedric from Hogwarts. Harry, after that, is capture, and his blood extracted and used to rebuild Voldemort into a strong physical form. Harry then duels against the Dark Lord for his life. He barely escapes Voldemort and eventually brings Cedric's body back to campus with the knowledge that Voldemort has returned. Analysis: The important turn of events in this movie heralds major change development of the storyline and the journey of Harry Potter as the main hero in this series. Harry is now no longer inherently safe from Voldemort like before when Harry's blood was has the magic against the Dark Lord. Now, both share the same blood as he used his Voldemort used Harry's blood to revive himself. Harry no longer is protected and now susceptible. He is now more representative of real-life heroes, who actually have vulnerabilities, not inherently indestructible by enemies as Harry used to be earlier in the series. This sharing of blood between Harry and Voldemort is also symbolistic of the struggles that real-life heroes have. It is like a connection across the dichotomy of good and evil, signaling the heroes also have their own evil side that they struggle against. Furthermore, when Harry's friend Ron turns against him, it further depicts Harry as a misunderstood hero. Ron estranged himself from Harry because Ron thinks that Harry intentionally enters himself into the contest for fame. However, later in the movie, Ron actually helps Harry to get through one of the dangerous rounds of the contest where the four students had to compete underwater. Ron's actions actually saved Harry's life. This part of the stories highlights the resilience of true friendship. No matter how significant the misunderstanding is, true friends will still help each other when in need and resolve the problem between them. Then when the four enter the last round of the tournament, the maze, Cedric encounters a minion of Voldemort, he is murdered by the killing curse. Then, Harry is captured by the other underlings of Voldemort. His arm is cut, and his blood collected to revive Voldemort. Harry has to duel against him for his life. He almost loses against the newly rejuvenated and strengthened Dark Lord. However, the souls of Harry's loved ones who were murdered by Voldemort appear from Voldemort's wand and give Harry's time to get to the Portkey to escape the maze. This scene demonstrates the theme of love's triumph over hate and evil. Critique: I love this movie and the whole Harry Potter series as a whole. There are, nonetheless, certain details that I think can be improved upon. The first one is rather a minor detail. It is when Dumbledore finds out the Goblet of Fire has chosen Harry as the fourth selectee to enter the tournament. The book says that Dumbledore ‚Äòcalmly' asks Harry if he actually put his name into the Goblet. However, the corresponding scene in the movie portraits Dumbledore's asking as aggressive and intimidating when he grabs Harry's arms and shakes them while questioning him. This minor detail, although does not affect the structural integrity of the storyline, somehow momentarily breaks the usual portrayal of Dumbledore as a gathered and calm man without serving any significant purpose. The second detail is when Harry is forced to enter the Tournament. J.K Rowling here could have better explained why it is that way, because the audience may have questions such as the following: Why is an underage forced to enter such a perilous contest even when he does not want to? Or Why can't/doesn't the administration do anything to keep Harry from the having to enter? Explanations to these questions can further strengthen the integral structure of the storyline. Overall, despite these small details that may be improved, I still give the movie 5 out of 5 stars.

The worst movie out of the trilogy, but really over hated. The reasons why people hate this movie is understandable, Peter Parker seems to have regressed on his love life which was developed and was seemed to be great as how the second movie ended, but in this film Peter Parker makes some decisions that make him a bad person when it comes to love and makes Mary Jane Watson feel not feel appreciated. Mary Jane Watson story is really not that good in this film they make her really dependent of a guy which in the comics, video-games, and TV shows/cartoons Mary Jane has always been an independent woman that takes care of herself most of the time. Villain wise this movie is also mid, out of the 3 villains, we only had one going into detail of why he was bad and why he took some decisions that made him a villain but only one had great character development and that was Sandman, for the other villain (New Green Goblin) we have had a background story of why he became a villain since the first film but to be fair they did do a good gob towards the end when it comes to that character. The main villain and the worst one is Venom, man came out of nowhere and managed to get into Peter Parker's apartment so easily without him realizing. Venom was a rushed character in this film, no background, man just landed on Earth from space and he only turned Peter Parker more into an anti-hero when Peter was his host but no interactions between Peter and Venom, also something to add, Venom turned into a suit which Peter easily took off and when Peter realized what was happening to him with Venom he struggles to take off his suit, makes no sense to me unless Venom realized Peter wanted him away so he just tried to stay with him. Once Venom reached Eddie Brook, it was more comic accurate but still a wasted villain nothing compared to the new Venom movies we have today. This movie is enjoyable but it is average at best compared to the other films.

A massive disappointment compared to the classic first two, "Spiderman 3" has a much shakier and convoluted story that tries to cram too much into its short runtime. The action is still pleasant, though the CGI somehow feels worse than the previous films. The villains are still good and memorable, though there are just too many to give any of them their time to shine. The direction that this film heads in is also very confusing, rewriting some important plot points and actions of the previous two films. Maguire, Dunst, and Franco are still very well in this movie though, and the acting of the villains is also on point. There are also a number of entertaining sequences, though most get overshadowed by the large amount of cringey and unnecessarily bad moments that make no sense. Overall, just a bad film that fails to conclude the ending that the previous installments deserved.

The trilogy ends on a confusing note. It's a really hard film to follow, there is so many stories here and all of them seems underdeveloped. The characters development which was what I preferred in the first two movies, doesn't feel relatable anymore outside few moments (most of the time during the scenes with Aunt Jay, the voice of reason). The big point of the movie was adapting the Venom arc, and the movie fails in every way. Venom feels very secondary, I would even say that if you remove everything about him the movie would be as "coherent" that it is. I know it's "iconic" now in a too bad is good kind of way, but for me the Peter Parker/Venom scenes was a secondhand embarrassment. I felt bad for the characters and I even felt bad for Tobey Maguire having to play these scenes. It's simply cringe. The special effects sometimes feel too ambitious for the time, they go overboard with the action scenes giving you tense moment but very noticeable green screens or CGI. It was a time where we qualify action movies as CGI messes and Spider-man 3 is the perfect example. The end is a little too cheesy and too easy.
Not a great movie. Tried to force too many villians in, or it would have been good.

I don't think there is a person out there that believes this is the best film in the trilogy. While it turns Spider-Man in a direction that I don't particularly like, I still find that this film shows some of the charm of the first two. I can tell this film was made with care and love, but I can also tell that the studio got their hands on it and turned, what I'm sure was a great plan from Sam Raimi, into a mess of too many villains and plots. I would have love to have seen a movie with Just Harry as the Green Goblin or Just the Sandman. I don't like the inclusion of Venom in the slightest, to me, Toby's Spider-Man is supposed to be a great lighthearted guy, the ultimate nice/good guy, and I loved that. But, the symbiote turns Toby into a dark individual that I don't think fits the series. For example, The Spider-Man from the 90's animated series was a great Spider-Man to use the symbiote with. While he was a great guy, and one of my favorite Spider-Men ever, he wasn't the ultimate nice guy that Toby's Spider-Man was on the big screen. They used the symbiote much earlier in his arc, season 1 of a 5 season show, at a time when he was still arrogant and immature, as opposed to a Spider-Man who had already progressed through 2 films. The version of Spider-Man in the animated series was much more self-centered and was a much better match for the symbiote. Overall, I like this movie, but I don't like Peter for some of it, and a can't help to think what could have been.

Talk about throwing in the kitchen sink... The third instalment of Sam Raimi's Spider-Man films really misses the mark. He tried to outshine himself by making everything bigger, louder, funnier and with more action... with disastrous effect. The story is laughably bad with way too many plot-points, the villains are over the top and the cheese just comes across as slapstick. Sometimes subtlety is better.

Movies aren't about having the perfect plot, it's about the fun, the experience, and the happiness you have watching it. It may not be A+ good like Spider-Man 1 and 2, but it is the perfect ending to one of the best superhero trilogies.

Honestly this movie isn't nearly as terrible as a lot of people claim - it's just a movie where the desires of the talented filmmakers were overridden by those of an executive. Primarily, Sam Raimi, the brilliant filmmaker who made the first two (in addition to the wonderful Evil Dead trilogy) did not want to make a Venom movie, as he considered Venom a boring villain, but the studio forced his hand to do it anyway. And as such, this is a movie made by instruction, made be a director that made the preceding entries out of passion. Combine this with some numerous production complications and self-proclaimed genius Danny Elfman refusing to write the music because he felt Raimi didn't appreciate his unbridled genius, and you've got a movie with massive, massive problems just due to happenstance. And it's actually rather sad, as much about the movie actually works very well -- The climax is hugely entertaining and ends with a moment of resolve, rather than defeat, the way Peter finally stands against Harry are actually quite cathartic, and the new Composer's musical score is much better than the forgettable-at-best fluff that we got from the previous two movies (as let's be real - the wonderful main theme was the only piece of music from the first two movies worth listening to). There's some efficient (yet widely misunderstood) comedy bits in this movie, and it is interesting to see not only Parker himself becoming increasingly violent, but one of the main villains increasingly, of his own accord, becomes a more and more volatile person, making him a good villain. If you loved the first two I'd ultimately recommend this one - the only real reason I hesitate is that there are some depressing "my dreams never came true" beats that come up during the story, but so long as you acknowledge that it's not nearly as good.

To be honest, surprisingly, Spider-Man 3 is my favourite from Tobey Maguire's trilogy. Tobey Maguire is still a bad actor, he and Kirsten Dunst still don't have romantic chemistry, but she improved as an actress. Despite the cast (the only good actors are Rosemary Harris, JK Simmons and James Franco), the villains are good. There is more action in this movie than in the other two combined, and I loved it because Peter Parker's arc was something I always felt bored watching. And this film is more than an emo Peter Parker. This emo Peter makes sense, I finally managed to have empathy for the protagonist, and the conclusion is perfect and touching. I ended the film proud of Peter. Finally, if I said the first film isn't that good, and the second one is good but overrated, this third one is underrated and deserves more than a "cult" status.

The final installment in Sam Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy in which Peter Parker bonds with an extraterrestrial symbiote that increases his abilities but brings out his anger and other negative traits. He also has to deal with Sandman, New Goblin and Eddie Brock and maintain a fragmented relationship with Mary Jane. Undeniably, the film is overstuffed with villains and plotlines that make it a bit too much. The fights and action sequences are very entertaining and well executed, though. Some scenes and dialogues are so cringeworthy that it pales in comparison to the first two.

At the onset of his third big-picture treatment, we find young Peter Parker in an unfamiliar predicament: he's genuinely happy! Almost annoyingly so, in fact. Even his longtime love interest, Mary Jane Watson, seems to think he's laying it on too thick and tries to tell him as much in a series of awkward, abbreviated conversations between crime-fighting bouts. Parker pays no mind, of course, produces a string of awful motivational speeches when she needs emotional support and swiftly swings himself straight back onto the singles scene. Well, that didn't take long. Now Spidey is sad again! Just in time to tangle with three(!) competing super-villains, a rival in the workplace and a major league identity crisis. Not unlike its predecessors, Spider-Man 3 has way too much going on, a problem that's ballooned with each subsequent installment. The first two films manage to succeed in spite of this weakness, persevering with a great shared cast, strong character moments and well-earned payoffs. In those films, Pete's best pal Harry Osborn slowly works his way through a patient, simmering villainous turn. Here, he's abruptly hot-shotted in the opening action scene, carelessly reset and cast aside until the finale. Venom is birthed and dispensed in less than an act. Sandman's arc has enough emotional heft to single-handedly carry the counter narrative, but he always feels like a third wheel. Gwen Stacey pops in and out of the frame at random. There's just no room for these subplots to breathe amidst all the frantic competition, the race to grab every last thread and hurriedly weave them into something loosely resembling a story. Maybe with a touch of nuance and panache, a skilled director could have worked a little magic and turned this troubled script into an acceptable early-period superhero flick. Sam Raimi is anything but a nuanced director. At best, he's capable but limited, habitually caught in the act of winking at his own shortcomings in uniquely entertaining ways. No wonder he's best regarded for his gleefully deranged horror movies, where over-stressed people behave irrationally (and a little comically) in high-pressure situations. Under ideal circumstances, he can incorporate his eccentricities into the fabric of a film without negatively affecting its story, but not with so many other jobs on his plate. I'm not sure if the hammy over-acting is his fault or the stars', but I tend to lean toward the former because it's so hopelessly widespread. Nothing feels natural in this film, from the janky dialogue and clumsy delivery to the rushed primary character arc and dated special effects. I can still remember how this felt in the theater, bad enough that I avoided revisiting it for nearly fifteen years, and it hasn't improved with time. I can see bits and pieces of promise dotted here and there, hints that the overachieving Spider-Man 2 wasn't just a fluke, but they're drowned by the hurry to expand an already-crowded universe and get everything back to an unconvincing status quo in time for the closing credits. Disastrously inept.

In many ways, Spider-Man 3 is structurally the same as its two predecessors: Peter starts out the movie as Spider-Man and the villains, who aren't inherently villains, become so as the movie progresses. The biggest difference this time is that there are two villains rather than one and Peter plays a big part in why the villains are fighting him. In many ways, this same structure works to the film's benefit and gives us some interesting characters and nice action sequences. It's another example of if a system isn't broken, don't fix it. SM 3 also adds a lot of depth to Peter's relationships with those around him, which becomes especially important as Peter changes throughout the film in pretty drastic ways that have big consequences for him. SM 3 is a movie that exemplifies that concept that you can be your own worst enemy. The acting is pretty good overall, although there is a casting choice that to this day I'm not a big fan of. The effects in the movie have slightly raised the bar from the previous films, making this a slight improvement from SM and SM 2. All that said, SM 3 is a bit of a letdown and isn't as good as the other two. Many scenes lack the directorial and written finesse than they had in the first two which causes some scenes to feel really awkward and a bit disruptive to the flow of the film. The dialogue is a bit cheesy at times and there are some scenes that don't make a lot of sense. Sandman and Venom are decent villains but they aren't quite as good as Green Goblin and Doc Ock were, which is partially because they come from different plotlines so there isn't as much time to develop their characters as there would optimally be. One of the biggest issues of SM 3 is exactly that: there are a bunch of storylines going on at once so the movie doesn't have a clear and direct focus for a lot of its runtime, so certain things don't get the development they deserve. The film balances all these stories as well as it can and overall does a decent job, but there are things that could've been explored a bit more. The ending has an emotional punch to it to nicely caps off the trilogy and should leave viewers satisfied enough as the credits roll. SM 3 is undoubtedly a letdown from its two predecessors but is a decent enough movie to be watchable and enjoyable at times.

review: DOTD was when the series started to kinda-sorta slip out of its original brand, most of the movie is awesome, just like the last two, the saviors are raunchy humor and innuendo in a lot of cases, but again it's varied enough that adults AND kids can like it. This movie though you can start to smell it on the wind. It's entertaining for adults too, but it's just a little... more kid leaning, subtly, you won't realize it for a bit, but it's there. Ice Age would've been better off retaining its adult-oriented story devices, and the addition of legitimate death in the first one actually dramatically improved the series' quality while it was happening, you need some darkness to make things really acceptional in today's market.

review: B.O.R.I.N.G No Time To Die was a far better finale. SPECTRE is a one and done Bond movie. Its good to see it once to understand parts of No Time To Dies plots, but it has practically no replay value after that. I recommend Casino Royale, Skyfall and No Time To Die when it comes to a typical binge on the Daniel Craig Bond movies and recommend Quantum Of Solace and SPECTRE just once. Casino Royale, Skyfall and No Time To Die have good storylines and great action scenes that work in tandem with the storyline and Daniel Craig was at his best in all 3 of them.
You know its not the best bond movie, but it'll pass the time and is worth seeing, thanks to the action sequences and Daniel Craig's performance as Bond, James Bond

So overall I like the movie but it could have been so much better. I just think they try to tie things in way too much with this. Does Blofeld really have to be Bond's stepbrother as well as the villain behind everything in the other Craig movies? I just wish they didn't try to have it all part of one giant plot and I appreciate with Bond has one off villains. And Waltz is underutilized in this movie.

Spectre is an entertaining and overlong spy thriller. Although it fails to reach the heights of Casino Royal or Skyfall- Spectre is a watchable, and often quite fun Bond movie. The action is great, cinematography is beautiful, performances are generally good, but the writing is fairly sloppy. Trying to have Blofeld become the one behind all of Bond's previous troubles is clearly retconning- and doesn't work great. Having Blofeld be Bond's jealous step-brother is just plain stupid- how would Bond not recognize someone he grew up with? The pacing is also a big problem. The opening is great with an amazing tracking shot followed by great action. In the middle act things slow down considerably, and the story isn't engaging enough to warrant it. Then the final act tries to squeeze in too much, and despite some great action it is jarring the way things jump from one event to the next so abruptly. It waits until the last 40 minutes to finally reveal the villain and have him interact with Bond- then we get an extended monologue, torture scene, and escape scene within a less than 20 minutes or less. The way Bond goes from having his brain scrambled to moments later being a deadeye shot, blowing up the entire base and escaping- is just silly and shows how carelessly some of the sequences were put together. There are a handful of other times where the logic just doesn't add up. Walken delivers a very hammy performance as Blofeld, a totally cartoonish villain when compared against previous Craig- Bond villains. All that said- this is a Bond movie with lots of style, great action, exotic locals, beautiful women, wonderful camera work, and a solid central performance by Craig (who is easily my favorite Bond).
Awesome movie. Only thing would be the relationship with Madeleine. Not as credible but overall one of the best of the series!

While not nearly as good as the other installments, "Spectre" still serves as an enjoyable enough Bond film, with an underused villain that had so much potential behind him and a story that takes us back to the more goofy Bond films. "Spectre" was still a letdown compared to "Skyfall," though it was still fun to watch.

Spectre is another entertaining and engaging Craig outing, even if a slight step back from Skyfall. Watch it for Waltz, he's as masterful as ever. We're glad Craig opted to avoid any ghosts and do one more.

Ah yes, the one that thinks it's Captain America: The Winter Soldier, but is actually Austin Powers in Goldmember. This is definitely a goofy Bond movie masquerading as serious one. I actually watched this twice in the theatres when it came out. That's how much I loved it at the time. I now know I was forcing myself to accept the glaring awful writing. I never particularly liked the writing even back then, but justified liking it for other aspects like directing, cinematography, musical score, action set pieces, and having the best costume design in the series. That last one I still believe. Just like how the jarring editing in tandem with poor blocking weighs the overall quality of Quantum of Solace down, so too does the writing of Spectre. Skyfall had some ridiculous plot holes as well but there were other aspects of the writing keeping it from being a totally trash script unlike this one. Thomas Newman's score is even better than I remember. I think I might even prefer it to his Skyfall score. However, the cinematography is way worse. For some reason I thought the super saturated sepia filter was present only in the cold open in Mexico, which would be bad enough, but it's like that throughout the film. Not a fan ever usually of sepia and here its at a whole other tier. I do really like Bautista's character. One of my favourite henchman honestly. The Austin Martin DB10 is one of my favourite Bond cars ever. It's number one of the modern cars (modern equals Brosnan and Craig eras). The car chase in Rome is decent, not as bad as some die hard fans say it is. I liked it. I would have preferred Rome be in winter to somewhat try to justify the lack of traffic. There definitely were some vehicles in the way, but perhaps not enough. Back to the writing. The C stuff that M is dealing with makes no sense. Dont they already have information on everyone? What exactly is going to change with having more of it? The Blofeld stuff makes absolutely no sense. Brothers? Seriously? not only is that bad by itself, it makes the world of of the entire series so much smaller. Bond also has to deal with him on his own by the end. Where is the rest of all his minions? and why in the old MI6 building? How did Bond shoot down a plane with a pistol (ok that one I always had a problem with, but now with everything else, it just feels even worse. When were they (Bond and Madeline) falling in love exactly? Because it wasn't in this movie. Speaking of which, never in this series have I seen more nonsensical reasons for having sex since The Man with the Golden Gun. Neither times did it feel appropriate. One of them was done for laughs and I wasn't laughing. some jokes actually do work though, the writing isn't absolute garbage. I like Q and a lot of his lines, most of the time. I like the Sam Smith theme song less and less every time I hear it. When it first came out, I loved it, was in my top 5 of all Bond themes. By now it's somewhere close to the bottom 5 for me if not already there. The graphic of the theme song is probably even worse honestly. Some weird shadows over people's faces going on. The cold open isn't even as great as I remember. No only is the sepia filter so overbearingly distracting, the first cut from the long take happens at a pretty random and awkward moment.

I wanted to see this one, because I loved 'No Time to Die' and didn't realize that it was a direct sequel to 'Spectre'. I figured James Bond films stood on their own. This was one was okay, but not as good as 'No Time to Die', 'Skyfall', and 'Casino Royale'. Craig's Bond films have their own kind of humor, and I dig it.

A tired and plastic bond who can barely move his face in a movie that brings nothing new to the franchise. There was time we would feel excited about a Bond movie. After watching this one I am excited that the current Bond is retiring.

Spectre continues the story of Daniel Craig as James Bond and unfortunately is not one of the strongest instalments of this franchise. In here James Bond is tested by one of its toughest opponents yet Ernst Blofeld played by Christoph Waltz who is set to take over all the intelligence agencies of the world and make the world bow to him through an organization called Spectre. Craig here continues to kick ass and in here is struggling with the passing of M as played by Judy Dench. Now the mantle is taken over by the great Ralph Fiennes who is not as caring as Dench's M but is more stern and direct and gets in more sparring moments with Bond. The meat of the story though is the '' Bond Female'' played by the great French actress Lea Seydoux of Blue is the Warmest color fame. This is the best female character for this franchise since Casino Royale and establishes a romance that has great consequences for the story. Unfortunately even with Sam Mendes back as director this movie pales in comparison to Skyfall. Is convoluted with a very long dull pace and despite the great performance by Waltz this villain is quite disappointing with a very disappointing climax. This film could have been so much better

I also think Spectre is much better than the reviews, and what you also have to remember - Daniel Craig plays the film with an injury to his leg. The opening scene where he walks through Mexico City must have hurt like hell.
It's the closest Craig's movie as 007 to those good old Bond movies. It's the best Craig's movie as 007

Spectre is...fine, I guess. It's not the best entry in the Bond series and it's one of Craig's weaker Bond movies by a long shot. However, it still has a decent story, good characters and good action to keep you engaged the majority of the way through the movie. Blofeld, played by Christoph Waltz, is kinda wasted in the movie, which is disappointing because Waltz is such a masterful actor and he could have had a much larger presence in the movie. Overall, Spectre is a decent movie in the Bond franchise but it could've been so much more.
A waste of a good cast, director, and cinematographer. Every technical bit in this movie is fine, the screenplay is what screws it up

review_date: Although it doesn‚Äôt have the compelling story of Skyfall, (and the script is occasionally by-the-numbers Bond), the mind blowing stunt work, fabulous casting, Craig‚Äôs dependable swagger and exceptionally artful cinematography - this is still an epic Bond film. And wow - some of the shots in this film are so uniquely interesting - the film is worthwhile just on it‚Äôs visuals alone.
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

Don't dislike this film at all, definitely over-hated. Had some good laughs, fantastic directing and action, but I see why some are mad over the script. If you can ignore some minor plot holes, it's still a fun James Bond film in which Daniel Craig is fantastic as usual in.

Spectre is satisfactory with a lot of elements that hold up throughout the whole film. Yet, several components get lost in the story that is not to the capacity it should be at. The story is flawed and does not flow right. This problem is apparent in the character arc of the villain. Just like Quantum of Solace, Spectre handles its villain terribly. Ernst Stavro Blofeld's story is so muddled with very little explanation. There is a lot of verbal exposition, but never any visual storytelling. Blofeld's storyline is a victim of this problem as the film had a near 150-minute screen duration yet can not show any relevant information. However, the film can get one of the Bond girls right and not just have L√©a Seydoux be the sexual one-off that Monica Bellucci is. Speaking of Bellucci, she is part of a weak opening. Bellucci should have never been in the movie since her character is a misfire. Spectre is the fourth film in this version of the franchise, and the filmmakers should know that they need to treat their characters better. The film also has a mixed bag in the technical aspects of the film. The cinematography is bland, with hardly any shots that are visually appealing. The film uses the hand-held camera too much and focuses on the wrong details. One of those two problems is more at the fault of Sam Mendes as his directing is a step-down from Skyfall. Mendes does not fulfill the concept and story of this movie in an orderly fashion. There are various moments in the film where it feels like a parody of a Bond movie that you would see on a sketch show. The cast is at fault here with some weak performances from multiple actors. Daniel Craig is at his lowest point in Spectre with a very emotionless performance. Craig delivered this fun cockiness in the other films, but here he exhibits a bland personality. Christoph Waltz is solid, yet it is hard to see the range of his character when Waltz has very little screen time. L√©a Seydoux is also a decent actor in the ensemble, and it was nice to see that she had a strong sense of emotion in times of uncertainty. Dave Bautista is a prominent addition to the cast and adds some much-needed variety to the film. Ben Whishaw is a delight in the role Q, yet he was missing that spark that he had in Skyfall. Lastly, there is Ralph Fiennes. Fiennes is excellent as M, and it was nice to see M expanded on with Fiennes making him a more likable character. Spectre is a misfire in the James Bond franchise, yet does have a few redeeming qualities in some of its departments. The story has a few bumps, and Sam Mendes is not doing the best work he can. However, Spectre is watchable as that is one highlighting aspect with any of these James Bond movies. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

review_date: Already plagued by overly conventional action spaced out by far too many quiet moments, Spectre puts the icing on the crap cake with an extremely farfetched attempt at turning the previous Craig 007 movies into a cinematic universe.
