review: FLAG THIS REVIEW
Like the MI6 building in the first act, things really crumble in the third act.

Like Quantum Of Solace, this is a film that is destined to suffer by virtue of being a sequel to its predecessor; in this film's sake, to possibly the best Bond film of them all. Once again like Quantum of Solace, this film benefits from revisiting long after initial release; though the action sequences and the over-arching plot are closer to the entertainingly over-the-top traditions of much earlier in the series, this is never over-egged. The balance is in fact just about right, and there are moments of direction and design that provide a visual impact that's quite unlike much I can remember in any other film in the series. It is too long - when Bond says 'this isn't over yet just' before we cut to the film's denouement from what we all expected to be the denouement when we saw it first time around, it's tempting to find yourself saying 'Really?'. The 4 (or will it be 5?) film arc of the plot requires this extra ending and whilst it does mean the film outstays its welcome a little, it's an undeniably well-executed final finale. That there are at least 2 Daniel Craig Bond films better than this (I'm writing this before seeing No Time To Die) could sound like a criticism, but on its own terms and with the benefit of time, this is a comfortable success.

Either Sam Mendes quickly ran out of ideas and just went with the 007 flow, or the Daniel Craig continuity is starting to strain thin, but at least this entry still has the slick action and visual sparkle that can keep it afloat.

So. Boring. And could have been an hour shorter. Instead there is 2 and a half hours of talking with a total of 20-30 minutes of action. Kristoff Waltz doesn't get enough screen time, and Daniel Craig is doing his best to make something out of the terrible writing. Worse than quantum of solace I think.
Set pieces, cinematography and overall flashiness are at the forefront of the filmmakers' intentions and like some previous 007 entries it's an action-packed ride.

Imagine a studio has a hot streak, it ain't broke, so they fix it. What do they fix it with? They decide "what if we do a remake of the WORST 'Scream' film?" and I actually LIKE Scream 3! At least it did those twists first as well as other ideas that were fun. It's not a great film, but I'd argue better than this one. Worse yet, this film is overlong and slow as sin. There's a couple of good action sequences, the cast is good, and treating it's female lead as more than it's male leads disposable condom are all great. The cinematography is decent too, but all this is wasted with the stupid twist done decades earlier and better in the film mentioned earlier, as well as a tendency to become formulaic, which HORRIFIES me. I HATE what this movie does to this movie's villain. It's too nostalgia-baity and pandering. I give this a 4/10. I'm scared No Time To Die might be just as unoriginally stupid from what I've heard. Fingers crossed that those people were lying or that movies' gonna suck. And I love Sam Mendes, Cary Jori Fukunaga, and Danny Boyle as directors! I think Skyfall is the best Bond film, but Specter might be one of the worst.

I will admit that they should have clarified the machine scene near the end more but my god I loved this movie. And yes while Bond comes across as a creep in the first half like Skyfall, they kind of reflect on that and he changes for the better by the end. Otherwise, the action was great, the humor was on point, and the Spectre organization was ominous as fuck. Bautista, while not really being a character, is super badass. I really loved the movie, only slightly behind Skyfall because of Javier Bardem, the opening sequence of Skyfall being so amazing, and Skyfall's Home Alone on steroids final battle. But, once again, an amazing action movie.

[‚≠êÔ∏è59%] Right from the beginning Spectre (2015) feels tonally inconsistent as it attempts to provide the quirkiness of the classic Bond movies as well as trying to deliver a very serious one. Everything about this film just falls flat, given the high ambitions of the plot, it all feels very mediocre and dull, with the Blofeld plot line and attempts at connecting all of Craig's previous movies together misfire. Not even a few captivating action scenes can save Spectre (2015) from being an ambitious flop which rarely entertains.

I think this is better than Quantum Solas, but not on the same level as the other two. This film more sticks with the bond formula of the earlier days. But I do love the ending of this film. Out of that, this one is a decent watch if your invested in Craigs Bond.

They legitimately borrowed an Austin Powers Goldmember plot point with their hackneyed attempt at creating emotional resonance between Bond and Christoph Waltz' blofeld. This movie recycled so much from previous films in the Craig era. It tried to give 007 a Bond girl that he truly cared for, but there was none of the chemistry and flair Casino Royale had in the Bond-Vesper relationship. It tried to do the secret organization pulling the strings bit that Quantum of Solace did with Mr. White and the Quantum organization. It tried to do the villain-has-personal-attachment-to-Bond thing that Skyfall did. And on all three fronts, it failed miserably. Worst of all, there were so many dull points in the movie. If you won't have the depth or subversiveness of the better Bond entries, at least have interesting action.

review_date: 3.0/5.0 Exciting and but a mixed bag at the same time. The movie can be slow at times and uneven. The action and acting is great, tho. Disappointing following the greatness of Skyfall. #Uneven
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

This is certainly not the best Bond film to be made, but it's another solid outing for Daniel Craig's 007. I thought the action, as in pretty much all Bond films, was the standout for me. The train sequence was brilliantly choreographed and the climatic scene added some spectacular set piece action that will be etched into the Bond archives. Performance wise all good as expected once more, however Christoph Waltz as the films leading antagonist provided his usual demonic demeanour and his appreance weaves nicely into the narrative that had been building through the films prior to Spectre. This certainly does no harm to a group of films that has built itself up, especially since Craig has been at the helm, as one of the best action franchises of all time.

Not the best plot, drags in some moments, with a weak finale and wasted vilain, but it was good to see a movie bringing "the formula" back, with the Gunbarrel, MI-6 old structure and some humor - the scene of Bond asking a vodka martini at the clinic is the best comedic moment of the Craig movies.

Rating: B "Spectre fails to reach the tremendous potential of its intriguing narrative and fascinating antagonist, but Sam Mendes still pulls off a decent James Bond flick. The screenplay raises significant issues with an incredibly dull subplot that deeply affects the pacing of a bloated runtime. In addition to this, Christoph Waltz's lack of impactful screentime is disappointing, to say the least, despite a brilliant performance from the actor. Fortunately, the jaw-dropping action set pieces elevate the overall film, which also benefits from gorgeous cinematography (Hoyte van Hoytema) and exceptional acting across the board. Daniel Craig and L√©a Seydoux's characters relationship is emotionally compelling, making Bond's mission feel more like an interesting personal journey. One of the best movies of the franchise is buried somewhere under the messy screenplay, but what can be found at the surface has much to appreciate."
Yes Blofield could have been portrayed better and the ending could've been more provoking, but all in all it was an enjoyable experience, especially the fight scene in the train.

By all accounts, the general style of the film is a little rough but the film itself is an entertaining and much more watchable story than Bond 20. Theres all sorts of good in this film and as far as i'm concerned, it balances out the bad.
Probably the lamest James Bond I've ever seen in my life, the scenes lack credibility and the scenario has a logic problem

review_date: Do I even want to know how Sam Mendes could go from the highs of Skyfall to this? That's rhetorical by the way, don't answer that. The pacing was atrocious, especially because I feel like they could have ended it at the two hour mark, with slight modifications, if any, and called it there. Hey, they brought back other Bond tropes I didn't like, such as storylines just being dropped and never brought back up again. The characters are also a bit flat this time around, the soundtrack's kind of generic, and Daniel Craig is as mumbly as ever, but he does deliver on the actions scenes, so he's done a solid job overall making this his Bond. The visual effects were well done, with neither distracting CGI of most modern blockbusters, nor the awkward mistakes of the 60s/70s/80s. The comic relief is good, and at the end of the day, this is still more interesting than some of the worst ones of the 70s and 80s. I'm really hoping the quality of Skyfall returns, like Bond has 24 times now. I will say, however, the surveillance stuff was timely commentary for 2015 the way Tomorrow Never Dies' was in 1997, and to this day for both, so they were at least trying.

Where this film succeeds is in its rich story. Tom Holland does very well in his portrayal of both Spiderman and Peter Parker, and the villain, played by Michael Keaton, is one of the more memorable villains in the MCU. However, the main issue I have with this film is that Spiderman never feels like his own hero, just like Tony Stark's shadow, up until the end of course. Even the villain, however, doesn't even have any conflict with Peter, he just feels like a villain that would fight against the Avengers, or more specifically, Tony Stark. I feel like the film relied too much on Tony Stark and never came out of his shadow. The film in general, however, was still fun to watch and it's one that I've seen several times, it's just that there are a few issues that I have with it.

My favourite Spider-Man movie. Tom Holland's version of the hero is the most human between the main trio (him, Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield). He's a real teenager: anxious, acts by impulse, he's the Spider-Man who most want to be a hero. Most people complain that Tony Stark replaced Uncle Ben in MCU. I completely disagree. When Peter met Tony he already was Spider-Man by around six months. Uncle Ben has already died and Stark was someone who gave Peter a purpose. His turnaround sentence is the best I saw in a Spider-Man movie. But a Spider-Man movie isn't only made of Spider-Man. We have Peter Parker's arc outside the suit as well. And it's excellent. The high school environment looks like a high school environment (the best friend, the bully, the crush, the cynical, everyone is here and they're great characters) and Tom Holland is the most charismatic and trustworthy Peter Parker (as a teenager, he looks and acts like one) and his chemistry with Laura Harrier (Liz) is undeniably cute. Finally, Vulture is an excellent villain: he's imposing, has a motivation that makes sense, and despite not having Spider-Man as a direct enemy, is a person who is next to Peter and had the superhero interfering in his plans. My only issue with this movie is Aunt May, who is constantly treated like a MILF, and that joke is the only one that is repetitive and never works. It's sad because Marisa Tomei is a good actress and has the perfect age-looking for the role.
I thoroughly enjoy this movie and I find it very watchable. I like Michael Keaton. 8/10

Spider-Man finally gets a full length MCU treatment in this (sort-of) reboot to the franchise. Tom Holland is probably the most accurate portrayal of our young hero, Peter Parker, as he deals with the after math of working with Iron Man's Avengers (see Civil War). Peter is an easy-going fun loving kid who wants the girl, to impress Tony Stark, and to be popular. The positive in this film is that it is a real coming of age tale with a kid trying to deal with being a kid. Even our villain, The Vulture, is excellently played by (my favourite Batman) Michael Keaton, who has less of a plan and is just plain greedy. This film suffered from a lack of consequences as Peter has nothing really to lose, only his potential position in the Avengers, which isn't that big a deal. The other problem with this film is it can't decide whether it's a teen flick, action movie, coming of age tale or an origin story. Because of this, the plot and pacing can be off at times, but the acting makes up for this as Spidey really shines through.

My personal/Most rewatchable Spider-Man movie to date. Of course that's not putting down the brilliant Spider-Man 2 from Sam Rami, however this movie is the one I gravitate towards when wanting to put on a Spider-Man film. The Amazing cast really helps push the movie to a higher level with 'Tom Holland' playing Peter Parker/Spider-Man this is the first time I actually believed the actor could actually be in high school whereas former iterations who looked in there mid 20s. Tom Holland to me plays both Spider-Man & Peter brilliantly with Michael Keaton also doing a superb job as the movies villain 'The Vulture' Michael manages to make you feel bad and understand the character one moment then makes you fear him the next, You have to give props to the actor when his powerless character is threatening a superhuman and you are actually worried for the latter. I would 100% recommend this film to any superhero/Spidey fan but I would also recommend this film to casual fans at it is just simply a good & awesome movie.
Lazy movie, too many unnecesary jokes, feels like a spiderman parody, the only good thing about the movie: of course michael Keatons Vulture, Rdjr and the hot aunt May.

An action-packed coming of age story full of laughs and engaging fight sequences, Spider-Man Homecoming is a cheesy story that doesn't take itself too seriously but still makes time for heartfelt scenes that show who Peter Parker is as a person. The CGI from Marvel is phenomenal, as to be expected. The plot is your average light hearted Marvel plot and it works about as well as you'd expect, the writing isn't some magnum opus but it's decent enough for it to be forgiven. The cast is however a bit hit or miss, Robert Downey Jr is charismatic and a blast as always and Michael Keaton is insidious and one of the better Marvel villains, but we can't speak about the cast without talking about its rendition of Spider-man aka Peter Parker. Tom Holland is truly fantastic, he's cheesy, he's quippy, he's charming, he's everything you could ever want out of a Spider-Man, and most importantly, he's having fun in the role. Unfortunately, outside of these three, the rest of the cast is pretty forgettable. The pacing while at times too fast is never terrible. Overall, Spider-Man Homecoming is a solid first attempt for Marvel at a standalone Spider-Man movie that at times just misses the mark.

review: After what was, honestly, a rather silly and childish first movie, this sequel is far more focused, far stronger in tone, glossier in production, more intricate in its story, and better acted. It's a genuine improvement all around. The way it plays out is almost too dark for some children, but only for the moment itself -- It's dark and scary in the way that children usually love, upon reflection that is. It's scary in the same way as a scary moment in The Neverending Story, or a scary episode of Doctor Who; it's effectively scary but it's not exactly Horror cinema. The fantasy elements are all high-concept and intricate, allowing children to really flex their proverbial thinking muscles, while at the same time they're dazzled by the gorgeous visuals.

review: This accomplishes the main thing that it was supposed to do--build on and expand the world of Harry Potter. It almost does this too much, where the story can sometimes get a bit muddled within all the bright and shiny things to look at. But that is also where much of the charm of the series comes in--where all the tiniest details have been taken into consideration and made to be interesting. Watching this, you WANT to explore Hogwarts with the kids. You WANT to see all the whimsical items in the castle, all the while forgetting there's also a story going on the background. That being said, how much can you truly fault a movie for trying to be interesting?

review: My favorite of the entire Harry Potter franchise, this film has the greatest mysteries, the best build up, an amazing climax and so much amazing character development. It starts off with classic scene after another - Dobby, The Flying Car, The Whomping Willow, The screaming plants - and ends in the dark chamber of secrets in amazing climactic fashion. A cinematic masterpiece, this is maybe the only film that is straight up better than the book. Even just the scenes around Christmas time, the hogwarts scenery alone, the playfulness of the young cast but the very real danger lurking - and who can forget Lockhart, the funniest character in the entire series. This is the Pinnacle of Harry Potter, the grandest of them all. Nearly 3 hours of cinematic masterpiece.

review: OCULUS REPARO!!!! One of the most useful spells. Now the trio spent their second year at Hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry. Just like the first, this one showed more cool and expanded the wizard world more. Again, I enjoyed the creativity from the script and source material. The story was a big step up. It became more complicated with more mystery and unpredictable twists. The threat was more alarming and prominent to the whole school. There was also a bigger danger to Harry and his trio, which made me more invested in them. Even though I was more interested in the story, the run time was a big issue. It was 10 minutes longer than the first and I became bored like halfway through. If the story was more investing and intense, maybe I would not feel as dragged. Overall, it is better than the previous in terms of story, and I still had a fun time. 8/10

review: After watching Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone I had gotten really high hopes for the Harry Potter franchise. I was expecting all of them to be as simplistic and visually appealing as that movie. With that in mind I watched the second movie today and sadly, it doesn't live up to the mark on almost any of the parameters. That's not to say that it's a bad movie. It's not. But it's not a good Harry Potter movie. To begin with, the movie's CGI hasn't aged pretty well. And that's actually really surprising because the first one was so good so this one should have had a higher budget and thus more advanced VFX. But other than the Basilisk, most of the CGI hasn't aged so well. Especially that of Dobby. When he was banging his head in the drawer in the beginning of the movie, the shelves of the drawer were shaking in the opposite direction of where they should shake. And when Harry puts Dobby in the wardrobe it looked more like the wind is opening the door instead of Dobby. There are plenty of examples of bad CGI in the movie but I don't want to take it too far. Speaking of Dobby, he's had a very bad introduction. The way he is behaving is annoying. If I were to behave like that my mom would have slapped me all across the face. Sure he does get a wholesome ending, but that's yet to see how he turns out. Draco also became more annoying now, with constantly trying to bully Harry even though he can't do a thing. Myrtle spoke like a nerd Harley Quinn. I get this movie is trying to be campy, but that goes way too far. The story is a good part here. Although it's not as easy as Sorcerer's Stone, it is still very nicely detailed. Too many incidents happen in it, but yet it does not feel bloated. It feels absolutely to the point, with none of that "side quest" things movies often use to pad the runtime. Everything happens for a reason and it all pays off in the end. The scenes with Ron, particularly in the beginning, are always funny and memorable. Though Hermione doesn't play as huge part in this movie as Harry and Ron do, she also gets a decent screen time, although without any character arc. I'm still on the second movie of this franchise, so I can't exactly say if this is among the good movies or the bad ones. But I really hope the rest of the movies are more leaning towards the first one in terms of tone. I remember every scene right now, but I can see myself forgetting most of the parts in the next few months.

review: "The Secret Life of Pets 2" was made to teach new parents a lesson Sometimes I feel like Max, the Jack Russell Terrier. As much as I want to be like Rooster, the cool and collective sheepdog, sometimes my nervous and over-protective energy can get the best of me as most new parents have realize in the beginning years. As if Illumination was thinking of me when producing the script, they decided to name the baby Max is zealously protecting over as Liam my own toddler's name. I was only expecting childish fun gags and witty observations about the animals that rule our lives. Never thought the film's moral compass was to make me feel less alone with Max complaining "why is the world so dangerous" as I try to prevent my little ones from hitting themselves into pesky edges in our household. True, this theme is a minor element in this entertaining, energetic, and humorous sequel that should satisfy fans of the original. However, being present in the most important subplot reminded me that the most important lessons can come from unexpected places. As Rooster (perfect voice casting portraying the gruff, aloof, grit, and authenticity of Harrison Ford) said to Max after he reflected paranoia of Liam possibly falling, "so what if he falls? He will just get back up." It's a perfect metaphor that we can't protect our kids at all times forever, to let them go to grow experimenting as Max put it in the end this "complex, scary and beautiful world." Following the model example of Rooster, Max learns to face his own fears giving an example of bravery and courage as a result to Liam. Of course, most people are not going in seeking out these themes in this animated feature rather a visual vibrant, well-pace, and fun time that doesn't outstay its welcome. This film hit that mark overall even feeling more so like an episodic Saturday cartoon. I say that because the structure is unusual considering there is three subplots that feels like three separate episodes that in the end interconnect for a finale. This lack of lasered focus linear structured plot results in a thin story that questions if a sequel only exits simply because its predecessor was a box office success. Nevertheless, at least the themes and lessons learned mentioned earlier intertwines with the three main characters in the final act. At times it seems a bit mature for the younger audience with multiple suspenseful tense scenes however even my toddler son took it well as if he were inspired to become Rooster himself. The voice cast is pitch perfect and strong all around that brings relevance and charm to these characters that will support a healthy fan base looking forward to the next entry. Thank you for the lesson Harrison Ford.

review: I can't help but wonder how many people have died as a result of this movie. It *could* have been a decent movie, but one scene ruined it... when the small dog, suffering anxiety & nervousness issues, had his cone ripped off by the big dog who then threw away the cone away and declared definitively, "You're cured." Anyone who knows psychology or who has suffered recovering from mental illness knows that kind all-to-common action gets people killed. I can't help but remember a friend who introduced me to that movie who during that exact scene and said, "I like that dog." ... as he refused to awknowledge or respect a mental illness his daughter was struggling with; and was just exacerbating her condition. It could have been a decent feel-good movie if it hadn't had that scene. But that scene turned it from a potential tool for healing and recovery to slipping glass shards in the medicine bottle. All in all, for the sake of people's struggling loved ones everywhere, I'm of the opinion that all copies of this movie should be burned.

I mean, just don't have kids. Don't ruin the film industry just because you suck. Anyway, this second installment was definitely worse than the first, and it's sad that Harrison Ford got sucked into it (although he did do quite well). The few mildly humorous jokes/moments aren't worth the runtime.

review: ‚ÄòThe Secret Life of Pets' was a pretty average animated film whose "what do our pets get up to when we're not around" premise made it relatable, funny and charming to pet owners/lovers. The sequel has practically nothing to do with its title anymore (you can only pull that trick once, after all) and loses anything that made it somewhat original. Now we're into very familiar animated-animal territory that we've all seen many times before. Sure, there are some good messages (albeit very standard stuff) and a few things that'll probably make you smile, but for the most part, as with its predecessor, it's not particularly memorable and, in fact, the most stand-out thing is the colourful animation (the backgrounds are lovely) and character design. In short, kids might enjoy it and there are a few moments that might catch your attention, but for most adults, there's not much here.

review: A Batman and Superman comic book movie should be at least somewhat entertaining. I respect the lofty ambitions Director Zack Snyder had but, as usual, he dropped the ball on the execution of those ambitions. This movie looks visually amazing and I absolutely adore the betrayal of Batman and the storyline he is trying to tell about superman. Ultimately there are side stories that are started and dropped randomly and the build up to the climax does not add up or have the impact that was supposed to be intended. What we have is yet another Zack Snyder half-cooked idea of a movie.

review: I've watched the movie for a total of 4 times and let me tell you something (two times on HBO and 2 second more on a pirate site): The movie is utterly garbage and unbearable to watch, even with the Utimate Cut. Till now, i still don't know why people are praising a poorly-written movie with extremely low pacing and dogshit performances, maybe because everyone can have diferrent opinions about a subjective subject i guess. Nonetheless, the movie is still something worth to be buried somewhere else outside of this world, far from our reach. There are many problems with the movie, but the biggest problem of all was the plot. It was just unbelievably stupid and corny, left the Martha scene alone. Don't get me wrong, i don't have any personal hate on Snyder but this movie is just something else beyond the conception of intelligence. I refuse to think that this was made by a decent human being. It's like watching a Neil Breen movie for Christ sake, everything is completely a trainwrecking mess. None of the details in it made sense in a way that a nornal mind can conprehend; how can a hateful, violent, gruesome vilgilante somehow found a immigrant alien to be hostile and then spare him the moment he knew that they had the same mother's name? Oh yeah, i know why, because the movie didn't bother to consider the logical thinking of the plot or the self-development of the characters that involved in it so they just did what they thought that be the (least) logical thing to ease the discord between the two. To summarise all of it in one sentence: it's a plain stupid movie.

review: An unbelievably garbled plot leaves me wondering just why so many A listers agreed to take part in it. Paycheque? Surely there has to be more to it than that for such big names as Affleck, Fishburne, Adams. Et Al. The directing is amongst the most hopelessly muddled that I've ever seen in my 65+ years of cinema involvement. (My father was a cinema manager, so that had a bearing on me seeing far, far more movies all through my youth than my contemporaries who had to buy their seats.). But this thing would have had me desirous of a rebate, especially bearing in mind the price of cinema tickets these days, (my days of freebie tickets ended - unfortunately - about thirty years back) The screenplay and dialogue is poor, poor stuff indeed. And - Superman as, effective,y, - a villain? What? I'm reduced to using terms not unrelated to those of abuse in another circumstance. It is crap, it is junk, it is unwatchable dross. Don't buy the DVD, but by all means if you're curious to see how bad a flick Hollywood is capable of turning out despite a vast budget, check it on Amazon Video. Wheee it's a free watch for Prime customers.

Wolf Warrior 2 (Rental) is the highest grossing Chinese movie (at this point in time) and is the basis for "wolf warrior" diplomacy. It is in essence a version of Rambo III, set in Africa with a late 1990s direct to video feel and ex-Chinese special forces protagonist. The action scenes sometimes work (the underwater opener and the man v tank showdown) but some are just over the top craziness. It is pro China (in the way most films are pro USA) but it may not be a bad thing, as long as you try to live up to idolized version of your county as opposed to justifying your own actions.
Patriotic but enjoyable This War is for fans of cheesy action movies from the 80s and the 90s
This is one of the most boring action movie I have ever seen and pretty loaded with Chinese propaganda.

Everything about this sequel to Wolf Warrior exceeds the first. The acting, the special effects, the story- all an improvement over the original installment. Wu Jing returns in this sequel. He also wrote, produced, and directed the film. The film surrounds Wu Jing's attempt to live a peaceful life in Africa when he his peace is disrupted by a mercenary army and a deadly disease outbreak. One of my criticisms of the first film was that I did not feel Wu Jing commanded the screen as the lead. Nothing could be further from the truth in this one. Rather than playing a Jackie Chan-esq character, Wu King finds his own as a compelling, interesting, and exciting action star in this one. He is very good. As for the supporting cast- Frank Grillo is always fun to watch. He appears to be the hardest working action star/character in the world. His fight with Jing in the finale of the film is well choreographed. Celina Jade is commanding as the love interest. Nwachukwu Kennedy Chukwuebuka steals every scene he is in as Jing's "Godson". This movie was one of the highest grossing pictures of all time. Sam Hargrave, martial artist, stuntman, and Director of the highly successful "Extraction, stunt choreographed the underwater fight as well as many of the action scenes. This explains a lot about its success. This one is worth watching. The ending foreshadows a "Part 3" and I hope it is at least as good as the sequel.

In terms of production and narrative machinations, this is a far more complicated movie than its predecessor, so props to Wu Jing on his Directing of this film to have it work; it's not some of the best Directing you'll see by any stretch (the acting is mediocre and some of the cinematography is really rather bland), but it flows and it functions without any actual structural problems, which most certainly isn't nothing. People came to watch Action, and this movie Stars and is Directed by one of the most underappreciated Action stars working today. As such, the action is almost always from Good to Excellent, and the story-beats, while somewhat thread-bare, are enough to keep the momentum up. I was also shocked as to how much had actually happened by the end of the movie, as the amount crammed into the movie feels like it was a full hour longer (not a complaint, just an observation), as it ends with a prolonged fight scene that ends up with him battling a tank. The movie does often times come off as a bit pretentious at times, as it features heroes protecting unarmed citizens from trigger-happy killers, but it really just boils down to being an excuse to have some really cool action sequences; the movie does make you empathize for the refugees, but their part in the movie is really just a trick to generate a sense of empathy from the viewer. There is also a very, very strong Chinese Military Patriotism element in this movie, making it also feel like a Chinese Michael Bay film, but I don't count this against the movie because it makes sense (being a film made in China) and because it's actually purely a positive message - It uses heroism to bestow Patriotic Propaganda but doesn't use it to justify any morally grey misdeeds on the part of the heroes (I mean, it's literally about soldiers protecting unarmed civilians under fire). If you want a fun time you will find it in this movie, which is explosive, full of stunts, and works well on a technical level as well.

review_date: You can tell they put a good deal of thought into making this one maybe if for no other reason than to give the viewer connections to the original trilogy story. I have to nick the film for a few reasons. It tries so hard in the first half to try and be a drama with Anakin unsure of what he should do. The movie then segways into him completely changing course mentally almost immediately with one scene in particular seeming unbelievable by any stretch - he was conflicted before this scene but he does a complete 180 in seconds and it just seems haphazardly written here. The movie also does a disservice to our prequel heroine, Padme. She is reduced to a stand by your man 'til it kills you 50s style house wife; it's sad because she was a cool woman who could fend for herself in the first two films. She's turned into a prop here and it's only her acting that saves it from being a wash. Last ding is that it's hard to believe the Jedi didn't know the Sith Lord was right in front of them the whole time; they're supposed to be wise and have prophetic abilities. All that to say this: there are some great battle sequences including the best lightsaber battle in the series. The back and forth storytelling works well here to keep the viewer engaged. I can't say the film is easy to watch in the middle - Anakin's transition into Vader is not only convoluted but disturbing. It's especially hard to watch in juxtaposition to the rest of the series' tone. We can assume things about good and evil but to see Vader's fall from grace is very depressing. It is easily the least enjoyable 40ish minutes to watch in the whole saga. The first 40 and last 40 minutes however are enough to make it not only good but the best in the prequels. As a standalone story it is well done but not a movie you'll want to rewatch for fun - it's essential to the overarching story and that's it.

review: Though the film can get a bit uneven at parts, the conclusion is ultimately satisfying and heartbreaking to watch as it wraps up this mediocre trilogy with spectacular fashion. "Revenge of the Sith" has the best story, CGI, and action of any of the prequel films made, and the film perfectly sets the stage for "A New Hope." I think that George Lucas had a perfect plan with this trilogy, though ended up failing in the process to get to this film. This third installment in the prequel trilogy is absolutely gorgeous to watch, and due to its very memorable and emotional moments throughout, "Revenge of the Sith" remains as one of the best "Star Wars" movie to date, despite its several flaws.

review: This move is 10/10 and I'm willing to die on that hill. The sound score, the fight choreo, Ewan McGregor's performance, and the way it tied the prequels to the originals were amazing. I see a lot of people complain that Anakin is "too whiny" when that's literally how he's supposed to be. He's an emotionally stunted man with childhood trauma who was drafted into a cult of religious soldiers at the age of 10. Also, no hate to Luke but I distinctly remember him being very whiny in A New Hope. This movie embodies what Star Wars is and is a thrilling yet heartbreaking conclusion to the prequels that shaped so many of our childhoods.

review: Star Wars Revenge of the Sith is my personal favorite Star Wars Movie. It brings the Prequel Trilogy to an exciting, dramatic, and emotional end helping shape timeline wise the next movies to come (the Original Trilogy) The story is an exciting one and contains some of the best duels in all of Star Wars which is strengthen by John Williams incredible soundtrack. The emotion and chemistry showcased between Anakin (Hayden Christensen) and Obi-Wan (Ewan McGreggor) is what makes the film hit even harder. Years later this movies popularity and view in the fanbase continues to grow as more and more people see the film for what it is, an incredible Star Wars movie.

review: A very underrated movie. This film accomplished what the prequel trilogy was aiming to do, which was to elaborate on the backstory of Darth Vader and Palpatine's rise to power through the corruption of the republic. We are shown how Palpatine's manipulation of Anakin comes to fruition after years of careful planning. We see the failure of the Anakin Obi Wan relationship and the establishment of Luke and Leia's upbringings. This film also has an amazing score, including some of John William's finest works such as Battle of the Heros and Duel of the Fates. This film also makes excellent parallels with the rise of Hitler and the fall of democracy in post WW1 Germany. I do have some issues with this film, namely some of the acting is a little over the top. I also think the handling of Padme's death was rather cheesy. I think it would have been more fitting if it was eluded that Palpatine killed her instead of heartbreak. Overall a great film that deserves less hate that it gets.

review: Star Wars Episode 3 The Revenge of the Sith (A) Might get some flack for this opinion but I don't care. This was my favorite movie growing up and I still have so much nostalgia for it. Anyone born in the 90s that is a star wars fan probably agrees that this was such a fun time to watch as a child. I remember my first time watching it and how amazing it was to see obiwan become ben and Anakin become Darth Vader. This inspired me to love movies the way I do today. Looking back at the movie now I definitely will note the cheesy dialogue here and there but it is still such a solid movie. I LOVE the lightsaber battles in this movie. I thought Ewan McGregor as obiwan was a perfect cast and Ian McDermott as Darth sidious is terrifying. Everyone should agree that this is by far the best of the prequel trilogy. George Lucas finally nailed one of the movies after his amazing original trilogy. Nothing but love from me here...

review_date: Catching Fire, the second (and best) film in The Hunger Games series is an absolutely phenomenal film. While I enjoyed the first film a lot and I thought it was a great adaptation of the novel, this film is 10x better. The stakes are higher, the acting is better, the cinematography is nauseating. It is everything a sequel should be. This film has such an incredible fast pace and energy to it that makes it so enjoyable to watch. We also meet new characters in this film like Finnick and Johanna, who are also my two favorite characters in the series. My only main complaint is that I do think it feels a little bit too similar to the first film since we do have to go through all the training and interviews and prepping all over again since Katniss has to go back into the games. But it‚Äôs still great to watch none the less, also Stanley Tucci as Ceaser Flickerman is amazing. Overall, Catching Fire is a phenomenal sequel and a phenomenal film in general.

review: Now this is how you do a sequel and adaptation! Francis Lawrence translated the book into film so incredibly well it makes me so happy. Once again, every actor and casting is amazing especially Jennifer Lawrence. Each gives a passionnate, exciting and emotional performance. The riots and all the political stuff is so intriguing and handled really well and gives the first half clear stakes and makes it really intense. The movie is also paced much better. Deapite a few rushed scenes, every scene is as long as it needs to be and makes the experience very smmoth. Now, about the Hunger Games aspect. Seeing old winners and other districts was one of my favorite parts of the book so I was happy that Lawrence nailed that aspect, especially with Finnick and Johanna, whose characters are captured perfectly. Hell, every character is handled really well. The design for the arena is inspired and incredible and the action is creative, intense and filmed much better. It's clear Lawrence really wanted to please fans of the book and he did. Wish they added the scenes of the previous Hunger Games and some scenes like Katniss's judging were longer but overall, a great adaptation.

review: Guardians 2 is a strong follow up to the original film, somehow creating more depth and humour with each character. The only weakness lies in an over-saturation of what made the first film so special, which was the subtle humour mixed with classic music. These wonderful elements now are more blatant and over the top. Saying this though, this is the Marvel sequel we were all waiting for, incorporating unknown characters without brow-beating us about upcoming films in the MCU, potential spin-offs and sequels and just creating more depth in the Guardians universe. I am looking forward to Adam Warlock being featured in the sequel.

review: This film is definitely a step-up from the first installment as the story is just so much better. James Gunn really poured a lot into this movie which led to such an amazing film. The overall message of the movie is so beautiful and offers so many iconic moments. The film always has something going on and a lot of the story details never get lost in other plots. Some aspects of the film are a tiny bit complicated, but it doesn't hurt the movie all that much. A large reason why this movie feels a lot more whole is that the characters are way better developed here. Peter's story excels greatly into something really beautiful. I would even say the same about Yondu as in the first film, Yondu didn't feel all that important. This film, however, made me greatly appreciate Yondu and his actions in the first film. Rocket, Gamora, and Nebula also get some more character development that I think benefited them greatly. Even new characters like Ego and Mantis were very easy to attach some type of connection to as they are both very well developed. The only character I would say is poorly written is Drax, which sucks because I really liked Drax in the first film. Drax came off as rude and annoying for a large part of the film and his jokes weren't all that funny this time around. As much as I loved the characters in this film from a story standpoint, the actors weren't all that great. Both Chris Pratt and Zoe Saldana do a poor job in their roles. Their line delivery is off some of the time and I never felt the energy their performances had in the first film. Plus, both actors never convinced me that they had a love connection forming. Another actor that struggled was Dave Bautista. He was sometimes trying too hard to sell his joke or line that it came off in a cringeworthy way. However, the rest of the cast was pretty solid. Bradley Cooper did a fantastic job just like in the first film and new additions to the franchise Kurt Rusell and Pom Klementieff do an awesome job with both really nailing down the personalities of their characters. Michael Rooker is the stand-out to me in this film. Rooker had some great line delivery and really made the message of the film feel powerful and impactful. The production design of this film was flawless. Everything looked so stunning and the design of Ego's planet was just so well done. The color choices were great and how the technology on the planet moved was just so cool to watch. However, the cinematography felt a little weaker in this film. It was still very good, but I don't think cinematographer Henry Braham really made any shots look visually breathtaking like Ben Davis did in the first film. Something that did improve was the score. It was better than in the first one with Tyler Bates creating some memorable tracks and more of a balance between songs and the score. Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 was definitely a step-up storywise, but somewhat of a step-down when looking at some of the cast. Even though I do like this film better than the first one, I do think the cast was a lot better in the first installment rather than the second. However, the strong, heartfelt story really hides all the casts' flaws and really sets this film over the top. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com
rt_name: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 - Movie Reviews

review: The first Guardians of the Galaxy was a lot of insanity and a fair amount of heart -- this Sequel has a fair amount of insanity and a lot of heart. And I really mean it - much of the movie does ask that you feel "this is funny" or "this is cool", but there are numerous parts where the movie make you feel Mortified, Triumphant or even legitimately Sad. The final few minutes of the movie before the credits roll are absolutely spellbinding, and I literally tear-up every time I watch the final act of this movie. The final act is both Inspiring and then Heartbreaking shortly afterwards, and the fact that a Marvel movie has, upon multiple viewings, brought me to tears really shows how outstanding this film is. Like many, I would've liked a bit more insanity, but this is EASILY the Second Most Insane movie of the MCU (part 1 being the #1 spot), and since the trade-off was genuine emotional impact, I am more than happy with the exchange we got. If you love movies that cover a wide spectrum of emotions and does so effectively, then Guardians of the Galaxy 2 might be the best movie to do so in a very long time. You will laugh, you will cheer, your heartrate will occasionally rise and you will end it having had your soul crushed. In terms of pure entertainment and emotional impact and satisfaction, I'd argue this might be the best Space Opera since The Empire Strikes Back - yes, I really mean that.

review: GotG Vol. 2 isn't quite as good as its predecessor, but even though it does fall into the "sequel is worse" category, it still remains a solid and entertaining MCU blockbuster and comes close enough to the original to be enjoyable. The script doesn't have the finesse of the first movie causing the humor to drag and be a little over the top at points, but the actors do a fine job of getting around this causing a few of these moments to be genuinely funny. It's nice that this movie takes us deeper into the character of Peter Quill by exploring his family, a route that was set up well at the end of Guardians 1. What's even better about this is watching how Peter learning about and discovering his true family impacts his relationship with his "new" family: his fellow Guardians. This impact adds some emotional depth to the film, and makes Peter Quill a surprisingly complex character and takes him through a really nice arc that forces him to truly consider his relationships with those he cares about the most. Pratt supplements this with another great performance as the character, and his fellow Guardians castmates hit the spot as well. The movie makes sure to make good use of Kurt Russell as Ego by giving him plenty of screen time, a backstory, and a few emotional moments of his own. It also kicked ass to see the true power and capabilities of Yondu's flying arrow, something we got a taste of in the first movie but was amplified substantially in this movie. It's also still a relief and breath of fresh air that this film has no connection to the Avengers and the rest of the cinematic universe other than us knowing that it's a part of it. As mentioned before, what really prevents this movie from reaching the heights of GotG 1 for me is the humor, since even with the acting the script hampers this movie's ability to be as funny as GotG 1. GotG 2 is nonetheless still a fun and entertaining movie and is sure to leave viewers satisfied as the credits roll.

`Inside out` is probably one of the worst animation movie I have seen. It lacks a sense of character recognition, at times purpose and importantly emotional connect.

The emotions of an eleven year-old girl named Riley are brought to life inside her head as they move from Minnesota to San Francisco. The voice casting in this film is amazing! Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith, Lewis Black, Bill Hader and Mindy Kaling are terrific as Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust respectively. Them and Richard Kind as Bing Bong drive this film. This film has so much thought put into it (pun intended)! The way they portray things like memory, abstract thought, dreams, depression, etc., is so creative and somewhat educational. The finale also brings a great emotional lesson for anyone. Not only is the story and backgrounds creative, but the animation and attention to detail is simply astounding and makes this film worth watching repeatedly. This movie is a must watch!

Animation quality - top of the line, shallow a human to the role of a puppet of his emotions and addressing such a concept to children calls for vengeance to heaven

Pixar has made movies of all kinds - What if toys had feelings, what if insects had feelings, what if monsters had feelings, what if cars had feelings, what if fishes had feelings, what if rats had feelings. And now they have made Inside Out - what if feelings had feelings? Inside Out is probably one of the most underrated movies that Pixar has made. It was the first original Pixar movie which I didn't get to know about when it released (the first such one was a sequel, Monsters University), and I'm really surprised how this movie gets overlooked so easily. The way I see it, this movie is a social commentary about how we perceive life with our emotions. Riley here is a metaphor of us, how we feel when we move to a new place and are unable to handle the new life. In such situations we either feel scared, angry or depressed. When Riley starts crying in class, Joy tries to stop Sadness from ruining her memory with a vacuum but ends up destroying all her other memories. This is another metaphor from our lives, where we end up forgetting all our happy memories in times of desperation. Later on Joy and Sadness are in her memories, where they see Riley's childhood drawing of Bing Bong whom she considered her friend. The plot has been made with a complete sense of nostalgia. When we feel nostalgic, we feel both happiness and sadness at the same time. We are happy because we got to live those times, the time which was better than what we are living at the moment. We are sad because we know that time never stops, and so everyday we are straying further away from when it happened. We will never be able to live the day again, and it shall only stay in our memory. While Joy and Sadness are not present Fear, Anger and Disgust control her. I don't think I need to explain this. Riley has lost all her happiness and does not feel any sadness. Keep in mind she had previously cried in class, which is something very embarrassing for a ten year old child. As a result she does not want to show her sorrow in front of everyone since she fears people will laugh at her, so instead she tries to cover it with anger and disgust. This is just like how we behave when we are depressed but are also too afraid of what others might think if they learn about it. And then there is the memory dump, the place where the old memories are forgotten. This is one of the deepest messages that the movie gave us. To save Joy and Sadness and allow them to get out of the pit, Bing Bong readily sacrifices himself. This is because he had always considered himself and Riley friends, and he was ready to sacrifice his own life for this. It also shows how Riley has now lost the memory of Bing Bong due to her depression and frustration, and it is something she will never remember again. This is a metaphor of how we forget the small details from our childhood which gave us joy once we grow out of the phase. It also symbolises that although Bing Bong has been lost forever, Riley's joy and sadness will always remember him. This is similar to how we get nostalgic whenever we see our childhood writings and drawings. And finally when Joy and Sadness do make it back, then Joy chooses to let Sadness guide Riley. If she wanted she could have guided Riley and make her feel happy about reuniting with her parents. But in that case the moment would have completely lost the impact. So instead Sadness did it, which is why Riley started crying, something she had not done for a long time. This is yet another metaphor of when we are unable to hold our sorrow for too long and burst out crying. As a result her parents are finally able to understand the situation she is in and give her more love. In the end Riley starts feeling happy, since everyone has understood the value of Joy. She was the first emotion that Riley felt, and the one who guided them all in the time of desperation. All the other emotions came to her afterwards, which is why they are not as emotionally attached to Riley as Joy does. Joy knows what is the best for her, just like how we feel the best thing for our life is what makes us happy.

Summary: Five emotions‚ÄîJoy, Anger, Fear, Disgust, and Sadness‚Äîlive in Riley's mind and help her navigate her pre-teen world. Having just moved from Minnesota to San Francisco, she has a lot of changes ahead! Takeaways: Incredible representation and teaching moment for children about our emotions.

Just‚Ä¶.how? How did Pixar make another flawless film after three films that I would either consider meh or bad? I just don't get it! Let's just make sure Pete Doctor directs every Pixar movie ever and we will be a-ok. I don't want to talk about all the good things with this movie, because let's face it: everyone has done that. Instead, I want to talk about all the things that this Pixar movie does better than all the others. First, I think this is the best voice cast for any Pixar movies prior or after this. The only one that kind of comes close for me is Toy Story 4, but that's for a different review. Biggest highlight is of course the great work of Amy Phoeler as Joy, it was just spot on. Next, comedy. Seeing how the main character is literally the concept of Joy, I would like to think that this movie was going to be funny. And I was right with this being, in my personal opinion, the funniest Pixar movie. Lewis Black as Anger is just a laughing riot to me. He was hilarious! Finally, how can you not talk about this movie without mentioning the ending, with two big emotional parts that really leave a huge impact. The first being the death of Bing Bong, which feels a little like it comes out of nowhere, but you're going to remember it. And, of course, when Riley comes home from running away and the parents also say that they miss the old home‚Ä¶.OMG it's so good! The only kind of problem is that Anger is mainly the reason all the islands get destroyed, and no one addresses it at any moment. But that's minor, and no one is going to be thinking that in their first viewing, I only noticed it in my most previous viewing of the movie anyway. I really think someone should do a deeper dive into this movie, cause it really deserves it. However, I can only praise it for so long. Go to Disney+ and watch this flawless film and to see the best Pixar has to offer!

Inside Out review A heartfelt animated movie, "Inside Out", takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions with creative imagination and a look back at some nostalgic moments we might have had in our childhood. Unlike any other, Pixar studios created an original movie of the emotions that go behind a person's mind and made them into having their own personalities. Focused on the mind of a little girl ,Riley her life is shown as typically any perfect childhood. With the presence of the emotion joy it shows her story of her two loving parents raising her and living the life with many moments that one child creates. Including the building of humor, friendship and playing your favorite sport. But as all children go through the other emotions such as sadness, fear ,disgust and anger it will include her experiences. However, her life takes a sudden turn when she has to move with her parents from their hometown Minnesota to San Francisco. Her emotions will be put to the test in adapting to a new lifestyle they're typically unused to. To start off , it shows the beginning of the first years in Riley's life. Transitioning from stages to the preteens years of her life. This is where she experiences many emotions and personal likeness and dislikeness. Riley is seen on her journey as she experiences all typical childhood memories. From learning how to walk to talking your first new words. Discovering your least favorite meal to favorite toy to take with you everywhere. The laughter you create and the sad moments you experience. The rewarding moments of receiving a good grade to being upset for losing an important game. As Riley is growing she has experienced majority exciting emotions until a certain news comes to her attention. She will be moving from her childhood home Minnesota, where she was born, raised, and grew up to miles away into the city of San Francisco. Despite the change , her emotion Joy makes Riley see all this in a positive way. Meeting new friends, decorating a new room and many more ideas. Arriving at the new location, Riley is quick to notice the drastic change in seeing her new home. Adapting to the city and less outdoor activity is one of the unfortunate changes making her find new adventures. On her first day of school, she is introduced to her classmates and told to talk a bit more from her time back home. As she recalls some of her favorite memories, the emotion sadness touches her favorite memory, changing Riley's memory to a sad moment and turning it into a sorrowful memory. Joy continues to try and make Riley enjoy the new memories. After they had another similar disagreement Joy and Sadness cause the core memories to be knocked from their containers and accidentally vacuumed along with them into Riley's emotional interior. With this problem, it leaves the other emotions Fear, Disgust and Anger to run the emotions until the others return changing RIleys behavior. Throughout the film it shows the many obstacles and challenges Joy and Sadness must go through to reach the headquarters. Following with revisiting old memories and lifelong imaginary friends. It will take a spin through some future glimpse some being Riley's future boyfriend and many more. Overall this unfortunate event turned out to be a better lesson. The emotions appreciating each other's teamwork to help Riley have the best life she could as she grows up. Enjoying the moments one creates as living life with a positive attitude.
While it seemed like Pixar's morale was rapidly declining, this emotional masterpiece tipped the scales.

[A] gem from Disney that carries a lot more than a moral. The film captures different perspectives that are relatable and intimate to the point of finding yourself experiencing it. The message of this film is clearly Inside Out indeed.

Normally, Almost every animation which are made by Disney and Pixar are interesting to most people because they mostly fun, happy to watch, beautiful graphic, etc. , but I think 'Inside out' is more than that. I have remembered that in the time this movie has been released, it was very famous. But I have not seen it yet until two months ago that I watched it. The first time I have seen this movie to the end. I understood to many media why they rated this animated movie very high. First It is about the graphic of the animation. As we have known. Disney and Pixar are one of the best animation studios about graphic, and they have done to this movie very well, such as an appearance of a character. There are lots of details about graphic, sharpness of the video, etc. Second, sound effect. In my opinion. Sound effect are very important to every movie in the scenes that want to show, or express more the feeling to the audiences than only the movie scene. And this movie expresses the feeling to the audiences very well such as happy, sad, scared. The last thing and it is the most interesting point is about feeling. It is what this movie expresses to us. For me, this part is the point that makes this movie different to other animation movies that Disney and Pixar have made. It is more than a movie for entertaining. It teaches us how we can control our feeling , however I will not tell you what feeling that I mean. I want you find it by yourself in the movie. Then after you watch it, you will understand what I have told to you. But there is one inferior point in this movie. It is distribution of the character. Some characters are very notable, but there are few characters have a few of air time, scenes that they act. In my opinion, 'Inside out' is still one of my best animation movie. For me, I give it 1/3 of the best Disney and Pixar movie of all time. If anyone is looking for some full of quality movie. 'Inside out' is the great choice. concluding, very well work for Disney and Pixar making this movie. I give 9 out of 10. I hope you enjoy my review more or less. Thank you so much!

I hated this movie because I didn't like the "heroes" or agree with their Machiavellian quest to mind f@#k someone in the name of antitrust. It is wrong to drug people and them mind r@pe them as they lay unconscious and helpless. It is better to institute and enforce anti-trust laws that would break up large giants like Google and Amazon. We can't have economic freedom without bodily autonomy and basic civil liberties as well as a government that enforces those liberties. Kidnapping Fischer was a vicious, cowardly and morally bankrupt and not the work of a hero. I disliked the character so much I didn't care what happened to them so the movie was boring as well. The fact this ham fisted, pedantic and desultory film is supposed to be "intelligent" is particularly disturbing. Imagine a future where computer nerds rule the world by forcibly kidnapping us and then implanting "good" ideas into our brains and those of our children to make sure we do the "right" thing. Would you care if one of those nerds got killed going too "deep" into your brain while you lay unconscious and helpless? That is the way I felt watching Fischer's kidnapping.

This one takes multiple viewings to truly enjoy. I really wanted to like this movie like everyone else and wasn't fully satisfied or thrilled the first time I watched it. Then I watched it again and appreciated the extremely impressive elements of it much more. The directing talent from Christopher Nolan is truly remarkable and the special effects/CGI is great. The action scenes especially in the middle of the film were my favorite parts, plus the ending scene. Not to mention the cast of actors that they were able to have participate in the production, very noteworthy. The film does have some issues though that may alienate some viewers. Much of the phenomenon in the movie is left up to a lot of interpretation and can make your mind too blown while you're still trying to keep up with the plot. It can be a lot to take in all at once and confuse people who aren't used to a movie like this. Plus I think that the romance between Cobb and Mal bogged down the main mission of the team a little too much, but I still see why something like that was included. Overall a pretty good movie! There is a lot to say about this movie and many ways to analyze it and that's why it was popular I guess!

A perfectly paced, written and directed story that will send your mind to an endless pondering and mesmerising journey. Nolan really knows what he's doing when it comes fiction. He knows how to deliberately lose the audience's comprehension to then retrieve it with magnificence. What truly makes Nolan's famous fiction movie Inception a masterpiece of time and reality mayhem, is the way the story is written and developed. It starts with a pretty strenuous concept: the inception of dreams. But then, as the story unwraps, with well-pace actions, embracing dialogues and great characters dissections, we begin to fathom what this concept of infiltrating dreams can serve for, alongside how it actually works ‚Äì using great insight of true physics and thorough studies upon the very subject of dreams and time. All leading to an ending that wraps into this "open ways" notion. The casting is straight up perfect. Leonardo DiCaprio embraced the role of Dom Cobb as a professional, really diving into the trauma of the protagonist and exploiting the pain and adventurous errands that this character went through in his past. Tom Hardy nailed the role of the Eames, a character capable of impersonating others within one's dream, using his seriousness and his passionate sheer acting. Cillian Murphy, managed to play the role of a broken son left with the legacy of his dead father like a boss, using his prowess acting and his bewitching voice. And last, but not least, Eliott Page, who really knows how to do her job and create an emotional and interesting character, Ariadne, ready to help her team as the ingenious architect of dreams. I could spend a day writing about the story and how the cast, the full cast, is perfectly chosen, but I think the points I've given are enough to catch your attention ‚Äì without spoiling the whole narrative ‚Äì if you haven't seen the movie yet.

Compelling if not a bit convoluted. It takes its time in the beginning - holding itself at too high a bar if you ask me - only to finally get going at the end of the 2nd act and beginning of the 3rd. All in all, 'Inception' is still one of Nolan's better movies and deserves at least one watch - but I wouldn't blame you if you didn't.
The concept of "Inception" and the plot tied in so perfectly together, creating a mind-blowing, must-see movie.

If you've ever had a weird dream that you thought for certain was real, or realised you were dreaming whilst in a dream, then Inception will make total sense. If not, then Inception may not have blown your mind like it did mine. With a strong cast, led by Leonardo Di Caprio in one of his more intense roles, and some awesome visual effects, Inception is an exciting, suspenseful mind bender with a clever script and a good sub-plot, that will keep you guessing until the end.
Amazing Directing, Captivating Plot, Overall Great!
Leonardo DiCaprio is absolutely captivating in this movie. Extremely intense and fascinating story line.

This movie requires a lot of concentration because of its mind-bending script. I for myself found this movie a little frustrating and a bit satisfying simultaneously. Splendid work by Nolan and his crew, DiCaprio was fabulous and all his co-actors did a marvellous job aiding the film. Though this film needs to be minded multiple times to get a crystal interpretation, this is a must-watch movie inclusive of Nolan's alchemy.

review: There are few objectively bad cinematic experiences that I like as much as the Michael Bay Transformers movies, but Part 2: Revenge of the Fallen, is the one I will never rush to defend. It's aggressive, it's loud, it's obnoxious, it's WAY too long, and I never thought I'd say this about a Michael Bay movie, but: It feels Lazy. This last one is the biggest oddity in regards to this movie, as Michael Bay's biggest problem has always been that it feels like he Directs and Edits after drinking a double-dosage of RedBalls Energy Drink (for those that watched Chapelle Show), but half of this movie looks like Bay just Directed it after taking Melatonin, as the cinematography is surprisingly plain, the stunts less intense than his usual work, the action blocking is a lot less intricate than with any other movie of his, and there's so much in this movie that simply did not need to exist that it felt like Bay was shooting most of this out of obligation. Let's throw in the fact that this movie is simultaneously the Most Comedic yet Least Funny entry of his Transformers movies, and you also have a movie that suffers greatly from inconsistent tone (a problem the others suffered from as well but not nearly to the degree here). The one distinctly good moment in this movie is a desperate fight in the forest between Optimus Prime and several Decipticons, as it's one that plays out with genuine stakes, has weighty consequences, ends on a powerful note and feature's excellent cinematography, choreography and sound design. It's a shame as this bit is genuinely great, the sole legitimately shining moment in a movie that balances between low-tier mediocrity and the outright awful.

review: When I had heard everyone say that Transformers movies keep getting worse as time moves on I was actually very hesitant to watch this. I really liked the first movie so there was no way I could believe that THIS franchise could possibly be bad (although I did see that later on, I didn't see it here). In my review of the first movie I said how I got interested in the Transformers franchise after watching it, since I didn't know this was actually a toys company and not an anime series. If that movie was just the introduction, this was where the real action takes place. I saw Revenge of the Fallen on Amazon Prime soon after the first one. I only had one week left before my Prime subscription would expire, so I had only decided to dedicate this time to watching all the Transformers movies so that I could understand what this franchise is all about. Unlike the future movie this one actually expanded on what was established at the first movie. Although the human characters were not as interesting as the previous movie and the story was also pretty much empty, the action scenes completely made up for it. As usual the CGI and action was very good. The new characters introduced were fun to watch. I really like to see it when new characters are brought in and given their own character development as they transform into cool cars. However not everything about this movie was good. Like I said above the human characters were not as interesting. The entire blood about Sam going to college and his parents continuously pestering him was very annoying. This was the last time we got to see Mikaela, which is also something very sad IYKWIM. This movie was able to explain very well the entire concept of Transformers, something that the prequel fail to do so. Before I used to think that Autobots and Decepticons are supposed to be cars, but now I know that they are actually robots which can turn themselves into whatever they see in front of them. I would definitely give a rewatch afterwards sometime in the future whenever I have to show this franchise to a new generation.
rt_name: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen - Movie Reviews

review: This may be controversial, but I believe Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is one of the best films in the franchise. This film is slightly messy, but only if you don't pay attention. The movie isn't finished yet, and you can tell; there are some funny awkward jokes strewn around, and there are a few minor narrative holes here and there, but I can see where they're heading, and I LOVE it. The plot is very interesting to explore, including the history of Transformers and the lasting effects of that legacy that transcends time. Also you will not find better action in any other film than in this one; the action is nonstop and visually appealing and it will keep you at the edge of your seat. All in all, my childhood favorite and an actually enjoyable watch.

review: The best of the five Twilight Saga films, "Breaking Dawn: Part 2" - because it is the end! Yes, but it also rises above the other four because it is NOT a sappy film wallowing in the morose, moonstruck moodiness of the eternal love between Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson). Rather it is mash-up, and just an ok mash-up, of the "Underworld" and the "X-Men" series of films with some decent, and distracting, vampire characters with special skill (who knew this about vampires?!) and an above average climatic fight scene that turns out rather unexpectedly. Was it worth sitting through over 10 hours of these five films? That will remain highly unlikely other than for the most diehard fans.

review: I liked the first part of "Breaking Dawn" enough to make me curious about this movie. While I do think the opening and closing moments of the movie are solid, I think this movie seriously drags in the middle. For a movie that is supposed to be the big finally, this movie is super underwhelming. As usual, the acting and dialogue aren't great, but this movie mercifully doesn't focus much on the unconvincing romance in this series. I just feel the way it ends is kind of a cop-out, happily ever after type of ending, and it makes the whole series feel a bit pointless. I can't speak on behalf of the book but I think this franchise saw an opportunity to make some money and dragged this story into two full-length movies when in reality just one big two and a half hour movie might have been handled more neatly and effectively. As it stands, this isn't the worst "Twilight" movie but I can't say it is one of the better ones either.

review: To tell a tale out of school, out of all the horrible Worst Picture Razzie winners, Twilight: Breaking Dawn Part 2 was the main reason I retained from doing this marathon in the first place. On top of not getting into the teenage vampire and werewolf trend in early 2010's, I didn't want to expose myself to the cinematic bubonic plague known as the Twilight franchise. Unfortunately, the 8-year record is broken as I have now seen one of their movies, the final one. Previously, Bella Swan-Cullen (Kristen Stewart) gave birth to Edward Cullen's (Robert Pattinson) half-vampire baby Renesmee (Mackenzie Foy). In Part 2, Bella and Edward's love-child brings a conflict between the Cullen family, the pack of werewolves lead by Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner) and the Volturi cult led by Aro (Michael Sheen). Having not seen the other films or read the Stephanie Meyer books, I could never follow why being immortal would be a threat to the Volturi vampires or how the vampires inexplicably gain powers like chopping logs like a cheese cracker, superspeed, or super-jump. It also didn't help that the visual effects are far below the standards of a Sci-Fi channel movie, demonstrated by the werewolves, motion blurs, the backdrops, and the baby. Another list of stupidity: Bella learning to act human, the elemental powers that contribute nothing to vampirism, the ethnic stereotypes, and the climactic battle near the end which was all a vision. The only redeeming and entertaining value in the whole series so far is Michael Sheen, who bites the scenery gloriously and even has that silly hammy laugh as an act of threat. While nicely shot and not with some crazy and funny moments, Breaking Dawn Part 2 is still a poorly written, poorly acted and poorly directed mess. (1 ¬Ω Ugly CGI Renesmee Cullens out of 5)

review: The best Twilight film...mostly owing to the fact that it's the last one of these suckers (no pun intended). There's a final battle that's actually quite badass, despite being remarkably gore-free for an all-out massacre...which then leads to probably the cheapest movie cop-out I've ever seen in a movie, though I won't spoil it for you. Michael Sheen has more screen time after being limited to just two scenes in the terrible New Moon movie and only allowed to have a Marvel-style mid-credits scene cameo in the last movie. And, the movie for once isn't boring with some nice cinematography and a decent opening credits sequence. It's still not good despite being the best film but I'd rather take an average fantasy action film than a dull romance anytime. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson's performances aren't any different from what we're used to seeing from them at this point, the ending is probably not as happy as Stephenie Meyer and Bill Condon seem to think it is and it's clear the special effects budget was dedicated to just the final battle because Bella and Edward running looks abysmally fake and the CGI baby is much more creepy here than in Part 1. Did I mention the cheap cop-out? I think I did. Glad to get this franchise over with though I might see the adaptation of The Host, seeing how the book is written by the same author. It is fascinating to see how a series that was always generally considered to be not good still managed to have movies that were all hugely successful at the box office. While there have been good first films followed by a series of crappy sequels such as Transformers and the Resident Evil movie series, Twilight was considered to be a bad film franchise from many detractors since day one yet the sequels still managed to show up amongst the 10 highest-grossing films of the year from 2009 to 2012. We might never get a definitive answer as to just how popular this series ended up being but for the time being, let's all take a moment and feel either relieved or sad that this series has come to an end.
