Somebody alert the press! Independence Day got itself a sequel. I don't know where the studio brass' collective heads were when they green-lit this movie but my best guess is that they took a jump to the left out of a time warp. Never the less, everyone's favorite Sunday afternoon movie is back with a new chapter starring Jeff Goldblum and Bill Pullman reprising their roles as David and President Whitmore along side Liam Hemsworth, Jessie T. Usher who plays the son of the absent Will Smith's character and Maika Monroe as Whitmore's daughter. Also returning are Brent Spiner and the incomparable Judd Hirsche as David's father Julius. In short everyone is here to take on another swing at the alien menace who, in response to their crushing defeat in 1996, have sent in a call to their home planet for reinforcements. The biggest stumbling block this movie has is just how impossibly late it is. The original film, despite it's flaws, had a lot going for it with it's white hot cast, adventurous spirit and unique story. It didn't matter that a computer running Windows 95 could somehow interface with an alien spaceship or that Vivica A. Fox and Boomer the dog avoid a trillion degree fire by hiding from it in a closet or just how impossibly racist Judd Hirsche's character was. It just felt right at the time. This movie however is just so long overdue that it's no longer the cute as a button baby that we would have embraced with open arms had it come out in 1998. Instead, it's an overweight 34 year old man with a mustard stain on his horribly faded Blues Traveler t-shirt. The overall story feels dated, juvenile and ridiculously out of place especially when compared to the films that came in it's wake over the last 20 years like Edge of Tomorrow and Battle Los Angeles which believe it or not is a better film than this. The action is confusing, the story is limp and certain characters make returns only to die or unceremoniously be written out of the story for no real reason at all. There is an extremely interesting side plot dealing with an ground war that the aliens fought with human forces in Africa which would have made an incredible film in and of itself but that bit is forsaken in favor of more cameos and another far more convoluted story line that ends with an even more unbelievable and convoluted cliffhanger. Ultimately I can't really recommend this movie to anyone other than the biggest of big ID4 fans. Independence Day: Resurgence gets a 2... out of 5

Despite expensive and generally good production values, creating some vivid CGI, this movie suffers from an absurd, discordant script and a substandard plot, with so many ludicrous occlusions, and vacuous cinematic dross, that the entire film üé• is reduced to a frustratingly mediocre waste of resources. Direction and acting is straight out of a cheap, rubbishy cartoon comic; a cloying sense of superficial jungle drumming allied to a stultifying sense of vanity gone bananas totally swamps this movie, reducing it to a classic example of profligate cinematic dross. A movie not worth seeing and one to avoid like the plague! Not recommended.

review: Eddie Redmayne as Newt Scamander was just too charming, all fantastic beasts looked magical, and I really liked the inclusion of a no-maj discovering the wonders and dangers of the wizarding world. Also, the fact that the main characters are adult, fully trained wizards gives a whole new experience of magic compared to the years we spent watching mostly magical schoolchildren. The look into a magical government was also nice. The "Fantastic Beasts" part of the film was great. The other part, dealing with society and politics, was quite disappointing. The film tried to include too much to satisfyingly develop all the parts. It's worth watching for Redmayne and the magical animals, though.
mojo_name: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them
rt_name: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them - Movie Reviews

review: I have just finished watching the movie on Prime Video and everything is absolutely fresh in my mind right now. I had no idea what I was going in for. I didn't read the original book or watch any trailer before seeing this movie. All I had heard was that this takes place in the same universe as Harry Potter, which is why I watched it. And honestly speaking, this movie is nothing different from what I expected it would be. The problem with this movie is that it's very, very cliched. It uses those exact plot points that make an annoying movie, well, annoying. That's literally how this movie begins: Making an annoying creature do things for which the protagonist gets in trouble. This is just like how Dobby was in The Chamber of Secrets, except over there he was doing it because he had been asked to do so. The marsupial mole over here wasn't doing it for any particular reason at all, except for being cringy. If I were Newt I'd have just let him get caught and die. And then of course, Newt is unregistered. The way the movie began made it seem like Newt was a complete idiot, except that the whole point behind his character is that he's smart. He's the only one person who cares about the beasts of the magical world unlike the zoophobic wizards. Every species in this whole movie - muggles, wizards, magical creatures - everyone was unlikeable. They all did things which made me want them to get their comeuppance. The only thing that saved this movie for me was the world building. I have heard that the book is actually a guidebook for all the creatures living in their universe. So this, being an adaptation, was the only good part in the entire movie. And it was so beautiful that I enjoyed this otherwise irritating movie. I really wish that was the main focus of the movie instead of them being about fugitives running from the law and something something Ezra Miller. Another thing I really liked about this movie is the depiction of the 1920's America. All the characters looked like they belonged in that age. The ignorant, hateful behaviour of the people from that time was very well depicted, if that was intentional. The acting was great. People reacted just like how they would if the CGI was present before them in real life. Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is a movie that seems to be more oriented for a young audience, since they are the ones who will find it more appealing. It has cool and cute animals, funny scenes, childish storyline and overall the 90's and early 00's vibe to it. It's a one time watch for the adults, since the only good thing to offer for a mature audience is the phenomenal CGI. It won't remain as interesting if watched for a second time, which is why I'd recommend you to not ruin the experience by watching it for the second time.

review: It definitely helped to watch the entire HP series in the days leading up to seeing this movie as I didn't find myself disappointed at all by it. I firmly expected them to not completely recapture the magnetism of the main series as there was practically no chance with an entirely new cast, and I wasn't itching for a continuation of the franchise I'd loved as I'd just seen the old ones. Redmayne made for an enigmatic leading man, though I wasn't enamored with Waterston and I never truly understood the appeal of Farrell. The CGI is very good, particularly the non-creature stuff but the beasts are good too when not sitting right next to a real animal, like the Niffler near the beginning. The clear intent with this one was to worldbuild, which I found mildly unnecessary (and a bit obnoxious with them exchanging Muggle with No-Maj for No-Apparent reason), but I liked the plot itself for the most part too. They seemed to stay a bit too long in the suitcase each time they went as it started to feel like an entire universe was inside and that they may set one of the movies exclusively in there, but that would be so far removed from reality that I doubt it'd be very entertaining. The score was appreciable and the costume design was great.
mojo_name: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them

review: I absolutely loved this film- I was amazed at just how big the wizarding world is, expanding the Harry Potter world we all love. I connect to Newt, Tina, Jacob, Credence and Queenie, all in different ways, which is a fantastic thing and something that is so hard to get. The plot twists are so iconic, from red herrings to super reveals, settings so miraculously done, all the magical creatures, costumes and everything is done to such astounding detail. It kept me gripped for every single second.

review: No story & too much CGI I have to say that I am really disappointed of the movie as a whole. The Harry Potter movies are easily one of the best and most rewatchable movie franchises so far. And this movie is sadly nothing like the original HP movies. The only thing that is has in common are the special effects (for the apparitions). There was no real dialogue between the characters. Just silly one-liners and the occasional humorous remark. I am also very angered by the fact that they just introduced a new concept (obscurials) to the HP franchise that would literally change everything (if obscurials exist why hasn't Harry Potter become one? After all he fits the criteria). There was also way too much CGI in the movie. It became a real nuisance after a while. Especially because it wasn't even "up to today's standards". My final critique concerns the overall flair of the movie. It just didn't feel like it belongs to the magnum opus that is the HP movie franchise. And righteously so; why did they film it in NYC? The HP franchise is the most British thing since James Bond and Doctor Who. I never really realized it before but now that I watched this movie it became very clear to me. You can't just change the location like this and expect the audience to embrace it. Sorry. What's next? Fantastic Beasts in Japan? No thanks. We already have that, it's called Kaiju.

Esta trata sobre el Pr√≠ncipe encantador que quiere venganza por lo ocurrido anteriormente, lo cual me gustaba al inicio como una motivaci√≥n para el villano pero solo lo convirtieron en un tonto en vez de un villano serio e intimidante. Los personajes que nos presentan son mas de lo mismo, que no buscan trabajarlos en su tonalidad y que buscan rellenar la trama con algunos chistes malos e innecesarios; aunque hay chistes muy buenos en la pel√≠cula. Se le puede destacar la animaci√≥n y lo entretenida que puede ser. Los nuevos personajes no me gustaron para nada y tuvieron escenas innecesarias. Sacaron el protagonismo de las otras pel√≠culas que ten√≠a Fiona y eso no me gust√≥ nada. Por ultimo, el final con el discurso de Arturo deja mucho que desear y parece sacado de la nada para darle un final abrupto al conflicto. En conclusi√≥n una mala secuela, siendo la peor de la franquicia, aunque tiene momentos muy divertidos y entretenidos que no igualan a las anteriores y por eso no es tan recordada. Shrek the Third was the first Shrek movie I learnt of. I always used to see the Shrek franchise as something of a fairy tale, one that I can't possibly like. There were many reasons why - Shrek looked ugly, the animation wasn't exactly what I'd call 'gorgeous', and the little me couldn't tolerate seeing a princess beat up soldiers (I know, it happens in Shrek 2 and Shrek the Third but I couldn't tell the difference). So I finally watched it, just to see what all happens in it and why exactly does everyone meme it so much. I liked the first two so much that I decided to watch this movie too, and it was... meh. Shrek the Third started off really well. But the problem with this movie is that, well, it created an expectation too high. The first five minutes were actually very good, with Prince Charming grieving over his mother's death and everyone mocking him. But immediately afterwards it changed to the bad guys deciding to hate him for being bad. This didn't make sense, because that's literally what bad guys do. And then the bad guys unite to wreak havoc and... Remove a stamp? It looked like a joke that could have been in any other movie. Speaking of jokes that could have been in literally any other movie, there are plenty that happen over here. The king dying and then coming back to life before dying properly, Shrek throwing a champagne bottle at a ship making it sink, Puss explaining how babies are made, Shrek and Donkey threatening the librarian (I still remember seeing that scene in the trailer as a kid), Puss and Donkey not being restored to their original bodies completely in the end and of course, the entire plot of Arthur being a loser. But of course this movie isn't absolutely terrible. I really liked the speeches that Arthur gave; once at the campfire when he and Shrek talked about their lives and once in the end where they defeat Prince Charming. The part where Puss tries to look cute when he's in Donkey's body and the soldiers get disgusted was also hilarious. I also enjoyed the part where all the princesses come together to storm the castle. I hated that scene as a kid but now I find it funny. Shrek the Third is the only 3rd movie of a franchise that I have ever realised wasn't as good as the previous ones. I watched Spider-Man 3, Star Wars: Episode VI, Despicable Me 3 and even played Batman: Arkham Origins, and I really liked them all as much as I liked the other two. It doesn't have quite the charm that the first two movies, for that matter all the other three movies have. It's a pity that I really wanted to like this movie, but it seems too mediocre. Although I won't mind watching this again.

This review contains spoilers. According to many Shrek the Third represents the lowest point of the franchise. And they are right. I'm not saying this is a bad movie. It is simply meh. The continuation of the story is perhaps a bit too banal, but in full swing with a familiar continuation. The animations are very good, but nothing comparable to the latest films. The known characters undergo practically no evolution, both Shrek and the others, but donkey always remains the nicest, even if honestly it is less than the other films. the king's death scene is perhaps the most hateful scene in the franchise that wasn't funny at all but just pissed you off. The parody continues, even if it is less intense than the previous ones 2. I don't have much more to say: Arthur is a decent character, Prince Charming doesn't suck as a villain, but he's not on par with his mother and the story is pretty predictable in many places. It seems as if this film is only cheaper than the previous ones by not giving anything really innovative. But it's not bad. it is watchable.

review: Starting with the most important thing about a comedy based movie: this film is endlessly hilarious and even when one joke doesn't work you know there are at least five coming up that will and that when they do work, they REALLY work. This, and the similar ways the premise is used, makes this film very similar to its predecessor but it's not quite as good in a few ways: the characters aren't boring but aren't as fleshed out in some ways, the beginning doesn't set things up badly but it's pretty obvious what will happen and it's a little less funny. Despite this, the movie is still really entertaining through it's fast paced but still mcguffin based plot and really well done performances from everyone involved. On top of this, the movie looks really cool and realistic which adds to the tension it builds, which it does really well especially in the Baboon scene. Although it definitely trys to expand the universe in which it takes place, it definitely could have used some different ideas and a MUCH better villain which is weird because this was my biggest problem with the first one. It builds to a well deserved if not a little long conclusion that left me genuinely happy about the sequel that will hopefully come in a couple of years (with covid you never can tell). What a hilarious fantasy that lives up to the previous' reputation.
rt_name: Jumanji: The Next Level - Movie Reviews

review: A minor improvement upon its predecessor, Jumanji: The Next Level is still good fun but almost an exact carbon copy of its forerunner, that's both its biggest strength and weakness. The cast this time around is even better, returning actors deliver even better performances and the newcomers blend in without any issue. The chemistry they share has gotten even better and it's still a delight to watch! The special effects haven't changed much, they're still phenomenal but not any better than its precursor, mainly the intricate designs for the fictive creatures and the expansive landscapes were pleasing to look at. The pacing, however, is just as awful as the original, it still tries to pull off that videogame level style but hasn't improved in the slightest compared to the original, it's still just as clunky and makes some scenes unbearable to sit through. The life system they introduced before is back and this time they've improved upon it but it's still flawed. The twist of making them swap the number of lives is a unique idea but there's still no form of tension and they again get rid of those lives by killing them off for comedic purposes. The action sequences on the other hand are probably the best part of this movie, especially the bridge escape scene! They're hysterical and chaotic but not to the point where it's unclear what's going on all while making use of each character's unique attributes in a fun and quirky way. The soundtrack was just as much of a banger as before, Guns N' Roses is back and even more fun this time around and the orchestrated themes are even more exhilarating and hype! All in all, Jumanji: The Next Level is a solid thrill a minute blockbuster with enough to leave you satisfied.

review: Jumanji The Next Level - 7.5/10. Jumanji Welcome To The Jungle was one of the best surprises in 2017. The ability to connect with the original Jumanji, while also introducing a new audience to the world of Jumanji through a video game platform was interesting. Next Level returns to the same formula as Welcome to the Jungle, which kind of makes the film lose the charm and unexpected fun that came with the previous film. Next Level delivers on performances again, with Kevin Hart's character mimicking Danny Glover being a huge highlight. The action sequences are fun, but they seem repetitive, as we already had seen these character go through peril before, even with the avatar switched shenanigans making it funny. It's pretty nice to see Karen Gillan and Jack Black being in more of the forefront for the majority of the film, as it helps provide both performers more scope to showcase their comedic talents. As for the film itself, it's still a fun ride with a lot of great jokes, but it's just missing something. It seems like the movie was made as more of a bridge for the sequel (which looks like it will go back to the basics and familiarity for some of the older fans of the series). All in all, Next Level is still a great movie, and definitely a fun film for the whole family!

review: I think this film is really where the series begins to hit it's stride. It has expanded the world from the last film, but not so far as to distract from the story, and at this point, enough of the world has been established that it's not as distracting as it was in Chamber of Secrets. This allows the film just enough room to breath and everything is seemingly working in harmony with each other. While the films have gotten progressively darker, it is done appropriately so. Harry Potter is growing older and more experienced, so his day-to-day problems as a wizard should reflect that--all the while edging closer to his confrontation with "He who won't be named".

review: LUMOS MAXIMA!! Let there be light. The third in the franchise, and we followed Harry Potter and his friends in their third year. It's worth noting that the director changed from Chris Columbus to Alfonso Cuar√≥n. Even though this is the third, I'm still amazed at the new magic tricks that the source material created. They also became goofier and funnier. The CGI was decent for the most part, but some were noticeably bad. The biggest change from the first two was the story, which became more complexed and involved playing with time. This came with a problem for me: in the first hour and a half, I felt like the story was going nowhere, and the pieces were random. However, the ending act tied everything together and explained what happened a lot, perhaps more than it needed to, but probably for the young audiences to follow. Even though it's 20 minutes shorter than the second one, the runtime still felt very long, mostly because of the set up that seemed to go nowhere at first. It would be better if the story moved faster and connected the pieces sooner. Overall, I'm still amazed at how well and creative the script and source material used its universe to entertain audience. The story was more complex, which was good and enjoyable, but nonetheless still felt too long and lost me couple of times. 7/10

review: By now the series has found its sweet spot between dark and light, fear and wonder, childhood and adulthood, strangeness and convention. It's trimmed some of the fat in comparison to the first two films, but is still a little too long - otherwise is probably the series at its peak.

review: After watching The Chamber of Secrets I was a bit skeptical to continue watching the franchise. That was what I had in mind when I began watching this - Will it also show filthy, cringy characters? Is there going to be terrible CGI with literally no beautiful locations? Are there going to be tons of disgusting scenes? Turns out this movie is better in terms of all those things. And definitely worth a watch if you haven't done it already (I know you muts have, I am the only 90's-born stooge who still hasn't watched this series). The story this time takes a much dark, complicated turn. In the beginning of the movie itself Harry kills his aunt, or so it seems since it has been left ambiguously. He doesn't even hesitate from using his magical powers to scare his family anymore, although it is never explained how his uncle knows that he's not allowed to use his powers. This time, just like every other time he is to escape from home and go to Hogwarts station. But this time he does it in a bus being driven by a ghost. I like how every time Harry has to escape from home it always happens in a funny and wholesome manner. Those are the scenes that I could watch forever without getting tired. As the series is progressing, Harry Potter is having a higher budget, which is clearly visible by the fact that now it is following the "show, don't tell" principle of storytelling way more often. And that's why the story is using a lot less runtime giving exposition or conversations but rather on actually doing things. I learnt this the hard way. I was doing my project on my computer while watching the movie on the phone, and I missed a lot of scenes and had to rewind to see them again. This is a habit that I had developed from the last two movies of the franchise. And I'm really happy to see that supposedly the Potterheads must have really enjoyed seeing it in the theatres or wherever they saw it. They wouldn't have wasted any time on the talkikng scenes like sci-fi movies normally do. However, I am more used to having Harry Potter having a simple story, just like the movies of that time like Narnia and Lord of the Rings. I was doing a project while watching the movie on my phone, so I stopped seeing the movie for like, 5 minutes and by then everything had changed. I never understood when Harry and Hermione went to the past and what exactly were they trying to change. I also didn't know who that guy was who sat on the flying creature and flew away. Also what finally happened of the Dementor, I completely missed out on that part. There is something about the Harry Potter movies that stops me from wanting to watch them, and I have no idea why. I also get this feeling with Stuart Little and Narnia. So I can't say for a guarantee that I will rewatch it to watch the scenes that I skipped. Although this movie is a major improvement over Chamber of Secrets, it doesn't match the standard that Sorcerer's Stone has set. I have heard enough about Harry Potter and how much it means to everyone, but personally for me it's not a franchsie I could possibly bond with for some reason. I hope I change my mind soon after future movies.
mojo_name: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban

review: Captain Jack Sparrow is back, along with Will Turner's son, Henry, in search of Poseidon's Trident. Johnny Depp reprises his role as Sparrow, but doesn't succeed at giving the character the charm he has from the first movie in the franchise, though it may be the way the character is written. Javier Bardem plays the villain well, but some spoken lines early in the movie were hard for me to understand. Geoffrey Rush does a great job as always. The writing for this film seemed to make things up as the movie went on instead of maintaining or expanding the lore from the previous films, like playing a game that the rules change while you're playing, it wasn't really fun. The design of the villain and his crew was interesting to look at. If you're a huge fan of the franchise, then check this movie out.

review: This film revamped my love for the POTC franchise! It had everything I loved from the first two movies: belly-aching comedy, chaotic action scenes, a villain that strikes fear even in the viewers, the genius Jack Sparrow in his purest drunk-haze form, and a story line that follows all the original, beloved characters. Most of these things were absent in On Stranger Tides, which left a hole in the franchise in my opinion. Perhaps the most uplifting part about this film was the emphasis on family and how family means sacrifice. It's funny how a family can melt a Pirate's ruthless heart of gold.

review: Pirates of the Caribbean Review: Pirates of the Caribbean, is a saga of 5 films, where we can see how Captain Jack Sparrow with several characters that accompany him such as William Turner III, Elizabeth Swann, Joshamee Gibbs, Calypso, H√©ctor Barbossa, among some others who help him or are with Jack, it depends on the movie, it's the characters. Barbosa is the character who wants to kill Jack (because everyone always wants to kill him). In the first movie, Jack wants to recover his ship, which is "the black pearl" that is commanded by Barbosa (in that movie the bad guy) whose character is hated, but in the end we all love him, he kidnaps Elizabeth (thinking that his last name was Turner), which continues to appear in the other films. review: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales Pirates of the Caribbean is an adventure and fantasy film by director Joachim R√∏nning. There are many famous actors in this film. Johnny Depp as Captain Jack Sparrow, Javier Bardem as Captain Armando Salazar, Geoffrey Rush as Captain Hector Barbossa, Brenton Thwaites as Henry Turner, Kaya Scodelario as Carina Smyth. The plot is very unpredictable. The undead Captain of the Silent Mary who seeks revenge on Jack Sparrow and try to steal the Trident of Poseidon to kill every pirate at sea. All the battles take place in the sea, which is very unusual. Dialogues between the characters are on pirate jargon with hard humor. It looks very convincing. Also, there are many surprising moments, for example, the death of one of the main characters. The end of the movie was amazing. While watching a film, you can't get dull. In conclusion, there are very few films in the world that look like Pirates of the Caribbean. I really enjoyed it and I'm looking forward to the next part.

Mac and Me was released in 1988 and was a blatant rip off of E.T. This movie is a true masterpiece. I first saw it back in 1994 and it stuck with me since then. I miss those times terribly, however I can imagine how amazing it would have been to see it in cinemas back then! It is one of the best films ever created accompanied by one of the best soundtracks to ever be recorded. En cuanto a lo que no me gust√≥ es que algunas escenas duran mucho m√°s de lo necesario (la persecuci√≥n en bicicleta o mucho del inicio de la pel√≠cula que me pareci√≥ muy lenta) y algunos de los actores j√≥venes ofrecen actuaciones no muy buenas (a pesar de esto, Drew Barrymore es genial). A heartwarming tale of a young boy who befriends an illegal immigrant who is wanted by the government for crossing the U.S. Border.

[‚≠êÔ∏è98%] Many look back upon E.T. with much nostalgia, and rightly so, it has something for everybody. Not only is it a perfectly crafted story but the emotional impact is dialled up to 100%, largely thanks to young Henry Thomas delivering one of the greatest child actor performances of all time, his relationship he builds with E.T. is the spine of the film and an intricate part of the movies success and pedigree to this day. E.T. the Extra Terrestrial (1982) truly is a masterpiece which has aged magnificently, no matter how many times one watches it, they will always feel the happiness and sadness of the beautiful story told. You would be heartless if you felt no sort of emotion throughout its runtime.
E. T is the best movie to show the typical charm and imagination of the childhood (all of this showed by a director with a the right vision of these values). 10/10

E.T. is typical of much of Steven Spielberg's early work ‚Äì it telegraphs exactly how you should be feeling at any given time, thanks mostly to John William's score, which provides guidance and direction on what emotions you should be tapping into. Despite Spielberg's penchant for cheap manipulation, E.T. is actually a pretty good movie and manages to hit most of the right notes. It's the story of an alien who's been left behind after his ship departs Earth in a hurry after a threat from humankind and the relationship he develops with the young boy who finds him. Some scenes go on for far longer than necessary (the bike chase, for example) and some of the young actors give less than stellar performances (despite this, Drew Barrymore is great), but, overall, it's an entertaining family film that leaves you feeling satisfied, for the most part.

Simply put, ET. THE Extra Terrestrial is THE best film of the 1980's and one of the greatest American films of all time, as well as one of the most beautiful and innocent. It really deserved to win both the Best Picture and Best Director Academy Awards of 1982 over Ghandi. And Drew Barrymore deserved an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress. Her performance at SIX years old is simply amazing and so natural. Here in 2021 it's easily forgotten what an event ET was during the summer of 1982.....and the fact that it held the top spot on the worldwide and domestic box office for a staggering record of 15 years, until the release of Star Wars in January 1997. Any film holding the domestic box office record for 15 years now is unthinkable....although The Force Awakens $936 million seems completely untouchable now. People also forget ET was really a tiny little film, made for under 10 million dollars in 1982...somewhat low budget even in 1982. But with the king of the box office, Steven Spielberg at the helm and John Williams' INCREDIBLE Oscar winning score, ET soars like a $100 million dollar film. It's larger than life. And while we're talking about John Williams' score, incredible, powerful, triumphant and heartbreaking all at the same time. I would call his music to ET the greatest film score of all time if it weren't for Star Wars (1977). Most of us who grew up with the film know all the stories about the inception, inspiration and production of the film so theres no reason to repeat what countless reviews have said about the film. This review is strictly about the importance of the film and the pop culture phenomenon it became. Those of us who are lucky to be old enough to have seen it during it's original theatrical run in the summer of 1982 will never forget the experience. It's one of the most vivid memories from my early childhood. I remember it like it was yesterday. I saw ET for the first time on my 5th birthday, July 19th 1982. I was taken to Walmart before the film for a Skelator He-Man action figure and Castle Greyskull playset. I went to see it at the Belle Meade Theater in Nashville Tennessee, one of the oldest and nicest theaters in the south. I remember bouncing out of the car in excitement, the hot, humid summer evening air hitting me, and the bright orange summer sunset. We sat in the upper balcony, which was my first experience in a theater like that. I cried the entire way home, and my mother had to read me the ET storybook to get me to fall asleep. There are some things you never forget. And the first time seeing this beautiful film is a memory those of us 43 and older will never forget. ET will always be the true box office champ to me. And if you disliked or hated this wonderful achievement in filmmaking then I feel sorry for you because you have a cold, black heart.

Reviewed 9.3.21  This film recently appeared on a list of top 25 all-time action movies.  And if action is simply what you're after, mission accomplished.  Tom Cruise continues his run of insane stunts, this time jumping solo from 30,000 feet.  While the rest of the white-knuckled action is spread throughout the ever-expanding cast of MI characters.   The most notable additions in this installment are Vanessa Kirby as a mysterious intermediary, and Henry Cavill as a supposed CIA hitmen that plays more like an alpha male meathead. Kirby adds to what was already a phenomenal female talent pool, and for my money, is the real reason to continue to give these movies a chance.  Kudos to Cruise and the MI producers for helming a series that offers up female roles on par with their male counterparts.  And within the storylines themselves, it's the femmes that truly rule this former boys club, and the entire production is better for it.   Unfortunately the main storyline of a nuclear arsenal gone rouge falls flat.  Been there, done that.  After a slow start dominated by unnecessary mansplaining of the overly convoluted plot, things eventually settle in.  And they do mostly stick the landing, with an ending that wisely returns to the emotional bond of the MI core.

If you've sought to avoid the Mission: Impossible franchise, or Tom Cruise himself, this film offers is a safe opportunity to reconsider. At this age and at this stage Cruise brings a contagious onscreen effervescence, and I say that as a guy who doesn't say effervescent much. McQuarrie's plot and script are as tight as they are charming, bringing drama and levity in apposite doses. And, of course, I love any really good guy flick that I can enjoy with my wife and daughters!

The best Mission: Impossible movie and one of the best action movies. Fallout delivers on every category: the action sequences are the best of the franchise and there are so many standouts like the HALO jump, bathroom fight, Paris chase, rooftop chase and the helicopter chase. Each action scene is better than the previous and they build up in intensity. Every actor delivers excellent performances, it was great seeing Julia and Ethan's relationship developed, it's perfectly paced and structured and it's a thrilling ride that leaves you on the edge of your seat even if it's predictable. The score is also absolutely phenomenal and truly carries a lot of scenes and McQuarrie really seemed to improve his directing. It's such a beautifully shot and edited movie you can't help but keep your eyes off it. What a phenomenal movie in every way! I don't know how they'll top this one.

One of the best directed action movies in recent years, certainly one of the best in this decade. Usually, sequels get worse and worse. Mission Impossible is the one of few movies I can think of that gets better and better with each part. It's almost unbelievable that the sixth sequel to any franchise looks this good and fresh. Interestingly, the director changed for each film in the series and this film is the first where the director team remained the same. The last three are very good, and this one is probably the best in terms of quality. An interesting story that requires attention, tense action scenes that are at the highest level. I must also mention Tom Cruise who is a masterful actor as well as an action star who participates in various stunts. Shooting, driving, racing, jumping, parkour, flying, the character did absolutely everything in a very tense film through his 140 minutes, which is not a small amount for an action film. one of the most appreciated things about Cruise is that what he does onscreen is real. He really does those leaps between buildings. (He broke his ankle on one of those leaps and shut down production for seven weeks.) He really does drive a motorcycle at high speeds against traffic. He really does fly a helicopter. Who knows what motivates this guy, but the results are incredible. The music, the stunts, the actors, the cities, and the landscapes. Everything was put together amazingly well. And an ending scene that you will never forget. And, some people may find the plot quite complicated, and it is. You really need to pay attention. I recommend watching MI5, and, if you have time, all the others. There is a reference to all of them along with the movie.

2012 is enjoyable trash that I've watched dozens of times. It's laughable at times, yet thoroughly enjoyable if you don't take it seriously. It's a mix of a really interesting premise with a mess of completely unrealistic actions scenes and subpar acting. The first 30-45 minutes are actually pretty engaging. I really enjoyed the buildup and the scientific findings. Then, it just turns into a comedy fest with a father protecting his family from near-death every five minutes. I mean, if this were to have been even the slightest bit realistic, it probably would've been regarded as a great end of the world flick. Instead, the directors chose to go with the typical Hollywood approach of over-glorifying chaotic action with no regard for plot/writing. However, said actions scenes are highly entertaining in my opinion and the ending gives you the payoff of a "warm, fuzzy climax", while also completely unrealistic. I regularly throw this movie on to watch in the background when I want to mindlessly watch something and for that reason alone, it's worth a watch. If you're expecting to find Oscar winning-worth performances, with a brilliant cast and writing, this probably isn't the movie for you.

If - like Roland Emmerich - you're going to fashion a career from making the same movie over and over again, you could do worse than this Carry On Armageddon. Once again a shopping list of different storylines somehow converge on The White House and a president who whispers every platitude (Danny Glover). The ostensible lead is John Cusack, juggling family, winnebagoes, and a bonkers bearded soothsayer (Woody Harrelson). Good CGI, long stretches where characters talk very slowly and with rather too much emotion, and a wasted George Segal. Very long, very Emmerich.

This movie has plenty of problems, but the special effects and hyperactive plot is enough to keep anyone watching. And I'll admit, I still come back to this movie to re-watch when I want to pass some time and satisfy disaster movie cravings. 2012 has a disaster for almost everyone. You want volcanic eruptions? Check. How about megatsunamis? It's all there. I feel like that plays a big role in why I still enjoy coming back to the movie despite it not having much of anything else going for it. I'm a sucker for disaster movies. The special effects are quite spectacular. I would even say almost too over-the-top at times. But it's certainly enough to keep anyone from turning the movie off immediately. It also helps to distract from a not so great plot, which is riddled with plenty of cliches that are all too familiar in the genre. I am a scientist, and so I'm always analyzing the science behind these movies. Of course, it's science-fiction though, so it's not exactly going to hit it right on the head. I would just love to see more movies out there that are less "fiction-y" and more realistic. On the flip side of the coin, while the events that transpire in the movie stem from a fictional concept, I applaud the writers for coming up with something that's not horribly derivative. Can't say I've seen a disaster flick where the end of the world is caused by neutrinos heating up the Earth's core! Everything thing else... though, is more derivative and highly predictable. I feel like some of the conflicts in the plot are a bit overdone, cliche, or otherwise unnecessary. Nonetheless, it's a disaster flick that I won't stop watching anytime soon!

I almost feel bad giving three stars to a movie that cost $200 million. On the other hand, it grossed $769 million worldwide, so that makes me feel a little better. I tried to watch this movie a few years ago. I turned it off about halfway through, just because I was weary of the CGI special effects. They're so much like watching a cartoon. This is, without doubt, the most over the top disaster film ever made. The entire city of Los Angeles slides into the ocean, Washington D.C is obliterated, and I've lost count of the other cataclysms, but there are dozens of them. As to the characters, there is a family with young kids (there always is), the U.S president, brilliant scientists (of course), and thousands of extras, most of whom get pummeled to smithereens by toppling skyscrapers or tsunamis or exploding volcanos. Oh yeah, a giant cruise ship gets decimated by a tsunami. I liked that. I've always hated cruise ships. This movie will certainly give you your money's worth. But it's basically a 2 1/2 hour cartoon. Not a funny one, either. And there's obviously no point in raising the issue of plausibility. Cartoon's aren't supposed to be plausible.

YES, YES, YES... it's totally unbelievable, unrealistic, has over the top disasters. However it is a seriously end of the world, great CGI, disastrously, feel-good, action packed, fast and fun movie to watch and on my list of disaster repeats.
It's a guilty pleasure popcorn üçø flick with tons of dumb fun & illogical inaccuracies...

Roland Emmerich delivers an apocalyptic adventure to viewers in this intense, explosive catastrophe. The film makes use of various world-ending prophecies, including the Mayan calendar to rip cities in half and crumble monuments to the ground. '2012' follows various characters across the globe as they race to save whatever's left of humanity. The film opens in India, where Dr Adrian Helmsley is called to the world's deepest copper mine, only to discover the Earth's crust is heating up quicker than expected and must rush back to the United States and present this information to the President (Danny Glover). On the other side of the country, in sunny Los Angeles, is failed author and limousine driver, Jackson Curtis. While camping with his kids, Jackson meets Charlie Frost (Woody Harrelson), a man who preaches that the end is near. What happens next leads Jackson and his family on a globe-trotting adventure to China for a shot at survival. As Jackson makes his way across the globe, Government officials Chiwetel Ejiofor and Oliver Platt try to save what they can, all the while trying to maintain law and order. Despite '2012' being a high-octane action film, Emmerich still manages to display emotion. Final phone calls to loved ones provide a sense of closure to some characters, while for others, it fills them with sorrow and guilt. The 158-minute runtime can't help but drag on, and there's a few unnecessary scenes and lines of dialogue that could've been skipped. The visual effects throughout the film are incredible, even with a few issues here and there. They're extremely detailed and do a great job of getting across just how much damage has occurred all around these characters. Co-writers Harald Kloser and Thomas Wander provide '2012' with a decent score that compliments the chaotic atmosphere of what's going on on-screen. Chiwetel Ejiofor gives a great performance as Dr Adrian Helmsley, starring opposite Oliver Platt, who gives an acerbic performance as Carl Anheuser. Glover shares a heart-wrenching scene in the White House chapel with Ejiofor, where he says 'I'll be the last President of the United States of America, do you know how that feels?' A quote like that makes viewers realise the magnitude of what's happening. John Cusack gives a superb performance as Jackson Curtis, a divorced father of two who just wants to maintain a good rapport with his kids. Oh, and if you recognise the name Jackson Curtis, that's because the character is named after the rapper 50 Cent. Emmerich was a big fan of the rapper and wanted to name his lead character after him. Something that Emmerich did well with '2012' is he gave viewers two different points of view. One from the more public, working-class side and the other from the up-high, government officials. That's something that not many action films do. Despite the film mentioning the Mayan calendar and culture, the Mayans didn't actually say that the world would end in 2012. Unless you include the end of the world, the main theme throughout '2012' would be family. Jackson Curtis tries to save his family and Adrian Helmsley gets to say goodbye to his father. Tony Delgatto (played by the late George Segal) tries to reconcile with his estranged son before being abruptly cut off. The film provokes the idea that your wealth and/or job can determine your survival, and when in extreme situations, people are willing to put a price on life, ‚Ç¨1 billion per person to be exact. There were production plans for a TV sequel titled '2013', but it was cancelled due to budgetary reasons. In conclusion, '2012' is a chaotic catastrophe with fiery scenery and heart-warming familial moments. The film features good performances from the entire cast and keeps an equal focus on both the ends of the world, and the people who are desperate to survive.

review: With hideous CGI, an all too familiar story, and just uninteresting new additions to the Indiana Jones saga, "Kingdom of the Crystal Skull" is a significant downgrade compared to the others. Overused CGI bogs this film down the most, though the ridiculous plot about aliens in a Mayan temple also brings the movie down significantly. The villain is also not that interesting, and the entire story doesn't feel very original, riddled with plot clich√©s and conveniences throughout. About the only good things in this film are the action and the humor, which I think still lands. Where this movie is strongest is when it strays from the whole "alien" main plot. In the end, while I enjoyed some of this film, it just isn't nearly as good when compared to the others.

review: It was at least nice to see Indy and Marian get back together, although it's impossible to believe two such awesome characters would produce a kid as dorky as Shia LaBeouf. review: Maybe it's because I had an Indiana Jones lunch box in grade school that leads me to not fully understand the hate this chapter in Indiana Jones gets. I felt it was still a fairly decent movie that is straightforward, well paced, and coherent and that is more than can be said for a lot of other movies of today. It's just not close to being better than anything else in the franchise. Truth be told, that monkey vine swinging scene was pretty bad.

review: I feel really sorry for all of those for whom this one dind't cut it. I DO understand the points they make. Neither did I fully enjoy the maya-alien plot nor every action scene in this. Shia was miscast and his performance didn't help in the slightest to make up for that. It's not a bad performance, but he's all over the map. The material he had to work with was not strong to begin with, however. Indiana Jones was something, a David Koepp script couldn't fix. The CGI gets a lot of flac for a couple of mild blunders (compared to actually bad CGI), but really isn't that bad. The departure in the end is pretty amazing. Overall this doesn't compare to its 3 predecessors. Yet, I keep revisting this movie because watching Spielberg fail is still way more entertaining than watching other directors peak. There is still much to love about this. It is by far one of the best adventure movies of the 2000s. If it had been an off brand adventure flick, people would hold it in high regards. Yet, under the weight of an Indiana Jones film, the standards are higher.

I watched a long time ago and I had a conflict about this film, I couldn't understand why Spider-Man 2 was considered one of the best superhero movie ever. I'll be honest, I was a kid and I didn't process the film like this days, that doesn't mean that the film didn't like in that moment. Now days, I get on the train to swear that Spider-Man 2 is the best Marvel film ever. It's an amazing mix of genre which has you on the edge of your sit during all the film. It'll thrill you, it'll make you sad, it'll amuse you, it'll make you jump out of your seat in excitement. It could be said that I am exaggerating but this film is perfect in every single aspect, the script, directing, cinematography, visual effects, the performances, editing, sound and soundtrack, achieving an unique style to be the benchmark talking about Spider-Man. It squeezes all your feelings while with a gorgeous eloquence speaks us about the importance of kindness above all. It could be summarized with great tenderness with the next verse. "I believe there's a hero in all of us, that keeps us honest, gives us strength, makes us noble and finally allows us to die with pride. Even though sometimes we have to be steady and give up the thing that we want the most. Even our dreams "

Probably the best movie out of the trilogy. Peter Parker is now graduated and is struggling to live on his own, he is struggling love wise as he cannot express his real feeling towards Mary Jane Watson, this causes Peter Parker to become a really stressed person which leads him to struggle with his responsibility to be Spider-Man, he is losing his friends as they start losing trust in him. Villain wise this is probably the best out of the 3, it goes really into detail of why the villain is the villain and later on realizes all of the actions and damage he has done which makes the villain start having inner conflicts with himself as he has to pick to archive his dreams or keep humanity safe.

An improvement to the original one, "Spiderman 2" brings yet another memorable villain, with an emotional and compelling story and great action while still continuing the story perfectly from the previous installment. The acting is still perfect, and the expanding of the universe is done very well. Much like the original, the CGI still feels a bit outdated to today's standards, though it was decent enough for its time. The plot and story is arguably better, and the villain is about as well done as Green Goblin, if not better in some ways. In the end, I really loved this film, and I think it stands as one of, if not the absolute best, "Spiderman" film ever made.

Wow, so much better than the first one! Not a masterpiece but just a hell of a lot more fun. The first 30 minutes of the movie are an absolute blast, with real humor that lets Tobey Maguire take himself a little less seriously for a while. It starts dragging a little bit as the plot picks up, strangely, but it's got bright spots here and there until the end. Alfred Molina is all around pleasant as Doc Ock, although he comes off as a little cartoonish at times. J K Simmons is amazing as always, and I appreciated the Bruce Campbell cameo. Kristen Dunst is still passable as best, although her one-dimensional, male-dominated dialogue doesn't help. Tobey Maguire still can't make facial expressions. This movie tries to introduce some interesting ideas about mental health, responsibility, and self-care, but doesn't really develop them into anything more than "Spider-Man kicks ass whenever the plot needs him to." Peter has a bit of character development, but he tries his darndest to avoid it until circumstances force it on him. The ending is somewhat satisfying but overly cheesy for my taste. With vastly improved visuals, comedy, and characters, Spider-Man 2 is flawed but still miles ahead of its predecessor.
Spider-Man 2 is not only the best superhero movie of all time, but it's a great movie nonetheless.

It's nice when a niche movie is confident to wear its own identity loud and proud, and this was one of the main reasons why so many, myself included, loved the Sam Raimi Spiderman film from 2001. It doesn't hurt that the film was a solid bit of what I like to call Uplifting Blockbuster entertainment, but Spiderman 2 keeps what worked with the first and adds depth and greater dimension. The villain has gone from a Charismatic Evil Baddie to a Charismatic Morally-Conflicted Baddie, the evolution of Peter and his friend Harry feels logical and realistically painful, the relationship between Peter and MJ is genuinely sweet, and even Aunt May is given a lot more time to showcase her character, and her inner strength, and her scenes with Peter about his confession to her are a serious emotional gut-punch, flawlessly and organically fused with what is otherwise a feel-good superhero action flick. Let's also throw in the fact that the CGI is a massive step-up, particularly in regards to the character animation, the action scenes are notably more intricately designed and the setpieces are actually more inventive and climactic. There's also a Transition involving sunglasses that might be my favorite Transition of any movie (or anywhere outside of some used in Sherlock). This is filmmaking at its most confident and free-flowing, and Sam Raimi is one of the best quirky filmmakers of all time, effortlessly fusing a unique and offbeat sense of fun with a big-budget adventure movie for mass audiences. If you like the genre, and don't need it to be ultra dark and pensive (the latter of which this movie sometimes is, mind you), then this is an absolute must-see, along with the first.
It's still crowned to be the best Spider-man movie, it's darker, more interesting villian "Doctor Octopus" and the realtionship between Peter and Mary is better, Franco did a really good job.

Considered as one of the best superhero films of all time and winner of the Best Visual Effects Oscar in 2005, this second installment in the Sam Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy follows Peter Parker, now dissatisfied with life when he loses his job, the love of his life, Mary Jane, and his powers. And amid all the chaos, he must fight Doctor Octavius who threatens to destroy New York City. This movie's villain has a strong character development from beginning to end in its depiction as a conflicted antihero and now is one of the best superhero villains ever, a portrayal Alfred Molina should always feel proud of. The action sequences are great and the plot is captivating, with the train scene being one of the most memorable Spidey moments ever.

It's unanimous that Spider-Man 2 is better than its predecessor. The villain is better, Dr. Octopus is as imposing as Green Goblin and I could take him seriously, there are genuinely heart-touching moments that were almost absent in the first film, and the final 50 minutes are a spectacle. But the other side of the movie, Peter Parker's personal drama, is, like in the first film, hard to watch. Tobey and Kirsten still don't have chemistry, and consequently, the romance arc is, again, dragged (I missed Dr. Octopus during a moment). And Tobey Maguire, despite everything, is not a good actor, it's hard to empathize with him. Aunt May (looks more like grandma May) and J.K. Simmons are even better, and the newspaper boss is even funnier.

This just may be the best comic book movie of all time besides Infinity War and Endgame. Danny Elfman returns to expand upon his already incredible score while Tobey Maguire and Alfred Molina both shine as the two biggest parts of the movie. Even Sam Raimi does a better job directing this one than the first. Almost everything about this movie is great and I still think this is the best Spider-Man movie to date.

There was a lot to like in this movie, that's for sure. I very much appreciate how they've developed characters in a way that any interaction between two of them feels like fanservice. I didn't think I'd appreciate the addition of The Rock as much as I ended up liking him and while I love the previous composer, I loved the addition of the grungey rock segments in the film score. The prison fight scene with Brian pulled me out of the movie as it was too obvious that they had sped up the framrate to make the movements appear faster and more violent than they were and throughout the movie the choreography involved fight moves clearly pulled right out of WWE, like the dropkick/elbow drop combo and the chokeslam and the freaking diving headbutt of all things that took away from the realism in a way that I disliked. I also thought it was absolutely implausible that The Rock's character would agree to let the bad guy go after chasing him for so long when it literally meant endangering millions of people all for one person as that's a stupid character arc and an objectively poor decision. He should've just shot the dude right away before he could call the kidnapper since that's pretty much how they prevented Mia's death anyway, jamming his phone. And the bad guy's radical switch from calculated smart guy to bloodthirsty dumb guy was poorly written. The action scenes were probably the best of the series so far though, and it was an enjoyable viewing experience overall.

An amazing sequel to the first film, bringing in more mutants and exploring more of deadpools connection with the x-men. The continuation of comedic references of different films and different film universes makes for a good laugh just as it did for the first film. the film continues to find ways to make sure that deadpool remains to be both a villain and a hero as his character is in the comics.

It is not very common for highly successful superhero movies that explore a new genre have an equally successful sequel. Superman and Superman II, Iron Man and Iron Man 2, Man of Steel and Batman v Superman, there are plenty of examples where a great movie is followed by a mediocre or even a bad sequel. But this one is definitely not one of them. Rather I like Deadpool 2 more than its prequel. Since the previous movie was more set up in order to give an origin story and have the regular good guy vs bad guy fight, it did not have much time to explore over its humour. And this is exactly where Deadpool 2 does the job. The story revolves around Wade Wilson once again with his popping over his wife's death by a bunch of mercenaries and alongside that he is trying to save a boy from becoming a supervillain and getting killed by Cable. This movie it takes itself very lightly just like the prequel and breaks the fourth wall continuously as the story passes by. There is even a joke on Josh Brolin playing the role of cable as Deadpool says, "Suck it, Thanos!". Multiple comic scenes take place throughout the movie e which include the formation of the X-Force, Deadpool being made an X-Men trainee and no one taking him seriously, Wade Wilson been sent to prison, Deadpool fighting Cable and releasing all the mutants only to be ripped in half by Juggernaut and Deadpool growing out as a baby from the bottom half. The action scenes of this movie are even better than the previous one. I really like the scene from the beginning of the movie where Deadpool is fighting a bunch of Yakuzas in Osaka. The camera revolves around Deadpool as he slices down all the man who have come to save the leader. When juggernaut and colossus are about to fight Deadpool says, "Big CGI fight coming up!". When he is about to fight cable for the first time, Cable ask him who he is to which he replies, "I am Batman!". Overall there are multiple action comedy scenes sprinkled all across the movie. The movie also gives an important message, which is not something we normally see in an X-Men movie. Deadpool tells Russell to let the headmaster live, as killing him would send him on the path of villainy from which it will be impossible to come back. Instead of Russell Deadpool chooses to take the bullet from Cable and his death becomes the reason why Russell chooses to give up killing and become a good person instead. This also saves Cable's family from dying and he can go back in peace. But soon afterwards that message is discarded after the headmaster is run over by Dopinder's taxi, thus fulfilling his dream of becoming a contract killer. Deadpool 2, being the movie for a mature audience as it is, is hard to think of home to watch with, considering such a movie cannot be watched with the family and friends have watched it anyway. This is the reason why it's a good thing they decided to make a sequel of this movie and connect it to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. If Dark Phoenix and The New Mutants were not made, this could have been the most perfect way to culminate the X-Men franchise and merge it with the remaining Marvel Cinematic Universe. I can't wait to watch more of this.
One of those extraordinary films that is hilarious, clever, visually stunning and emotionally potent too! The most enjoyable superhero movie.

Deadpool shows the power of a well-written screenplay, which is fast, sharp, incredibly funny and immensely self-aware without ever staying in the dreaded "meta" zone for more than a few seconds at a time (like Deadpool mocking Ryan Reynolds as only being successful because he's good looking). The main hero has a woefully cynical worldview, but he is actually extremely observant, and isn't just cynical due to viewing the world via an emotional skew - there is bad in the world, from the little injustices that everybody simply lets go, to the uneven value placed on human lives based on the circumstances, and his dark jokes about these things actually feel like a raunchier version of something George Carlin might have come up with. And on that note, yes - This movie is overpoweringly raunchy, so if this is not something you enjoy, then you have no business being here. Luckily, the movie has a lot more than just comedy to offer. It features a surprisingly somber story of a mildly deformed man running away from the eyes of the one he loves, which is actually quite touching. And along with that, the movie has a fair amount of action and some moments of genuine intensity, and both of these aspects are very well done; while Tim Miller might have made the most Poorly-Directed Terminator movie with Dark Fate, his Directing of Deadpool is absolutely spot-on, nailing the humor, heart and adrenaline almost flawlessly. It's not a perfect movie, but mostly because its unique and extreme style of humor, much of it winking to the camera, is so consistent that it does eventually get slightly tiresome - it's like listening to 3 Weird-Al albums back-to-back; it's always funny, but the humor is so consistent that it just wears off after a while. But if ultra-dark and raunchy humor work for you, as does some surprisingly brutal violence, then I cannot recommend Deadpool enough. I absolutely loved it and plan on watching it numerous times moving forward.

A total cotton candy movie but that's still one very enjoyable carnival treat. The only ding I have to give is the dated look of some of the sequences especially the final action scene. A lot has been said about this movie so I'll leave it at this: watch this movie if for no other reason than to see what all the fuss is about. You'll at least appreciate the Star Wars culture and you may become a fan yourself.

review: A unique and influential film that still continues to affect the world today, "A New Hope" remains one of the strongest "Star Wars" films to this day, providing insanely iconic scenes, lines, and characters that many people who haven't even seen the movie can recognize. The acting is done very well, and the worldbuilding is one of the best. This film also perfectly sets up the rest of the saga, introducing new characters and places while still leaving room for tons more to be added. The story and plot does begin to slow down after the second act finished, though it quickly picks up again during the attack on the Death Star. Overall, just a great film that continues to remain a timeless classic.

review: George Lucas isn't quite the most creative person in the history of Hollywood, but he was creative in the exact right way at the exact right time, inventing not only a unique fusion of genres (that proved way more successful than even he could have imagined) but a new type of special effects approach (moving the camera around an object, rather than the opposite like everyone else). The original Star Wars represents the pinnacle of a simple story with a hidden depth when examined closer. The world is well realized, the villains incredibly intimidating and memorable, what is and is-not possible is well established quickly, and it largely plays out as a feel-good movie with a few moments of genuine tension or drama. Mix in good performances, likable characters, awesome action sequences and some of the best audio (both music and sound effects) of any movie, and you've got a movie that has, and will forever, stand the test of time.

review: [‚≠êÔ∏è96%] Instantly viewers fell in love with the Star Wars universe thanks to A New Hope's (1977) fantastic immediate world building, all done in a natural way thanks to a great plot which takes the characters to necessary places for events to play out. All of the development for the Galaxy, force and many other aspects is done in a very efficient way which allows the viewer to be excited for an expanding galaxy and hence why the franchise still runs over 40 years after this film. Given the year it was made, 1997, this movie has some very impressive special effects, better than some you see nowadays in 2021. Despite limited screen time, Darth Vader immediately established himself as a legendary villain thanks to his menacing presence and his ability to steal every scene he is in. You couldn't ask for a better introduction to one of the most influential franchises of all time.

review: A legendary ambitious start to the ever-expanding star wars saga, George Lucas opened our eyes to new possibilities of blockbuster filmmaking and things have never been the same since audiences have seen that opening crawl for the first time. Starting in the middle of the story(Episode IV) It is a thrilling adventure of young farmboy Luke Skywalker who with the help of old Jedi master obi-wan Kenobi follows his hero's journey and begins learning the ways of the force and become a Jedi himself as he and hotshot smuggler Han solo along with wookie Chewbacca(captain and co-pilot of the Millennium Falcon), work together with the companionable droid duo of R2-D2 and C-3PO to rescue princess leia, and help the Rebel Alliance in their fight to restore freedom and justice to the Galaxy as they go up against menacing Darth Vader and his waves of imperial storm troopers. The story is a perfect morality tale as good goes up against evil and it feeds people's hunger for adventure, thrills ,and comedy. This 1977 film is a classic and with the story, John William's brilliant musical scores and the huge leaps that it takes with special effects and other filmmaking techniques(which were many building blocks towards even better techniques for modern filmmaking) this film will live on in people's hearts and minds for generations but don't take my word for it, go out there and see it for yourself!!! no longer will you have to fear about not knowing what the force is or what a wookie is or even how many languages C-3P0 can speak, this film is the perfect first steps into a larger world! May the force be with you,Always!
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope
rt_name: Star Wars: Episode IV -- A New Hope - Movie Reviews

review: Some kind of movie magic happened when Star Wars was made. From the reported chaos of its production, somehow everything fell into place by the time the final film was released: the perfect cast, groundbreaking special effects, amazing sound effects, great editing, an awesome music score and a fantastic adventure story with not one, but two, very different heroes taking centre stage. Star Wars has a level of realism, showing us a futuristic world where technology is fully integrated into people's daily lives, and everything has a ‚Äòused' look that made it seem very real. The iconic opening shot, with an absurdly massive Star Destroyer crawling across the screen in chase of some hopelessly outgunned little space ship, informed us that this was a world unlike any we had seen before - a place far, far away and in another time, just as the opening credits had promised. The central robot characters R2D2 and C-3PO were both believable and likeable. It was an inspired choice to have only one of the robot speak English, with the other one left to communicate through simple electronic beeps, leaving us searching for meaning in the robot's simple movements and head turns. Mark Hamill was perfectly cast as Luke Skywalker, the naive young farm boy who gets caught up in a galactic war with rebellious freedom fighters. Hamill's boyish good looks made him very relatable to the young fan base, many of whom dreamed of being Luke Skywalker long after they had left the movie theatre. Carrie Fisher was also good as the beautiful but sassy Princess Leia, and Harrison Ford announced his arrival as the alternate hero Han Solo. The story never labours, instead moving at a solid pace as one small adventure unfolds into the next. There are moments of genuine emotional depth, such as when Luke looks out over the Tatooine landscape towards the planets dual setting suns. as if longing for the future to arrive. There is also great action and adventure as the movie progresses to it climatic battle against the awesome Death Star. Star Wars still looks fresh today, and can be enjoyed over and over again.

review: Maybe it's wrong of me to criticize the storytelling in a film when the film itself is just an adaptation of what must be a really awful book to start with. But what the hell, here goes. . Americans seem to really love their treasure hunts don't they? But believing that people centuries ago sprinkled clues throughout their work, trusting that every hidden clue would survive centuries of world events (including two world wars as it turns out) and also trusting that people centuries later would find and correctly interpret and follow those clues.... What utter horse****. . Right now it's possible that i am getting my terrible films mixed up, but i think that there are even clues that could only be found because of technology like x-rays. And there is no way anyone living 500 years ago could have predicted that tech, not even DaVinci himself. . It's laughable. And this is laughably bad. But no joke, i recently suffered from a prolonged bout of insomnia, so i rented one of this films sequels, and that cured me within an hour.

review: I always thought the best selling Dan Brown book, being a nuanced mystery thriller, would not translate well onto screen. Sadly that's the case with this average and rather underwhelming adaptation. It's not a bad film, but it doesn't live up to the hype of the book. The screenplay is okay but it's let down by poor cinematography which is perplexing when you consider all the spectacular filming locations. However, it feels like its filmed in perpetual night with most of it spent shuffling around dark, murky rooms where its actually very difficult to see whats going on. I'll give credit to a fairly uplifting ending but still very average.

review: The Da Vinci Code is overly long and stuffed with historical/religious explanations rather than meaningful dialogue. The twist villain was silly, but I'll admit that I didn't expect it. Then I thought the ending was poor. The cinematography and visual effects were bland, and even Hans Zimmer's soundtrack wasn't as good as it is without the film. Disappointing considering I've heard good things about this film.

review: If you are looking for dumb fun with some star power, this is your movie. The story is generic, most of the action scenes are WAY too over the top, the script and acting are both mediocre, and the final product is just an explosive mess. However, explosive mess movies can serve up some enjoyment. Not a bad flick if you have time to kill and just want to play around with some dumb fun.
rt_name: Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw - Movie Reviews

review: Fun action film that goes a bit too far at times but makes for a enjoyable ride. The cast is fun, with Johnson and Statham bouncing off each other nicely as Hobbes & Shaw, while Idris Elba makes a compelling bad guy. Behind the camera, director David Leitch makes some fun action scenes but doesn't quite get the emotion of the characters, delivering the family moments that make the "Fast & Furious" franchise truly work. A pity, since the ingredients are there, from Shaw & his sister to Hobbes and his estranged family, but it never quite jells. A fun watch, but a little shallow.

review: Wow. Just wow. This isn't a superhero movie or even a sci fi and is not in the same genre; people must learn what that is, instead it's more like a special effects packed action fuelled fast paced blockbuster with brilliant technology, style, money and humour. You can expect the level of nonsense nowadays more so because most of the fast and furious entries lately have been too over the top they were from the start. Now, you've the very best in action stars Jason Statham who at only five foot nine took the usual hammering in terms of a roasting from the Americans. Plus you've Dwayne who looked amazing in this until the later stages when he appeared to have lost his entire pump with the amount of work he had put in. The two characters got at one another in the same way Kevin hart does which was fun at first then became tiring. The film was at its best when it was more serious. Future tip dial down the undue excess, dial down the immature phrases and dial down the special effects and you've instead of showing off all the money most of the cities you filmed in just do not have, actually use what was best in the film, old school and charisma. Special mention for the females in this movie, the extras including the army of bad guys were very poor in this almost made this comic book like, but the female lead did her part even if she was just a spare part towards the end. Statham was bound to produce coming from some silly films such as spy and the Meg, whereas Dwayne had to pump up to de-emphasise his ageing stubble, the two looked remarkable they got on well. Jason is better when he's no nonsense serious and so is the rock with that added humour and banter. Although at times this went too far like with Ryan Reynolds to be taken as a serious movie this annoyed me. The audience compared this too much to the franchise which is just as mad, finally less irrelevance on super cars and more on actually showing us just how sensational these two men are.

review: The first two thirds of this movie are a little bit of a slog - it takes a while for the story to get going and for the cast to really have anything to work with, and most of the action up until this point has been generic and really nothing special. A lot of the CGI is obvious and awkward. But the final act in Samoa is so exciting, beautiful, and action-packed that it pretty much redeems everything we went through to get there. Dwayne Johnson finally gets his chance to shine in this installment, showcasing some solid fight choreography while also showing surprising restraint in the humorous and emotional scenes. Jason Statham also gets a lot of redemption (as does his character), making him a lot more likable in this film than in the previous F&F installments. Although it's marketed along with and takes place in the Fast & Furious universe, this film is firmly NOT a Fast & Furious film (which is ultimately for the best). For one thing, Hobbs & Shaw is almost entirely a buddy comedy film, with a good bit of action and some emotional scenes thrown in. Ryan Reynolds is funny and unexpected, although Kevin Hart's character felt altogether unnecessary. Although it's much more of a traditional action film than what we're used to in this franchise, it stands on its own pretty well and gives the leads a chance to shine apart from the bloated cast of the main series.
rt_name: Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw - Movie Reviews

review: The origin story of the character from Disney's Sleeping Beauty animated film done in live action starring Angelina Jolie. This film is not a live action remake of the original film, instead making the villain of the original the protagonist of her own film. Maleficent is one of my favorite villain characters of all time and I wish they would have told the original story (expanded for time) from the villain's point of view. Instead they ruin the characters of the good fairies and Maleficent herself. Angelina Jolie is perfectly cast as the title character and does a great job in the role. The scene taken from the original movie when she curses Aurora as a child was really well done. The rest of the movie is not what I wanted, nor what I needed. #notmymaleficent

I've waited a long time for this to finally return to Disney+. Honestly, the wait wasn't worth it. Between the hype, a sequel & Jolie, I expected magnificent special effects, adventure, and an epic character study of a good-hearted-girl-turned-evil queen. It has great effects; I will give it that. But, where the film fails is in its character-arc. Rather than display Maleficent's gradual transition, the film spends a max of 4 minutes, where Jolie goes from a weepy girl having lost her wings, to a woman limping in frustration, to an villainous queen seated on a thrown of her own making (and with a pair of body guards lookin like undead versions of Groot). This is not character development. And, there is also very little to be said for the man she loves, who ultimately becomes the rival King. His portrayal falls flat, but I'd can hardly blame. The character is one dimensional with dialogue to match. And, his betrayal, with no buildup, makes about as much sense as Maleficent's turn to the darkside. Might have to skip the sequel.
For anyone that wondered ,,Why was Maleficent so cruel to Aurora in Sleeping Beauty?'' - here is your answer.
