There are people here who are disappointed that this movie has no resemblance to the animated movie from decades ago...but that is presumably the intended idea. The movie is certainly scary and violent without being gory, but definitely don't take little kids to see this one. It will be quite unsuited for them. Maleficent begins life as an immature fairy in a beautiful, harmonious fairy world next to a conventional and harsh kingdom. She is visited by Stefan, a boy of a similar age from the kingdom, who implies that someday he will live in the king's castle. An innocent romance begins, but soon ends as the boy grows older, and the current ruler of the kingdom attempts to invade the fairy world with his army to steal its treasures, only to fail. As the old king is dying, Stefan claims the throne by amputating and stealing the fairy's wings. He gets the crown, marries, and has a baby daughter...only for the now-embittered and vengeful Maleficent to arrive and place a curse on the daughter. Stefan is forced to have his daughter raised by three fairies to try to keep her safe...and in the process, becomes embittered and vengeful himself. But over the years, as the daughter grows up, unaware of what had happened, Maleficent sees her and starts having second thoughts. But the cold war has started between Maleficent and Stefan; can Maleficent undo the damage she has done? Like most characters in recent fairy tale-themed movies, nobody is entirely good or evil, and everyone is the victim of the attitudes of their respective cultures and eras. Good for teenagers or above, but too upsetting for the young kids.

Definitely one of the better live action remakes. Angelina Jolie is obviously incredible, the visuals and CGI are mostly impressive, I really like the score for this movie and there's some really epic and emotional moments in this movie like the action scene against the king, Maleficent cursing Aurora and the entire 3rd act. It's quite impressive and can get pretty violent for a Disney movie. But by far the biggest issue with the movie is the pacing. This movie drags on so many times during the 2nd act, especially the scenes with Aurora discovering the moors and it just isn't interesting but overall, it's a good time. I enjoy it.

Maleficent is such a disappointing watch for a few reasons. The first 20 minutes were icky, with the child actresses not being the most expressive. The start of the movie just felt like a huge waste of time, but when Maleficent got her wings cut off by her boyfriend who went psycho on her for a really dumb reason, I thought the movie might pick itself up. It did indeed do this... for about 5 minutes. Evil Maleficent was intimidating for a few seconds and how she put a curse on the princess for revenge, but then Maleficent kind of just picked on Aurora (the princess) and then they became best friends 5 minutes later because Maleficent related to her? Then Aurora goes to her father's castle after finding out Maleficent put a curse on her. But when Aurora gets to the castle and meets her dad, the dad just goes, "L.O.L, I told those stupid fairies to deliver you the day after today." And then the king just locks the princess up with no compassion at all. The final battle was pretty lame. Maleficent just drops the king, learns some stupid moral, the end. The film's pacing is really off, wasting the first twenty minutes with bad acting and a dumb twist villain, then rushing Maleficent's redemption 10 minutes later with the movie not giving you enough room to see Aurora's personality. To top it all off, the movie ends with a rushed out ending. Don't even get me started on the side characters. Everyone here is so unlikeable. For instance, the fairies aren't as fun in this movie as they were in the original movie. These fairy's just end up not even caring for Aurora. The crow (who's the best character in this movie) does a better job of looking after Aurora than the fairy's could ever do. The king is just really angry for no rhyme or reason, yes his child was cursed, but he just shoves her to the side in the final act like I just said. Maleficent her self is just pathetic, she just ends up being soft, but since she's the good guy, she actually ends up bing pretty likeable. But since she's just a big softy now, all of her intimidation she had in the original is gone. The movie takes itself too seriously at times as well, with the closest thing too funny is when Maleficent is picking on Aurora when she was little. In conclusion, just go watch sleeping beauty.

I really like this film, best spider man ever in my opinion. Ok, something had to be fixed for sure (the development of Harry Osborn's character wasn't that good, for example, but if we think about the initial intention of the making of TASM 3 and 4, maybe he would have received the right development; also Electro skin wasn't good because he wasn't like the comics one, but I think that when we watch a film based on comics or books or kinda of, it will never be like the original) but the good stuff is more than the bad. After watching it for the first time in maybe 3 or 4 years and thinking about it. I don't think I hate Amazing Spider-Man 2 anymore! Is it convoluted? Absolutely. Is there too much in it that goes absolutely nowhere (mainly because they were questions to be answered in a conclusive chapter of a trilogy) yes maybe a little too much! Are the origins for the villains a little cheesy or bad? Maybe they weren't bad maybe it was just the execution of it because I could be wrong but I think they draw heavily from Ultimate Spider-Man comics. BUT the score is incredible, of every single Spider-Man movie we've ever had ASM2 is the absolute most gorgeous and visually stunning. No movie is this fucking cool looking. Andrew gave his performance 110% and his chemistry with everyone even someone giving as bad a performance as Dane DeHaan seems to work for the movie it is. Every actor gives everything they've got in this and you can tell, it's not like Spider-Man 3 where you can tell that almost nobody cared and because everyone's acting is so good in this the emotional moments do hit and they often hit hard!!! Honestly this to me has the best, most accurate portrayal of Peter Parker; funny and smart as hell that's not just trying to impress Mr.Stark, what he doesn't know we see him actually try to figure out without the solution being "Oh Mr.Stark put this in my suit already!" Most of my issues with this movie has always been that I hate (and still do) that a looooot of the plot is heavily solved through pure coincidence. That whole plane massacre sequence at the beginning of the movie where Richard Parker is fighting for his life to try and upload his confession video not to send it to a news station, not to send it to someone he knows will do something good like Ben or another scientist, not the police, he sends it to his private computer currently sitting in a secret laboratory under an decades abandoned subway terminal that you only have access to by inserting in these specific slightly different subway tokens that are hidden inside his calculator that Peter only found because he got mad and threw the calculator and it broke and it just so happens that the video sent was also an apology to grown up Peter. Yeah that's absolutely convoluted and even with my newfound respect and even liking for the movie thinks that whole thing should have been cut. But look at the villains, all the groundwork is there. Their stories are actually well grounded and good, it's just the performances that made them seem stupid. Max Dillon becoming Electro; he's a man whose always belittled, bullied at work by EVERYONE despite being one of the top people in his field, has no friends had to buy his own birthday cake and sing Happy Birthday to himself that when he finally gets power he can exact the revenge on those who've wronged him! That's an awesome origin story it was just the weird direction in how Jamie Fox, who I don't blame for the bad performance, director Mark Webb other than Amazing Spider-Man had only done indie romcoms. And even with the weird writing and directing Jamie Fox gave it his all. Harry Osborne his mom died and his dad never cared about him, sent him away when he was really you and rarely if ever saw him or thought about him again. The first time he sees his father in years he's on his death bed saying "Hey, this disease I have. Guess what? It's genetic haha!" Then he has to learn to trust Peter because everytime he's made a friend or thought he did they only liked him for his money! And I do like that subplot of Oscorp trying to push out Harry but trying to figure out how. That too is great groundwork for the bad guy. Now this I do blame Dane DeHaan for because he's reacting to everything right but there's still just something about his performance that makes it seem cringey. Paul Giamatti gave the worst performance of his career as the rhino but hey no movie no matter how great is perfect. But the fight choreography in this is Incredible, it's not like a lot of superhero movie fight scenes where either it's too dark or the camera is too shaky and you can't see what's happening or there's a lot of weird cuts and transitions that you still can't see what's happening. This was a for a while my absolute least favorite comic book movie right up there with shit like Superman 4 and Batman Forever and Robin but being that I haven't watched this in years I do admit this is now a guilty pleasure. It's by no means simply due to the plot issues a good movie but I do enjoy the good aspects a lot more now.

Well, the villains in this film are the worst. It has a round story, but everything feels so artificial, the only thing that I felt it so natural was the scenes of Peter and Gwen, they have an excellent chemistry on screen. Also, it has very good visual effects and good action scenes and that is why this film is a little bit better that the first one.

A noticeable downgrade from the first, "The Amazing Spiderman 2" feels more like a beginning of a sequel that never happened. The entire film does not feel complete, and the ending feels rushed over. The villains, Electro especially, are all just forgettable despite the cast that is behind it. The action and humor still lands though, and Garfield and Stone continue to play their characters very well. The conclusion leaves a very sour taste in your mouth, especially when considered that there is no sequel to follow this up, which was originally planned. Overall, this is a confusing mess of a film that I really wanted to love more, though it failed to stick the landing in one too many areas.

I skipped The Amazing Spider-man franchise due to so much negative reviews from fans but then decided to give it a try. Actually, I liked this franchise. It was fun to watch but it looked like movie hasn't move out of first part. Showing us Peter parents fate and romance scenes more than villains scene was a bad idea. When a sequel is made, it is made using new ideas but it looked like director used maximum elements of first part due to which you can't feel fresh while watching second part. Overall, it was fun to watch but not better than part first part.

I'm sorry but it's hard to take the Electro in this movie seriously when he does not look remotely like his comics counterpart. Also, why make Harry Osborn look creepy, like a deranged serial killer? Plus, the storyline does not make sense, the main problem being: Max Dillon idolizes Spider-Man before becoming Electro but becomes a villain after becoming Electro. üôÑ And for reasons I cannot explain, the death of Gwen Stacy just wasn't moving. Terrible handling of an iconic part of Spider-Man's story.

While disappointing after the first one, the second one still has a strong enough script and an amazing cast: Emma Stone, Andrew Garfield, Sally Field, Dane DeHaan, Jamie Foxx. DeHaan was an absolute standout in this movie and he completely stole the show. His portrayal of Harry Osborn is my personal favourite- he manages to make us feel pity, disgust, annoyance, and empathy, all at different points for this tortured character. I would have loved to have seen more of DeHaan's abilities and talent in the ASM franchise. *SPOILER ALERT* Marc Webb's directing is absolutely phenomenal and genius. When Aunt May reveals that Peter's father was a traitor, the camera angle tilts- Peter's work has been turned on it's side, it has become askew. Later, when Peter finds the Subway train and finds out the truth about his father and his work, the camera rights itself- Peter's world is righted.

WARNING: THIS REVIEW HAS SPOILERS! The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is the worst Spider-Man film until then. The cast from the first movie still does a great job, but none of the new characters works. Harry Osborn is a poor version of the emo Tobey Maguire with a bit of Draco Malfoy. The actor is terrible and his arc is badly developed and also rushed. Electro is the worst Spider-Man villain in the cinema of all time. Jamie Foxx here is as invisible as his character, who has no motivation for hating Spider-Man (Lizard also didn't have, but at least he was imposing). And the romantic arc, which was masterfully done in the first film, becomes a "To All the Boys 3" but with Noah Centineo's character being the protagonist. There's no history. The best things of this film are: it deepens on Peter's parents backstory, the chemistry between Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone still works and Gwen's death is painful and touching. Oh, and the movie should have ended in the funeral scene, and everything after it could be post-credit or middle-credit scenes.

Even more of a mixed bagged than its predecessor, The Amazing Spider-man 2 improves on the good parts of the original like its protagonist and the chemistry between the cast, but it butchers so much stuff. The saddest part is, it felt like director Marc Webb had a clear vision for the sequel but the studio interfered and forced him to shove another villain in at the last second. Speaking of villains, one is poorly written and just lazy, and green goblin's development is just non-existent. The pacing is god awful during the second act and every subplot feels out of place, the sinister six setup feels like Sony was just trying to make more money by teasing them and the story arc of Peter's parents (if you can even call it a story arc) has no place in the story and doesn't have a satisfying pay off. Nothing we learn about them is something that subverts our expectations, it's all old news. That being said, Peter Parker, Gwen Stacy, their relationship and Gwen's death scene are all phenomenal. It's strange seeing Marc Webb being able to deliver on arguably the most powerful death scene in any movie, and then also be the man responsible for Electro and Green Goblin. There's not much more I can say that hasn't been said yet, it's corporate pandering, it's lazily written and could've been so much more if they just focussed on one villain and expanded on the dynamic between said villain and Peter. If only there had been a The Amazing Spider-man 3, maybe that would've been the golden child of the series.

No wonder a third one was never made.

review: It's finally here! The last chapter to the popular Hunger Games movie series that broke literary sales records, made Jennifer Lawrence's career and influenced young girls everywhere to take up archery is finally coming to a close... well sort of. This is only part 1 of the final chapter. In it's infinite wisdom, Lionsgate films has decided to take the Harry Potter route in finishing off the Hunger Games series. What can I say about this movie that hasn't already been said about the second to last Harry Potter movie? Some may call this film a necessary bridge to the final chapter of the series, others may call it a gradual build to something far grander in scale than what we've seen before in other Hunger Games films. Some may say that but the fact of the matter is, this movie is just plain old fashioned filler. Trust me, I've read the books and the only thing you're seeing in this film is pure filler. I don't think I'm giving anything away by telling you that The third book of the Hunger Games saga depicts the events of a massive war between the capital and the other districts but it's not ALL just a battle, there are quite a few pieces of plot that need to occur leading up to the epic spectacle of war, things that the makers of the Hunger Games film series would rather just get out of the way than have them share the spotlight with what is sure to be the special effects event of fall 2015. I could go on and tell you about everything else in the film as far as the cast and the story and the special effects but honestly, nothing has changed since the last film. Everyone does a good job and the film ends up where it needs to be but the overarching feeling behind it all is that it all of it adds up to being just a bunch of Hollywood BS stretching out projects for no reason. There's no real reason for this movie to exist, everything that happens here could have been explained in the first 20-30 minutes for the most part, Lionsgate just decided that they wanted to line their coffers with a little more coin before this franchise ends. Eh, who can blame them. Money is money after all. Unfortunately it doesn't add up to a very entertaining ride for everyone else in the theater. All in all, if you're a fan of The Hunger Games films, you're seeing this for only one reason, to get to part 4 where the real action is. If you're just a casual fan, I'd say read the back of the DVD case or the wiki synopsis and hell, just watch the trailer and prepare yourself for part 4 because that's what you should be paying to see, not this. Perhaps I'll have a different opinion of the series once part 2 of Mocking Jay comes out, but as it stands right now on it's own, Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1 gets a 2.5...out of 5

review: I don't care what anyone says. This movie is great in so many ways, which is shocking since the actual book wasn't that good but the movie manages to stay loyal to the book whilst also being a great movie, even if it's only part 1. Every actor gives 10/10 performance, including the casting for Coin, the sets for district 13 and 8 are fabulous, I loved seeing the rebels in district 4 and 7 as well as the added scene with Snow talking to all of Panem. It makes for an intense , suspenseful political thriller that allows the viewer to take in what happens by not moving too fast. The Hanging Tree sequence is probably my favorite in the franchise, the score is remarkable and the action that is around is great. It's not perfect as it does have to adapt from a book that is just good and splitting it into two parts was a bad idea with not much action in th book but it's still a great movie.

review: A smart political drama to get teenagers involved in politics. Francis Lawrence's coming of age sci-fi political drama The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014) is an interesting installment in a franchise built on blood, then goes deeper into social dynamics and what it takes to create a revolution. Suzanne Collins' writing is interesting as she acknowledges the need for political propaganda in order to maintain order and unite the districts. Mockingjay - Part 1 sets up for the grand finale with style and class as Katniss must film President Snow's atrocities to inform and unite all people to her righteous cause. I think Lawrence finds fresh perspective on teenagers rebelling and relating to these heroes with his slick direction. I must mention that Lorde is on the soundtrack for this movie. Her astonishing dream pop anthem "Yellow Flicker Beat" calls on the youth to rebel and be themselves with frightening majesty. I love how it's the last thing you hear in the movie as the end credits start to play. Likewise, James Newton Howard's score has never been more evocative and emotional, especially towards the end of Mockingjay. I love his music for this fiery franchise. Jennifer Lawrence is incredible as empathizing with Katniss Everdeen and the struggle of an oppressed people. The Hunger Games movies mean more than entertainment, but a warning against allowing your society to crumble. We should all be rising together like Katniss in these turbulent times. Lawrence is inspiring, lovely, and haunting as the distraught and conflicted Katniss trying to do what she believes is right. Josh Hutcherson is excellent as the captured Peeta Mellark, painfully tortured and forced to deliver half-hearted messages to the Mockingjay revolution. Liam Hemsworth is interesting as the conflicted Gale Hawthorne, who wants to be there for the already spoken for Katniss, while fighting alongside his people. Woody Harrelson is outstanding as the heartfelt Haymitch Abernathy, standing alongside Katniss through it all. Elizabeth Banks is increasingly emotional as the entertaining eccentric Effie Trinket. Julianne Moore is fantastic as the cold and calculating President Alma Coin. She bears a knowing confidence I find revealing. Rest in paradise to the ever amazing Philip Seymour Hoffman as the crafty architect of the Mockingjay revolution Plutarch Heavensbee. Jeffrey Wright is more clever and cunning than ever as the technical genius Beetee. Stanley Tucci is more underhanded as the propaganda announcer Caesar Flickerman. Donald Sutherland is more vindictive and vicious than ever as President Snow. His calm fury is fascinating to watch unfold on the masses. Willow Shields is very emotive as Primrose Everdeen with her hurt looks and helpful healing practices as a revolutionary nurse. Sam Claflin was awesome in Catching Fire and he's captivating with his dark dramatic performance as Finnick Odair. Jena Malone gets a memorable cameo as Johanna Mason. I wish she were in more of Mockingjay. Mahershala Ali is cool as Katniss' new protector Boggs. Natalie Dormer is cool and gorgeous as the propaganda director Cressida. Ve Neill's make-up for Dormer is so wonderful with her green tattoos and undercut hairstyle. The costumes in Mockingjay are all wicked armor with plenty to love. Philip Messina's harsh industrial production design is striking like Jo Willems' vivid cinematography. I love his wide shot of Katniss shooting down two jets with her bow. The close-up of Jennifer Lawrence's face to the jets is killer. Lastly, Alan Edward Bell and Mark Yoshikawa's snappy editing makes Mockingjay's 123 minutes fly by like the bird. In all, Mockingjay is not as phenomenal as The Hunger Games or Catching Fire, but it inspires a sense of anarchy and rebellion in you for sure.

review: Once you grow up and realize the realities of conflict, inner turmoil and the fight to do what's right, you hopefully lose any immature attachments to fleeting fancies of the heart. Sadly, this film doesn't recognize that. Collins wrote these books for a YA audience but the stakes within the plot are so high that the naive YA heart tugs are a fatal error. Katniss and Peeta's love story arc was never fully developed in the first place , so for her to be so hung up on Peters fate that it causes her to play the reluctant hero role is outright silly. There are scenes early on in this film where Katniss is screaming and crying over poor Peters fate that is supposed to make us feel for her quest for love, instead it's just a childish distraction. Had she stepped into the hero role and been mature enough to know that none of her allies had any choice in the impending revolution, thus meaning Peeta no harm, it would have been such a stronger and more well defined study in the rise of the Mockingjay. It's like you're watching a 14 year old Tiger Beat mellowdrama play out for no good reason. All that aside, the dystopian vision of censorship, power and mind control from within governmental systems is well thought out and worth the trip down the rabbit hole. The heroines conviction for the cause does bloom eventually, thank God. Otherwise, this film would be a waste of time.
rt_name: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 1 - Movie Reviews

Por otro lado, la pel√≠cula no iguala a la primera ni obviamente a la segunda, pero por lo menos es un digno final de la franquicia y no es olvidable para nada. Tambi√©n me gust√≥ mucho el soundtrack de la pel√≠cula y la animaci√≥n es genial, se nota una gran evoluci√≥n en cuanto a las anteriores y que se gasto mucho mas presupuesto esta vez. En conclusi√≥n, una pel√≠cula incomprendida con un final muy digno que se mantiene fresca gracias a las hermosas animaciones, el gran desarrollo de Shrek y una buena historia. Muy recomendada.

This review contains spoilers. I honestly don't understand all this hatred of the movie. I didn't grow up with the Shrek saga: during the lockdown I saw all 4 films in order. And for someone who saw the film for the first time, I found it a great product. The animations are a big improvement over the previous 3 films and the characters are beautiful to look at. The story is very controversial, but I found it to be in full swing with the franchise, because let's be honest: Shrek never really changed his temper. It certainly hasn't stayed where it started, but evolution is minimal. Here, finally, he manages to have a real evolution in line with the character. In my opinion, Shrek has not undergone a regression, but only a wave of nostalgia that blinded him. The idea of going back is what the franchise needed: going too far was a huge risk. So, instead, they eliminated the damage of a third sequel. The remaining characters are well adapted to the other reality and donkey always remains the best. The villain, the focus of the film, has a very good characterization and his plan is very well done. On one issue, however, I can agree: it is less parody and more serious. But that's exactly what the franchise needed as an ending (for now). With the fourth film, the franchise doesn't lose the whammy, it stays fresh thanks to the beautiful animations, great development of Shrek and a good story. An underrated masterpiece.
Just to say the movie improved over Shrek the third, but the problum with this movie is that it's just not funny, it has a good message but the story itself is pretty messy.

Overall this was a real high note to end off the series with and the villan is spectacular.

review: This triquel to the Madagascar franchise is better and worse than the first two movies. Honestly the idea of bringing the characters who have been on an adventure for the past two films ending up in a circus feels mediocre. The film once again keeps the same flaws with the poor pacing, the lack of character development, the hit-or-miss jokes thrown out of nowhere, and the message it tries to tell. However the movie does have more charm and better animation quality. There is one scene that nearly blew me way visually at the circus when Alex, Marty, Gloria, Melman, and the rest have their final performance. And the characters do have a side romance plot which does feel like something pushing the story a bit more forward. But that's basically it like I've said before.

review: Oh, dear. One of the more traumatic incidents of my teenage life was my friend's mother blaring that horrendous will.i.am song on a two-hour car journey. Admittedly, this still dwells in my mind and this rating might not be fair. I just found myself gritting my teeth far more than laughing. Maybe I need to brighten up. Look at that cast. The additions alone are star-studded. Frances McDormand playing a villainous Frenchwoman? Bryan Cranston playing a Russian tiger? Jessica Chastain playing a jaguar? Gold waiting to be found, but their accents were distractingly below par, especially in McDormand's case. Sacha Baron Cohen as a lemur having a whirlwind romance with a bear voiced by Frank Welker of Scooby-Doo fame might have looked good on paper, but reeked of unoriginality and never once provoked so much as a smile. Imagine my surprise when I saw that Noah Baumbach wrote the script. Not exactly what he seems to be known for. There are a few good jokes, make no mistake, but the entire affair seems like a half-baked, scattershot cash-in upon guaranteed success. The story follows every necessary and unnecessary indulgence and contrivance in the book. For that reason, I simply could not enjoy it.

review_date: I only have vague memories of watching the first Madagascar movie with some friends and their kids. At the time I thought it was kind of cute, but mostly forgettable. I certainly didn‚Äôt think it was going to spawn an entire franchise of films and TV shows, but to my surprise it did. One of the sequels was Madagascar 3: Europe‚Äôs Most Wanted. And, for the record, I did indeed watch this without seeing the 2nd movie in the franchise. I don‚Äôt think much context was needed because this movie is its own insane thing. My distant memories of the first Madagascar film told me that it was all about them wanting to escape captivity to live in the wild. As a result, I found it quite odd that the entire plotline of Madagascar 3 was structured around the heroes wanting to return to their cages. I guess they felt they had a level of fame in the zoo, and they wanted to be loved and adored by humans again. In order to earn their way back to the US they decide to join the circus. There they meet some new friends that love them and accept them as part of the act. From that point on, I‚Äôm sure you can write the rest of the plot for them. It‚Äôs not an original story, and I found it rather boring. There‚Äôs been a trend in many animated films lately to include fast-paced insanity instead of story or actual comedy. This annoys me tremendously, and gets me cringing rather than laughing. Madagascar 3 is a poster child for this film-making style. Everything is moving at a mile a minute, and we‚Äôre asked to laugh just because it‚Äôs weird. I cannot even recall a single joke that worked in the film, and the story was utter nonsense. As one small example of the stupidity of this movie, somehow the animals all make it from Madagascar to Monte Carlo (I guess by swimming there.) Yet they must go through the entire plot of joining the circus, and working to make it successful enough to tour in New York, in order to make it back home. I understand the real goal of the film-makers was to get the animals in a new and interesting situation, but they couldn‚Äôt even invent a decent way of getting them there. I was so detached and disinterested throughout this entire film, despite the fact that it has some decent voice talent. Sadly, they were all performing their voices in an exaggerated fashion, so it was rather obnoxious. There were times when I was actively trying to ignore Madagascar 3, so that I wouldn‚Äôt be annoyed by its frenetic idiocy. Maybe this stuff works for kids, but for me it was tedious, to say the least.

review: The Joker is a 2019 Drama/Thriller featuring the talents of Joaquin Phoenix and co. I personally really enjoyed this movie. From the amazing cinematography to the Oscar-worthy Score, this movie is one of the best to come out this year. Joaquin Phoenix's performance is one of the most mesmerizing performances I've ever seen on screen, the way he depicts his character is not realistic, but also deeply dark and disturbing to viewers. This man is able to creep out and disturb the audience just by laughing. No music or special effects needed. The plot, though flawed and at times unrealistic, is very, very dark and disturbing. I wouldn't recommend this movie to young audiences. To everyone else, though, this is a must-watch to not only become aware of many difficulties of the mentally ill, as well as why horrible things like what happens in this movie happens in real life.

review: Hell to Pay has its problems such as Harley Quinn feeling pointlessly shoehorned in, an excessive cast of characters despite the short runtime and a somewhat convoluted explanation behind an otherwise really good plot twist but the Suicide Squad's third film outing following Assault on Arkham and the 2016 film is still tons of fun. Not to the same level as the kickass James Gunn film I saw two weeks ago but it's another good showing of why DC continues to remain virtually unchallenged when it comes to the direct-to-DVD market. The voice acting is great as always, the action sequences are thrilling, the plot, while generic, fits Task Force X better than the generic doomsday villain of the live-action film, there are good dynamics between some of the characters, the quips put a smile on my face and last but not least, the movie actually tries its damnedest to justify its R-rating unlike The Killing Joke and Justice League Dark, which were honestly less violent than the crazy stuff shown to us in Flashpoint Paradox. Thank God I'm not squeamish to these kinds of things, otherwise I'd have come out of cinema showing of the equally bloody, if not gorier, 2021 film a gibbering, nervous wreck. While slightly inferior to Assault on Arkham, Hell to Pay still succeeds in doing what the 2016 film failed to do, give the Suicide Squad the film adaptation they truly deserve that truly embraces its source material's "no-punches-pulled" nature.
rt_name: Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay - Movie Reviews

review: Before I begin to review this movie I would like to take a moment to tell how much I lived under a rock when it came to superhero stuff. So as a kid I never liked superhero cartoons. I always found them over the top. So I had no idea whatsoever about superhero stuff. I thought Batman is just like Superman except he wears a mask, Superman is weak af because I always used to see him get beaten up every time I skimmed through the cartoon channels and saw a glimpse of Justice League or Superman. And the best part - I didn't even know what DC was. I used to think all the superheroes are made by Marvel. So when Suicide Squad was announced in 2016, our teacher had asked us which movie we want to watch. I had said Rustom (a Bollywood film) while the rest of the class said Suicide Squad. I had seen posters of Suicide Squad and I used to think it's just some mindless action film like all zombie movies. So my friend told me it's gonna have Joker in it. I combines two and two together and understood that Suicide Squad is a DC movie. And no, my stoogeness is still not over (wait for it): I was now excited for the movie, because I thought Joker will be played by Heath Ledger! So of course, then we know what all happened. The movie was bad, everyone lost hopes from DCEU, yada yada. But anyway, why I brought this story up is because my very first introduction to Suicide Squad was by the 2016 movie, and that's surely not a good way to be introduced. Sure I understood the concepts, but I had no respect left for the franchise. It's like learning about Green Lantern or Fantastic Four from their movies (...okay, I'll admit. That's how I learnt about them too). So now that I was watching DCAMU, I was a little nervous from watching this movie. But then I thought, let's just go with it. What's the worst that can happen? And surprisingly this is way better than the trashy movie. Now don't get me wrong. I'm all in for the Ayer Cut, provided it fixes that movie. But now I have already been introduced to Suicide Squad the wrong way and nothing can fix that. This is much better. Finally this was the movie that brought the Flashpoint Paradox back to relevance with the rest of the DCAMU movies, which was otherwise never talked about again. The whole Ticket to Heaven storyline was awesome. Everyone was dying at some point, so it was very thrilling to root for any one character. Although I had a hunch that Harley Quinn and Deadshot will never die since they didn't die in the movie either, yet I was really tensed for them. This is in spite of the fact that I don't like either of the two characters. But seeing them all travel in a bus and interact with each other for the first time was very nice to see. The animation, fight scenes (especially Zoom cutting down Bronze Tiger in the end), everything was so awesome. It's nice to see how much DC can do if WB does not keep meddling it. If this movie didn't exist, or rather should I say, if I had not decided to become interested in superhero stuff and not just looked at what the normies are looking at, I'd have continued to hate Suicide Squad. The Suicide Squad, Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League, the possible Ayer Cut - I'd have hated them all and not even bothered to see them. Thanks to this movie I have become a lot more accepting towards this franchise and can now watch it without the fear of getting bored.

review: If you're looking for a proper Suicide Squad film, this is a close as you're going to get (so far). Fast-paced, action-packed and violent with a dash of mature-ish humour, the tone of the film is pretty much spot-on and exactly what you'd expect (and want) from a film about a bunch of tough-to-deal-with, eccentric killers forced into a team together. It's full of interesting characters and great interactions which means you're never bored. It plays out more like an action/thriller as opposed to your typical superhero film, complete with a few unexpected twists, which is definitely a good thing. This is one for an older audience and is just a helluva fun time. Once again, it proves that Marvel may be the kings of live-action, but DC is light-years ahead when it comes to animations.

review: Lately, DC's animated features have been a bit of a mixed bag of good and bad. "Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay" seems to suffer that same fate but in a way that still leaves the film entertaining. On the negative side, the film has some really awkward character animation and some really horrible 3-D animation. On the positive side, however, the story is great and does a killer job of connecting itself to one of DC's best animated films, the voice acting is fantastic, and the action and content is able to be exciting and dark without it feeling like it is being gratuitous in nature. Basically, it is one of those rare occasions where DC manages to deliver an R-rated feature that doesn't feel like the goal was to get an R-rating but rather tell a great story that just so happens to get an R-rating. Overall, this is a great addition to DC's animated library. Hello! My name is Rev. Ron and if you feel like checking out more of my reviews (including a more in-depth look at "Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay") you can visit my blog at RevRonMovies.BlogSpot.com. Also, if the mood strikes, you can follow me on Twitter (@RevRonster). Thanks!

review: X men days of future past is easily one of the best x men movies of all time and marked the return of Bryan Singer to the franchise after several disappointment entries after his departure. This film is solid and probably underrated featuring great direction, a great story and a large cast that unites the original x men trilogy cast of Patrick Stewart, Ian Mckellen, Hugh Jackman, Halley Berry with the prequel cast of James Mccavoy. Michael Fassbender, Jennifer Lawrence, and Nicholas Hault. All the performances are great notably a delightfully funny and witty small appearance by Evan Peters as Quicksilver, James McAvoys tortured performance as young xavier, and Michael Fassbenders almost superior interpretation of a young magneto rivaling the charismatic Mcckellen. The movie sends Jackmans wolverine back to the past to meet with young xavier played Mccavoy to stop a future apocalypse. This movie is fun as it brillianly goes back to the past and present weaving between the two separate casts and trilogies in an epic way. Jackman is great with the prequel cast serving as the bridge between the two franchises. The movie has its weaknesses as the story can be devoid of logic and a lot of plot holes created by previous entries. Yet it features great drama, and lots of action that turn this movie into a superhero epic. Easily one of the best in the franchise.

review: One of my favorite superhero movies of all time. I just adore this movie so much. I love how it immediately jumps into the plot. No setting up characters, just expositon done right and the best part of the movie is definitely the story and pacing. It's awesome seeing the older and newer X-Men cast and it's such an engaging story (and it's a time travel movie) with perfectly clear high stakes. You're always on the edge of your seat, wondering what'll happen, making the movie unpredictable and it's perfectly paced. No scene is too short or fast. The acting, visuals and action are absolutely marvelous with so many cool mutant powers. It's really compelling as well seeing a broken Charles with a great character arc, a Logan who steps into the role of mentor, an awesome Quicksilver scene and it once again explores the relationship with human and mutants and time so well and that 3rd act is phenomenal. I always wonder how it's going to end. My only complaint is we didn't see much of Wolverine in action but damn is it a masterpiece.

review: I'm gonna be a little too honest here: I bingewatched all the X-Men movies, so I often forget about this movie. Many times I get confused when someone mentions a scene from this movie, and I'm like, "wait, it happened in THIS movie? I thought it happened in First Class/Apocalypse!" And I'd prefer admitting that it's my fault than it being the movie's fault. X-Men: Days of the Future Past is what I'd call the movie that bridges X-Men: First Class with the other canonical movies, and at the same time also helps in eliminating the bad movies like The Last Stand and Origins. The movie begins with, as usual, mutants being attacked and eliminated. So to save all of them, Wolverine goes back in time and stop Mystique from killing Bolivar Trask, a defence contractor. Wolverine reached the 1970s, when he was still a mutant without vibranium. And to set planes in motion, he has to find Charlex Xavier, Magneto, Beast and Mystique. Bolivar Trask used Mystique's powers to create Mutant Hunting Robots. In the beginning they were only meant to be used to fight in the Vietnam war, but seeing how Mystique and Magneto revealed themselves, they decided to use the robots to hunt down the mutants itself. They didn't see whether mutants are also sentient beings or not, they just wanted to have them eliminated. And that's when the roles of money and power play. It was on the order of President Nixon that Bolivar decided to make those robots, which President Nixon had ordered only because of Bolivar's influence. So in a way it was a loop of blame. And when Professor X, Wolverine and Quicksilver reach Magneto to save him, we finally get to see the fabled Quicksilver scene, where he takes down all the prison guards single handedly. It was the most iconic moment from the movie, and no amount of appreciation can praise it as much as it deserves. The modern day scenes were also adding to the tension, and in the end when Mystique is left with the choice whether to kill Bolivar or not, it is a quite tense moment whether the mutants in the modern time will survive or not. In the end we see that all the mutants who had died in the previous movies had also come back to life, and the franchise was brought back to where Bryan Singer had left it in X2. Normally it is very difficult to reboot a franchise (read Sonic 06). Not only do you have to understant the major events that need to ve removed in order to fix the franchise, you also have to make the reboot-turning movie really good, otherwise it will just contribute to being the hot garbage that the other movies of the franchise are. And that's the reason why I believe this movie is underrated. It single handedly fixed a failing franchise, joined the acclaimed prequel into the main timeline and became a success both critically and financiallly. It deserves to be one of the most iconic X-Men movies.

review: Captures both the warmth and depth of the classic book's overall story while also capturing the spectacular land of Narnia that you'd imagine from the book. Well-told with a strong good-vs-evil theme appropriate for children (no blurring of the lines here) and morality lessons about bravery, selfishness vs selflessness, caution with strangers, etc aplenty. Some have argued some of the acting was subpar but it wasn't a big deal to me. The music is appropriately majestic and the action retains your interest throughout. A must-see for famiilies.

review: Four children from London escape the bombardment during WWII to the home of the Professor. While there, they discover the wondrous world of Narnia inside a wardrobe. The children actors do an excellent job in the lead roles, especially Georgie Henly who played Lucy. Tilda Swinton, James McAvoy and the voice of Liam Neeson are also standouts. This is truly a wonderful adaptation of the book. The special effects are hit and miss, you can tell several heads are giant practical effect masks, some green screen scenes are obvious and some of the character animation is off. But the hits are spot on! Aslan's eyes are beautifully animated as is the rest of him and the Beavers as well. Highly recommend this movie, go check it out!

review: C. S. Lewis was the author of the Narnia story series, which was meant to be a "Lord Of The Rings"-type scenario for children. Lewis himself wrote about religion and was a convert to Christianity later in life, but the Narnia series was not necessarily intended to be an allegory about Christianity, contrary to popular myth. Degrading death and rebirth of someone is obviously not exclusive to the Bible. I mention this because the novels (which I haven't read) and the movie are simply epic adventure stories. So how are they on their own merits? The establishing parts are good; siblings living in London during the Blitz are sent to safety in the countryside, and while playing they discover the title magical kingdom. Unfortunately the children don't really engage us, nor does anyone else, and the story is rather confusing. Worst of all is the ending, where the kids have grown into adults during their time there, but when they get back to their home, they are kids again. Huh? Special effects are okay, but that was about it. Go see Peter Jackson's "Lord Of The Rings" instead.

review: The gentlest of young adult blockbusters. It boasts solid CGI and general design, and the adult casting is impeccable. Still, this adaptation's biggest asset is its faithful reminder of how great the original story is. It doesn't change much, and what it does change is largely positive (Edmund's death). It's far from perfect; Peter is annoying, Aslan is a bit tamed down, the battle is overlong, the musical score is bad. Nonetheless, Lewis's brilliance mostly shines through.

review: Book adaptations tend to belong to four categories - the highly flawed commercial successes which the real fans of the book hate with intense passion (Percy Jackson, I'm looking at you), the critical and financial flops (A Wrinkle in Time, Artemis Fowl), films that have a separate passionate fanbase from the book and tend to lean towards the successful kind (Harry Potter is one good example, Winnie the Pooh) and finally - the guys who get picked up, shelved around, are always "in development" and never see the day of light. The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe was neither. It wasn't a Harry Potter, and it wasn't a critical mess. It also was produced, and merited itself even more films. And after doing all this, it stays true to the adaptation. Fair enough, Christian parents would be a little disappointed seeing their favorite theologian novelist's book getting adapted into what is more of a pure light fantasy and less of a biblical allegory. Although Arsalan is still revered in a similar fashion, the overall aesthetic is far more Lord of the Rings than it is The book of John. It is cinematically well-done, from the bombing of London, the cigar-smoking landlord to the insides of the land of Narnia. The characters do tend to be forgettable though. Not from a depth of good acting or that they aren't fleshed enough - they are fleshed way too much. The White Witch is of course my favorite (from a narrative standpoint and not moral or personal whatsoever) when it comes to the main characters, and Arsalan does a pretty decent job too. It has several heart-warming moments to watch and utter "Aww" to, but the only thing it lacks are more LOL moments. Overall, a 3/5 and would say it is pretty fresh.

review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe This magical fantasy, released in 2005, is a gorgeous screen version of Clive Lewis's novel The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. The film directed by Andrew Adamson turned out to be really beautiful, full of magic, breathe-taking story and interesting characters. Due to expensive and high-quality special effects, the film ended up with a big budget of about $ 180 million. When I first saw this film ten years ago, I was completely captured by this story, and loved it forever. Four children, Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy, are sent by their parents from London to the village to an old professor - a friend of the family. Once, playing hide and seek, the young heroine Lucy discovers a mysterious wardrobe, thanks to which all four find themselves in the fabulous country of Narnia, where fantastic people, animals and creatures live. It turns out that this peaceful country is under the rule of the evil Witch, because of which it is always cold and eternal winter. Children must help King Aslan, the Great Lion, who founded Narnia many centuries ago, defeat the Witch, break the spell and free the inhabitants of Narnia. I wanted to pay attention to the visual effects, special effects, make-up, scenery, the whole atmosphere in the film - everything was done just perfectly. Watching this fantasy, as if you really find yourself in the magical world of Narnia, in which you want to stay forever. To summarize, I want to say that the film is thought-provoking, spectacular and well-filmed.

review: Long bloody title, but a great film no doubt. I had seen 'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' before but hadn't watched it for years and years, I remembered the vast majority though - it's a memorable film after all. There's a great battle scene in there, some fun characters and strong effects. It's a tad too long, but not by much. It has a nice charm to it also, as they set up Narnia excellently. The quartet of children are very well cast, all four of them suit their roles to a T. Georgie Henley is sweet as Lucy, while William Moseley and Anna Popplewell fulfil the roles of Peter and Susan comfortably. Edmund, meanwhile, is of course annoying, but Skandar Keynes does a good job portraying him. Elsewhere, Tilda Swinton and Liam Neeson are terrific casts as the White Witch and Aslan. Both do great, especially Swinton. James McAvoy, Ray Winstone, Michael Madsen and Rupert Everett are smart choices too. I've, as far as I'm aware, never seen the two sequels so very much look forward to seeing what they have in store for me. They'll do well to match this first film, that's for sure.

review: The film The Lion The Witch And The Wardrobe is good and disappointing at the same time. I love how Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy all work together when in danger they always keep each other safe, and they always support each other. Peter saves Susan and Lucy from the wolf. Also, in the battle, Edmund saves centaurs, fauns, and animals by sacrificing himself and destroying the witch's wand. I also like Lucy. She is a good character because she's kind and forgiving and always wants to help people. She forgave Mr. Tumnus. The parts that aren't in the movie makes me sad because I was really looking forward to seeing some of those scenes, like when they were playing with Aslan in a big ball of love and joy.

review: MOVIE The movie The Lion,The Witch, And The Wardrobe is disappointing. The worst part is that the creators took all the joy out of it and replaced it all with wars and battles. In the book The Lion, The Witch, And The Wardrobe, you don't actually see the battle. Instead you see joy and happiness, but the movie focuses on violence and war. The courtyard scene with giant Rumblebuffin and the lion who said "He said us lions" is missing. So is the scene when the children, who were now adults, talked strangely, for example when Peter said, "For in all my days I have never hunted a nobler quarry." Instead they speak very casually. I do not like how the creators changed so much of the book. It ruined the whole movie this way.

rt_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe - Movie Reviews

review: It is one of the rare cases in which it makes no difference to read the book first or see the film first. Both make the other better, and as an adaptation, the Disney movie is simply flawless. Each line of each scene in the book was accurately transcribed on the screen, also accurately transcribing the emotions and sensations of each moment in the way that C.S.Lewis endeavored to do. But besides being an extremely faithful adaptation to the original, this film also has its universe expanded in a coherent and aggrandizing way to the story it is telling, with several original scenes being created for the script. Scenes that add context, deepen the characters, make what is epic more epic, what is magical more magical and what is deep deeper. It is no exaggeration to conclude that this film is probably the best adaptation of a book ever made.

review: This prequel to Monsters, Inc., tells the story of how Mike and Sully met in college. The biggest draw for the first film was the relationship between Sully and Boo, and while Mike and Sully's relationship was interesting, not continuing to develop Sully and Boo was a disappointment. The choice to make a college fraternity movie out of this franchise is interesting on the same level as making a spy movie out of the Cars franchise. There are also several plot points that do not mesh well with the set up from the first movie. On its own, this movie has some great comedic and emotional moments. The voice acting is great and the animation is amazing as always from Pixar. There is a scene during the third act that shows Mike and Sully sitting in front of a Moon lit lake and it is absolutely beautiful! While this film does not expand the franchise the way it wanted to, this movie is worth your time.
Honestly I thought it was better than the orginal and was one of the few prequels that legitimatized its existence

by the time this movie came out alot of kids that grew up with the original were headed off to college which makes mike and sulley all the more relatable. This prequel tells the origin story of mike and sulleys unbreakable friendship and how they met in college before working at the factory there are a handful of new characters my favorite of which Is Dean Hardscrabble the centipede lady who has one of the best/creepiest character designs In the monsters series and is perfectly voiced by Helen Mirren the climax in the human world where mike and sulley get stuck in a camp and scare a bunch of cops is one of my favorite scenes in pixar canon at its core this is a fun college movie that kids and some adults might enjoy

review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

If you wanted some more background on Mike and Sully before the events of Monsters Inc, this is the movie for you! Unfortunately, we don't get much more insight into the characters and the plot is fairly plodding. If you want some nods to the original with an amazing cast of voices, this is your ticket, but don't expect to be wowed. It's not Toy Story 2.

Summary: Head back in time with studious Mike and slacker Sully as they study what it takes to pursue a successful career as a monster. All students prepare for the annual "Scare Games", but it turns out it isn't friendship at first sight for the dream duo from the first movie, Monster's Inc. Takeaways: The prequel to the hit movie did not disappoint. Family-friendly and well-thought-out. Honestly, may even have been funnier than #1.

Ok so‚Ä¶.this movie has some great moments. Is that enough to call this a great movie? I'm gonna go out on a limb and say no. This movie has two things that I think are truly great, being the theme and the ending. The theme of the natural (Sully) vs the hard worker (Mike) I think is great. They should use that in more of their movies, I wouldn't mind seeing that again. The ending also portrays to this theme, showing how Mike still found his passion in scaring by coaching other monsters. If only the rest of the movie was like that. First, the animation and voice acting is still stellar. The story and everything that has to do with them being in college is boring and predictable. It's just 80s college movie stereotypes, and I don't want to see that in a Pixar movie, I'm sorry, I just don't. Also the jocks vs the nerds stereotype with the scare games is another thing I just don't want to see in a Pixar movie, again, I just don't want to see that‚Ä¶.AT ALL. That made this movie from a good and entertaining one, to barely serviceable. This is just another Brave to me. Just like that movie, I would only watch this movie if you want to say you've seen them all. If not, I'm sad to say, this is another one I would skip. To be honest, this feels like an appetizer before the next big Pixar flick.

Monsters University was okay. It wasn't bad or anything it was okay. The main parts that I like were between Mike and Sully and the OK team. Other than that though the movie is pretty bland. The rest of the characters were forgettable and while the Scare Games are fun to watch at times it's not as good as the first Monsters Inc movie. However the ending of this movie is actually really good and mostly the best part of the movie, but overall the movie could've been better. 7/10

I never got to know this movie existed. I used to live under a rock back when it released. So the moment I learnt that Monsters Inc has a prequel, I immediately watched it with my sister. We didn't know what we were going to witness other than the fact that the title itself says it's from the time Mike and Sully were in college. And it really stood on our expectations. It's funny, adventurous and has the character development that we want to see in a Pixar movie prequel. This time around Mike is the protagonist. His life is shown from the school days to studying in college and then finally getting a job at Monsters Inc. Seeing him really reminded me of my own days of school, which is the reason why I liked his character so much over here. Sully is like one of those normie guys whom I'd always choose to stay away from in my school/college days. I absolutely hate people like him. And that's what made me side by Mike even more. But eventually as Mike and Sully became friends and took part in the competition, I began liking Sully slowly. He's the kind of a character who may act like a douche, but is not completely bad. He does not behave that way because he himself wants to. He's just doing it because he thinks this is what will make him popular. Coming from a big family he never understood the way normal people behave. And once he became friends with Mike, he slowly began to change. Although he still didn't trust Mike, because of which he cheated to make Mike win by adjusting the dial of the scared child. The ending was actually pretty unexpected. I was thinking they will graduate from college and then become employees at Monsters Inc. After all, the college name sounded just like the company. But the ending seemed completely random and hilarious. They slowly rose up to the ranks, answering the question within the last 30 seconds. I watched this movie about 2 years ago and I have very little memory of it. So I can't exactly remember every single detail that happened in it. I can definitely say that this was a very fun movie, although not exactly memorable. I'd say Monsters University is a good movie, just like all the other Pixar sequels, if you're a fan of the previous movies and want to watch something fun for the whole family. It's quite surprising no one takes its name when talking about Pixar sequels. They only say Cars 2, Finding Dory, Incredibles 2 etc. I wouldn't have even known about it if I didn't open the Pixar Wikipedia page and scrolled through all the names of the movies that I wanted to bingewatch. This movie is definitely something I'd watch again if I get the chance.

I like this prequel in the sense we get a lot of world-building. Honestly, it was awesome to see Mike and Sully have a rocky start to their friendship. I enjoy how we get to see Randall before he is out for revenge. I think it is a really cool movie and you get to see Mike struggle with something he has been dealing with his whole life. It does capture the classic Pixar magic but something about the original captures my heart as I grew up to it. I do this this is a fun addition to the story.

This felt very much like a generic animated movie stuck in first gear during the first half of the runtime. The new characters were decent, but the story itself didn't feel very original. The movie starts becoming more focused in the latter stages of the ‚ÄòScare Games' when stakes feel higher and this is where characters begin to develop their one-dimensional personalities. Also, seeing a more realistic art style in the landscape when Mike and Sully visit the human world was unique. I liked the idea of the B-movie cabin in the woods horror scene to scare adults. It gave the movie a fresh change. I didn't find the underlying tones, mood, or humour that you'd expect in a Pixar film, and there was little that would appeal to adult viewers.

This review contains spoilers. Monsters University exists. Luckily it exists. Let's clarify immediately that I loved this film to madness. I really like the US collegiate environment and I really enjoyed seeing Monsters Inc's monster world again. So why didn't I give it 5 stars? Because unfortunately the film has flaws, but there are also great merits. First of all, the animation is of great quality and the amount of monsters created is impressive. The moral of the film is the thing that needs to be given more credit. We have always been used to messages like: always follow your dreams, do not be discouraged by difficulties, become someone. And then comes Monsters University which teaches you that we have impassable limits and that we shouldn't believe too much in dreams. Only this, for me, should be shown to all children: it is a really important message. The film is divided into 3 acts: Mike's arrival at university, the scare games and at the end the surprise with the two protagonists who face the human world for Mike's aversion to the fact that he doesn't scare anyone. All three acts are well done. Honestly my favorite is not the third act, as everyone thinks, but the second: all the games are great and Johnny Worthington III, the second act villain, I love it. But let's go now to the painful notes of the film. The film already contradicts itself in its existence: in Monsters Inc Mike says that they met well before university. But here it is necessary to specify how they knew about the sentence and tried to create a link anyway, which however was too forced. So I can perfectly understand why they didn't. The new characters added, except Dean, are poorly characterized and are not given much space. Most of all I would have liked to know more about Johnny's past and why he bullies Mike. Moreover, even the members of the ozma kappa themselves do not have three-dimensionality. Randall, however, forms the lowest point in the characters. I love Randall at Monsters Inc, but they made some serious mistakes here developing him. He is presented to us as kind, shy, however the opposite of how we all know him. So during the vision I wondered how they were going to change his temperament. Well, he becomes a popular monster thanks to Mike and therefore has access to the ROR group (Johnny's fraternity so to speak). So, during the games, I honestly didn't see any gradual changes, but it seems like suddenly, during the final game, Randall totally changed his character. Don't tell me that failing to scare Sulley's retaliation is justifiable. An early-film Randall wouldn't have taken it so badly. If you wanted to radically change Randall, maybe I would have put the background on ROR or I would have already shown a different character at the beginning of the film. Because in my opinion the influence of the RORs is no excuse. The relationship between Mike and Sulley is really well developed, even too much. Perhaps the real problem with the film is precisely that: they thought too much about Mike and Sulley leaving out the other characters. That said, the film, despite its flaws, managed to do the most important thing, which is to make you fall in love with the characters and the film in general. A student plot, Pixar-branded animations but above all a morality worthy of the study make Monsters University a very good film despite the superficiality of the non-main characters.
I like this, sort of, sequel or pre-movie to Monsters Inc. I think it was fine but It wasn't my super favorite. It was a good idea and was executed good.

Though not nearly as great as the original, "The Matrix Reloaded" is still a fun film that improves upon the original in some ways though disimproves in several others. Where I think the sequel succeeds is in the action, which is done much better in this movie than in the first. The CGI is also improved upon in this, as is the world-building with the introduction of the teased city Zion. However, where this film falls short in comparison to the first is the story, which feels more predictable and bland than the original. Also, the whole idea doesn't feel as fresh anymore, and the dialogue feels dumbed down. This was still a rather enjoyable film, and a worthy sequel to the amazing first Matrix movie.

(Contains spoilers of this one and the first)Well, it was nice. At least, it was better than expected. I thought it would be a disaster but honestly, it was correct without being absolutely fantastic like the first one. I think that the story wasn't good and that is why it wasn't really good. Too much useless moments and it is long for nothing. Honestly, it could have been 1h45 and it would have been better. Also, I think Neo has too much power. I mean, he can be the One without being a mix of Superman, Spider-man, Batman and Black Panther. He revives Trinity, ok. He flies, ok... He fights thousands of Agent Smith, well that is a bit too much. Also, I think the VFX are worst than in the first movie. Some moments were animated like in the Polar express and I didn't like it. I know it was impossible to do it differently but that made me under appreciate the visuals. Now, I really liked the script. It was richer than in the first one. Keanu doesn't just ask questions and there is some really nice lines. Especially from Morpheus. More sci-fi and thought-provoking talks and I like it. Come on guys, this ain't bad. Matrix Reloaded is nowhere near the level of the masterpiece that is the first movie but is it a bad sequel or movie? No. There's some great worldbuilding like the addition of Zion. I love the design and it's awesome seeing the free human city mentioned in the first movie and it was also great seeing the people freed from the Matrix and what they suffered through including some of the politics. The action and choreography of this movie is outstanding with the freeway chase being the standout and while some of the CGI is poor, the effects are incredibly impressive for the most part, the acting is great just like the first movie, more philosophical reasons are discovered like the concept of human choice, cause and effect as well as this idea of reason and these philosophical conversations are interesting especially with the Oracle and Merovignian. The Keymaker is another interesting bit of worldbuilding and I like Trinity and Neo's relationship and seeing their love for one another and we also learned of the origins of the Matrix and contrary to popular belief, I liked the inclusion of the Architect, subverting the story from the supposed chosen one trope that was so insisted by Morpheus. All in all, it's a good sequel. It's really flawed though. There's this dance party in Zion with a ton of overly sexualized characters that's dragged on too long, the plot takes a while to get going and the fact that the movie was split into two did not help. The movie tries to do too much with its ambition and this has the whole Zion plotline as well as the machines invading it sadly forgotten most of the movie and some of the action and philosophical conversations are too long, ruining the pacing. The movie feels kind of tensionless with the lack of threat. The way Neo revives Trinity and discovers his new found power makes no sense . Neo is also so overpowered in this movie now and Agent Smith is brought back somehow and does nothing. The ending is quite unsatisfying, being rushed but frankly, this movie doesn't deserve some of the hate it gets. The first Matrix is way better but this is a good sequel that, while very flawed, has a lot of the great stuff that made the original a masterpiece.

This is good but not as a stand alone. I think the love of the first film and the interest in the characters and story carries most of this film. While it is a continuation of the original and seems to pick up where the original left off, it seems off point fo the importance message and mission that ended the second. We do see an expansion off the rebellion and are exposed to more members of the Resistance; however, that is not necessarily a good thing. There is more disharmony than I expected among and between these characters in light of the heroics of the original. Fishburne, Moss, and Reeves are great. Some new characters are very intriguing. Others not so much. While there is more of Agent Smith in some ways- he is much less interesting in others. The fight scenes and visuals are still stellar. The visual effects are spectacular. The music is compelling. This film does not hold up to the first- but no film really could. The real question I keep asking myself is whether this film should have been made at all. Regardless, Neo is one part Anakin Skywalker, one part Paul Atredes, and 100% one of the coolest characters in modern movies.

I just rewatched all three of these movies yesterday so now is the perfect time for me to review them. The Matrix Reloaded isn't a bad film at all, it's nowhere near as good as the first movie but there is still a lot about this film that makes it interesting and worth watching. I do have my fair share of complaints about Reloaded but I'll get to those at the end of my review, I'm going to explain what I like so much about this film first. For starters, The Wachowskis took the already visually stunning, intense and masterfully coreographed fight sequences from the first movie and turned everything about them up to 11 for Reloaded. The freeway chase sequence in my opinion is still one of the most suspenseful and intense action sequences in all of modern film, and the fight sequence between Neo & Agent Smith in the park after Neo's conversation with The Oracle is just straight up awesome. Before I first watched this movie as a kid I never thought I would find something like Keanu Reeves fighting a literal moshpit of Hugo Weavings so mindnumbingly entertaining. Sure, a lot of the CGI in that fight scene is kinda cheesy and dated looking rewatching it now almost 20 years after it came out, but I feel like critics who allow stuff like that to take points off of movies as a whole are way too nitpicky. I also really like the introduction to the last human city of Zion in this movie, it has a perfect dystopian feel to it. I also love the way we get to see Neo's powers evolve throughout the film, it has a very special way of slowly showing that Neo is growing to become the most powerful being in all of The Matrix. The sequence at the end of the movie where Neo's visions about Trinity dying come true and he uses his new powers to literally digitize his arm reach inside her body to jumpstart her heart and bring her back to life is really cool. But that is where my affections toward The Matrix Reloaded end and my many problems with this movie begin. First of all and this is my biggest problem with not only this entire movie but also all of The Matrix Revolutions is that it doesn't feel like Neo's story anymore. Reloaded & Revolutions seemed to entirely forget that Neo is supposed to be the main protagonist of these movies, instead he spends pretty much the entirety of both sequels feeling more like a melodramatic side character while the movies shifted all of their focus on Morpheus, Niobe, Commander Lock, and the crews of The Hammer, The Logos and The Nebuchadnezzar. This movie is pretty much all about stupid senseless arguing between Commander Lock, who might I add is one of the most idiotic and hateable characters of this entire franchise and Morpheus. The entire "build-up" to the war in the mediocre excuse for a third film could have been and SHOULD have been a small side-plot. Not the main focus of basically the entire movie. Also, I hate The Architect. That entire sequence needs to be removed from the movie completely. It ruins the mystery of The Matrix by literally showing you who created it. One of the best parts of the first movie was that nobody truly knew where The Matrix came from or how it was operated, by introducing The Architect in his stupid room made of TV screens the directors were literally taking 60% of what makes these movies so cool and shooting it in the face at point blank range. In my review of the first movie I mentioned how much I like the philosophical feeling that presents itself throughout the whole plot. In Reloaded that sense of philosophy is completely gone and instead everybody basically just speaks in riddles for 2 hours & 18 minutes, the worst offenders of this complaint being THE FRENCHMAN, Agent Smith and The Architect. My last problem with this movie overall is Neo & Trinity's romantic relationship. The Wachowskis couldn't write convincing love if someone held a gun to their heads. Whenever these two are on screen together they just make out like high schoolers and throw sappy Valentine's Day card level compliments at eachother and we're expected to believe they have his strong loving relationship just because the movie tells us to think that. AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THAT AWKWARD 5 MINUTE LONG SEX SCENE. Also, The Keymaker was completely pointless to the plot besides to guide Neo to The Architect, which is one of the worst plot twists in film history. Anyways, for the most part this movie is entertaining to watch for the action sequences and scenes that actually involve Neo. Other than that, this movie feels more like a spinoff than an actual sequel to the first Matrix movie. 7 out of 10.

With the trailer for The Matrix Resurrections hitting Comic Con recently (although still widely unavailable for the rest of us) I had an urge to rewatch the sequels. Since the last time I saw The Matrix both the original directors have come out as trans (Lily and Lana Wachowski) and have since stated that the original film was an allegory about being transgender. It's certainly not a reading I considered at fourteen, I was more sold on the many different types of religious allegories that appeared to be spattered throughout the film. It will be interesting to rewatch now knowing the exact interpretation that the directors intended. Anyway I started with Reloaded. I remember being insanely excited for the film when it came out, and although it's not close in terms of having as many interesting things to say as its predecessor, Reloaded has many aspects to it that still impress. The freeway sequence remains a standout, and Neo's fight with an increasing number of Agent Smith doubles isn't quite as grating as it was the first time round. Critically The Matrix Reloaded was on a hiding to nothing on its release; however good it might have been it wouldn't have been good enough. And although many argue there was no need for these sequels, Reloaded does a much better job of following up The Matrix than it gets credit for. It will be interesting to see how Revolutions holds up; I've always been an apologist for both the sequels despite their backlash from all sides. Perhaps that sort of attitude will lend itself favourably to Resurrections on its release in December this year; I have literally no idea what to expect of it.

Action lovers gotta see this one. Lots of CGI yes but disregarding how poorly its aged its only a few scenes. This movie flows very well. Keeps you watching anxiously. A superb sci-fi action film! Had to deduct half a star for some of the preachy, long winded dialog scenes with unnatural and overly sophisticated language (sounds goofy at times).

Even more overrated than The Matrix. How can people not see the lack of substance here? The plot was dull, nonsensical, and took too long to get going, there was far too much dialogue and bad, robotic dialogue at that, which ruined the pacing and made the film boring, there was no character development besides an unnecessary sex scene and some kissing, the acting was mediocre, there was too much CGI, the action sequences were repetitive and largely CGI, the costumes were silly once again, the soundtrack felt like nothing new, and the cinematography and editing were unattractive. Why did Neo become Superman? Where did all the people come from? How do they manage to produce food? How come they weren't found and killed by the machines? Nothing was explained because it couldn't be explained. The film was completely mindless besides the choreography.

The MATRIX trilogy remains an absolute landmark work of sci-fi, but the films do feel slightly self-indulgent now, each for different reasons. In this second film, the repeat, extended martial arts scenes drag down what is otherwise a heady and sophisticated work of philosophical sci-fi that skillfully deepens the Matrix mythology/metaphor.

The Matrix Rehashed, I mean, Reloaded, was always going to be a tough sell. Our minds were fully bent by the first film, but there was not much left in the Wachowski bag of tricks for any sequels that would allow them to hit the same highs. More Kung fu. Meh. More bullet time. Meh. More Agent Smith (literally). Double meh. In my view, there was a wasted opportunity to do something different with the Smith character, just as Terminator 2 did with the T800 (Schwarzenegger's character). For example, they could have explored the idea that Agent Smith has become an outlaw program, having been freed within the system by Neo, requiring other characters within the Matrix to assist Neo to destroy the exile program. Instead, they chose more of the same, Neo battles multiple copies of Agent Smith, but this time with unrealistic cgi fight scenes, with a muddled plot that doesn't seem to go anywhere. Spoiler alert: Matrix III dishes up even more if the same. Let's hope Matrix iV brings us something genuinely new.
