The Matrix Reloaded is a worthy sequel packed with incredible action. The film relies on its intense and lengthy fight scenes, the freeway sequence is memorable. Matrix Reloaded has solid character development with heavy focus on the romance between Trinity and Neo. Not nearly as good as the first film but a fun action blockbuster.

After the runaway success of The Matrix, the Wachowski sisters had the most creative and financial power of their entire career. It's safe to say the anticipation to The Matrix Reloaded was incredible. It was a cultural phenomenon and constantly the topic of discussion during free time at high school. The sequel sees Neo (Keanu Reeves) and his allies race against time before the machines destroy their city of Zion. While seeking the truth of The Matrix, Neo must face a vengeful Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving). Packed with as much visual flair as the predecessor, I clearly remember my jaw hitting the floor at the thrilling action sequences. They're full of energy, kinetic and wonderful to watch. The fight choreography is incredibly varied, mixing hand-to-hand martial arts with guns, and even car chases. The highway sequence is possibly one of the best set pieces of the past decade. The performances from everyone are just as strong as before. Keanu Reeves (Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure) delivers a somber and cool attitude of Neo. Whereas Hugo Weaving (Mortal Engines) is perfectly cast in a career-defining role as Agent Smith. He knows exactly how to best articulate the dialogue. While The Matrix is definitely a superior movie, The Matrix Reloaded is a worthy follow-up.
very nice and unpredictable

The Matrix Reloaded has grown on me over the years. Its a good Sci-Fi movie but was probably always destined to fail to live up to the original masterpiece. Its more style than substance and less intriguing. The old saying 'less is more' comes to mind and perhaps the curtain gets pulled back too much in this sequel. The Wachowskis do attempt to inject new philosophical ideas but they don't always land. Nevertheless its a triumph of action and style with some interesting new characters like The Architect and Monica Bellucci's Persephone.

Just like the previous film, The Matrix Reloaded seems to be more focused on sounding big and epic rather than giving us interesting characters to care for. However unlike the previous film, this one doesn't even do a good job hiding it, as most of the scenes, rather than being dedicated to innovative and badass action, are more interested in spewing exposition and setting up the next movie.

I like Reloaded as much as I like the first movie. It's true it may have lost a bit of its novelty and mystery, but I still think it's a very entertaining film. Just like the first movie, the action scenes are amazing and they still hold up. Philosophical and political subtexts and undertones are still present. For what it's worth it, I believe Matrix Reloaded is a worthy sequel. I like it.

Like the first film, Reloaded spends more time explaining its concepts than really exploring them, though it certainly has plenty of new ideas to bring to the table. It also has a lot of action scenes‚Äîof varying quality. A lot of this movie tries desperately hard to feel smarter than it is, but the whole thing might be worth rewatching just for that killer highway car chase scene.

Brings the movie down by a lot.

review: Where do I begin? This film, despiste the story they're trying to tell us, is full of predictability, sci-fi scenes and too much creativity. Characters with super strength and a very and already seen in this saga predictable story. It looked like I was wacthing Iron Man instead of good-old Fast and Furious. The number of beyond-human scenes is incredible. I could close my eyes to it and follow the story, but even the story is filled with flaws. I guess 'for the family' is a good slogan, but not for a film franchise. At least, not to such a unrelastic one. P. S.: In the next film, they're going to Mars ... 'for the family'.

review: F9: The Fast Saga - PG-13 (2h 23m) 2021 - Action, Adventure, Crime, Thriller 2.5/5 stars So my thoughts are kinda all over on this one. On one hand, this was exactly what the series is supposed to be. Over the top crazy, I mean the franchise inches towards crazier with each installment. I remember way back when, in the first film when they were stealing TV/VCR combos and having fun street racing. Now they're literally going to space in cars... (with little to no explanation about the issues with that idea.) This one did some fun things with returning characters, some of which I guess survived moments that are now pretty lame if you re-watch the older films. The ending was really interesting, I'm crossed because it kinda felt forced but at the same time was a fun was to pay homage to a character that doesn't appear in the film. As a whole, the story of the film was more than predictable but they never have been. The reason I didn't go lower with the rating is similar to how some of the Amityville sequels get higher ratings than most would think. I don't care if you spend $500 or $500 million making a film, if you know what the film is and play into that, then in my book it's a win. I'll continue to check out this franchise because they're a fun brainless popcorn flick and sometimes that's exactly what you need! I wonder how they'll top going to space! #f9 #thefastsaga

rt_name: No Time to Die - Movie Reviews

review: Old man 007 has no time to stop for a piss in this return to formulaic form for the franchise. Evil geniuses with evil accents, car chases, a watch that has some sort of a magnet in it, a lair, a staggering array of incompetent henchmen, failing to actually kill Bond‚Ä¶. tick, tick, tick, tick tick. Lovely Bond girls presented in a less attainable or more responsible way than Connery would recognise. Great backdrops, martinis, Aston Martin V8, the Navy, M, Q, other letters, 2*007s; tick, tick, tick. Pheobe Whaller-Bridge clearly worked a bit of magic on the script, adding humour to what would have been a worthy but exhausting affair. It's way better than the dirge that was Skyfall and a nice way of spending an afternoon dozing off your booster vaccination.
rt_name: No Time to Die - Movie Reviews

review: While I liked Skyfall better I cannot think of a more epic or caring way to close out the Daniel Craig era of Bond than No Time to Die. Craig has brought not just a gritty realism to the Bond but also a humanity that was evident from Casino Royale and only grew as the series progressed. The humanity that was often lacking in period iterations of Bond were on clear display. If I were to criticize this movie it would be that it may have been better served as a 2 part epic rather than an occasionally rushed, but brilliant piece of action/drama storytelling. I highly recommend this movie.

review: An elderly gentleman finally gets to go on an adventure to Paradise Falls. As many people have already said, the first 11:30 of this movie is fantastic! Once again Pixar displays their ability to tell a great story without using a word. Post that eleven and a half minute mark the film doesn't live up to that opening, it isn't bad, just not as great. The voice acting is well done, but no real standouts. The animation from Pixar is again terrific. This film succeeds in invoking a sense of awe, adventure, comedy and in the end will warm your heart. Highly recommended movie, go check it out!

One of the few times I've been in a movie theater where it went totally silent. That beginning montage starts so happy and ends so heartbreaking all with the same tune just slowly morphing into a slower more somber version was brilliant. All you could hear in that silence of the theater was sniffling. A wonderful heartwarming tale of the grouchy old man and the enthusiastic young kid meshed so well together. The only thing I didn't like was that it kind of dragged in the middle.

A movie that a lot of people hold it on high regards but I have never had that feeling. Yes, the opening scene is phenomenal and the humor is good and emotions are flourished like any other Pixar film but I kind off disconnected with it sometimes but that's just my personal opinion.

Once again pixar delivers A touching movie that will tug at the heart strings there is plenty of deep moments and humor mixed in Russell and mr. Fredricksen have a good relationship its no finding nemo or toy story but still has it where it counts
One of the best animated films ever made and maybe the best Pixar one
ES MUY TRISTE EL INICIO, MUY GOD
A great movie, considered a classic. Just re-watched it. 7.5/10

review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

Wow! Last time I saw this animated masterpiece, I must have been like 7 or 8 years old and it was one of those films that I was watching on repeat. I think that what I liked about it when I was this age was principally the visuals. The animation is just fantastic. It is colorful and marks the memory. Also, being full of animals and having a nice and beautiful story probably helped in my appreciation of this movie when I was young. But today, for my first rewatch in lots of years, I've realized how good, punching and perfect this film is. I laughed so hard at some parts, cried at other and felt stressed for some others. The emotions are so much present that I was living all the feelings on earth in only 1h35. Pixar did a PHENOMENAL job on this. From the animation, to the story, to the voices, the feelings it brings and the sort of morale (live adventurous but also keep the adventures apart if you have a love that is stronger). This movies took my tears Up to my eyes and I love it!
This Pixar movie is so adorable, I get never tired of it.

While not revolutionizing children animated films, Ne Zha provides an epic tale, that is bound to entertain younger audiences. It is very well animated, with visually spectacular action scenes. It also leaves plenty of room for franchise potential. 8/10
Now this ones gonna make you cry.

What may mainly seem like the familiar colorful playfulness of CGI-animated movies we know in the States is enhanced by edgy, dark details that are apparently free game in China - "Ne Zha" is an action-packed adventure for those craving for verification of other countries' control over the medium.
I thought it was good overall, nice story, but a little tricky to follow at times. Look forward to the sequel
The animation is freaking incredible

That was so much fun to watch! I laughed and cried while thoroughly enjoying every moment. I JUST watched this on Netflix and really feel the need to share this treasure. The storyline is fresh and wasn't predictable. The graphics and animation were very enjoyable. It's cute enough (and safe) for kids and engaging for adults. We watched it in Chinese with English subtitles. My husband doesn't speak Chinese and loved it. There's actually some mixing of two different Chinese dialects so i think subtitles helped me too lol. The cultural elements was also spot on. It reminds me of vintage Pixar.
This movie is super cool . It is fast-paced, funny, nicely drawn and would make people sob too. I highly recommend everyone to watch it. It is such a pleasant entertainment.

The story telling is fluent and concise. Characters are well modeled, nice fight scenes and astonishing voice casting. So surprised that this company can make a Disney level cartoon. Absolutely deserve a 5 star.
make me proud of china

On August 31, 2019, "Ne Zha" made the second largest box-office record of Chinese movies. So you may wonder, what makes "Ne Zha" so popular? "Ne Zha" which was a new released animated movie last summer based on a chinese legendary mythical figure called "Nezha" directed and written by Jiaozi. It is still on trends because of its interesting acting styles and meaningful content. As soon as I saw it, I became a fan of this movie and even watched it twice later. Nezha was chosen to be a reincarnation of a good spirit. However, unfortunately it was replaced with the evilest spirit when he was born. He showed his stubborn and mischievous nature which made the villagers panic. In the process of his growing up, the villagers had always treated him with prejudice and fear, no matter what he thought or did. The prejudice was that monsters in people's hearts can cover their eyes and can't see the truth. Finally, until Nezha tried his best to save the villagers, they really let go of their prejudices and accepted him. The reason why I like it is because it gives us some positive energy about life. Nezha said: "My destiny isn't written in the stars, but held in my hands." You know, maybe we all have our own destinies. However, there are still some parts of our lives that can be changed to be good if our minds are set to be so. So who are you, do you have the final say? We are constantly defined by various occasions and needs. Regarding the truth about ourselves, sometimes we have no say in ourselves. Just like the protagonist Meursault in "The Outsider "by the existentialist master Camus, he has no right to speak on the truth of the case he is involved in. This world is sometimes so ridiculous, and many of us in it just endure silently. Therefore, the explosive moment of "Nezha" must arouse the blood and passion in the hearts of the audience. We need Nezha, even if it's just in the movie. The film retains the essence of Chinese traditional culture, good visual effects; the other is the modernity and sense of humor in character shaping and language style. There is also an ugly side in the film. Compared to the truth, many people are more willing to believe in hearsay and then look at people with colored glasses. Moreover, the writer clearly used "Ao Bing" as a contrast to Nezha, highlighting that whether a man or a devil is an independent choice, rather than a subject that is destined by nature. Generally speaking, I take the view that this Chinese animation is of good quality and worth watching. The final product is fascinating and stunning with great humor, deep emotion, exciting action.
My fav Chinese animated film.

The movie of Nezha is set in a Mythical world in China. There is a powerful orb that absorbs all energy, which was meant to be destroyed by Taiyi and Shen, two immortals with great powers. It is known as the Chaos Pearl. The Chaos Pearl is divided into two opposite orbs by Yuan Shi (the primordial lord of heaven) the Spirit Pearl and the Demon Orb. Casting a spell of destruction on the Demon Orb to be destroyed in three years so that it doesn't destroy the world. Yuan Shi gives the order to Taiyi to take the spirit pearl so that it can be born into a human. The spirit pearl was supposed to be born as Nezha however due to Shen switching the orbs a young boy is birthed from the Demon Orb whose demonic nature is apparent. As a young boy, Nezha is loved by his parents who lied to him to tame his demonic nature. He is trained by Taiyi to become a demon hunter and is told that he was born from the Spirit Pearl. Becoming impatient he escapes to hunt demons where he meets Ao Bing (also trained to hunt demons) who was born from the spirit pearl as a dragon and was educated rigorously to become a demon hunter and to beware of humans. They fight together the demon however Ao Bing loses, and Nezha ends up rescuing him. The villagers however misinterpret the situation and blame all the destruction on Nezha due to his demonic nature. Nezha and Ao Bing become friends. However Nezhas's third birthday is coming, his parents throw him a birthday party and force the town to come. Shen visits Nezha before the party and tells him that he has lied to his whole life and that he was born of the demon orb. Nezha feels betrayed and unleashes his demonic powers destroying everything and almost killing his dad however he leaves to await his fate. Shen knows that if Yuan Shi finds out the truth about what had happened. Tat all of the dragon race will be condemned. So Ao bing decides to use his powers to destroy Nezha's village to erase any evidence of the events. Nezha is shown through a vision that his dad had been trying to find a way to remove the curse. In which he takes the curse upon himself so that Nezha could live. Because of this Nezha returns to his village to stop Ao Bing from destroying his village. He defeats Ao bing but spares him. When lighting comes to kill him he surrenders to his fate. However, Ao bing joins him in taking the hit of the lighting. Because of them joining the Chaos Pearl is once again united and can absorb the full hit of the lighting. Taiyi makes it possible for their spirits to survive. This story plays the themes of nature vs. nurture and choice. Even though Nezha was naturally born with a demonic spirit, didn't have many friends, and was feared and hated by his village, he was raised by good parents who loved him, taught him to control himself, and was told that he was born from the spirit pearl. So when Nezha was growing up, he had a pretty positive paradigm about himself, which led him to be able to control his demonic nature and be good. On the other, hand, we see Ao Bing being born from the spirit pearl he was told that he was going to be great, he did however have a rougher upbringing being raised by the king of the dragons and trained by Shen, and like a dragon, he was a hated creature by humans, but he was loved by his kin. When the time comes for them to know, and be faced by who they are. They have the choice to be what their destinies told them to be, or who they were raised to. Having to choose to act upon their natures, what they were told their whole life to be, or choose between good and bad. Nezha decides to act for himself and not let his nature control him, he decides to defend his family, his village, and what is right. What is interesting for me is not Nezha's struggle with choice, but it is Ao Bings. He was way more likely to be good since he was born from the Spirit Pearl, but because of the way he was nurtured to protect his kin he struggles with the choice of helping Nezha save his village or helping Shen. However, in the end, he helps Nezha and also helps Nezha's life as a spirit by uniting their powers. Overall I love this movie because of the character development presented and the message of us choosing to act and not be acted upon. It is also light-hearted and a perfect family night movie. The final rating would be 5 stars!

The story is rich with emotions, character growth, struggle, adventure and laughs. As for the animation itself, even though it is in 3D, it is really good, was refreshing to see how different it was from your standard animation offering from either Japan or Disney/Pixar.

This is probably my favorite animated movie ever. I prefer animated movies to live-action and I have watched plenty of animated movies from all over the world. Ne Zha tops all of those movies without a doubt. It's always been difficult for me to pick a favorite animated movie, I actually never even had one before this; Ne Zha is so different from all the others it's refreshing. I'm eager to see what this studio does in the future. Ne Zha is more for teens and adults, so if you're one of those "animation is only for kids" people, I urge you to give Ne Zha a shot; it really is worth it.
One disadvantage I can come up with is that many jokes here are cringe-worthy, like dad jokes in the early 2000s.

While undeniably annoyingly overwhelming in action sequences in the third act and messy in pacing, Ne Zha is terrific in the entire first half, very intriguing in its fantastical mythology and so gorgeously animated with spectacular visuals. It's a fantasy epic that is very engaging to watch and so stupendously mounted on multiple fronts. It truly is exciting seeing China finally get on board in the animation medium with this high-quality blockbuster.
Exquisite scenery and stirring twists on an old tale

Nezha is one of the most popular and well-known mythical characters in China. Nezha appear in many myths. There are various versions of Nezha's story, and it has been adapted many times in animation and movies. But this adaptation is revolutionary. In the original myths, Nezha is a good boy, but the plot is way more violent. In the myths, Nezha is human baby borne with divine power. His father is indifferent and strict with him. One day, Hezhan caught the Dragon Prince killing children, and then he killed the Dragon Prince (cruelly skinned the young dragon alive). When Dragon King found out, it came to Nezha's revenge. The Dragon King wanted to flood Nezha's hometown with seawater. To protect the village, Nezha committed suicide in front of the Dragon King and his parents. Later, Nezha was resurrected in the lotus and became a God. Then Nazhe destroyed the dragon palace, caught the Dragon King, and became one of the Gods of War. In other versions, Nezha killed a total of 9 dragons. Comparing to the original myth, this movie is chill and light hearted in a good way. The rebellious character of Nezha is fresh and interesting to watch. This story emphasis on the lesson of "choosing your own path", where the original version is more about "unconditional self-sacrifice" and "Â≠ùÈÅì(obedience towards elder family members)". The revised story in the film is more in line with modern values than the original myths.
AWESOME!!!! I would 100% recommend this to anyone who appreciates animation and a thrilling story, whether you know about Chinese mythology or not!
The animation is well done compared to other Chinese animated movie. The storyline is smooth gave Viewers a very good ideas of what is going on.

Really touching and hitting the heart! Facing the misunderstanding, discrimination, and unfairness, Ne Zha, a lucky kid beloved by his parents, insisted his virtues and fought against his destined cursed life. He woke up everyone's softest part hidden inside deeply. No one is destined to be evil or criminal, love can release everyone's true nature.

Alfonso Cuaron's Gravity is a roller coaster ride through space, a testament to the resilience of a human being in the face of unimaginable adversity. Sandra Bullock plays Dr Ryan Stone, an astronaut left alone in the vast expanse of space when her colleagues are killed by space debris. The entire film is thrilling, but the first thirty minutes are absolutely remarkable, a crowning achievement in special effects and cinematography. The special effects and cinematography are stellar throughout the film, as are the sound effects and the performance by Bullock. The scene of Bullock making radio contact with a father consoling a crying baby is both inspiring and heartbreaking. Rarely has a film packed so much into an 82-minute running time.
As thrilling as "No Country For Old Men", and as beautiful as "Interstellar", Gravity is Cuarons' masterpiece. A titillating survival expedition, filled with hope and optimism.

There's no denying that this film is a cinematic masterpiece when it comes to the cinematography and sound design, but there's a distinct lack of story and drive which makes it quite disappointing and monotonous in places. I won't score a 1 as the CGI carried this movie, and helped boost the score ever so slightly. Clooney's character death felt like a desperate attempt to get some action in. Also, Bullock won a nomination for her acting? This wasn't deserved in the slightest, mostly grunting, heavy breathing, and terrible one liner clich√© comments. There is a heart-racing premise and there are indeed incredible special effects, but it falls short and mostly at the hands of the actors and narrative arc.
Better than most, if not all, space movies. Cuaron is a stellar director.

Stunning view with high octane suspense from start to the end, what can you ask for more from 2 awards winners? Absolutely in my re-watch list, pretty scary will piss & shit your pants but not a horror movie.

My biggest fear through the film was that Bullocks Botox would zit explode at zero gravity. Obviously pressured by the studio the coming together of the two stars on screen is additionally ridiculous in an already pointless endeavor. Additionally - all the movies visual greatness is lost on any Home Screen. If you want a survival movie that gets it right - All is Lost. The Bullock - Clooney smugness ooozes like a Zenomorphs slime from the screen in Gravity.
Star wars, pero para los oscars

Gravity boasts some of the strongest visuals around, but threadbare characters and some hiccups in the writing and Bullock's performance when she must perform by herself without the solid Clooney hinder the overall quality of the piece. The film is short but drags in the middle and becomes carried away in its own spectacle. For some, I have no doubt that this is captivating, but it lacks the substance necessary with Cuaron not focusing on building strong or particularly likable characters. A shame, due to the same man's almost faultless direction.

I did the full treatment on this one, 3D IMAX. I was blown away by the photography and the pacing of the story. When I left the theater, my legs felt wobbly, like jelly. I got to the parking garage, got in my car and right before I was about to start it my head suddenly felt woozy and I started laughing and controllably. And then I realized what was happening - oxygen deprivation. For almost an hour and a half my pulse had been racing non-stop, my metabolism in overdrive and my breath quick and shallow. That was when I realized just how much of a thrill ride I had been on.
This is the worst movie I have ever sat entirely through. I can't believe Sandra Bullock got sucked into this movie. The only good part of the movie is that George Clooney did not survive.

review_date: The movie is a stunning exercise in high budget production trying to save a hot mess of a film. The films beautifully constructed shots and editing is actively being detracted from by the absolute disregard of high school level physics, a story that couldn't be less engaging and is the most basic accumulation of stereotypes (US good, Russia bad, China stupid; mentioning deceased family as a tear-jerker; sacrifice of a main character to heighten the stakes....) to try and construct a semblance of relatability for audiences. It is an affront to modern space technology, a premise that should've been outdated even in cold wars films, and a soundtrack that does nothing but horror-style tremolo strings rising in pitch slowly for 90 minutes straight. In general, the only "thrill" achieved by the movie to make it actually fit the description of "Sci-Fi Thriller" was the soundtrack desperately hammering every single horror staple home to a nauseating degree. Combine this with the unfitting joke-scenes completely subverting any seriousness that might have been left, and what remains is a hot mess of garbage that looks somewhat beautiful. How this movie won 7 academy awards is beyond me.

I remember deciding to watch this movie in cinemas because critics were all praising it as one of the best movies of that year. I watched it in IMAX 3D and remember being blown away by the movie. It won: Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Visual Effects, Best Film Editing, Best Original Score, Best Sound Editing, and Best Sound Mixing at the Oscars which is a lot of awards. The synopsis is "Dr Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) is a medical engineer on her first shuttle mission. Her commander is veteran astronaut Matt Kowalsky (George Clooney), helming his last flight before retirement. Then, during a routine spacewalk by the pair, disaster strikes: The shuttle is destroyed, leaving Ryan and Matt stranded in deep space with no link to Earth and no hope of rescue. As fear turns to panic, they realize that the only way home may be to venture further into space". I've decided to rewatch it on a whim but this time on my home TV. The question is if this movie is overrated or deserving of its accolades. Let's talk about the concept first, it's great. A survival movie in space, with no monsters or anything like that, is such a great concept that has not been done before or since its release. The movie perfectly illustrates the horror but also the beauty of space in a way that surprisingly meshes well together. On that note of the beauty, the cinematography is amazing. A lot of amazing cinematography is usually using real shots but Gravity does it all through CGI. It shouldn't work as CGI is quite obvious and bad CGI can even take you out of the movie but Gravity doesn't "fall" in that category. There are a lot of gorgeous shots that feel like paintings and this is partially thanks to the amazing visual effects. The set design for the space ships are claustrophobic and further emphasise the loneliness within this movie. The score is great and elevates the tension in the scenes where the score is prominent but during the more hopeful scenes, the score is more orchestral and beautiful. The movie doesn't rely on the score too much and sometimes just lets the silence of space or the breathing of the astronauts to suck the audience into the movie and it works. The movie is visually spectacular but what about the characters and story? The movie is revolved around Dr Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) who is our point of view character. For the most part, the movie makes us care about her because of the situation she is in and that is fine. However, the director (Alfonso Cuar√≥n) decided to include a scene that elaborates on Ryan Stone's backstory on Earth. This is a good choice as it makes the audience more sympathetic with her and more understanding of why her personality is what it is or why she does certain actions or choices in the movie. Matt Kowalsky (George Clooney) is a sort of anchor character that support Ryan throughout the movie. He has a contrasting personality to Ryan as he is funny and charismatic yet due to being more experienced is also one who guides Ryan. I like the dynamic between the two of them and when both of them are interacting it's funny or heartwarming. I also have to praise Sandra Bulluck as she does a great job in carrying this movie. Her performance whenever she is struggling in space feels genuine and I can feel the fear and panic just from the tone of her voice. She also delivers in the emotional moments that bring the scene to life. She was deserving of that best actress nomination at the Oscars. George Clooney does a pretty good job as well. Although, he mostly just plays Matt as the witty and charming guy. I do like it when the two are together, George overshadows Sandra which sounds weird but that is exactly what it should be in terms of who their characters are and what the plot is asking. I don't have many flaws with the movie that aren't just nitpicking but I do think the fact that Dr Ryan Stone seems to constantly panic in the first half of the movie kind of weird. Dr Ryan Stone just seems to not know the basics of being in space so know it all Matt Kowalsky constantly has to tell her stuff that I think she should've known. From a movie perspective, I get why this choice was made so that the audience can easily understand things about space but it could've handled way better in my opinion. Additionally, we get some backstory on Dr Ryan Stone but we don't get anything on Matt which I find a bit odd and lessens the impact of a certain scene. Unfortunately, I do think a lot of the impact this movie has is sadly lost because I am not watching it in a cinema. You could argue that with a lot of movies but for me watching this throughout certainly made me think "this would be way better in a cinema". In conclusion, I still really enjoyed the movie. Yes, the movie is impressive because of its style but in terms of substance, it certainly is lacking. However, the movie is just so visually spectacular that I don't mind it. Furthermore, a lot of great movies such as "Dunkirk" and "1917" do similar things to Gravity and they are both great movies as well. Gravity still is one of the best space movies to have come out in the last 20 years. I feel this movie accomplishes a lot with visual effects and space cinematography. A lot of people might not be talking about this movie anymore but for me, I certainly will still remember it.
Technical perfection and special effects not seen in the cinema so far ... But also a film about hope and finding it even in the darkness of space ...

review: The Winter Soldier was almost my number one pick and at one point was number two. I was a sceptic when I heard that Sebastian Stan was returning as one of the gruffest characters in Marvel history, as his pretty boy Bucky Barnes didn't add much to the plot of the first film. I was pleasantly surprised at the actor's versatility and strength portraying the role of the Winter Soldier. The Russo Brothers were an excellent choice to helm this sequel, which is not only one of the top superhero movies but one of the best action movies of all time. The story, acting and action is fantastic as well how this film leads into strong consequences that further impacted the MCU.

review: Steve Rogers is one of the best characters to come out of MCU. He's paired up with Natasha "Black Widow" in this story. I love her fighting style and 'grit' but her character is simply not given enough rope to work with - I guess she needs to remain 'mysterious' until her own movie. As a result their relationship fleshes out in a way I understand but do not "feel". By contrast, the Captain America figure is laid bare and we can see the different factions and emotions pulling at his deep seeded loyalty. I like this story as it gives a setting to his moralistic wrangling and, like us all, he just wants to see his choices make a difference and to feel like he has agency over his own life. The Winter Soldier idea is cool - the whole Shield is a shell that has grown the enemy within is not new, but was decently executed. Falcon seems to survive too easily. Does he even have 'superpowers'? He take a ton of punishment if not. The movie is too long - of course, all of these MCU movies are too long for an action flick. But I take at least two sittings to watch anything these days since I'm on my own couch anyway, so no big deal. I knocked off a star due to that length and the fact that very important dialogue to halfway decent plot is spurted out after a gut punch, or growled through gritted teeth, or whispered while explosions go off in the background, or shouted while a crescendo of 'dramatic' music flares too often.

review: "Breaking Dawn Part 1" just loads it on even more that the previous three films - it being wooden acting, bad dialogue and stilted plotting. It all starts out with the forest wedding of Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson). This then turns in to a honeymoon with unanticipated consequences. Just way too much extended scenes and drab dialogue that should have been cut. And the inability of the two leads to barely go through the motions of acting at being in love is galling. Add to this a plot sequence that I won't give away, yet it just further adds to this saga being a mockery of 'values'. Now, most of all I blame the author Stephanie Meyers for hoisting this on us all.

review: After two movies in the series I didn't like, I was surprised to say that the first part of "Breaking Dawn" is pretty watchable. A lot of people and reviewers prepared me for a boring movie in which nothing happens but that's not what I felt from the overall package. Sure, the movie is just as cheesy and ridiculous in its first half and I did find myself rolling my eyes during it. However, once the main plot of the movie kicks in halfway, I thought it was pretty solid. The pace moves much quicker and the focus is taken off of the romance just for a little bit, and the movie is better for it. I am not saying this is a great movie as it still has many technical issues in terms of acting and writing, but I will say it is far better than anything this franchise aside from the first movie.

review: I actually did enjoy the wedding and honeymoon of this movie. I know Edward gets a lot of flak for acting like an emotionally abusive boyfriend and Bella's shown to be just as flawed with or without him and people aren't wrong about that but Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson do share surprisingly good chemistry during this section of the movie. Perhaps it's not all that surprising seeing as how this was from the director of the live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast. Visual effects ain't half-bad either. Then Bella gets pregnant. This is where it all goes downhill for me. We spend the rest of the movie at the Cullens' house once Edward and Bella leave Brazil, with a few scenes that take place in either the woods or Charlie Swan's house and I'll just say that the whole pregnancy conflict honestly doesn't feel all that interesting given that the stakes don't feel particularly high. The action being dialed down to zero compared to the relatively decent asskicking in Eclipse doesn't help one bit. The "Part 1" of the title is an incredibly transparent attempt to cash in on the success of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows which were both critically and commercially successful (I personally consider it to be my favourite Harry Potter movie but only if counted as one movie). And I'm sorry, a well-intentioned anti-abortion message just doesn't seem like enough to warrant the adaptation of the final book being a two-parter. Give Deathly Hallows some credit, at least there was some epic and visually stunning wizard-vs-wizard action and I actually do care about those characters and understand how high the stakes were there. And the anti-abortion message would be fine if not for the fact that the concept of imprinting means that Jacob falls in love with a creepy CGI - still better than that animatronic they were initally going to use and fortunately the uncanny valley only comes in affect when we see her up close - baby. Gee, why don't we hear a lot from Taylor Lautner anymore when his character will likely never live that down? Breaking Dawn Part 1 is not a good movie and has its fair share of silly moments, most notably the wolves speaking telepathically when there was no indication that wolves could ever actually do that in earlier installments plus it looking siller than if the VFX artists decided to animate lip movement, but at least Part 2 has an epic battle...though I do know the big twist about it.
mojo_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1

review: Twilight Breaking Dawn Part 1 is a movie from the Twilight saga which originally is a serie of 4 books. They made 5 movies out of it. In my opinion it's a quite good fantasy movie but more made for young adults and teenagers. This movie was directed by Bill Condon and released the 18th of november 2011. The 3 main actors are Kristen Stewart ((Isa)Bella Swan) , Robert Pattinson (Edward Cullen) and Taylor Lautner (Jacob Black). In this movie Edward and Bella get married, she unexpectedly got pregnant during their honeymoon. This twist causes a lot of debates and fights between the recently married lovers and between the vampires and werewolves. The baby could cost Bella's life. The actors are believable, their acting skills are better than in the previous movies thus as the screenplay. They respected the books well. The movie is well shot, the camera angles are good : mostly close shot, extreme close up at the right moments (extreme close up on Bella's eyes at the end, the last image of the movie), Upward and Downward shots during the duel between the Alpha wolves, establishing shot during the wedding to show the beauty of the place and all the guests,... The soundtrack is very, very good, it's mostly alternative/ indie rock songs and a piano melody throughout the whole movie. There are percussions adding to the piano melody when actions are happening. The special effects (wolves' transformation) and make up are good too, all the Cullen have a really pale face and pregnant Bella needed to look very sick and skeletal and it is very well done. So if you're looking for good fantasy movies, I can only suggest you the Twilight saga and especially the 2 latest one.

review: "New Moon" is a real step down from the mediocre "Twilight". The worst aspect of this film - it bludgeon the audience with a Romeo and Juliet undertone and self harm as an antidote to breaking up - not a good message for teens. It has way too heavy an emphasis on the whole tortured separation between Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson), with Stewart even more wooden than in the first film and Pattinson almost catatonic. The only real plus is the added twist of hunky Jake (Lautner) 'dogging' Bella - who is just shameless in how she leads him on. The near finale in Italy really amped it up but not enough to save the film. Much, much too long - could have easily cut 30 minutes or more.

review: New Moon, the second instalment in the Twilight Saga, is probably not for anyone who is not remotely interested in the original story. It is not a standalone film. There is much more action (although balanced out by the extreme inaction of Bella's severe depression of the first third). Chris Weitz definitely made this a more polished and big-budget looking film than the original. Although whether the polish ultimately adds or distracts from the love story is an interesting question, there are some really beautiful scenes (especially the Italian scenes with the Volturi). The actors are not as painfully awkward and have become more comfortable in their characters and with each other and that does make the the entire viewing experience better. New Moon gets a lower score, because it's not my favourite segment of the story.

review_date: When I watched the first Twilight film I felt that it was bland and uninteresting in every way, and one thing I most certainly did not feel was interest in what happens next. It simply doesn‚Äôt feel like an ongoing saga after that first film, so I was curious to see how they would manage to continue the story when they got to New Moon. Well, it‚Äôs certainly just as boring. The one and only thing I will commend this movie for is that they at least addressed in some small way the general creepiness of the Edward-Bella relationship. Sure they just mention it in passing, and try to laugh it off, but there is a moment when they talk about the fact that a man that is literally hundreds of years old is seducing a teenager. Aside from that, there are no redeeming qualities in this film. The first big flaw in New Moon is that a large chunk of the movie involves Edward leaving and all the relationship stuff being taken over by Jacob. This is a problem because Robert Pattinson could act better than Taylor Lautner in his sleep. Lautner actually manages to be worse than Kristen Stewart, and I didn‚Äôt think that was possible. He is utterly devoid of charisma, and never once convinces me that he is falling in love. Combine that with Kristen Stewart‚Äôs expressionless staring into the middle-distance and you have the worst love story imaginable. As part of this stupid relationship we get to see Bella once again proving herself to be utterly clueless. Despite constant blatant hints and obvious clues, she is simply dumbfounded that werewolves exist. However, the more egregious problem with New Moon, and the reason it made me actively mad, is how it handles the break-up of Bella and Edward. I know it can be devastating to have your heart broken, but this film is so committed to the idea that these two are soulmates and have some supernatural bond, it sends ridiculously harmful messages to teens everywhere. Not only is Bella reduced to wailing in such a dramatic fashion that a responsible father would probably force her to spend time with a therapist, but it gets worse than that. At the idea of never being together again, both members of this couple feel that suicide is their only hope. It‚Äôs dark and depressing, and exactly the opposite of what we should be teaching young people. I don‚Äôt have much more to say about New Moon, because not much else happens in the movie.

review: "New Moon" has a few of the qualities that worked in the first movie, but also takes what was bad about it and makes it worse. This movie's main issue is that its main purpose is to create a love triangle and it does little to move the plot forward. The world is explored a little more and there are some exciting moments near the end, but this movie still doesn't have enough to make it worth sitting through. The first movie was just okay but this one feels like it doesn't do much in terms of plot progression. Overall, this franchise is okay at best and it is actually quite surprising how much people do like these movies, even as just entertainment when one of the entries can be as iffy as this one.

review: The only good thing about this film is that it's not worse than the first one. Like it's predecessor, it's super slow paced and has incredible pacing issues. It's like a broken car that won't start so you have to push it. The acting isn't as horrendous as the first but it's script is still incredibly weak and shallow. The plot feels like it could have actually been tolerable but it never really reached that stage. A big issue with the first film I had was that it felt like the plot was an afterthought in exchange for shitty character interactions. This film does the same thing but Jacob and Bella's dialogue is slightly more interesting than her dialogue from the previous film. Ultimately I can say that this whole series is a big disappointment, if I remember correctly the next movies have a lot more story driven elements or maybe they don't I don't remember. But the point is, these first two films seem really uneventful and I think the book would have worked better as a tv adaptation rather than a film series.

review: "A whole lotta nothing in between somethings". That's the precise sentence that an article I read summed up New Moon as. Guess they were onto something. Not only is the pacing incredibly slow but all the things that the first film had bad, this movie does worse. The acting is worse, the script is worse and it's hard to take seriously. With cringy dialogue, an overlong runtime and unlikable leads. Basically the Cullens leave because Bella got a papercut on her birthday and she spends 3 months sitting on a chair sulking and apparently that's all she did in those 3 months, seeing as how she never changes clothes and nothing in the background looks any different. The few things the movie has going for it are: some decent-ish, if disappointingly brief, action scenes with some decently rendered CGI werewolves and Michael Sheen's performance. Shame he's not in a whole lot of it because God forbid we put in someone who's good at acting, regardless of film quality, and have him stay there for more than 10 minutes. We wouldn't want the other actors to be revolting now, would we? Also, why doesn't she stay with Jacob? True, I already know who she'll end up with (I haven't felt this much suspense since Katniss, Peeta and Gale) but Jacob actually does have more dimensions than sparkly Cedric Diggory ever had. And I'm not saying that because we share the same first name. If you're a Twilight fan, more power to you. But if you're not, this movie is so boring. Even if the franchise was already fairly short on action to begin with, that doesn't excuse the fact that barely anything happens of interest despite being a story about vampires and werewolves.

review: They had us in the first half, not going to lie. Though I was really happy with the direction this film immediately went for in creating a soft sort of post-apocalyptic world for humans and apes to get along in, I wasn't exactly sold on the approach that this film took. It was just under an hour of nobody trusting nobody, blunders being made and guns being waved and while it was certainly wrought with tension, it was the stressful, unpleasant sort of tension because both sides and all the stand out characters on both sides (except Carver, He was just an idiot) have such believable and pitiable motivations and social predicaments that the idea of conflict between them (something I knew was eventually going to come) seemed completely undesirable. With the plot moving so slowly at the beginning, it was slightly agonizing to experience. However, there was enough interesting character dynamics (Caesar and Malcom, Caesar's son's apprehensions, Koba's stirring hatred, Maurice with everyone but especially Malcom's son) and visually resplendent world building to keep the film going until Koba does the fateful deed. After that, the film blooms fully into it's singularly unique, compelling, tragic, chaotic and almost operatic identity. I think it was the only right decision the writers could have made to have the apes strike first. After the first film we have sort of been conditioned to see the humans as the enemies of the apes and what with the enormous arsenal and testy nerves of the human colony, it seemed that the oppression of the apes would soon come again. It was exactly the development the Caesar and the apes needed, a conflict, betrayal, a villain in their midst to drive home that the apes are not intrinsically better than the humans. The moment that Caesar realizes this, lying wounded in front of his son, brought low by the betrayal of his own kind and humbling himself by returning to the home he had moved on from is a powerful moment and what I think the entire film was leading up to. Caesar and Malcom both realizing the worth of the other's kind and acknowledging each other as friends. On a big picture scale, the apes trilogy is using it's second installment to level the playing field between apes and humans to set up the climax of the third act, but it does so in an explosive and poignant way. I think the flavor that this film has that most science fiction action films do not is a feeling of tragedy. Not tragedy in the sense of failure, but in the conflict and mistrust between and within the apes and humans that inevitably will lead to great strife. This film has action, drama and heart but each of these is given a vein of tragedy. Thankfully, it is the kind that is epic even in it's laments and drives some hard hitting questions home as the apes become smarter and stronger. Heck, not only do they talk a lot more, by the end they were speaking in metaphor while beating the snot out of each other. It may sound odd, but that kind of thing is what I think the apes movies are made for. Another significant advancement‚Ä¶ have I mentioned that this movie is very good as a sequel? Paying homage, carrying themes over from the first installment while giving the narrative further believable direction and a wider focus? Well now I've mentioned it, and the greatest thing about it is the increased inclusion of the best character in the series: Maurice. Maurice already has the advantage of being an orangutan which is makes him cuddly and imposing at the same time, but he also gets the singular honor of being the good friend to the main characters and since not as much attention is given him, he is not tarnished by a lesson needing to be learned or a flaw to correct. He's just pure awesome. When he turns his piercing eyes toward Malcom's family and utters his one word in the film "run" I got chills. He's just a peaceful, understanding presence and he's the only one who gets along with both sides (something I wished could've happened for everyone) and when he had to, he grabbed that ape and showed him who's boss. I love that kind of character. I was genuinely concerned when he got shot but was relieved to see that he just shook it off like the bad-A he is. Such good stuff.
mojo_name: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes

review: Matt Reeves' outstanding Apes trilogy is the bar that every reboot/remake that modern film should aspire to. The middle film in his trilogy sees the imperious Andy Serkis reprising his role as Caesar in a post-apocalyptic world, where most of the human race has been wiped out by Simian flu (yes, it's more topical than it was on its release date). Caesar clashes with fellow ape Koba over the way in which to approach the human race leading to a split amongst the colony, and resulting in civil dispute. Weta digital's visual work is nothing short of remarkable, and the communication between the apes is staggeringly realistic. Serkis is the star, as he his throughout the franchise (utter shame on Oscar for not recognising his work) and the way the physical performances of Serkis and co combine with the special effects to give you a world in which you truly believe everything is real, deserves the highest of praise.
mojo_name: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes

review: I was shocked that this was almost as good as the original, which I found to be among the best origin stories ever made. There was some deterioration for me that big critics didn't see, namely that the dialogue between the apes seemed intended to be rudimentary but was in reality just very poorly written. They didn't seem to gesticulate enough to convey the emotion the lines were meant to have and so the subtitles just didn't match up for me. I think they improved the CGI on the apes but did so at the cost of doing rather poorly on the herd of deer and the bear in the opening scenes. I loved the heel turn of Caesar's lieutenant, the overall plot and the film score, which was top notch. This entire series seems set to grow in critical acclaim as the years go by.

review: Great live action movie of Transformers. First time watching this and it was great. 5/5.

'Transformers' is a movie that I hold dearly to my heart. I watched it over and over on loop almost every day as a kid, I was hooked. I loved it because the action was cool, the main character was my idle, and the robot cast had cool designs. But how does this movie hold up, now that I'm a little older? (surprisingly well actually). The movie follows Sam, a young man who has bought his very first car. But little does he know, that this car is an alien from the planet cybertron. The aliens have come down to earth, in order to obtain a powerful item, the allspark, a relic that can give life to machine, and repair the robots home planet. There are two factions fighting for it, the autobots (good guys) and the decepticons (bad guys). On the one side, the autobots believe in the right for all life forms, while the decepticons only care about power. The film also follows William Lenox, a soldier that was attacked by a decepticon, and now has to fight for survival. The movie ALSO also follows this Australian hacker that provides a bit of plot progression, and that's it. The plot is pretty cool, and the way that the movie focuses on multiple characters is neat, but how do the characters play out? Sam is quite charming, due to his interactions with characters being oddly comical, in a certain type of way, and is probably relatable to a lot of guys. His love interest however is incredibly dull. Mikaela is nothing but a love interest, she has no personality, and she just willingly does what the characters tell her to do. William and his team of soldiers were funny, they had a few memorable one liners, and William has a nice motive and a cool action moment towards the climax. As stated before, Australian girl is just there for plot, but her friend, Glen, is incredibly funny (also some great one liners from him). Other characters such as Sam's parents are very interesting characters, Simmons is again another funny character, and that's about it for the human characters. The Transformers themselves (character wise) are really lame in comparison. All five autobots have personalities, but you don't get to see them that often, as they: A. don't appear that often. B. usually fighting most of the time. C. have dialogue that is strait and one dimensional, especially Optimus's. There is also a moment in the film were one of the robots, Bumblebee, is captured, and it's played as an emotional moment. However, you don't feel anything because you barely even know the bot because the movie never gave Bee enough room to show his character. Megatron and his decepticons are very intimidating, but they have little personality, outside of being big baddies. The reason why a lot of people don't like the film is because of the focus on the humans, and not the Transformers. Personally, i'm 'okay' with it, but I don't think it's something that would completely ruin the movie. As of the action scenes, they are awesome. Watching the bots beating each other up is very amusing, and is only helped by the wonderful CGI, that still holds up to today. The Transformers all have a certain shade and glossiness that makes them fit into the backgrounds. Their transformations are incredibly satisfying, with all the funky sound effects and moving parts. The overall designs of the Transformers had people divided, but these are the ones that me and a lot of other kids grew up with, and they're all just as good as the original designs. In conclusion, 'Transformers' (despite not being that much about them) is a really good movie, thanks to its funny/memorable human cast, awesome action scenes, and CGI that still holds up to this date, highly recommend.

I had high hopes for the first transformers movie, it seemed to be the only decent one besides bumblebee based on the reviews. But Michael Bay's need for out of place awkward and strange banter seep in to the film and make you feel uncomfortable at times. There were no proper payoffs, certain things were mentioned and not seen again. It didn't have a lot of why I like transformers, distinct character personalities that are complex and fun. It had some interesting observations about human beings, and I'll admit it was cool seeing the live action iterations of different autobots. But Transformers was a disappointment.
Another good Transformers movie which helps along the series!!!!

As a kid I didn't know that Transformers is a set of toys. I only used to think that it is an anime series. The first time I learnt about the movies was when one of my friends got a Nexus tablet to school and played this movie when there was no teacher in the class. I really liked the opening scenes and decided that at some point I will watch this movie. Little did I know that the opportunity will come 8 years later when the lockdown would happen. I watched it and enjoyed it very much. Transformers is exactly what I wanted to watch when I used to see the terrible anime. I didn't like Optimus Prime very much back then but in this movie I understood why he is so important to the franchise and now I am a huge fan of Optimus Prime. There were so many other Transformers whose names I got to learn as I watched this full staff I used to see this movie in parts on TV and I used to think that Bumblebee was Hotshot. After watching this movie I was feeling like replacing the the logo of my car with the Transformers logo. All the Transformers movies have very good CGI, cinematography, choreography and colour grading. What the other movies lack in, however, is a good story and acting. This movie has all of that. I really wish all the other Transformers movies were also like this. Here I cared about Sam, the army guys and of course, Mikaela (¬∞"U"¬∞). This is one of the only two Transformers movies which actually has a good plot (the other doing bumblebee). If the future Transformers movies had built up on what this movie created they could have actually been very awesome. But instead they focused more on creating a bigger universe with more cars and more merch to sell rather than on character development. I can often come back to watch this movie because of the cool cars and fight scenes, without having any of the cringe the future movies had.
In my opinion the best movie about Transformers. The action and the music is great. The only bad thing is that Optimus prime appears until the middle of the movie

This film is a true gem that is sometimes neglected owing to its numerous sequels. Unlike the following several, this one has legendary humor. Along with the 1986 film, this is an outstanding masterpiece. Unlike some of the subsequent films, this one features some well-written human characters that are both interesting and entertaining. The photography is superb and the film appears to be really stylish. The narrative revolves on a teenage boy and his car works surprisingly well and feels like many of the more classic Steven Spielberg films such as Jurassic Park or E.T. The dialogue is really good and Glen is very relatable. I think that the way they portray the Decepticons in this movie as absolute hulking unstoppable beasts that you need to work together to defeat was really cool. The designs for the transformers are menacing and aesthetically pleasing. All in all there's a lot more than meets the eye to this film!

I really like this film, best spider man ever in my opinion. Ok, something had to be fixed for sure (the development of Harry Osborn's character wasn't that good, for example, but if we think about the initial intention of the making of TASM 3 and 4, maybe he would have received the right development; also Electro skin wasn't good because he wasn't like the comics one, but I think that when we watch a film based on comics or books or kinda of, it will never be like the original) but the good stuff is more than the bad. You get attached to the characters but also to the actors, who play really really good, and the final scene (from the battle to the end) it's something EPIC!
A Movie More or Less, But One Thing Saves the Movie Gwen Stacy's Death!

After watching it for the first time in maybe 3 or 4 years and thinking about it. I don't think I hate Amazing Spider-Man 2 anymore! Is it convoluted? Absolutely. Is there too much in it that goes absolutely nowhere (mainly because they were questions to be answered in a conclusive chapter of a trilogy) yes maybe a little too much! Are the origins for the villains a little cheesy or bad? Maybe they weren't bad maybe it was just the execution of it because I could be wrong but I think they draw heavily from Ultimate Spider-Man comics. BUT the score is incredible, of every single Spider-Man movie we've ever had ASM2 is the absolute most gorgeous and visually stunning. No movie is this fucking cool looking. Andrew gave his performance 110% and his chemistry with everyone even someone giving as bad a performance as Dane DeHaan seems to work for the movie it is. Every actor gives everything they've got in this and you can tell, it's not like Spider-Man 3 where you can tell that almost nobody cared and because everyone's acting is so good in this the emotional moments do hit and they often hit hard!!! Honestly this to me has the best, most accurate portrayal of Peter Parker; funny and smart as hell that's not just trying to impress Mr.Stark, what he doesn't know we see him actually try to figure out without the solution being "Oh Mr.Stark put this in my suit already!" Most of my issues with this movie has always been that I hate (and still do) that a looooot of the plot is heavily solved through pure coincidence. That whole plane massacre sequence at the beginning of the movie where Richard Parker is fighting for his life to try and upload his confession video not to send it to a news station, not to send it to someone he knows will do something good like Ben or another scientist, not the police, he sends it to his private computer currently sitting in a secret laboratory under an decades abandoned subway terminal that you only have access to by inserting in these specific slightly different subway tokens that are hidden inside his calculator that Peter only found because he got mad and threw the calculator and it broke and it just so happens that the video sent was also an apology to grown up Peter. Yeah that's absolutely convoluted and even with my newfound respect and even liking for the movie thinks that whole thing should have been cut. But look at the villains, all the groundwork is there. Their stories are actually well grounded and good, it's just the performances that made them seem stupid. Max Dillon becoming Electro; he's a man whose always belittled, bullied at work by EVERYONE despite being one of the top people in his field, has no friends had to buy his own birthday cake and sing Happy Birthday to himself that when he finally gets power he can exact the revenge on those who've wronged him! That's an awesome origin story it was just the weird direction in how Jamie Fox, who I don't blame for the bad performance, director Mark Webb other than Amazing Spider-Man had only done indie romcoms. And even with the weird writing and directing Jamie Fox gave it his all. Harry Osborne his mom died and his dad never cared about him, sent him away when he was really you and rarely if ever saw him or thought about him again. The first time he sees his father in years he's on his death bed saying "Hey, this disease I have. Guess what? It's genetic haha!" Then he has to learn to trust Peter because everytime he's made a friend or thought he did they only liked him for his money! And I do like that subplot of Oscorp trying to push out Harry but trying to figure out how. That too is great groundwork for the bad guy. Now this I do blame Dane DeHaan for because he's reacting to everything right but there's still just something about his performance that makes it seem cringey. Paul Giamatti gave the worst performance of his career as the rhino but hey no movie no matter how great is perfect. But the fight choreography in this is Incredible, it's not like a lot of superhero movie fight scenes where either it's too dark or the camera is too shaky and you can't see what's happening or there's a lot of weird cuts and transitions that you still can't see what's happening. This was a for a while my absolute least favorite comic book movie right up there with shit like Superman 4 and Batman Forever and Robin but being that I haven't watched this in years I do admit this is now a guilty pleasure. It's by no means simply due to the plot issues a good movie but I do enjoy the good aspects a lot more now.

Well, the villains in this film are the worst. It has a round story, but everything feels so artificial, the only thing that I felt it so natural was the scenes of Peter and Gwen, they have an excellent chemistry on screen. Also, it has very good visual effects and good action scenes and that is why this film is a little bit better that the first one.

A noticeable downgrade from the first, "The Amazing Spiderman 2" feels more like a beginning of a sequel that never happened. The entire film does not feel complete, and the ending feels rushed over. The villains, Electro especially, are all just forgettable despite the cast that is behind it. The action and humor still lands though, and Garfield and Stone continue to play their characters very well. The conclusion leaves a very sour taste in your mouth, especially when considered that there is no sequel to follow this up, which was originally planned. Overall, this is a confusing mess of a film that I really wanted to love more, though it failed to stick the landing in one too many areas.

I skipped The Amazing Spider-man franchise due to so much negative reviews from fans but then decided to give it a try. Actually, I liked this franchise. It was fun to watch but it looked like movie hasn't move out of first part. Showing us Peter parents fate and romance scenes more than villains scene was a bad idea. When a sequel is made, it is made using new ideas but it looked like director used maximum elements of first part due to which you can't feel fresh while watching second part. Overall, it was fun to watch but not better than part first part.

I'm sorry but it's hard to take the Electro in this movie seriously when he does not look remotely like his comics counterpart. Also, why make Harry Osborn look creepy, like a deranged serial killer? Plus, the storyline does not make sense, the main problem being: Max Dillon idolizes Spider-Man before becoming Electro but becomes a villain after becoming Electro. üôÑ And for reasons I cannot explain, the death of Gwen Stacy just wasn't moving. Terrible handling of an iconic part of Spider-Man's story.

While disappointing after the first one, the second one still has a strong enough script and an amazing cast: Emma Stone, Andrew Garfield, Sally Field, Dane DeHaan, Jamie Foxx. DeHaan was an absolute standout in this movie and he completely stole the show. His portrayal of Harry Osborn is my personal favourite- he manages to make us feel pity, disgust, annoyance, and empathy, all at different points for this tortured character. I would have loved to have seen more of DeHaan's abilities and talent in the ASM franchise. *SPOILER ALERT* Marc Webb's directing is absolutely phenomenal and genius. When Aunt May reveals that Peter's father was a traitor, the camera angle tilts- Peter's work has been turned on it's side, it has become askew. Later, when Peter finds the Subway train and finds out the truth about his father and his work, the camera rights itself- Peter's world is righted.

WARNING: THIS REVIEW HAS SPOILERS! The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is the worst Spider-Man film until then. The cast from the first movie still does a great job, but none of the new characters works. Harry Osborn is a poor version of the emo Tobey Maguire with a bit of Draco Malfoy. The actor is terrible and his arc is badly developed and also rushed. Electro is the worst Spider-Man villain in the cinema of all time. Jamie Foxx here is as invisible as his character, who has no motivation for hating Spider-Man (Lizard also didn't have, but at least he was imposing). And the romantic arc, which was masterfully done in the first film, becomes a "To All the Boys 3" but with Noah Centineo's character being the protagonist. There's no history. The best things of this film are: it deepens on Peter's parents backstory, the chemistry between Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone still works and Gwen's death is painful and touching. Oh, and the movie should have ended in the funeral scene, and everything after it could be post-credit or middle-credit scenes.

Acho que foi o √∫nico filme que me deixou com um ar de "o que acontece agora"? Infelizmente o 3¬∞ filme n√£o aconteceu, e eu sempre me pergunto como seria o 3¬∞ filme. "Teria sido melhor ou pior que os 2 primeiros?" O Espetacular Homem-Aranha 2 tem com√©dia, romance, a√ß√£o. Tudo o que um filme do Homem-Aranha deveria ter. Esse filme √© uma das adapta√ß√µes dos quadrinhos do Homem-Aranha simplesmente perfeita, tanto que parece que estamos assistindo o Homem-Aranha ultimate em live action. A atua√ß√£o do Andrew e da Emma tamb√©m ajudaram a salvar o filme. A trilha sonora tamb√©m n√£o peca, Hanz Zimmer caprichou nessa. N√£o me arrependo do que vou dizer... Esse √© um dos filmes preferidos de comic-book. Os efeitos especiais desse filme s√£o uma coisa de outro mundo. Marc Webb nos entregou um filme "puro" Homem-Aranha, e ele fez isso muito bem. Infelizmente a Sony atrapalhou cortando cenas importantes para o desenvolvimento de muito personagens, como por exemplo da Felicia, ou do Max, que infelizmente acabaram sendo esquec√≠veis. Mesmo assim, esse ainda √© um dos poucos filmes que nunca vou me cansar de assistir.

Even more of a mixed bagged than its predecessor, The Amazing Spider-man 2 improves on the good parts of the original like its protagonist and the chemistry between the cast, but it butchers so much stuff. The saddest part is, it felt like director Marc Webb had a clear vision for the sequel but the studio interfered and forced him to shove another villain in at the last second. Speaking of villains, one is poorly written and just lazy, and green goblin's development is just non-existent. The pacing is god awful during the second act and every subplot feels out of place, the sinister six setup feels like Sony was just trying to make more money by teasing them and the story arc of Peter's parents (if you can even call it a story arc) has no place in the story and doesn't have a satisfying pay off. Nothing we learn about them is something that subverts our expectations, it's all old news. That being said, Peter Parker, Gwen Stacy, their relationship and Gwen's death scene are all phenomenal. It's strange seeing Marc Webb being able to deliver on arguably the most powerful death scene in any movie, and then also be the man responsible for Electro and Green Goblin. There's not much more I can say that hasn't been said yet, it's corporate pandering, it's lazily written and could've been so much more if they just focussed on one villain and expanded on the dynamic between said villain and Peter. If only there had been a The Amazing Spider-man 3, maybe that would've been the golden child of the series.
One of the best chemistries on screen and original use of dubstep. Wrong Electro. Too many villains. Floppy ending.

I highly enjoyed the set-up of the main antagonist, Electro as he paints a beautiful picture of the pains of loneliness and being so accustomed to be treated like the most inferior of all(seen through his boss) despite being contributing the most(designing the plan that the entire power grid is based on. Why are there so many haters for Electro. You all have zero empathy.

Considering how much I loved the first film this was extremely disappointing. Had the same problem as Spider-Man 3 by throwing in way too many new villains. It was a structural nightmare. No wonder a third one was never made.

The fights are some of the best in comic book film history dare I say! The final battle with Electro and Green Goblin was amazing! Spoiler: Gwen Stacy's death was so emotional! Just a phenomenal movie that doesn't deserve the hate. If you love it as much as I do then great, but if not give it another shot, because I trust believe this is a 10/10 movie!

Y'know what? Them's good spooks. Was this a good film? I'm not sure. Was this a good horror film? Probably not. But was it fun? Yeah, it was a lot of fun. It has a lot of problems. It's clunky, some of the narrative hooks don't go anywhere. There are a lot of characters, and as a result, they can be a little one-dimensional at times. But was it fun? Yeah, it was A LOT of fun. I loved how boyish this film is. It feels bratty and raucous, and that's fun. Horror films lack a lot of fun these days, and this makes me enjoy horror. Seeing kids being scared of supernatural monsters is way more convincing and scary than seeing 30 year olds getting scared by the same thing. This film clearly learned all the best lessons from Stranger Things, and applied them admirably. Again, is this good? Not especially. It's kitschy. It's silly. It's sloppy. And that's why it's good. Sometimes you just want something messy, and this fulfills all those needs. It's not a bad time. Additionally, this is an exceptional horror film for high school age kids. Show this to your high school kids; they will LOVE it.

I am VERY back-and-forth on this one. On one hand, the acting and scares are good, but on the other, the pacing and consistency in character motivation is very bad. Specifically the pacing; there are long stretches of time that focus on Pennywise and the external stakes, but it all goes to a halt for the entire second act, which completely fudges with the momentum the audience is already feeling. But because the payoff still remains satisfying, I don't think any of my problems with the movie significantly affect the quality of the film.

review_date: Fun, beautifully directed, bursting with heart and amazing chemistry between the cast. IT has a lot of passion and respect for its source material and shines because of it.
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

It takes the simplistic world of 1989 and twists it upside down to a disturbance-filled land of absolute craziness. The film does not get anything amiss in all departments. The script is very well written and has a lot of aspects that support the overall vibe of the horror flick. There are many lines in It that bequeath an impact after the viewing is over. The themes of youth and individuality loom over the film in such a tangible way. The screenwriters also handle most of the film's characters well. A lot of the characters have strong character development with good backstories to strengthen their actions. The two characters I would say have trouble connecting with the rest of the story are Mike and Henry. Both characters do not feel strong enough to grasp their goals. Mike is better than the two named, yet he still feels disconnected from the rest of The Losers Club. Henry makes no sense by the 3rd act of the film and seems a bit off from where one would expect him to be. The film also runs for a bit too long as it gets slow in the second act. Having the movie be under the 120-minute mark would have made the film feel more like a continuous flowing story. Andy Muschietti holds the reins on the film as the director and does a pretty solid job. Muschietti has a lot of innovation when it comes to the environment Pennywise lives in. However, the imagination of Muschietti does not feel right visually. The film looks and feels like A Nightmare on Elm Street, yet it does not have that same surprise factor as the film mentioned. Pennywise is great, but having it be a bit more spontaneous would have made the film feel more elevated. The cinematography also suffers from this problem. Chung-hoon Chung is not wrong with his work. However, it does feel a little constrained and repetitive at times. The most shining visual aspect of It is the production and set design. The art direction combined with the stunning sets and locations is outstanding and helps hide some of the other visual flaws. The cast of It is the most compelling component of the film and makes it what it is. Bill Skarsg√•rd is jaw-dropping in the film. His performance of Pennywise shapes the movie so astonishingly well. When Skarsg√•rd first speaks in that opening sequence, it sets a chilling, disturbing tone. Skarsg√•rd keeps that tone throughout the whole film. Jaeden Lieberher leads The Losers Club and honors that title in his performance. His sentiments shine bright in the third act, and he does not disappoint. Sophia Lillis was also such a powerhouse as she portrayed Beverly in such a powerful way. Jeremy Ray Taylor's performance was loaded with emotion and sometimes hard to watch as he made his actions feel very real. Finn Wolfhard and Jack Dylan Grazer are the funniest out of everyone in the cast and have a lot of great lines that stick throughout the film. Lastly, we have Chosen Jacobs and Wyatt Oleff. Both have solid line delivery and needed to be on screen more often. It is disturbing yet holds a strong message with incredible themes that make the film feel comprehensive and modern. The influential performances from all the cast members hide the slight script problems and lackluster visuals at times. In the end, It will surely make you think twice about ever wanting to see a clown in person. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com
