I was really looking forward to seeing this movie and I had expectations because the trailer looked good (although it's obvious you can't always judge movies just from watching the trailer). However, ultimately it was a huge disappointment. At first the movie was decent. The plot was good, there was character development, and it was funny. It gradually declined for me. As I find it annoying how this movie solely depends on CGI for the jumpscares/creepy moments. There are plenty of great movies out there that don't depend on CGI or jumpscares in order to scare an audience. A great example of this would be the movie "Get Out". There is little to no CGI/jumpscares in that movie, and yet it is one of the best movies I have ever seen. The atmosphere is creepy as it is, so it would be unnecessary to add CGI in this instance. CGI only works where it is necessary, in my opinion. In the TV Show Stranger Things, they use CGI to recreate a giant monster. So it was necessary to CGI. Whereas the CGI in IT makes it come off as cheesy. Pennywise could be just as scary without special effects. This is why IT will never be one of my favourite movies.

Yeah, it's one of the best horror movies, although it's not an total example of the genre, I myself didn't feel a real fear, but that doesn't mean it's a quiet movie, it does have its moments of tension and you can get scared. Well, I confess that I had to watch "It" twice. In the first one I didn't feel a good immersion and, because of me and maybe the film, the experience was not so good, I would say apathetic. I say this because I couldn't get on with the narrative and when it got into gear, I fell behind, I don't think I was in the "vibe" of a horror movie, so much that some important and tense moments in the movie were boring and even funny, beyond what questions unanswered, which I imagine will be answered in chapter two, weighed more heavily on my experience than they should have. However, I decided to give it a second chance, this time I saw the film more focused to value the experience, and I must admit I had a much better experience, well, first I would like to highlight the character development, which is exceptional, very well built, and , even if it takes a considerable time, it is important to sustain the story and the presentation of the characters, making the viewer feel part of the group of friends and care about them, it is clear that this development is better done in some of the than others, but overall it's pretty good. Achieving this empathy for the characters is already half the way for a horror movie. Another point is the great performance of Bill Skarsg√•rd as Pennywise, he manages to masterfully employ attitudes and gestures in the character that only contribute to his terrifying construction. In summary it's a very solid movie, which in theory is a horror movie, but it fluctuates between genres in a nice way, being a good movie, not only for horror enthusiasts, but for anyone who wants to watch a good movie.

The middle chunk of the movie is IT just showing up to each kid individually to scare them then going away. After you realize NONE of these people are in actual danger in any scene they are in, the horror loses all it's power. Oh no the sick kid is being chased by some diseased person, it's so obvious nothing will happen that it almost becomes comical. My favorite part is when they finally get to pennywise's layer and there's like this weird five second dance routine he does that had me laughing, like this is scary to some people?! I'm giving it a star more than it deserves because the painting chick was actually unnerving and if they were the central villain it would have worked better.

Interstellar is not a typical sci-fi save the day run of the mill film, and the heart of this film carries a message I think everyone can learn from. Interstellar takes the tropes of space travel and grounds them into reality time is everything and exploring space has the ultimate cost of time. Time is the most important resource in our lives. Yet there is something ever more powerful than even time itself that this movie presents. Our emotions and our connections with others are ever present. We are humans and we seek to connect no matter the cost, and despite being millions of light years away and time pressing forward in an endless march our connections will grow, break, and form anew. Because as cheesy as it may sound, despite the nihilistic nature of our existence our bonds and connections with others can be just as effective and quantifiable as any part of known physics

This movie is visually stunning! Yes it tends to drag from time to time and the concepts that it is setting up tends to exceed its grasp but, interstellar is a fantastic thought provoking sci-fi that dares to ask the questions about what it means to be human and the direction of mankind. The performances, as usual with Christopher Nolan movies, are great.

One of my absolute all-time favorites. I agree wholeheartedly with several of the more educated reviews on RT. The negative reviews are from people who probably try to one-up everyone else's story at a party. There is something for everyone in this movie. The acting, the cast, the plot, the cinematography, the emotional ride... everything about it is spectacular and I feel this may only be appreciated decades from now, as we continue to learn more about the universe/space etc. I've seen a number of reviews that say that Interstellar is "over ambitious" but I couldn't disagree more. It's one of the most ambitious movies ever directed and not only did they pull it off, they nailed it. When it comes to the expansion of our universe, I don't think anything is farfetched, but Interstellar made me feel as if I was journeying into our future and watching a real-life space exploration take place, rather than a science fiction flick. I will be watching this with my grandchildren one day! Absolute 10/10, must see.

Amongst the best Chinese Si-Fi, it has proven that everyone can make a good film putting aside political belief & self-interest but will prefer more diversification & inclusion in culture & language. This movie was recommended by a podcast/radio host (Molly Wood) as an example of the rising presence of Chinese creatives in western culture. For that reason it was interesting to watch. If you pay attention to the seemingly unending production/distribution credits of modern films you'll see an ever-increasing impact of Chinese capital/influence. The movie was okay. I imagine it would have been better for me if there was descriptive video. I was just thankful it had English dialogue overdubbed. Still, being a big action production I'm sure I missed a lot. This film was based on a set of short stories by the Chinese novelist Liu Chixin. Chixin won a Hugo Award for the "Three-Body Problem" which is also recommended by Molly Wood. It's on my "to read" list.

review_date: It's a combination of "Gorath" and "Armageddon", with an all-Chinese cast, propaganda colors, flattery to the Chinese authorities, and produced by skilled filmmakers. I watched this movie as a prep for watching it on Netflix because it was written by the author of Three Bodies, so I didn't have high expectations, which was to be expected. The director of Three Bodies is new and young, and his sensibilities are modern and I'm sure he won't be overly dramatic, so I have high expectations. The only thing I'm worried about is whether the production team will be sensitive to the Chinese authorities since the film deals with politics such as the Cultural Revolution. That's my only concern. Certainly interesting from the standpoint of watching a big-budget, save-the-world blockbuster that does not conform to usual Hollywood tropes and values. It was fairly gripping, edge of your seat stuff at times. Character development was a bit weak.

Like Communist Russia, Chinese writers have found that the sci-fi genre lends itself to futuristic imaginings and alternative universes that can circumnavigate or disguise prickly topics. Especially if those sci-fi writers or filmmakers include some nationalistic nuance while chasing their own creative dreams. This nationalist strain first came to my attention while reading Liu Cixin's otherwise dazzling 2006 novel ‚ÄòThe Three Body Problem'. It's a sprawling space opera that can be boiled down to a China-led planetary resistance against a pending alien takeover from afar. As I ploughed through all three tomes of this series, I was at once wowed by its sci-fi inventiveness and perturbed by its China-centric visions of the future. At first, I thought it was because I had spent a lifetime reading and watching American and British sci-fi. And indeed, there are enough American-led and American-filled spaceships in the genre to fill up the entire Andromeda Galaxy. Another example of American cultural imperialism, some might argue; while others might contend that American writers are perhaps entitled to populate their fictitious spacecrafts with their ilk, having landed the first man on the moon and now a crop of rovers on Mars. Ken Liu, translator of ‚ÄòThe Three Body Problem', was quoted in 2016 as saying that, "When you go into space, you become part of this overall collective called ‚Äòhumanity'. You're no longer Chinese, American, Russian or whatever. Your culture is left behind." For a preeminent translator of science fiction, it's ironic just how wrong Ken Liu was about the near-future of his genre, not to mention the evolving space race between the U.S and China. For it appears the Chinese are taking a leaf out of the American playbook by rushing to assert their own brand of sci-fi nationalism alongside real-world advances, such as their landing a rover on Mars and another on the dark side of the moon. Those lingering suspicions about Liu Cixin, meanwhile, were finally borne out by the transformation of his novella ‚ÄòThe Wandering Earth' into China's highest-grossing science-fiction film of the same name in 2019. Once again we have the scenario of a China-led planetary resistance, this time against a future global catastrophe rather than aliens, which brings nations together in a herculean effort to save mankind by rocket-boosting Earth all the way to Alpha Centauri. Whatever the naivety of Cixin's cultural viewpoints within this far-fetched story, the scriptwriters made sure to excavate and amplify the story's nationalistic undercurrents, so much so that China basically becomes the saviour of the universe (cue Flash theme song). For all its spectacular effects, the movie's Sino-jingoistic perspectives are worrisome at times, above all that climactic scene where diverse nationalities, including Russia and Japan, all come together to selflessly work as one ‚Äì under Chinese hegemony, naturally ‚Äì to get some thruster or other restarted. All that brotherly pushing and grunting for one common goal is like something out of a propaganda poster for the Cultural Revolution. Still, it's a far cry from China's recent past when you couldn't direct or show any films about ghosts, zombies or ‚Äòun-scientific' subjects.

Chinese blockbuster-style action-scifi/disaster movie with shallow character development and lots of flashy visuals. I did like some of the plot twists, they were just surprising enough, not quite the same tired crap that Hollywood keeps throwing at us, but I especially liked two big refreshing aspects: 1. It underscores how everyone has to unite behind a single large-scale plan to effectively tackle large-scale problems (typical Western individualism and competitive attitude will not solve Earth-scale or humanity-scale problems, if anything such attitudes will be - or are already - an obstacle in themselves) 2. Its vision is actually imaginative and ambitious, it's not just the boring old "let's restore life to exactly what it was before the Big Problem hit us (let's get back to business-as-usual)". It's a huge project that will not produce any benefits for hundreds of years and yet is still presented as the right thing to do and the heroic endeavor to believe in, vs. the usual quick-payoff short-term goal to "just return life to normal" of jaded Western scripts. Hope to see more of this type of vision in future movies, because Hollywood stuff these days is just completely uninspiring crap - all they can show in their sci-fi is the world going to s**t and humans unable to stop it and just ending up with some dystopian BS as the new normal.

This movie feels like it's missing important pieces, and that makes it very difficult to get invested in most of the characters. Even the main characters, Liu Qi and Liu Peiqiang are barely developed. It's unclear why Qi is so eager to leave home forever at the beginning of the film, and that's what essentially starts the plot of the movie, and his resentment towards is father is barely explained with a really awkwardly-timed flashback. And this issue is even worse with the side characters. Rescue team 171 shows up 25 minutes into the film, and they play a major role in the plot, but they're never actually introduced. They have a big dramatic moment at about the 1 hour mark which is kicked off when a member dies of exposure, but it fell completely flat because I had no idea who that guy was, and the other characters' emotional reactions just came out of nowhere. There were lots of small details that were equally grating. The cuts are structured so it's often unclear how much time has passed, and it's hard to keep track of where the characters are and how they got there. I think the film has an interesting story and tries to tackle some meaningful themes, but for me it completely failed because of the lack of connection I felt to the characters.

review_date: The Twilight Saga: Eclipse could also go by the alternate subtitle ‚ÄúHurry up and wait.‚Äù This movie tries to create tension for basically its entire runtime that there is an onslaught coming from some evil vampires, and then spins its wheels as everyone prepares while simultaneously wallowing in angst. It is agonizing to watch and mind-numbingly dull. The romance stuff that fills the majority of the film is so painful. There is nothing but a ton of clich√©, and horribly-acted ‚Äúromance.‚Äù I cannot help but be creeped out by these relationships, and they seem almost 100% unhealthy. I‚Äôd like to say the climax somehow adds enough excitement and action to save the film, but it is so ridiculous and is filmed terribly. There is no intensity or excitement to these battles, they are just people using CGI to run faster or jump higher than you can follow with your eyes, or to turn into a cartoon wolf. Then they start ripping body parts off the bad guys. In a strange choice, to avoid an R rating, it seems that vampires are made out of cement and when killed they just crumble apart into pieces and there isn‚Äôt an ounce of bloodshed. It doesn‚Äôt help that I don‚Äôt care about any of these characters, but I was so bored by the whole thing even in its most action-packed moments. review: An improvement over the last two Twilight movies, and by that I mean less bad. The acting is slightly better, it's actually quite fun to see Edward and Jacob trash-talking each other, Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson have better romantic chemistry and I actually did appreciate the build-up to the big action sequence which was actually quite awesome. Yet Eclipse, despite having being cinematic enough to warrant an IMAX release, still falls into the same traps as the last movie thanks to dialogue that's hard to take seriously ("Dad. I'm a virgin"), slow pacing (though admittedly not as bad as New Moon) and an uninspired script. Rather shocking considering the screenwriter would go on to be a showrunner for an admittedly good TV show. But then again, having a script faithfully following a Stephenie Meyer book was probably destined to be not good. Also, for the movie that fully focuses on that one evil vampire who's out to get revenge on Bella and Edward, she doesn't really have a lot of screen time. She's not even played by the same actress. The summarized Entertainment Weekly review of "The best 'Twilight' movie so far" is right but that's not really saying much. It's just the big climactic action sequence that helps this movie earn 2.5 stars.

This movie is so great that it will in fact, make many young girls realize that they are neither Team Edward or Team Jacob, but Team Bella. Because while Bella is on a quest for the Sparkley D, young girls watching will be fawning over Bella and the homosexual vibes she gives off in this movie alone. (plus she kind of dresses like a frumpy homosexual through the entire series. So how can you not fall in love with her?) So if you love vampires, angst, insta-love, marriage proposals, and frumpily dressed protaganists (with a side of mayham and vampire fights), this is the movie for you!

Impending danger and doom awaits. The action sequences are quick but brutal for a PG-13 film. With a Twilight film, less is less and more is more. Eclipse is the latter.

review: I'm a bit surprised to see this at 93% on RT. Then again, I'm sure a lot of critics are like a great many viewers, not asking that much of their blockbuster action thriller outside of the very much required outstanding action scenes and thrills. Ghost Protocol has numerous scenes to satisfy that audience- Hunt swinging out from a 150+ story skyscraper to (hopefully) get the momentum to get back inside; a car chase through a sand storm; escaping Russian soldiers at the Kremlin just as it begins to explode along with gas beneath the street. Yeah, there is some clumsy, overly obvious 'lead-them-by-the-nose' writing at times. C'mon guys, at least some of your audience is smarter than that. Is the actual Russian really gonna confuse Hunt for a Russian too, even though he speaks with no Russian/Slavic accent at all along with poor pronunciation? Are all female agents and assassins busty bombshells there to manipulate men's baser urges? Cruise is...Cruise, so he's great for this part. Pegg's was a cliche, but not a big distraction. Renner was functional, as usual. Patton was gorgeous as always. And Nyqvist was good, but he doesn't pull off sinister for me like he pulls off the diehard good guy. He'll always be Blomkvist to me. 3.3 stars

review: This is when the Mission: Impossible franchise went from being good to amazing. There is so much to love about this movie: the impeccable score from Michael Gachinno, the wide variety of locations we get to exist, the amazing comedy from Simon Pegg and Jeremy Renner (who was a great addition), an intense concept about the IMF being disbanded with Ethan being alone, a story with incredibly high stakes and urge to keep going and well-shot and edited action scenes: the opening prison scene, the Kremlin inflitration, the car parking fight and the entire Dubai sequence that kept me on the edge of my seat the whole time and that's the best thing about this movie. It's so suspenseful. While the plot is quite predictable, you're always wondering how or if our heroes will win because there's so many instances where they almost lose or narrowly escape and it just makes the action scenes so intense. It's by far the best MI movie when it comes to the suspense and tension. My only complaint is the villain is by far the worst in the franchise but honestly, I'll never get bored of this movie.

review: Reviewed 1.25.21  The 4th installment in the Mission Impossible series serves as a reboot for the film franchise.  After the diminishing returns of the original trilogy, Ghost Protocol introduces key new characters, via the acting chops of Jeremy Renner and Alec Baldwin.  And of course Tom Cruise ups the ante with even more ludicrous stunts, many of which he performed himself.  Most famously, he hangs off the Burj Khalifa, still the tallest building in the world.  These additions, along with the increasingly influential role of Benji Dunn (performed with aplomb by the irrepressible Simon Pegg), do indeed inject much needed vigor.   Unfortunately, it all gets mired down in a clunky story that fails to capture the imagination.  It's a retread of the 'nuclear annihilation' storyline that has been beat into the creative ground for 70 years now.  Additionally, the scattershot nature of the plot leads to constant confusion.   In the end, the film is best viewed as a setup for the stellar films to follow.  For that reason alone, it's must-see for fans of the franchise.  For those uninterested in watching a subpar movie in order to prep for subsequent movies, skip it, and start fresh with the far superior Rogue Nation.
rt_name: Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol - Movie Reviews

review: Brad Bird brings a cartoonish energy to the 4th in the franchise, which pays off in the speed and imaginative set-piece stakes, but rather overdoses on the knowing humour. The plot becomes tiresome at the halfway point, when there are so many double-crosses and location jumps that you spend too much time trying to work out what's going on. Even as ludicrous a series as Mission has to retain a degree of plausibility to keep us invested.

review: The third Mission Impossible completely changed the style of the franchise and the way in which it looked and felt. It made the franchise feel up to date and modern again and a film that everyone could enjoy. The 4th film decides to build upon that and take it to that next level! The stunts and action sequences felt bigger last time. Ghost Protocol instantly takes that to another level within the first 25 minutes of so of the film. The prison escape and Kremlin scene give us more hand to hand combat, bigger and flashier gadgets and a thrilling explosion and chase scene that all beat anything show in the third movie. You have to admire Tom Cruise as well. Say what you will about him but he has a bit ol' set of balls on him! The stunts he's performed over the years have always been awesome but in this 4th instalment he outdoes himself and puts himself at risk to give us an even more crazy and authentic type of action sequence that blows us away. A lot of Hollywood actors would leave this to the stunt men but Cruise does it himself and is such a perfectionist that he always strives to go bigger and better than before. The one thing with these Mission Impossible films is that they all seem to fall under the same story. Don't get me wrong I still love them despite the fact it seems every single time either Ethan or his whole team seem to get disenvowled from the IMF and cast out as the bad guys when it's clearly obvious they're the good guys. You would have thought the IMF would have learnt by now not to jump to conclusions when it comes to Ethan. That being said there's usually a mole or traitor in the organisation so I can understand why they may not trust anyone fully. This reoccurring plot point doesn't spoil the film it's just you kind of know each movie they're going to be struck out on there own and it is kind of lazy writing despite the fact we never dwell on it. Jeremy Renner's addition to the cast as William Brandt is a welcome one. You can see they really wanted to set him up as the next Ethan Hunt but Cruise hasn't lost a step as the lead agent so that transition never happened. He is still a welcome addition to the cast but you have to feel for him a bit. He was brought in here and in the Bourne franchise to take them both forward as the leading man and both times they went back to the tried and tested leads. That may be because Matt Damon and Cruise are both irreplaceable actors and characters. This is the first movie that also really linked the others together with a lot of mentions to the 3rd instalment and Brandt being closely linked to Hunt's wife apparent death. Making the movies tie together is a clever choice and makes for a more cohesive franchise. Talking of welcome additions the expanded role given to Simon Pegg's character Benji is a masterstroke. He appears more in the first 10 minutes of the film than he did the whole of the previous movie. Having him in this more prominent role works so well as he's an excellent foil for Hunt. With Ving Rhames part in the movie limited to a end of movie cameo we needed a partner for Ethan to work off of. No offence to Rhames but Pegg just works so much better working with Ethan. His brilliant brand of comedy makes Hunt seem more likeable as well. He's just a light hearted character whose comedic moments are welcome and don't distract from the film and never feel forced or unnecessary. Ghost Protocol is a step up from the previous film in every way but one. The villain here is weak. I genuinely forget each time who the big bad is in this film. With the first three instalments we had the brilliance of Phillip Seymour Hoffman and memorable actors like Jon Voight and Dougray Scott. This time around the villain is just pure and utter forgettable and never really appears enough in the movie to be remembered. That makes the end part of the film suffer more than other instalments and makes you switch off just a little bit. For this movie to go to that next level it needs as more engaging bad guy. If Hoffman was in this movie then without a doubt it would have been elevated to a higher score. As it is this film just falls a little bit in terms of my scoring. The best in the series to this point for sure but not quite the finished article!

review: I can't remember the last time a film series announced that it was filming two sequels back to back-and that crucially, it filled me with joy rather than irritation. Christopher McQuarrie's announcement that he had begun work on Mission Impossible's 7 and 8 adjacently was music to my ears, and Rogue Nation is a huge part of why. McQuarrie's two instalments thus far (Rogue Nation and 2018's astounding Fallout) have been alongside the best action films of the decade, the epitome of popcorn cinema done well. McQuarrie's relationship with Tom Cruise is the main reason why we are getting this, and their work on the serviceable but forgettable Jack Reacher series was very much the warm up for the main event of what will end up being Mission Impossible's 5 through 8. Rogue Nation will fill your saturday night with thrills.

rt_name: Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation - Movie Reviews

review: I never get tired of rewatching Tom Cruise as Ethan Hunt in Mission Impossible films. For me it's the greatest spy action franchise of all time (sorry 007) and even though I really enjoyed the previous 4 installments, to me Rogue Nation and Fallout are just masterpieces. Rogue Nation has Rebbeca Ferguson's Ilsa Faust as one the best and most exciting characters in the franchise history. She is truly the equal of Hunt. Sean Harris is also one of the best villains this series gave us, and the film is full of amazing set pieces chief among them the Vienna Opera segment and the Casablanca tank dive followed by a very exciting motorcycle chase (I am not even going to dwell on the exciting opening). More importantly, Fallout owe Rogue Nation a lot, because without Rogue Nation setting up all the right pieces, Fallout would not have been as fantastic and exhilarating sequel to it . To me I go back and forth between these two as my co-champions, and because of them I am so much looking forward to 7 and even 8.

review: I think I slightly prefer this over Ghost Protocol and that is saying something. Rogue Nation is everything I wanted in an action movie: incredible action sequences and sets like the motorcycle/car chase, the underwater sequence and the opening scene, plenty of creative gadgets, memorable performances throughout, great comedy from Simon Pegg and Jeremy Renner, fun characters, it's well-shot, well-edited and there's just a vibe to this movie none of the previous movies have with its story and directing. It takes the intense concept of Ghost Protocol of IMF being disbanded and Ethan having no help to him being a fugitive and hunted by the IMF. What a concept! And combied with an unpredictable story that keeps you on the edge of your seat and wondering what will happen next and seeing Ethan and everyone having to make these tough devisions, you get probably the most intense MI movie. What a masterpiece!

review: Reviewed 1.26.21 It's quite the achievement when the 5th installment of a series is the best-to-date. The story involves a sinister organization known as The Syndicate, whose aim is the antithesis of the IMF (Impossible Mission Force, for the uninitiated). The action is top-notch, and the plot keeps you guessing. And the cherry on top of it all is the introduction of a scintillating new character, Ilsa Faust, played with mysterious beauty by Rebecca Ferguson, in her breakout role. The influence of writer/director Christopher McQuarrie is clear. Both the structure and execution are taut, and demonstrate the sure-handedness of a creator with action/adventure chops to spare. From the genius of The Usual Suspects script he penned 25+ years ago, to his more recent experience guiding multiple action packed movies, his experience has come to bear on a franchise in desperate need of inspiration.

review: The answer to that question is probably given in the first scene. In each film I've applauded Tom Cruise for his lack of fear and creativeness when it comes to his stunts. The opening for this film for me is by far and away the most brilliant yet. Hanging out of a plane is something most actors would pass over to their stunt doubles. Nah not TC. He will do that just to make sure we know he's not scared of absolutely anything. He instantly just goes to that next level AGAIN and we're blown away by it. Making one of the most memorable moments in the whole franchise and instantly setting this movie off down the perfect track. My main grumble with the 4th instalment in this franchise was the villain. He was basically easily forgettable. I only watched the film a few days ago and I can't remember what he looks like let alone his name already. Rogue Nation though doesn't make that mistake. In fact they correct on that in the first 10 minutes of the film. They introduce a instantly recognisable villain in Sean Harris's: Lane and make him a threat straight off the bat. Not only do they introduce him but they give us the larger threat of the Syndicate which is a group that could destroy the world. So instantly we have a face to put to the name of that group. It's excellent story telling and within the first 15 minutes or so the movie is off to a incredible start that it never lets up. One thing they do once again in that first 15 of the movie though is disband the IMF. OBVIOUSLY. They bloody love this plot point. But once again the film around it is so good we don't dwell too much on this tired retread. Rogue Nation again keeps adding to this team feel they're trying to create. They introduce us to Rebecca Ferguson and Alec Baldwin's characters who you know instantly are going to be major characters not only in this film but going forward. Ferguson is a great foil and love interest for Cruise and she is a improvement on Paula Patton's Jane from the previous film. Jane isn't mentioned at all in this movie which I do feel is a mis step as they seem to want continuity but you have to explain why major characters from previous films are missing. Baldwin is brilliantly over the top. His lines especially when describing Hunt and the IMF are some of the most exaggerated and ridiculous I've heard in a long while but because it's him saying it they seem to work. With Harris absolutely sparkling as Lane, Rogue Nation does an excellent job of introducing new and compelling characters that many films struggle to do this far into it's history. Having even more Simon Pegg is a masterstroke once again. The writers have quickly realised how important he is to this franchise and it seems with each film they're bumping up his role. This film makes him a completely pivotal character who plays into the major moments of the movie! One character who is slightly relegated from his role in the last movie though is Renner's William Brandt. He was brought in with the idea that he would replace Cruise as the lead after Ghost Protocol but as the film did so well and Cruise showed no signs of slowing that idea was scrapped. Whereas he was shown as a major force in the last film in this one he's shown as a side character only whose main use is to have some comedic back and forth with Rhames. He's solid but that's a major relegation from where he was meant to be! The movie has some truly brilliant scenes. The opera scene is one of the best in the entire franchise and again appears pretty early in the film. This movie starts off brilliantly and never relents. The story moves along at a frantic but natural pace throughout and only brings you in more and more. They build on the Syndicate's introduction and make them and Lane the most calculated and dangerous villains the IMF have ever faced. In this instalment more than any other the film relies on elements of comedy. With Pegg leading the way as usual and the weird team up of Luther and Brandt we get some moments that truly tickle us. That never takes away from the film but rather adds to it and makes it that little bit better. The cast chemistry is through the roof in this one as well. Cruise and Ferguson have a much better chemistry between them than he did with any of his previous love interests. Patton is well and truly not missed in this film and I doubt we will ever see her again in a MI. One thing I hate though and that's not just in this film but films in general is how they give Brits such stereotypical and horrendous accents. The head of MI6 is guilty of that and it just comes off lazy and annoying. We don't all have posh or cockney accents all the time. It's a lazy troupe that Hollywood pedal out in so many films. They really need to break from this stereotype as it's just flat out annoying now. Rogue Nation is the best Mission Impossible to date. It's built on successful ground work from previous films and then fixed some of the flaws those movies had. The film starts off hot and just gets hotter as it progresses. It is the perfect Mission Impossible film and it's going to be very hard to top.

review: i never get tired of watching this movie
Tom Hanks has done it again.

Combining elements of comedy, motivation to satire. Forrest Gump, a film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring veteran actor Tom Hanks, manages to instill very deep moral values in every scene. The film, which was made in 1994, deserves to be called the best film of all time. The film, based on the novel by Winston Groom, tells the story of a man named Forrest Gump. Forrest who since childhood was considered a stupid child with an IQ of 75 has a unique life story. Having been belittled by everyone, Forrest continued to go forward with a stupid label by others against him. Forrest Gump is an epic film that makes the audience realize that behind the shortcomings there are many advantages in each person. The nature of the main character Forrest Gump can certainly be a good example for everyone. So what kind of traits can we imitate from Forrest Gump's character? 1. Loving Parents We can see how much Forrest Gump loves his mother. In the film he is willing to swim from the ocean and run through the city when he hears the news that his mother, Mrs. Gump is sick. Forrest Gump certainly realized that his mother's struggle could not be reciprocated with anything. The mother who always supports Forrest in the midst of his shortcomings makes Forrest realize that his mother is his hero 2. Always positive and optimistic Although Forrest Gump is known as an idiot character in the film. But his stupidity is not a problem for a Forrest. He keeps going and always thinks positive. Don't complain and always try. In the film, Forrest Gump always shows his positive nature in any situation and in any crisis. Can you copy this? 3. Never give up and be generous Of course, if you have watched the Forrest Gump movie, you will realize how generous the character Forrest Gump is. After he managed to create a shrimp company with the initials of his friend Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. He and Lieutenant Dan, a character frustrated by his disability during the Vietnam war, started a shrimp fishing business. After repeatedly failing to catch shrimp at the beginning of his search for shrimp. Forrest Gump didn't give up. He tried many times and of course failed many times. Until one day his shrimp catch was successful and together with Lieutenant Dan he managed to create the most successful shrimp fishing company in his city. Forrest Gump, who seemed to be a very successful businessman, didn't feel happy.Until finally he handed over his company to Lieutenant Dan and gave his income to the Bubba family, his best friend who had motivated him to start the shrimp fishing company 4. Good promise holder Bubba is a black man whom Forrest met when he joined the military. Forrest and Bubba's relationship is quite unique. It's said that their friends don't seem too close. But this is the other side of the Forrest Gump movie. Bubba, who when he was with Forrest, always talked about the world of shrimp, of course, for many people who listened to him talk about shrimp, it was quite boring. But not with Forrest, he always listened to Bubba talk about shrimp and Bubba's dream that when he finished his military duty he would set up a shrimp company with Forrest. But unlucky, Bubba died on the battlefield. Until it was left Forrest with his promise with Bubba to set up a shrimp fishing company. Instead of burying the promise. Forrest kept his promise to his best friend Bubba by successfully founding a very successful company, the Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. Forrest's promise and dream with Bubba finally came true 5. Don't forget friends and best friends in any situation The next Forrest Gump trait that you can emulate is that he always helps anyone. You can see it in the film even in critical times when Forrest and his troops are attacked by the enemy. Had separated well with his best friend Bubba and Lieutenant Dan. Forrest did not want to stay silent, he finally returned to the battlefield and saved his friends who were still alive even though they were full of wounds. No exception for Lieutenant Dan who he saved even though he had to lose his leg in the end. Lieutenant Dan, who was frustrated with his disability, was angry with Forrest. But again Forrest did not want to forget the Lieutenant Dan. He accidentally meets Lieutenant Dan who turns into a beggar in a wheelchair. Forrest, who at that time was a hero of his country, certainly felt sorry for Lieutenant Dan. Over time Forrest managed to raise new hope for Lieutenant Dan by getting him to join his shrimp fishing company. Lieutenant Dan joins in until Forrest gladly hands over the company he built to Lieutenant Dan. An extraordinary trait. 6. Faithful in love affairs Not only comedy and motivational elements in the Forrest Gump film. Of course the romance drama between Forrest and Jenny can be a good example for everyone. The single love story between Forrest Gump and Jenny seems to break the audience's heart when they see how loyal Forrest Gump is to Jenny. Although he had been separated several times for a long time and many times Forrest Gump was rejected by Jenny and many times he saw Jenny's bad side. Forrest Gump remained standing faithfully waiting for Jenny. He still loves Jenny with all her flaws. Until finally he and Jenny got married. But the marriage did not last long because Jenny had to leave the world early due to a virus due to her wild life. Forrest Gump must have been very sad, Jenny's long-awaited love finally ended briefly. For Forrest Gump, Jenny was his first and last love. 7. Good father At the end of the story, Forrest Gump who has become a father, gives his best love to his son. He applies the love he gets from his mother who is also a single parent. Without Jenny's presence, Forrest Gump performed his role appropriately to be a good father to his son. This film deserves to be watched and imitated in our daily lives because there are so many valuable messages and moral values that we can follow in this film. This film, which has been nominated for 13 Academy Awards, you must watch this at least once in your life!!!!

Watching Forrest Gump is a bit like watching your 6-year-old niece's gymnastics routine: charming at first, even mildly impressive, but more and more tedious as she performs again and again. Yes, Gump is a good-hearted, simple man who inadvertently changes the world and helps the people around him - the film shows us this, over and over again, for more than two hours. One suspects that with lesser acting it would be impossible to get through, but Hanks' committed performance and equally stellar work by the supporting cast make it good enough when you're in the mood for brainless schmaltz.

The book this movie was based on, which I haven't read, was more satirical in tone, which explains the basic concept of a simpleton managing to have such great influence on American politics and culture without being aware of it. His childhood leg problem inspires Elvis Presley, he unintentionally mocks Lyndon Johnson's showing off his surgery scar, he goes to Maoist China to play Ping-Pong, he unintentionally starts the 1970's jogging fad, etc. The book's story was purposely contrived; the movie plays everything straight. As for those who claim the movie glorifies stupidity, the phrase "Stupid is as stupid does" has a more honest message, namely that stupidity isn't an inability to think but an unwillingness to. As for the movie's uncomplimentary view of the counterculture, there was plenty of bad as well as good about the 1960's-divisiveness, racial and other hatred, violence, the spread of venereal diseases, etc. But not only the left gets skewered. Remember the scene where the legless Dan described being told he could "walk with Jesus"? The acting serves to make the movie work, just as Monty Python's comedy worked by everyone being able to play it all straight.
This movie is an absolute classic for all ages. It gets better every time you watch it. Definitely a must-see.

It's an impressive feat to make a movie with this many sad and dark elements this wholesome. The writing is quite strong especially when it comes to the main characters ‚Äì this is especially true considering Forrest's limited intelligence. In lesser hands Forrest's story would feel very contrived, but here it works. This is in no small part thanks to Tom Hanks' great performance.

I challenge the hardest soul on the planet to be unmoved by this masterpiece. It has so much connective tissue to the human condition that it defies description. It buckles me every time I watch it. Great cast, astonishing premise and a work to be studied ad infinitum. Easily in my top 5 of all time.

When I first saw this movie I thought it was a work of near-genius. However, over the years, as my cynicism has truly seeped in, I can finally observe this box-office hit with steely eyes. It is much ado about nothing at the end of the day, his near-stalking of his indifferent friend Jenny now comes across as creepy, and the manipulation of the movie-going audience is quite disturbing. The subsequent times you experience it the film becomes less an uplifting movie but more an obvious vanity project for all involved.

The story of forest instills a dilemma,can ALL these happen in just one short life? Being born with a low iq and disability in the legs,as kid Forrest runs to flee from his naughty classmates chasing him, braces in his legs fall apart and he feels like running with air. Growing up,he joins the US army fighting in Vietnam war,initiates shrimp business returning from the battlefield to keep words of his loving friend. Forrest Gump: A Simple Man in a Strange Land. This week I watched the 1994 film Forrest Gump. Directed by Robert Zemeckis, the film stars Tom Hanks, Robin Wright, Gary Sinise and Sally Field and tells the story of a mentally disabled man named Forrest Gump who lives through and witnesses many crucial events of the 60's and 70's and with his innocent, hardworking yet simple nature seemingly lucks into a very successful life. Around Forrest are many people going through the turmoil of the times and while their lives are affected negatively by the tumultuous culture they cannot help being positively influenced by Forrest's simple and sweet nature. What struck me most about The film is what a straightforward and honest approach to filmmaking it is. The story manages to be heartwarming and uplifting without sugarcoating any aspects of what happened in the 60's and 70's and portraying what life was like for many who were young adults at the time. Each and every aspect of filmmaking is masterfully done and every trick in the book is used in it's impressive technical side but it's groundbreaking achievements and magnificently utilized tactics do not point us toward awe inspiring spectacle but instead draw us even nearer as an audience to the harsh realities and human lives that it portrays. I think the movie works so well because it is not attempting to be blatantly nostalgic and not trying to be saccharine about its subject matter but it uplifts the spirit and moves the soul in its soaring heights and devastating lows. It is the drama of life presented in a very real way with one central thing elevating it and lightening all the terrible things we see and hear throughout the course of the film: Forrest Gump. By centering on such a fascinating character that is completely unaffected by the chaotic world around him, who holds stubbornly to his old fashioned values and walks through life with simple goals that are not swayed by the tide of cultural upheaval around him, the film creates a new and powerful way to look at the events of the 60's and 70's but also a unique and meaningful way to look at life itself. The film is set in the 60's 70's but it is not tied down by a single time period. Forrest is a man apart from his time and thus apart from any time. The themes and characters are timeless in the questions they ask and the struggles they face and so a film set so conspicuously in such a crucial time in history is able to speak to what came before and what will come after it in an eloquence that only its title character could provide. Yet another masterclass in good filmmaking in all respects (and recipient of six Academy Awards) all of its many achievements are as nothing to the heart and person at its center and each aspect points in its own way to the man at the heart and succeed in effecting us as an audience much like Forrest Himself affects those around him: innocently and unassumingly taking us along on a journey that will move, amuse and even inspire. Sweet and heartwarming without losing any emotional push for it, Forrest Gump is an achievement in portraying a unique perspective on the world that draws out all of its joys and sorrows in a very poignant way. The film truly is like a box of chocolates, you might not know what you're going to get and you may not always like it but the experience is an enjoyable mix of sweet and bitter and the aftertaste is truly satisfying. Forrest Gump, through its clear direction and talented and dedicated performers and artists, excels at portraying not only the world of Forrest Gump but the world through his eyes. Of course the flow and unity of vision in the film must be attributed to the director Robert Zemeckis and the value of the story lies with the inspiring adaptation work from Eric Roth but if I were to choose two people who defined the spirit of the film for me and truly seemed to understand and convey its themes and messages it would be Tom Hanks himself and composer Alan Sylvestri. The truth of the matter is that without Tom Hanks there would be no Forrest Gump. The words of the character and his life are all printed out in the script but it took an extra special performance to truly hit home how special Forrest really is. It is not an understatement when the poster for the film says "Tom Hanks is Forrest Gump'' because that is simply how it is. Even with his recognizable face and presence Tom Hanks becomes Forrest Gump, portraying all the simplicity and innocence, loyalty and love that Forrest has in the only way possible. That is why Tom Hanks is Forrest Gump because it could not have been anyone else. I've already said that every aspect of the film points to the man at its center and rests on his character but the character rests on Hanks and he carries the weight with wonderful skill. As Tom Hanks hides in plain sight in the film so does Alan Sylvestri's truly inspiring score. In all ways it is as simple and sweet as the main character but while it is sometimes happily so other times its simple strains can be truly heartbreaking. Each theme is so successful in creating the emotions necessary. The simple bouncing melody that represents Forrest's relationship with his mother, the tragic and somber strains of Jenny's theme and the triumphant brass whenever Forrest is running. Of all the things that give us the lens to see the film through Forrest's eyes it is the score that hides unnoticed most of the time but keeps its spirit of innocence amidst many songs of the time that appear on the soundtrack. The mixing of the pop music of the time with a simple mostly piano instrumental score is the spirit of the film captured completely on the musical spectrum. Surrounded by the culture just like Forrest yet maintaining its beautiful symplicity and emerging at the end as the element that tugged at our hearts even if we did not realize it. In all aspects the film pulls off the enormous feat of placing the audience in the heart of so many turbulent events of history yet keeps us safe in the peaceful protection of Forests honest and well meaning outlook. Forrest comes in contact with some of the worst parts of society and some of the hardest parts of living and yet he keeps going and is not swayed by all that goes on around him and thus we the audience can watch knowing that terrible things may happen but we can still rest in the quiet comfort that is simplicity. This was all said without even mentioning the cinematography, production design and ridiculously unnoticable visual effects and other strong supporting performances throughout the film. Forrest Gump is a masterclass in all aspects of filmmaking and it has a great amount of merit because of it but at the end of the day its biggest achievement is the story it tells with those elements. With a film that covers the highs and lows of three decades of a man's life, one can expect many deep questions to be asked and timeless lessons to be learned. One of the central messages of the film is hinted at in its very first shot of a feather blowing in the wind until finally resting at Forrest's foot as he sits at a bus stop. It is then said explicitly as Forrest mourns at Jenny's grave. He says to her "Jenny I don't know if Momma was right or if. If it's Lieutenant Dan. I don't know if we each have a destiny, or if we're just floating around accidental like on the breeze, but I, I think maybe it's both. Maybe both is happening at the same time." The genius of the opening credits of the film is that it portrays this Idea literally while still lending to its message. The feather floats for a long time going in all directions, quite accidental like on the breeze but it finally and inevitably ends up coming across the main character. That was its destiny. And at the end of the credits one almost can think that by brushing the foot of our protagonist the feather is passing the nature of its existence on to Forrest as he recounts the story of his life, a life that he seemed to luck through. Unaware as a feather and just as poised to be blown wherever the winds of his fortune blow. Yet his life is not one happy accident after another. He still has a destiny. That which he sees and pursues. In his simple straightforward way, Forrest is pursuing his destiny much as a feather on the wind. The film's presentation of contrast between the old world of Forrest's and the new world of the sexual revolution gives ample opportunity to ponder a simple question: Does Forrest belong in the world he lives in? In other words, is this no country for Forrest? Yes the question is posed in another more explicit way in No Country For Old Men but hidden beneath the Drama of Forrest's life and the humor and heartbreak of his incongruence with the rest of the world is the question of belonging and Forrest's is an acute case of this predicament. Such is the depth of the question that it can only be pondered and it is too distant for a concrete answer on paper so I can't even begin to try and answer it. Suffice it to say that there are so many spiritual, cultural and human themes in Forrest Gump, so many joys and sorrows of the human experience that its depth can be pondered long after the Film comes to an end and before that, with so much substance as backdrop, creates an almost overwhelming cinematic experience. At the center of every great drama there is the human person, full of flaws and doubts, misgivings and mistakes but all the while continuing to live their lives for better or worse. The central character of this drama is Forrest himself, so apart from the cares and troubles of the world and yet still doing his part to ease some suffering as he goes through his incredible journey of a life. Blissfully unaware of how truly terrible life can be, Forrest nevertheless experiences so much of the sorrows of life and comes close to so many terrible events that devastated the 60's and 70's. Forrest's relationship with those around him and to the events that surround his life is best summed up in his own words "I may not be a smart man but I know what love is" He feels compassion for such men as John F. Kennedy and John Lennon even though he can't fathom as to why they would be killed. He fights bravely in Vietnam and saves many of his fellow soldiers' lives even when he can't even begin to grasp that there is a terrible war going on around him. He cares for his girl Jenny, always looking out for her good even if he doesn't understand what tragedies have filled her life. Forrest Might be mentally unaware of all the events surrounding him but he is very aware of the people in his life and he reaches out to them in the only way he knows, with love and compassion. The two that are most affected by this are Jenny, the love of Forrest's life and Lieutenant Dan, his commanding officer in Vietnam. Both are victims of the time they live in, caught up and swept aside by the culture and the current events. Jenny grows up with an abusive father and when she gets nowhere with a folk singer career she embraces the hippie lifestyle and lives a life of destitution and despair. Lieutenant Dan was saved by Forrest in Vietnam but protested furiously, wanting to die with his men. When he loses both legs to injuries sustained in the battle he too starts a destitute life in Washington D.C. Throughout her life Jenny has come to Forrest for comfort but it is clear that because of her upbringing she does not know how to love a man like Forrest in the right way. She finally realises this and when Forrest asks her to marry him she declines and leaves the next day. Finally after three years she sends a letter to Forrest inviting him to visit her. It appears that after so much time she has finally learned why her life was so drastically different from Forrest's and is living a quiet life as a waitress and caring for her son Forrest Jr. The two finally marry and live their days happily until Jenny dies from sickness. Though Jenny lives a wild life apart from Forrest, his calm and simple presence through it all finally brings her around to recognizing the good in life. Lieutenant Dan is perplexed by Forrest's honest to goodness attitude during the war and afterwards becomes angry at Forrest for it as the two live together for a time. Lieutenant Dan states to Forrest that it was his destiny to die in Vietnam and that Forrest took it away from him. When Forrest goes to start a shrimping business Lieutenant Dan joins him, keeping a promise he made on whim that if Forrest ever bought a boat then he would be his first mate. Through Forrest's influence, Lieutenant finally realises that his life is worth living and at long last finally thanks Forrest for saving him in Vietnam. In taking a choice that may have seemed against a real "destiny" Lieutenant Dan and Forrest make their fortunes in a characteristically unexpected way and run a successful shrimping business. Through his childlike simplicity and love, Forrest's life was able to give hope and purpose to two who had none. The characters of Forrest Gump could be relatable but only to a select few. The truth of the matter is that they live human lives, lives that anyone can connect with and be moved by. Forrest Gump is incredible. A mix of bitter and sweet, joy and sorrow, laughter and tears, tragic historical events and flights of whimsy all with its title character in the center, telling us the story of his wonderful life. Though its narrative is powerful it is nearly outshined by the prowess with which it is told. Direction, performances, music and visual effects all bringing a deeply personal story to glorious life. With a strong backbone of cultural, personal and spiritual themes, the narrative hits very deep and can resonate with all people. Of the characters only one thing can be said. The highest compliment I can give: They are human. After watching the film I thought "this is now one of my favorite films" and in the course of writing this essay I realized just how much can be said about it. What can I say except it is a true piece of art that tells a genuinely moving story.

An impressive film, but not M. Night's best one.

The twist that everyone knows has now reached me, a self-declared "film expert". Even people who haven't seen The Sixth Sense have heard of the mindfuck moment par excellence. I managed to avoid what is probably the most spoiled movie scene in history for 21 years and all I can say is, I was still completely caught by this twist. The concentration was so much on not missing the decisive moment that the story of a child therapist who helps a child who, according to his own statements, can see dead people, got a bit lost. Yet no end of homage should be paid to the acting performances in this film. Bruce Willis embodies the child therapist Malcolm Crowe, for once a completely different role than what one we are used to from him. No stubborn anti-heroic action hero, but an empathetic workaholic who supports his young patients with everything he has. This has a negative effect on his private life and especially on his relationship with his wife Anna (Olivia Williams), who often sees herself as second best because of Malcolm's iron will to work. Crowe is, on paper, the protagonist of the film. After the initial focus is more on him, he makes room for the real star of the story as the film progresses. The then nine-year-old Haley Joel Osment delivers one of the most profound and authentic performances of any child actor as the psychologically damaged outsider Cole. Mysterious at the beginning, for a long time you don't know what demons haunt this boy and why he behaves the way he does. Only through the later realisation that Cole can communicate with the dead do we understand him better and are immediately fascinated by him. The second half of the film de facto belongs to him alone and we accompany Cole on his way to no longer be afraid of his illusions, but rather to engage with them and find a coherent way of dealing with this "curse". Director M. Night Shyamalan knows how to stage this unorthodox character, who doesn't conform to any clich√©s of children in films, in such a way that as a viewer you always d'accord with Cole's slightly absurd behaviour. A perfect complement to Cole's life is Toni Collette as his mother Lynn. She raises her son alone and struggles to understand how to relate to his weird and unpredictable ways. This strain affects her so much in many parts of the film that Collette is often called upon in emotional breakdown scenes, which she handles fantastically. Quite a great portrayal of grief and the desperate search for logic. If you don't know the twist of The Sixth Sense, the film still provides the big bang despite its advanced age. The question is rather whether you should watch Shyamalan's breakthrough work at all if you already know the twist. The mere fact that Willis appears in a different role than usual, Osment and Collette deliver their best career performances to date, and the two protagonists have very amicable chemistry makes the film worth a watch. It's also an atmospheric thriller, peppered with trippy horror elements, that manages to generate an insane amount of tension. Top directing, minimalist but great music and a terrific final punchline!

The Sixth Sense - 10/10. M. Night Shyamalan's breakthrough film catapulted him in to the big leagues of directing, and also brought a new voice into the mystery/psychological thriller genre. Revolving the story around a young boy who sees dead people, the film could have easily been a horror film or one that is a psychological drama. But more or less, this is an excellent drama first, diving into the mentality of the young boy (played amazingly by Haley Joel Osment), his mother who struggles with raising him (a fantastic performance from Toni Collette), and the psychologist that helps the young boy (a revered and surprisingly subdued performance from Bruce Willis). Its a movie that has some scary scenes here and there, but the gist of the story is propelled by the excellent tone and atmosphere brought to life by M. Night and cinematographer Tak Fujimoto. Its a dark and dreary film, mixed in with this coldness that you rarely find in PG-13 horror films. Also, you can't talk about this film without referring to the plot twist and literal red herring's that happen through out the film. Its quite an amazing feat for a young director, to establish a film full of small details that the viewer must be keen on noticing while watching. It makes for a much more attuned viewer and creates a sense of purpose to each and every scene. An excellent thriller that sparked a wave of copy cat films and inspirations. But, the original will always be the best!

The Sixth Sense remains Shyamalan's best film to date because of its effective suspense, horror, and solid emotional core. However, it's not perfect. It's just a dash heavy on tropes (cue the spouse watching the video of a wedding). And if you know the twist going in, which nearly seems impossible if you've been exposed to any pop culture, the film is probably not going to be 100% effective. Osment gives a performance far greater than his years here, and is supported by solid, workmanlike efforts from Willis and Collette. Less of a true horror film than it is a suspense/thriller.

It might seem at first that after watching this movie for the first time, the next viewings would not be that rewarding because of its now known finale. But actually this is not the case. The schock and surprise are not there anymore, but instead you get to observe many other details and nuances of the movie, and they are very rewarding.
A classic suspense film. M. Night will never be more powerful than immediately following this movie.

"The Sixth Sense" is an excellent thriller that blends the horror of ghosts and the torments of the mind. M. Night Shyamalan directs this movie beautifully and paired it with the phenomenal performances of Bruce Willis, Haley Joel Osment, and Toni Collette. The color scheme, tempo, and suspense of this film is truly remarkable. Plus, it does not rely on cheap scares by ghosts to provide horror, but on the story to strike fear in the audience and provide scenarios so much more frightening than any jump scare. Also, the twist ending everyone is talking about is extremely brilliant, and even makes the second viewing better. This movie is a classic piece of cinema every film fanatic must see. For that, I give "The Sixth Sense"... 5 stars.

I never believed that I would find a film that would give me the same emotions as the movies that were already on my top ten list, but this film astonished me and I am very happy I have got to see it. When I started watching, I thought it would be a horror and nothing else, being ready to say how overrated this movie is and how I don't believe that anyone likes it, but, the further the plot got, the more amazed I got. I only saw in the end of this film that it was directed by Shyamalan and I was shocked, as right now there is barely anything good coming from that director. As well as Bruce Willis, who right now is not an A tier actor anymore. This film is an emotional ride, as it makes you sad, happy, amazed and scared. I found myself actually scared because of the jumpscares, even though I understood they were coming, they worked really well. They were not screams, they were just people, dead people. Such intense moments help the viewer understand what the main hero could have felt while seeing a dead person. Music is outstanding, as it makes for the greatest part of the film's experience, but actors are even better. This is Bruce Willis's best performance ever, in my opinion. The thrilling part of the movie is outstanding, as you never know what is coming next and you never believe in what you have just seen. The whole plot leads you into creating theories and making countless questions, which is what I consider a good film. The ending is the best part of the film, as it comes to the logical conclusion and it is a massive emotional explosion. It is very good and I have actually cried in the end. There are countless allegories that could be made out of this end and one of them related to me really well, which is why I believe that this ending is one of the best movie endings ever made. This is a true must watch for anyone, this movie is already cult, which is amazing, in my opinion. Honestly one of the best thrillers I have ever watched, which is why I adore this movie so much. A definite 10/10, I wish I could have even gave it more, because this is a film that actually got me touched and made me judge this film by what I felt, not by my standard criteria. Astonishing, amazing, incredible -- there is not enough words to describe my experience while watching this film.

I think it's overrated. It's not a bad movie at all. And I think it certainly had a significant impact on other movies of this genre since 1999. I just didn't find it that stimulating. I figured out the big twist at the scene where Malcolm goes to the fancy restaurant to meet his wife. She doesn't acknowledge him at all and that seemed too weird to me. Then that continued for the entire film, nobody but the kid was ever aware of Malcolm's presence so I became certain I was right. And by the time I got to the big reveal, I was just like "yeah, got it." And then the movie ends. Like I said, it's not bad. It's just not nearly as great as the ratings it gets. Or maybe I just accidentally spoiled it for myself too quickly, I don't know.

So much promise, so poorly delivered. When I saw the trailer for this I remember being excited. I loved the idea of seeing Superman in those years between Smallville and Superman 1. Instead, we get a quick push to Metropolis, and a CGI-driven crap fest that could have just as easily been a Pixar cartoon. It had some good acting from Michael Shannon, and a passable performance from Henry Cavill (passable being high praise for a guy who couldn't act his way out of a paperbag). But in the end, it was "just another hero movie" that paled next to the Bale-Batman trilogy.

To me I love Superman but I've always found the character on relatable to a certain extent. I'll see what Zack Snyder what is going for with this movie. I commend the approach that he took to subvert one of the most recognizable superheroes. To me this movie does work for the most part. I love the backstory that they tried to lay out and I liked the idea of how superman is supposed to be conflicted. Having said that, the action can be a little drawn out and seems to go on forever and the idea of Clark Kent exploring what it means to be a hero is something they glossed over and never really dived into.

This is a modern interpretation of Superman. One not bogged down and entrenched in nostalgia, but one that looks to examine his character to seek an understanding of how he becomes the world's greatest superhero. Is the character perfect? No, he's a god-like being with powers he doesn't understand who was raised by humans who were afraid for his life should anyone find out. He is learning as the movie goes, and eventually ends up in a climactic battle with General Zod. Since this is a grounded take on Superman, there were casualties in this epic struggle between two god-like beings - but that's part of the realism. The fighting between Kryptonians was depicted unlike any other fight, from the speed of strikes to the way Superman gets up after being knocked down (instead of getting to his knees and standing up, he simply starts flying) and that attention to detail is amazing. The movie is very colorful, with the colors emphasizing the mood you should be feeling in any given scene. This is a film I will watch again and again as the years go on.
It's a good sequel with the bright animation and fun characters, but if the story was stronger I can see how this could have been better.

This review contains spoilers. If I had to point out a franchise that I have always loved it is definitely Kung Fu Panda. I have a special connection with this Franchise, having seen all 3 films a lot of times. Reviewing them recently, as well as realizing that they are great films, I noticed that the best of the saga is the second chapter. It intelligently and naturally advances the franchise, taking it to huge peaks. The story is fantastic and leads us to understand many unspoken questions about Po in the first film in an unpredictable and astounding way. The final battle, then, is well done and perhaps the most beautiful scene in the film. Po, as already mentioned, is the absolute protagonist, but the remaining characters also have the right space and the Furious Five are balanced. Lord Shen is the best villain in Dreamworks with a psychology of a true villain, but also the cue for really funny comic moments. The jokes are well constructed. The animations are wonderful. Kung Fu Panda 2 is not only a film that I am attached to, but it proves to be a masterpiece in many ways. With awesome characters, Oscar-winning scripts and gorgeous animations, Kung Fu Panda 2 is the best animated sequel I've seen.

this second film, in my opinion, is not as good as the first, however, it expands the universe more, of much more development for the protagonist, the villain is very interesting and the humor still works, without a doubt it is a great action entertainment and comedy.

Wow! I don't think I'll ever forget how this movie made me feel. I watched it back when I was a child, and many years later, it still brings that same feeling. But now ,a little bit older, I can truly appreciate the deeper thematic elements I didn't pick up as a youngling. The animation is one of the best I've seen in any animated movie, blending CGI and 2d animation to create a visually stunning film. The script is put together well, and the dialogue is deep, with great philosophical traits. The tone was actually darker than I expected it to be. The heart and the emotion in this film, growing from very well put together character arcs. And thanks to John Powell and Hans Zimmer, this film boasts one of the most epic score of my animated film! For me, it is the greatest of the trilogy. I give this film an A

Unpopular opinion: I think this one is equal to the original movie and, in some ways, it transcends it. Although I understand why people don't like it. Still, it does everything that a sequel is supposed to do and does it so well. It expands this universe with new locations and new forms of Kung Fu all while maintaining its witty sense of humor and gorgeous animation. But there are three specific reasons why I believe that Kung Fu Panda 2 surpasses Kung Fu Panda. First of all, it manages to develop Po, our lead protagonist (and one of my favorite movie characters), in such a unique way. We think that his arc is complete and yet they find a way to continue his journey of self-discovery. Even though he's a badass in this one, he doesn't lose his charm. Second, the Furious Five are at their best in this film. They've got some great action scenes with Po. Tigress really helps shape Po's character arc in this film and she shows much more vulnerability. I thought this was a really smart move considering how they have similar origin stories (if they ever tried anything romantic with them though...ugh). But the best part of this movie is the villain. Not only is he terrifying, but the writers also found a way to connect him with Po's origin story. And it is done just so beautifully. The Kung Fu Panda series will always hold a special place in my heart. Like the first one, it doesn't feel dated even after it being out for quite some time. I highly recommend it, but not before watching the first one.

review: I just came from seeing The Hunger Games: Mocking Jay Part 2! Based on the award winning book, the long awaited sequel marks the finale of the film series that made actress Jennifer Lawrence a star and inspired young girls the world over to rock the braided ponytail and take up archery classes. When we last left Katniss Everdeen and her friends, she was in the midst of planning an invasion of the Capitol city in District 1 to seize control of the country of Panam from the villainous President Snow who had just succeeded in brainwashing and turning the love of Katniss' life Peeta and turning into a slobbering lap dog of the capitol. Now, Ms. Everdeen and company soldier on towards The Capitol, destiny and a reckoning with President Snow. I really have to commend this movie on its faithfulness to the book. Director Francis Lawrence really did a great job of turning the book into an action packed adventure. The movie was well shot and the supporting cast did a really good job too especially Jena Malone and Michelle Forbes. The only qualms I have with the movie come from it's dramatic moments between Peeta and Katniss which all come off as hokey and overly manufactured to seem more dramatic than they should be. At the same time, other moments, that actually were naturally dramatic and probably should have been focused on are played a lot dryer than they should have been. Ultimately, I can't fault the movie too much because in actuality, the book played things out in the same way, and what am I going to do about that? Complain that the movie is too much like the book? On the whole, I liked a lot that this movie had to offer. The special effects and action sequences were very impressive and it was very loyal to the source material; so much so that the only things I didn't like about the movie were the same things I didn't like about the book. So if you liked the novels, I definitely recommend seeing the film but if you're just a movie watcher, you might be less satisfied. In the end The Mocking Jay Part 2 gets a 3.5...out of 5.

review: Mostly satisfying ending to the franchise with great acting, great emotional moments with Finnick and Prim's death as well as the ending, the visuals and sets are just as good as the other movies, the action scenes are pretty exciting and it has this massive scale to it and it stayed incredibly loyal to the book and stayed unpredictable and different from usual endings. There's some really memorable moments as well like Coin's death, the battle in the sewers and the ending scene. Also, I love how it wasn't just a predictable finale about the rebels marching into the capitol and killing Snow. It has deep themes about the futility of war and tryannical rulers emerging. the However, cutting the book into two parts really affected this movie. Mockingjay Part 1 did drag out a bit but it wasn't a big deal but considering this is a part 2 and the book is pretty short at 390 pages, it made the movie drag and have more build up and it's clear they were trying to stretch it to a 2 hour movie. It also suffers from blindly following the book ironically. Mockingjay is easily my least favorite Hunger Games book (still good but not great) due to infuriating decisions in the story like knocking Katniss out when the rebels finally win as well as not really letting Katniss do much! It's still a good ending but it's no Deathly Hallows Part 2 or Return of the King. (B)
