review: A fine finale to a great young adult series. Francis Lawrence's teen sci-fi action film The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015) is a massive spectacle featuring insane explosions, large setpieces, impressive CGI, and heartfelt character arcs to conclude Suzanne Collins' YA series: The Hunger Games. Lawrence's direction is solid for the bittersweet end as he makes the action exhilarating, while the Mockingjay's revolutionary losses hurt. He could have done something more experimental as The Hunger Games now feels old hat with so many dystopian coming of age movies around now. Collins' writing is very clever with tyrants and revolutionaries getting critiqued for their brutal methods. I like how Katniss is not the deciding figurehead of the revolution, but merely a symbol of righteousness as The Mockingjay. Her decisive final arrow is a spectacular movie moment, but President Snow's downfall occurs earlier thanks to the people rising up against their oppressive government. Jennifer Lawrence is wonderful as the heroine Katniss Everdeen. She puts the weight of the world on her capable shoulders with emotive acting and stalwart bravery in the face of danger. Lawrence captures the modern woman who can be both strong and emotional without judgement. I liked her as an actress for all 4 Hunger Games films. Furthermore, Josh Hutcherson is great as the brainwashed Peeta Mellark learning to love again. Liam Hemsworth's conflicted feelings are apparent as Gale Hawthorne. Willow Shields is as devastating as Primrose Everdeen as is Mahershala Ali as Boggs. I am sad to see Sam Claflin's Finnick Odair go. I adore the gorgeous Natalie Dormer's courageous camera director Cressida as well as the striking Jena Malone's feisty Johanna Mason. Donald Sutherland is fantastic as he bows down as the fearsome dictator President Snow. Julianne Moore is amazing as the coldly shrewd President Alma Coin. Philip Seymour Hoffman still gets some memorable moments as revolutionary tactician Plutarch Heavensbee. Woody Harrelson and Elizabeth Banks get emotional send offs as Katniss' mentors Haymitch Abernathy and Effie Trinket. Jeffrey Wright is interesting as the tech wizard Beetee. Stanley Tucci is wasted as the propaganda announcer Caesar Flickerman. James Newton Howard's score is the unsung hero of The Hunger Games franchise with his emotionally sweeping music. Jo Willems' cinematography comes up with several crafty shots that frame the revolution and the dictators with equal majesty and gravitas. I just wish Suzanne Collins' writing was stuck to more besides her heartfelt look at teenagers building a new world. The zombies underground and the furry fashion designer was just dumb. I think there should have been more action or Katniss shooting her bow to keep you engaged. The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 is a bit bloated at 137 minutes, especially when the endings keep coming without satisfaction. I wanted a happier ending I suppose, instead of the bittersweet one with few farewells.

review: Interesting, likeable characters in a plot that may be a pinch over-the-top and stretching the limits of suspension of disbelief, but still good nonetheless. You'll wonder where the "6" comes from in "Big Hero 6" for most of the movie but overall a creative movie that'll leave you hoping for a sequel (stay for the post-credits scene).

A young teenager creates a group of superheroes to save his city. This is Disney Animation's first film using a property from Marvel Comics. The heart of this film is the relationship between Hiro and Baymax, Hiro's brother's nurse robot. The film really delivers on that relationship and does well with the subject of loss. The supporting characters are unique and interesting. The animation is the quality that you would expect from Disney. The voice acting is also well done with Ryan Potter as Hiro and Scott Adsit as Baymax being the standouts. A highly recommended movie, go check it out!

When I was in 10th class and this movie was announced, I had no intention of seeing it, because I haven't seen the last 5 movies. That's how much I lived under a rock. By the time I learnt it doesn't have any prequels the movie was long gone from the theatres. So I finally watched the movie when it came on TV and damn this was a movie I'd have loved to see! Later on I got to know this is based on the Marvel comics, so technically this is the first Marvel movie I have ever watched (because I live under a rock, remember?). The reason why I liked Big Hero 6 so much is because of Hiro Hamada. I have always been interested in robotics and have participated in a robot combat competition myself. Other than that I was preparing for JEE so I was as such very much into science. So right off the bat we begin from a relatable protagonist. Tadashi was also a very nicely made character. When both Hiro and Tadashi go to his college my focus was on how nicely they both talk. It actually feels like they are physically there, as Hiro looks around and Tadashi gives remarks as he gives Hiro a tour. When he shows Baymax to Hiro the part where Hiro thinks he just made a duct tape shows how natural their behaviour was. The other characters were also very interesting, although I don't remember their names anymore since I watched it so long ago. The movie has all kinds of emotions that make it appealing to the audience. It will make one laugh, cry, angry, excited, scared and awestruck. The heroes, villains, story, plot twist, emotional conflicts and even the little details scattered throughout the movie have all been placed very well. Just watching the hero-villain fights didn't let me be seated. Baymax is so cute. The Stan Lee cameo in the end was also unique. Overall I'd say the message of this movie is the most important aspect about this movie. A hero, who has lost his brother who was his only family and has gone into depression, is brought back to high hopes with the souvenir that his brother left him. His brother's friends were there to help him, his step-mother was supportive of him and overall everyone around him was always wanting the best for him. This is what finally allowed him to be the superhero. His emotional conflicts, whether he should entirely act on his feelings or take a calm and collected approach, whether he should kill someone or never harm a person, whether he should use his powers alone or assemble a team, all of this was in his hands. He did everything he hoped will make his brother proud. I enjoyed this movie so much that later on I showed it to my sister and recommended to all the children I met. This is what a movie should be like. It has a good story, memorable people, character development, conflicts, emotions - everything needed to make a good story. These are the most grounded heroes I have seen in any animated movie. I really hope it gets a sequel. I can't have enough of it.

This is more than a good family super hero movie. It stands on its own with a good story, excellent pacing, and a lot of heart. It's earnestly funny and doesn't subvert its established rules for the sake of a quick joke, a mistake common to far too many of its peers. The superpowers are interesting and creatively implemented, the villain is unique, memorable, and flushed out. Sure, it's childish in a few places and whenever someone says, "Woman up," it's cringe-inducing, but those nitpicks aren't enough to bring the rest of the movie down with them. Closest comparison: It's like Iron Man by way of Frozen. Setting: Super Hero Plot: Super Hero Tone: Family Adventure
A great Disney superhero movie

I was genuinely surprised when watching this movie that the only character who I think isn't generic, boring, or annoying is Baymax the emotionless robot. However, despite its bland characters, Big Hero 6 is beautifully animated and colorfully designed enough to warrant at least one viewing.
A pretty good superhero movie with compelling drama. The twist villain may be horribly built up with confusing side motivations, but that was their mistake.

Big Hero 6 is an overpraised Disney film. It's basically a mix of How To Train Your Dragon when Hiccup rides on Toothless for the first time and Monsters vs Aliens when the monsters don't succeed as a team until the end. In other words, it really wasn't original besides the robots aspect. The superhero concept was painfully child oriented, the twist villain was terrible, and the robots besides Baymax were ridiculous and completely unbelievable. The whole child genius thing wasn't great either. The writing was the biggest let down, and the film could have been more emotional considering the circumstances - it was no Up or WALL-E. Furthermore, the plot was predictable, especially the ending and what happened to the brother. However, Baymax was a fantastic character, the animation was brilliant, and there was some good humour in the first half. The second half was definitely worse and things seemed to get increasingly silly as the film went on. It's an acceptable film, but it's very far from the best animated picture. Most animated pictures have a little bit for everyone, whereas this was blatantly more child oriented.
Good story, great animation.

Wish I would have seen this years ago. This film is on par with Zootopia, which prior to watching this I would say is Disney's best movie in over 20 years. It's story was really investing from the start. I was constantly interested in what was going on with the characters, which were all engaging, and it never stopped being entertaining. I loved it from beginning to end. And I laughed out loud quite a few times thanks to the amazing character that is Baymax. The very serious emotional themes in this movie were also handled incredibly well for children to be able to watch while adults can understand what is happening on a deeper level. Great film.

I'm probably in the minor cause I didn't like this movie at all. It's really rare that a disney movie feels too childish for me. This, Frozen II and Ralph breaks the internet are too bland and childish for my taste. The characters and plot are really forgettable, and the villain is so ridiculous and predictable. One of the most boring disney movies ever.
Everyone seems to love this movie. It was just okay.

Cool animated superhero film, one that I think is good. There are moments I like about 'Big Hero 6' and moments I don't like quite as much. I'll start with the positive parts. The animation is excellent, as is the music (nice song from Fall Out Boy). It also has a fair amount of heart, not as much as the film intends to add but still more than most. Now for the lesser things; that aren't bad per se, just not as well done in my opinion. The plot doesn't feel like anything too refreshing, I feel it's a story I've mostly seen elsewhere; in a few areas it kinda reminded me of the sorta stuff you'd see in a Scooby Doo episode, at least in terms of the twists and/or antagonists. I, also, don't love the design for Baymax - making a character with no facial expressions or true emotion always makes it harder to get attached to them. I do like his purpose, mind. As for the cast, they're decent just not memorable to me. Ryan Potter and Daniel Henney are solid as Hiro and Tadashi, I enjoy their bond together. I'm struggling to remember any of the others though. All in all, a good film - it's just missing a couple of things that would've made it greater.
Outside of Pixar this is possibly my favorite animated film (well also aside from The Iron Giant).

A surprising and incredibly captivating story with charismatic characters to make the experience even more fantastic, "Big Hero 6" is a great movie for anyone who expects from Disney who was inspired by a beautiful adaptation of the same name.

With stunning animation, colorful visuals, charming characters, thrilling action, and an emotionally affecting story that deals with heavy themes like grief and family relationships, it's a fast-paced family friendly animated superhero flick that's a great addition to the Disney catalog.

review: This was certainly a disappointing installment in my favorite franchise. In an ideal world they would've really knocked this one out of the park and set themselves up for a third movie that might've corrected their diminishing box office returns. Instead this actually felt like a huge mess and most of the blame rests with Rowling here -- she treats her attempts at screenplays like they're truncated novels and apparently eschews the help Kloves might have provided in trimming her work into a functioning movie script. I can imagine reading my way through multiple chapters of plot twists and family business and enjoying it, but it didn't make for a good viewing experience whatsoever. I'm glad they kept the Credence character (apparently they thought they may not) but the entire point of the movie being to figure out whose family he belongs to was deeply uninteresting, especially when the conclusion to this series is already known... it's a prequel that fleshes out the story almost entirely of people who we didn't previously know or care about. They also turned the "fantastic beasts" and their suitcase home into Pokemon-esque plot-solving devices rather than emphasizing them the way the title suggested. Other than the bad screenplay I was also displeased to see that Newton Howard had near-completely abandoned his first score in favor of all new material as one of the best things about the main Harry Potter series was the re-use of themes throughout. It sucks that Depp ruined his own career as he really did a fine job here, though they drastically underutilized Dumbledore & Kowalski. I still didn't hate this & I'll watch the third movie, but I'll go into it with very low expectations.
mojo_name: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald
rt_name: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - Movie Reviews

review: I love how this film is slightly different to the other Wizarding World films, seeing how the film has dramatically darkened, the intensified tension and ties between all the characters is so vital, especially to the interpretation by viewers. The character development of Newt, Tina, Leta, Queenie, Theseus etc., the introduction of interesting cameos (Dumbledore, Flamel, Nagini) is what brings such a depth and vastness of the story. The finale; the astounding speech by Grindelwald, the perfect CGI at the end, the biggest reveal in the course of magical history; it was all powerful and unique. No matter what, my opinion of this film will never change.
mojo_name: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald

review: Yes, there are plot holes and continuity issues. I found a few of them jarring. But honestly, the real issue is that the movie simply isn't very good. The first Fantastic Beasts movie had charm, personality, new characters with depth, and of course, lots of fantastic beasts! This one pretty much missed the mark on all of these. Leta Lestrange was compelling , but everyone else rang hollow. They completely debased Queenie's character, taking all of her complexity and cleverness from the first movie and blowing it all up to cram her into a tired trope. We know where the main story arc of the series is going, and we're a long way off from it yet. The main source of "suspense" in this movie is Credence's true identity: what pure-blood family is he from? I couldn't bring myself to care one iota, and it didn't help that the answer at the end makes zero sense whatsoever. Plot twist reveals at the end of movies should explain mysterious events that occurred earlier. This one explained nothing, and was so preposterous that it's got me rolling my eyes in advance at the inevitable retconning that's yet to come. Or maybe it was simply a lie? In any case, it was a completely unsatisfying ending. The forced connections to the Harry Potter series got tiresome very quickly. McGonagall is teaching at Hogwarts despite it being chronologically impossible! Oh cool, Dumbledore was teaching a kid named Mclaggen! Remember Nicolas Flamel? Let's get him involved! And did anyone really need a Nagini origin story? I'm going with no. No to all of it. All of these shoehorned links highlighted the obvious: that this movie can't stand up on its own.
mojo_name: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald

review: The second movie from Disney that is based on one of their amusement park attractions, however besides the name and curse this film has no more basis from that attraction. Captain Jack Sparrow and a blacksmith named Will Turner must save Elizabeth Swan from a cursed pirate crew. This is a well constructed movie with great writing, solid acting, wonderful soundtrack and a satisfying ending. Geoffrey Rush does a great job in the villain role and you can tell he really enjoyed playing the part. Johnny Depp also creates an iconic character in Captain Jack Sparrow. The score, written by Klaus Badelt, is also iconic and will be heard in the theme parks for decades. After the success of this movie they added Sparrow to the theme park attractions. A highly recommended movie, go check it out!

review: While one might scoff at my high rating of this movie, it's extremely difficult to think of a single Blockbuster that gets every single facet so perfectly correct -- The screenplay is sharp and clever, the story is high-concept yet classical in feeling, the plot has more than a few genuine surprises, the set and costume design is intricate and detailed, the cinematography lush, often times telling a story without words, the action well-staged, the musical score is outstanding and almost every performance is great. It's a fresh take on old ideas and given a polish that only the most competent craftsmen (and women) can achieve. It's not going to appear on many Best Of All Time lists, and in many ways it shouldn't - it's just filmmaking at top-tier master-class level, and with excellent writing to boot.

review: Shiver me timbers. After the disastrous Haunted Mansion (2003), Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl should have not worked. In 2003, no one was exactly anticipating Disney's live-action adaptation of one of their oldest and cheesiest theme park attractions. However, Gore Verbinski (The Cure For Wellness) directs with such energy and creativity that the story is exhilarating. It's a scary tale about ghost pirates, romance and rum, plenty of rum. The set pieces are well-conceived and feel alive with a palpable sense of history. Johnny Depp's (Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas) iconic creation of Jack Sparrow carries the picture. The way he walks and the way he talks, he just inhibits the character perfectly. Opposite him is the incredible Geoffrey Rush (The King's Speech). Playing the perfect antagonist, the pair riff of each other brilliantly. The Curse Of The Black Pearl remains a rarity that not only met my expectations but exceeded them. I can clearly recall after leaving the cinema in the summer of 2003 eager to see it again.

review: Phenomenal film! Johnny Deep as Jack Sparrow is definitely the highlight. You cannot take your eyes off him and he's so captivating and funny! The costumes, makeup, sets and visuals are simply eye-catching even 17 years later, Hans Zimmer's score is unforgettable as usual, the action sequences are so exciting and creative and fast-paced whether it's a ship fight or a sword fight, Will and Elizabeth are great protagonists that are very distinct in terms of personalities and the story is generally well-paced, original, creative and has clear stakes and Barbossa is a great villain but he's not just a one dimensional bad guy. He has an understandable motivation. Every character is just so interesting and well acted. What stops this movie from being a 5/5 is some lazy writing where characters just appear from one place to a next as though they just apparated even though the task should've been difficult and it's a bit too long. Regardless it's a phenomenal film that I love! (A)

review: Pirates of The Carribean The Curse Of The Black Pearl *****SPOLIERS***** 5/10 Disney's live action movies are kind of like living in a small apartment build unbeknownst on top of a sinkhole. Low ceiling, but super low floor (Live action remakes, Artemis Fowl, John Carter ect.). In this metaphor the first three Pirates of The Caribbean movies get to join Mighty Ducks in the attic above the apartment because the franchise is actually pretty good. The first movie is the weakest of the trilogy however, but still it stands on its own as a solid entertaining pirate adventure. Johnny Depp stars as Jack Sparrow, the world's best pirate, so it may seem anyways. The movie centers around his former crew, trying to reverse an ancient curse by returning once stolen gold. May as well spoil my opinion right away but I believe this curse is the weakest part of the movie. The pirates are immortal as long as the curse is active so any sword fight with them can only end in a loss or a temporary victory. This made the climax of the film kinda boring, as it's just a waiting game to see when the pieces will be returned. The cast of characters is the movie's strongest aspect and thankfully it takes full advantage of it. Jack Sparrow is goofy, but still incredibly savvy and competent. He never seems immortal or untouchable; he faces true peril and struggle. For such a recognizable figure he loses so much and that's fully for the best. He loses his ship, crew, friends, gets captured and then Jailed for his crimes! Fortunately for him meets the world's second biggest simp, behind Jack from Titanic, Will Barton. Will Barton is my second favourite character in this entire franchise, a man whose attraction to Elizabeth's see's him giving up his entire life, home, moral code and career just to deliver her to her fiance. True white night right there, pokimane tier 3 subs and got shit on my man Will. Elizabeth Swan is a capable damsel in distress with an interest in pirate culture, for some reason. It's never really explained, but it's helpful regardless. She's fine, moving on. The comedic relief shines in this movie. The two pirates are the stars of the franchise in my opinion, they're just fantastic. Pintel and Ragetti absolutely steal the show, delivering the most comedic lines and the most memorable scenes. In conclusion, while the finale is lacking in steaks, the movie overall is great. Fun action scenes, great comedic relief and comedic tone. The pirates movie is a solid movie.
mojo_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl

review_date: Continues the story but seems forced in parts. The CGI is actually worse here than in any other Star Wars movie - a mistake to overuse computer graphics to tell a story IMO. The fighting is not as memorable as the Phantom, there's not much going on in space that's interesting, and the dialogue is awful. The scenery is the only excellent part of this film. If I'm being brutally honest this is one of the worst Star Wars movies - forgettable, bad graphics, and bad acting.

review: With dialogue that is unbearable to listen to and a story that is extremely convoluted, "Attack of the Clones" stands as the worst "Star Wars" movie to its date, providing some of the worst dialogue between characters in any movie ever made. The entire story tries to cram too much information into it, and it ends up jumping around a lot to try to fit everything into its run time. However, where I think that this film soars is in its action, especially the battle of Geonosis, which takes up the entire third act of the film. It is absolutely entertaining to watch and the CGI helps it out a lot. The new characters introduced are also very great, and the worldbuilding is some of the best. However, due to its high number of flaws, while there was a lot I enjoyed about the film, the high number of bad ends up bringing this film down for me.

review: The director George Lucas' attempt at reinventing his famous trilogy, Star Wars, is at worst an epic disaster and a mistake. Wooden performances and extremely dated special effects that make Lucas', A New Hope (1977), look like a masterpiece. With that said, it still holds what makes Star Wars a timeless saga. It's characters, though undeveloped, are interesting and watchable enough for me to bluntly enjoy the experience. I can also complement how it is not a carbon copy of his original work, and follows a different premise. I have to say, in conclusion, that Attack of the Clones is not a good movie, but nor is it bad. We have seen worse from the franchise.

review: After the disappointment that Star Wars Episode I was, I couldn't get myself to watch the second movie in the prequel trilogy. But the thing about Star Wars is that there is no way you can possibly hate the franchise no matter what it does. Even if there's one bad movie there's still a new hope (ba dm tss!), that probably the next movie does fix some stuff. And I can tell you with a guarantee that Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones is definitely not that kind of a movie. And no, I'm not scared of some kid marking my review unhelpful who probably lives in the basement of his parents' house. One problem that constantly plagues the Star Wars prequel trilogy is that most of the good stories happen while the camera is not on the characters. There is a scene where Kenobi and Anakin are in an elevator while going to save Padm√© from an assassin and talking about their previous adventures. And trust me, all those adventures sound WAY more fun than what we are being made to watch. Most of the characters shown throughout the movie are there just for the sake of being there, without any amount of character development. That's not to say I absolutely dislike this movie. I really like the whole Jango Fett arc. It was one of the most memorable parts of the movie. There was also the colosseum fight which wasn't good but at least it was memorable. Also the part where C3PO accidentally falls on the assembly line and gets his head replaced by another robot. Other than that most scenes are easily forgettable, not as in I have forgotten they ever happened, but rather I have forgotten whether they happened in Episode II or III. I had to look up the scene I wrote in the above paragraph to make sure it happened in this movie. The CGI, once again is terrible. I don't know what's the problem with the cinematography of this movie. It makes it look so boring. And of course, here's the movie where Anakin and Padm√© start getting, well. I don't know what's with Star Wars movies and accidental incest. I get it's supposed to be a space opera, but this goes a little too far. Also the acting is super campy. One person will finish the dialogue, then the next person will speak. And I think it's a good thing because of how high the background music is. If two people start speaking together it will become impossible to hear altogether. I had said that I'd try giving another watch to Star Wars: Episode I, which is hard because of how cringy Jar-Jar Binks. But here it's hard because only the Jango Fett scene was fun. This is, in my opinion, the worst Star Wars movie made by George Lucas. Trust me when I say I get no joy from saying all of this. I still had the courage to watch the franchise further, and I'm really glad I did since Revenge of the Sith really redeemed the trilogy for me.

review: This is a 3 Star worthy movie that is stretched to a runtime considerably longer than it should be. The movie itself is largely a bit entertaining by and large, even though it's really rather hollow, which makes the obvious time-stretching bits a bit more taxing.. What's really odd is that if you look at the Deleted Scenes, there are A LOT of well-written bits of Character-building that were cut from the movie, and I really, really cannot fathom why these were cut instead of some of the bits that made it into the movie, as these are EASILY some of the best moments in the movie. Like, truthfully, I kinda wish that they made an Extended Cut of this movie, because these Deleted bits, if placed back into the movie, would likely make the movie have more impact...It might still suffer from the poor pacing, but everything would actually have more meaning, which is the main thing that this movie lacks: A Purpose. Now, in terms of the movie itself, the dialogue is not of good quality, but it's more 'flat' and 'functional' rather than something the kind of dialogue that fancies itself brilliant but is actually dumb, and frankly, I prefer this kind of bad myself. The image is crisp and the use of HD filming, as this was one of the very first movies to ever do this, was certainly effective, and while much of the CGI certainly looks dated (admittedly some still looks good), the Composites in regards to how everything Practical and Digital fit together still holds up. The musical score is a bit better than that of Episode 1, as is the Acting, although the latter really just brings it from the low-end of Mediocre to mid-tier Mediocre. And lastly, the action is pretty good, but not on par with Episodes 3, 5 or 6. Sadly, the movie also focuses on a love story at the center, and it's really quite shallow and awkward, albeit I do think there's a couple of very small moments that do slightly work. But overall, this is just a somewhat unnecessary movie, as could've ultimately been made into a 15-30 minute story, but I think George Lucas simply wanted his Story to be in a particular place for his Final Chapter, which is certainly fine - the problem is just that this movie suffers as the result of it. Still, I don't remotely hate this movie - I'm just more than willing to admit that it suffers from many shortcomings.

review: This Marvel film is a disposable exhibition of excess grounded only by a desire to fill space and make some use the contracted stars available in the absence of a solid story. It's always watchable thanks to the stars Hemsworth (decent), Hiddleston (committed but occasionally over-the-top), Portman (not her best role), Russo, Hopkins (why?), and Eccleston (could have been anyone) with a sprinkling of Elba (best part), along with some decent action, but the attempts at humour float along listlessly in this film vacuous of ideas. The lengthy flashback at the beginning coupled with contextualization means that the main kickoff doesn't occur until nearly the halfway point, leading to an extremely rushed middle and a middling conclusion.

review: The Dark World is a textbook example of the "sequel is worse" trap. The action, dialogue, humor and story are all major letdowns from its predecessor. This movie also has the unconvincing and lackluster villain problem, as Malekith is underwhelming and doesn't add much to the film. It feels as though he there mostly because the movie needed an antagonist and he was just thrown in there, and he doesn't add much emotion to the movie and overall feels bland as a villain. The script tries to overcome this at a few points but fails to do so. Stellan Skarsgard is done very dirty in this movie with his character becoming a sort of "crazy person"; this again adds little to the movie and is unnecessary. The actors do their best with their roles, but the chemistry isn't really there for the most part making the movie fairly boring. There are only two things about this movie that are worth watching it for: the interactions between Hemsworth and Hiddleston and the intro of the reality stone. Hemsworth and Hiddleston carry this film from start to finish and have a few nice and emotional moments, and the reality stone helps to further along the MCU storyline, giving viewers a legitimate reason to see this film. Other than that, Dark World is a huge letdown from its predecessor and remains today likely the worst movie released in the MCU.

review: I liked this movie, I really did, but it is probably the weakest movie in the MCU. 'Moana' is probably one of the best musicals that I have ever seen. I also consider it one of the best films that i've seen. The premise of the movie is that a young girl named Moana adventures beyond the reef to put a green rock back into a giant grass lady that creates life itself. Along Moanas way, she takes on sea monsters with a demigod named Maui, who was responsible for stealing the green rock in the first place. Characters in this film are fun, all of them having a personality, and a role. The protagonist, Moana, is fun, energetic and funny, but not to the point where you can't take her seriously. Her conflict is that she wants to 'beyond the reef', but her father forbids her because he's still scared by the loss of his friend. The whole 'my friends gone, feel bad for me!' is mainly there so we can forgive him for being a doo doo kaka to Moana. Moana's grandma is neat, she says some pretty smart lines at the start, but she passes away thirty minutes into the movie. I'm not saying that it's a bad thing, but just something that could of been slightly tweaked. Maui (hope i'm spelling his name right) is one of the best parts of the film. He interacts with Moana in such a way that it's hysterical at times, as he throws her off a boat multiple times, and always just disses her. fortunately, they make up for it near the end, which is nice. For the animation, it was top notch, and still is today. This movie is five years old now, yet the animation still holds up. Now let's talk about what I liked most about the movie, the songs. These musical numbers are so catchy, that I'd gladly download and listen to them in a casual sense. Every single song is a jam, not a single one feels out of place or just not good. Out of all the songs, 'Your Welcome' would have to be my favourite. Over all, 'Moana' is one the greatest Musical/Disney movies to ever exist. I'd highly recommend you checking it out.

I thought it was overall pretty good. I wasn't a huge fan of the story and found it a bit boring and I felt like Maui just came back for no reason. I still think its a pretty good movie, one of modern Disney's better ones. I like Moana and her personality and her chemistry with is pretty Maui. I think Maui's character ark was pretty good and Tamatoa was great. I don't think it's as good as the greats like Lion King or Hercules but I get why people like it.

A must watch! One of Disney's absolute best in terms of animation and soundtrack. The story is beautiful and the heroine is beautifully acted and sung. There are many laughs and also quite a few touching moments. I wish i had seen it earlier! 10/10 for me!

This movie blew my mind when I saw it, and I reference it all the time. I hate to sully it with any implications like this, but it is a feminist classic. This is the biggest blockbuster I've ever seen from Disney where the main beast driving the plot isn't romance. It's so inspiring to see a female lead who is the hero, and the one who saves her world from what has been stolen from herself. This is how Moana kicked "Citizen Kane" out of my top movie spot. She introduces the Goddess in non-scary ways, though we know how certain religious myths have set her up to be a monster. Moana understands the monster has been created by man through theft of the divine feminine's heart chakra, and she's the only one who can give the Goddess her heart back. It's Biblical, which His-Story gave to Moses, and Disney rightfully placed it back in the hands of our beloved Moana. I love you Moana. Thank you filmmakers for making this one. This little animated girl changed my life.

This review contains spoilers. It is indubitable how Moana (Oceania in my country) is one of the most loved animated films of recent years. And when I saw the film on Saturday I found a great confirmation of it. The animations have always been great from Disney, but more than ever here I've seen the film literally come to life: the ocean is human and the action is epic. The story is well written, always giving a sense of unpredictability and a great crescendo. The only drawback in my opinion is a meaning given to the villain who is defined as the God of fire, when the initial Goddess and he are the same thing: I did not understand what this means. The characters, even here, prove to be profound and plausible. Moana and Maui are 2 great protagonists, while the chicken, if at times it gives genuine laughter, at other times I would have liked to come in and put an end to being him. Tamatoa is a great character. In general I liked it, but I don't know how I don't think it's a masterpiece like Zootopia that came out the same year: maybe the single elements are excellent and the whole did not convince me .. Despite this, Moana is undoubtedly a film not to be missed and which differs from the usual concept of princesses that has bored me. With photographic animations, deep characters and a story full of surprises, Moana is a great movie

This review contains spoilers. Sing. This 2016 Illumination film has been the subject of a lot of criticism, but also people who really like the film, like me. Indeed, to be honest, I never understood any of the criticisms leveled at the film. The story is very well done and does not encounter any kind of inconsistency, remaining substantially consistent with itself. I don't think it's absolutely predictable, but full of unexpected twists. However, the subplots are the real engine of the film: none of this is even remotely superficial, but it manages to give you a glimpse of who the participant of the Buster Moon show is. True, Gunter doesn't have a subplot, but maybe you can explain a little more about him in the sequel. Speaking of the characters they are all nice and no one is incomplete in development or anything. The story nevertheless decides not to make Mike evolve: choice that I understand, but after Mike's scene moved by Meena's performance (one of the best scenes in my opinion) honestly deserved a more dignified ending. All the other characters represent different characters, but above all they do not make Buster choose them immediately: a choice that gave a sense of unpredictability. Between them sprout a camel, three frogs and a giraffe which was soon replaced by Johnny. The animations are very well cared for and colorful: obviously nothing comparable to Zootopia, but it still makes a good impression. The final scene with the ruined theater is simply fantastic. The soundtrack, the backbone of the film, is full of pop songs from the last few years, which is fully consistent with the theme of the film. But there is no shortage of original songs: Set it all free, beautiful rock song and Faith, sung by Stevie Wonder and Ariana Grande. If I have to be meticulous I would have preferred to see other genres of music besides the traditional ones, such as EDM or even reggaeton. However Sing never found it a bad movie, quite the contrary. It's not perfect (otherwise I would have given full 5 stars), but that's okay too. I very much hope for a sequel worthy of this film that can genuinely carry the franchise forward. With funny characters, colorful animation and an unpredictable and at times original story, Sing is a film that can easily compete for places of honor in animated cinema.

Kung Fu Panda 3 is another fresh entry in this franchise. It had a very important work to end this trilogy perfectly and it did. It is arguably the most ambitious film in the series and a lot emotions thrown into the mix. And the humor is great. Although only the animation of pandas isn't that much finished but if you have only this flaw in the movie then you are successful in entertaining an audience. Also, the climax is one of the best. So now, I can say confidently that kung fu panda is one of the most consistent franchises of all time.

Unlike The second movie this one doesn't manage to reinvent itself in a meaningful way. Instead, it takes the route of replicating the first movie's messages to a lesser effect. The result is somewhat convoluted and less satisfying. The humor is also dumber and a lot more hit-or-miss than the earlier installments. All in all, the film isn't bad but it's a far cry from its predecessors.

My issues with this movie comes down to one key issue: its relation to the first two movies in the trilogy. This shows through in a number of ways: largely the story and the drastic change in tone. The story of the first two movies has Po out of his depth, coming to terms with a facet of himself through great effort and struggle. In the first, he must come to terms with the responsibility he always dreamed of having, and the consequences should he fail to live up to that responsibility. He goes through a crucible, realizing that every single one of his heroes despises him, and what he represents, then realizing he is expected to defend the valley from the greatest threat it has ever faced. In the second movie, Po must face the man who killed his parents and led a genocide of his people, orphaning him and making him the last of his species. Lord Shen is certain that he killed every single panda. Po must come to terms with his past, and in doing so saves all of China from a despot. The third movie starts by completely subverting the plot of the second. The pandas survived! The reason the second movie exists, and Po's struggle therein, is now far less meaningful. And Po's struggle in the third movie is less interesting and less meaningful than those previous. He's told he's now a teacher, and worries that he isn't able to do his job well. The stakes are far lower, and the emotional impact is similarly reduced. If he can't teach well, then his friends training will suffer until he figures it out. Then, upon arriving in the Panda village, Po just... figures out how to teach. He didn't go through anything in an attempt to figure out how to teach, he just magically got better. The other side of the story, in which Po finds his family while dealing with Kai, is similarly bland. His father, who we've never met and have no reason to care about beyond a single line in the second movie and the expectation that 'if he's Po's father, then we have to care about him', is introduced and immediately we're struck with the expectation that the character deserves the audience's attention and emotional connection. The writers didn't let Ping feel replaced, they didn't let Po wonder why he'd lived without his people for his entire life, and they expected an emotional connection to exist in a vacuum. As far as antagonists go, Tai Lung was amazing and Lord Shen impeccable. Kai threatens far less than his predecessors: Tai Lung threatened the entire Valley, and beyond. Shen threatened all of China. Kai threatened a few dozen characters, less than 10 of which we actually know. Kai doesn't connect to Po's inner struggle at all in the same way that Tai Lung and Shen did. And Kai's attitude throughout is far less distinctive than his predecessors. The humor and campiness of this third installment were also grating, especially after the wonderful physical humor and genuinely intense mood that the first two movies attained at critical points. Meanwhile, the final fights here are interspersed with random panda villagers doing one move, then celebrating, or Po just grandstanding, instead of genuinely reaching out to his enemies as he did in the first two movies. That said, these are far more apparent than the issues above, which took me a while to put to words. I'm far happier just watching the first two movies and considering that the end of the series.

I had to think really hard about my thoughts for this movie. I hold the Kung Fu Panda franchise very close to my heart. I have invested a lot of my time in not just the movies, but as well as the side series. Overall, I think this is a great movie, it just left me feeling very underwhelmed. It still has all of the great elements from the first two films. The animation, the action, and the deep themes are all present in the third installment of this franchise. The new style of Kung Fu that is introduced, chi, was a pretty good addition. Also, I liked how they were able to reintroduce Oogway into the storyline. And of course...you have Po, who is still the lovable and funny lead protagonist we all love. All of these aspects are the reason why I love this franchise so much. However, I still feel that there was a lot of missed potential here and somethings that simply weren't going to work for me. Kai as the villain was fine for me, but he felt much more generic compared to the villains from the previous films. I didn't like how Shifu and the Furious Five were off in the distance for this film (though their minimal amount of screen time is pretty awesome). But my biggest issue with the film is the other pandas (more specifically Li (Po's father) and Mei Mei). The other pandas make the film feel a lot more childish, and I didn't find any of their interactions with Po to be that funny. This was something I expected though, so I wasn't as bothered at that. After, the primary audience for most of the DreamWorks films is younger children. But there were two new characters that I believe were the epitome of wasted potential. First of all their is Po's biological father Li. Considering how the two of them reuniting was the main plot of the story, it seemed like a great continuation of the storyline. But most of their interactions with each other are meant to be for jokes, and when the creators tried to make some emotional moments with them, it felt sort of disingenuine. And then you've got Mei Mei. This flirtatious Panda was the most disappointing part of this film for me because I had such high hopes for her. Giving Po a girlfriend would have been a genius move on their part as it could really help shape his arc as the Dragon Warrior. Her one good interaction with Po is their first one, where she's flirting with Po, but making it seem like he flirting with her. And that's it. That is literally all that she does. She learns how to use nunchucks...and...um...she...uh...yeah that's about it. It might seem like I am being hard on this movie and I am. But it is simply because I know the potential that these movies have. That with another sequel in the works, DreamWorks could give us a franchise that could surpass How to Train Your Dragon. They didn't utilize certain plot points that would have made this movie so much better. If this were the last movie, I definitely would have disliked it much more, but maybe they can make amends in future installments. As nitpicky as I am, I think that this still a great family film that I recommend. Just make sure you watch the first two movies first.

This isn't my favorite Pixar movie (at least not anymore), but it is arguably the best film that they made. One, it's a superhero movie, which already gets a bunch of points from me, because superheros are most definitely my thing, my genre (outside of animation of course). However, besides it being a superhero movie, it's a great character drama about Bob Parr and his midlife crisis. So basically, it's about a guy going through a midlife crisis, but he's a superhero with a family full of superheros. Doesn't that just sound amazing? Cast: excellent. I mean come on, you got Samuel L Jackson in this movie, I don't need to explain it anymore. And this movie might have the best Pixar villain ever in Syndrome. It's technically a twist villain, but done in the best way possible. Honestly, nothing to complain about here. Is there no big emotional moment, no. But this movie doesn't really need that‚Ä¶.at all. It's a must watch. Go to Disney+ and watch arguably the best animated movie ever made!

Pixar has made an animated movie on all the different aspects that we see and admire in our life - there's Coco on culture, Soul on life and death, Finding Nemo on marine life, Ratatouille on food and Cars on, well, cars. But the one Pixar movie that completely stands out for me is the one made on the superheroes. I have watched The Incredibles about like, twenty times as far as I can remember (almost always in Hindi), I think I have lost count. And yet it interests me the same way as it did the first time. It's clearly because of all the hard work that went into making this movie. The first time I had heard about The Incredibles, it was when it had a Happy Meal toy ad. I used to hate Violet and like Dash because of how that ad used to show her as someone who bosses him around. The reason why it did so was because it reminded me so much of my family, minus Jack Jack. The father, the mother, the elder sister and the younger brother. The entire theme of this movie is that this is supposed to be a family of superheroes. They are also people just like us, living their life in peace and quiet. It is also visible since they easily blended in with the normal people the moment they got outlawed. This clearly showed that the way we always treat them to be either gods or demons, they are more than just that. Another great aspect about this movie is the animation. It is the reason why I liked to watch this movie over and over again. Now of course all American animated movies have great animations, but this is something completely different. It looks and feels more like a videogame. As a kid I used to often play with my Wii remote when Bob broke into Syndrome's lab, pretending it's a game and I'm controlling him. The textures, the way Omnibot moves around, the fight scenes, everything gives a very videogame-like feel to it, something similar to the PS4 Spider-Man or Batman Arkham. And finally what makes this movie so great is the story and the character development. What made the Parrs so likeable? Because each of those characters are lousy, incompetant and just overall bored of their lives in the beginning of the movie. They have everything they need to make their lives fun, but they have no right to use them. So finally when they slowly get to use those powers, they are getting more excited about it and quickly adapt to the situations. In the aftermath of their fight they have made their lives better because now they are a lot more positive about their future. The Incredibles, in my opinion, is a timeless classic. Everyone should definitely see this once in their life. It's one of the movies that absolutely defines what Disney-Pixar is. I'm really glad this movie got all the fame it deserved, and probably a lot more is to come in the future (games, cameos, spinoffs, even more sequels) since I just can't have enough of this.

The Incredibles is Pixar's own version of an avengers like superhero group made up of what appears to be an average middle class family that actually have superpowers. Before the avengers made an appearance on screen this now classic was released. Is brilliantly directed and written with lots of humor and creatively explores the issues superheroes would face once they retire and decide to live normal lives. Actors Craig T Nelson and Holly hunter do a great job voicing the characters of Mr. Incredible and Elastigirl with an exquisite performance by Brad Bird as the eccentric Edna Mode. The movie has some weaknesses such as the motivations of the villain, the character development of the kids, but with great action, humor, and great storytelling this classic shines and has aged well.

Premiering at the 2015 Toronto International Film Festival, Ridley Scotts's 'The Martian' tells the incredible story of one man's survival after being left on Mars. Spanning over 141 minutes, 'The Martian' brings Andy Weir's 2011 novel to the big screen in a well-paced, well-written affair that features a star-studded cast with Matt Damon at its helm. Presumed dead by his team after a vicious storm during a manned mission to Mars, Mark Watney (Matt Damon) finds himself stranded on the red planet, 385 million kilometres away from home. Relying on his resourcefulness, Mark must find a way to keep himself alive and find a way to signal to Earth that he didn't die while NASA and his crew try to reach him. Matt Damon gives a great performance in the lead role. He does a terrific job keeping viewers interested throughout the film, especially considering he's the only person in the majority of the scenes. The supporting cast, including Jessica Chastain, Kristen Wiig, Sebastian Stan, and a whole host of Hollywood's finest, all give solid performances across the film. Not only does Damon do a splendid job keeping viewers entertained, but Drew Goddard's screenplay makes sure viewers don't get bored when Watney starts mentioning things like hexadecimals and many other scientific details. For the most part, the science behind 'The Martian' is surprisingly accurate. Some are cosmetic, but the most important one, the storm that causes the film's events to take place, is something that can't physically happen. Scott's use of various wide and overhead shots does a great job emphasising Mark's isolation and loneliness. The visual effects on display throughout the film are impressive. The VFX department does an incredible job making sure the CGI used looks realistic and doesn't blatantly stand out to viewers. Despite being a futuristic sci-fi film, 'The Martian' incorporates themes that link to ideas of human nature and humanity's future. Man's natural desire to persevere and survive plays a key role in the film - If Mark didn't have this overwhelming hunger to survive he probably wouldn't have made it home; this directly links to themes of hope and possibility. One of the first times Mark addresses the audience, he directly says 'I'm Not Gonna Die Here'. The film asks the question of what future space travel will look like, and if we might actually have humans on mars sooner rather than later. The biggest theme, however, is isolation/separation and what effects prolonged isolation has on someone. The only thing that appears to keep Mark sane through the film seems to be his access to a video log, telling both the log and viewers, what he's thinking and planning. The psychological effect of this shows up when Mark is finally rescued by his team and instantly tears up at the thought of being with other people again. Even the production design carries across this theme; the crew's kit and equipment remind Mark that he's all alone, with nothing and no one. On the whole, 'The Martian' does a brilliant job making the viewers feel like they're with Mark. The production design, camera movements and performances all help the viewer feel as though they're in the scene with Mark. Overall, 'The Martian' is a superb film that showcases a sensational performance from its lead and features striking cinematography. Ridley Scott provides audiences with a movie that fans of off-planet adventures will enjoy for years to come.

The Martian An enthralling and rigorously realistic outer-space survival story. Smart, thrilling, and surprisingly funny, "The Martian "offers a faithful adaptation of the bestselling book that brings out the best in leading man Matt Damon and director Ridley Scott. What's so fascinating about the film is that it truly turns on the solving of problems! The story goes by when astronauts blast off from the planet Mars, they leave behind Mark Watney (Matt Damon), presumed dead after a fierce storm. With only a meagre amount of supplies, the stranded visitor must utilise his wits and spirit to find a way to survive on the hostile planet. Meanwhile, back on Earth, members of NASA and a team of international scientists work tirelessly to bring him home, while his crew mates hatch their own plan for a daring rescue mission. The storytelling techniques work well enough to keep the film engaging. Its a film about human error, the will to survive, and the responsibility that we have as human beings, not just to the work that we dedicate our lives to, but to one another as people. Despite being marketed under the mainstream bait of a "space movie". The acting and plot are great featuring the best work and the best performance I've ever seen from Matt Damon, and an outstanding supporting cast. The Martian is an extraordinary tale of Watney's extreme optimism, courage, determination and most importantly, ingenuity. It's more than anything, a love letter to science.

The Martian is a genuinely fun movie, and if asked, I'd give it nine out of ten stars. The characters, primarily Matt Damon's Mark Watney, are charming and fun to watch, which honestly makes the whole movie work. The beginning is strong. Everything on Mars is hectic, until it isn't and Mark Watney is stranded on Mars. The narrative takes time with Watney, the near silence from Watney and tense synth-y score really pulling the audience into Watney's head, almost uncomfortably close. Very intimate. It sets up‚Ä¶ not stakes, exactly, but the seriousness of the movie. Later, Watney will joke around accompanied by cheesy 70's music, but in the beginning, the movie grounds itself, letting the more serious moments later also finding their place alongside the sillier ones. Matt Damon really nails Mark Watney, making him likable with depth in a way that makes me forgive how little character development takes place. With all the talent, gravitas, and charm the other actors bring, the acting is one of the strongest parts of the movie. You can't help but root for Watney to get saved, for his crew to come rescue him, for everything to go right back on Earth. The narrative does them all favors too, because even though you're sure he'll be saved and everything will be alright, all that goes wrong keeps making you wonder, "What if?" Even if that's not a question in your mind, it's immensely entertaining to see Watney get from Point A to Point B. The script is clever in this respect, and while I don't know if the science was correct, the movie impresses upon its audience complicated science without making it feel too easy or too difficult to understand. The lighthearted moments are definitely one of the biggest draws of the movie. Just as this movie is rooted in serious stakes and dangerous situations, it has little jokes or bright music to uplift it. The movie treads a careful balance without the humor seeming forced or the tenseness dragging everything down. It succeeds, for sure. The suspense feels more real when broken up by those little fun moments, and the little fun moments make the movie all the more watchable. Overall, this is an absolute blast of a movie, and I would recommend it if you're into fun sci-fi!

An interesting Matt Damon science fiction film that turns into a somewhat dull and clinical affair with regard to its long runtime in combination with a lack of thrills, and an absence of emotional weight of, for example, the psychological effects of isolation.

The acting, dialogue, pace, plot twists - everything is great in this movie, and I always liked it. But the underlying message of spending colossal resources to save one human being, when millions unnecessarily starve to death here on Earth each year, and countless more millions suffer and die from lack of help - is enormously hypocritical, and at the same time true in it's hypocrisy. And I wonder, if Watney was asked would he want to be saved or donate those resources to the starving instead, what would he have said - whatever it would be, it would be telling.

Ridley Scott this time has adapted Andy Weir's best-selling novel of the same name. Which detailed a stranded astronaut's story to survive on Mars with the resources he has and botany skills to boot. Scripted by Drew Goddard of The Cabin in the Woods fame and starring Matt Damon in the central role of Mark Watney. All of this has come together to form one of Ridley Scott's best films for some time. Certainly at this point in time, his best film since American Gangster. The story goes that a space crew is stationed on Mars, there to explore the Acidalia Planitia plain as part of their expedition. A storm rages which prompts them to leave, but not before Mark Watney played by Matt Damon is struck by a piece of a satellite antenna and is presumed dead by the crew. NASA gets wind of this and has a memorial service in his name, believing him to be dead. Sure enough, Watney survives but is in the risk of losing air. Having managed to make it to to the base, he comes to the realisation that he is alone, with little food and contact with no-one. Therefore using a space log to update his activities, he plans to use his special botany skills and ingenuity to survive. To make contact in the hope that he can somehow escape and reunite with his crew and Earth itself. The film works on several levels. The cast themselves are part of an ensemble and all shine together in this film. From Matt Damon as our lead, a worn-down but cocky and confident individual, who you all root for to make it back home in the long run. To Jessica Chastain as the ship's commander Melissa Lewis, the authoritative and leading figure to her crew and all-out disco music fan. To Chiwetel Ejiofor as NASA's director of space missions who carries the burden on earth to bring Watney back safely. To Jeff Daniels director of NASA who is cautious and decisive to a fault, just to name a few. The film manages to be surprisingly funny even during the more sombre and dark moments. By no means is this film a comedy (as the Golden Globes believed it was‚Ä¶) nor is it out of place or sporadic. Which is a credit to Drew Goddard's script who possesses a successful track record of subtly blending drama and comedy together to significant effect. I think it is also a credit to Ridley Scott, who doesn't downplay or fight against the right tone for the film, but more flows with it. Sometimes a script and Scott's vision in the past would conflict disastrously ‚Äì but here it's lighting in a bottle. The steps Watney takes to survive, whether growing potatoes in a confined space of dirt and faeces by using leftover rocket fuel to produce hydrogen or dismantling equipment and ship parts to make movement viable by the direction of NASA scientists; is fascinating to watch. Not just because the audience know what's at stake, but the level of humourous insight renders any steps into dreariness; making it an excellent but reflective thrill ride of a film. Just watching the movie blending all those successful elements together marks it as a triumphant rendition of the novel itself and offers surprises along the way. This is undoubtedly a film that isn't there to make a grand, ultimate statement. Nor is it trying to be a deep, experience film like in the vein of 2001: a Space Odyssey or Interstellar but is just only an entertaining, enjoyable survival story. That has its moments of reflection and more than enough time for the audience to spend time with Watney on his journey to survive and also be in the company of a great cast to boot. To the power of the botanist and film director, this is definitely one of his best outings and reaffirms Ridley Scott as one of cinema's greatest storytellers.

A perfectly great and original superhero movie, that should have been R-rated, which was perfectly ruined by the studio. The masterful Vince Gilligan was at the helm of this movie for the first half, which is why the first half was so good but after "creative differences" he left halfway through production, which is why the second half of the movie is like a totally different movie altogether. It's a shame because Deadpool wasn't released until 8 years after Hancock, and that movie proved that a superhero movie could be R-rated and still have a huge box office! And has since then inspired many other superhero movies to be R-rated and which is why Marvel studios are now brave enough to make Deadpool 3 R-rated and include it in the MCU. Hancock could have been SO good, but the Sony said "we want kids to watch it too for the extra money" (paraphrasing here) and look where it got this movie. It was the waste of a potentially great movie! Will Smith also gave a great performance as Hancock and it's a shame we will never see a sequel that could've been done right.

If we're being honest, Hancock didn't pack much weight at all. Will Smith is the reason why this film didn't completely flop. From the start, I caught the notion that everyone behind the camera just didn't really care all that much; They basically let Will Smith, be Will Smith, and just carry the film with his stature. The narrative on it's own was a big issue. It had such a choppy pace and flow, being super fast paced, with little - to - no setup. The script by Vincent Ngo & Vince Gilligan was pretty funny, but lacked wit, and powerful dialogue scenes. If this film was more of Will Smith cracking tongue and cheek jokes, and fighting bad guys, it probably would've been better, being a harmless action/comedy. Jason Bateman & Charlize Theron did their best to compliment Smith, but the character developments they tried to display during the second act, wasn't all that good, or necessary. Theron was just a plot device until the third act, with her character becoming short lived. I was fond of Jae Head's performance, for what little meaning he had. For his first motion picture, he does very well, and seems to be a favorable young actor on the rise. The effects and action sequences were done pretty amateurishly, feeling too cartoonish, and sloppy. The didn't really showcase anything new, or eye catching, being the film's biggest disappointment.

Although a lot of the build-up feels a little pointless at the end, this heist-style F&F film is a lot of fun, with solid special effects, pretty engaging characters, and (of course) some wild car stunts. Hobbs is a great addition to the cast, and Johnson really gives it his all with his sweat-drenched performance. It was also fun to see the ensemble highlights from the previous installments all together in one place, finally. I'm very much a fan of the film's poking fun at Han's inevitable trip to Tokyo, and I'm thankful that they're postponing it yet again, as his character proves to be a lot of fun in this film. My biggest complaint with this film, as I mentioned, is that the entire middle act is spent with the characters planning and practicing an elaborate heist. Unfortunately, everything falls apart so much at the end that 90% of the plan goes completely out the window. Don't get me wrong - the action-packed final sequence is a hell of a good time, but it does feel somewhat invalidating of all the really engaging technical challenges the team faced. I also felt that the film was overall lacking in, for lack of a better term, fast and furious scenes - they spend a lot of time talking, running, shooting, and punching, but not a lot of time actually driving cars (until the extended final chase sequence, of course). Despite this, I really enjoyed Fast Five.
The cars are faster, the speed is intense, and the stunts are more wild than ever before. FAST FIVE is action packed and more serious than its predecessors.

Dom (Vin Diesel) and Brian (Paul Walker) work together with their friends to disarm a powerful Brazilian drug lord through a 100 million dollar heist. Agent Luke Hobbs (Dwayne Johnson) joins this movie, so prepare for greater battle. This is a major shift in the franchise, as they incorporate the heist sub-genre. So there are less racing, but the car chases are still there. I love how they plan their moves to get the vault. The police wants Dom and Brian, so the duo obviously has to run away

Fast Five is when the franchise went insane with the now signature heist action and explosions that the franchise is known for. The introduction of the Rock in this movie is great as he brings his awesome kick ass no nonsense personality to the role. The movie features an ensemble cast from previous movies and leads to awesome action sequences, funny moments, and just pure popcorn entertainment. Although the movie is outrageous, the story is well written which leads to a very fun and well made movie that took fast and furious from a million dollar franchise about street racing and cars to an action packed franchise and the world has never been the same.

When I first watched this movie, I was a young child in 2011 when it first came out and I grew up to really have a big passion for cars. At the moment I didn't know this movie was going to have an impact on my hobbies as I grow older. I watched this movie again with my friends when I went to college and after watching this movie for the second time, I was able to get a much deeper sense for the different aspects of this movie. This movie does a great job involving everything a boy would enjoy; which includes fast cars, action, and women. The superb cinematography in this movie really caught great scenes of fast cars and fight scenes. I remember as a kid I would be in awe watching the super cool cars speed by in street races and wanting to have a cool looking car like that one day too, and now almost ten years later I have grown up to own a mustang that did feature in this movie. Besides the action scenes, this movie also had a great soundtrack that went along with it. The quick tempo music went along perfectly with the action cuts in this movie to stir up excited emotions in the audience. All the characters in this movie are really likeable and overall a great cast. This movie along with the rest of the Fast and Furious series are all outstanding movies that do great in all aspects of film making.

review_date: I have often heard people say that The Fast and Furious franchise starts off a bit slow, but they get much more fun at Fast Five. So, I made the jump from the first one all the way to the fifth to see if people were right. I figure if this chapter in the saga doesn‚Äôt work for me then it‚Äôs clear that none of them are going to be my cup of tea. I will admit that it is more fun watching these guys as big-time international thieves than just a bunch of street-racing punks who steal DVD players. It‚Äôs always a blast to see the tropes of a heist movie as our heroes assemble their team, devise their plan, and then execute the plan (dealing with any bumps in the road as they go.) I didn‚Äôt feel like I missed much in character development by skipping some of the movies. I just accepted that this team had grown closer, and moved up in the world from petty larceny to the point that they are pulling massive heists in non-extradition countries. It also seemed fairly obvious that they expected us to like them all despite the fact that they were convicted criminals on the run from the law. Finally, I understood the sly references to Tokyo Drift, because I‚Äôve heard many times before that it takes place after these films. I do like some of what they are trying to do with the franchise in Fast Five, but I struggle with it as well because it feels like they are taking everything so seriously. This doesn‚Äôt feel like a fantasy world, and yet these men and women are superhuman. They can survive anything, they never get shot, and we even watch Vin Diesel break a pair of metal restraints with nothing but brute strength. Also, I‚Äôm not a car guy, so all the time spent drooling over luxury sports cars and watching them race in circles was kind of dull for me. Plus, these aren‚Äôt even real cars because they have supernatural powers just like their drivers. The big chase at the end is one of those things that is meant to be pure fun, but I was sitting there baffled that this made any logical sense. A fleet of semis couldn‚Äôt pull that much weight at those speeds, let alone a couple of cars. Not to mention all the civilians that must have been killed by that huge thing swinging around as they raced down the street. So much for the family being good guys, they are mass murderers! It seems that Fast Five has proven, even when they make some improvements to their formula to increase the level of fun, the required suspension of disbelief (and interest in cars) is too much for me to enjoy.

review_date: I liked it a lot better than the second movie and MIB 3 almost matches the great storytelling and pure enjoyment of the first! Agent J has to travel back to 1969 to repair history after an Alien criminal travels back in Time to kill a younger Agent K. Will smith (Agent J) interacts mainly with the younger version of his mentor and partner Tommy Lee Jones (Agent K). The younger K is played brilliantly by Josh Brolin, and you can tell he is a younger TLJ in the movie. There are notable Twists and turns that make the movie worth watching. If this is the last MIB movie, then it is a good wrap up.

The acting was great, the visual effects were a significant upgrade, and the cinematography and soundtrack were still decent. Josh Brolin played young K well, and the ending was an interesting twist. I'm rather surprised it took my over 7 years to finally watch this, especially considering how much I liked the original as a kid. It is way better than the second one in the original trilogy and recaptures much of the magic of the original. Josh Brolin does a terrific Tommy Lee Jones impression and Will Smith is at his Will Smithiest. I love the 60s in general and find it to be a fantastic setting, even if it's terribly underused in this movie. Likewise I'm generally a sucker for the time travel conceit and while they could have done more with it, it might actually be an even better premise than in the other 2 movies. Jemaine Clement also made for an interesting villain in Boris the animal, although again, this movie squandered him, the era, and the time travel to a degree but remains satisfactory nonetheless, despite all its predictability. The one particular note that I felt was forced was the twist where we discover something that not only is statistically improbable to the point of absurdity but just feels shoehorned in due to some executive's insistence or some poor decision on the writer's part. The time travel also makes no logical sense whatsoever, but, if you go into it with just popcorn movie expectations, then it delivers.
This could of got overly complicated but it manages to feed the information to you in a great manner. If your a fan of this franchise then you will enjoy this installment.

The movie is too crowded, and that is the main problem. The script is poorly written and creates an unfocused, messy film. The "government vs. Tony Stark" plot is intriguing and was a sophisticated plot point to explore in the first act. However, it loses itself in the 3rd act when none of it gets mentioned again. The villain of the movie is also terrible. Ivan Vanko does absolutely nothing in this film. His motives are unclear for the first hour of the movie, and there is hardly any explanation for anything he does. Justin Hammer, who also fits the villain trope, is also poorly written. A video of him almost killing someone leaks, and everyone still loves him at the end of the movie? It's just terrible writing. Trusting Justin Theroux with a story like this still makes no sense today. Theroux butchered so many characters making them feel unlikeable. For example, Tony is literally in a relationship with Pepper, but he shows interest in Natasha and other females. Yes, Tony is one to be the flirty type, but character growth is essential. No character grows in the film making for a pointless story. The only good part of the script would be the Howard Stark plot point. It brought a lot of heart to the movie and made the film watchable. Other than the script issues, everything else in the film was mediocre. The cinematography did not feel as visually stunning as the first installment. There were only a few shots that looked appealing. The production and set design also felt weak. Most of the movie takes place either in an office building or Stark's house. That does tie back into the script because there was no innovation in where the characters would be. However, that does not excuse the production and set design teams as they did not elevate those locations to make it stand out. Jon Favreau does a so-so job directing Iron Man 2, and it was nowhere near as good as Iron Man. What Favreau did on Iron Man was spectacular. In this installment, everything felt generic with no real suspense or emotion. The action sequences were one of the worst parts of the film as they had no thrill or uneasiness whatsoever. Jon Favreau was able to create that sense of fear whenever danger was around Iron Man. Yet here, it is like Tony can get out of any situation without any problems. The tone Favreau created for this movie was just not at the level it should have been. The cast was the only good part of Iron Man 2. Robert Downey Jr. is superb as always and does not disappoint even with a butchered character arc. Downey knows how to play cocky so well. Gwyneth Paltrow also does a lot better in this film than in the first installment. Paltrow's performance is watchable and made me like Pepper more as a character. Don Cheadle also does a great job in the role of James Rhode. He brought a lot more emotion to Rhodes' personality, which allowed for a better connection to him. Sam Rockwell is so unlikeable in this film. That is great since his character is supposed to be unlikeable. Lastly, Mickey Rourke is a mixed bag as, with such a terrible character arc, his performance can not save it. Overall, Iron Man 2 is a deeply flawed film that can never stick the landing in almost all of the departments of the film. Justin Theroux ruined this movie with his awful writing as he handled these principal characters in such a disappointing way. Everything else is also a step-down as only the cast can start the thrusters in this version of Iron Man. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

Other than giving a somewhat decent introduction to Scarlett Johansson's Natasha Romanoff so as to set up the Avengers films and giving Sam Jackson some funny moments as Nick Fury, Iron Man 2 is a major letdown from its predecessor and falls into the "sequel does worse" trap. The film loses much of the finesse that the first one had, and manages to squander Sam Rockwell and Mickey Rourke. Whiplash shouldn't have been this movie's villain; it would've been more entertaining to watch Tony spend two hours fighting the government for control over his tech, and the writers would probably still have found some way to get Natasha into the story. At least that way it would've made more sense as a sequel to Iron Man. The big actors, both new and familiar faces, do their best in their roles, and some of the fights are entertaining to watch, but all of that isn't enough to keep this sequel afloat. Overall Iron Man 2 tries to add to and build on the MCU but succeeds more in taking away from it.

One of Pixar's best movies! Remy, a rat, is an aspiring chef and finds a way to realize his dream in Paris. As with every film, Pixar ups the game in animation. The water, fire effects are great as is the movement of the rat characters. The human characters are stylized, but believable in a cartoonish way. Brad Bird does an amazing job as director/writer and crafts an excellent story. Patton Oswalt is great as Remy and Peter O'Toole is a perfect cast as Anton Ego. The writing is also well done, Ego's review near the end of the movie is a highlight. An amazing film, go see it!

With some stunning animation as always, a beautiful score that captures the essence of France perfectly, and a driving factor behind our lead that's way too realistic and mature to be in a children's flick. This movie truly is Pixar's Magnum Opus. It might be advertised as a fun adventure for kids, but it's truly a movie about the driving factor behind the entire human race, our stimulus to create. This is one wonderful dish you won't want to miss out.
