I live by that motto today and try to help my friends learn the art of cooking. I never thought I would empathize with a rat but here I am. This movie was perfect when it came out and is still perfect now. Highly reccomended!

For me, this is another great Pixar movie, being my second favorite out of all 26 films (the top being about a robot who saves a trash earth, but that's for a different review). But the issue is that there are other Pixar films that are conceptually and emotionally better. Again‚Ä¶.if we are going on what Pixar film is probably the best made one, it's a toss up between Monsters Inc and The Incredibles for me. Yeah, I'm just stalling on this review. I could be here for days talking about the themes alone, but there's a YouTube video that already describe everything this film did right. If you can, watch "Why Ratatouille is Pixar's Magnum Opus" by Schaffrillas Productions. He explains why it is the best Pixar movie Better than I ever could. My only thing is that this movie falls under the same category as Finding Nemo for me. Has a few better moments then some of the 5 out of 5 Pixar movies (Anton Ego anyone?), but there's not a huge emotional moment, and the movie constantly tries to bring Chef Skinner back, which seems like kind of lazy writing. Also there's a stereotypical betrayal which is so dumb, but it's "technically" needed. Besides that, some parts of this movie feel like an Indy film. Again, watch the Schaffrillas Productions video, he goes into so much more detail than I do. Wanna watch arguably the best Pixar has to offer! Watch this well cooked movie on Disney+ and see for yourself!

Ratatouille was actually a pretty interesting movie. I had a lot of fun while watching it. Yes it may not be the most memorable Pixar movie but it is interesting. So it's about a Rat named Remy who dreams of becoming a chef at a famous restaurant in Paris. However the only problem with that though is that he's a Rat. However he does eventually ends up in this famous restaurant in Paris after he parts away from his family. However he realize he could have his dream come true when he meets a human named Linguini and helps him out cooking delicious meals while no one knowing the truth on who's the real cook. To be honest with you I actually thought that this movie had really interesting premise. That they actually used really well also they really handled the animation on the food really well and the story it's self was a pretty interesting. However the one problem that I have with the movie is that it's really not that memorable. Sure the characters are likable and well animated but they aren't as memorable as Woody, Buzz m, Nemo, Marlin, Dory, etc. Another thing about this movie is that I feel like the pacing could've been better. Ratatouille is not one of Pixar's best movies but it does keep you interested in both the characters and the animation, so while it might not be as memorable, it does put a good taste in my mouth. 8/10

review: This review contains spoilers. I had a bit of contempt for watching this saga: I had a bit of youthful prejudices that limited my vision. During the lockdown, however, I wanted to find several animated films that I had not seen, including this saga. When I saw the first one I was amazed by its beauty (you will also find my review). But the second managed, I don't know how, to do much better. This sequel cleverly continues the first film setting it years later when Hiccup and Toothless are now grown up. The tone of this film, generally speaking, is dark, like Toy Story 3. And I really like animated films with dark tones. The relationship between the two protagonists undergoes a notable evolution which becomes very mature. The villain is one of my favorites at Dreamworks: he is very evil. I liked one of his scenes in particular, as well as one of the most moving: when Drago takes control thanks to his Toothless alpha and goes so that he kills Hiccup. The father, however, saves the blow and dies. Moreover, although he had always traveled by ship, on that occasion he rides Toothless to make Hiccup feel even worse. The twists are not lacking and they are unpredictable. The animations are spectacular and gorgeous to look at. The characters are all nice and well developed. The film is simply fantastic: a masterpiece for sure. With a well thought-out storyline and great characters, How to Train Your Dragon 2 is absolutely a movie worth watching.
rt_name: How to Train Your Dragon 2 - Movie Reviews

review: An excellent sequel to the masterpiece that was the first movie. The animation has greatly improved and looks stunning, the soundtrack is just as spine-chilling, the first 10 minutes do a great job in establishing how Berk has changed in the last 5 years, Stoick's death was incredibly dark and emotional, especially since he sacrificed himself for Hiccup, I love his interactions with Valka and that song and their reunion are some of the best scenes in the trilogy, the universe gets expanded with the introduction to the Alpha dragon and it takes a darker tone and develops the character and themes pretty well. I have some issues however with the characters. Valka is just forgotten in the 3rd act and I feel like her coming back to Berk should have been impactful, Drago just stands around and yells and is just forgettable, the teenage vikings are so unfunny and annoying, Astrid is kind of out of character with her being reckless and her and the teenage vikings don't receive any consequences for them leading Drago and his army to where Hiccup as it was their fault. Even Toothless is just a side character until the 3rd act. These flaws however don't ruin the movie and is still a great sequel despite being the weakest of this phenomenal trilogy.

review: Easily the best of the X-Men movies, and debatably the best Marvel movie to date, "Logan" sees a far darker tone for Marvel, and shifts drastically from the fun and goofy tone of previous films, both MCU and X-Men universes. The acting is superb, and Hugh Jackman gives his best portrayal of Wolverine to ever hit the screen. The entire film is very emotional, and constantly tries to jerk a tear out of your eyes. The ending is bitter-sweet, yet it leaves the audience oddly satisfied as it feels like the perfect conclusion to a franchise that has been going on sine the original "X-Men." As serious as this film does get, however, there is still loads of chemistry and jokes between the three main characters (Logan, Charles Xavier, and Laura), and the movie never becomes too serious to the point of boredom. The only real issue I have with "Logan" is that the villain is somewhat forgettable, however, the movie is still enjoyable (albeit brutal) to watch, and it is entirely targeted towards an older audience, which I thought opened up this movie from the limitations it otherwise would have had.
I mean, nice try. But this movie makes almost no sense and basically grants no one any payoffs.

Easily the best film in the franchise, and one of the best superhero films of all time, It is a satisfying conclusion to the Wolverine trilogy and builds upon the tone of the previous Mangold directed film. 10/10

Honestly the best X-Men movie ever. The harsh grittiness and dejected Logan is so much more realistic. This is how the X-Men movies should have always been. Hugh Jackman killed it in this role as Wolverine like we've never seen him. His sadness, his lashing out, his distrust of other people, all combine to make a stellar performance. Patrick Stewart was absolutely heartbreaking to watch as our beloved Professor X is weak and slowly dying. And the breakout performance of Dafne Keen was thrilling to watch. She barely speaks in the movie but her body language and facial expressions took that character to another level.

With the exception of Jessica Jones, Brightburn and Deadpool, I'm not a big fan of superhero tropes. They tend to be trite and formulaic, with no heart and no originality, high on action low on genuine emotion; and even less actually have well crafted dialogue. But I'm a huge fan of Logan. It's got all of this and more. It's the emotional core that makes it special though, with exceptional heart, well done script, and meaningful dialogue. And an incredible, believable performance by its three leads. It actually reminds me of Rocky and The Unforgiven more than a superhero film, in that it shows the flawed, yet beautiful, humanity at the core of every underdog; merely through the cracked lens of being "super". And it's all the better for it. An absolutely tremendous film, that always moves me to tears.

review: When I was smaller, I recall this movie being my favorite of the Jurassic Park trilogy. Rewatching it today, I am utterly disappointed. The characters are rushed, we do not feel connected at all to any of them, the storyline is mediocre and rapidly deteriorates. Even if the greenpeace dude was anti-human, it feels forced how he deliberately attempts to endanger the bad guys (opens cages, unloads guns), but someone needs to forward the plot I guess. While in the first, human life was spent sparingly, here it's just fun and games. Would have liked to learn more about the 'don't go in the high grass guy' seeing as it seems like he is important to the bald dude, but no. Whilst the woman scientist was excellent in the first movie (reliable and smart), in this movie this one is just a pain in the ass, useless and unable to have any sense of self-survival, but all this is excused to make the plot move forward. By the end you are just fed up and even the fun scene with the T-rex isn't enough to get you back into it, especially since they added huge plot holes at the end. Feels rushed, only watch if you are rewatching all of them.

review: I'll probably be crucified for saying this, but this is my favourite Jurassic Park film. More Goldblum and more dinosaurs is the perfect equation for excellence. The film definitely suffers from being in the shadow of the original which is objectively superior as well as being one of the most iconic science fiction films of all time. The film also definitely has its flaws (the velociraptor gymnastics scene and T. rex rampage come to mind) but makes up for it with some fantastic atmosphere, musical score (John Williams takes it up a notch with the music here, which has so much more individual personality) and an overall tone that is darker than the original. Ultimately I think people should give this one another chance and try not to compare it to the original film.

review: The Lost World Jurassic Park - 9/10. Steven Spielberg is one of the greatest filmmakers of all time. He's a director with a vision that was well ahead of his time. In terms of sequels and the way they are presented, I feel like Spielberg was a pioneer in terms of making sequels with a darker aesthetic and mood. Films like Temple Of Doom and The Lost World went down darker paths than the first instalments in their series (Raiders Of The Lost Ark and Jurassic Park respectively). In terms of The Lost World, I think it was the best decision to go down a more darker tone. The cinematography done by Janusz Kaminski is superb. The way he shoots the action scenes and uses shadows and the night almost like a separate character makes this film such a visual treat. Jurassic Park featured some amazing cinematography, but I feel like The Lost World is much stronger in terms of the visual tone it presents. People seem to have liked this film a little more as time has gone by. I've always loved it and it was one of my #childhood favourites. Jurassic Park is definitely the best in the series, but The Lost World comes in a close second. There are more dinos (3 Trex!), Jeff Goldblum is promoted to being the lead (Ian Malcolm is one of my all time favourite characters) and John Williams delivers an amazing score. Its such a fun filled ride, and quite horror-esque (something that I feel movies like this should attempt to be like!). The movie never fails to entertain, and just feels like it ages extremely well for an action adventure film. I feel like the reason why it's considered underrated is because its the sequel to one of the greatest films ever made. Its a tall task to follow, but I think it does a great job! If somehow, you've never seen this movie, go watch it!

review: Excellent Sequel Creating a worthy follow-up to a major blockbuster is no easy task. But if all the pieces are in the right place, it is not impossible. Four years after the enormous success of Jurassic Park, Steven Spielberg took control of the director's chair once more in an effort to enhance the franchise and add on to his already spectacular legacy. Did he succeed? In the eyes of most critics, no. However, I applaud Mr. Spielberg for an admirable effort and creating another crowd-pleaser, even if it didn't match up to the high expectations. On another personal note, I was very happy to see Jeff Goldblum reprise his role as Dr. Ian Malcolm as he has always been my favorite character in the series. Since Malcolm is now more aware of the dangers of John Hammond's activities, his personality is less goofy and more serious this time around compared to his previous adventure. It took several viewings for me to appreciate this film to its fullest. At first, it seemed weak because it sacrificed the philosophical messages that helped make the first film great to fit in more action. The philosophy is found in one of the key quotes by John Hammond. "Life will find a way." There *is* a point to all the chaos because it is all caused by the humans and their relentless desire to interfere with nature. Every tragic event seen in the film could have been avoided with sensibility and that is the message that is echoed throughout the entire series. Don't attempt to control the uncontrollable. If there's one thing that makes the film worth watching, it has to be the special effects and the dinosaur animatronics. The infant T-Rex featured in this film is so lifelike that I often had to remind myself that it wasn't a real dinosaur. It was *that* convincing. Also be on the lookout for Vince Vaughn (before he became the mega-star that he is today) as one of Hammond's researchers and a humorous scene involving a T-Rex in the modern world.
rt_name: The Lost World: Jurassic Park - Movie Reviews

review: It's a reasonably good film as long as you keep your expectations in check. It was never going to be as good as the first which is an all-time classic. The CGI is excellent and there are some thrilling and exciting set piece action moments. The screenplay is a bit more of a mixed bag. It takes a while to get going and you feel they cram a lot into one movie. However, its still a lot of fun and I would rank it 2nd or 3rd best in the franchise.

review: I honestly don't understand the poor reviews on this movie. Maybe because everyone, including the critics are comparing it to one of the greatest movies ever made in the original Jurassic Park but if this were a stand alone movie, the reviews and admiration would be much higher. I think this movie deserves at least an 80% rating. The technology used both for CGI and the vehicles and equipment the actors used on screen were way ahead of its time, considering this was produced in the mid 90's. This movie scared the shit outta me when I was a kid, as did the first one, and if you were to show this to a young kid nowadays it would hold up. If the original film is the best out of the franchise, then this one is the second best, and the third one the third best. The 2 most recent Jurassic Parks are absolutely terrible imo, they turned a legitimately scary idea and series of films into family friendly BS. The Lost World is when raptors were one of the main antagonists of the movie instead of Chris Pratt's golden retriever. Stop comparing this movie to the first one and watch it for what it is, and through the lens of when it was made and it'll blow you away.

review: James Bond is acted decently, the film however is not decent. Certain scenes are dragged out, certain plot points are just plain silly. Avoid.
Daniel Craig begins his outings as Bond, James bond, and does it satisfying action and a darker rebooted bond.

And now to Daniel Craig. I remember all the flack when they announced him as the new Bond (blonde and blue eyes, how dare they?) and then he comes out of the gate with (spoilers!) the best Bond film? Well paced, holds up well fifteen years later, and a perfect reinvigoration of the franchise. I liked Brosnan even though the last few movies were outright terrible. This one is just a great movie.

I must admit my skepticism of Daniel Craig as the latest Bond but he does a convincing job in his first film as 007. This Bond origin story dispenses with spy toys, playfulness and camp in favor of a more serious tone. It also makes Bond less of a hero figure and more of a conflicted and very skilled assassin. Jason Bourne comes across as having more of a hero persona. Fans of modern action films will enjoy this new version of Bond but Bond aficionados (of which I must admit I am not) may not enjoy it as much.

My favourite bond film of the 21st century. Maintains audience engagement throughout its course. Magnificent soundtrack and exceptional cinematography. Locations were well chosen and more importantly, well shot. For me, the beach scene in Barbados is the most memorable moment in Casino Royale.

The best Bond movie in decades, "Casino Royale" takes the franchise to much more extreme and serious lengths, ditching the goofiness of previous installments to create a more fresh and realistic film that hits all the right notes that it should while also coming up with a completely new beat.
Whilst none really stand up to much scrutiny, this is certainly the best Bond film of recent times and arguably the best of them all.

The original James Bond series as created by Ian Fleming feature a spy who lives the high life as he does his spy work, killing a few evildoers and making love to several women in the process. There were some gadgets, though not necessarily flashy ones, and Bond wasn't always full of wisecracks like he would be in the later movies. The idea might have been that the later movies were too full of wisecracks and fancy gadgets and they were toning it down. But they ended up overdoing it and turning Bond into basically a glorified serial killer. The older movies did have Bond do killing and blowing up of villains' installations. But in this movie, Bond kills willy-nilly, often without real necessity. On top of that, the scenes at the gambling table and his romance with the (supposed) heroine go on for too long. Bond may be young and inexperienced, but no wisecracks at all? We might as well be watching a "Bourne" movie.
The movie is awesome from the first movie of Daniel craig and the amazing scene of the casino

Craig's first and best Bond. He filled the well worn shoes superbly whilst adding his own muscly take. A strong narrative, breathless stunts and insane action set pieces make this our favourite ever 007 film. Royalty.
A perfect origin story for Bond, James Bond.
Some laughable silliness but not without merit.
The creation of the legend.
What more can one say about this? He reinvented James Bond with Casino Royal and brought him into the 21st century with his emotionality and humanity. For me, he is now the best James Bond.

Daniel Craig's first outing 007 was great. Rebooting a franchise can be a tricky thing to do especially a long running one like the James Bond Franchise but with its tough, gritty, and more realistic tone, Daniel Craig comes in and knocks it out of the park and it's understandable why Casino Royale is one of the best in the Franchise.
Overrated! Craig is a misfit for the traditional 007

Casino Royale is a masterpiece and it is still Daniel Craig's best Bond movie to date, with the only real competition being Skyfall IMO. Daniel Craig's performance as Bond in this movie was absolutely amazing, you know he is great when he overshadows Mads Mikkelsen, who also was amazing in this movie. The action is top notch, along with the storyline and the writing. Overall, Casino Royale is an amazing movie and it's my personal favourite Bond movie ever made.

Ah yes, The Bourne Identity one. This may borrow certainly from the Bourne movies, but it improves upon them and writing wise, it adapts from the book (Casino Royale) faithfully. This is one of the more serious entries and I absolutely love that. The action is shot coherently and the shots are held just long enough for us to see what is happening. The set pieces themselves are among the best in the franchise and this one film has a few of them. They are all great. Daniel Craig is fantastic in the role. Not my favourite bond, not even in my top 3, but he's still really good. All of the official actors that played the character brought something to the role that none of the other do quite as well. Craig has the best run. He just does. I hadn't notice before, and thought he only started doing this in his later films, but he mutters here. It is a negative, I am unable to sometimes make out what he was saying if not for watching with subtitles. Vesper is a fantastic Bond girl, but if there were any negatives I have for this otherwise masterpiece it is that Bond falling for her felt a bit forced. Not too forced, in the end, it still is believable, I just needed a bit more time with them together is all for it to fully 100% connect with me.
A fun movie, though I feel like the Daniel Craig series takes itself too seriously sometimes. This is certainly the start of it. The action scenes were great of course.

Casino Royale is a 4-star 100 minute movie stretched out to a painfully long 160 minutes, and that's a shame. The story is pretty good, the villains, while not memorable, are certainly intimidating, the action scenes are solid and the movie's technical merits are quite good. While it certainly got tiresome after a while, Craig's more realistic and Anti-Fun Loving take on Bond certainly helps make this movie feel like an entirely different beast than those from before, and one that you could genuinely take seriously. Craig's performance is a strong dramatic one, and he does have the gravitas required to carry a movie with this dark and aggressive of a tone. The main problem with the movie is that it just feels endless; I remember watching this in numerous 30 minute chunks and even then I was feeling the weight of it. If you like a more serious tone with your Action movie, then Casino Royale is certainly going to deliver - it's not as ambitious as Batman Begins, the movie that it clearly took inspiration from (that being the "Gritty Reboot" of a franchise), but it's certainly good at what it does, for the most part.
This movie may have saved the Bond Franchise!

Exhilarating, fresh, serious, intense, and Daniel Craig delivers a performance for the ages, not just as James Bond, but a cinematic legend is born. If you prefer the campy, gadget-ridden, melodramatic and unbelievable Bonds of the past, this is not the Bond for you. This Bond is human (he hurts, he bleeds, he loves, and he has chosen to live the life of an assassin to serve his country. Nothing comes before duty for this 007. Unlike many of the out of shape, or average physique Bonds of the past, Craig's Bond looks and captures the physicality of a man that can kill with his bare hands. The movie's opening let's you know that this 007 is ice cold, as he becomes a 007. The pacing is perfect, the best poker game in cinema history, and a love story that will engross and capture the audiences emotion. Action set pieces are among the best (and are the best imo). If there is such a thing as the perfect Bond film, this is it. And no one does it better (past, present or future) than the incomparable Daniel Craig.

review: This by far is the best movie that there is in the history of cinema. I read the critic reviews and cannot believe there lack of depth. This is what a historical Roman execution would have looked like. Scourging itself killed most people. Jesus endured a Roman scourging then a Roman execution which is by far one of the most tortious ways to die ever envisioned by men. Gibson's use of flashbacks is unbelievable and his subtle theology is just brilliant. As an example - the opening scene in the Garden of Gethsemane is with a serpent and the devil tempting Jesus. This is a call back to Genesis and the Garden of Eden. Adam was tempted by the serpent and fell. Jesus as the new Adam is also tempted by the Serpent in a Garden except He does not fail the test He literally "crushes the serpents head". While this is not in the bible - this is making the theological point that Jesus fulfils the prophesy of Genesis 3:15 and by the very scenes in the movie which portray His passion and death He crushes the head of the serpent in the spiritual reality. The acting in the film is breathtaking. Considering that Jim Caviezel literally almost died several times in the filming of the movie and was in tremendous physical pain while on the cross his acting was not so much acting but actual agony. The score moves the audience to tears every time you watch this movie even for the millionth time. This movie is one you watch, buy and share. It is timeless.

With a surefire Ang Lee behind the camera and Suraj Sharma's excellent performance as Pi, Life of Pi manages to show off a marvelous bond between human and tiger with staggering visuals, powerful realism and even emotional satisfaction.

It's well done. It's visually appealing. The CGI is decent. And there's some depth here. I can't really decide if the movie is arguing in favor of spirituality/religion or against it. Maybe it's neither. The whole point is that Pi made up the story with the animals so that he could live with the memories of what he had to do to survive, killing, cannibalism, etc. The tiger never really tried to eat Pi because he is Pi. Pi didn't like that his more primitive side had to come out to survive but he also knew he couldn't abandon the tiger as it was part of him and they needed each other. And people do this all the time. We remember uncomfortable things in a brighter light than the reality. We excuse ourselves from facing our own demons by making up a metaphorical tiger and acting like it was something separate from ourselves when we really understand, on a completely honest, rational level that it was us, but we don't want to embrace that truth. I'm also not so sure about the island. I guess it represents his thoughts of giving up hope of rejoining the world. He could stay there and die alone but he decided that's not what he wanted to do. He wanted to keep moving on and trying to find people again or die trying. And he viewed it as a sign from god that he needed to find the island to realize it wasn't his time to just give up and die. And this is why his tiger side had to leave the island with him. This part makes me think the tone of the film is pro-spirituality/religion, even though it recognizes it's not rational. The larger idea here is that religion is basically a coping device that people use to adopt a brighter perspective on the harsh realities that we have no evidence suggesting we are of any significance or anything more than an accident. I think atheists, and even some theists already realize this. So this isn't some revolutionary idea. And the movie dragged a bit in some places. But it is well done and worth seeing at least once.
In a nuthseel: FANTASTIC!

There are beautiful and inspiring moments in this film, life of pi delivered a great lesson within the film, the entire film feels magical despite the terrible moments the character has to go through and every challenge he faces.

Most recently, I watched a movie called "Life of Pi". This film is about a boy who ran away from home, who got into a difficult situation and ended up alone in the middle of the sea, along with a tiger. In this film, we were shown that there are no hopeless situations. You need to go to your goal and take all the difficulties as a test. You need to appreciate what you have right now, you need to love and cherish your loved ones. This film made a strong impression on me. I think that absolutely everyone will be imbued with it when viewing it

It was interesting film... I don't know what it has to do with god, but pretty cool. Beautiful film, with hints of the Odyssey meets humanist animal mythology... could be interpreted as a psychological journey through life changing experience... storms, islands & homecoming...
I laughed, and cried. Mostly I cried. I feel like I was reborn at the end of this movie. Perhaps as a carnivores island.
I remember watching this movie in theaters, and it was such a beautiful experience with an amazing film.

Inconsistent visual effects, too focused on religion, and a bit drawn out. The plot was unique I'll give them that, and the narrative style worked, but the likelihood of him surviving in the real world would be extremely low, the weird island and many other plot points were silly, and the writers relied on the topic of religion far too heavily. I felt surprisingly little for the main character and his family, which goes to show how the writers failed. In fact, I was far more concerned about the animals. Some of the visual effects were excellent, whereas others were as fake as Don Cheadle's English accent. CGI was definitely overused, but the cinematography and soundtrack were decent. The film was still enjoyable overall.
If you lost hope watch this movie.
Easily one of my all-time favorite films. This is a story about why we tell stories, as well as about why spirituality forms such a timeless part of the human psyche.
Still feel ill when i think about this movie...especially how certain theological professions are handled about as intellectually as crayon scribbles in a holy book.

Very smart too being able to write the entire numerology of pi, 3.14 etc. That whole ship scene and him going overboard with the little boat into those humongous waves gave me crazy anxiety. Some of the scenes were very unrealistic which made everything seem very much fiction, which I guess this whole story is. That carnivorous island part was really interesting. The way the island was shaped like a human being that was laying down. The island was alive, like a breathing organism. The whole relationship between him and the tiger was interesting. All the hardships they went through. And that whole thing about the tiger not looking back to say goodbye before he went into the jungle, that stuck with me. It's kind of like not being able to say goodbye to the ones you loved or had some kind of meaningful relationship with. Philosophical in nature. This is a movie about faith, religion and the greater power of god. It's about love and pain. Very beautiful nature landscape imagery. Trippy and magical at times like the scene with all the jellyfish and the humpback whale. Even though the whole movie is practically CGI and looks pretty dated, it is an incredible feat what Ang Lee was able to pull off.

Movie Rating: 10/10

SPOILER ALERT! Summary: The movie starts in Canada where a Canadian writer visits an Indian boy named Piscine Patel, also known as Pi, and asks him to tell his epic survival story. The story begins in Pondicherry, India, where Pi's parents own a small family zoo. Pi is raised practicing Hinduism. Later in his life, he is introduced to Christianity and then Islam, and he starts to follow all three religions as "all he wants is to love God", no matter how he does it. When Pi is a teenager, his dad decides to sell the zoo and move to Canada. They go on a sea voyage with the animals that they are going to sell in Canada. One night, a heavy storm happens, and the ship begins to sink. He tries to find his family, but he gets thrown into a lifeboat by a crew member. The next morning, he finds himself in the boat with an injured zebra, a hyena, an orangutan named Orange Juice, and a Bengal tiger, hiding beneath the canvas of the boat, named Richard Parker. After some time, the hyena kills and eats the zebra and then Orange Juice. Finally, Richard Parker kills and eats the hyena. Pi is left on the boat alone with the Bengal tiger. Pi finds emergency food, water, a whistle, and a handbook for surviving at sea in the lifeboat. With all these supplies, Pi builds a floating device and attaches it to the boat so that he can keep a safe distance from the tiger. He then realizes that he must tame the tiger, or the tiger will eventually eat him. He blows the whistle and rocks the lifeboat enough to make the tiger seasick. Even though he cannot fully train him, he is able to make the tiger subdued by blowing the whistle. After crashing into a breaching whale, Pi loses almost all of his supplies. Due to starvation, Pi starts eating raw fish, even though he is vegetarian. After a few months at sea, both Pi and Richard Parker barely have any strengths. They find a weird floating island full of edible plants and freshwater. But soon, Pi discovers that the island is carnivorous. At night, the island emits acid and consumes everything on it. Pi also finds a human tooth inside of a plant. Then he stocks the lifeboat with supplies and leaves the island with Richard Parker. Eventually they reach the beach of Mexico. Richard Parker runs into the jungle and stops at the edge of the jungle. Pi hopes that the tiger will look back and acknowledge him, but he doesn't. Pi is brought to a local hospital. There, he is interviewed by two Japanese officials. He tells them this story which they find unbelievable to report. Pi then tells them a similar but much darker story. In this story, everything is the same except for one part. He shares the boat with his own mother, Gita, a sailor with a broken leg, and the ship's cook. After some time, they are worried about the limited supplies in the lifeboat, the cook kills the sailor and then Gita. Pi then kills the cook for self-defense purpose. Analysis: This movie talks about the fight to survive. As mentioned before, Pi believes all three religions. He has developed kindness towards all things and has learned morality from these religions. But when facing death and starvation, Pi has to abandon his own morality to survive. Animals in the first story all have a corresponding human character in the second story: Gita is the orangutan, the sailor is the zebra, the cook is the hyena, and the tiger is a projection of Pi himself. And I believe this illusion created by him actually helps him to survive the endless sea voyage after knowing that he has committed a horrible act, which is against his personal morals but is natural for tigers, without losing his sense of humanity. And seeing people as animals is much easier under those circumstances. Critique/Recommendation: The actor Suraj Sharma gives a marvelous performance in this movie. And director Lee did a great job on visual effects. It also leaves us a question: which story do you prefer? Are you a person that believes in things that make sense? Or are you a person that believes in miracles? You can have different interpretations of what "really" happened, and there is no right or wrong answer. I really enjoyed this movie and would definitely recommend this movie and I'll give it a 4.5 out of 5 stars.

With some convincing CGI, moments of great emotion, suspense, and fear, as well as some stellar performances that make you root for the characters, mixed all in with a uniquely crazy plot, Life of Pi is a brilliantly entertaining film for the masses.

review: After the disappointment that Age of Extinction was, my hopes from this franchise had fallen to zero. However, I still had one ray of hope - it couldn't be worse than that, right? The story is already bad, the characters are no longer interesting, the continuity doesn't matter anymore, and hey, just one more movie is left after which I'll get to watch the super-awesome Bumblebee, so let's just tolerate one more movie. And boy, was I wrong when I didn't take one more factor into account: At least the cinematography was good in all the previous movies. Here even that fails. The most distracting thing in this entire movie is the continuously changing aspect ratio. There's a very important rule in filmmaking, that your jump cuts should be so seamless that the audience shouldn't realise when the jump cut takes place. Look at Marvel movies. When Black Widow fights there are like a gazillion jump cuts in just one somersault. If that is supposed to be silently moving across the room, the jump cuts of The Last Knight are like dragging an almirah across the room hoping no one would notice. You can literally see the jump cuts happen! And speaking of jump cuts ruining the mood, whenever the jump cuts happen in the same scene it feels like it is a completely different scene. Like in the scene where they are in the elevator and they see the butler bot over there, it feels as if the scene outside the elevator is a completely different place. The lighting is also so bad, it doesn't even feel like there's continuity until the jump cut happens again and the camera goes back to Cade and company. Apart from that there is also a scene where Cade stops his car in front of the sheriff and when he's stopping the car there's a lot of dust. But when the jump cut happens the dust is all gone. And while he's still stopping his car his voice starts coming. Like, he isn't even moving his mouth and the words are coming out louder than the car's engine. Another time the ADR ruins the mood is when the butler bot is playing the piano when the story of the Transformers is being narrated. He is asked to stop playing... Twice! A bad joke is repeated twice in just fifteen seconds! Then of course there's the fight between Optimus Prime and Bumblebee, the legendary fight for which everyone came to watch it. Because the movie had been advertised by saying that Optimus Prime is the bad guy in this movie. And guess how their fight ends? Martha! No, not by saying those exact words, but something similar. Just as Optimus is about to stab Bumblebee, he says, "I'm Bumblebee. I'll lay my life before you!" And that changes Optimus Prime's mood. First of all, why did it change his mood? He's a robot not a human. Emotions can't alter his programming. And secondly how on earth did Bumblebee suddenly start speaking? It's not like his voice suddenly fixed. It was permanently damaged. It's kinda weird that in this movie the humans are not the bad part. In fact I really liked its starting, where they were showing Merlin take help from the dragon Transformer to win the battle. I also liked how those kids were collecting spare parts to survive. Even showing Optimus Prime on his planet looked so cool. The way it began I was really wondering why on earth this movie has such bad reviews. If the movie focused on either of the two things it could have been a great movie. I really wanted to like it, but the jump cuts were making me laugh even on the serious scenes. I'm sorry, Michael Bay. But I think you've ruined a good movie by hiring a bad cinematographer.

It's that kind of movie that would make you refuse to eat your popcorn even whilst watching it the first time over. Transformers 5 is a funny joke, but with a bad punchline But the funniest part is that I used to think of Transformers 2, 4 and 5 as the best Transformers movies. But I can see the clearer side.

review: The critics went out of their league to criticize this movie. But they fail to see this movie for what it is. A thoroughly entertaining and funny experience with absolute Bayhem! You can't analyze and think too hard on what you see. This is meant to be two and a half hour with amazing special effects, epic music and ridicolous moments. This movie looks so grand and epic on the big screen in cinema, thanks to Bay filming it almost entirely with IMAX 3-D cameras. After an very intriguing prologue set in medieval times with catapults casting fireballs and big armys clashing together in "Gladiator" style, we also see Stanley Tucci as drunk Merlin pleading with transformer knights. The crazy tone is set after the first 5 minutes. The movie is like the previous ones, hyperactive and fast paced. There are explosions and fighting, and very few quite character moments. But the few that are work well, especially the "father-daughter" set-up with Cade Yeager and Izabella. They have tough love but strong chemistry, and I wish we would see more of them together and more of Izabella, because she was the best actor in this movie. All the other well-known actors seem to know they are in a Transformers movie. They don't take it too seriously, it is all about acting over-the-top and bonkers. The ones that do that best is Anthony Hopkins with his hilarious robot butler "Cogman". I think simply they're presence made this movie the funniest out of the 5. The plot is very bloated and stuffed, altough the story is generic and similiar to the previous ones. It is all about finding Merlin's staff, that in Quintessa's hands will rebuild Cybertron and destroy Earth. Earth who is revealed to be Unicron, the ancient enemy of Cybertron. The talisman that Cade gets from a dying knight will lead to the staff. And cybertron is approaching earth rapidly, while also Megatron collaborates with the "TRF" who is the new rogue military force. And I haven't mentioned that Optimus Prime gets brainwashed by Quintessa and turns bad. So I could see why this is too much for someone, it was clearly an answer to "too much of everything" from the writer's room. But it worked for me. The middle act in London is the most crazy and ludicrous. The final act is an massive showdown of earth shattering preposterousness. An workable ending for the Bayformers, but then we get the stupid cliffhanger which should have been cut out. Personally I would've liked a more grounded movie with less subplots, who is more focused. We could follow the kids we meet at the beginning instead of Viviane and Cade troughout the movie and I would have liked more of Nemesis Prime. This movie clearly had a lot of talent and merits behind the screen, and although the movie is pretty forgettable and hated by many, I still found it to be worth watching. It captured a sense of escapism and if you want to experience a big-budget massive summer blockbuster that also is fun, this is the movie for you. Roll out!

SHOT. -camera movements without reason -cuts and framing that would be nice if it was a PARODY of an action movie and that would make anyone with eyes cringe. -random vignetting like they don't know how to use a fucking lens -no character development... no characters at all... -no reasoning behind the character's actions -awful pathetic attempts of "comedy" -lines that you can feel the actors hurt while delivering them... but on the bright side, if you don't understand what "having a motive" for everything in your scenes mean, every frame of this 2 hours and a half "film" is a perfect example of what not to do. the spectacle is the same as always and the only reason its not just half a star, a few things have improved since the previous ones which is not saying much, and the sexualisation of characters, even when it hasn't disappeared, its less prominent in this one. it is a scream of glory for the vfx artists but nothing beyond that, and i have to clarify that some scenes keep being nonsensical visual noise, and shortcuts in the transforming part of a movie called transformers leaves some things to desire in that area too, but some effect filled scenes were actually interesting.

review_date: Madagascar 2 Escape from mort is an important, seminal film. First off, the emotion wow. The themes of racism hit hard (where something like black kkklansmen did not). First off, the love triangle between gloria, moto moto and melman is striking and honest. When melman (swimmer) finds gloria making out with moto moto his heart is crushed. Oh and we can't forget about the penguins, who are back and just as epic as ever. The boss baby voices the villian, who steals a staff and manipulates the power hierarchy to become the Lion King. Alex finds his parents and has an emotional journey about identity, classism and family. Alex also can't recognise which Marty is the real one. Overall, an admitted jump in quality from the previous Madagascar.

Madagascar Escape 2 Africa is the follow up from its predecessor Madagascar and it doesn't quite it that mark. The film is very funny and the plot is fast paced but it just isn't as good as the brilliant original. The film contains great casting choices made by Leslee Feldman which stays the same as the first and has Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, David Schwimmer, Jada Pinkett Smith, Sacha Baron Cohen and Bernie Mac. I was shocked to see that Alec Baldwin was casted to star in this film. He played the villainous Makunga. The films plot is basic and continues on from where the first one left off, the animals trying to get back to New York. The Madagascar animals fly back to New York City, but crash-land on an African nature reserve, where they meet others of their own kind, and Alex especially discovers his royal heritage as prince of a lion pride. What i loved most about the plot is that it was fast paced so the film didn't dragged and was enjoyable without getting you the slightest bit of bored. What I hated about this film is that they was too many subplots going on about each main character at once, so you had to worry about more than one subplot instead of one so you could get a bit muddled with the films story. I know people are loving Moto Moto right now but I didn't like the films character. I know that I going to get lot of hate but I think that Moto Moto was just included in this film so they was able to add a story about Gloria's life in Africa. When the were looking for water nearer the end of the film you saw Moto Moto getting gold from underground but from then on Moto Moto was not mentioned for the rest of the feature so I was wondering, would ever happened to Moto Moto. Moto Moto isn't the only new character with that problem, most of the new characters which were introduced, also felt like they were just plunked into this film for the story to progress. The film doesn't suppress the humour like the first, but that doesn't mean that this film isn't funny, it is one of the funniest DreamWorks films ever made. I didn't noticed any plot holes but there most probably were plot holes. Nonetheless Madagascar Escape 2 Africa doesn't withhold the strengths of its predecessor but is still a very funny and re watchable film that I have seen countless times and it never gets old.

review: So there I was, browsing through the new Netflix streaming content and I came across, War of the Worlds: Goliath. With a user rating of 4 stars no less, so I figure, why not. I've always liked the H. G. Wells novel, and both the 1953 and 2005 movie adaptations, so surely a Dieselpunk/Steampunk inspired animated version of the classic text should at least be entertaining. Well, not so much. War of the Worlds: Goliath, is a sequel to the classic story, and catches up with humanity fifteen years after the Martians attacked Earth. Having reverse engineered the alien war machines, early 20th century Earth sees the human race utilizing some very advanced technology. They've also set up a global initiative to recruit the best soldiers from around the world to pilot super advanced battle tripods, and prepare for the inevitable return of the Martians. Despite the rich source material, and the really intriguing concept behind the sequel, War of the Worlds: Goliath ends up being surprisingly dull. The international cast of poorly developed characters, end up being silly racial stereotypes, and the production is littered with moments of cheesy contrived melodrama. The story isn't all that complicated, yet there's so much in here that didn't make any sense to me. Its only been fifteen years since the last Martian attack ended, and there's credible evidence that a second attack is imminent. So why is everyone talking about the start of World War One? Hardly makes sense right? The Martians nearly took the planet only fifteen years ago and are coming back for round two, but let's start a global conflict using all the cool new weapons we've got! I don't know about you, but if I was the leader of the Martians, I'd just sit back and let the human race do my work for me, and then swoop in near the end to take control. The way in which the battles were fought didn't make any sense either. Soldiers repeatedly attack Martians with regular guns, shooting regular bullets, which barely scratch the paint off the invading machines. But they keep doing it anyway, and that gets old really quickly. At one point bullets hitting the protective shell on a smaller alien walker don't hurt the machine at all, but in the next shot it's easily smashed by a soldier and his knife. What? There are plenty more moments like this, and each one sadly highlighted just how poorly developed this great story premise was. On the plus side though, I did enjoy the design of the alien walkers, and the battle tripods. While a lot of the action didn't make any logical sense, it was at least decently animated and the sound design and editing was nicely done. Movie Prep: There's plenty of action to go with the cheesy dialog, and at least the effects of the Martian heat ray are decently realized. I wouldn't recommend this movie for really young children. Best Format: It's a decent looking film so a regular DVD or streaming show on a nice big TV is good enough. Best Element: The design and animation of the Martian tripods. http://talkiegazette.com/war-of-the-worlds-goliath-2012/ http://facebook.com/talkiegazette http://twitter.com/talkiegazette

review: Based on the German fairy tale of "Rapunzel", this is Disney's 50th animated feature. The writing in this film is excellent! The changes they made to the source material make this movie work. The comedic writing is also on point and makes this movie one of the funniest in Disney canon. Zachary Levi also helps the comedic aspect with some well delivered lines. Casting Mandy Moore to voice Rapunzel also helps with the music aspect as well as some very memorable songs written by Alan Menken. The animation is also top notch and creates one of the most beautiful scenes ever put to film. I can't recommend this movie enough, a must watch!
Even in its acclaim, this is an underrated Disney classic, being a beautiful and heartwarming work of self-aware comedic genius that yet manages to capture the magic of their Renaissance films.

review_date: Tangled is one of those movies that over the years I tried and tried to watch over and over again and this summer I finally got around to finishing the final product. Tangled is the story Rapunzel where she lets down her hair and lets her evil mother come up in her tower and tell her how bad the world is when all she wants to do is see it for herself. This was the movie that pretty much kicked off Disney‚Äôs animation for the 20th century. A lot was riding on this film and it was actually a very big success. A lot of the people in the world debate between Frozen and Tangled, personally I like Frozen a lot more. There‚Äôs not a lot wrong with this film it just didn‚Äôt really connect with me on a level that I was hoping for. I think everything in this movie is very beautiful and the songs are really well done, but there‚Äôs just something missing and I don‚Äôt really know what it is.

This Movie is great when its written and then half the time its tons of info then action. The most Underrated Bond of Craig's carrier.

A massive disappointment, especially when considering that it was a direct sequel to the much superior "Casino Royale." The action is nauseating, the story is convoluted, and the entire film feels much more serious than it should, taking out the charm of the original and swapping it with a much more gritty James Bond. The title sequence is also a large let-down in comparison to others.

Quantum of Solace is a big drop off from Craig's first outing. Although, there are some strong action scenes, the story is unnecessarily convoluted, while 007 comes off on the sulky side. Not much solace here.

Quantum of Solace is a watchable, if forgettable, entry in the 007 series. It pales in comparison to the dynamite opening act of Casino Royale, but this movie does work best as a direct follow up to that film. It picks up immediately where CR left off- Craig is still fantastic as Bond- this time playing him as a man wounded by betrayal and dead set on vengeance. The story is pretty messy, it is often unclear what is happening and why. Amidst the so-so writing however- the action is still quite solid. This is a decent action film that doesn't leave a strong impression. As a Bond movie- it is solid. This might be Craig's weakest 007 entry, and I still like it about as much as Goldeneye- Brosnan's strongest 007 entry.

Ah yes, The Bourne Supremacy one. Considering this was written during the writers strike, the writing is not that bad. It even made me laugh a few times. The use of S.P.E.C.T.R.E. without legally having the rights yet was clever and intimidating. This has probably top 5 costume designs in the entire franchise, with is a huge complement because in that regard, it's almost always A+. The Bond girl is great too. Bond himself is no nonsense and Craig is giving the most no nonsense performance of his entire run here. Love it. On the other hand the Villain is a short, slimy, nothing of a frog that no one remembers. I didn't even notice he had a henchman until way past halfway through and they pretty much are the worst if not easily top 5 worst villain and henchman in the series. The villain's lair is the most bland and boring lair ever and the location it's in is even worse. There are other villainous lairs in the dessert but the dessert landscape even looks better in those other entries. The hair stylist is not doing Craig any favours. Having the gunbarrel at the end instead the beginning is a colossal sin. It gets minus half a star just for that alone. I don't care what the reason is, that this film directly follows Casino Royale. That is not an excuse. The cinematography is filtered with a disgusting sepia, but like a some kind of night time version making it even worse. There is also some weird awkward CGI use. Even with all those negatives though, I would still give it 4 stars. The editing/blocking drops this entire score down very much. Not a single shot is held long enough for me to see what is going on in relation to to their surrounding geography. The blocking in tandem makes it even harder to follow. Nothing is in frame that needs to be in frame and the shots don't track from the last shot to the next. There is supposed to be a consistent tracking focal point between shots to help guide your eye to the next shot. There is a technical term for this that I did learn in film school that I forgot now and I am too lazy to check my notes. Also, Google had no idea what the heck I was talking about after quickly checking. In addition, the shaky cam is out of control. The Bourne films and Casino Royale (2006) had shaky cam and none of those gave me the sensation of car sickness like this did. All a shame because the action action choreography is this is great or at least I think it might be great. I don't know because I just literally cannot tell what's going and not just in the action scenes either. There are more than a few regular conversation that are hard to follow because of abrupt, out of nowhere cutaways.

Contrary to all of the pompous reviewers and snobbish Bond aficionados, I found this installment in the Bond franchise to be entertaining because of its divergence from the typical Bond witticisms, gadgets and other tired cliches.
Pretty damn fun and better than average villain.

Okay, it can't keep up with Casino Royal, but still, I don't think it's quite as bad as many think. I've certainly watched it four times now, and it's getting better and better for me. It's a good sequel to Casino Royal, and you can see his evolution as a person. What you must never forget is that the script was never finished, because back then in the US the screenwriters went on strike.

Quantum of Solace gets a bad rap for some dodgy editing, but the film is a blast from beginning to end. It manages to tell a compelling and timely story that examines both the political and social dimensions of Bond in a way few films in this franchise have. It's a revenge story that thinks very little of revenge and questions the violence inflicted by its weary hero. Highly underrated.

Quantum of Solace is a consequential mess that has very little going for it. The narrative structure of the film is unnecessarily complex. A lot of the movie uses random characters left and right without actually fleshing them out. Of course, the characters' goals are legit and fulfilled by the end, but everything else is quite half-baked. For instance, Gemma Arterton's Strawberry Fields does absolutely nothing in the film besides being a wannabe Bond Girl. This equivalent happens to other characters in the movie. The movie goes through so many characters that it is hard to formulate a strong connection among them. Yes, the script was affected by the 2007-2008 Writers Guild of America strike. Yet, it does not make sense how the plot could get extremely confusing with worthless information. The editing is a colossal mess in this film. The unnecessary cuts used in the action scenes are atrocious and make the editors' job look sloppy. The editing also influences the way the action sequences present themselves, as it is hard to see the scene's climax when there are more than twenty cuts in just ten seconds of that single scene. Some sequences also go on for way too long, generating a monotony feel when watching the film. The cast, like Casino Royale, is probably the most enjoyable part of Quantum of Solace. Daniel Craig shines in the lead role, and his performance was solid compared to the first film. Olga Kurylenko was great in this film by carrying a lot of prominent chemistry with Craig. Kurylenko also understood how to command emotions throughout the stunts, showing that she could handle more action flicks in her career. Despite her character flaws, Gemma Arterton is satisfactory in the small role she has in the film. In a similar boat, Giancarlo Giannini makes an impact in the cast despite his small role in the movie. Finally, just like in this film's predecessor, Jeffrey Wright and Judi Dench both steal the scenes they are in and are one of the movie's highlights. When accumulating some positives of Quantum of Solace, the score comes to mind. David Arnold does a more suitable job here than before, as it felt more pertinent to the film. The score also had more traditional spy elements that supported what was on screen. The production and set design are also pretty solid, with very few flaws in those departments. Although, the disastrous editing did make it hard to appreciate it at times. Overall, Quantum of Solace struggles to maintain its identity throughout the film, making it feel like a jumble of madness. Even though there are some luminous aspects like the cast, the score, and the production design, the inadequate script and the harsh editing bring the film down significantly. This is widely regarded as the worst Craig Bond film to date, and I have to agree. (At the time of writing this, No Time to Die has not come out, but I doubt my opinion will change.) The filmmaking style, with all the choppy editing, poor CGI, and shaky-cam action, is extremely amateurish and so disappointing after the high bar set by Casino Royale. Speaking of which, this feels more like a lazy, half-assed epilogue to that superior movie than a coherent story in and of itself. Yes the WGA strike was going at the time, and Craig himself did some rewrites, but nobody looks like they're having fun here...especially him. To make matters worse, the villain here is just so lame and forgettable, like so much of this movie. Sure, there are worse ways to spend a rainy Saturday afternoon...but there are FAR better.

Both the villain and the new Bond girls return to being easily forgettable cliches. Despite boasting the shortest runtime of the entire franchise, I couldn't wait for this unexpectedly poor sequel to reach its underwhelming ending. A stain that the next installment would fortunately clean‚Ä¶"

[‚≠êÔ∏è63%] Following the success of Casino Royale (2006), Quantum of Solace (2008) is instantly a disappointment thanks to its sloppy writing and irritating editing, right from the start that is apparent when every action scene felt like it is in fast-forward given the amount of cuts in a short amount of time. Daniel Craig continues to be a good James Bond, however all of the other elements let him down, from the boring plot and poor villain. As it is entering that modern version of the character, it abandons 007's iconic gadgets which make this entry feel like just your average spy movie rather than a James Bond one

Having so successfully carved out a new James Bond in Casino Royale, the follow up Quantum of Solace is a surprising misfire. The storyline is weak, as is the creepy Bond villain Dominic Greene, played by Mathieu Amalric. The pace of the movie is off, as it stumbles through a cumbersome script and overly complex storyline, which may take a few viewings to make sense. There are scenes that are out of place in what is supposed to be a reimagined Bond universe, like the scene where Bond and Camille skydive from their crippled plane, with only Camille wearing a parachute, the join in the air and pull the chute moments before crashing into the ground, landing hard without so much as a a broken bone or sprained ankle. Given Casino Royale was trying to create a much more realistic Bond, this scene is anything but realistic. This movie also resorted to the old "and now Bond blows up the villain's lair" scene at the movie's climax, which is also a let-down. There are some good bits, like the exhilarating car chase scene in the opening sequence, but this is not enough to make up for its flaws. Quantum of Solace is still a watchable Bond film, but not likely to become a Bond clsssic.

Any other James Bond film seen on a 'worst films' list would naturally be blasphemous, but Quantum Of Solace is dreadful. Admittedly badly hampered by the writers strike, this doesn't excuse thrashing out a script that my two year old daughter could improve upon whilst she slept. Dominic Greene wants to buy some land in the desert and prevent some people getting some water or something. I wrote my university dissertation on James Bond, that's how much I love it, but this is beyond the pale, enormously aided in its sprint to the executioners block by a truly atrocious theme from the usually reliable Jack White and Alicia Keys.
The action scenes are as good as any bond scenes...but as a follow up to casino royale it highlights just how good that film was...the villain is poor and weak in this for me...

Quantum of Solace is not that bad tbh. Honestly, watching the bland Spectre made me appreciate this more. Daniel Craig once again kills it as Bond and I like how he gets over the death of Vesper especially with the last scene and the movie does a decent job showing his desire of revenge with the brutal, violent action and dark tone. M is a scene stealer again, the score is great and I like how Camille has the same motivations as Bond and she has a pretty tragic backstory and it's nice having a bond girl that's not after Bond. Some of the action is also cool like the boat scene and plane scene and it's a fast paced movie with a short runtime so entertaining. I also appreciate the brutalness and violence of this movie. Seeing Mathis back as an innocent person was also sweet and on paper, the villain is interesting. Having this secret organization no one is really cool. It also has some great locations and that final battle with the house burning, reminding Camille of the day her parents died was cool visual storytelling. But it's filled with some truly monstrous editing. 70% of the action is filled with obnoxious editing: shaky cam, fast cuts, close ups so it's so hard to get invested in the otherwise well-choreographed action (you can clearly see the great stunt work) and there's too much action. There's like 3 action scenes in the first 30 minutes alone and I'm pretty sure this movie was done to make up for the lack of plot. To be fair, the film was written during the writer strike but even still, this movie's plot is incoherent, confusing and not that interesting and it's filled with a bland villain with no charisma. The actor is trying his best but the villain is not threatening and I don't care for him, which is a shame. The movie is way too short as well. At 106 minutes, there's not enough time to develop a seemingly interesting plot or characters. Even Bond's revenge story feels like it's taking the back seat. It's so rushed and the terrible editing doesn't help. I don't feel any stakes or tension. I'd much rather watch this over Spectre but even still, this is a disappointment. Need to rewatch Casino Royale honestly. (C-)

review: Okay so as the common man might think I am being too harsh on my personal rating, the true fan will understand. And what really made up my mind about it is...well...because I watched MIB 3 right before International. Aside from the soundtrack and the suit...it carries nothing from the previous movies. The third was a perfect blend of what made people like the first, with better special effects, clockwork humor and storytelling, and a real tour de force with the addition of Josh Brolin as young agent K. The end twist wraps up the trilogy wonderfully. You see the heart and soul of Men in Black is the chemistry between two agents fighting the absurd. I too was shocked to see a woman in black in the third, but it didn't shadowed the entire movie. I don't know why they tried to put a feminin touch to the franchise root, as I'll never understand why they did the same with Ghostbusters, but the issue here is not what they've tried, as bold as it may looks at first sight, but rather what they've accomplished : matching a Hollywood star with a rising one...and failed to make them enjoy the ride. The story is never gripping, the action is non inspiring, the drama is inexistant, and the stars were aligned for a bad omen in a science-fiction that doesn't know how to reinvent itself. Perhaps they should've made a MIB 4...because it doesn't feel international...it feels irrational.

review: Visually stunning and absolutely slathered in color, The Croods: A New Age might as well be James Cameron's Avatar in terms of its animation quality. And you don't even need the 3D glasses! The film is stuffed with delicious colors that shine and shimmer, making it impossible to want to look away. Luckily, the animators were smart enough to balance out the richness of those bright, juicy colors with plenty of more earthy, arid color climate to keep the eyes from exploding from oversaturation. Once again, we are treated to the familiar voices of Nic Cage, Emma Stone, Ryan Reynolds, and the late Cloris Leachman, whose character is given a monumentally different treatment this second time around. Two newcomer voices, Leslie Mann and Peter Dinklage join the cast, but unfortunately, there's nothing all that special about their inclusion to this second installment. Luckily however, with their inclusion, comes new character dynamics and relationships. These are juggled with relative ease, which is impressive considering that the pace of the film is blink-and-you'll-miss-it all throughout. Sadly, many of the animal hybrids that joined the Croods at the coda of the original film have been discarded with no explanation (likely because they were killed, given that death is frequently mentioned as lurking around every corner out in the wasteland areas); however, new ones are introduced and they are just as lovable, if not more so than the original cast of fictional creatures. The story itself brings nothing new to the table as far as its own message is concerned. These days, it's increasingly difficult to present the message of "don't judge people who are different than you" in a new way, no matter what type of cinematic format or genre you include it in. This is a kids' movie at the end of the day, so you have to take its message at face value. Where this sequel far outperforms its predecessor is in the comedy. There are a number of laugh-out-loud moments from the beginning to literally the last moment. Some laughs are for the kids; some, are for the kids-at-heart, but a handful of them are universally funny, and if you're not laughing during this movie, might I suggest you see a doctor to ensure you aren't suffering from some form of depression? Between the laughter and the outright joyride that is the 3rd act, kids will likely be left with a sort of sugar rush, and the adults should, at the very least, have their endorphin count slightly increased. The Croods 2 isn't revolutionary, but it will surely leave moviegoers young and old looking forward to another chapter. And considering they capped off the film with a Tenacious D cover of The Partridge Family's "I Think I Love You," we can only hope that Jack Black will return to Dreamworks Animation's recording booth for the next time we check in on our neighbors, The Croods.

review: The Croods: A New Age doesn't live up to the first film and feels like a downgrade. The first film was such a delight with lots of heart and fun. The sequel feels like a watered-down version of the first with a lot more jokes that diminish the story. A lot of that comes down to the story which isn't that great. The story feels so bland with little to no substance. Some of the plot points are actually a bit laughable and just aren't that great. The plot points also feel borderline cliche and don't really feel all that original. There are even plot points that were reused from the first film. Grug's whole character arc in this film is the same one as the first film. There is no change whatsoever that leads the film to feel so uninspired. There are some great messages like girl power and acceptance, but they either make it too in your face or too discreet. There isn't a good balance of ideas around the film. A lot of that has to do with the pacing which is just so bad. This movie is so fast and doesn't take the time to flesh out ideas. Each scene is gone through so fast that it doesn't feel like the characters are becoming better or worse. Speaking of the characters, they are really poorly handled in this film. A lot of the characters feel half-baked with nothing special about them. The film focuses too much on Grug and Phil that the other character arcs feel washed down with no substance to them. Yes, the film is entertaining, but a movie needs to tell a good story with good characters at the same time which this film doesn't do. What didn't disappoint was the animation. The animation is such a step-up from the first film and really makes all the creative, visual ideas look so amazing. The Bettermans' land is just so vibrant and has so many different colors filling up the screen. I do wish that the character designs stayed a little bit closer to the original character designs from the first movie just because it was a little hard to adjust seeing how features were changed to fit the new animation. However, once getting used to that, the animation just shines throughout the movie. I once again loved the voice cast. Emma Stone and Ryan Reynolds really knock it out of the park and know how to make their characters feel unique. Nicolas Cage did a great job despite his character being severely flawed. Catherine Keener was also a delight to hear and her performance of Ugga was just as great as the first film. Kelly Marie Tran was such a lovely addition to the cast. She too made the character her own. It wasn't "Kelly Marie Tran voicing a teenage girl". It was Kelly Marie Tran making Dawn a very unique and special character. Peter Dinklage and Leslie Mann were also spectacular in this. Something Dreamworks does the best at is putting together an amazing voice cast which I think The Croods franchise shows the best. Overall, The Croods: A New Age is a step-down from its predecessor. It never feels like anything special like the first film. The humor really takes over this film which is very sad to see. With very little support from the script department, the film relies heavily on its amazing voice cast and breathtaking animation. When you take those two positives away, you get just a big ball of undeveloped fluff. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

review: I'm always skeptical of sequels. Very few of them measure up to their predecessors. But this movie was just as much fun and just as visually stunning as the first Croods movie. My nine-year-old daughter laughed so hard that we had to pause the playback to wait for her to catch her breath two or three times during the film. And she's pretty squarely in the film's target demographic. There's plenty for adults to enjoy as well, with sly satirical jokes peppering the script in the manner that has become the hallmark of Dreamworks Animation, and there is some wacky fun to be had in the closing sequences (no spoilers here). First-time feature director Joel Crawford does a great job of putting it all together. I look forward to seeing more from him in the future. There are a lot of movies aimed at kids out there. You could do a lot worse than this one.

review: To be honest, I only saw the original "Croods" one time. In that viewing, I thought it was a visually pleasing and cute movie but I really didn't remember it much. I decided to check out this sequel since in general I like DreamWorks animation and think the first movie is one of the more solid entries. This movie has some great visuals and the characters are a lot of fun to watch. However, this is one of those movies that is clearly geared for younger audiences. I don't think it is a bad movie for adults, but it isn't one of those movies that all ages will enjoy at the same level. I did like the progression of the story and thought as far as animated sequels, this one was pretty okay, and at the very least, kids will have a blast with it.

review: Take the template from the wildly funny and successful The Hangover, move the locale to exotic Bangkok, recreate the same events with some minor modifications (replace tiger with monkey, replace trunk of car with freezer, replace roof of hotel with elevator and so on) and you have The Hangover Part II. It's undeniable that the sequel has some laughs, but they tend to be few and far between. In addition, the events in this version are even more improbable than the original and it tends to have an uglier and nastier vibe than it did the first time around. Phil (Bradley Cooper) is meaner, Alan (Zach Galifianakis) is more obtuse, Stu (Ed Helms) is more hysterical, and Doug (Justin Bartha) is more invisible. Truthfully, it'd probably be time better spent watching the original a second time than to waste time on the sequel.

review: Today I am going to review The Hangover Trilogy. I am reviewing all the three films together because the series has now become quite old and I think no one would read full page reviews of each movie. But, if you request I would write a detailed review for each movie too. The series revolves around 4 friends, Philip(Bradley Cooper), Stu(Ed Helms), Alan ( Zach Galifianakis) and Doug ( Justin Bartha) and one more interesting, a recurring character, Chow (Ken Jeong), who is an international criminal but besides that, he is very funky. In part two, the four friends "the wolfpack" travel to Thailand for Stu's wedding. But things take a roll towards the previous chapter and this time Stu's future brother in law goes missing. This film is also very entertaining and I hope you will enjoy their second hangover ( I wouldn't reveal the destination). The film is equally good and well made. I find no discrepancies from the side of filmmakers, but still, you will enjoy the first part more as the same theme is being re-used here and you know that if the theme is re-used each time successively then it loses its very own essence and the perceived satisfaction decreases. But still, I give a big thumbs up to this film too.

review_date: When you create a comedy sequel, I understand it can be difficult to figure out how to recapture the magic. But if the only solution you can come up with is to do the same thing again (but bigger and more extreme) then perhaps you should just avoid trying. Sadly, this is the case with The Hangover Part II. This movie is so blatantly trying to recreate the first film that the characters keep saying things like ‚ÄúOh no, it happened again!‚Äù Acknowledging your lazy idea is not good enough to excuse it. What made that first film good is completely gone in this one, and every attempt at a joke fell completely flat. The first film was kind of clever in the way it slowly laid out the breadcrumbs that would reveal the next thing that happened. It was like solving an elaborate mystery, and that kind of storyline is intriguing to me. In The Hangover, they were able to retrace their steps in a logical fashion and it felt like you could almost watch the movie in reverse and see the events of the previous night step by step. The Hangover Part II wasn‚Äôt thought out that well, and has them find random clues by chance without any logical reason, just to keep the story going. The first Hangover movie found a way to win me over so that I actually liked the characters despite their irresponsible behavior. The Hangover Part II was never able to pull that off, so I just ended up being annoyed by them. When you make this mistake once it can be a funny story, but twice and it‚Äôs a real problem. I also hate that movies like this demand that the characters maintain a bond with people who are clearly insane, like Zach Galifianakis‚Äôs character, despite the fact that every moment around this person brings them frustration and difficulty. The biggest sticking point of the film is that Ed Helms‚Äôs character is supposed to be getting married this time, and he‚Äôs worried that the bride‚Äôs family will not approve. Then they do absolutely nothing to resolve that story in a satisfying way. I don‚Äôt care how much he stands up for himself, when this idiot shows up late for his own wedding (with the bride‚Äôs brother missing a finger, a new face tattoo, and after having an affair with a transgender person) the bride herself should kill the man. The Hangover Part II is an all-around failure, and even fans of the first should avoid this sequel like the plague.

review: Marvel Animation√¢??s unique √¢??2-D wrap√¢?? animation style where the standard animation is scanned into a computer for added weight and facial expressions. It√¢??s still a serious work in progress. At times, the effect looks more realistic than a simple cartoon, but all too often the herky-jerky animation is distracting as the character movement resembles mid-90s CGI cartoons. And the character lip synching is the animation√¢??s most glaring flaw. It looks like the character√¢??s mouths were pasted on in post-production. That√¢??s great for a comedy sketch, but not for a project meant to be taken somewhat seriously.
