review: Returning to the cool style of "Iron Man & Hulk," this latest Heroes United partner-up is typically good with the unique animation that proved itself to be a good way of animating a story; and the Captain America-style action that paints the film's atmosphere. What's also fun was the reused music cues and themes from the previous Marvel animated productions and even the MCU (Marvel Cinematic Universe - Phase 1) films. However there are only a few weaknesses within that could've went more. And the fact that both films with the animation, length, recycled soundtracks, and starring voice actors respectively from the current animated series seems that these films were cheap with a nice value of entertainment as the results. (B+) (Full review coming soon)

review_date: Will smith (and his dog) is the Last man on Earth! In a mix between Forrest Gump, and Several Zombie movies, Will Smith is a Military Scientist who is by himself in New York, after an airborne virus infects the people of earth and changes them into monsters. The movie itself could have been better, But the ending itself made sense. (The alternate ending is also good but it‚Äôs kinda weird)
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

Go watch the Omega Man - it's the same story but grittier and works better in the 70s with that bare, bleached out 70s look and real actors. Or even Vincent Price being depressed. Smith works it and has the muscles and the dog, which we get to like, and the empty streets work well. Unfortunately, my 'survivors' are just, well... very CGI and slightly silly.

Never have I anticipated the release of a movie as I had this one and come away so disappointed. When I heard there was a dog in the picture, I didn't expect it to be directing the movie and this is on dogs dinner. The script is not bad, Will Smith puts in a fantastic performance, you really do believe this man is the last man on earth, who had seen his family, his country and the world die in a terrible plague. Sadly the Director employed cartoonish CGI rather than user actors as the night seeking mutants. Even when Smith is supposedly hunting deer in his sports card through the empty streets it looks phony. The night seekers rather than being scary looked stupid and completely unbelievable. These are people who have supposed to have been turned into rapid mutants unable to bare the sunlight after a miracle cancer cure turns into an epidemic. Nope not these mutants they tear walls apart with their bare hands, climb on ceilings. Richard Matheson's story was problematic in the first place, when you read it, it seems once he has come up with the vampire idea he cant explain it. In the previous and best version, Charlton Heston battles against very believable mutants, who while vengeful and murderous are still sick people doomed to die of plague following germ warfare. The original film version stuck closest to the novel and would have been fine apart from a hopelessly miscast Vincent Price, whos camp delivery and Italian co-stars, weakened the movie. It says a lot that the additional features in the DVD release of I am Legend are far better than the main feature. I feel sorry for Smith and the other cast members who all did very well indeed. Even the initial shots of the deserted animal infested city were good, but the flashbacks to the unfolding disaster were badly shot, so you never really see the victims bleeding out as they fall sick with the virus. The helicopter crash scene was fairly well done but not as powerful as the same scene in the Charlton Heston version, where his pilot, suddenly falls unconcious from plague. Once you see the mutants in Will Smith version you just know you wish you hadnt walked into that movie theatre. I don't know what it is about this story but no one can get it right. Boris Segal almost managed it, but not quite. That though is for another review.

A good performance by Will Smith, but overall a fairly standard zombie apocalypse film. If only the original cut had made it, rather than this altered version, it would've stood out more. But, of course, the studio didn't like the more unique version that has an actual theme and idea behind it, and instead strong armed the film into being the more standard presentation that it became.

It's a great movie that dives into an apocalypse with a man trying to stay alive as well as stay sane. It does a good job portraying just how alone he is and how he copes with that is what makes him likeable, what makes him human. Even the small things matter in creating a character, and I think this movie is underrated for it.

This film is of superior quality when it comes to others like it. The dramatic tone of the story is eased in a light manner by adding some occasional humor. The cinematography of the film is quite stunning, the VFX are adequate, and Will Smiths performance is among his better ones. The only negative I really have for this film is how often they showed the infected. I feel that the movie would have been more terrifying if we didn't know what they looked like or at least not until the end.

This is outrageously stupid. But this is a movie for an average gamer, and an average gamer doesn't think critically. Thirdly, the plot is a giant cliche without any twists whatsoever, like, woah, the girl the protagonist falls in love with turns out to be a beauty in real-life, what a surprise, oh, and she has a scar that is hardly noticeable, but is there to show how the protagonist doesn't care about her looks.

I have teenage nephews that have never seen or heard of "Aliens", "Robocop" or "The Iron Giant". Some of my younger colleagues have never heard of "Laurel and Hardy" or "Johnny Weissmuller". So watching young adults from our 2045 future using detailed references of 80's pop culture like "Buckaroo Banzai", "The Shining" and the pulse rifle used in "Aliens" made this movie implausible. The CGI was at times overwhelming and cluttered like some one puked fluorescent candy colored slurpy on my screen. Director Steven Spielberg should remember the days of his mechanical shark, when he ingeniously did less to deliver more.

In this Pixar film, two monsters named Mike and Sully must protect a young human girl from an evil plot. In typical Pixar fashion they really up their game in the animation department with each film. In this movie you can see their improvement in the textures, specifically Sully's hair and their snow animation. The story here is great and the relationship between Sully and Boo, the young human girl, is the heart of the film. Randell, the antagonist, is voiced well by Steve Buscemi and is a threatening presence throughout the film. The very last scene of the movie always leaves me with the warm-fuzzies. Highly recommend you check this movie out!

For 2001: PIXAR's fourth animated entry continued to prove the studio's passion for storytelling resonating with audiences 'Monsters Inc' asks the question what if monsters were actually real and hid in our closets, not only that but actually lived in their own world working for a living? Actors Billy Crystal and John Goodman play Sully and Mike, two best friends who work at a company called Monsters, Inc that specializes in collecting human children's screams to turn into clean dependable energy But the days are getting tougher with kids getting harder to scare and a scare shortage might be on the rise Sully is the top scarer competing with rival Randall Mike has a girlfriend Celia and the company is run by Mr. Waternoose Things change big time when a little human girl named Boo stumbles into the monster world thereby putting Sully and Mike in a bit of a pickle Moreover all monsters are lead to believe that a single touch from a human child is toxic But Boo bonds with Mike and Sully while at the same time they try to keep her avoid getting caught in a darker conspiracy PIXAR does it again with top-notch computer graphics, wonderful voicework, a really creative setup, nice monster designs being very distinguished, funny moments, and plenty of emotional ones too Sully and Mike are the best kind of duo buddies, Boo is so adorable tugging at the heartstrings, and the writers have the monsters fear something not from their world they don't quite understand A funny twist of us being scared of monsters but having them be scared of us in return I remember seeing it in the Adirondacks with my sisters and we were enamored The movie was another hit making over $800 million A perfect mix of pathos, humor, adventure, and heartbreak I like Jennifer Tilly as Celia and Steve Buscemi as Randall Im really glad too they put the movie as a level in Kingdom Hearts 3 20 years later and the movie still leaves a big impact on our culture as well as animation fans even spawning a prequel, video games, and a recent Disney + tv series 'Monsters Inc' is one of the earliest examples of children's entertainment that works telling a human story with non-human characters at the helm

My first ever exposure to Monsters, Inc. was when we had gone to McDonald's and I got a Mike Wazowski toy. I was really scared of it, and my sister used to often scare me with it. Little did I know that Mike is supposed to be the comic relief of the movie. Later on I saw the trailer, and eventually the whole movie. And now I can say with a guarantee that Monsters Inc is one of the better Disney movies. Sure there are some things I didn't like (which I will talk about later) but other than those things, this is absolutely perfect. One thing I really like about Pixar is that they always take one thing we like from our lives and then expand it into a full blown story. You play with toys? There's Toy Story. You like fishes and the ocean? There's Finding Nemo. You like cars? There's...well, Cars. So similarly over here we were all afraid of monsters coming into our rooms when we were sleeping alone as kids, and that's what this movie is based on. Unlike the conventional monsters who want to kill us, these monsters are working for a power company who just use children's screams for powering up their world. The story revolves around Sullivan and his best friend Mike Wazowski, who work at Monsters, Inc. Sully is a professional scarer while Mike collects the screams from the children. However, there is one rule that the monsters must abide by - children should not learn about their world otherwise they will no longer be scared and the monster world will run out of energy. Things go down very badly when Mike and Sully find out that Sully accidentally brought a little girl named Boo back to their world. Meanwhile Randall, the second best scarer and Sully's rival, is making a scream extractor which will help him extract the most screams and make him the best employee. The movie is twenty years old and still the world shown here is very dynamic even by today's standards. The third act where Sully, Mike, Boo and Randall are jumping from one door to another was very cool. The animation is also very good, especially the fact that every single hair on Sully's body is distinguishable, and all the pores on Randall's body can be seen. The comic timing is also great, like the part where Randall says, "Say hello to my scream extractor!" and Mike immediately says "Hello.". And also the part where Sully thinks Boo got crushed so he faints just as the emotional music starts playing. Now like I said, there are a couple of things I didn't like in this movie, which is what stopped me from giving it a perfect score. First of all I really liked Randall. He was my favourite character in the whole movie. He looks cool, his superpowers are admirable and he's stronger than he looks. But he still loses to humans. First with Boo, who is literally a child who can't even speak. And then by grown humans who beat him with a broom in the end. It would have been better if he got stuck in the middle of nowhere like he made Sully and Mike do so. And the second thing is the part where they are in Nepal. That was boring to say the least. Monsters, Inc. is one of those movies that can be enjoyed by both children and adults. It is very rare for a Disney movie to be that way nowadays, so it can be revisited back even today. Like I said, its animation has aged very well, which is why it is so much fun to watch it without feeling something is off. And it has a sequel too, something it took me too long to learn about. I really liked it compared to most movies Disney has been making nowadays.

Man, Pixar kicked this century off with a bang! Also, expect a lot of repeated points from the Toy Story 2 review until probably Cars. So yeah, I just don't feel like spelling it out, but I am. This is movie is basically perfect in ever way possible. Going off the Toy Story 2 review, this has the comedy down, the great characters, and the emotion. Man does this movie have emotion! However, this movie starts the trend of the ending being the most emotional moment of the movie. Of course, this is one of the best examples of that. If I really had to find something to complain about (just because it's a movie review and you have to talk about something negative), it's that Mike can be a little bit too much of a jerk sometimes, but he's really funny, so he can get away with it. He's definitely less annoying then someone like Mr Potato Head in the first Toy Story, far from it. So yeah, if you haven't seen this one, shame on you! Go to Disney+ and watch it now! It's currently the best Pixar movie I have reviewed so far, and it probably is one of the best ones Pixar has ever made!

Billy Crystal's performance just give so much energy to the character. However the one problem that I have with the movie is the villain Randal. I just didn't find him that interesting. However even though he's not as interesting to me he does provide some funny moments as well. However with all that being said there is a twist villain that is much better and can be really interesting for the movie. Monsters, Inc was really fun and enjoyable to watch, with fun characters and with a surprisingly engaging story. 9/10

A Middle Eastern country falls into civil war. (Although this is filmed in Morocco and boy, does it look like Morocco.) A SEAL team is sent in to evacuate Chinese civilians out of the country. There's also a secondary storyline involving terrorists trying to get hold of radioactive material. This movie borrows so much from other movies. It starts with Captain Phillips, continues with Black Hawk Down, and throws in American Sniper and Hurt Locker for good measure. It does move, I will give it that. The second half of the film is nothing but explosions.

This film is a mess. It varies in quality between B Movie and top notch effects, as if several scenes were tacked on at the end of filming when the budget was spent. The director attempts to distract the viewer from the absence of any sense of realism in the strategy of the action by making it as chaotic as possible, with the only pauses in the action inserted almost nonsensically in order to throw a bit of dramatic acting in the mix. The scenes change so rapidly that it can be confusing to follow just whom is supposed to be where or what the dangers are, and at times it becomes a Call of Duty simulation as the main antagonists put James Bond to shame in terms of their ability to avoid bullets... until it's time to wrap up the plot in which case all of a sudden the stubborn Chinese soldiers become human again. It feels like a film that started out with a big budget and high expectations but then was pushed out to salvage whatever funds were thrown at it. It feels like it needs another few months on the cutting room floor.

With the support of government, the boats and the soldiers are so good looking. However, when the movie is too full of action and shooting, you will clear up your memory when step out of cinema. One of the best action war genre films. Despite the jingoism and patriotic intent to save lives not only Chinese but Africans as well as foreigners, actions in the films bridges the understanding of those involved in operations tend to be more understanding about the nature of soldiering. The constant manner of visions of death, decapitations, dangerously near dying, etc, depicts the gruesome images conflict operations can become. Survivability is only via aggressive and offensive participation to stay alive and fear is the grim reaper's calling. When Dante Lam directed Operation Mekong, the actions are less tragic but still Dante loved to embrace that 'brave encouragement' to fight on in the face of facing multiple deathly threats and firepower. This film will be good for China, as the film will encourage young Chinese that China can do good in the world if its force is used in the right way.

Nothing remotely accurate about the 2015 Yemeni civil war or the evacuation of foreigners in this movie. Everything you see is highly exaggerated and bluffed. In reality the evacuation went smoothly without problems and it is as boring as it sounds. This is a great movie by itself and as a fictional movie. The fact that Dante Lam and the PLA tries to pass this off as a biographical war drama movie is the reason I'm giving this movie only 2.5 stars.

a very good film. There was a tacked-on scene at the end that was outright propaganda, but everything else was there to serve the story. Interesting characters and relationships (for an ensemble). I read reviews saying there was no character development and wonder if that perception is just unconscious racism - all chinese look alike. i'm not asian but i got a sense of most of the main characters as individuals, and mourned the losses along the way. Physical effects were generally high-quality, including heaps of graphic shots of injuries and bodies (you have been warned) and an isis-style beheading (it does not cut away). again though, this stuff is not gratuitous and serves the theme of self-sacrifice. admittedly some of the computer effects were second-rate - cgi seems to be the 'jet engine' of chinese cinema.

review: I have to say this is a movie that does not deserve the harsh ratings many people give it. It is more than just a twilight clone, and in fact a movie I consider to be far superior to any twilight movie in my honest opinion. The plot is a classic romance with a great BDSM twist. The movie is not corny and it does not play out like a bad hallmark channel romance. The characters here are reasonably fleshed out, their motivations make sense, and there is an overall great plot. I personally love this movie. I think it nails everything it aims to and is a must watch for all those who haven't seen it yet.

review: I felt violated afterwards! This movie basically tries to make abuse look sexy! The characters have the emotional IQ of a three year old, especially the lead female role. I read two of the three books out of pure curiosity, but started skipping entire pages and later chapters just to get through the book. Who has sex three or four times a day!? The books are childlike and absolutely boring. Also, they have no storyline other than two people permanently having sex, a woman with no backbone and an absolutely narcissistic controlling man! Also, if you tell a guy that you are still a virgin, his response should NOT BE let me help you with that problem!!! The movie and the books are creepy. Since when has it become sexy for a woman not to be able to choose how she wants to dress, what she wants to eat, where she wants to go....even her cellphone, exercise and waxing habits are under his control. She is basically just a possession. The movie is rated 16 only! Not nearly enough. I sat in the movies with giggling 16-18 year olds and thought to myself this movie should not be seen by anyone younger than 25 and in a healthy relationship with common sense to realize that this is not healthy or normal. I would feel ashamed if I was the parent who allowed my 16 year old to watch this movie! This is the basis that these emotionally fragile children will build their relationships on one day! This movie opened a lot of doors that needed to stay shut! DISGUSTING!

review: Remember when everybody was talking about the book Fifty Shades of Grey by E. L. James? Do you also remember the equally terrible movie adaptation on Valentine's Day weekend in 2015? The story of Anastasia Steele (Dakota Johnson) and her sadomasochistic relationship with young businessman Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan) has been the most entertainingly awful piece of literature and a subject of parody in the first half of the 2010 decade. What made the novel so infamous were the exaggerated sex scenes and the laughable internal monologue. The movie however, trims those elements down in favor of a conventional romantic drama instead of raising the bar with James's text. Don't get me wrong, Fifty Shades of Grey isn't without saucy moments, but there are so few drips to squeeze and they get bogged down by scenes of Mr. Grey gawking Anastasia with materialism, stalking her at dinner parties, or sending creepy text messages. Christian has an entire collection of whips, butt plugs, and other BDSM sex toys, yet he never takes advantage of them in the movie. With the funny narration being replaced by generic pop songs, the film also loses its charisma and never explores Annie's lustful desires. I'm not asking for this movie to be ultra-pornographic, but I expected more steamy activity than just hard spanking and rubbing ice on the nipples. Despite Sam Taylor-Johnson's effort to better the book's prose, the result of Fifty Shades of Grey is extremely mild and not the least bit titillating. (1 ¬Ω Exploding Inner Goddesses out of 5)

review: I really wish they would stop remaking movies no one likes and actually pays to see. That being said, I saw this on a flight for free and it wasn't the worst out there. JC Reilly is a gem of clever stupidity and makes this barely watchable.
Enjoyed it more the second time around (gearing up for Godzilla vs. Kong), however, it has a breathing problem and the characters aren't memorable enough to care.

A fresh take on King Kong, though it follows close to the same clich√©s of many other previous installments. The CGI is good enough, the action is good enough, and overall the entire movie just feels good enough, which is shockingly bad considering its star-studded cast. There is just too much CGI (though not as much as Peter Jackson's take on King Kong. The worldbuilding and expanding upon the first monster-verse film, "Godzilla," is really well, and the after-credits scene promises a future crossover between these two monsters. The new design for Kong is interesting, though I prefer the original look. Overall, it was an entertaining film with just too many clich√©s to make it anything but just another CGI muddled monster flick.

It may look like a monster movie. It may look as a blockbuster, full of stars. Look twice. It earns with repeated viewings... under all the noise and CGI action, lies a satire/allegory on Vietnam war (that actually can be translated to any superpower going to remote places to secure resources). It is even brilliant at some points, with great directions, good acting, and superb VFX and set pieces. Not perfect, of course, but a must see for good cinephiles, if you ask me. Don't dismiss it.

Kong Is disturbed on his home of Skull Island by some researchers along with their military escorts looking to discover the secrets of the lost island. This has an all star cast with Tom Hiddleston, Brie Larson , Samuel L Jackson, John C Reilly, John Goodman and more. For a film as heavy handed on special effects as it has to be, they are nothing short of magnificent. The world created on this island is pretty impressive and this is a pretty great popcorn movie. Filled with action and adventure, it's a fantastic ride.

Another solid outing in the MonsterVerse, Skull Island lives up to the bar set 3 years earlier by Godzilla and is another exciting and engaging kaiju film. Skull Island does a lot of stuff right that Godzilla also did: it has a story, a human-centric perspective and a good amount of build up to the conflict of the movie. This time, we get to the fighting a lot sooner than we did in Godzilla, but not so soon that the movie feels like it's entirely based on it, making this an improvement on Godzilla. The script and directing allow for the characters to be interesting and have some nice and funny dialogue, and also for the story of the movie to flow and develop nicely which helps to keep viewers invested in what's happening. The movie has some twists and turns along the way that spice things up and keep the movie interesting for both the viewers and characters, and does a nice job of tying the opening scene into the plot of the movie without it feeling too disruptive. Skull Island also does a great job of not squandering it's A-list cast, being actors such as Tom Hiddleston and John Goodman, by giving all the big characters plenty of dialogue and moments to shine a little bit. It also gives it's lesser known actors the same opportunities, something I appreciated. The big-monster fighting action is great and is just as good as it was in Godzilla, which works immensely to this film's benefit cause we get a bit more of it than we did in Godzilla. I like how Skull Island gives the humans more of an opportunity to fight and hurt the big monster antagonist of this film, since Godzilla did most of the work in the other movie, and it shows that humans aren't completely useless against these creatures and they can lend a helping hand. All that said, SI suffers from the same predictability that Godzilla did, and it's very easy to figure out, for the most part, what's going to happen. There isn't too much mystery in this movie and a lot of what goes on follows typical expectations. There's really only one curveball that the movie throws in, but other than that it all goes according to formula. The other issue I have with this movie is character stupidity. A lot of what goes wrong for the characters in this movie is because of their own actions, so most of what they go through is because of their own doing. To put it in broader terms, they create their own demons and pay the price for that severely. The fates many of the characters suffer is avoidable, unnecessary and founded in decisions based on emotion. Many of them do their best to get out of the situation that they're in, but are hampered by the actions of other characters. This is an area where this movie falters a bit from Godzilla. Despite these flaws, Skull Island is a great kaiju movie that hits the bar set by Godzilla in many ways and is another solid installment in the MonsterVerse.

Honestly I hate King Kong. I can't stand seeing an ugly gorilla killing cool dinosaurs. Initially I had skipped this movie and directly watched Godzilla: King of the Monsters, but seeing how many references of this movie that movie had in the post credits and the fact that I needed to watch this to understand Godzilla vs Kong is why I watched this movie in the first place (I still haven't watched Godzilla vs Kong though lmao). This movie, however, wasn't that bad. In fact the CGI is pretty good. But that doesn't change the fact that an ugly gorilla is killing cool looking Skullcrawlers here, although I was satisfied that he could win only with the human help. Samuel Jackson plays the role of an annoying general who gets his comeuppance (which is the reason why I have given it such a good rating). He was so irritating. When he said he will kill all the Skullcrawlers after he kills Kong I felt like going in the screen and slapping him. Like, just one scene ago your entire squad got thrashed by only one Skullcrawler child and here you're dreaming of taking down every single one of them you zoophobe!? The movie takes place on an island in the 70's. Although Kong gets very less screen time and there is too much talking and exposition, it wasn't as bad as the Godzilla movies. The human characters were actually interesting. I liked the part where one of them dies when a giant spider steps on him and everyone thinks it's a tree. The professor who explains the entire context of the tribes worshipping Kong was also an interesting story. In the end they all manage to get away from the island and tell the world about what they saw. It was a good ending. If they had done something like saying why they were going to keep it a secret I'd have legit given it a 1 star rating. The CGI has been done very well. Although it features a number of cool creatures (the Skullcrawlers especially), it does not induce the same frantasy feeling that Godzilla movies do. It only makes it feel like giant creatures fighting in an island. It doesn't feel "legendary", like what you feel when you watch King of the Monsters' trailer. It just looks... Meh. Kong: Skull Island may not be some very extraordinary movie, but you do have to watch it if you want to watch Godzilla vs Kong. It's a bit annoying but makes it up with the colour palette. I really hope this is the last time I'm seeing the ugly gorilla. Because I am never going to re-watch this.

It def feels like a movie not close to being authentic or realistic pertaining to the characters. The army guys all look and sound like actors. And how they set things up are too convenient. Hey all those guys that died in 5 helicopter crashes scattered in a half mile I got all their dog tags in 5 mins. But the monster stuff is great love Kong.

review_date: 'Kong: Skull Island' has once again shown that in this cinematic monster universe, the VFX created monsters are the best characters that can be developed throughout their film. This second installment of the monster universe after the first 'Godzilla' proves to be almost an exact copy. Audiences are given a monster where half of the cast wishes to kill it and the others understand and empathize with it. Only this time, there is some more development within certain characters such as John C. Reilly's character which had the best lines and most in-depth story. Unfortunately no one else on screen truly shined. Samuel L. Jackson did a great job, but was unsympathetic towards audiences with his character's personality and decisions. The movie is also very scary at points which is enjoyable to see from a film such as this. The VFX were astonishingly well-done and Oscar-worthy. Overall the film is a good time with amazing action sequences, if you need a fun movie to watch, watch this.

review: FLAG THIS REVIEW
Not a great movie to write home about but Cars 2 is a fairly good sequel!!!

Lightning McQueen is challenged to a World Grand Prix, a series of three races in three different countries, and brings along his best friend Mater who gets involved in an international espionage plot. Creating a movie where the main protagonist is now the comedic side character from the first movie is a difficult undertaking. The most difficult part is creating a story arc, including character growth, for the comedic character that the audience can get behind. This movie tries to move Mater to a logical growth arc, but at the end of it he isn't the same loveable tow truck we fell in love with during the first movie. In addition, I'm not sure what it was about the car universe that was created in the first movie that demanded a spy thriller movie. This plot seems to come out of nowhere. Props to Larry the Cable Guy for doing the best he could with what he was given. Michael Caine also does a great job in the voice acting department. The backgrounds of the three races are spectacular! If you enjoyed the first movie or this plot sounds interesting to you, then check this movie out.

Lightning McQeen manages to have understandable goals and still be an unlikeable idiot while the rest of the characters find some way to look past Mator's stupidity or are also stupid wich doesn't make sense considering how smart they are supposed to be as super spies. Also, about that superspies thing: Why? I don't know but, weirdly i kind of enjoyed it because of how much it related to the Cars universe (i can't believe i just wrote that i mean what has my life come to) as does the villain who isn't fleshed out in the slightest but has an interesting storyline so‚Ä¶ I actually quite like the story and how it goes around the world because this fillm isn't boring in the slightest and you will experience a series of different emotions while watching it: anger, confusion and hilarity. What a strangely entertaining, rubbish movie.

I've been watching the Cars series of films with my 3 year old daughter; Lightning McQueen is currently one of her favourite things/people/cars, along with Thom Yorke. (She's also taken a real shine recently to U2's utterly under appreciated masterpiece, 1993's Zooropa). When Cars 2 had finished, one of my first thoughts was that they had learned their lesson in cutting the run time down. Imagine my surprise when I realised Cars 2 is 3 minutes longer than its predecessor. Cars 2 got panned on release, and it's true, it has issues (McQueen's best friend with whom we are supposed to sympathise remains pretty annoying) but the main drive (whey) and selling point of Cars 2 is that it's essentially a James Bond film, with cars. Far from being dismissive rubbish, Cars 2 is a real spectacle. It looks superb, it's globetrotting is very Bondian, and the real life locations reproduced in glittering, shiny animation transports you across the world, and, yes, made me feel like I was there, as ridiculous as that sounds. What the original film did well was the racing sequences; so Cars 2 ups the anti, with more of them, in fantastical environments, especially a genuinely jaw dropping picturesque race in Porto Corsa (based on Monaco). Michael Caine has great fun as an Aston Martin spy, we're introduced to him in the opening sequence, a spectacular action piece on an oil rig. Cars 2 is not Pixar's best film, and it is flawed, but the further I've got through writing this review, the more I've realised I thought it was tremendous.

I think the worst part of this film is that they really did try, but at no point did anyone at Pixar realise just how unfitting the plot was. The first Cars had a similar problem, in that the whole idea of a world where cars and select other vehicles replace ordinary people, just doesn't work with the plot, making us question more about the premise of the film than had it just been called "humans racing" and been about human sprinters rather than racecars. Cars 2 exacerbates this problem to the utmost of extremes, providing what is essentially a James Bond film that could have been really good if it were about people, but the clunky nature of its premise just makes the whole thing seem less like a typical Pixar passion project and more like just a shameless cashgrab. When the plot of a film undermines the premise of that film, it's fundamentally flawed before even crossing the starting line.

This review contains spoilers. We all agree that Cars 2 is not one of Pixar's most successful films, indeed in my opinion it is the worst. By saying this I am not saying it is weights, but simply meh. The animations are definitely the best point of the film, with excellent graphics and meticulous details, as well as I liked how the customs of the countries were conceived in a non-stereotypical way (an Italian says it). The backgrounds are pretty. For this film it was decided to shift the focus from Lightning to Mater, a rather questionable choice. Why give such an important role to a comedic sidekick? But above all, what did Mater have to say? A morality was created for him that he did not need. In the end he only realized that Mater was a comedic sidekick. Which we already understood. In Finding Dory, Dory was a comedic sidekick, but they still managed to create a great insight for her into her short-term memory and her family. Which unfortunately is lost in Mater. After all, Lightning is a bit of a regression of personality, making it difficult to recognize from how it came out in the first film. The two spies are not of great character, but I would not go so far as to say that they do not. The villain is another of the problems of this film. The villain is twist and therefore, in fact, the spectator must find out together with the spies who is sabotaging the race. Unfortunately the detective storyline doesn't work. In this genre, usually, you are presented with a lot of characters, all not completely innocent, so that the viewer finds out together with the detective who is the culprit. In Cars 2, in addition to the spies and the main protagonists, we have the competitors of the race and Axlerod, the organizer of the event. Being able to guess that the competitors cannot sabotage themselves, breast would be idiotic, Axlerod remains. I know that the film is aimed at a younger audience (which I would not expect from Pixar anyway), but here it is a bit exaggerating. The story is not that great and indeed it is a bit predictable, with Spy elements that have absolutely nothing to do with the racing world and clash. The Twist, as already mentioned, was handled very badly. The jokes are not sought after and fall a bit into childish. Cars 2 never gets off to a good start - this blatant cash grab Disney wanted to sell merchandise doesn't offer anything really interesting on the table. Despite this, the well-kept animations and an all in all enjoyable story make Cars 2 a film that I would not fully recommend, but it will not be pitiful to see. With an uninspired protagonist, ultra-predictable villain but superlative animations, Cars 2 is Pixar's "worst" product.

review: [color=black][font=Andy][size=3][img]http://media.movieweb.com/news/dvd_boxart/hi/10/1010.jpg[/img]Now here's something interesting from cinema pioneer Peter Jackson, a DVD release of special features before the film came out. [u]The King Kong Production Diaries[/u] were a series of short documentaries that played on the web site KongisKing.net during the filming of the movie. On this DVD, the 5-minute shorts play in sequence and give great and often funny incite into the making of [u]King Kong[/u].[/size][/font][/color] [color=black][font=Andy][size=3]Actor's Jack Black and Andy Serkis have a blast hamming it up to the camera. In one diary, Jack gets upset because his height has been misrepresented on the KongisKing website. He then proceeds to tell Peter Jackson that wearing a male version of high heels in right for his character. The DVD is like film school in a box, every aspect of the production is covered here. Even the lighting continuity guy has his moment to shine. [/size][/font][/color] [color=black][font=Andy][size=3]Now we all know that this will not be the only [u]King Kong[/u] DVD released. I'm sure an extended edition will be coming soon with all kinds of special features for the geek in all of us (remember [u]The Lord of the Rings[/u]). This DVD proves Peter Jackson is the king of special features and if you want to know about epic filmmaking, he is your man.[/size][/font][/color]

rt_name: King Kong: Peter Jackson's Production Diaries - Movie Reviews

review: During the extended production of the [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy, filmmaker Peter Jackson collaborated on a series of web-based production diaries. The diaries covered all aspects of production, from set building and costuming to special effects. In order to account for users with low bandwidth capabilities, the diaries were kept to a relatively brief three to seven minutes long. The diaries allowed fans of the [i]Ring[/i] trilogy (and Tolkien's novels, of course) insight to the complexities of filmmaking on a scale rarely attempted. When Jackson announced his next project, a remake of [i]King Kong[/i], his collaborator on the web diaries for the [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy, Michael Pellerin, suggested that another set of production diaries would serve a similar function, keeping Jackson in contact with his loyal fanbase (not to mention excellent pre-release publicity for [i]King Kong[/i], but that was apparently a secondary concern). The end result of Jackson's collaboration with Pellerin, 54 production diaries spanning the 131 days of principal photography that began in September 2005 and ended in April 2005 (exclusive of pick-ups, which involved flying the central cast and some supporting actors back to New Zealand for insert shots or new scenes), have been removed from Pellerin's website, kongisking.net and repackaged on a two-DVD box set as [i]King Kong: Peter Jackson's Production Diaries[/i], complete with a 52-page scrapbook, production art prints, and even a letter of authenticity. Since the producers of [i]King Kong[/i], Universal Studios, owned the rights to the production diaries, the diaries were pulled from Pellerin's website, kongisking.net, before the release of the DVD set on December 13, 2005. Pellerin's website, however, still hosts more than 30 post-production diaries that are potentially as insightful (if not more so) than the production diaries. The post-production diaries are probably best downloaded now, while they're still available (presumably they'll be pulled from the website sometime soon and repackaged into an extras-heavy extended or special edition of [i]King Kong[/i]). The production diaries open with a slightly harried, but still plump Peter Jackson (he lost over 70 pounds over the last year and a half) announcing the first day (actually night) of shooting aboard the full-scale mock-up of the S.S. Venture (Jackson suffers from seasickness, so he couldn't shoot on the actual ship). As the diaries evolve, Jackson, often wearing his favorite shirt (either that or he owns multiple copies of the same yellow shirt) introduces his fans to key members of the behind-the-scenes production crew, including his cinematographer, production designer, miniatures and model makers, and special effects staff at Weta Digital (Weta Workshop provides physical effects and props). The diaries essentially work their way down the production hierarchy, stopping to interview production managers, carpenters, and even transport drivers. The first disc focuses primarily on the creation of Skull Island, from concept art, to the building of full-scale sets and scaled miniatures (on the order of 1/10 or 1/20) to add depth and breadth to the vistas of an impossibly primeval world. Several production diaries cover the creation of the ship that takes the central characters to Skull Island, the S.S. Venture, which exists as a seaworthy ship, a full-scale replica built on a backlot, interior cabins and storage on a soundstage, and a highly detailed miniature. Although the first disc briefly covers the New York set building, most of the second disc covers the filming of the New York City scenes which bookend [i]King Kong[/i] ([i]King Kong[/i] has roughly three major locations, New York City, the S.S. Venture, and Skull Island, with the central characters returning to New York City in the third hour). The second disc roughly follows the scenes filmed on the set of a recreated New York City (a combination of physical structures, some only partially built, miniatures, and digital effects), circa 1933. The cast, of course, is on hand to lend their support, with Jack Black joking his way through the diaries. Naomi Watts shows more reticence in front of the video camera, but viewers do get the opportunity to hear Naomi speak with her native, Australian accent (she moved to Australia from England when she was 14). We also get the chance to see Jackson take his cast and major crewmembers to New York City and, of course, the Empire State Building (Naomi looks distinctly uncomfortable, huddled as far away from the edge as possible). We also get a surprise visit from another A-list director currently working on a 2006 summer release (Jackson decision to hand over directing chores to this director is a well-timed gag). One diary humorously covers the search for a production spy who's taken and posted photos of the sets and soundstages online. Not surprisingly, he posts under a username or handle (hint: he borrows the name of a major character from Jackson's [i]Ring[/i] trilogy). The preceding description only scratches the surface of what the production diaries cover, but even then they're best supplemented by watching the 30-odd post-production diaries available on kongisking.net (they can be downloaded and saved as high or low resolution video files). [i]King Kong[/i] fans might want to hold off on purchasing the current version of the production diaries until they are combined with post-production diaries on the special or extended DVD edition. If the multiple release strategy for [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy is any indication, Peter Jackson will first release the theatrical edition on DVD during the summer and an extended edition containing all the diaries (as well as other unspecified extras) sometime next fall. The current two-disc DVD of the production diaries does have an additional diary unavailable on the website, a 16-minute featurette that covers the over-the-top fight sequence between Kong and three T-Rexes on Skull Island, from conception through realization. Overall, the two-disc DVD set contains insightful, exhaustive (in both senses of the word) look at the logistics of filming an effects-heavy period film.

review: [font=Comic Sans MS]this movie was ... not good. i wouldn't recommend it - nor would i go see it again. i understand that this movie was, in fact, a remake w/ a few enhancements... but i wished we could've enhanced our depictions of blacks in early cinema. 70 years later and we still have bones in our noses and are viewed as savages. Aesthetically speaking, this movie looked no more advanced at times than an 80's film. during the row-boat scene towards skull island - you could see the moving screen behind the actors in the rowboat... that is [b]SO GOONIES[/b]! [/font] [font=Comic Sans MS]there were a few scenes that i thought were magnificient - the bug scene was nasty enough to make me cover my eyes and King Kong's fight w/ the T-Rex really kept me at the edge of my seat...[/font] [font=Comic Sans MS]with all that said - i can't wait to see the original 1933 version to truly compare...;-)[/font]
rt_name: King Kong: Peter Jackson's Production Diaries - Movie Reviews

review: During the extended production of the [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy, filmmaker Peter Jackson collaborated on a series of web-based production diaries. The diaries covered all aspects of production, from set building and costuming to special effects. In order to account for users with low bandwidth capabilities, the diaries were kept to a relatively brief three to seven minutes long. The diaries allowed fans of the [i]Ring[/i] trilogy (and Tolkien's novels, of course) insight to the complexities of filmmaking on a scale rarely attempted. When Jackson announced his next project, a remake of [i]King Kong[/i], his collaborator on the web diaries for the [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy, Michael Pellerin, suggested that another set of production diaries would serve a similar function, keeping Jackson in contact with his loyal fanbase (not to mention excellent pre-release publicity for [i]King Kong[/i], but that was apparently a secondary concern). The end result of Jackson's collaboration with Pellerin, 54 production diaries spanning the 131 days of principal photography that began in September 2005 and ended in April 2005 (exclusive of pick-ups, which involved flying the central cast and some supporting actors back to New Zealand for insert shots or new scenes), have been removed from Pellerin's website, kongisking.net and repackaged on a two-DVD box set as [i]King Kong: Peter Jackson's Production Diaries[/i], complete with a 52-page scrapbook, production art prints, and even a letter of authenticity. Since the producers of [i]King Kong[/i], Universal Studios, owned the rights to the production diaries, the diaries were pulled from Pellerin's website, kongisking.net, before the release of the DVD set on December 13, 2005. Pellerin's website, however, still hosts more than 30 post-production diaries that are potentially as insightful (if not more so) than the production diaries. The post-production diaries are probably best downloaded now, while they're still available (presumably they'll be pulled from the website sometime soon and repackaged into an extras-heavy extended or special edition of [i]King Kong[/i]). The production diaries open with a slightly harried, but still plump Peter Jackson (he lost over 70 pounds over the last year and a half) announcing the first day (actually night) of shooting aboard the full-scale mock-up of the S.S. Venture (Jackson suffers from seasickness, so he couldn't shoot on the actual ship). As the diaries evolve, Jackson, often wearing his favorite shirt (either that or he owns multiple copies of the same yellow shirt) introduces his fans to key members of the behind-the-scenes production crew, including his cinematographer, production designer, miniatures and model makers, and special effects staff at Weta Digital (Weta Workshop provides physical effects and props). The diaries essentially work their way down the production hierarchy, stopping to interview production managers, carpenters, and even transport drivers. The first disc focuses primarily on the creation of Skull Island, from concept art, to the building of full-scale sets and scaled miniatures (on the order of 1/10 or 1/20) to add depth and breadth to the vistas of an impossibly primeval world. Several production diaries cover the creation of the ship that takes the central characters to Skull Island, the S.S. Venture, which exists as a seaworthy ship, a full-scale replica built on a backlot, interior cabins and storage on a soundstage, and a highly detailed miniature. Although the first disc briefly covers the New York set building, most of the second disc covers the filming of the New York City scenes which bookend [i]King Kong[/i] ([i]King Kong[/i] has roughly three major locations, New York City, the S.S. Venture, and Skull Island, with the central characters returning to New York City in the third hour). The second disc roughly follows the scenes filmed on the set of a recreated New York City (a combination of physical structures, some only partially built, miniatures, and digital effects), circa 1933. The cast, of course, is on hand to lend their support, with Jack Black joking his way through the diaries. Naomi Watts shows more reticence in front of the video camera, but viewers do get the opportunity to hear Naomi speak with her native, Australian accent (she moved to Australia from England when she was 14). We also get the chance to see Jackson take his cast and major crewmembers to New York City and, of course, the Empire State Building (Naomi looks distinctly uncomfortable, huddled as far away from the edge as possible). We also get a surprise visit from another A-list director currently working on a 2006 summer release (Jackson decision to hand over directing chores to this director is a well-timed gag). One diary humorously covers the search for a production spy who's taken and posted photos of the sets and soundstages online. Not surprisingly, he posts under a username or handle (hint: he borrows the name of a major character from Jackson's [i]Ring[/i] trilogy). The preceding description only scratches the surface of what the production diaries cover, but even then they're best supplemented by watching the 30-odd post-production diaries available on kongisking.net (they can be downloaded and saved as high or low resolution video files). [i]King Kong[/i] fans might want to hold off on purchasing the current version of the production diaries until they are combined with post-production diaries on the special or extended DVD edition. If the multiple release strategy for [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] trilogy is any indication, Peter Jackson will first release the theatrical edition on DVD during the summer and an extended edition containing all the diaries (as well as other unspecified extras) sometime next fall. The current two-disc DVD of the production diaries does have an additional diary unavailable on the website, a 16-minute featurette that covers the over-the-top fight sequence between Kong and three T-Rexes on Skull Island, from conception through realization. Overall, the two-disc DVD set contains insightful, exhaustive (in both senses of the word) look at the logistics of filming an effects-heavy period film.

review: It's a Russian movie that I watched in dubbed English: this offsets the presentation. The story itself was actually pretty good, it has great pacing, twists, surprises without jump scares, but the delivery was rough. Maybe its a Russian aspect of how conversation happens, but the dialogue itself was awkward and I found myself just not caring about the characters unless it related to the premise. The effect work was actually really good too, but the "normal" parts of the movie just didn't cut if for me. Not for me, can't recommend unless you're looking for a Bad Movie Night candidate, then it'll probably be a really good time.

review: Starts off super funny and cute, but anytime the movie tries to shift to being serious it fails. Anyone who finished grade-school will find the science in the this movie laughable. If you can ignore the insult to basic science and the cringe 'serious' scenes, it's a fun watch. Definitely a good candidate for a quality big-budget remake with today's film tech.

While you won't find Oscar potential here, this film is a thrilling ride that has it all: laughs, suspense, action, and heart. It is leaps and bounds more watchable (and RE-watchable) than Deep Impact could ever hope to be. The film never claimed to be some lofty arthouse masterpiece. It delivers exactly what it should: two hours of roller coaster action and snappy humor with fun characters you're rooting for. What else do you need from an action movie? Pass the popcorn. Enjoy!
I had fun of the size of Texas!
A good premise but faulty special effects make this movie a so-so movie!!!
At worst offensive and at best just plain boring.
It is beyond the unbelievable, it is offensive. Even trying to ignore the scientific issues, it is hard to watch
One of my favorite movies back in the late 90's. Sure it was cheesy as heck but come on, what a cast! And great action by Michael Bay.
A total guilty pleasure with sooooo many great one-liners. It might have more plot holes than Swiss cheese but I love it.
I've watched this movie at least ten times and thoroughly enjoyed it every time! It is straight up fun! Don't over think it, just enjoy it!

One of the greatest popcorn flicks of all time. Incredibly entertaining from start to finish with enjoyable characters, fantastic charisma, and an emotionally satisfyingly finish. A testament to just how useless professional movie critics are at their jobs.
If it weren't for the overuse of Steve Tyler music that made too much of the movie feel like an Aerosmith video, it would be a 5 star.

Armageddon is a that type of movie which is loved by the people who love watching movies with no logic. The movie was all about space, astroids, rockets etc but there was zero logic. Michael Bay is already known for making non-logical long movies. This movie was too long (2hr25min) and too slow. You will loose interest after some time or even get bored to death. At one time, it seems like movie will never end. Only thing that saved movie was performance by Bruce Willis and Ben Affleck. Rest, everything was bad. These types of movie was basically made for enjoyment but the way this movie was executed it seems like this movie was made for torture. Overall, it was very bad experience for me and would recommend this to anyone who takes his/her own responsibility if anything happens to him/her after watching the movie.

I remember when this film hits the cinemas, I was 16. It was spectacular then, and its still is, after watching it minutes ago. The plot, the script and the actions were awesome. Armageddon is such an underrated gem and it's such a great movie. The movie's got a great story, which is about these NASA astronauts finding out that a large asteroid will destroy earth in the next eighteen days. However, they find out that their only way to save earth is by getting this oil driller called Harry Stamper (Bruce Willis) and for him to recruit a team. The acting throughout this movie is honestly great especially from the main characters who are in this movie. The dialogue which is given from the characters throughout this movie is very hit and miss. There is some really good dialogue at times but sometimes there can be some very cheesy dialogue throughout this movie. Also, the humour throughout this movie is honestly really good, especially from Rockhound (Steve Buscemi) he's got so many funny moments in this movie. The cinematography from John Schwartzman is decent. He captures the scenes pretty well throughout this movie but sometimes the lighting isn't so good. The movie's got some pretty good pacing for most of the build ups, which end up happening throughout this movie. Finally, the movie's got a brilliant soundtrack. The soundtrack features some great songs from such artists as Aerosmith, Bob Seger and Bon Jovi. The movie's got a few little stupid moments scattered throughout and some scenes which take you out of the movie. Overall, Armageddon is honestly a great movie. The movie's got a great story, great acting, brilliant humour, some pretty good pacing and a brilliant soundtrack.
Stellar performances by Bruce Willis and Billy Bob Thornton highlight this film. The beautiful shots and action sequences combined with an excellent story make this a must-watch.
I can only take so many cheesy lines and dramatic yelling during ridiculous action scenes. I liked Deep Impact better.
I went to the theatre To see Armageddon. When it was over, everyone stood and clapped. So it's obviously good. good enough to watch more than once.

"Armageddon". It was very touching. I understand why so many people say this movie is a masterpiece. Although it's easy to predict how this movie would end , I was still so impressed. The characters who were selected to save the earth were charming, and Bruce Willis was so cool!

Good watch, might watch again, and can recommend. This has a great premise and stacked cast which is incredibly well balanced not only between the "diggers", but the control crew and the astronauts as well. While they take that opportunity use the characters to really build the world, the story really just boils down to "meteor going to kill earth" and "guy and girl connection, but girl's daddy doesn't like". Surprisingly the latter takes up a significant amount of time in the movie, but everyone gets their moment in the spotlight. Steve Buscemi definitely has some of the most memorable moments in the movie. This is the first movie I can think of that has this sort of detail of space travel, let alone tried to simulate the hellish landscape of an asteroid. It really feels like they put the production value into not only to making the movie look good but getting the details right. This is a "I laughed, I cried" sort of movie, and while I don't think it does any one thing especially well, it definitely delivers a solidly good experience.
Deep Impact is better, has the same premise. And it doesn't have that shitty Aerosmith song in it.
It is one of the stupidest films ever made. It is also one of the most entertaining, with a great cast, and great cast of characters.

review: The Day After Tomorrow is a guilty pleasure of mine. There are many flaws but it's entertaining and I enjoyed the premise and cast. There are plenty of plot holes, so if you're looking for a brilliantly directed movie with a stellar script, you're not going to find that here. I feel the CGI was way ahead of its time and there're some incredibly visuals throughout. It did, however, feel like a typical Hollywood movie at times, with unrealistic and eye-roll-worthy decision making from the main characters, as well as some highly questionable events that take place that make next-to-no-sense. If you lower your expectations and take it for what it is, it is pretty enjoyable though but certainly doesn't merit any awards.

review: Roland Emmerich is a master of creating spectacularly overblown disaster schlock that is the cinematic equivalent of junk food. His films never pretend to be high cinema, they know that they are nonsense and use that knowledge as a vessel for brainless entertainment. With the exception of the genuinely awful 2012, this has always been a recipe for success. The Day After Tomorrow swaps the aliens of Independence Day and the monster of Godzilla for the terrifying power of mother nature, and is aided by some stellar special effects and spectacular action set pieces. Is the science wildly inaccurate? Yes. Is the dialogue corny? Yes. Does the film provide relentlessly entertaining nonsense? My god yes. At the end of the day, sometimes you need easy to digest films that provide escapism from the monotonies of daily life, and this film fits the bill perfectly.
rt_name: The Day After Tomorrow - Movie Reviews

The Day After Tomorrow - Movie Reviews

review: The Day After Tomorrow - 7.5/10. What Roland Emmerich does a great job with his big budget films is entertain with gargantuan set pieces of world shifting events. The Day After Tomorrow plays with the idea of global warming, and flips it to global cooling. The visuals and CGI are outstanding. The whole tsunami sequence and then subsequent freezing scenes are just spectacular to watch even today. The acting is a little shoddy, with decent performances from Dennis Quaid and Sela Ward. Otherwise the film is really just a special effects extravaganza geared towards making a statement against global warming. As a film, its super entertaining as a disaster movie. As a movie on critiquing a serious issue like global warming and pollution, the film lacks a little. Its commendable that Emmerich has tried to make a disaster film tied into a more serious issue. But the movie works mainly as a fun watch and if you just watch it that way, you will totally enjoy it!
rt_name: The Day After Tomorrow - Movie Reviews

review: Some fair effects, story is based on an interesting premise, but the screenwriting and plot construction are grim indeed. Nothing encapsulates this better than the death scene for Ian Holm and his pals. Doomed to freeze to death in northern Scotland, they toast each other with the last Scotch whisky in the bottle. The toast? "To England." Now, for anyone who doesn't know better, calling a Scotsman "English", or Scotland "England" is the sort of remark that'll get you a size 9 boot up your backside in any Scottish boozer you care to visit. Compound it with drinking whisky at the same time and you've got a level of gauche ignorance which is irritating. Sadly, combine this with an at times excruciating and ridiculously pat story and it's a one watch only disaster of a film. It's also lazy. Granted, one sacrificial second line good guy croaks, but otherwise it's tokenism and a lot of heroic Caucasian 'Murricans winning the day for the USA, and btw invading Mexico because the US of A is a bit parky now. On the plus side, messrs Quaid, Gyllenhall and their pals look suitably smug at the end, so that's ok. The film isn't ok. At all.
rt_name: The Day After Tomorrow - Movie Reviews

review: For all of its greatness in the area of techno-effects, The Day After Tomorrow is sorely lacking in plot and dialogue. The only story we want to see come to fruition is Sam (Jake Gyllenhaal) saving Laura (Emmy Rossum) from her impending doom. Nothing else is interesting. There's not even a "saving the world" message. We area all gonna die on this massive extension of the Arctic Circle. The good news is that we're going to be part of the food chain for the polar bears, who will one day dominate the world as the dinosaurs once did. There's your Day After Tomorrow Part 2 spoiler.

review: This incredible and thrilling film was directed and scripted by Roland Emmerich in 2004,it is an apocalyptic science fiction story about how the climate is changing on our planet. The main character is the paleoclimatologist Jack Hall (starred by Dennis Quaid) announces a new "Ice age" to the government,politicians decide not to believe in what he says because they should spend lots of money in order to protect people and save the planet.However,they will soon regret about their decision because the ice storm is around the corner! The other characters,such as Sam Hall (Jack Hall's son starred by Jake Gyllenhaal) and his girlfriend Laura Chapman (Emmy Rossum) are brilliant and brave.They strongly struggle to survive, even though it seems impossible.Sound effects are amazing and they make you feel interested in what is happening,although sometimes they're not so fun. I strongly recommend this film,I think everyone would enjoy it because of its plot and the clear message that it wants to share.Even though there's not a cliffhanger, you will never forget it!

"Ted Movie review by Cyranical" John Bennett is a kid that everyone in his entire neighborhood hates, he strives to have friends but is unable to make them. On christmas his parents give him a Teddy bear that he calls Ted, due to his lonely and ankward nature this Teddy bear serves as his best friend; he also constantly wishes that his friend becomes real. One day his wish comes true and Ted comes alive, the two then become inseperable friends from then and out. 35 years later they live in the same apartment and are still on good terms with each other, but this time with a catch John now has a girlfriend; a office worker that goes by the name of Lori. Lori hates Ted because she thinks that it causes her boyfriend's life to be immature and stale, this prompts her to give him an ultimatum; that being he has to choose between her or his best friend. Pros: -Can sometimes be funny and enjoyable -Great performances from the main leads -Has the ability to shift the mood to it's favor Cons: -Family Guy humor consisting of shit, fart, racist, nudity, profanity, drug usage and homophobic jokes plus outdated pop culture references, oh and some jokes that just revolve around random stupidity as well -Stereotypical characters and execution -Plot is way too straightforward and predictable -Has moments where it legit makes you cringe and makes you pause the movie -Is not consistently funny enough -Weird soundtrack Overall Ted is a movie best watched when you and your friend are drunk over at your mom's house, or when you just want some quick laughs. It legitemelety feels like live action family guy, except Peter is now a talking Teddy bear. It is a movie about Immatury and scatological humor so your enjoyment of it will depend on if you like it or not, to top it all off it is also not consistently funny enough; sometimes cringe and stupid; in addition to that it has a predictable plus basic plot. I would only recommend this movie if you are a fan of Sett Macfarlane's shows and works. I give Ted a 6/10 for my overall movie rating, this has been Cyranical signing off.
This movie isn't for everbody, but if you have that very distinct sense of humor, it's a riot! This movie isn't some magical masterpiece, but it's comedy gold that most people can appreciate.

I would say it's awesome, one of the few comedy movies that actually made me laugh. Also, I admire a lot that the director himself voices Ted, that's amazing! A bit of a weak plot, but it's not that bad.

The cast is great, and I think it would have been a very different movie if they had used anyone else in any role. The concept alone is unique and refreshing, "Did you see the movie about the teddy bwear that came to life?", that's this movie. You almost owe it to yourself to see such a unique concept. And they they do some fantastically structure humor mixed with some rather contrastingly serious romantic drama. They even mix in a touch of horror, and I was even able to get into it, despite it being about a Teddy Bear that has express displeasure about not being constructed with a penis. I can't imagine ever watching this and not being entertained.

Me and my friend recently watched Ted the movie after he watched both movies earlier in the year. I was given good expectations for the film and while some of the jokes land pretty well and the concept is executed better than it could have been the story itself left me wanting something better and some of the choices the film made just didn't work for me. Specifically the psycho family that kidnaps Ted later in the film. Also while some jokes land pretty well this is a comedy and a lot of the story itself is played for laughs. Some of it is just painfully unfunny like the character of Teds girlfriend, the aforementioned family, and other small moments. The things that did work were sometimes over emphasized and the story while very contained just wasn't for me. While I can see this movie working for other people it just didn't for me. There is nothing wrong with the story but there are plenty of things wrong for me as a viewer. I think that this is the kinda movie that was made for certain audiences specifically those who grew up in the 80s. Still my friend enjoyed it for what it is and I did too it was funny at times. However I would not re watch this film and although I will probably end up watching it I am not exited for the sequel that was released. Also Teds voice sounds way to much like Peter Griffin as mentioned in the movie which I appreciate self awareness but the voice needed to be more distinct in order for the character to be any more than Peter Griffin in a teddy bears body hanging out with a immature Mark Wahlberg.

All things considered, a few motion pictures are with the end goal that they are adored by crowds of each age gathering. The film about which I am going to discuss today falls under that class, Ted and Ted 2. The film rotates around John Bennett (Mark Wahlberg) who during his youth days, on the event of Christmas Eve wanted that his teddy springs up and it works out as expected. This film at that point manages the further existence of John as a grown-up, how Ted turns into a necessary piece of his life and how he influences his own life. This film, as I would see it, doesn't exhaust you and holds you till the end. It is pressed with amusement, sentiment, and some exciting activity as well. Although there are some scenes unsuitable for children, for example, when John and Ted smoke together or there might be some private minutes among Ted and his sweetheart, which gives this film an "A" rating yet at the same time I see this film as extremely engaging. The initial segment, Ted (2012), rotates around the life of John Bennett, his relationship with Lori Collins (Mila Kunis) and how Ted unfavourably influences their relationship. The subsequent part, Ted (2015), managed the life of Ted and his relationship with his better half Lynn (Jessica Barth). Right now, the film, Ted likewise faces a personality emergency as the American Government will not consider Ted as a typical individual. Seth MacFarlane has offered a voice to Ted and has likewise coordinated the establishment. His course is excellent remembering that it is his presentation directorial adventure. The screenplay and the story were additionally generally excellent. And if I say something about dialogues then they are very well written. Be it be dialogues of Ted too and the dialogue delivery is also really very entertaining and impressive. This was not the first occasion when I saw a film of Mark Wahlberg and Mila Kunis cooperating. Separately just as together this pair unquestionably functions admirably. I prior saw them in the film Max Payne (2008), where Mark assumes the title job and Mila assumes the job of Mona Sax. I truly regard these individuals as entertainers a great deal. Seeing a delicate toy come into life is a different encounter for me and I imagine that it would engage all of you as well. Although the film has become very old I think it has not lost its engaging variable. There are many things which we can learn from every movie and that is the case here too but I would state only one thing which I found out to be the most important. It is based on the priorities set by an individual in his or her life. Priorities are dynamic; they never remain fixed. John should have realized the same point. He should have felt that since he is in his 30s or 40s, Ted should not be his prime priority now. I know Ted is his best friend and they are so-called ‚Äòthunder buddies' of each other but they can maintain it but now through a certain distance. He did not realize so which adversely affected his relationship with his girlfriend, Lori Collins and which (though temporarily) spoilt his relationship with Ted, but that's not always the case in real life. Relations in today's world are very tender and need to be taken care of and for that right steps and the right time needs to be taken place to maintain every relation and lead a balanced life. By and large, these two movies, as I would like to think, merit watching work.

This movie was very well done as director Clint Eastwood delivers a hard hitting retelling of the life of the American Sniper Chris Kyle. While the story isn't 100% faithful to the actual events they're based on, the message strikes home and the story makes you feel as if you witnessed Kyle's life firsthand. Another great point of the movie is that Eastwood didn't shy away from showing the effects combat has on our nation's warriors, showing the effects of PTSD and how it affects the world around Kyle.. However, it is a war movie, which, admittedly, aren't for everyone.

Action packed but could have delved deeper into the topic of psychological trauma. The plot was reasonable, but the pacing seemed to drag on a little in places, and the ending was too abrupt. The trauma of war was shown to some extent but should have been expanded on, and there wasn't much emotion in general. You can also argue that it's pro America and pro war. Moreover, the main character was portrayed overly positively considering Chris Kyle seems to have a record of lying. However, the acting was solid, the combat was believable, and the visual effects, cinematography and soundtrack were all fine.

While I've seen my fair share of war films. Fiction and non-fiction. American Sniper was able to show a bit of what it's like bringing that trauma home, and how Chris Kyle became an historical American hero. I thought this film had some great emotional moments and an amazing performance by Bradley Cooper. I do wish it had shown more emotion on the effects of war and the trauma. But for what it is, I was satisfied.
Great movie. I spent allot of my military career in the middle east and this movie brings back allot of memories.

Clint Eastwood trova il suo perfetto eroe americano; soldato infallibile, amante della Patria e predisposto al sacrificio per chi gli sta intorno. Il racconto ti incolla fin dal primo minuto grazie ad una potentissima partenza con l'utilizzo di un flashforward ad effetto, e da quel momento si sviluppa lineare nel tempo prendendosi il giusto spazio in ogni fase. Bradley Cooper interpreta splendidamente il soldato Chris Kyle rendendo giustizia a ci√≤ che realmente fu.

Instead of providing a thoughtful examination of the full extent of the weight that combat takes on an individual, Eastwood settles for a Wild Western style shootout in Iraq that ultimately leaves American Sniper feeling less weighty, consequential, or impactful as what it perhaps could have been. Still, this may have been Bradley Cooper's best effort upon release.

American sniper is a great war movie and surprisingly unique in some areas. The story follows Texan Chris Kyle as he becomes a SEAL sniper and his struggles in service in the 2003 Iraq War. Kyle eventually becomes the most famous sniper in American military history but still with a difficult decisions on his family life and mental health. Bradley Cooper plays a great and believable honest and patriotic soldier, with his performance coming across as believable and perhaps even relatable for some. Clint Eastwood's direction is an evident bonus to the movie and really helps the action sequences and cuts between Kyle's life. What is unfortunate about the movie however is how the trauma of war is almost dismissed in the movie. The health of Kyle is seen and briefly touched upon but fails to ever be truly diagnosed with the cause or a way to help. Overall, American Sniper is a thrilling (and sometimes tragic) biopic war movie that should not be missed by fans of the genre.

MI2 has so much action that happens off screen that it was necessary to use slow motion to make the movie more than an hour long. The misogyny and innuendo has aged horribly and was probably even cringe worthy back in 2000. The finale takes everything great about the MI1 finale and throws it out the window. A bad underground fight sequence is followed by a truly terrible car chase that so blatantly defies the laws of physics that a viewer could not be faulted for thinking it a parody. The final showdown between Hunt and Ambrose is poorly choreographed and relies on a multitude of idiotic decisions by both parties for it to have any semblance of tension let alone happen in the first place. MI2 is the worst in the series by far, only watch it if inebriated and still expect to laugh at how bad it is.
