X-Men: Apocalypse is the kind of a movie that will make you remember all the good scenes, and you will forget why you hated it. But when you rewatch it you realise that nothing makes sense. But for me, however, I only came to watch the CGI stuff. I haven't read the source material. Neither do I have any idea about who Apocalypse is and what he wants. So I'm gonna judge this movie entirely based on what happens in it, how the CGI is and how all the characters are. And trust me, it fails in half the things. So first of all, I really liked the idea of an ancient mutant coming out of Egypt to learn about the current affairs and then deciding to take over the world. Though I wouldn't have given any points to this movie for this plot since it's a comic book adaptation, I will still give it extra points for showing it so nicely. Then there was the scene where Cyclops gets his powers. I don't know why, but I used to think this scene was from X-Men Origins: Wolverine. So after that there's a scene where Magneto is shown to have given up his previous life and started living as a family man, but the mutant hunters storm his house and kill his family. I really found that scene emotional. But after that the movie started feeling like it's crumbling down. The same Apocalypse who saves Storm by using sand to cut down everyone's head suddenly decides to never use this power. And also, what is a Storm with a mowahawk even doing in Egypt? It was never said that she's from there. There is a cage match between Warren Worthington III and Nightcrawler, and Mystique comes over there to get Nightcrawler out of there. But it doesn't make sense. How was Nightcrawler even captured in the first place? Couldn't he just teleport out of the cage? Also Mystique is someone completely different this time. I know she can change her look, but even her original look changes. And then there's of course the most iconic scene of this movie: Quicksilver saving all the kids from the explosion! But later on the whole point of that scene gets ruined when the army comes up and captures them anyway. They are transported into a secret lab, and guess what? Wolverine is also there. He was obviously brought in there for a scene that could be shown in the trailer, because then he's gone and lost forever. So anyway, Charles is captured by Apocalypse, the good guys fight the evil guys, something something happy ending and that's it. Most of the scenes in X-Men: Apocalypse were forgettable. The memorable scenes, well, I forgot they were from this movie. To write this review I had to watch Honest Trailers and Cinemasins just to remember what all happened in this movie. Like I said before, I used to think Scott getting his powers in the middle of the class was from X-Men Origins: Wolverine. I thought Quicksilver saving everyone was from Days of the Future Past. Same goes for the getting arrested scene, the Wolverine fight scene - I thought it was all from the prequel. Now I will have to edit my reviews for those movies too.
7.5/10. I don't find this film bad cause the action is still pretty good but Apocalypse is a weak villain. I love the Quicksilver rescue scene though.

this is an exciting movie but if you are watching the entire X-men series in chronological order it doesn't quite fit in. Characters who are killed in this movie are inexplicably alive later in their time period. Other aspects of the plot do not align well with earlier and later movies, which is common with this series, but perhaps could be explained by the creation of two timelines in The Days of Future Past. If you are planning on watching the series through I would recommend researching what movies belong to the two timelines to watch with more cohesiveness.

Apocalypse is a frustrating movie for me. On one hand, the action sequences are really well handled especially the final battle and the Wolverine and Quicksilver scene. They are very creative and very fun and there's some great worldbuilding in this movie with the origins of Apocalypse and combine that with colorful visuals, it's very interesting to see, everyone gives their A-Game performance-wise, it was awesome seeing a young Jean, Storm and Cyclops and this is by far the best Magneto. He's written so well here. On the other hand, Apocalypse is really poorly handled. He's basically just Ultron but with no screen presence, the first half of the movie is just set up for the final battle and just drags on and on with too much going on and it can be frustrating on rewatches and what happened to the nuclear missiles that were luanched and the plot is kind of disappointing for an X-Men movie, still having the thematic elements you expect but leans more to generic teritory way more than any X-Men movie. Jennifer Lawrnece is also shockingly awful here. I liked her in the previous 2 movies but here she screams ‚ÄòI don't want to be here'. It's still a decent movie but could have been a lot better.

Upon first watch I didn't like this movie because it didn't meet my expectation of who Apocalypse is based of the comics and cartoons. He's a large hulking intimidating powerful mutant and his horsemen and just as terrifying. I believe this is most people's reason to not like this movie. However when watching the movie back to back with X-men: Days of Future Past (the best of the entire film series), this movie is actually pretty good and holds to the characters pretty well. Apocalypse is even done pretty well when you get past the lack of stature and his voice. Apocalypse was one of the first mutants and the fact that he can transfer his essence from one mutant body to another, gaining the new mutant ability while retaining his other abilities and extending his lifespan, makes him a very interesting character. Basically that means this Apocalypse is not the final form of Apocalypse which is enjoyed in the comics and the cartoons.
Just not very good at all.

review: Darkly thrilling and pleasantly humorous for a Sherlock Holmes picture. Guy Ritchie's mystery action-comedy Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011) changes the private detective Sherlock Holmes into a crafty boxer, cunning planner, and creative improviser. Ritchie's direction is phenomenally his own with a riveting fast pace and striking use of slowing down the camera and rapid fire cuts from editor James Herbert to keep 129 brief in feel. Ritchie is a fun director with his own unique style as an English auteur, and Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows is as funny and exciting as any of his very British pictures. Robert Downey Jr. is outstandingly entertaining as peerless private detective Sherlock Holmes himself. He is effortlessly cool and constantly funny with a calm demeanor displaying cunning intellect. He captures Holmes' meticulous nature with Downey's own freewheeling persona. His chemistry with Jude Law's Dr. John Watson borders on the homoerotic. They pair so well in this movie that I do hope they shoot a sequel together. Law is stoic and upset, yet tender and sincere as the stalwart Watson. Jude Law's man of action gunfire sequences are very cool like Downey's epic boxing duel with Professor James Moriarty, played by the ferocious Jared Harris. Harris' genuinely frightening villain Prof. Moriarty could have gotten him an Oscar as he's absolutely intimidating with his serious gravitas and deep voice. Each line of his is clever and thought out. I'm glad Guy Ritchie cast Jared Harris as the iconic Holmes nemesis. Noomi Rapace is lovely as Madam Simza Heron with her natural locks and formidable action prowess. She's cool and classy with an Earthy feel to her wonderful performance. Noomi Rapace is an actress I need to seek out more of her films for sure. Rachel McAdams makes a dreamy cameo for her devastating part that McAdams plays to perfection. I wish she were in this movie more, but alas, her character serves her purpose. Kelly Reilly is great as Watson's wife Mary Morstan. Her charming personality and clear frustration with getting shoved aside for Holmes is quite entertaining. Michele Mulroney and Kieran Mulroney's script is a tight crime narrative about international and underground dealings and explosive assassinations. Their writing is blissfully funny, truly charming, impressively intricately plotted, and thoughtfully complex as they leave you clues to all the happenings herein, so you never feel too lost. I appreciate their development in making Holmes emotional in losing Irene Adler and Watson destroyed in losing Holmes. Adding Stephen Fry's cheerful, pompous, elitist, and absurd Mycroft Holmes was a nice touch from skilled writers. Philippe Rousselot's cinematography is gorgeous and creative with stunning wide shots of England, France, Germany, and Switzerland alike. His close-ups are striking, but I'd say his medium shots during all the close quarters combat is the most impressive as he clearly details what will happen, then shows us how it all plays out cleanly. Rousselot's camerawork and fast tracking shots during the train shootout and forest bombardment are astonishing feats of filmmaking. It's honestly insane that Guy Ritchie attempted such ambitious action sequences, but they pull it off thanks to Chas Jarrett's special effects supervision, Rousselot's camera whip pans, and Ritchie's careful planning and sheer force of will direction. Sarah Greenwood's production design is very careful and neat in making each period room look accurate and ornate. This film is stylish and fashionable, so of course Jenny Beaven's costumes are sleek and refined as well. Nikita Rae's make-up is realistic and playful for Holmes' disguises. Hans Zimmer's score is blaringly loud and pounds the intensity of each situation into your brain. In all, Guy Ritchie directed a repeat success like a machine pistol firing off a second round in rapid succession.

review: Critics say these movies are examples of "Style over substance", further proving the institution to be a joke and a farce. Presence of strong, captivating style does not damn a movie to have no substance, and it's the critics' fault for not being to withstand a strong, pronounced taste. This movie hosts some of the most brilliant action and spectacle of the last decade, while still not sacrificing anything that made Sherlock Holmes loveable in the first place. I'd go as far as to say that few directors and writers understood Holmes better. Many deductions Holmes makes in this movie are right out of the book, and any new ones were written with the same methods as the old ones. The only change these films really made was taking Holmes's loneliness, and his quiet dependence on Watson as a companion, and bringing those aspects to the forefront instead of hanging them in the background like the novels. Also, Watson's occasional bickering with Holmes is fleshed out in this movie. Along with an original plot, these aspects help the movie extend beyond a mere adaptation of the novels, becoming a fresh but familiar reinvention. If you were to read the books, you would see that many of the aspects Critics call un-Holmes like are, in fact, very Holmes like. Anyone of the film critics who said this movie doesn't understand Sherlock Holmes needs to watch less Rathbone, and read more Doyle.

review: I always like the bastard child in a film series; A Game of Shadows is the more OCD, less consistent, more creative, brisker and also somehow more protracted, more exciting and bolder entry. It's more flawed but more rewatchable, it's more confusing but it's far less boring. It does bizzare things, like killing McAdams' character so early, and in such a way that is intentionally obfuscated, and it's a deeply messy movie with Ritchie's signature excess, to pave over the cracks in his ability. But RDJ is clearly loving his role and Jared Harris' Moriarty is a fun, if inept, part. The chess match ending sequence(s) rivals anything the British TV show thinks is clever, with a nice nod to the books, and the action has a charged wit and an energy. These films are well tooled machines and I have to say I'd be excited for the cheeky retro-modern escapades in a third entry. No likes mariko2 partsnetflix21.00laptop COMMENT?

I had watched Despicable Me only so that I could finally understand what the whole deal with the minions was. But I ended up liking the movie and all the characters in that. As a result I decided to watch the sequel as well, which I ended up liking even more than the first one. So I thought why not just go all out and watch every single movie? And so I watched this one, and I really I think it was not something really great, although it did manage to do what it was meant to do: give us the laughs and have a good time. Despicable Me 3 is about Gru finding out about his estranged brother Dru who is living a very rich life but does not have the evil nature of Gru and thus is not liked as much by his family. And so grew is forced to take his brother along with him to stop the evil villain Balthazar Bratt, a child actor from the 80s who has faded away with time. Although the minions in this movie are way less than the previous two I don't mind this at all. In fact I kind of found them annoying and I wanted more of the human characters than those yellow Facebook meme sources. Balthazar is my favourite villain from this franchise. All his acts are very funny. Whenever he is on the screen you know you are in for some good time. There are often callbacks to his show which is very campy and has barred CGI according to today's times, which is just like how we see shows from the 80s today. He always dances and plays songs whenever he is out on the heist. It is fun to watch Gru and Balthazar fight in the opening scene and also the way Baltasar dances as he defeats all the guards on the ship. The animation of this movie is way better than the previous two, especially when it comes to the action scenes and car chasing. What this movie lacks in however, is the amount of campiness and cliched moments of having an amateur person come out on a secret mission along with the professional friend/family member. In fact the whole idea of the protagonist having an estranged twin brother is a cliched idea which has been used many times in Bollywood films. Although this isn't a very memorable movie, it does exactly what all the other movies from this franchise do. It is able to create a fantasy world with fun and loving characters who do goofy things and we enjoy them while it lasts. And this is the reason why I don't think this franchise should have more movies. By the time one movie comes we have already forgotten what happened in the previous one. Although I wouldn't say that this is a bad movie, I would definitely say that you would not remember anything other than the good parts once the movie ends, and this is the reason why this movie is so much fun to remember since I don't exactly remember what I didn't like about it.

Cinderella was full of interesting side characters, but if the main characters were a spice they'd be flour. This movie is widely claimed to be an inspiring 'girl power' flick, despite the prince continually sweeping Cinderella up and saving her from everything, the repeated lyric of 'love will save the day' and the prince continuing to pursue her after she turned him down. Cabello's Cinderella is just not the strong independent woman she is advertised as - she is a starry eyed dream girl who floats around waiting for other people to make her dreams come true. The music is comprised of pop songs everyone's already heard a thousand times and original lyrics that frankly make little to no sense. The ending feels sudden and unnatural, with the king's sudden changes of mind, and the story feels off. The dialogue is cringey and the representation is next to nought outside of the dancers and the occasional side character, like the Billy Porter fairy godmother - it feels like he's being used as comic relief or some sort of novel drag queen for the straights to laugh at.

Madagascar isn't a bad movie. I definitely think it has fun characters, funny scenes, quirky animation, and a talented voice acting and soundtrack. However the story is poorly paced. Too many things happen every second before I can even breathe when watching this movie. Aside from the pacing, like critics have said there's not really a moral to it either. I guess it does have some kind of lesson on friendship mostly between Alex and Marty, but it's barely used. And I get the ending was like a follow up to the sequel, but here it doesn't make much sense seeing the animals ditch the zoo and stay in Africa for a while knowing the zookeepers would eventually question it. It's a movie that's good with comedy, but not very good with the script.

Story/Screenplay: (4/5) A fun, family-oriented film that succeeds in telling the story about zoo animals escaping to the wilds of Madagascar. Original and funny. Duration/Tempo: (4/5) At 1 hour and 26 minutes, it's a very, very short movie that felt longer, but still short. Cast & Crew: (4/5) My fave voice acting goes out to Tom McGrath as Skipper the Penguin and Conrad Vernon as Mason the Chimpanzee. Both were small roles, but they were brilliant nonetheless. Overall, the cast performance was strong. Summary: (4/5) The story and cast were very good, and the film felt short. A thumbs up.

I watched this film about 4 years ago and I could not get through it. It disturbed me so much. I was not in a good space and it scared the hell out of me. I have not read the book or anything and we know how hard it can be to Adapted a screenplay from a book but the film on its own is very good. The biggest surprise is Brad Pitts acting. I think this is the beat thing he has done that I've seen. Every emotion is in his face. When They say less is more there right his performance is so spot on without all the extra garbage some actors give. The story you can say is like all other zombie movies but that's works because what else would be the story if it was not trying to find out where it came from or how to fight it. The fact that the zombies are fast just gave me anxiety because how would you fight it, they are too fast Unlike typical zombie movies with a walk so slow. I've seen this now about 4 times and I caught something new each time. You have to give Pitt and the director a lot of credit for making such a good film. Films are suppose to make us forget about all our problems and put you in another place. This film sure did that for me. I give it a solid A.

As Zombie movies go, this one stays within the lines of the "viral infection" genre; usually some percentage of people are immune, and they have the ability to run at full sprint and attack in a frenzied manner. Having said that, it does have some amazing scenes that I have never seen in a "zombie" movie before, favourite one being *spoiler warning* The zombies are drawn to the sound of singing inside the walls of Jerusalem, they start scaling the walls creating a huge mountain! That moment when you see them come up and over is so scary!

World War Z (Filmed on 2013) Brad Pitt plays a U.N. worker who must leave his family behind and go search for a cause or cure for a zombie outbreak that is pretty much destroying every form of life. On his mission he must travel across the globe trying to see what might work in the human's defense of the zombies. I'll admit upfront that I haven't read the book that this film is based on so I can't comment on if it butchered the book or if the film got it right. That aspect of the conversation just doesn't bother me but what does bother me is that we've got an insanely high budget and yet they couldn't work out some sort of interesting story. For the most part we just see Brad Pitt going from one beautiful location to the next and we see that the once beautiful place is now full of zombies. Every once in a while Mr. Pitt has to walk through dark hallways and what really hurts the film is that these sequences just aren't scary.

review_date: I love this movie because it‚Äôs nostalgia
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW

Pixar's first attempt at a princess story is about a Scottish princess named Merida who is at odds with her mother and inadvertently changes her mother into a bear in an attempt to change her fate. The Scottish landscape in the background is beautiful and adding to it some Scottish sounding music really sets the atmosphere of the film really well. The movie begins and ends with narration from Merida that felt to me like it was disconnected from the rest of the story, like they jammed the fate theme in at the last minute. The story is rooted in a lack of communication misunderstanding, and I'm not a big fan of that style of story. The backstory of Mor'du, the big bear, is fascinating and so well conceived they made a short about it. There is definitely enough good stuff in this film to recommend a viewing.

review_date: It's the same as Cars 2 but it has heart felt emotion and a beautiful mother and daughter beauty in it.
review: FLAG THIS REVIEW
Pixar making kingdom movies is certainly not their speciality of movies.

Brave wasn't that bad. The story is not Pixar's best, but it is certainly interesting. The main character Merida is a okay Disney Princess. She's not Belle or heck even Moana. But Merida is just okay. To me there's nothing that interesting about her, that makes her stand out from the rest. However that doesn't mean she doesn't get better towards the end of the movie though. When Merida is with her mother as a bear that's where she starts to get better and the movie starts to get interesting. Brave is at its best when Merida and her mother bear starts to communicate with each other. That's wear the heart and character development comes into play. It shows that the mother really did care for her child but the only reason why she was so strict with her is that she just simply want the best for her. The mother is actually the best character in this movie considering the fact that she does go through most of the development of like I said earlier actually showing that she cares for her daughter. Also I really love how the animation on the bear's facial expression she never talks while she's a bear witch makes it more interesting and engaging to watch. While Brave might not be Pixar's best it still is a charming and surprisingly intense movie. 7.8

Doesn't do enough to break the princess mold and feels more Disney than Pixar. The plot is thin, seems like the whole thing could have been avoided if she talked to her Dad. Animation and voice acting is good though

This movie isn't as bad as I remember‚Ä¶but I don't think that makes this movie good. First, all the good things. The animation and voice acting, like the majority of the Pixar films, is great. The setting of medieval Scotland is actually a lot more interesting and imaginative that I remember. The monologues\speeches that Merida gives are a little cliche, but still pretty good. And the her shooting for her own hand is easily the best scene from this movie. Now: problems. None of the characters are really done that greatly, but Merida isn't really that good of a person. She keeps blaming a witch for all the problems she has done, and that gets really annoying after awhile. The king and queen are fine, the witch is fine, the little boys are fine, it's really Merida that I have a problem with, that and the villain. Mordu isn't bad in anyway, just kind of boring. The two biggest negative things for me is the story and the twist. The story isn't as cool as it was set up to be in the trailers. I'm sorry, I don't come to Pixar to watch a child and parent disagreement story. If I'm going anywhere to watch that, I'll just rewatch Mitchells vs the Machines again. Now, the twist. It seemed like a good idea on paper, and it comes close in some aspects, but it's not executed as well as it could be. And that's how I would describe the film as well. The good parts are there, but they are just too scattered to make this a good movie. I have to be kinder to it because it had a troubled production, but it's still one of the weaker Pixar movies and easily the worse Disney princess movie ever made, I can't deny that. If you want to say you watched all of them, I guess it's fine. But if you're hoping for a good movie, sadly, I would have to say skip.

Really enjoyed this movie. Still beautiful animation 8 years later and the story holds up as well. Breathtaking scenery shots. Story very deep and touching but with plenty of silly humor to keep everyone entertained and as an adult even the slapstick humor rarely felt like too much and was actually pretty funny. Main character is forced to grow up, take responsibility, and put other's needs before her own. Shows how people can change and how sometimes the people we feel are villains really aren't evil - both mother and daughter are shown as complex humans warts and all. For a change, no one had to die or fall in love for the character arcs to evolve.

Brave is a 2012 animated comedy-fantasy film directed by Mark Andrews and Brenda Chapman.It is the 13th Pixar film,and certainly a great one as their previous. Brave follows Merida the daughter of Scottish King Fergus and Queen Elinor.She is a skilled archer who wants to make her own fate in life and pursue her own dreams.She is then forced to get married,as the tradition requires at a certain age but she is in her own mind and seeks help from a witch to change the fate and be her own person in life. This movie is amazing,from the glorious animation to the characters who are likable just as much as they are interesting.Merida is a strong female lead character who chooses her own path in life and makes her own decisions for herself.She has dreams and most importantly is "brave" enough to pursue them till the very end.She's also smart and Kelly Macdonald's voice work just helps the cause with her amazing Scottish Accent. The story is very interesting and intriguing while still being emotional that gives depth to the characters.But it also has funny moments throughout,even though the finale is very dark and also even sad which in my opinion is great. People has been complaining about the twist over and over again and how it is more of a kids film than for adults,which Pixar is used to making.But I disagree because while it is an absolute treat for kids,it is also dark at times,it has adult jokes here and there and what's very important,it has character development at its finest.The place where Merida and different characters in the movie are at the beginning and where they end up is just brilliant and life changing.The lessons they learn through their adventures,them being good or bad,and the way that this movie teaches people that we can make our own fate if we are brave enough to follow our hearts,that makes for an unforgettable experience

Trainwreck of a film. Merida is unlikable and bratty, the dad and the kids are genuinely annoying, a witch with magical abilities that aren't explained, and horrible humor. The queen is not as horrible as Merida but still terrible as a character, but the plot is strong enough I guess. Overall, don't waste your time with this
So stupid, the worst Pixar movie.
It's had it's funny and dramatic moments but overall it's just a fine movie

An exciting protagonist isn't enough to carry a film rife with slapstick humor and undercooked plotlines. Pixar rarely submits tepid entries, and perhaps if this film carried a different studio's logo it would have retained another half-star, but this film falls short of the line that they've drawn for themselves over the years.

Disney's 'Brave' is a fun and magical journey with loveable characters and a great script. The animation is very well done and the film accomplishes many things such as the female and Scottish representation. It's lovely to see a princess who does not require the help of male characters to accomplish a victory. The film still has the potential to do more world building and some aspects of the film seem rushed.

It's very noticeable that this movie used this trend of showing a different image of princesses and, well, as it's the 21st century, it's what we needed anyway. It uses that story formula where the main character is a rebellious person that then has to face consequences for their actions. Then the movie ends with family reconciliation giving good morals to children and at the same time making adults happy for this. And mixing this with those Scottish provocative themes, we get a satisfactory result thanks to Pixar's successful formula.
My absolute favorite. Great music, characters, story, love Scotland. A must have in your collection

review: Irvin Kershner's "The Empire Strikes Back" is an ambitious, heartfelt and soulful sci-fi classic that stands the test of time as crowning jewel of the Star Wars franchise. With the second Star Wars film, Kershner took the series in a dark direction by expanding on the timeless themes of the original. Using spellbinding cinematography, Kershner draws viewers into an apprentice's journey towards conquering his invasive enemy in a far-away galaxy. Kershner's decision to employ practical effects over CGI to recreate cartoonish characters pays off tremendously. It lends authenticity and realism to the movie's motion-capture characters missing from recent entries in the franchise. Kershner showcases extraordinary control over production design, action sequences and score, using these elements to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. Lawrence Kasdan's screenplay is also superb, and expertly utilizes cross-cutting storytelling to convey a Jedi's quest towards glory. It's hard to not admire phenomenal performances. Mark Hamill delivers one of his greatest career performances as Luke Skywalker. With spellbinding expressions, he conveys determination, heroism and parental regrets of a novice jedi that struggles to come to terms with his mysterious ancestry. Harrison Ford is equally fantastic in the role of a suave smuggler that relies on wits to outsmart enemies in the galaxy. Ford brings undeniably stylish swagger to one of his most iconic roles that turned him into a star. The final, most noteworthy standout in the cast is James Earl Jones. As the menacing Sith Lord Darth Vader, he brings shades of sympathy to one of the most reprehensible movie villains. Besides technical aspects, the final component of "The Empire Strikes Back" that contributes to its success is its message. Unlike other films in the franchise, the movie tackles emotional themes of destiny, legacy and parental regrets that make it the most meaningful Star Wars movie. Nearly 40 years after its release, it remains a sparkling lightsaber whose force inspires movie-goers to trek across galaxies in soaring millenium falcons even if shocking secrets about father figure enemies are written in their phantom of menace destinies.
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back

review: The pacing of the middle chunk of this movie is slow; it's deliberate but certainly a bit of a drag when rewatching this movie from time to time. And there -- I've just done the impossible: I just worked out the one genuine grievance I can give to this movie. Beyond that, The Empire Strikes Back is rightfully cemented in the categories of Best Action Movie Ever, Best Sci-Fi Movie Ever, and Best Sequel Ever, as this movie is, beyond my grievance above, about as close to Cinematic Perfection as we may ever see. It explores the hidden depths of A New Hope and actually builds upon it with material that is even more interesting and engaging than in the first movie, and throw in that this is the Second Act movie, where the heroes are at their lowest, this movie features some emotional gut-punches that the first movie simply does not have. While the first movie made Darth Vader a memorable and intimidating villain, this movie escalates him to being possibly the single greatest Movie Villain of all time, as he is not only immensely powerful, he is shown to be smarter and more unrelenting than we (the audience) previously thought. Along with that, the Empire is shown to be more effective than they appeared in the first movie, with the AT-ATs being one of the most memorable Sci-Fi Action creations ever, even if they are a bit impractical. The main thing is that this movie genuinely ramps up the tension of almost every situation because you truly believe, more than in the first movie, that the heroes are often times in genuine danger. This makes the final action sequence the most intense, despite the fact that it's actually the least complex in regards to execution. On that note, the two big setpieces: the Battle on Hoth and the Asteroid Chase, are both absolutely stellar, pun intended, making EXCELLENT use of this sequel's increased budget, alongside some excellent action design. And perhaps the biggest accomplishment of all is that this movie features genuinely impactful emotional beats at the end, with what is easily one of Cinema's greatest twists of all time, and ends on a note of genuine hope, despite an ever-increasing somber and dire tone. It's considered a masterpiece by many because it is a masterpiece, and for what it does, there are almost no other movies in existence that does it as good, let alone better.

review: One of the greatest sequels in cinema history and without a doubt the best Star Wars movie to date! Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back does everything its predecessor did and so much more. If we go by the criteria of what makes a good sequel, it passes with flying colours. It expands the universe of the original in new and meaningful ways by introducing fresh new planets like Hoth and Bespin and some of the best characters in the entire franchise: Lando, Yoda, Boba Fett and of course Palpatine. It continues the story of the original by taking the next logical step, having Luke face off with Darth Vader and making their dynamic and conflict even more interesting by revealing that they're related. It expands on the themes of the original by showing what the Light and Dark side truly represent and how they differ. And finally, it undoubtedly leaves a positive impact on the franchise by being a masterpiece and being at the center of everything that has yet to come. For how this movie stands on its own, it's magnificent, Luke, Leia and Han all go through excellent arcs and all learn from their mistakes in a way that is interesting and compelling to watch. Darth Vader still has the same presence he had in A New Hope and they set up his return to the light extremely well by having someone more evil than him, making his eventual turn more realistic. The action sequences were a delight to watch, from the battle of Hoth, to the final fight between Luke and Vader, you can't help but marvel at the splendor you're experiencing. The special effects they used were revolutionary, from the usage of paintings to create large, beautiful landscapes to the puppeteering done by Frank Oz, all of it has aged like fine wine. The acting has improved drastically from the original, Mark Hamill is much more likeable as Luke Skywalker and Harrison Ford is more sympathetic but still maintains that hint of contumacious. The chemistry our main trio shared in the original transfers over to the sequel flawlessly, it's even more fun to watch them bicker and argue this time around. Last but not least, this movie's highest of highs is its climax. The fight between Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker, while not the flashiest fight in the franchise, manages to deliver on a tense fight that holds an immense amount of dramatic weight. Han Solo freezing in carbonite was also something no other movie dared to do at the time, having the heroes lose the battle and have one of the heroes seemingly die was extraordinary and wasn't just there for shock factor as it weaves itself seamlessly into the grander picture. Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back isn't just a movie, its George Lucas' magnum opus. It truly is the grandmaster of the franchise!

review: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back is a fine example of how to do a sequel well. With its predecessor Star Wars being instantly recognised as a watershed movie and an absolute classic, a follow up film was always going to have gigantic cinematic shoes to fill. Thankfully, new director Irvin Kershner does a marvellous job with Lucas' new story, and the talented team at ILM perform their magic once again to help bring the world of Star Wars back to life. All the cast are reunited in this film, which would not have been nearly as good if any of them had declined to return. The Empire Strikes Back is story evolution, not a repeat of old material or a re-telling of the same story, which is what you get in so many inferior movie sequels. The film's opening sequences firmly establish the two key story arcs in Star Wars - Luke's journey to becoming a Jedi, as well as his relationship to Darth Vader, and Leia's emerging relationship with Han Solo. What follows is high adventure, taking us to incredible new places and introducing fantastic new characters from the Star Wars universe, culminating in another epic fight scene with Darth Vader, but this time against the enthusiastic young Luke Skywalker. The sets, special effects, miniature model work, props and costumes are all faultless, and Frank Oz's puppetry work with Yoda is first rate. John William's masterpiece score shines through again, perfectly encapsulating the mood of each scene. Personally, I much prefer the original theatrical version compared to the modern Lucas cut with added CGI features. It is no surprise that Empire Strikes Back tops the list for many moviegoers, as either the best Star Wats film or even the best film ever.

It's fun. I grew up on The Simpsons. They've been a part of my entertainment life since I can remember. Back in the 90s, I used to tape the episodes on those old cheap blank VHS tapes. I'm pretty biased and have an emotional connection to the whole Simpsons universe. But even if I didn't, I think I could still enjoy this one.

I've never really been a fan of "The Simpsons", not even during its glory days in the early 1990's, so I can review this movie on its own merits. In fact, I rented it to watch with my girlfriend who likes the show more than I do. She didn't seem to get too excited over it either. Basically, the story is about Homer adopting a pig and causing it to mutate, and he accidentally poisons Springfield's water supply with its excrement. He and his family are run out of town, but soon afterward the EPA learns of this and the Schwarzenegger-like US President is convinced to put a giant dome over Springfield to prevent the pollution from spreading. Homer and his wife and kids, already outside of Springfield, travel around and eventually decide to do something about the dome. Besides its length, the only difference between this movie and any regular Simpsons TV episode is that you get to see Bart's genitalia during the skateboarding scene toward the beginning. This movie has nothing in it for anyone other than Simpsons fans, if even them.

The Simpsons Movie - 8/10. The Simpsons Movie, coming a few decades after the iconic show had started, is still a very fun film encompassing the main tenants of why the show is revered. Having the whole family and Springfield gang in the film, the citizens have to deal with an environmental disaster, with the Simpson family needing to help change the fate of the city to get things back to normal. Borrowing some themes and storylines from some of its more iconic episodes, The Simpsons Movie does a fairly great job of satisfying long time fans and also new viewers who have never seen the show. Its iconic comedic style of blending biting satire and also classic humour is on display throughout the film. The Simpsons is one of my favourite shows of all time, and it always does a great job of mixing great emotion with its humour. For a show that is so reliant on making episodes that are different from each other, and not following through a long story arc, the film does a good job of creating a story that won't affect any sort of continuity or story arc. Though I do wish it was a film that explored more of Springfield, its still a fun time and a great watch!

Forgive this forward, but I literally watched all 31 seasons because I was sick and have never understood what the fuss was about the Simpsons. I really have to conclude that the appeal of the Simpsons was a simple lack of options when it first came out, and then it just grew in power by simply existing for so long. For this movie: Uninspired watch, probably won't watch again, and can't recommend, unless you're already a Simpsons fan. It's really just a lot of the Simpsons being Simpsons, but that also means that the overall story writing is actually pretty good, even if the character writing is rather repetitive. I did enjoy the introduction of Ploppers, Spider-Pig, but it doesn't really even out everything else. The big adversity is an "under the dome" scenario, which is actually interesting enough to explore, but because it's the Simpsons, we know that nothing ultimately interesting is going to happen, and that everything is going to resolve like its TV counterpart. Now, that said, the TV show does drop unexpected, unexplainable shifts, like the death of characters. I don't think Fox was brave enough to put such a thing in the movie, which would have completely changed the gravity of the movie. It's fine, it's well produced, it's just not very interesting, and I don't think I'd ever watch it again unless I was binging the Simpsons again, and wanted to watch it in order.

Honestly, there's not too much to say beyond that: It's fun but more somber and serious than I would have liked, the technical accomplishments are quite solid and the cast, while not exactly engaging in highly demanding roles, are generally quite good. Fortunately, the movie does remember to have fun in the big climax where the titular Meg attacks a super populated beach, and the ways that Statham kills it would make Chev Chellios proud.

Is this film good? No. But is this film enjoyable? Also no. Shark films have a bit of a notorious reputation for being bad. Just look at titles such as Sharknado, Sand Sharks and the Shark Attack series. With a film like Jaws shining as the example of how good these films can be, none have been able to reach anywhere near that level. While this film doesn't reach the same Marianas Trench depth level of bad as Shark Attack 3: Megalodon, it certainly isn't one of the better shark films (I'm not sure if it'd even make my top 5). There are some fun moments throughout and OTT action sequences. However, this doesn't really make up for the awful dialogue, cringey attempts at humour and overall absurdity of the whole thing. I suppose you can't really expect high art from a giant shark film starring Jason Statham but at least make it enjoyably bad or embrace a darker tone and go for that R rating. I did appreciate the Jaws references though.

If you want to watch a shark movie where everything works and will leaving you hanging on the edge of your seat, watch Jaws. If you want to watch a shark movie that is so outlandishly and deliberately over the top that it's laughable, watch Sharknado. The problem with The Meg is that it tries to tip-toe on the line between the two and fails miserably. Even if you can get past the dizzying camerawork, the frantic editing, and an abundance of dopey dialogue, good luck accepting the idiotic storyline. It's a tale filled with more logic-defying close calls than imaginable and a surprising number of marine biologists who can't seem to stop themselves from falling out of boats. Top it off with one of the most implausible endings ever and you'll be left shaking your head in disbelief when the final credits roll.

review: Ralph and Vanellope venture into the internet to find a part to fix Venellope's game. This film does not follow the video game format from the original, instead focusing on an internet experience filled with meta and self-referential humor. While it was great to see Disney characters interact with one another, I do wonder how this movie's meta humor will age. While everything that goes wrong in this movie is Ralph's fault, he does kinda make up for it? As expected, the animation is top notch and the voice acting is on par with the first movie with Gal Gadot and Taraji P. Henson being a welcome addition. There are some truly funny moments and a heartfelt message at the end. A movie worth your time.

review: As Wreck-it Ralph is one of my favorite movies, I felt like the sequel failed Ralph's character. The first movie was all about Ralph proving himself and finding out his place in the world. But then the sequel throws all that away. I could barely watch the final fight scene because I felt so strong second hand embarrassment. Part of what made the first movie so good were the great side characters, Felix and sergeant Calhoun, but they weren't relevant in the sequel. Which would be fine, if they had a good reason to do so and other things to make up for it, but they didn't. Besides, the movie relies too much on references to pop culture. When the most memorable scene of the movie is the one where Vanellope meets the other princesses, I feel like it really failed at delivering the message.

rt_name: Ralph Breaks the Internet - Movie Reviews

review: I really liked Wreck-It Ralph back when I saw it. Ever since then I had been waiting for a sequel. Somehow I had a hunch that one will be made. And here it was: Ralph Breaks the Internet. I was expecting it to be something about gaming again but since it was more inclined towards the internet instead of gaming and also seemed to be more targeted towards children than the OG fans, I decided to skip it. Then 2 years ago I suddenly decided to watch it and now I really like it. Of course it's not as good as the original, but that could be said about any Disney movie. Ralph Breaks the Internet is set after the events of Wreck-It Ralph, except that Felix is divorced and Ralph continues to hang around with everyone else outside the games, until the point where he pulls a complete Disney character and ends up breaking Sugar Rush arcade's steering wheel. Now Ralph and Vanellope are out to get the steering wheel from eBay to stop the arcade game from being thrown out. It's what The Emoji Movie could have been like if it wasn't bad. Disney movies always have good animations, those which can make anyone go nostalgic. And here there are several Disney characters shown on the internet in 3D like the Disney princesses (they gave my little one a rush; if you know what I mean XD), MCU characters, Star Wars etc. So in case you wanted to know what they'd look like as 3D animated characters, this is the best place you can see them. The sense of humour was also very good. Character development, however, is the bad part. It was only driven by "Ralph didn't want to lose Vanellope". The story isn't that good either; it's plagued with product placement. Plus there are many popular game characters like Sonic (yay!), Eggman, Bowser, Pac-Man ghosts etc. I'd have been happier if the sequel to Wreck-It Ralph was about gaming more instead of the internet, since that's the community among whom the prequel liked. It's a good movie, just not a good sequel. Let's hope the third movie gets back to the roots, since this looked more like a PSA for kids on how to use the internet.

review: This film should've been way better than it was. There were many plot holes, the Disney princess scene was unnecessary feminist propaganda, and the B plot involving the Sugar Rush racers was essentially ignored. Felix and Calhoun were absent for most of the film, Vanellope goes turbo and breaks the rules of the first film, and the characters from the first film are out of character. Ralph suddenly thinks it's ok to unleash a virus in a video game when he fought one to save Sugar Rush in the previous movie upon knowing how dangerous viruses are. Vanellope becomes so selfish that she prioritizes Slaughter Race over saving her game and her people, and the movie doesn't call her out on her actions like it does with Ralph. Also, the Sugar Rush racers were reformed at the end of the first film and each racer had a distinct personality, so there was no need to reduce them to moody 5 year-olds for the sake of a forgotten B plot. Couldn't the directors have instead showcased their reformed personalities and their new relationship with Vanellope and Ralph in a storyline that actually worked for the franchise? As a fan of the first film, I feel as though the writers forgot everything that had happened in the first film. I was sorely disappointed with this unworthy follow-up and only consider the first film canon. If you are a fan of the first film like myself, I recommend that you refrain from watching this sorry excuse of a sequel.

This movie is a cash grab at best and basically the emoji movie with Disney's name on it and Wreck it Ralph characters in it. review: This movie really is a weak entry in the modern era of a Disney films. As of writing this review it is December 2020 and this movie has already aged terribly. The moment you add memes or internet trends to a film, it becomes essentially a period piece, the movies then-relevant topics are now outdated and irrelevant. Also, quite frankly it doesn't make sense that Disney Princesses are in the film. If Disney exists, does that mean Wreck It Ralph is a movie too, 2 years on and it's still difficult to wrap my head around. Skip this Disney adaptation of the emoji movie and just watch the first one.

review: The animation was great, the voice cast was amazing, and just seeing how they depicted the internet was the best part. While it was really fun to see how the internet world looks like in the eyes of our characters, I feel that they relied on it too much, as well as some parts feeling pretty unnecessary like Ralph reading the comments when trying to go viral. I get it was trying to send a message, but they could figure out some ways to cut time. I also wish they would have spent more time on Felix and Calhoun's storyline instead of consistently on Ralph and Vanellope's story. Still, it was a pretty good movie and sequel; Disney and Wreck-it-Ralph fans will be pleased with the movie.

review: I really love the Hotel Transylvania movies, as there is a lot of mythology in them. This one has Poseidon/Neptune (Gaffigan), the Kraken/Kaliyanaag (also the symbol for cryptocurrency fyi), and the caduceus/staff of Mercury/Kundalini. The moment with the Kaliyanaag-Kraken is straight out of Hindu mysticism, as the Krishna stand-in (Sandler's Dracula) dances on the head of the sea monster to stop it from eating everyone. This is about the sea people (Ericka/Poseidon-Neptune) versus the monsters running the dream sand hotel, and can't we just all get along? Apparently we can. The filmmakers just don't show the marriage between these camps, as the movie wraps with no sign of Ericka, and yet there is an engagement on the table...

review: Favourite movie out of the trilogy. The animation was very good and colourful, and gave the whole movie a very lighthearted and fun feel. The way the new characters looked was very enjoyable too. The music in this one didn't feel like it was just randomly thrown in, it was written to be in the movie. The music overall was very catchy, well known, and fun. It almost makes you feel like you want to get up and dance. Out of the three movies, this one had a proper plot and a villain that had a backstory. It felt like the characters had a purpose; defeating the villain. I also enjoyed the idea of giving each character something to do in this movie. Just like the other two, this film had some jokes that weren't quite laugh out loud, and others which older kids+ wouldn't be amused by. Overall this would be a great movie to watch with the family due to its light hearted tone.

review_date: Alright, I‚Äôm done with these movies. My wife likes them for some reason, but I am so sick of this nonsense. The first Hotel Transylvania was terrible, the second had some moderately redeeming qualities, but this third chapter is just irritating. I cannot take any more of that stupid voice Adam Sandler uses for Dracula. In small doses it can be kind of funny when he uses it in a live action film or when he‚Äôd use it back on SNL, but he pulls that obnoxious stuff for the entire runtime of these movies. The humor of monster things in place of their human versions is so overplayed at this point, and that‚Äôs really the only jokes they have for this film. I guess there are a few moments of physical comedy that work, simply because I like watching these characters‚Äô hurting, but that‚Äôs about it. The plot is so predictable that I literally called it within less than 10 minutes, and my wife got mad that I was spoiling the movie. It doesn‚Äôt help that they have a completely irrelevant opening sequence that tips their hand so even a small child could probably guess who‚Äôs going to be the villain in the story. They attempt to include some subplots in Hotel Transylvania 3, yet they manage to make them so insignificant and pointless that I couldn‚Äôt understand why they were included. Like the little kids bringing a giant dog. Was there a point to this other than having the dog there to help out a little in the final scene? What about the stupid family of 5000 wolves? Nope, just an occasional aside to remind us that they have some time without their obnoxious furballs. Even the climax is moronic, as it drags on for way too long, and I kept begging for it to stop. Then it ends with a lame pop culture reference that is older than most of the kids who enjoy these awful movies. Writing this kind of bad film-making off as a mindless kids‚Äô movie no longer flies with me. There have been too many great movies that appeal to young children, but also are solid enough to keep adults from ripping their hair out. This kind of bargain basement nonsense is barely good enough to qualify for a direct-to-video release. I would recommend everyone avoid Hotel Transylvania...all of them!

review: I guess we are back. So Tim (James Marsden) is no longer a child threatened by his infant brother Ted (Alec Baldwin). Tim has a family of his own now: a wife (Eva Longoria) and two daughters (Ariana Greenblatt, Amy Sedaris). One of his daughters is a boss baby in her own right, and she makes Ted enter the picture again to stop a plot involving babies eliminating parents. Of course, there is no other way to counter this but to have the two brothers take a serum that will turn them back into children again to infiltrate a school headed by a nefarious principal (Jeff Goldblum), and yes, I am well aware of how insane this sounds. Now I was pretty neutral on the first Boss Baby. I thought it was passable, but I never for one minute thought it was something you could build a series upon. Hollywood is going to Hollywood, and when something overachieves with financial success, you're going to go back to the well until it runs dry. Rest assured, in case you couldn't already figure it out: that was a bad call. To me, this is a prime example of everything Dreamworks regularly catches flack for. It's too much emphasis on cheap visual gags, it is chaotic, and they don't spend more than the bare minimum amount of time needed to pen a script. I mean really, just go back and reread my attempt at a plot synopsis to identify that writing was never a point of emphasis. An assumption was made by the creators that their intended audience has ADHD, so they opted to make a story that perpetually crashes forward with reckless abandon like the boulder in Raiders of the Lost Ark. The animators are overexcited, and the kids in this will frequently move like the villain in Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 for no reason at all, which was something that I frequently found to be grating. Even before I hit the halfway point of this, this movie had made me physically tired. I'm not even exaggerating when I say that it made me feel like I should have just gone to bed early to catch up on some sleep. The most frustrating thing I found about this is that when it calms down to let everyone breathe for a moment, there are some sweet moments to be had. There is a father-daughter bonding moment with music that I think worked quite well around the midpoint, and I could have used a lot more of that throughout. Granted, I can count these sweet moments on one hand, which is why I can't award more points than I would like to. I don't know how preteens will react, but I think that only the youngest of audiences will get anything out of this. I predict that everyone else will grow weary the longer this goes on, and I can't say that I blame them. This is a movie that should have been scrapped in preproduction if we are being completely honest, and the creative integrity featured is nothing more than a handful of scraps at the most. The Boss Baby: Family Business is a cash grab that is not worthy of your time.
rt_name: The Boss Baby: Family Business - Movie Reviews

review: Fantastic movie, would be an amazing family watch and it is a funny and fun ride, nothing too forced, just a nice watch. You don't see it often anymore so it was really refreshing. Again, if you can't find anything to watch, shove it on the screen and lose yourself for an hour and a half. Then spend the next two days reminiscing on your childhood. Recommended!

These themes were obviously picked up on by the legacy media lefty critics here on RT thus the disparity between the audience score and the critics score. When in doubt audience score rules

review: It slow & steady affair surrounding the famous beach
Classic war film that doesn't change history to appease the woke crowd. Truly breathtaking and vividly beautiful.

Absolutely magnificent in its gritty, realistic take on the true story of the Battle of Dunkirk. Hans Zimmer's score was utterly gripping and kept with the theme of time. The fact that it sounds more and more like a clock speeding up keeps you on the edge of your seat. Christopher Nolan delivers in everyway as always. The acting down to the minor roles are flawless. If you want to know what living with Severe Anxiety is like, watch this movie haha.
Amazing way to tell a story.

As a war movie, this movie is fine. But that's all I can give it. I can't help but get thrown out of the movie due to the films overall structure. The hopping from time to time and trying to decipher where things are happening chronologically is something that I'm not a huge fan of in movies in general. If done correct, in my eyes, it does add tension to a movie but, I felt that this movie did not do it well. The action is brutal and let you know the horrors of war. Having said that I feel that this movie could have done better if we actually were able to connect with a protagonist. I know that's not the point of this movie but, I think that would've worked better in my eyes.
I would say this is a good movie to understand what happened at Dunkirk. But it really doesn't show how the Nazis decided to spare the English troops leaving Dunkirk. But a great quality of cinima.

I love Christopher Nolan as a director but Dunkirk is one of his lesser movies. The plot of the movie was really missing and thats why I don't rate it higher. But if you take the plot out of the picture it is a really good movie.

A good film spoilt by the completely Anglocentric focus throughout. There is no focus on the Battle of Lille without which Dunkirk wouldn't even be a thing, or at the very least have a different outcome. Nor a focus on the rescued French soldiers who returned to the front. Nearly crosses over into the realms of patriotic delusion, albeit the reality of the terror and fear is well done...Dunkirk was a rout and should be shown as such...the story is not Britain's alone.

Christopher Nolan sets a beautiful setting for what it was like for soldiers when this event occurred and tells the story in 3 parts so profoundly that it sticks together like hot glue. Atmosphere is what Nolan did best and it creates a sense of fear and stillness like non I've seen before. A must see, though my only criticism is that some ( and by some I mean 1 or 2) events are not entirely realistic, other than that, I beg you to see this.

review_date: I love WWII movies but I couldn‚Äôt get into this movie. One, the events are out of order which was confusing at times. Two, there‚Äôs very little dialogue which hinders character development. The only characters I found myself caring about were the father and son on the rescue boat. Which, upon reflection, were the characters that had the most dialogue. Still, I kept watching, hoping there would be some sort of payoff at the end and, while I suppose there was a small one, it was not one that made up for the two hours I had invested.
review: SHOW MORE

I really wanted to like this movie. A slice of WWII history I knew little about. But this just isn't presented well. I didn't care about the characters. The story never built up to get me to feel any emotion. Also feels like the scenes are out of sequence, which became confusing. It also made it hard to tell a consistent story as the movie went on. I ended up just being bored.
One of the best war movies I have ever seen

Dunkirk is a solid war film and a must-watch for any Nolan enthusiasts or war film purest, but for a Director who I had always said, "Christopher Nolan should make a World War 2 movie" and who had the perfect style of dark, gritty, and envelope-pushing material...I sure was let down by this movie. Upon first viewing, this movie can be needlessly confusing, which is nothing new for a Nolan film but where movies like Interstellar, Inception, or Memento can benefit from being a little confusing forcing the audience to figure it out themselves. But a war film like Dunkirk doesn't really benefit from this style of storytelling, it's a very suspenseful movie at times but loses all of that by not delivering on any consequences for the characters.
A absolutely stunning picture. Great use of sound design and mixing. The aerial footage is the best I've ever seen in a film. Accompanied by a beautiful score as well.

This is a fantastic war film. It sets out to give the viewer an accurate depiction of war, without gratuitous violence yet without whitewashing. It's not the war fought by heroes, but that of ordinary people. It captures the fear and suspense any ordinary man has, as the characters panic and hold on for dear life. And though some of the soldiers are not especially heroic (almost all except Tom Hardy's Farrier), you are left with an optimistic view for the future of mankind.

The individual characters are not very interesting, and the scope of the conflict is a bit jarring and lacking at times, but Christopher Nolan's jaw dropping use of practical effects and effectiveness at instilling suspense make Dunkirk a damn good movie

Dunkirk is an intermission from the Nolan sci-fi craziness of Interstellar, Inception, and Tenet in favour of a gripping addition to the period war film genre showing that this genre has some life in it yet. Critics constantly hound Nolan for his weak dialogue, and Dunkirk largely foregoes dialogue in favour of atmosphere to the film's benefit. The cast sink into their roles with efficacy. Who would have expected Branagh to star alongside Harry Styles? Nolan maintains the suspense throughout the entire process by delivering varied angles of the titular event, but mentions must go to Zimmer's score and Van Hoytema's cinematography. The director's practical effects and other trademarks for visual flair mean that Dunkirk always remains interesting and often excels through splendid cast, pacing, and ambition.
Best bloodless WWII film I've ever seen.
A good movie, but one that is not fixated in character development.

The level of tension and uneasiness which the ticking score not-so-quietly instills, combined with the amazing cinematography and Nolan-esque shifting time scenes made this an amazing movie experience in the cinema, whilst appreciating the mostly-non-CGI scenes which honestly radiate the effort which such a production would entail. Definitely a must watch!

This film was utterly absorbing and brilliant. Eschewing many of the standard war-film creative devices, "Dunkirk" delivers an immersive and realistic recreation of the 1940 Dunkirk evacuation of the British Expeditionary Force during the fall of France to the Nazi Blitzkrieg onslaught. From the very beginning of the film, the audience is thrown right into the fray of three storylines revolving around the evacuation and never truly allowed a rest. From dodging German bullets in the streets, cowering from dive-bombers on the beaches, and having ships sink from under us, to sailing to Dunkirk as a civilian volunteer, to flying a Spitfire fighter trying to protect the operation from German aircraft, the legend of Dunkirk is explored superbly. The immersion is very much helped by the film being shot at Dunkirk itself in the ground storyline, on open water for the sea storyline, and in the air with genuine World War II warbirds in the air storyline. There are some elements that detracted from the film, however. Director Christopher Nolan's aversion to CGI makes the filmed experience impeccable but forces the film to include a Dunkirk far too intact and clean than it was in real life, anachronistic ships, and too few men to truly resemble the real Dunkirk. Nonetheless, the film captures the terrifying and intense atmosphere excellently.

Three parallel stories, but none of them were really impressive. They also prefer to call the enemy as "the enemy" and not Germans! I was expecting a more impressive movie from such a sensitive subject.
Best artistic war movie. A visual wonder!
