Not your common war movies. Intense psychological and suspenseful sequences. Another Nolan's time-bending masterpiece. Great cerebral flick but not too hard to piece the concept together.

I watch a film every day. I love films. It's been my thing since I was a kid. I remember when my mom bought me a DVD player for my bedroom when I was a teen, before most people had one in their living rooms. I say that because as a someone who loves film it's hard to explain to people the difference between films you like, films you love, and films you feel people have to see. I try not to waste people's time so I choose to mention the last category. Dunkirk is such a film. I need to carefully choose where to start. Why do I love this film? For starters there is how unusual it is. Upon watching this film you may not notice but this is one of the weirdest war movies ever made. Most war films have large battle sequences. Dunkirk is a character driven film set during a war. Think "Saving Private Ryan" (another film everyone must see,) but as a suspense thriller character piece where the war is outside the story. This film only wants you to care for the characters and not the action. It's weird, it's contradictory to studio thinking, and it's counter productive to any film maker looking to make money, but it is genius. The second thing I love is the time jumps. Upon first watching this film I didn't understand the time jumps and I didn't fully appreciate the film. It's actually three films. It's a film about a port which takes place during the course of a week. It's a film about a boat captain going to rescue troops which takes place during a day. Last, it's a film about a fighter pilot which takes place during an hour. This is Nolan. Every film Nolan manages to bend time and perplex his audience during at least a couple of sequences. This time he does it for the entire film. The last thing I love about this film is the characters and the themes. This isn't a war film that glorifies war. This isn't a film about heroes, even though there are a couple. This is a film that shows human beings in a situation where they will most likely die and it revels in the tension and passions that rise up from such a situation. This is one of the finest scripts ever filmed carried by some really great performances. Tom Hardy, Kenneth Branagh, even fucking Harry Styles is knocking it out of the park. This movie has some amazing acting in it and it's backed up by an amazing director with an amazing script. See this movie.

Dunkirk: Hope in the midst of loss. This week I'll be taking a look at the stunning war film Dunkirk. Written and directed by Christopher Nolan, it features a large ensemble cast including Fionn Whitehead, Tom Glynn-Carney, Mark Rylance, Kenneth Branagh and Tom Hardy. The film recounts the historical events of the evacuation of the French town of Dunkirk after it had been surrounded by the German forces, trapping more than 400,000 British soldiers on the beaches. The narrative follows three different perspectives of the event; young soldiers trapped on the beach, one of the many civilian vessels that sailed toward Dunkirk on a rescue mission and two pilots trying to protect British ships from German Luftwaffe planes. The thing that struck me the most from the outset of this film is the incredible technical achievement that it is and especially in nonlinear visual storytelling. The editing especially is so precise, well paced and consistent that even though the three story lines are happening at different times and sometimes even overlap, the flow of the narrative is never confusing or very hard to follow. Using barely any computer generated effects, there was no cheating on the structure and flow of the film's visuals and it presented a unique challenge to the editing team. Incorporating a complex element of balancing a weeks worth of action for the land, a day for the sea and an hour for the air added to the list of unique challenges bringing the film together would pose. Overall I was struck by how great the post production was on this film and how necessary being great was for the film to actually work. Making a film that breaks so many narrative rules and structures into a powerful yet still entertaining blockbuster is a feat that only spot on editing could have accomplished. Large and sweeping in scope while maintaining a sense of dire urgency and dread, the film deftly balances it's numerous elements to create a truly engrossing and moving experience. With time running out and losses getting heavier, the film portrays the situation that the men of Dunkirk had to go through by telling the fictional stories of three different groups and stirringly portrays their struggle to keep their courage and hope alive in the face of death. Dunkirk creates it's tense and desperate setting by a relentless mix of pace, music and encompassing cinematography. Hans Zimmer provides a score that is jarring in many respects. As he did in Interstellar, Zimmer departs from the tropes common to the scores of the genre and definitely does not create a score that invokes the period. He instead provides a musical wall of low foreboding synthesized textures that conveys the feelings of desperation and fear in the soldiers with raw upfrontness. Also like Interstellar, the sheer weight and power of the score and the way Nolan often pushes it to the forefront might be a cause for a headache or simply feeling overwhelmed but this is definitely not because the music or score itself is bad but because it is doing precisely what it is meant to do. The job of the score is not always a pleasant one and while it is true that blending the music seamlessly with the background is usually the best way to convey the subliminal message music sends, sometimes to convey the intensity and overwhelming nature of the film one is watching, a score equally as intense and in your face is required. The gorgeous cinematography in the film also conveys the spirit of intensity while maintaining impressive visual quality. Filmed almost entirely on Imax cameras and without a single frame composed entirely digitally, the film team had their work cut out for them on this film but under the masterful leadership (and often camera handling) of cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema, a sense of epic scale is achieved alongside the tensity of the action. The camera never cheats in this film because it never has anything to hide. So much was built practically and shot in camera that the action could be displayed as it is without having to cover things up with visual tricks. The feel of the camerawork places the audience in the story in a very immersive way while still maintaining a tight sense of dread. Shot in natural lighting and sometimes in very tight and constricting spaces, the cinematography is sometimes breathtaking, always wide in scope and captures tension in a unique and bold way. Another element that sets Dunkirk apart from a common war film is it's lack of dialogue and short runtime. Nolan expressed that from the very beginning of the film he wanted it to have a third act feel. To place the audience in the situation with the characters with no lead up or back story other than a few words of text on the screen and a leaflet falling from the sky. Dunkirk succeeds in it's gutsy attempt to create a film that is "all third act" with it's carefully crafted narrative acting as a strong skeleton for the rush of non-stop terror, action, movement and emotion that it pours out. With innovative tactics of yesteryear blended with distinctly original and modern storytelling and style, Dunkirk creates a visceral experience of a historic event that is to be revered and remembered as its subject matter should be. The miracle of Dunkirk is an example of the human spirit to not lose hope in the face of death. Dunkirk was ultimately a defeat and yet at the same time a victory. This paradox is what makes the event so fascinating and makes the film so worthy of scrutiny. There is more to the hope in the soldiers and civilians of Dunkirk then just a belief that they will survive; there is also a more realistic hope, a more courageous hope that even if they face danger or death that they will be able to do some good with the situation. The people of England never thought to give up in the face of their defeat but put all of their efforts into an seemingly impossible task of enlisting hundreds of civilian ships to evacuate 300,000 men. Because of their stubborn hope they won a victory in the midst of their defeat. One may look at the situation as a whole and say that England simply eluded being annihilated and that no military advantage was gained in the event, for the people and the spirit of England, having their boys home safe was good enough and the film definitely portrays that side of the story. It doesn't pretend like Dunkirk was not a devastating loss, one of the final shots is of the pilot Farrier being taken prisoner by the Germans, but it does recognize and convey the spirit of Dunkirk and convey that spirit of unquenchable hope that was so important to the people of the time and is important for us who remember. However, the question in war is rarely "what can I do?" but "how can I do it?". In other words, the opportunity to do good and to be brave abounds but day to day choices become much more difficult. Risks still exist and every choice may cost you, another, or both of you your lives. In the film, in all three storylines, the main characters take every situation and try to do the most honorable thing they can. It doesn't always work out for the better for them, but others are affected and no deed goes without an outcome. In times of war, sticking to a true north may be the only way to keep one's head level and make the right choices, in the film, the characters stick to a code of honor that keeps them grounded while the horror of war swells around them. Another weighty topic the film addresses that the context of the story suggests is the value of lives over the strategic blow of a defeat. To clarify, I realize that escape was the only option at Dunkirk and that defeat was inevitable but at the end there is not a sense of defeat even though many British vehicles, supplies and lives were lost. The simple fact is that the leaders in England understood the real thing that needed saving and put all of its effort into making the best of a bad situation and in so doing made a bad situation good. The events of Dunkirk, and the film especially pose a dangerous battle between hope and desperation. Only by keeping hope alive was that good achieved. Near the beginning of the film the main character Tommy sits on the beach and observes a soldier that has given into despair and walks into the sea, drowning himself. The battle between hope and despair is so dire in wartime and especially in the situation of Dunkirk because despair is self destructive and speeds you on your way to death, while hope is a driving force to keep going through that fear into life. There can be no middle ground. Even with minimal character development, dialogue or time to reflect, Dunkirk still delivers much to be thought about afterwards and a lot of deep meaning to be unpacked. One of the more brilliant aspects of this film is the way it deals with character. With barely time to remember their faces and not enough dialogue to remember their names, some may find it hard to empathise with their stories. However, this approach is entirely intentional and is not a product of lazy or poor writing. By giving the audience no background and minimal introduction to the numerous characters in the three storylines, I believe Nolan is doing two things, by not devoting any time to the introduction of his characters he is trying to make the possibility of their deaths much more believable. It is an almost universal understanding that if the main character dies he or she will die at the end. Anything before that doesn't hold any weight or stakes because the film is about them and usually has devoted so much time to their introduction and characterization. In Dunkirk, each man is simply another soldier among the thousands who may get lucky once, but might not get lucky again. The other thing that points to the intentionality of the overall "facelessness" of the main characters is that the reality is that Dunkirk is the story of thousands and thousands of individuals and to limit the narrative to focusing intently on a few would be to narrow the subject. Nolan portrays each place where Dunkirk was lived out, on the sea, in the air and on the beaches but by keeping his characters fictional and vague he is evoking the universality of the event and almost making it allegorical. Each character is almost meant to represent the entirety of their group and the experiences and feelings that each group had. Using this tactic, Nolan is attempting to not water down the events, but put them into an even more poignant spearhead. In this allegorical way each main character gives an example of the spirit of the film. George, Peter and Mr. Dawson all push faithfully on toward Dunkirk, saving two soldiers on the way and press on even when it seems pointless to do so. Tommy defends the life of the French Gibson when he is threatened to leave the rapidly sinking boat that hides them from the enemy. Even though he lied about his identity and even though Tommy knows that someone must leave the boat or they will all die, Tommy insists, risking his own life in the conflict. Farrier chooses to turn around and defend a ship full of fugitives even when his fuel is critically low and he ultimately gets captured on the beach but saves many lives because of his decision. Even Colonel Bolton makes a sacrifice of courage when he opts to stay on the beach and risks his life to oversee evacuating the French troops after the bulk of British forces had been evacuated. Each character represents the courage and spirit of the men at Dunkirk in a way that we might not remember their character specifically, but we will remember what they have done. Dunkirk is a riveting and relentless experience that is not only a testament to good filmmaking, but also a testament to a historic event that should never be forgotten. Nolans standards for filming as much as possible for real and his technically challenging script pushed the filmmakers to their limits in editing, sound design, production design, music, the whole works. The film puts thought provoking messages and themes into its narrative while still maintaining a fast pace and all the stylings of a thriller. Choosing more archetypal characters rather than his usual flawed central characters, Nolan quite intentionally disconnects the narrative from any specific person to create a more comprehensive account of the massive event that was Dunkirk. The film captures the spirit of what Dunkirk was with surprising clarity. The final scene speaks especially poignantly as Tommy reads Winston Churchill's address to the English people after their troops had been returned safely home. Churchill's famous speech where he promises "we will fight them on the beaches" holds an all new meaning as a message of hope and resolve plays over the aftermath of each storyline. In the midst of pain and tragedy, fear and terror, loss and pain, Dunkirk emerged as a beacon of hope for the war to come. As this film reminds us of that, it also stands as a beacon of great filmmaking, the innovation, massive amount of organization in its making mirror its subject matter and deliver a moving and awe inspiring experience.

MINOR SPOILER ALERT Dunkirk is an exceptional film that deserves all the praise that it's received! It may be one of my favorite war films that I've seen, but to be frank, I haven't seen that many war movies, and I know that in this film is especially tame in terms of gore, but I kind of liked that because it forced you to focus more on everything that was happening and being felt by the soldiers, scared of death and full of suspense and awkward silence. The film really excelled in many different areas. I'll first comment on the acting, which was probably the most underrated element of this film. One must remember that these actors were given very little to work with, but they were able to communicate so much through body language and facial expressions. The jealousy of being unable to get on the boat, the need to remain calm under extreme pressure, the feelings of traumatic stress, etc., were all expressed very convincingly and only through a few lines of dialogue and everchanging faces. While it's definitely not the best acting ever, I do think it's worth mentioning because of how little the actors were given in the first place. Cinematography and editing were just beautiful, definitely the best parts of the film. I was surprised to find out that it did not win Best Cinematography at the Academy Awards, but I haven't seen Blade Runner 2049 so, what do I know? All I can say is that the scenes shot in the air and on the water were some of the most beautiful scenes I've seen yet (though I am saying this as someone relatively new to cinema). One scene in particular, where the one fighter's plane just glides along the beach of Dunkirk, and we see Dunkirk's landscape as the plane gently falls, seemed so realistic and breathtaking I thought I was in the plane myself! Needless to say, I was extremely impressed. In terms of direction and screenplay, I thought that Nolan did a great job. I liked his unique take with the film, and I thought that the absence of dialogue had Nolan's intended affect, which was to ultimately incite the same sense of fear and silent hope that the soldiers had experienced in the viewers. Nolan's direction is unconventional in that this is supposed to be an action-war type film, but what makes it work is the fact that it does have a decent amount of action and suspenseful scenes, yet everything has much more solemnity so the film is more grounded and realistic. There were very few things that I disliked about this film; the theme of nationalism sort of annoyed me because that's kind of why they were in the war in the first place, and at times the film could be a tad bit boring, though not as much as I expected it to be. Ultimately the reason why I decided not to give this film the full five stars is because it honestly didn't completely amaze me and it's definitely not something I'd casually watch again, but still, I'd recommend it to friends.
Not as good as the original . The uniforms too clean

Dunkirk is a combination of three narratives going on that end up merging together. The nonlinear storyline helped to add to the anxiety & uncertainty. I found it genuinely stressful from the opening to the closing sequence and there's so much that your senses are never even given a break. More like an experience of true horrors of war showing that war is not about some brave personalities with weapons. It's about nameless and faceless soldiers facing an existential crisis, the possibility of randomized death, and how they can either respond with despair or hope. Hans Zimmer's terrific use of sound also puts you right there in the middle of the war and some of the sound effects were so real that you couldn't help but feel as if you were right there which provides you an intense experience of death. Christopher Nolan shows again why he's an important phenomenon in films today. His work is experiential, his screenplay is more action than words. The class this man brought to movies is unmatched by any other filmmaker in recent times.
Amazingly creative storytelling but far from Nolan's best. Basically zero fun in this film which makes the relatively short run time critical.
Fun movie that my whole family enjoyed.
It's structure is both a blessing and a curse. Thankfully the film doesn't overstay its welcome and has plenty of tense and well crafted sequences.

Man, this movie is such an experience to watch. Christopher Nolan just knows how to make these wonderful stories with great atmosphere. The three individual plots are great enough, but how they meet up is just great. Another thing that is great is the action, which is probably accurate to what was happening at the time, which is nice. Speaking of facts, to my knowledge, the movie is pretty accurate. Also the cast is just great. Like dude, you were able to put Harry Styles into the movie and make it work. That's not suppose to happen!!! Also the big name stars do their job well as well. But there's one problem to this near flawless film, which is the characters. The actors playing these people are great, but the characters really aren't. Like they're not bad per se, just‚Ä¶.forgettable. I literally watched this movie a hour ago and I don't remember any of the characters names, except for Georges, the only reason being that he dies in a weird way. Sure, you can have a great story, but none of it is going to matter if you don't have memorable characters, which Dunkirk doesn't have. Besides that, it was nominated for best picture for a reason. If you can deal with a movie with very little in the character department (like myself), then this has to be on the top of your list.

Dunkirk is an war action movie directed by Christopher Nolan and released in July 2017. The mains characters are Tommy(played by Fionn Whitehead) Peter(Tom Glynn-Carney) and Colonel Winnant(James D'Arcy). The movie takes place in Dunkirk during the Second World War. It tells the story of the evacuation of British and French troops under enemy's fire. This evacuation was a success with the help of civilians boats. The plot is a little bit difficult to understand because their is no explanations during the movie. Why have to guess were the movie take place, when. But this make the movie very unpredictable. After that, I would say that the movie is very absorbing. It's easy when you watch the movie to identified yourself to the characters because there is a lot of different personalities. The visual effects are very outstanding and make the movie even more realistic. This movie cost 150 M $ so it's an high budget movie. Photography is impressive. There is a lot of different filming technics used in the movie. The acting was very natural and realistic. Actors are really thinking like real terrified soldier doing everything do save there lives. The script is very realistic with a little part of inexplicable. It is also moving and spectacular. It's a real blockbuster. To conclude, I found this movie very realistic and absorbing. The story is complicated to understand but when you are in the movie it's really absorbing and you live every minute of the movie.
WOW! You truly feel the fear joy and sadness experienced by these heroes. I 100% recommend this movie

I will certainly give points for creativity in regards to this movie (or..episode?), and I will acknowledge that the opening several minutes is actually legitimately quite chilling, watching Godzilla destroying the world with literally nothing able to stop him. However, the movie dips in quality fast and hard shortly after, and never really rebounds at all. In fact, when this first movie was over, I legitimately wanted to know if the writers were intentionally trying to make me angry by writing a movie that's as frustrating to watch as possible. For starts, let's go with the fact that the humans return to Earth and everything is literally so deadly, that even if Godzilla was taken out of the mix, "Hell on Earth" would barely begin to describe it. There's literally 10,000 mini-kaiju for every human, and the plants cannot be eaten as they are literally as hard as steel, so as a viewer, you really start to wonder: "What are you even trying for?!" Even if the heroes completely win every objective they strive for, they still lose in every conceivable way regardless, so when they fail to achieve pretty much every objective anyway, it feels less like a compelling drama and more like the kaiju-cinema equivalent to watching a long video of a dog stuck wedged between two rocks. This is made worse by the fact that the main characters are universally either completely flat or outright unlikable, with the central protagonist being the biggest offender. He's nihilistic and embittered (to put it lightly) but he's also somewhat self-righteous, and honestly I wouldn't follow him if I were one of the nameless, faceless people in the movie, even if the situation was significantly less bleak. And lastly, the movie gives us some entertaining sci-fi action against Godzilla at the end, which would be fun if not for it being a massive tonal shift from the rest of the movie, as well as the realization that every human unit is irreplaceable -- Like, normally, watching Godzilla take on a group of tanks and jets is a lot of fun, but when the entire world's military is just 10 jets and 20 tanks, you can't just casually watch him take these units out; the gravitas does not allow for it. And honestly, all of these just culminate in a movie that just made me drained by the end, as there were too many frustrating elements that I legitimately stopped caring altogether well before the climax. It's sad because the story starts from a really solid premise, and while not exactly excellent, the animation is of solid quality, with one of the more interesting concepts of Godzilla seen to date (like...he looks like he's made of tree-bark or something), but due to a fair number of central miscalculations in the story's development, it ended up becoming what I would easily call the least enjoyable Godzilla (Proper Godzilla at least) movie ever made.

Not amazing but definitely a good twist on the usual Godzilla story but it seemed more like a setup movie which, in the end, it turned out to be. Haven't seen the next movies but overall this one is solid and had me entertained.

With Godzilla: Planet of the Monsters, I love how they brought back some kaiju or monsters from previous Toho films, such as Kamacuras, Orga, Dagarla, Dogora, Anguirus, Rodan, and Mechagodzilla for a cameo appearance. The new creatures the Servum are really interesting new monsters in the franchise, including Godzilla Filius basically serving as the spawns of Godzilla Earth and I love the new design and history on Godzilla. Rather than basing it on reptiles just like previous incarnations of the character, they made him into a plant and I can see where the Anime filmmakers were going which I'm glad they went for that. The only main issue is with the main character Hauro Sakaki who resembles two characters, Eren Yeager, and Anakin Skywalker which it sounds like they're taking the original attitude from someone's characters. Overall it's a good Godzilla movie, I recommend people should watch this, but if you don't like it, then you decided on if it deserves a second chance. This movie shouldn't throw hate.

I miss Godzilla. I miss his personality, his animal intellect, his occasional joie de vivre he would exhibit in his happier moments. I miss the convoluted plots with aliens, flying saucers, giant robots, time traveling and diminutive twins. I miss his rubber-suited energy, brought to life by Nakajima and Satsuma with much verve and vigor. I miss his stable of charismatic monstrous friends and foes, sending crowds fleeing in terror from their thunderous confrontations. Something got lost over the years, and it seemed to peak at the turn of the new millennium. The 1998 Roland Emmerich American version may not have done the radioactive beast any favours in corrupting his appearance and behaviour, pushing fans to call him Gino (Godzilla In Name Only), but one could say that Godzilla ultimately was killed for good by the puerile mess that was Ryuhei Kitamura's GODZILLA FINAL WARS in 2004. It took 12 years for the massive creature to reappear on Japan's shores, of course after Gareth Edward brought the beast back in 2014 in another American iteration of Japan's favorite Kaiju, in a film that promised a lot but offered little to be excited about. SHIN GODZILLA was a mixed bag to be certain. While it served a rather clever sociopolitical satire of Japan's stifling bureaucracy (something Shusuke Kaneko had already explored beautifully in his 1998 remake of GAMERA) and an eerie comment on the recent Fukushima disaster, Godzilla himself was a mere shadow of himself. Ponderously plodding across the Japanese countryside, stiff and monolithic, he was now a mere symbol for man's folly and destruction, harking back to the 1954 film that started it all. A noble intention, but lacking the sense of menace the original Ishiro Honda directed classic conferred to the Big G. Arguably, I would say that Shusuke Kaneko (him again) managed to create a more intensely savage and terrorizing beast in the 2001 monster mash GODZILLA, MOTHRA AND KING GHIDORAH: GIANT MONSTERS ALL-OUT ATTACK. Nevertheless, the film's social commentary helped the film achieve critical and box-office success in Japan, triumphantly bringing back the creature to his home turf. Which brings us to GODZILLA: MONSTER PLANET, (Hiroyuki Seshita, Kobun Shizuno) which is the first feature length animated film featuring Godzilla (we will not mention the embarrassing 1978 Hanna-Barbera cartoon series, or the 1998 animated Spin-off of the Emmerich film). The film has a very intriguing premise: Earth has been devastated by Godzilla and his monstrous ilk, forcing humanity to escape to space, in search of a more habitable planet. Their quest bearing no fruit, and their life support running low, they decide to come back to their home planet, hoping that the 10,000 years that has passed on Earth since their departure will have left behind a less hostile world waiting for them. I think the title of the film points out this hope is crushed under a gigantic radioactive foot. Sporting a gorgeous animated style, mixing adeptly a more classical style of anim√© with computer animation, the film is lovely to look at without a doubt. The music by Takayuki Hattori (who had previously scored GODZILLA VS SPACE GODZILLA and GODZILLA 2000) is appropriately bombastic, evoking Akira Ifukube's work on the original series.So the film SOUNDS good too. The film exploits poorly its promising classic science-fiction premise, though, preferring to focus on the tired cliche of Captain Ahab obsessed by his own white whale. The main character Haruo Sakaki elicits little sympathy with his constantly breathless snarling performance, and his ill-fated quest for revenge endangers many hundreds of his compatriots. He is surprisingly delivered command of a mission to destroy Godzilla based on a plan that is reminiscent of the rebel's scheme to blow up the Death Star in STAR WARS. Tensions between the characters is kept at a strict minimum, to help propel the fragile script by Gen Urobuchi along at a pace that is still quite a bit deliberate. Even then, little time is spent on how life could be sprung forth anew on this future Earth where only fossils of its once great structures remain and where monsters dwell. This being the first in a proposed trilogy, one can only hope this aspect will be explored further in the following chapters. Will I feel compelled to watch them is the question. As for the true star of the film, he is sadly no different in characterization from SHIN GODZILLA's lumbering lifeless husk, heavily wrecking havoc with little signs of conscience of his surroundings. More plant than animal, he most likely is meant to represent literally a force of nature (something not new in the 64-year-old series) which rips away any chance of being more than a growling allegory. By doing so, there is a somewhat pretentious attempt to make Godzilla relevant again, like SHIN GODZILLA did a year prior. But should it come at the expense of his identity that he developed over the last 60 plus years? I'm not asking for him to dance a victory jig like in INVASION OF THE ASTRO-MONSTER, or entertain conversations with his fellow monsters with the help of word balloons as he did in GODZILLA VS GIGAN. But surely there is a way to portray him as a living being with emotions and even motivations and still keep a sense of that precious symbolism alive. There is no need to make him into this grandiose empty vessel, only meant to carry the weight of his crushing metaphors. Sigh‚Ä¶ I miss Godzilla.

You would think that Godzilla & Anime would go together like chocolate and peanut butter...but this isn't a very good one in all honesty. I will admit that there are a lot of really great ideas, the world building is solid, the animation is good, & the score is decent...but literally everything else falls flat on its face. The movie actually starts out great where the situation with the kaiju is DARK, like "end of the world" dark...but it has way too much technobabble and very little action. I will admit that when you finally see Godzilla at the end of the movie and it is AMAZING; he really feels like a God this time, annihilating the humans and aliens with so little effort. But outside of the beginning and end... there's really not that much to this

I preface this by saying I'm a big fan of two particular Japanese exports: anime and Godzilla. They each have their problems but they both have a range of pros that keep me coming back to watch more, whether its the creativity and artistic freedom a popular animated medium like anime allows or the basic nature of a guy in a giant monster suit crushing little model buildings and fighting other guys in other suits. When it comes to Godzilla Monster Planet (or as Netflix is showing, Planet of the Monsters. I'll hearby refer to it as Godzilla Earth as that's what I've known it as until now) it seems to have just brought all of the negative points from one aspect of its foundation. Firstly, the positives. The creature design is fairly good actually, by far the best part of this production. It's more akin to the Legendary Godzilla design of the more recent Western movies than the 'guy in suit' aesthetic that Japan have stuck with even as recently as Shin Godzilla. He has weight, presence and the horrific aspect a lot of Godzilla movies don't tend to give much focus. He has a few unique abilities specific to this version of Godzilla, but nothing particularly stand out. The premise isn't particularly bad either. The general premise of the first part (as to avoid any spoilers) is that the inhabitants of Earth were forced to flee into space after monsters started to rise and destroy the planet, the most fearsome of the monsters being Godzilla. Years later, they try to destroy Godzilla and take the planet back. It's set in the future so there's some sci-fi technology in there which does help set this take on the King of Monsters apart from others which are largely based on existing technology of the era (exceptions to things like the oxygen destroyer). Now after that brief praise, some negatives. The anime foundation really shows its ugly face here bringing nigh every trope I'm long past being able to stomach. Why they chose this 3D anime style is beyond me. 3D animation in anime rarely looks good and is something studio's are still clearly a long way away from mastering. As with most examples, it's probably to cut costs and nothing more, not used to actually do something 2D animation would be unresonable to do. There's nothing on screen where 2D animation wouldn't look just as good or even better, nowhere that 3D animation is used to actually improve the visual experience. It all feels very cheap and amature with the choice of animation style there to lower costs rather than improve the product. When video games such as Guilty Gear, Dragonball Fighterz or Fire Emblem are emulating a 2D style of Japanese animation better than actual TV series or Movies, probably just don't bother with it. Like most parts of a production, 3D animation is used properly when you don't even realise or forget that it's even there. The characters themselves are very bland, the typical cast of stereotypes you'll find in the vast amount of forgettable anime with little to nothing that makes them stand out in terms of both visual characteristics and personality. "I just want to become more powerful so I'm not useless!", *gasp* "I-it can't be!", "I'll hold them back, just go!" and running towards things to attack whilst screaming, pretty much every trope is here with zero self awareness. Godzilla is ultimately about the human characters with the monsters typically having very little actual screen time. This cast of characters are difficult to sit with and Godzilla really doesn't suit the overly dramatic "this isn't how people actually behave" style that the anime genre often delivers. Alongside that, we have the futuristic technology and concepts this sci-fi rendition brings. This itself isn't a problem, on the surface it is all visually and conceptually appealing and as stated, something unique for this rendition of Godzilla...But again, anime tropes. We have characters over explaining even the most basic of ideas treating the audience as total morons. It's too much. A lot of this the audience could work out for themselves, "show, don't tell" as the saying goes, though the writers for this obviously don't know when to shut up. The soundtrack hits a fine balance between forgettable and awful. Typically anything with a guitar in it sounds utterly terrible but other than that, the OST as a whole is just bad enough to be noticable but nothing I didn't forget about literally a scene later. Instrument choices are questionable at best, pieces are often tone deaf, its not rare to have a track totally out of place for what's actually going on in the scene...Oh, and the tracks in the credits are the typical female fronted pop song you'll find in the vast majority of anime, again, a trope that just has no place in a franchise like Godzilla. It's a shame that I had such a bad time with this. It's the end of Christmas/New Year, I had one day to myself between my other half going back to work and myself starting back, new Netflix subscription, I looked forward to sitting down and binging this series for some tasty Godzilla goodness I've not had the chance to experience yet...And it feels like I shouldn't have bothered. Would have legitimately prefered to sit through Godzilla '98.

Dear lord this film sucked. and so did the entire trilogy! It's almost nothing but a boring story, unlikeable characters, and an overpowered Godzillla. The Anime Trilogy could of been WAY better of it were not for the producers lying to the fans and what not. To here, there is no story buildup at all, and the monsters of the movie are poorly made, including Godzilla.

Beginning my first concentrated foray into the anime genre, I thought it would be best to start with a cultural icon I was familiar with: Godzilla. This thinking has since been proven misguided. Godzilla: Monster Planet is an accomplishment in cinema; it is impressive that a movie featuring the King of the Monsters can be so boring. A non-speaking giant lizard is remarkably the least one-dimensional character in the production. I never knew how little I cared about the "science" explaining why Godzilla is so formidable an opponent, but luckily I had this force fed to me for conservatively half the movie. The one redeeming quality is Godzilla does seem to be truly a creation of God like longevity and proportions in this take. Will likely not invest time in sequels, as even an hour after watching it I still cannot remember a single character's name other than "we get it, your macho" alien, "constantly seeking revenge and relevance" protagonist, and "what are you doing, fighting?" young girl.

Yeah, I enjoyed it. It was a great opening for a weak trilogy, everything was good except for Godzilla that moves very slow. I mean yeah, he's big but I simply didn't like that Godzilla too much, his design was fantastic though. The main characters were great in my opinion, in the first time I felt worry for them when they were in trouble, this movie was good but unfortunately the trilogy decreases in quality gradually.

The emotional level of this movie is indescribable. The graphic aspect and editing job on this movie is better than the world that we live in today. Godzilla is suppose to be the main antagonist of the series, but as you dig deeper and depper you soon realize that he is a misunderstood being that we cannot understand with our current knowledge. Godzilla on the surface level is just the "King of Monster", but he represent a higher being that is meant to be the savior of main kind. You don't truly understand Godzilla mindset in this movie, but I hope they make a mini series to show the life and struggle of Godzilla. I do not see how this movie could further to be shown without it winning a noble piece prize. I had to go back to this movie multiple time and analyze each individual frame to discover the true master piece of a film this really is. After watching this movie I cannot go back to my daily life without relizing that I will not be blessed by this artwork at every second of the day. I wish that I could recommend this movie to every possible life form on the planet.

World building first episode of the trilogy, it is interesting to see this take on multiple alien races come together to help take on humanity's greatest threat ... Godzilla. Or is it really the biggest threat?
Godzilla: Monster Planet has a lot of potential, but disappoints big time in terms of scope, imagination and characterization.

Even with it's good animation and spectacular musical score, Planet of the Monsters is slow, full of exposition, topped off with horribly flat characters, boring action sequences, and limited kaiju action. Sure, you can have limited monsters in your movie, like how the 2014 Godzilla did, but at least in 2014, every minute of Godzilla was worth watching. In this film, Godzilla barely even walks. The only cool thing he does is shoot his beam. Oh, and the twist at the end was highly expected, even if you didn't see the trailers. Don't waste your time on this bland and boring mess. Go watch Shin Godzilla or Godzilla (2014) instead.
Heavy metal Godzilla.

1 Star - 5 Stars The ultimate question? I am a huge fan of animation, sci-fi, monsters, Godzilla sure. Let me start by saying the animation? is absolutely gorgeous. What Are The Elements Of A Good Story? Now for the ripping. Here are some to consider that will hopefully summarize this film. Plot - "Kill the monster". Almost as good as Dwayne Johnson in Skyscraper; a story about a building. I'm sure some movie executive spent many brain cells coming up with a movie about a building. Maybe, 1 brain cell. So in this case, 2 brain cells. Characters - There are a lot of them and I never really cared for any of them. Good or bad. Setting - The animation is gorgeous! Style Tone - The animation is gorgeous! Overall, I gave this movie 3 stars just because of the animation? or should i say ART is absolutely gorgeous. The minute details, shimmering of light, expressions, shadows and glows. It is kind of like looking at a gorgeous model. You cannot take you eyes off of. Yes, that is called staring. I am sure she/he has a great mind, personality, giving, talented. But who cares its shiny. There it is... This movie is "Shiny".... Watch and you will see what I mean and most likely will say, "yes, its good". In my case, three stars because the ART really blows my mind. This movie could have been written, directed and produced by Hajime Sorayama himself (did I just age myself?).

Harou is an idiot! He was so adamant about killing Godzilla for humanity to finally be inhabit Earth again and let's Godzilla live in the ending!! The plan and movie was pointless. Next time kill Harou along with Yuko.
Godzilla plays 2nd fiddle to a group of humans who couldn't possibly be more annoying. All I wanted was for Godzilla to stomp them, but the movie keeps putting the focus on them.

review_date: Godzilla: Monster Planet starts off strong, but quickly turns into an uphill battle. It's a slow painful climb until the last 5 minutes of the movie where it gets really good. The main problems with this movie are the boring characters, and the lack of world building. By the end of this movie we know next to nothing about the setting we are introduced to aside from it being earth in the future. Would not watch again.

A semi-interesting story, beautiful creature design on Godzilla and beautiful animation are all present in "Godzilla: Monster Planet" / "Godzilla: Planet of Monsters." They are, unfortunately, surrounded by too much exposition and uninteresting characters. Also, why can't a Godzilla movie actually star and feature a lot more Godzilla!?

While the story is a little lackluster and the characters are bland, the animation is so beautifully crafted into 3D it's worth a watch. Godzilla in Anime should've happened a long time ago. He is every bit as imposing as the Legendary Studios blockbuster-version (albeit moves a bit slower) and they even used the same bone chilling roar.

I have to admit that the animation in this movie is terrific. It looks amazing as you would expect from a Japanese anime feature. There's also the stock anime melodrama and scale, both aspects that should suit the big green lizard well. However, the meagre story and dreadful script disappoint and fail to deliver some much needed weight to the story. I understand that the intention is that this is the first of a trilogy of movies. Let us hope that the only way is up.

Why bother making an anime godzilla movie if you're not going to utilise the freedom of animation to show us things that would otherwise be difficult to do with live action. We've already seen plenty of films where humans take on godzilla. Give us something of bigger scale rather than a less ingaging shin gojira with sci fi themes. If you're going to make a godzilla anime called monster planet, make it a planet full of monsters and do what Destroy all monsters struggled to do with practical effects back in 1968 - big scale kaiju battles. Instead all we get is a film I can barely stay awake through as we follow barely developed characters as they shoot at godzilla as he stands there and returns fire with a Lazer every few minutes... I mean come on. Huge missed opportunities ??

From all the Godzilla movies, this offers the best story for the king of monsters. The post-apocalyptic take gives audiences a fresh taste of the beast and it's true impact to society. However the climax didn't give justice the awesome premise it built up. Looking forward to the sequel!
godzilla is so huge and nice spaceship

This is part one in a planned trilogy, and yeah, that's sort of how it feels. To be fair, the world it builds is interesting as hell, I give the movie a lot of credit for its world building. The idea that our earth has basically been taken over by Godzilla, and when we return to it the environment has adapted to him as the dominant species is a damn intriguing idea that I have certainly never seen taken on before. I also like seeing Godzilla put in the spot of the straight up villain after years of skewing him into the sort of anti-hero role. Also with the futuristic place of the movie, all the sci-fi gadgetry and alien culture we have now is interesting to see played around with. All of this stuff in the movie, I was really enjoying. My problem with movie however is a big one...literally. It's Godzilla. He's just not in much of the movie, and when he does show up, he barely even moves. There's just no excuse for this. The guy in the restrictive rubber suit moved more, so now we have an anime where his potential for movement is endless, and he basically stays in one spot? There is simply no excuse for this, and it kind of pissed me off. It's Godzilla in anime form, this is your opportunity to really have fun with this character. But instead he just stands in some trees and moves his head around a little. And yes, without getting too much into spoilers, let's just say he doesn't really do that much even. Some of the action scenes with the other creatures of this planet of monsters are cool, and I did like the exploration of this world, but when you call your movie Godzilla you give your movie a certain responsibility. I loved the movies world building, I even enjoyed some of the characters, and the animation is pretty good and there are a couple quotable lines throughout. The world building is really what gives this movie the ranking it does, I was actually pretty engaged in this universe because of that. But the problem is, it can't help but feel like the first chapter that it is. All I can say is, chapter two better be god damn amazing.

Sin duda basada en el material estadounidense, este piloto del kaiju japon√©s depende totalmente de su im√°gen para sostener un anime gastado, aburrido y sin mucho sentido, a pesar de ser visualmente impactante.

A 500-thousand-ton beastie rules the Earth as humans realize they've made a fatal mistake moving into space to find a new home. Solid science explanations that aren't overwhelming. Over-sized humanlike aliens who want everyone to think everything's going to work out just fine, even though they back one kid's plan that everyone else thinks is tantamount to disaster. There's something wrong about those aliens.

Since it was recently released on Netflix as Godzilla, Part I: Planet of the Monsters, I'd been more than curious about the first full-length anime feature film to feature the king of monsters. In addition to tall, dark and gruesome, the film also features a number of other cameos, if you know how to recognize them: Dogora, Kamacuras, and Dahagra, to name a few... (yes, I saw Mecha too, but that's just a bit too obvious). Anyway, you'd think that for any Godzilla fan, the whole thing sounds like a dream come true. Unfortunately, the stiff, emotionless, low quality, chuggy animation (I'd swear I can see at least half the movie frame by individual frame); tedious, mind-numbing, sickeningly repetitive dialogue; sloppy, non-sensicle story; and conspicuous absence of ambience and music for a vast majority of the film make me wonder what kind of cheap attempt at a cash-in prompted this little excursion into Dullsville. The only thing that kept me watching was the simple fact that the boring, uninspired story promised that little bit of action which, finally accompanied by some ear-catching background music, tried to help this helplessly floundering fish back into the water. On the other hand, since among the gallery of expressionless faces the likes of which we haven't seen since Advent Children, only Haruo's seems to display any sort of emotion, and even then, I can't tell if he's angry or just struggling to drop a load in his trousers over the constant flip-flop of opinion and strategy the movie seems to play around with, there's honestly nothing which can elevate this movie above the rank of--and this is surely fitting--pure cannon fodder. Galu-gu was certainly right when he described the entire theory as "preposterous." That this movie would earn more than a single star for its dead weight is ludicrous indeed.

review_date: So disappointing! The characters (the three of 'em) are very generic and one dimensional (angry protagonist is annoying AF) and there's only ONE female character, apparently, in the whole space colony and she does nothing relevant at all. Sadly, because this is heavy in exposition and repeating that exposition the lack of compelling characters made it worse AND on top of that, the art style is SO bland at times you don't know who is who and who is where. Music is generic. Plot wise it's riddled with BIG plot holes that made the characters' plan nonsensical. To put salt in the wound, the movie teases you with very interesting flashbacks that look fun and entertaining! (Other Kaijus! Homeless aliens want to help humans vs Godzilla in exchange for refuge!) THAT should have been the movie! Don't waste your time with this crap.
review: SHOW MORE

Directed by: Hiroyuki Seshita and Kobun Shizuno (Knights of Sidonia) Starring: Chris Niosi, Martin Billany, Edward Bosco Written by: Gen Urobuchi, Sadayuki Murai, Yusuke Kozaki Review: Godzilla's latest outing shows that he can be a menacing force in an animated format. It's a shame that it couldn't have been in a more interesting movie. The movie is being distributed in America and several other countries via Netflix. It may initially look like a series, because it will ask to play "Part 1, Episode 1", but it is just one ninety minute movie that was released theatrically in Japan. It is expected to become a trilogy, which may be the reason it is shown like this, with Parts 2 and 3 to be added afterward. This movie has a different feel from previous Godzilla movies. It starts after the monsters have rampaged the cities. Humanity has fled the Earth with help from an alien species, after giant monsters have taken over the world. Now, they have returned to kill the worst monster there was, Godzilla. The movie feels more like a space anime, even when Godzilla shows up near the end. The animated format suits the monster, keeping him from looking as fake as he does in certain live-action outings. The scenes also show him in an effectively menacing light. He is a very powerful force, and the animation style emphasizes that. But the rest of the movie is not as good. Before the final Godzilla fight scene, there is over an hour of things that are not as interesting. The concept is kind of intriguing, but the characters feel flat. This is not helped by the fact that there is very little action, and a lot of space jargon. That is not to say that it was completely boring. It still has some great science fiction visuals, and a unique take on the Godzilla story. It just doesn't have the pull that it should. But the climax is really good, and the ending, while it is obvious sequel bait, did make me interested in seeing what happens next. Hopefully, the sequels would have more interesting characters. jaythemovieguy.blogspot.com

review: This review contains spoilers. How to Train Your Dragon 3 was a huge disappointment. I will be unpopular, but let me explain in detail why I didn't like it. The first 2 films are absolute masterpieces. The characters, the story, the animations ... Everything was just perfect. For the third, therefore, I had enormous expectations. Then, at the end of the film, I was pretty angry about how they developed this story arc. I mean, in short, the ending is wonderful, for sure. it is also very moving. But the beauty ends here. Everything else is just one stretch after another to get to the good ending. it's as if they already knew how the trilogy was going to end, but didn't have the slightest idea how to get there consistently. The villain, Grimmel, is one-dimensional and left me nothing. The animations, of course, are spectacular and are very colorful. But this is not just a movie. It's not just a nice ending. I know I shouldn't make comparisons, but for example Toy Story 3 (which after there is 4 is another matter) not only has a beautiful ending that will have moved everyone, even non-fans, but also a good villain, a articulated and well-structured story, a great evolution of the characters but above all great emotions. Here all this is only in the beautiful ending, but not in the rest of the film, too flat and made to stretch the broth. How to train your dragon 3 had great potential, but unfortunately it did not succeed in its intent.

review: its good but very sexist undertones, whether its the light fury not being regarded as the queen of all dragons (despite the same abilities as a night fury) to the end showing Hiccup and his son on a boat, showing him the world and then handing him off to his wife. Also theres a daughter who doesnt even so much as get her hand held at the end- it is mainly regarding his son. I feel like this movie could have been improved by not making the 4 main females either a side kick (ruffnut, light fury of toothless, astrid) or as merely the mother with no significant role. The mother was the best representation of women empowerment, showing just that women can do shit too lmfao. Also, this is a world of vikings yes. But it is also fictional with dragons. Women were considered empowered in the land of vikings- they were tough. They're tough too yes but only in their relation to how they can serve a man. Just kind of made the movie leave me with a bad taste in my mouth. But, women were considered property until the 1920's and not permitted to open bank accounts until the 1970s so I guess i'm asking too much. Decent plot overall, not a lot of character development. Toothless was the most 3d character with many layers because they had femininely represented him in the earlier movies and now had to make him the guy in his relationship with the light fury (who isnt even given a nickname)- they couldve done a lot more considering they're dragons and their only point of reference is how to write for humans ig. Good show either way but kind of disappointed me. At least hold your daughters hand at the end and show her the world like you're showing your son. Did you just have her to replace Astrid? Idk, just kind of backwards when you consider the main demographic is incredibly impressionable young boys and girls haha. 3 1/2 stars pretty good

review: The 2019 film: How to Train your Dragon Hidden World was astonishingly heartwarming and felt like a true masterpiece, However The general story line felt similar to the previous movie: How to train your dragon 2 that was released in June of 2014. The Film is about the Viking leader, Hiccup and his rare Night Fury dragon, Toothless on a Quest to find another Night Fury dragon, and to explore the world to discover new dragons. They discover another Dragon like Toothless however in their search they attract the attention of the powerful and fearsome enemy Grimmel the Grisly. A ruthless dragon hunter who wants to wipe out all dragons. Hiccup and toothless must find the hidden world of Caldera to hide their dragons and keep them safe from Grimmel's wrath. The relationships between the characters in the movie were strong and full of emotion. And the acting was fantastic, you could really feel the bond between all the characters. The movie had plenty of funny and dramatic moments over the course of the story. I personally enjoy the animations and the atmospheric environments in the film. And the music in the film was very well composed and added to the mood of film perfectly Many Scenes in the movie brought me Joy or sadness. It was full of great moments that made me laugh or smile, as well as some parts that brought a tear to the eye. Although the plot felt kind of similar to the previous movie with them dealing with an enemy who wanted to destroy/control all dragons it was still unique. The ending was both sad and happy which can be a difficult effect to produce in films. I highly recommend you watch How to Train you Dragon Hidden World because it was a wonderful experience, and I could watch It repeatedly. It is well worth your time and money. Just be sure to watch the two previous Movies first so you do not spoil anything.

Quite frankly stunned to see such negative reviews on one of my all-time favorite sequels. Yes, the storyline is a little repetitive at times, but there are countless scenes that give me full on laughter belly ache every time. Perfect cast and the family differences are everything you worry about when your parents are introduced for the first time. Some of the scenes are brutal and make you feel embarrassed to the point of discomfort, which exactly what you'd expect when your parents are trying to put you on blast in front of your fiance. I actually prefer Meet the Fockers to Meet the Parents and wish they stopped with this one. One of my favorite comedies that left me laughing and cringing from start-to-finish.

Oddly compelling if you can look beyond the tired gags and the fact the whole "Jack is a strict Dad who used to work at the CSI" has outstayed its welcome. If you look into how much love and support the Fockers put into each other, their son and life in general, juxtaposed with the harsh, cold, distrusting cynicism of the Byrnes family... There's actually something you can take away from it. It's also got a few things that'll make you smile, but pretty much everything good in this film comes from Dustin Hoffman. As you'd expect.

Besides the fact that the dad in this move is basically my grandad, this is a pretty great movie. Jokes aside, this is a great family night movie for anyone into romantic comedy. Definitely one on our frequent rewatch list.

review_date: I began my acquaintance with this trilogy precisely from the second part. I watched it once in my childhood, not even knowing that it was a continuation, because the title doesn't have the usual numbering. Therefore, for me, this film is completely independent and separate, although in conjunction with the first part it looks organically. This is a great example of a sequel: in it, the story continues, not repeats. After watching Meet the Parents, the logical question remains: what about the Fockers? So getting to know them is a natural continuation, revealing the story on the other hand and deepening the main character, the case when the second part cannot be missing. Without it, the first film is inferior. The disadvantage is, perhaps, a significant difference in the time intervals between films in life and in the plot. It is noticeable that several years have passed from the first part, while in history the action takes place hardly in a year. In a good way, both parts should be one film divided into two. But otherwise the comedy is excellent, sometimes surpassing the first in humor. But it is for my taste. I understand people for whom some jokes here may be over the edge. However, for lovers of this style it's just sweetie. And the actors are still the best that is in these films. Nowhere else can you see in one frame such Hollywood legends as Robert De Niro and Dustin Hoffman. For their joint scenes alone, I am ready to revise this movie.

One of those movies that has just enough going for it to really make you realize how awful it is. First and foremost among its shortcomings is its plot line. Starts out at a snails pace, then abruptly splinters off into about 8 other developments. What is so frustrating is that all these plot points pull against each other. None of them are even close to explained, and instead of trying to have them pull in the same direction, each new 'twist' tries to upstage the last, resulting in a big fat jumble of convoluted and inexplicable mess. The script is painful too. Both in its writing, and in its mannerisms. It clearly does not represent the way people act, speak or interact with each other. On top of the horrible script, the actors do absolutely nothing to help. Instead, they take bad material and drag it down to awful. Cameron Bright might as well be a cardboard box, as thats all he seems capable of playing. The score is underwhelming, and at times overpowering. There are a few positives. The set design is very good. The building has far more presence than any of the actors and characters. There are a few decent creepy moments (the cement pouring scenes in particular), and Mischa Barton's hotness (although it can't overcome her awfulness as an actress). These positives though are overwhelmed and buried by the permeating suck-tasticness of everything else.

Kung Fu Panda 3 is another fresh entry in this franchise. It had a very important work to end this trilogy perfectly and it did. It is arguably the most ambitious film in the series and a lot emotions thrown into the mix. And the humor is great. Although only the animation of pandas isn't that much finished but if you have only this flaw in the movie then you are successful in entertaining an audience. Also, the climax is one of the best. So now, I can say confidently that kung fu panda is one of the most consistent franchises of all time.

Unlike The second movie this one doesn't manage to reinvent itself in a meaningful way. Instead, it takes the route of replicating the first movie's messages to a lesser effect. The result is somewhat convoluted and less satisfying. The humor is also dumber and a lot more hit-or-miss than the earlier installments. All in all, the film isn't bad but it's a far cry from its predecessors.

My issues with this movie comes down to one key issue: its relation to the first two movies in the trilogy. This shows through in a number of ways: largely the story and the drastic change in tone. The story of the first two movies has Po out of his depth, coming to terms with a facet of himself through great effort and struggle. In the first, he must come to terms with the responsibility he always dreamed of having, and the consequences should he fail to live up to that responsibility. He goes through a crucible, realizing that every single one of his heroes despises him, and what he represents, then realizing he is expected to defend the valley from the greatest threat it has ever faced. In the second movie, Po must face the man who killed his parents and led a genocide of his people, orphaning him and making him the last of his species. Lord Shen is certain that he killed every single panda. Po must come to terms with his past, and in doing so saves all of China from a despot. The third movie starts by completely subverting the plot of the second. The pandas survived! The reason the second movie exists, and Po's struggle therein, is now far less meaningful. And Po's struggle in the third movie is less interesting and less meaningful than those previous. He's told he's now a teacher, and worries that he isn't able to do his job well. The stakes are far lower, and the emotional impact is similarly reduced. If he can't teach well, then his friends training will suffer until he figures it out. Then, upon arriving in the Panda village, Po just... figures out how to teach. He didn't go through anything in an attempt to figure out how to teach, he just magically got better. The other side of the story, in which Po finds his family while dealing with Kai, is similarly bland. His father, who we've never met and have no reason to care about beyond a single line in the second movie and the expectation that 'if he's Po's father, then we have to care about him', is introduced and immediately we're struck with the expectation that the character deserves the audience's attention and emotional connection. The writers didn't let Ping feel replaced, they didn't let Po wonder why he'd lived without his people for his entire life, and they expected an emotional connection to exist in a vacuum. As far as antagonists go, Tai Lung was amazing and Lord Shen impeccable. Kai threatens far less than his predecessors: Tai Lung threatened the entire Valley, and beyond. Shen threatened all of China. Kai threatened a few dozen characters, less than 10 of which we actually know. Kai doesn't connect to Po's inner struggle at all in the same way that Tai Lung and Shen did. And Kai's attitude throughout is far less distinctive than his predecessors. The humor and campiness of this third installment were also grating, especially after the wonderful physical humor and genuinely intense mood that the first two movies attained at critical points. Meanwhile, the final fights here are interspersed with random panda villagers doing one move, then celebrating, or Po just grandstanding, instead of genuinely reaching out to his enemies as he did in the first two movies. That said, these are far more apparent than the issues above, which took me a while to put to words. I'm far happier just watching the first two movies and considering that the end of the series.

I had to think really hard about my thoughts for this movie. I hold the Kung Fu Panda franchise very close to my heart. I have invested a lot of my time in not just the movies, but as well as the side series. Overall, I think this is a great movie, it just left me feeling very underwhelmed. It still has all of the great elements from the first two films. The animation, the action, and the deep themes are all present in the third installment of this franchise. The new style of Kung Fu that is introduced, chi, was a pretty good addition. Also, I liked how they were able to reintroduce Oogway into the storyline. And of course...you have Po, who is still the lovable and funny lead protagonist we all love. All of these aspects are the reason why I love this franchise so much. However, I still feel that there was a lot of missed potential here and somethings that simply weren't going to work for me. Kai as the villain was fine for me, but he felt much more generic compared to the villains from the previous films. I didn't like how Shifu and the Furious Five were off in the distance for this film (though their minimal amount of screen time is pretty awesome). But my biggest issue with the film is the other pandas (more specifically Li (Po's father) and Mei Mei). The other pandas make the film feel a lot more childish, and I didn't find any of their interactions with Po to be that funny. This was something I expected though, so I wasn't as bothered at that. After, the primary audience for most of the DreamWorks films is younger children. But there were two new characters that I believe were the epitome of wasted potential. First of all their is Po's biological father Li. Considering how the two of them reuniting was the main plot of the story, it seemed like a great continuation of the storyline. But most of their interactions with each other are meant to be for jokes, and when the creators tried to make some emotional moments with them, it felt sort of disingenuine. And then you've got Mei Mei. This flirtatious Panda was the most disappointing part of this film for me because I had such high hopes for her. Giving Po a girlfriend would have been a genius move on their part as it could really help shape his arc as the Dragon Warrior. Her one good interaction with Po is their first one, where she's flirting with Po, but making it seem like he flirting with her. And that's it. That is literally all that she does. She learns how to use nunchucks...and...um...she...uh...yeah that's about it. It might seem like I am being hard on this movie and I am. But it is simply because I know the potential that these movies have. That with another sequel in the works, DreamWorks could give us a franchise that could surpass How to Train Your Dragon. They didn't utilize certain plot points that would have made this movie so much better. If this were the last movie, I definitely would have disliked it much more, but maybe they can make amends in future installments. As nitpicky as I am, I think that this still a great family film that I recommend. Just make sure you watch the first two movies first.

The story moves pretty fast, usual for a 1h30 min film, nothing is really time filler. Will watch again in the future, no doubt.

review_date: Come with me if you want to know how one of the greatest action movies of all time holds up thirty years later. For a movie of its length, it's very engaging, but a few points do kind of feel sluggish here and there. I also took issue with not remembering if the T-1000's cop uniform was part of the shapeshifting, or if he stole it off the cop who found him. Those issues aside, they're small enough, but they kind of bothered me. Nitpicks aside, the plot made sense if you ignore the time paradoxes, and the characters were amazing. John Connor, despite being only ten years old, is a great lead character, and Edward Furlong's acting is brilliant, by both child acting standards, and acting standards in general. Linda Hamilton also demonstrates an amazing transformation from the first movie, and Arnold Schwarzenegger goes from stoic killing machine to a self-aware machine that learns what it means to be human. The visual effects hold up great, with one or two nitpicks I won't emphasize. It all enhances the story where it's used, only adding to the T-1000's threat. The pulse pounding soundtrack, and great dynamic between John and the T-800 add to the spectacular action set pieces, all of which are the primary elements that hold it up to this day, as well as its theme of the future being yours to write.
review: SHOW MORE

I thought the first movie was amazing but this movie is honestly better. Pretty much everything about this movie improves over the original. It's one of the best sequels and action movies ever. The visual effects still hold up and I'm still astonished that they managed to create these mindblowing effects in 1991 and this makes for some truly creative stuff with the T-1000, an excellent villain that makes you dread for the main characters. I genuinely did not know how the main characters would survive. The action is exciting and suspenseful with that motorcycle chase being the standout and that twist with Arnold's character being our Kyle Reese in this movie is brilliant! Speaking of brilliant, this movie somehow got me emotionally invested into a cyborg whether it was T-800's beautiful relationship with John as well as his sacrifice in the end, showing that while he's a cyborg, he has a ton of emotion in his heart. Sarah becomes a badass in this movie and I love the mother-son bond with John. Just about every character in this movie is so well-written and memorable including Dyton. and the story is tense, exciting and has massive stakes. Everything feels like a natural continuation from the first movie. James Cameron is a damn genius. This and Aliens are some of the best movies ever made.

It appears you don't need to leave your sofa for much of Saturday. Even though I'm sure everyone has seen it, it's a good chance to reassure yourselves that the Terminator films were once groundbreaking cinema, as well as being great films. Although Terminator 3: The Rise of the Machines (2003) is nowhere near as bad as people seem to remember it being, that is when the series should have shut down. Terminator: Genisys (2015) is bizarrely named, and it's bizarre that it exists, but at least there was an idea somewhere there, lost amongst the rubble. Terminator: Dark Fate (2019) I can't explain at all. I went in thinking this is the moment I might see another half decent Terminator, but sadly not. Terminator 2 however, is the high bar that every sci-fi film should aim for. The effects still look astounding today, you believe in all the characters, and the switch of Schwarzenegger's Terminator from bad to good for the second film is the stroke of genius that makes it work. It's still probably James Cameron's best film.
The Special Edition Director's cut is the best version of this film.

review: Buena pel√≠cula, injustamente criticada, creo que es un cl√°sico navide√±o que hay que ver obligatoriamente. Si hay que decir que tiene una gran cantidad de errores que me di cuenta reviendo esta pel√≠cula. Dejando de lado la gran direcci√≥n de arte/vestuario y el maquillaje elaborado, estoy de acuerdo con muchos defectos de la pel√≠cula dichos por la critica. Para empezar esta es una pel√≠cula basada en un cortometraje animado, y se la convirti√≥ en un largometraje de poco mas de una hora y media, estirando la historia con un ritmo lento, con una fotograf√≠a algo aburrida y con unos efectos especiales no tan buenos. Por otro lado, la pel√≠cula es sumamente mejorada por la brillante actuaci√≥n de Jim Carrey como el propio Grinch. Creo que con el gran manejo corporal y los di√°logos improvisados de Carrey lo vuelven un personaje ic√≥nico y que funciona para m√≠. Se mantiene fiel al car√°cter travieso del cortometraje original mientras lo lleva a otro nivel. Tambi√©n, creo que Taylor Momsen fue elegida perfectamente para interpretar a Cindy Lou-Who y su ternura es pr√°cticamente ic√≥nica y perfecta. El resto del elenco hace un buen trabajo con el material que se les da y el compositor James Horner realiza un gran trabajo. Por ultimo, el mensaje familiar de la pel√≠cula sobre el esp√≠ritu navide√±o puede no ser tan simple y puro como en el cortometraje cl√°sico, pero sigue siendo muy claro. En conclusi√≥n, un cl√°sico navide√±o muy ic√≥nico, con algunos fallos, pero que es una vista obligada durante la navidad.

review: How the Grinch Stole Christmas is a pretty bad movie. Jim Carrey as the Grinch would be considered pretty scary for some kids while I think Carrey is overacting. Speaking of scary, why do Rick Baker and Gail Rowell-Ryan think it's a good idea to give the characters of Whoville pretty horrifying make-up? Think the reviews on the make-up design is pretty overrated. Also, why do Brian Grazer and Ron Howard think it's a good idea to make a Dr. Seuss movie (family friendly) that contains dark themes and somewhat scary moments when their more audience is for children? To this day, I'll never understand what they're thinking. Overall, this movie is pretty bad. I've seen worse movies but I know for sure this is one of the worst Christmas movies I have ever seen. Instead of giving the naughty kids coal on Christmas day, make them watch the 2000 version of How the Grinch Stole Christmas for 24 hours!
