review: This is the version of the Grinch that I've grown up and it continues to give me the nostalgic kick I want during the holidays! This was a divisive adaptation during its release apparently while the criticisms remain fairly valid, the overall view on director Ron Howard's movie has softened over the years and become a surprise fan-favorite. Looking at this movie from a technical standpoint, it is largely unexceptional. Apart from the nicely whimsical art direction/costumes and elaborate makeup, I am willing to agree about the movie's many flaws; there is the padded narrative to turn a cartoon short into a feature-length film, the sluggish pacing, the somewhat dull cinematography not lending itself well to the wonderous cheery aroura that they hoped to capture, some iffy CGI/bluescreen and the rather wonky tones at play. Despite all that, I still find it to be consistently entertaining today as I did in the theater in 2000. The movie is substantially lifted by Jim Carrey's brilliantly hilarious and inspired turn as The Grinch himself. Much of the criticism towards the movie was mainly aimed at how Ron Howard let Carrey go so wild for the role with no restraint, leading to numerous scenes that go arguably a bit too long. But I believe with Carrey's impeccable physicality and improvisational quips, it just flat-out iconic and works for me. He remains true to the mischievous character of the original short while taking it delightfully over the top to another level; not to mention nearly all his lines are so damn quotable. There are other redeeming qualities along the way. Taylor Momsen was perfectly cast as Cindy Lou-Who and her natural cuteness is practically iconic, though its a tad shame her acting career didn't go to far after this. It is actually quite poignant how her character was more mature and had more sense than any of the adults in Whoville! Bill Irwin, who's like a low-key physical comedian himself, is very good as Cindy's father; bringing this warmth and bubbling demeanor to the proceedings as he is the first adult character to understand Cindy's thoughts about the true meaning of Christmas. The rest of the cast does a good job with the material they are given, composer James Horner puts out a lovely music score and I always enjoy the Faith Hill song in the end credits. The movie's familiar message about the Christmas Spirt might not be as simply put and pure as it was in the classic short but remains very clear and essential regardless. - 6.5/10 (B-)

review: Aesthetically, instead of a vibrant technicolor kelly green like in the original cartoon, Carrey's Grinch is the drab brown of a dead Christmas tree still up in January, with a look like he's suffering from mange. Ideologically, Howard's big budget eyesore is perfectly postmodern, another crass commodification not just of the holiday, but a commercialization of commonplace (and meaningless) gripes about the commercialization of Christmas itself, bemoaning the loss of some original real meaning behind Christmas and yet devoid of any spirituality or religious feeling whatsoever. As Bart so much more eloquently and sincerely put it: "Aren't we forgetting the true meaning of Christmas? You know, the birth of Santa."

review: The Grinch had a point. I've realized that the Whos of Whoville suck. The Grinch was bullied and harassed SO MUCH to the point that he moved to the top of a MOUNTAIN just to escape. Not only that, but for 53 years, every Christmas, they make SO MUCH noise that the Grinch can STILL hear them from the top of a MOUNTAIN. With that said, the Grinch had a point. Jokes aside, the Grinch terrified me as a kid. Especially when he jumps from the ceiling like a furry green Spider-Man and scares Cindy Lou. "You're the, the, the‚Ä¶ THE GRINCH!" This will forever be a Christmas favourite of mine since it's full of nostalgia. But if I take my nostalgia goggles off, this still holds up as a fun, ridiculous, live-action adaptation. This time around, I was able to appreciate just how much work went into the costumes, makeup, practical effects, and the set design. It felt like the animated short come to life (weird noses and all). Jim Carey is a f*cking legend. (Well, duh.) He brings SO much energy, charisma, humour, and heart to the grouchy Grinch. I don't even know how I was ever scared of him as a kid. (Probably because I was a little wimp.) Also, Cindy Lou is still adorable and her "Where Are You Christmas" song is still a banger. I'm indifferent on how this movie stretches the 26-minute animated classic into being 4x longer. They actually add some fun bits like the Grinch's origin, but it also feels like pointless filler even if was still fun. I also can't forgive this movie for being so stupid sometimes. For example, Cindy Lou catches the Grinch stealing her tree (and everything else in her house) but is too tired to recognize the ONLY green person in Whoville. It's a family movie after all, so I'll try not to think too hard. Ultimately, I still love this movie even if it isn't perfect. It just gets me in the holiday spirit and Jim Carey as the Grinch is Who-tastic! Score: 7 out of 10 Overall: Good Thanks for reading!

But dammit, if it isn't just a blast to watch Jim Carrey in his ridiculous outfit mumble to himself about how much he hates everything. This is a great choice for some mindless Christmas spirit.

review: I had no idea this was rated so badly! To me, my family, and all the people I've talked to about this movie, we all consider it to be a classic! Jim Carrey is at his all time best, acting as the Dr. Suess's Grinch. This movie should be rated at least at a 85%. If you are going to watch this movie by yourself with a serious point of view, then the film may come across you differently than those who watch with their family (as a family movie should be). All kids i know absolutely love this film. The acting is wonderfully done. The actors really did their part on making sure the whole family would enjoy the film. Jim Carrey had to do some serious training just to endure the suit he wore for the Grinch, which he needs some serious praise for. This man really deserves an award for his proformance. The story is very close to original that we all love, but with a bit of our modern day civilization thrown in it. With great story telling by the narrator Anthony Hopkins, this emotionally capturing film will make families hearts grow three times bigger and laugh three times harder than they usually would (like the ugly laughs you always try to hold back on). The characters are quite unique and well thought out. Each one making their own type of impact on you, which what a great is exactly supposed to do! I don't like to go in great detail because I hat giving away any major spoilers for those that are looking here for a curious reference to help them determine whether or not they should watch this film. I say ignore the horrible ratings and give this film a watch! It's the perfect movie for the family to enjoy!

review: I absolutely loved Jim Carrey as The Grinch! I loved his energy, the jokes that he made, and the design of the costume! The humor in this movie is phenomenal, I absolutely loved the jokes and references that came with this movie! I liked how they really touched upon anger, bullying, sympathy, humiliation, the urge of getting revenge, realization, and forgiveness. I liked how they gave The Grinch a realistic backstory to why he hates Christmas and the town of Whoville so much. I also loved the characteristics that they gave Cindy Lou Who. She was a really likable and smart character and I really sympathized with her when get would receive ridicule from the mayor for wanting everyone even The Grinch to be together for Christmas. I also loved Martha (Mr. Grinches love interest). She is hot, and she is really funny at times. I also loved Cindy Lou Who's parents because of their wacky, and clumsy antics. I absolutely loved the ending! This movie is a fun, entertaining, hilarious movie that has a good message and a good storyline and it is loyal to the book and the 1966 animation. I recommend it!
rt_name: How the Grinch Stole Christmas - Movie Reviews

review: What so many critics get wrong with this movie is the value of Howard's strivings with visual style of the film. The Burton-esque design of sets and characters provides a feast for the eyes which supports and allows for a more calamitous plot, one which others find drags the film down.
rt_name: How the Grinch Stole Christmas - Movie Reviews

review: I get that, as a film, this is not the best. Personally, I grew up with this adaptation, so it holds close to my heart. Jim Carrey plays the Grinch really well and even today still makes me laugh. One thing I will say, I did not like the child Grinch scenes as much as I remember. The child actor did not do it for me, then again the acting overall in this movie is over the top and outlandish. Jim Carrey is easily the best part of this movie. Grade: 80% (B-)

review: Great acting, nicely shot, thrilling story! Strong independent low budget feature film! Overall a very solid effort by Anthony Z. James.

It's refreshing that in a story centered around troubled men and their issues, the women in the periphery are not portrayed as victims or trophies, but completely self-reliant people. While the guys are trying to figure themselves out, the girls have theirs sorted by navigating the troubles, often created by their men, with education, focus, and perseverance. The female characters appear as safe havens for the men, guarded by doors and gates, and can be reached only when they drop their macho armor.
The deliberate pacing and focus on characters' internal world makes the dramatic and intense scenes towards the end feel very real, almost like you're there.

Where this little indie shines is an intimate portrait of relationship between father and son - we see the walls being built and broken down by their awkward banter, letting the vulnerable warmth come through their tough and stoic facades.

Arthouse film fans might really enjoy this is as a very curious mix of British kitchen-sink social-realism and American mumblecore-style indies - imagine a crime drama made by Noah Baumbach or Joe Swanberg.

Solid, slow-burning redemption story with authentic performances and inventive cinematography. While the set-up might seem a bit familiar, this lyrical and genuine take on it is definitely worthwhile.
no reviews found

85/100. This live action adaptation of the classic cartoon is one of the best live action Disney movies to date. Will Smith not only did the Genie role justice but he knocked the performance out of the park. Naomi Scott and Mena Messoud played both of their characters very well. All of the musical numbers were done to perfection, as well as the new songs included in the film. The animation looked great, even making a big blue Genie look like he belongs in our world. The only major gripe I have with this movie is the actor who played Jafar was nowhere near as harsh and menacing as the character was in the original. All in all, even if you do not like live action remakes and are worried they will ruin your favorite film, you do not need to worry with this version of the film. In fact, I may even like this live action adaptation better than the original.

review_date: The live-action remake of Disney's hit film 'Aladdin' is a fresh and fun return to the wondrous world we experienced in the animated version. The remake does a wonderful job of staying loyal to the source material while also taking great steps to represent its female characters much better by giving Jasmine a better storyline and her own musical numbers. The visuals are stunning and the musical numbers are insanely well realized in live-action. Will Smith does great as his version of the Genie, which he ensures doesn't undercut the amazing performance from the late Robin Williams' version of the character.

Naught terrible about it, but 'Rio 2' is a boring - if colourful and well meant - follow-up to the 2011 original. The whole plot is basically just a typical family drama fest, filled to the brim with the clich√©s of relative and love quarrels. It's also entirely predictable, which doesn't help. A few of the characters from the first film are shoehorned in too, especially Nigel (Jemaine Clement). Jesse Eisenberg (Blu) and Anne Hathaway (Jewel) reprise their roles, Eisenberg is the better of the two. Bruno Mars joins the cast, I actually liked his voice for Roberto but unfortunately his character is forgettable. I'd guess the younger viewers will like this, as well as a number of others. For me, it's just very average.

It adds more colorful visuals, more catchy soundtrack, and more humor while expanding on the world of the franchise. However, it ignores a cohesive and compelling narrative and interesting characters, while being filled with clich√©s and unfunny jokes, bringing an early and dissapointing closure to a promising franchise.

It's absolutely the best series! The fact that people are trying to get a hold of problems where animal wildlife is going down the drain is very important... And people need to know when it's time to finally do something about hunting and bird trading. There's a time and place to have fantasy movies... but Rio tells us that the world can't always be your imagination and you have to care about other species. The spix's macaws are in the problems because our kind only care about the huge lump sum of money that spix's macaws are worth... when we should just leave them alone. You can literally buy a high end race car on the spix's macaws worth.. that is pretty sick and upsetting But the movie tells the story that it's time to pay attention That's what Rio is All about and will remain in my heart forever. If you could please make more it can do good for this world. For the purpose of the series Rio 1 and 2. Rio 2 may have a very much lower performance score but I really love it and hopefully we can get Rio 3 2021 ((Absolutely fresh must see)) Also spix's macaws are to be reintroduce 2020 this coming year after Christmas from a newest Post from a wildlife conservation program. Thank you so much Rio series for making this happen. Your a powerful message

Rio 2 has gorgeous animation that's a step up from the first film, great voice acting and catchy songs as well as decent comedy but that won't save it from its case of sequelitis thanks to the iffy messages that are essentially double standards, a villain that's reduced to a joke (thankfully, he's not the main antagonist again. IIRC, the villain and heroes don't even meet each other face-to-face until the third act) and a more formulaic story compared to the original's charm with more heavy handed eco-friendly messages than you can shake a stick at. Rio 2 is not that bad and it does have more effort put into it than Ice Age 5 but coming off the heels of the first film, Rio 2's a bit of a disappointment. I genuinely feel sorry for Blue Sky because they're so notorious for milking out Ice Age sequels that the other movies are overlooked even though they're actually relatively decent and underrated films. Oh well, maybe one day they'll get their own personal Into the Spider-Verse. ME FROM THE FUTURE: Well, now that Disney's shut down the company, I guess that next worthy competitor to Pixar won't be coming from this studio anytime soon. Yes, I consider The Peanuts Movie to be their best film but I still loved Inside Out more and it's hard to admire just how much of a turning point the first Ice Age film was for animation studios (that an animated film that was made by neither Pixar nor DreamWorks could be a success, especially since the other two CGI movies that came out in 2001 consisted of a flop and a Best Animated Feature nominee that offended animation fans for achieving that honour...but it offered some innovation by being the earliest CGI movie done with off-the-shelf software instead of dedicated so there's that) when it became Fox's own personal Shrek. So that last quote has aged about as well as The Birth of a Nation. Sad that now Blue Sky will never get a chance to earn legitimate acclaim the same way Sony Pictures Animation is garnering nowadays. I'll miss you guys :'(

Troy was a beautifully choreographed, though inaccurate and messy movie at best- and a half-baked historical disaster at worst. I've never seen an adaption dilapidate its source as badly as this movie; each character and event was practically unrecognisable as based on the Iliad. And somehow the material things were lucky; the true appeal of the Iliad is its emotional depth, literary parallels, its focus on mortality, etc. We see none of that in the movie Troy. Replacing depth with romance, gore and battles doesn't work. (Two out of three of which are really the only salvageable part of this film, and I'm not talking about the romance: everyone seems to love the Achilles-Briseis arc, which, in the Iliad, was an abusive, nonconsensual bloodbath, and it is almost universally agreed upon that the man didn't give a damn about this girl. (Especially considering Achilles' sexual ambiguity) Which is nothing to celebrate in the slightest, and the writing isn't even that good; I wouldn't have really rooted for them if I hadn't know the real story anyways.) It feels like the writers purposely deviated from the source material just to annoy the viewer; not a single death, other than Hector's, was handled in a way that even slightly resembled the book. Not a single character arc either, and the list continues. The Iliad isn't a tale of forbidden romance, (not of Achilles and Briseis and definitely not of Helen and Paris; three out of four people mentioned are now considered to not want to pursue a romantic relationship with the other) or glory, and ESPECIALLY NOT THE FALL OF TROY. They were okay with Oddyseus though. Anyways, this movie ruined my week, and every time I think of it I cringe. Save yourself, and watch a better film. Honestly, I can feel Achilles rolling over in his and Patroclus' grave.
Historical film quite beautiful and exciting that entertains you even if not fully because it can not take off an aura of boredom that pervades it a bit all from the beginning to the end
Brad is beautiful. End of story. Put it on mute and watched him.

There is much to like in this flawed historical epic. Troy is a visual triumph with stunning costumes and sets and plenty of giant, brutal CGI battles. The purists and Greek scholars may take issue with the historical liberties taken - but as an epic inspired movie there is much to like including a standout scene where Eric Bana's Hector fights Brad Pitt's Achilles. Troy is a good movie but not a great one. What's missing is depth - much of the characters reasoning, emotion and story is half baked and lacks depth. It's perplexing with such a talented ensemble cast and a 3 hour 16 minute runtime. However, Troy was released in the early 2000s following the likes of Gladiator and Lord of the Rings and obviously looked to cash in more on action rather than story and emotion which is where it falls short. Nonetheless its an entertaining, historical epic.

I always liked Troy. Judging by RT reviews, allot of people like it too unlike the pro's. Good acting across the board. Good special affects. Its a long movie, so be prepared for that. This might be my favorite Brad Pitt movie.

The most epic film I've ever seen. The battle scenes are so realistic, like the duel (wonderful directing). And the James Horner's music is the best! Hands down, one of the most beautiful war movies ever filmed.
I think this is a classic that never fails

I've been planning to rewatch this since reading Song of Achilles and Circe this summer and the pace wasn't too bad considering the lengthy runtime, however I definitely remember liking this better when I watched it shortly after the release. The action scenes were decent and the robust cast delivered what they could, however, historical omissions aside, the dialogue was notably cringeworthy at times and just felt so watered down and predictable.

Cinematically a good movie and Brad Pitt was excellent as Achilles. It's just unfortunate that a Hollywood blockbuster in 2004 couldn't handle telling the real story of Achilles and Patroclus. Instead of telling one of the most epic and tragic love stories of all time, they chose to make Patroclus a minor character--a friend and cousin. It was nearly incomprehensible why Achilles reacted as he did in that context. I had a lot of trouble finishing the movie because of that. Patroclus impersonated Achilles because he couldn't bear to see any more Greeks die when Achilles refused to fight. Achilles went berserk when Hector killed Patroclus and he knew, according to prophecy, Hector's death would mean his own as well. He told the Greeks that when he died, he wanted his ashes mixed with Patroclus' and buried together so they could be together forever in the afterlife. You don't do that for your bro' cousin. You do that for the man you love more than life itself. I wish the movie had had the courage to tell that story.

I feel this movie is under-rated by the professional critics, because they look at the technical and feel it's a sloppy movie. I love the way the story is told, and the action is very well done in my opinion. So many movies do fight scenes that bore me, and I believe it's because they don't feel real or natural. In the movie, everyone speaks of Achilles being a natural fighter blessed by the gods, but his own language and more importantly to me, his moves during the battles show of a well practiced fighter. He uses the same moves over and over, which are impressive the first time one sees them, but the fact he uses them again and again, and they don't always work for him, but he then moves onto another one, shows he's practiced and trained these moves. It shows he's got a library of moves to choose from, and he uses them over and over. And they surprise his opponents who haven't seen him use them before, and that's why the often work for him, but to him it's the same-old-same-old. The fighting Choreography is top-notch for that alone, in my opinion... but, it's well done in so many ways.

A long watch, but just about a worthwhile one. I enjoyed 'Troy', in short. A film, interestingly given his recent exploits, written by a certain David Benioff. It definitely has more than a few pacing issues, but they only affect the enjoyment factor minorly - at least to me. The score is a little lacklustre, mind. The casting is outstanding, even if I don't think all the performances are anything to truly shout about. I found Brad Pitt and Eric Bana, although entertaining, a bit wooden in parts. Elsewhere, Orlando Bloom and Sean Bean are arguably underused from an acting viewpoint - though their characters play huge parts, of course. You also have a load of other familiar faces, from Peter O'Toole to Brendan Gleeson to Rose Byrne to Diane Kruger. The definition of an ensemble. The action helps keep things moving, the battle sequences are very nicely done. The film takes an age to reach the event that everyone knows about, but when it finally does it's excellent. The cast and the action are my big takeaways from this. I couldn't comment on its accuracy on the original work. As a film, for me, it's very good.
I haven't seen anything this trashy in 20 years. Oh, did I forget to mention I'm 20 years old?
movie critics are on crack, this film is epic
A good starting point to teach your kid about the greek mythology, but too artificial to be watched seriously.

While some may be impressed by the scale of the action, I was extremely disappointed with some of the creative decisions on display in Troy. Achilles is transformed into a generic modern action/war movie protagonist, the Greek gods, who were the most interesting part of the original poem, are completely absent, and interesting characters are transformed into one-dimensional caricatures. I may also add that the relationship between Achilles and Briseis is rather creepy due to the power differential. It was even more so in The Iliad, but at least there it was portrayed in a detached manner rather than positively.

I actually agree with most critics opinion here, but defer greatly when concluding if it is a good movie or not. Outside of lord of the rings, this is my favorite large scale battle movie. The choreography of the single combat scenes is masterful and really this movie hits the top of my list solely because of the beach invasion scene. as implausible and dumb witted it may be, the film makers presented us a way it is theoretically possible with someone like achilles at the helm. There is way more to appreciate about this movie than to hate. You just can't look at it with bias eyes. The film makers had a vision, different from the original epic, and executed it flawlessly.

I really liked this film even if it wasn't accurate. I like the idea of Patroclus being the cousin instead of a lover because it shows different kinds of love that people fight for. It also makes the lose more personal and hurtful since he was his family and guardian and he failed to protect him. I think the aspect in the beginning that Sparta and Troy just became allies and are enemies again makes the fight more important because both sides want to put an end to the fighting. The fighting is amazing, I like how at the end they do not shy away from showing the atrocities that the Greeks did to the Trojans. The visuals are very nice to watch. The only negative thing for me was that I wish they made it longer or made the whole event take longer, all the events seemed rushed. But besides that a great great movie.

Pixar's sequel to Toy Story has Woody being stolen by a toy collector and the rest of the gang must go on a quest to save him, but does he want to be saved? Once again Pixar ups the animation game, especially with the human characters. The new toy characters are welcome additions to the franchise, I am particularly fond of Jessie. Randy Newman returns as the music composer from the first movie and again really hits it on the nose. Jessie's origin scene is a wonderful blend of music and animation that gets an emotional response from me every time. Highly recommend this movie, go check it out!

'Toy Story 2' is one of the greatest 3D animated movies ever made, that is also a sequel. This movie is a huge step up to its original, in every single way. The plot of the movie has Woody hyped up about going to camp with his owner Andy. But unfortunately, Woody's arm gets ripped, leaving him to be shelved, and Andy had to leave Woody behind. Then during a rescue mission, involving Woody and a penguin, Woody gets kidnapped by the fat guy from 'Jurassic Park', in order for him to be sold to a museum, along with these new cow boy dolls that are also being shipped. A main conflict is then developed throughout the movie, that being, should Woody stay in a museum, were he can live forever, but never played with or loved again? or should he continue his life with Andy as a toy, despite the possibilities and risks that come with it? Both Woody and the viewer are given all valid points and reasons. It's a strong conflict, that works excellently with the main plot. The characters are true to the first film, yet they're different at the same time. What I mean by that, is that Woody, Buzz, Potato head, have carried over their personalities, but what they had learnt from the last movie, accurately reflects on how they would act now. Woody is really charming, and not a total meany. Though he had one selfish moment towards the end, that was crucial to his character. Buzz is now serious and wise, while not as funny now, he still has some nice little subtle jokes, leading to my next point. The jokes hear feel a lot more subtle and casually delivered, which is so much better. The animation is also a big step up, maybe even a little too good for 1999. My only complaint here is with Jessie, as she is mildly annoying first, then an even huger dodo bag then Woody. But she does have a back story that links back to the main argument of the film. From then on, she's a charming, quirky character, along with Bullseye and Stinky Pete (the other toys that were being shipped to the museum). 'Toy Story 2' is awesome, even looking at it as its own movie, not doing any comparisons. I will highly recommend this movie to everyone, for infinity, and beyond!

I now present to you the first truly great Pixar movie. From what I said in the first two reviews, the biggest problem I had with both Toy Story and A Bugs Life is that the stories are a little too simple and there are no real emotional moments. This movie is where those moments finally come into play. I am of course talking about Jessie's backstory, which made a majority of kids cry, including me when I was younger. Speaking of Jessie, the new characters that are introduced in this movie are great, the highlight being of course Jessie and Bullseye. If I truly had to nic pic one problem, it's that the Prospector (Stinky Pete) feels like a really lousy excuse for a twist villain. It just felt like the people at Pixar and Disney (I think they bought Pixar at this point but I could be wrong) said "so there's a villain in this story right?" Basically, it felt last second. However, this doesn't hurt the quality of the film at all. I remember Stinky Pete as not being too annoying, which I can't say for future villains by this company (cough, Incredibles 2, cough). Anyway, I love this movie, and chances are, you do too. Is this possibly the best animated sequel ever? Go to Disney+ and see for yourself!

Toy Story 2 was pretty awesome! This is actually the definition what a sequel should be. The animation is an improvement from the first movie and the story is actually better than the first film. I just find this one a tad bit more engaging. This time Woody is apparently a rare collectors item. He had a Tv Show called Woody's Round Up Rodeo. And was a really hot toy at the time. He finds this out after trying to save an old penguin toy named Wheezy from a garage sale. When he saves him though he gets taken by a guy name Al. When he finds out about his show, two new characters Jessie, and Bullseye tell their story of why Woody should stay with them. But of course he wants to get back home to Andy so there's tension between all of the characters. Toy Story 2 is to me the best out of the four. As much as I enjoy the first one I just thought that this one had more character growth and a whole lot of depth. I just had a lot of fun with this movie and I honestly think that this is my favorite sequel out of the Toy Story franchise. 10/10

review: This review contains spoilers. How to Train Your Dragon 3 was a huge disappointment. I will be unpopular, but let me explain in detail why I didn't like it. The first 2 films are absolute masterpieces. The characters, the story, the animations ... Everything was just perfect. For the third, therefore, I had enormous expectations. Then, at the end of the film, I was pretty angry about how they developed this story arc. I mean, in short, the ending is wonderful, for sure. it is also very moving. But the beauty ends here. Everything else is just one stretch after another to get to the good ending. it's as if they already knew how the trilogy was going to end, but didn't have the slightest idea how to get there consistently. The villain, Grimmel, is one-dimensional and left me nothing. The animations, of course, are spectacular and are very colorful. But this is not just a movie. It's not just a nice ending. I know I shouldn't make comparisons, but for example Toy Story 3 (which after there is 4 is another matter) not only has a beautiful ending that will have moved everyone, even non-fans, but also a good villain, a articulated and well-structured story, a great evolution of the characters but above all great emotions. Here all this is only in the beautiful ending, but not in the rest of the film, too flat and made to stretch the broth. How to train your dragon 3 had great potential, but unfortunately it did not succeed in its intent.

review: its good but very sexist undertones, whether its the light fury not being regarded as the queen of all dragons (despite the same abilities as a night fury) to the end showing Hiccup and his son on a boat, showing him the world and then handing him off to his wife. Also theres a daughter who doesnt even so much as get her hand held at the end- it is mainly regarding his son. I feel like this movie could have been improved by not making the 4 main females either a side kick (ruffnut, light fury of toothless, astrid) or as merely the mother with no significant role. The mother was the best representation of women empowerment, showing just that women can do shit too lmfao. Also, this is a world of vikings yes. But it is also fictional with dragons. Women were considered empowered in the land of vikings- they were tough. They're tough too yes but only in their relation to how they can serve a man. Just kind of made the movie leave me with a bad taste in my mouth. But, women were considered property until the 1920's and not permitted to open bank accounts until the 1970s so I guess i'm asking too much. Decent plot overall, not a lot of character development. Toothless was the most 3d character with many layers because they had femininely represented him in the earlier movies and now had to make him the guy in his relationship with the light fury (who isnt even given a nickname)- they couldve done a lot more considering they're dragons and their only point of reference is how to write for humans ig. Good show either way but kind of disappointed me. At least hold your daughters hand at the end and show her the world like you're showing your son. Did you just have her to replace Astrid? Idk, just kind of backwards when you consider the main demographic is incredibly impressionable young boys and girls haha. 3 1/2 stars pretty good

review: The 2019 film: How to Train your Dragon Hidden World was astonishingly heartwarming and felt like a true masterpiece, However The general story line felt similar to the previous movie: How to train your dragon 2 that was released in June of 2014. The Film is about the Viking leader, Hiccup and his rare Night Fury dragon, Toothless on a Quest to find another Night Fury dragon, and to explore the world to discover new dragons. They discover another Dragon like Toothless however in their search they attract the attention of the powerful and fearsome enemy Grimmel the Grisly. A ruthless dragon hunter who wants to wipe out all dragons. Hiccup and toothless must find the hidden world of Caldera to hide their dragons and keep them safe from Grimmel's wrath. The relationships between the characters in the movie were strong and full of emotion. And the acting was fantastic, you could really feel the bond between all the characters. The movie had plenty of funny and dramatic moments over the course of the story. I personally enjoy the animations and the atmospheric environments in the film. And the music in the film was very well composed and added to the mood of film perfectly Many Scenes in the movie brought me Joy or sadness. It was full of great moments that made me laugh or smile, as well as some parts that brought a tear to the eye. Although the plot felt kind of similar to the previous movie with them dealing with an enemy who wanted to destroy/control all dragons it was still unique. The ending was both sad and happy which can be a difficult effect to produce in films. I highly recommend you watch How to Train you Dragon Hidden World because it was a wonderful experience, and I could watch It repeatedly. It is well worth your time and money. Just be sure to watch the two previous Movies first so you do not spoil anything.

No one can be disappointed with Twister if they are coming to a film looking for lots of tornadoes. However, they may not have been asking for the corniest possible melodramatic relationship story between it. And that makes this a rare contender for 'it's so bad, it's good.' The twisters are sheer entertainment, and usually come in at just the right point to break up the horribly acted melodrama, which would otherwise be unforgivable. Right from the get go, the jerk is trying to get a divorce and the sweetheart doesn't want it. And that dynamic lasts the entire film, until she eventually wins his heart back. Except by that point, we think she's pathetic, and we don't mind if he gets twisted away.
To me this movie is a timeless classic. Probably gets bad reviews when you compare it to CGI and SFX of today but if you keep it in perspective of the time it came out, it's great

I was legitimately baffled that Jo "wanted" to be with Bill at the end of the movie. Jo was a professor with a DOCTORATE and had a team of research students who brought Bills IDEA to reality. She spent her life trying to avenge her fathers death, and Bill in a whirlwind (pun intended) tells her to essentially "get over it already" (meanwhile he doesn't go to therapy) and confesses his love for her behind his girlfriends back (of course she overhears this and decides to move on from this trash character). Throughout the movie, there is NO and I mean NO sexual chemistry between Bill and Jo, and it is clearly not reciprocated by Jo who is a hardworking, intelligent woman. Bill consistently destroys and derails Jo's research, telling her to leave her LIFES work behind in the storm, destroys Jo's car, and puts them in unnecessary danger. There's NO logical reason why Jo would want to be back with someone who disregards her safety, her boundaries, and lusts after her nonconsenually while having a girlfriend.

review: I was excited for this movie as this movie was back story of some of the characters from The Wizard of Oz (1939) and I can say that I am satisfied with the movie. Yes, the movie cannot match the level of the original but it has it's good moments. The performances by actors and direction was good. The visuals were stunning and there were some surprises which shocked me. I had few problems with this movie. First, the story seemed too dark. The original was also dark story but it was presented in light manner and in other words, proper balance was there. Second, the last act seemed little bit stretched. Movie could have been 20-25 minutes short easily but overall it will not effect your experience. Overall, it was a good prequel for a 82 years old cult classic movie and I hope they make more adaptations using Oz books.

review: Oz the Great and Powerful. Such a strange film. A mix of dull narrative clich√©s and unpredictable magic. More than half of the film passes through well with the help of awe-inspiring CGI and a clear vision. As Oz, James Franco performed solidly without wowing. I found Mila Kunis's journey as Theodora perplexing and ultimately predictable. The central romance, similarly, is neglected but paraded around as important. Michelle Williams and Rachel Weisz round out the main cast with more solidity without stealing scenes for themselves. Some of the visuals seemed over-saturated and bombastic in the opening scenes in Oz, but this becomes balanced by a few breathtaking sequences later on. This might not be vintage Sam Raimi, but as a film Oz's positives just outweigh its scattered narrative and occasionally distracting CGI to deliver satisfying popcorn entertainment. In the end, the sense of wonder that the film clearly desires for you to feel lands.

review_date: It is only fitting that attempting a movie like this only be done when technology can take on the task. Visually, Oz is gorgeous, fit for the best Blu-Ray/HD home experience for years to come. For even the most casual of Wizard of Oz fans, the story of how the Great and Powerful Oz came to be the Wizard is very interesting and, especially by midway through the film, is exciting to watch. The story, though very slow-starting and buried by the horrendous acting from James Franco and miscast Mila Kunis, eventually becomes all about the larger Wizard of Oz story and, thus, entertains. The viewer has to wait, though. Clearly this version is for kids. The dialogue is ridiculously simple, choppy and hard to sit through, at times. Honestly, it may not have been as bad had James Franco not been playing the main character. His performance is painful. Mila, though more adorable than I've ever seen her, has too high of a voice to pull of the "evil" persona of Theodora, once a good witch, turned wicked by her sister as a result of Oz hurting her. She just didn't fit. Michelle Williams and Rachel Weisz, on the other hand were the best of good and evil. Rachel is perfect as a conniving witch. Michelle is pure and beautiful as Glenda the good with of the south. How the story begins in Kansas was very well done, especially as you watch the screen turn from old black and white, center-screen film to stunning colorful, widescreen high definition. It was gorgeous. Having his own companions ala Dorothy with Zach Braff as his monkey companion and China Doll brought back the charm of the original film. Eventually the story unfolds and merges perfectly into the Wizard we know. It was an enjoyable film, but Sam Raimi could have done better at directing through the poor script. He may have done his best with what he had, but in any case, the dialogue could have been written by me. The kids in the theater seemed to love it, though. And that may have been the point all along. If you enjoyed the Wizard of Oz, you have to give a theater version of Oz a chance.

review: So when this came out, I was in middle school and just finding my mythology love. I'd also just joined the school band, all because I saw this film. I know many critics will say this movie was poorly done especially in comparison to the predecessor from 1981, but truthfully as a new audience of a new generation. I loved so much of this film. Critics would be fair to say the acting, could have been better. Critics would be less fair to say the CGI was a failure do to it's overshadowing by Avatar from 2009. What they'd fail to tell you is that film's budget was so much more and was given much more vision by its director. So although it wasn't perfect, it was good for what it was. I personally believe if you're looking for a quick, thrilling adventure of the ancient Greeks, or just want to hear an awe inspiring Score written by the same composer as Game of Thrones(It was great but I prefer this as it's much better and much more unique!) I'd highly recommend this 8.5/10 film!
rt_name: Clash of the Titans - Movie Reviews

review: Perseus demigod, son of Zeus, battles the minions of the underworld to stop them from conquering heaven and earth. Director:Louis Leterrier Writers:Travis Beacham (screenplay), Phil Hay (screenplay) Stars:Sam Worthington, Liam Neeson, Ralph Fiennes Must say right off the bat that there is no Ray Harryhausen here. The 1981 original will always be my favorite "sentimental" version;hard to beat Stop-motion animation from Harryhausen. That being said....once I reconciled this in my brain I really started to enjoy this remake. This isn't nearly as bad as it's reputation. Quite the contrary. The film has a lot going for it. The picture quality is very good. 3D aspect is fair. Many of the landscape sections have plenty of that gimmicky depth that so many people seem to like. There are some strange distortions here and there, like scenes where there are crowds of people having a weird embossed look. I watched the film twice Fist in 3D than in 2D format . It's still good enough for me that it's a distinct improvement over the 2D for the 3D enthusiast like my self. I enjoy just about any Greek mythology flick about the gods. The story is very loosely based on the Greek myth of Perseus. Sam Worthington played a good brooding Perseus. How does't like Liam Neeson as Zeus, the man just delivers in every role he takes on . Mads Mikkelsen brought his usual charisma . Gemma Arterton as love interest for Perseus was a standout. The beauty of Andromeda has brought to life from the stunningly beautiful Alexa Davalos . The audio is a thunderous and special effects CGI , action sequences are excellent. On that basis alone, it's an enjoyable film.

"Clash of the Titans" is just one of those lazy day movies that is good, not great, for passing the time.

My expectations going into it were pretty low to begin with but damn, this really exceeded the stinker factor. It's an uninspired, forgettable eyesore of a flick that looks more like a video game. Ray Harryhausen's stop motion effects, costumes and sets are a thing of beauty. His stop motion Medusa is just spectacular. Enough with all the generic looking cgi creatures in all these new films, bring on the Kraken!

review: While it's faithful story-wise to its source material while still differentiating itself simply by being darker and a bit more cynical than the '81 film, Clash of the Titans 2010, despite having its moments is a terrible remake of a cheesy '80s classic. With the exception of Liam Neeson as Zeus and, to a lesser extent, Ralph Fiennes as Hades as well as Alexa Davalos as Andromeda, the performances are not that good with Sam Worthington barely speaking anything above a whisper (watch with subtitles, kids), way too much CGI - though at least it's rendered well...no comment on the infamous post-production 3D conversion - an anticlimactic final battle which was the main reason most of us wanted to see this movie in the first place and difficult-to-follow action scenes make it easy to understand why director Louis Leterrier claimed that this was not his movie.

review: An absolute adrenalin rush. Highly recommend. One must wonder why the disparity in critic versus audience scores. This movie is a masterpiece of subtlety that rewatching brings fulfillment and joy to the heart. You are taken once again on tale of solitary moments cherished in time from proposal, trepidation, and Maleficent's undying love for Aurora. You feel her torment but realize with her the importance of understanding. One person's fear and prejudice forced two Kingdoms into a war neither one wanted. And you once again realize the sheer power Maleficent has at her command, even among her own kind, not just with respect to man. She is one not to be crossed and she made that clear. This movie is a wonderfully balanced journey of fear and bravery, pain and joy, and seeing peace rise from war. There is nothing Maleficent would not do for Aurora and that includes ... (no more spoilers) Watch this movie. Appreciate the nuance. Then watch it again. And when you read the critics reviews you will understand that they just don't get what fairy tales are all about. Now go!

review: More sluggish than entertaining, for me anyway. I enjoyed the first film, but 'Maleficent: Mistress of Evil' is one I never really got into. The whole premise surrounding Angelina Jolie's character is uninteresting, not helped by a lack of serious rationale for why characters, other than Maleficent, are acting the way they are; namely Michelle Pfeiffer's Queen Ingrith. At best, it's lame motivation. Jolie remains the star, while Elle Fanning is solid enough. Pfeiffer isn't as enjoyable as she should be, mainly due to the aforementioned, but still produces a good display. Chiwetel Ejiofor is a terrific addition to the cast, but I can't honestly say I'll remember his performance here - which is a shame. Warwick Davis is, slightly, underused too. Also, how strange to see former professional footballer John Carew on the cast; albeit in a minor role. The effects are, pleasingly, an upgrade at least; they all look great. I hold no ill feelings towards this, I just wish it was greater.

Review menu icon Profile image Aayush Rajhans 10 months ago On October 18th , i saw Maleficent : Mistress of Evil , and i saw it and enjoyed it a lot. As a fan of the first film , i was super excited for the sequel, let alone the release date change from late May to October of 2019. I went in excited and came out really satisfied . The story is very interest ...More 251 people found this helpful. Review menu icon Profile image Kirstanuci Kirstanuci 11 months ago What do you get when you mash up Wicked Avatar Black Panther and Sleeping Beauty... "Guess who's coming to dinner, literally?" A film that Disney does right by the Disney Brand. There is enough emotional friction narrative from family, duty, community, society with a heavy emphasis on love and forgiveness and letting go via having the nature of a resurrecting phoenix. The Director R√∏nning with a super cgi production crew, cinematography, costumes, scenery no stone was left unturned in presenting breathtaking delicately embroidered beauty. Disney really delivers a visual masterpiece to savor. Night forests (delirious/fairied) juxtaposed Versailles formal gardens (topiaried/soldiered) , a marriage of nature made and man made. Lush pixie dusted cul-de-sacs, concrete spired churches, separated by a mysterious dark grey river. Smokey mountain clouds. Pearl armed gowns, gold leafed jackets, quail feathers, assymetrical war paint. It's an endless procession of spectacle. You have to see it so you can just be blown away by the shots, camera work and angles. Off the chart artistry and technicals! All of this backdrop sets the stage of the understory of co-existence. Bridging the Gap. Can we relook and forgive to forge a new alliance? How did we end up at opposite ends? What's the cost? How many mistakes? How many betrayals. Who? Why? So many missteps by the characters bc of the narrowness of their personal desires and aspirations are contrary to everyone else they end up in conflict. Elliptical mirrors out of focus. Nothing can move forward without some one at some point "forgiving" And a Mother's Love, whether Human, Fairy, or Mother Nature's can be the most unconditional forgiving in existence. This is the discussionary journey each character unknowningly is on and unknowingly having with theirselves. How can I react to this with all I know and don't know, and what will I lose or gain. Heady stuff for Disney, but it's there. Endearing without being syrupy sentimentality. No kookiness. No reliance on a cute card. Just aces. Angela Jolie and Michelle Pfieffer, both bring to life the necessary passion and compassion for their sharp deeply focussed portrayals. Never clunky, garish, overplayed ~ on target with finesse, panache, and crackling charisma. They could have been shticky, not here. They carry their anchored characters effortlessly. This is a Disney film and is successful at that Disney exuberance. And a happy healthy ending. Ta-daa! Sometimes Disney Films get censored down that they loose the turbulence life presents ... but here they get the balance just so right. They don't beat you over the head with the situations each character is struggling with. Simple self-preservation. Will you lie, cheat, steal, betray or be truthful, compete fairly, be loyal in that self preservationistic plight? This is life's dharma: our behavior. To be fair, it's the contrapuntal acting duo of Jolie and Pfeiffer that elevate the story experience. The supporting cast does fine, we feel them but without the feisty spirited duo, it would have been just a nice film. Alot of development went into each theme, and each facet could be its own film. The editing is exemplary in folding each theme on each other, causing the many revolving relationships to shine as a whole. You can feel there is a lot of story, scenes and film left out on the editing floor that will end up in a sequel. All ages will cherry pick the takeaways from film, there is something for everyone. It is a G film with an all around "A". Hats off to Disney for the sensitive evocative story of healing by forgiveness, acceptance and allowing loved ones and ourselves to make mistakes and fail. And revise ourselves to rise up again.

review: Great watch, would watch again, and can recommend. This was a very impressive sequel to the original. I'm sure it had something to do with low expectations, "What are they going to do to follow THAT....ohhhh". It's probably the first time I've registered a large scale battle like this movie has since....I guess "Infinity War", but "Lord of the Rings" seems more apt as it is a fantasy movie as well. What's really odd is that this movie has too many story lines, but still manages to balance them acceptably. It also goes the extra mile to explore the angle of "it doesn't matter how different we are, but what we do with our potential" sort of thing. There are race traitors, and true examples of evil disregard for life. Michelle Pfieffer really owns her role as an evil queen, and sure they go into backstory to give a modicum of justification, but she gets into death in a very psychotic fashion, not to mention the page. While the most charming part of the movie is the most boring, unity and peace, it is amazing at the great lengths people will go to prevent such a thing, and that's really the movie that you're watching here: someone going to every length to be a hero, and just being a jerk instead. Well worth the watch, and I think most would enjoy even without having watched the first.

review: Climactic ending? Sure. Good movie? Eh, it was alright. A few things diminished my enjoyment of this movie to less than the first two. Firstly, the fact that the colonel didn't just kill Caesar right off the bat really bugged me. It wouldn't have been that much of a problem but his capture, though integral to his character arc, took way too much of the runtime and got less and less believable as time went on. Also the escape was too easy and didn't have any sort of tension or anything. Second, I was expecting something a little more tangibly climactic with the plot of this film. Yes, it was good to end on Caesar finally leading his people to a home of safety and it was pointed to realize that that was his purpose all along but aside from a line of dialogue here and there, I didn't pick up on the journey of the apes to a new home as one of much importance until the very end. That was my problem with this movie in general. More than it's predecessors, things just happen and they'll have a reason down the road but they don't have a logical reason to have occurred. I was expecting more than just a sequence of events plot. Even if the plot takes a step down, I think that the overall narrative remains true, even if the thematic elements aren't as clearly fleshed out. There were interesting new ideas (Novas, donkeys, and other signs of the worlds shifting) incredible new set pieces, the performances, visuals and digital effects were just as good as always and better but overall, the narrative punch was scattershot to me and had a weaker impact than the last two. Caesar stands out once again as the focal point but he can't hold this movie entirely together, it's become too big for him and maybe that's how it always had to be. The series outgrew it's main character on purpose and ended at the parting of ways. For me personally, it weakened the experience but I suppose, made for a better outcome. Caesar's journey is the natural last step in his arc but I was frustrated by the portrayal. It wasn't bad by any means I just didn't feel connected like I had before. The old familiar characters were there but it just didn't have the weight to me. I still loved Maurice. He was even more kind, more loyal and even more awesome and he didn't die in the end. This was truly an awe inspiring ending and overall a satisfying one but I suppose I wanted something a little more dynamic. I guess what we learned is leave humans alone and they'll kill each other. Run into the hills and be free. Ok then. I'll give this movie credit, it was quite an achievement. I just didn't totally buy it.

review: War for the Planet of the Apes is the best conclusion to this trilogy I could have hoped for. War, my favourite movie in this outstanding and underappreciated trilogy is the big finale, and it delivers. In every aspect. The CGI has peaked in this movie, Caesar, Maurice and the Colonel are the best characters this movie and we get to see the darker side of Caesar which I loved. Bad Ape was really good along with the little girl and and the story was amazing. Overall, War for the Planet of the Apes, is dare I say, a masterpiece and I wish that this trilogy gets the love it deserves some day.

review: It's hard to explain to someone that a movie about a civilization of intelligent apes is honestly incredible, but I try to explain it time and time again because this movie is outstanding. It's impressive to me that for the second time Matt Reeves has managed to take a story about apes and turn it into a touching, serious, and interesting movie. The VFX and cinematography give this moving some beautiful visuals throughout and the score and directing create many emotional and inspiring moments that take this movie to the next level. Maybe I'm biased because of my love for monke, but I love this move. 4.5/5.

review: The fact that fact that it took this trilogy for people to realize that undoubtedly Andy Serkis is the greatest performance actor of all time will always be surprising. Where we knew what Revenge Of The Sith had to go in order to set up A New Hope, we all knew where this one had to go to match up with Charlton Hestons (or Mark Wahlbergs) Planet Of The Apes movie. The maij difference between the 2 is that War didn't feel like it was shoehorned in to match up where ROTS did. Woody Harrelson gives us a style of him we haven't seen since Natural Born Killers (absolutely ruthless and dark). This may be the only trilogy ever made where a single one can't be knocked as bad or decent, the consistency of greatness these films have is something big franchises should look to for years to come. This movie also does not forget it's roots as social allegory of human nature in general. It makes my top 10 all-time sci-fi films as well as dramas

review: Absolute Shakespeare, this taught me how to be a good person and it taught me about onions. This phenomenal piece of art freed my mind of depression and the lack of understanding of people around me. This film really opened my eyes to the true possibilities of life. It made me able to accept not only people for who they are, but myself for who I am. Yes, I may be a vicious dictator who regularly sends entire races of people to their deaths in a gulag, but this film showed me that that's just not the real me. I can be whatever I want to be, so from this day forth I choose life. I will ignore the stresses and expectations placed upon me by my forebearers and choose to live a good and honest life. This is me coming out as a communist. Film weren't as good as the third. Lmao.

'Shrek' is such a classic movie, you basically haven't experienced life without seeing it at least ounce. On the outside, 'Shrek' is a pretty funny movie that mocks Disney. But it also has elements of a very intelligent love story, with a moral that is portrayed in such a brilliant way. The story follows an ogre named Shrek, who lives alone in a swamp, and he was happy that way. Until one day his swamp has been overrun by fairy tale creatures, that were banished there by the maniacal lord Farquaad. So Shrek has to get his land back by going on a quest with a donkey (named Donkey) to rescue a princess. Though a simple plot, it makes up for this with its lovable characters, and comedy. The main character, Shrek, is really funny, and his growth throughout the movie is beautiful. Shrek takes a-lot of punches through out the movie, as he gets his heart torn apart, and judged by everyone. But Shrek kept going, and by the end of the movie, Shrek finds what true love really is. Donkey, while not as funny, still got a few chuckles out of me. Fiona is a crucial part of the plot, as she first comes across to Shrek and the audience as this generic princess, but when she hears Shrek talking to Donkey about his feelings, Fiona softens up towards Shrek, and she starts showing her personality. Shrek then starts liking Fiona for who she is. I also really liked the main villain, lord Farquaad. Literally everything he says is memorable, thanks to how the voice actor delivered his lines. He is also a pretty big threat towards Shrek and Fiona's relationship. All of the main characters play their parts effectively, and none of them feel like they're sitting on the side lines, if you know what I mean. 'Shrek' also has an excellent soundtrack, that is too quite memorable. The reason why I couldn't give this movie a perfect score was due to the pacing at the start feeling a little off, and the animation can be a-bit jarring at times. But other then that, this movie is a masterpiece, I highly recommend it.

Like many say, Shrek is indeed one of the greatest animated films of all time. Everything about the film is done perfectly in its own unique way. Shrek is a great relatable character for literally the majority of the world, the story is really funny and even emotional, the other characters like Donkey, and Fiona have amazing character. The animation looks pretty good for its time, the voice acting by Mike Myers and Eddie Murphy fit their roles for Shrek and Donkey so flawlessly, and the soundtrack is beautiful. The message is also probably one of the deepest of all time in cinema history. Shrek is an important film and one of my top animated films out there. It deserves the attention it gets.

A film that spawned a thoroughly respectable sequel, Shrek's genius lies in combining comedy and fairy tales in a magical world/swamp. Having watched this only a couple of weeks ago, I was struck by how wonderful the animation still looks, nineteen years on. If we forget for a minute just how disgracefully old this film somehow is, it's easy to fall in love with this all over again. The wit and ideas that swarm all over the running time are out of this world, and the fact that Shrek 2 (2004) is just as good, only adds to Dreamworks' achievement. The less said about Shrek The Third (2007) and Shrek Forever After (2010) the better, so go and enjoy the original once again.

As a kid I hated Shrek. He looked ugly, the animation wasn't exactly what I'd call 'gorgeous', and the little me couldn't tolerate seeing a princess beat up soldiers (I know, it happens in Shrek 2 and Shrek the Third but I couldn't tell the difference). So I finally watched it when I had nothing better to watch, just to see what all happens in it and why exactly does everyone meme it so much. Turns out the little me was dumb. This is a perfect animated movie for anyone who appreciates a good sense of humour. Shrek is a story about the eponymous ogre who lives in a swamp, always wanting to be left alone. It's a parody of a fairy tale, so just like them the villagers often try to attack him, only to be scared away. Shrek is the opposite of what we see in our fairy tale hero - he's ugly, he's disgusting, he's an outcast, he belongs to the species whom the fairy tale hero kills. But Shrek does not care about what people think about him, or he did until he and Donkey went to slay the dragon and rescue Princess Fiona so that Lord Farquaad would return him his swamp. The message the movie gives us is that looks can be deceiving. Shrek is afraid no one will like him because he is just an ugly ogre, Donkey believes everyone thinks he's stupid because he's a donkey, Princess Fiona does not want anyone to see him at night because she turns into an ogre herself. Even in the end when the spell breaks and she sees herself in the ogre form, she is confused since she thought she will finally get rid of her curse, but it turned out the opposite is true. The dragon also seemed to be ferocious until Donkey asked her out. Shrek makes a perfect use of parody imagery throughout the movie. There is the Mama Bear from Goldilocks who has been killed and turned into a rug, there's Ginger Bread Man whose feet have been broken, the Magic Mirror describes Snow White in a double meaning manner, there are magical animals who are traded by the soldiers etc. That combined with the magical world and the moral that it gives, all of these elements combine to make a very fable-like story. It actually feels like this could be a bedtime story that would have been told in the medieval era if they were as progressive as us. I liked Shrek so much that I already watched it twice: Once while watching it on my own and once to show it to my sister. I really wish they make more of these. Shrek alone is better than all the other animated films made nowadays combined. I could have given it even more stars if it were possible. It makes me nostalgic and it makes me laugh. I couldn't want anything more.

Shrek is the first animated movie to win an oscar for animated movie and became an icon for millennials and generation z and is a masterpiece. Shrek tells the story of an ogre called Shrek who engages in the traditional fairy tale story of saving a princess with a sidekick. This film famously subverts fairy tale tropes and is a satire exploring the deep themes of beauty and appearance, love, and friendship as well as not judging a book by its cover. Feauring the stellar voices of comedians Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz, and John Litgow who bring these characters to life. But is the voice of Eddie Murphy as Donkey who blows it out of the park with Murphy's signature humor some of it which would fly over with kids. The film has great heart and is incredibly fun as it makes fun of the fantasy genre and is quite edgy at times not being afraid to do that in a family movie. Shrek is possibly one of the best animated films of all time and a now classic.

A day in the life of Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's marriage. Doug Liman's action romantic comedy Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005) is a crazy meta comedy about Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's marriage. Simon Kinberg's script is pretty funny with all these real life references to Pitt and Jolie's legendary relationship and celebrity. However his cheesy one liners and average romance writing is only possible because of Pitt and Jolie's real chemistry and excellent delivery. William Fichtner is funny as the marriage counselor too by the way. "Brangelina" were so famous that Mr. & Mrs. Smith was going to be a hit no matter what, but it's still a fairly decent movie. Plenty of exciting gunfire and a few memorable fights. The overall assassination plot is dumb, but you're watching for Brad and Angelina's charismatic lead performances. Liman's interesting direction makes all the espionage and action entertaining. I do wonder if Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie will ever get back together as they seemed like a nice couple. But, you never know what a marriage is really like unless you're in it. Micheal Tronick's editing is all over the place with erratic action cuts in the middle of romantic scenes and dramatic cuts in the middle of action sequences. He makes Mr. & Mrs. Smith's 120 minute run-time feels a lot longer. Bojan Bazelli's cinematography is very pretty. Everything looks like a clothing ad thanks to Michael Kaplan, Linda Matthews, and Toby Bronson's costumes and Deborah La Mia Denaver and Lisa Buono's make-up choices. What else can be said about Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie? They are both gorgeous, funny, stylish, and exciting as lead actors. They completely steal the show in Mr. & Mrs. Smith. I really liked the cameos from Jennifer Morrison, Michelle Monaghan, and Kerry Washington as the assassination guild members. Vince Vaughn is both funny and obnoxious in Mr. & Mrs. Smith, so take that how you will. It's not a great movie by any means, but it's such a fun novelty film that I cannot help but love it.

A bunch of "the arrow literally points to the next clue" moments mixed with facepalm -inducing coincidences and deus ex machina. Some of the sloppiest storytelling you'll ever see, yet somehow still kinda fun to see how stupidly our heroes stumble upon the obvious.

A decent plot but nothing too exciting. I liked the science vs religion debate explored. Ending twist was certainly a twist but after watching the last one, a little predictable. Following the clues was a little straightforward this time.

Next to zero character development within the film leaving only a history with Langdon as the audience's feeling of connection to anyone. Where The Da Vinci Code tried to show Langdon's use of art and symbols to solve the clues, this movie skips any attempt to do so which robs the character of what makes him fun in the books.
A movie that coasts on the basis of narrative convenience, Angels & Demons serves nothing more than passing time.

Our favorite symbologist, Robert Langdon, is back with another chance to save the face of faith. The second installment in the Langdon trilogy. Action, thrills, suspense and a lot more make this second movie even better than the first.

"Angels & Demons" has some thrilling moments and a more than capable cast, but the movie fails to leave an impact. I thought it was interesting at first, but the story becomes overly convoluted and ridiculous and I never found myself particularly invested in it. I didn't particularly love "The Da Vinci Code" movie, but I was able to have more fun with that movie. This movie feels longer than it is due to inconsistent pacing and I felt like it really dragged. I have no idea if it follows the book well at all, but as a movie, it wasn't always easy to get through. Overall, this is one of those movies that isn't awful, but I am not sure I liked it enough to call it good, or even okay.
Great movie! So underrated!!!

While some view "Angles and Demons" as an improvement from it's predecessor, I personally found the film version of Dan Brown's "The Davinci Code" to be far more thrilling. The predictability of Angels and Demons was at a scary new level, leaving nothing thrilling left to the imagination. Far too long and full of every illuminati/conspiracy cliche in the book. Some of the action may keep viewers around until the end, but Angels and Demons is over 2 hours of something that feels all too forgettable once complete.

More religious shenanigans as cardinals in Vatican City have been kidnapped and are beginning to be killed one by one unless Tom Hanks' Robert Langdon can decipher some more long forgotten clues about the mythical Illuminati. This one has a bit more excitement than the Da Vinci Code. But really it's more of the same but paced a bit better. Ewan McGregor co stars.

Well it did a very good job to takes us to places Dan Brown described, so the location selection was just what we imagined. Yet, to stuff the book as it is into a movie plot with all side explanations and monologues is an impossible mission. Nevertheless, they did well to change some absurd details in the book to make more sense on the screen. The screen writer and the director failed a big deal here, the original literature requires more work to fit into a movie.

While being a fun, fast-paced thriller, Angels and Demons is a noisy attempt at adapting a very good book to the big screen with mixed results.

With higher stakes, better pacing, more action and being different from its source material yet still faithful to the main story of the book, Angels & Demons is an improvement on the previous Dan Brown adaptation (though considering that A&D was the first book in the Robert Langdon series, maybe this movie being better was a given, even if their were a decent amount of changes, most notably, Ron Howard deciding not to make this movie a prequel to The Da Vinci Code) though the story is rather implausible with a hilariously absurd climax that, even with the changes, lent itself better to the page than it did to the big screen. Plus, the movie's more faithful aspects also extend to Dan Brown's inaccurate research and dialogue that sounds more like a Wikipedia article rather than plot-important exposition for the audience's sake. But at least, this was an exhilarating adventure. The book was better, though :/

I thoroughly enjoyed the book written by Dan Brown, and if you go into this film without reading the book first, it can be a bit of shock of what takes place. I credit mostly the adaptation of the book in the movie towards my rating, however, the cinematic score was what was able to complete the film. Rating: 2.5/5

I've read the book. And the film doesn't disappoint. Beautiful locations. And even though the historical information is factually incorrect so as to fit the narrative, it is still very believable. I can't help but be sucked into the fantasy of it all. I suppose if you're not into history, and are not into the lore of ancient secret societies of europe, i can understand if there's not much in this film to get you excited. But I'm a bit shocked that these Robert Langdon movies are not better received. But i find them to still be very enjoyable after multiple viewings.

A beautifully staged, lit, shot drama film that lacks emotional drama or suspense, let alone magnetism from key players. Film perhaps unfairly ravaged by critics simply because it's academic/cultural leanings are all bunk and because the film is supposed to be something like a spy thriller but lacks energy regardless of piling clues and supposedly tense conflict. Movie is based on book about Illuminati scholar involved with a counter-terror plot at the Vatican. Religious imagery and portentous, flatulent dialogue abound. Probably the best thing about the movie is the rich colors and impressive old-world scenery.
Angels and Demons surpasses it's appalling predecessor and is entertaining without being too preachy.
It is a fast paced and fun film, but one that does not stand up to scrutiny. A fun afternoon time waster but when compared to the source material is pretty weak.

You don't go into a Dan Brown movie for character development, great acting, or the special effects. (Seriously, don't look at the effects. They're meh at best.) No, you go into a Dan Brown movie to watch people frantically travelling from place to place, and in that sense Angels and Demons delivers. [I'd like to give a huge thank-you to the film makers for leaving out one of the most ridiculous plot twists I have ever read in any book.]

review_date: This film is too good in my personal opinion, the film techniques were used properly, such as camera angles, sound, lighting and much more. I enjoyed watching beautiful shots of the Vatican city in epic scenes of action and persecution. Although unfortunately has bad score in the criticism and was not widely accepted by various circumstances, it is still important to recognize that this film not only attracts a conspiratorial public, also a scientific or agnostic public could enjoy this exciting film of mistery and conspiracy theories. Here you can also find important values, such as the importance of studies and preservation, since these are the keys used by these characters to solve the whole problem that involved the destruction of the Vatican and the murder of those who involved the Papacy, besides, they demonstrate as a great power that the human being has at his disposition, which serves to solve the most difficult problems that exist in life. However, the internal conflict that these characters face is ignorance, since they have to solve an ancestral mystery, which only the Illuminati knew in their hidden society. Also in the Climax you will find great answers to your doubts, and you will learn in detail about the Papacy and the Catholic Church in the past , and you will be able to learn about important theories implanted within the church about the feared and powerful sect of the Illuminatis .

review: A surprisingly accurate movie theologically with thought-provoking subplots (what would you do if you were God? What would be the ramifications of our sinful inclinations when combined with the powers of God? How does God's power interact with free will? etc). The unique romantic comedy combines with those theological conundrums to create a story that is both mentally stimulating and entertaining. The only knocks on this movie from a family perspective are some sexual situations/innuendo, language and a flip of the bird.

A television field reporter for a local station in Buffalo, New York blames God for all the wrongs in his life and claims he can do God's job better than him. Then God takes him up on that offer. The first two acts of this movie are hard to watch as Bruce makes bad decision after bad decision. The final act does a good job bringing it all together and giving you the warm-fuzzies by the end. Jim Carrey does a great job in the title role with his over reactions putting us in his shoes really well. I believe I will forever see Morgan Freeman whenever I picture God from now on. The message is good here, but I think the enjoyment of this movie depends on if you can get through the first half of it.

Flawed, sure, but who genuinely doesn't want to see the "if only I was God" premise played out by Jim Carrey? It doesn't go down the pious route - which wouldn't be believable - but Bruce tries to use this power for personal gain. There's some amusement in here and Carrey's 'everyman' character does come across fairly believably. Morgan Freeman also makes a good God, I think it's fair to say.
It just kept me entertained. 6.3, C+

What a great idea for a movie and who better than Jim Carrey to turn it into something really fantastic? But like so many films of this ilk, the premise fails to reach its potential as either a good comedy or a meaningful message.
