Story/Screenplay: (2.5/5) Children are a targeted audience for this story, but in it, our antagonists are sociopaths. They're not even funny sociopaths. All in all, the storyline had potential, but it wasn't as family friendly as I would have liked. Duration/Tempo: (3/5) At 1 hour and 36 minutes, it's a short movie that felt a bit longer. Cast & Crew: (2.5/5) Leslie Mann, Jesse Eisenberg, and Anne Hathaway were good, but the overall cast was mediocre. Summary: (2.5/5) The story and cast were not good and the film felt longer than it actually was. A thumbs down.
Nice animation funny and crazy

This is a good example of putting together a great cast of celebrities, who aren't even that bad of voice actors and the experience feels awkward. I don't know if the voice direction was poor or if the voices just didn't fit the characters, like a bad dub of anime. The worst part of this is just that it's about birds. Most of the bird characters feel cheap, except the main 3, and it's hard to get invested in them on any serious level. That might be the key though, taking this movie serious on any level might be the mistake. The writing is actually pretty good, complete with pivotal moments, a complex villain, a heap of mad circumstance, and beautifully constructed relationships between characters. It really is like a great writer got saddled with a premise and just angrily crafted something passable out some exec's daughter's fascination with birds. It's a good movie, and I will likely throw it on again in the future, but it'll probably be with an, "Oh yeah, the BIRD movie...". Can recommend.

I have twin two year old boys and finding a gem like this that keeps them calm while I can clean or cook is rare. They watch this movie at least 4 times a week and we haven't gotten tired of it yet. I think it's one of the cutest animated movies I've seen. It incorporates singing and dancing with a movie about bird smuggling which is something I've never seen before. Worth the watch with small kids, I'm just as interested in it as them and it doesn't have the annoying kid songs like most kid movies.

Rio has some cringy moments and I swear I saw the same character model for a random guy being reused 4 times but when you look at the quality of 2011 animated movies that aren't from or distributed by Paramount, Rio is actually quite heartwarming and fun. The music is catchy, the animation is bright and full of colour, the voice acting is good and there is also a fair bit of comedy for all ages. Oh and, uh, there's some fanservice of sorts. I know it says rated G and there was even that instance where after they got a PG rating, executives were having none of it and edited some footage to be rerated G on appeal but if your children are wondering what's that thing expanding in their...uh...you get the idea. I feel sorry for Blue Sky because they have such a poor reputation as "the company that milks out Ice Age sequels" that the original movies sandwiched in between get overlooked. But if you're looking for a good bird movie that doesn't involve penguins, Rio is likely the one for you.
With music, laughter, and a cute animal couple. Rio is truly a great kids movie. In fact, The fact that this movie isn't critically acclaimed is ridiculous.

Saving Private Ryan is the most unrelenting, intense, heartbreaking and realistic war movie ever made. Final Score - 84/100

It's been many years since I watched Spielberg's war epic, and I can assure you, the opening sequence has lost none of its heft. I'm talking, of course, about the Omaha beach landings, not the cold opening of a veteran visiting a grave (I don't want to give anything away there). It remains one of the most astonishing pieces of film making ever put to screen, and what is impressive about the film is that the key battle scenes throughout, shot in the mud and filth of desecrated rural France are every bit as focused. There is a very loose connection between the plot and a real life tale, and if there is a criticism of Saving Private Ryan it is perhaps its opening and closing. It adds an emotional heft that doesn't really need to be there in my opinion. But it's a small quibble, and Saving Private Ryan remains an incredible piece of film making, one that Spielberg backed up in the genre by going on to produce Band Of Brothers (2001) and The Pacific (2010).

review: I think this film benefits greatly from the low expectations the idea of another reboot to a talking ape franchise creates. I know I personally had no clue what this movie was going to do and even littler clue of how it was going to do it. Add in my preexisting knowledge of the trilogy dynamic and coming in I was rolling the dice on my enjoyment of this film. Though the shock may come from the low expectations, I can safely say that it was shockingly incredible. Let's just get the regular stuff this movie nailed out of the way. The cinematography, special effects, music and even performances were all surprisingly great. The way the film palpably speeds up little by little until it comes to a conclusion that is roaring full throttle is an excellent use of a tight 90-minute runtime. I think what makes this film so amazingly special is not just it's inclusion of intelligent apes but the way the plot focuses almost entirely on them and in particular, Caesar. Caesar is the anchor around which the whole film comes together. Without him, this wouldn't have been half the experience. Every time I looked at Caesar, I was dumbfounded at the intelligence so apparent on his face. What Caesar is to the film, so his face is to his character and here comes the incomparable Andy Serkis, making history again as he and a visual effects team on the cutting edge bring another unlikely character to life. It is that life, that look in Caesar's eyes, the way he twirls a twig between his fingers, his focus and his piercing stare create a riveting new protagonist for a unique and incredible story. And that was all that needed to be done. From the get-go I was completely invested in Caesar's story and wonder of wonders, I found myself much more invested and much more interested in his scenes that contain no dialogue then the scenes with the human characters. Caesar's journey is riveting to watch as he uses his wits to gain more and more control of himself, his fellow apes and the humans around them. I was blown away, my jaw dropped when Caesar says his first word and I was struck in his final scene with James Franco to see that he was standing just as straight and tall as his former caregiver. To expound on that scene (and the gripping third act rampage) another great achievement of this film is bringing Caesar to his ultimate destiny as head of the new tribe of intelligent Apes. It's a great Sci-fi achievement to make such a foreboding event as apes striking back as one that is made as a strike for justice. I can't wait to see how this is all fleshed out more in the next two films. And yet this movie walks the line, Caesar must leave behind that bad but also the good things humans have done for him and at least at this point, he is by no means perfectly commendable in all his actions (though the human touch does lend him compassion, an essential step on the path to humanity as it were). All in all, this is excellent science fiction that uses it's unique angle to tell an engaging and enthralling story rather than explore philosophical themes to deeply and that is completely fine by me. Man, I didn't see that coming. What a ride

review: Stunning visuals, smart plot, and very entertaining, little complicated Rise of the Planet of Apes stars James Franco who works at a company which finds Apes to use for tests and as a mother of a Ape geys out of control and has to be put down Franco's character has to take the mothers son like he is a father, the Ape Caesar (Andy Cerkus) grows fast and learns things very quickly, now after he is involved in a incident he is taken into a sort of Animal Control place were there are many caged Animals, now Caeser is staying there for 90 days til he can go back, while surrounded bu other Animals Caeser is learning more about his roots and to be more like his fellow Apes and other Animals and has actual interactions, while some of the people take the Animals and use them as test subjects, and a virus breaks out and slowly there are many problems and becomes a epic beginning, there is spot on Ape CGI (except one frame were Caesar opens a cage) the action throughout is pretty good with Apes becomes smarter and learning, the Apes get revenge on the others who treated them badly, this a outstanding film, and is sci-fi but tackles more about the drama and connections between characters. Mixed: This is not a film for everyone as some people (who are sensitive to Animals in cages) might be scared with Animals in cages and abused (as the some of the humans dont care id the Animals die), this is a mature emotional thematic film which might be too much for sensitive viewers Overall: This is a magnificent film that any one who likes sci-fi drama should check this out Grade: A Entertainment scale: 9.7

review: I believe this is the greatest origin story movie that lacks a real literary basis to have ever been made, aided in great part by Serkis's pioneering motion-capture prowess and the extremely well-done CGI throughout the film. They did an impeccable job eliciting emotional responses to the characters and the general sense of direction the movie had felt adroitly handled. Everything down to the casting was top-notch: Lithgow made a fantastic Alzheimer's dad, for example. Having watched the previous 6 apes movies I was relieved that they didn't rely on guys in monkey costumes and instead showed the apes as they are in real life for the most part. The catalysts to Caesar's mistreatment did start to come off like an idiot plot as the misunderstandings would be difficult to make in real life, but that's the only criticism I have. While I expect the sequel to be a little heavy on action and less on the characters, I am excited for it as this movie was just extremely well-done.
mojo_name: Rise of the Planet of the Apes

review: Rise of the Planet of the Apes is both enjoyable and lovely. It was a powerful film. The film could have been just a bit longer. I felt the movie was paced a bit too quickly. CGI is great. Cesar's facial expressions tell it all! You feel his rage, his fear, and his child like innocence through his wonderfully animated eyes. There were a bit too many plot jumps in the last 30 minutes, but all in all, it was directed very, very well. Coupled with a good score, mellow at times, but highly dramatic which heightens the tension. I highly doubt this film will disappoint the fans of the original. You will love and enjoy it.

I hated this movie, a terrible sequel to a movie I thought was really funny. The plot goes in all kind of incoherent directions and I honestly hated Drac. He's so unlikably selfish in this movie that it's borderline awful to think his part in the plot is the primairy storyline. The worst part of it all however is the ending. Just when you thought Drac's predictable character development has finally passed by and you can stop disliking him for his selfish needs, this out of nowhere villain appears to give the movie a climax, and it all ends with a lame-ass fight scene with overexaggerated animation that makes the action more stilted than engaging.

Hotel Transylvania introduces a Dracula's Grandson Dennis into the world of monsters and finding out if Dennis is a Vampire or human by taking him on a road trip to put him through tasks and activities to show what a monster does, while his parents are away visiting his human grandparents.

This sequel was slightly better than the first. It still seemed slightly direction less in some parts, but as a whole, this sequel had a plot and it knew what it was doing. Dracula is a very inconsistent character, but other than that, the other characters where fine. Jonathon seemed more likeable in this movie and the new characters where enjoyable. This movie had some good jokes, but I don't think there was any that really made you laugh out loud. There were still some jokes in here that just didn't work with older kids+ but the younger kids enjoyed. The animation was good but nothing special. Same with the plot, it has been done before so nothing special there. Overall it was a fun and light hearted watch but it definitely wasn't one of the best movies I've ever seen.

We should be encouraging children to embrace feelings and the child's character loved that "monster" on TV and it should be encouraged. I also felt there should have been a stronger response to the characters that mocked him for liking that "monster". We also need to show kids that it's wrong to bully or to think they're cool for not liking stuff that seems kind and fun. Kids will love what they love dad it's a very good thing if they love things that are like that monster thing on tv. I just wanted the messages to be slightly clearer.

review_date: Fast-paced, great first and final acts, great special effects (for the most part), iconic outfits (the gold bikini), despicable villains, large space battles, and cute characters (the Ewoks), Return is a great movie in the series. The movie was my favorite in the series as a kid and still holds up really well now but is still a little corny in parts - something that would become sadly more commonplace with future installments. I absolutely love this movie though and can't say it's not great because the action sequences and everything else already mentioned are just so good. You may cheer at the end especially if you watched all the movies that are chronologically before it.

review: A great conclusion to one of the best trilogies ever made, "Return of the Jedi" is yet another timeless classic that wraps up the original "Star Wars" trilogy with fabulous fashion. The final fight is very emotional and intense, and the action is done much better in this film. The worldbuilding continues to be superb, and the CGI continues to be great for its time, though it does fail to hold up to today's standards. However, where I think this film is worse than its predecessors is in its story and plot with the second Death Star, which feels unoriginal and familiar. There are also many more plot holes throughout the film when compared to the previous installments and the film have a few more clich√©s in it. However, I still mostly loved it and it does a perfect job at wrapping this iconic trilogy up.

review: While this movie isn't as perfect as the first two, it is genuinely excellent, contrary to what many would say (for reasons I'm not entirely sure). The characters are every bit as well-written and likeable as in the preceding films, the story is still engaging (if just a bit thin, as it's ultimately an extended Third Act of the over-arching story), the villains are still immensely intimidating, the music is still wonderful and the action sequences are still awesome. Heck, from an action standpoint, this might be the best of the three, as the Climax is very long, featuring both a Ground Battle and a Space Battle, alongside a third based on Story Resolution, and despite the >30 minute duration, this climax NEVER loses momentum. While this movie doesn't have the depth of the first two, it does escalate everything that worked before, and because of this, the emotional catharsis from the climax of this movie is sublime -- I honestly can't think of any other Action series that ends with such a perfect emotional satisfaction. It's well-written, well-directed and has both adrenaline and sincerity, and apart from an overlong first act, I cannot think of a better way this borderline-perfect Trilogy could have ended.

review: Twice, maybe, but is it possible to create the Star Wars magic a third time? Lucas said yes and, gratefully, we agree. Star Wars Return of the Jedi is the conclusion to the trilogy we all hoped for. More of what we loved, without resorting to more of the same. Lucas dreamt up even more exotic new places to show us, such as the forest moon of Endor, exciting new creatures for us to behold, such as Jabba the Hutt and the Ewoks, and plenty of thrilling new action sequences, including the rescue of Han Solo from Jabba's Palace, the speeder bike chase on Endor and the battle against the new Death Star. The plot is simple but effective, resolving many of the questions we were left with after Return of the Jedi and ending with the penultimate battle between good and evil in the re-match between Luke and Vader (spoiler alert: good always wins). We get to see more of the Emperor and to understand more of Vader's life as a Sith Lord, and to appreciate the internal conflict he felt towards his son. The special effects and sound effects were once again great - nothing particularly new, but we didn't need them to be new, just reliably great. All of the cast return, and you can tell that they have grown comfortable with their respective roles in the intervening years. There are no boring bits, it's just another exhilarating adventure that we almost feel part of as we join the ragtag band of rebels as they race across the Star Wars galaxy.

review: Now before you rush ahead and quickly mark my review unhelpful, hear me out alright? Return of the Jedi is the only movie of the trilogy I had no hopes from. I had heard of people saying that it's the worst in the series. But considering I got bored from A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back I thought this one is going to be even worse (why I got bored of them, that's written on their reviews. But still if you're too lazy to check it's because I always somehow get bored watching old movies). So I had absolutely no expectations from it. Turns out it has the most story of all the Star Wars movies. The movie began with answering the question as to what happened to Han Solo. He gets rescued by Luke and Leia. We even get to see the iconic Boba Fett in that scene. Later on we get to see Lando. Even though I haven't heard about him and I actually had to look up his name while writing this review, he looks pretty iconic. I don't know if this was a popular look or this movie made the look popular, but I guess the latter is true. There were many other NPC characters throughout the movie, but for me the selling point were the Ewoks. And I don't care what all the "die-hard Star Wars fanboys" say. The Ewoks are so adorable! I wanted to pull their cheeks. Their scenes were so cute and funny. The way they fought the Stormtroopers or treated C3PO like a messiah was really wholesome. I really wanted to see that kind of stuff in Star Wars movies. Just because it's set in space doesn't mean it always has to blast out laser guns or have huge flying ships. After all, it's set long long ago in a galaxy far far away. There could be many tribes living over there as well. And seeing them hold up makes me believe they still exist somewhere in today's time, having evolved into becoming teddy bears as advanced as humans. And finally Darth Vader's final fight scene in this movie, in my opinion, was way better than The Empire Strikes Back. We actually get to see what Darth Vader looks like, and he hasn't cut Luke's arm for this. This is the correct way of drawing out emotions. The one who is making the audience emotional should be in pain, and not the one being made emotional. Darth Sidious was really intimidating, and I really wanted more of him rather than the trash that Palpatine was. Star Wars: Episode VI is even today my favourite Star Wars movie. It doesn't matter what others say about it, it's gonna be the most OP in my opinon. In just 2.5 hours it managed to tell more story than the entire sequel trilogy combined. And the best part - the spoilers from this movie aren't even as popular as Episode IV or V, so I could watch it without already knowing what I'm about to watch. I'd absolutely watch it again.
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi

review: Though the weakest of the trilogy, Return of the Jedi offers a satisfying conclusion to the Skywalker storyline (or at least until Disney picked it up ). The notable success of this film is the visual effects, being the best of the trilogy, and the story arc of Luke being well developed and resolved, culminating in one of the greatest fight scenes in film history. Unfortunately the story is lackluster at times, borrowing heavily from the first film, with beats that are predictable and feel like rehashes at times. 7.5/10

review: Awful on so many levels. There's no contrast between Charlie's "normal" world and the Chocolate Factory. Everything is dark, twisted and creepy. Speaking of creepy, Johnny Depp's characterization as Willy Wonka is at best off-putting. Unlike Gene Wilder who was eccentric but at his core human, Depp comes across as a psychopath with no relatable human characteristics. He looks at the children with at best, disdain. The songs are GOD AWFUL, being chaotic, clamorous, melody-less over done set pieces with awful CGI. Everything is always dark of course. Speaking of CGI there's way too much of it and the color tone for the movie is grayish blue for the most part. It's dismal, dreary and more suited for a horror movie than a child's fantasy. Grandpa Joe is there and has no personality or purpose in this film unlike the wonderful Jack Albertson performance from the original. But the worst is Charlie Bucket. I could not give a damn about this character, he's not interesting, he's not sympathetic, he's just there. The fault lies squarely on the shoulders of Director Tim Burton. He relied much too much on visual effects for entertainment and forgot to give us characters we care about. As the original Willy Wonka, Gene Wilder said, this movie is an insult. Charmless and a burden to sit through.
rt_name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory - Movie Reviews

review_date: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a 2005 British-American musical fantasy film directed by Tim Burton and written by John August, based on the 1964 British novel of the same name by Roald Dahl. The storyline follows Charlie as he wins a contest along with four other children and is led by Wonka on a tour of his chocolate factory. The film has an original script. The plot is exciting and infinitely-variable. The film had the perfect cast. The film stars Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka and Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket, alongside David Kelly, Helena Bonham Carter, Noah Taylor, Missi Pyle, James Fox, Deep Roy, and Christopher Lee. The acting is brilliant. The characters turned out to be colourful and convincing. Special effects are impressive. The film is really interesting. Suitable for fantasy and comedy enthusiasts. You shouldn't miss it.

review: I saw this movie 16 years after its release. I didn't expect CGI to have aged well, in fact it didn't. I find the plot uninspired, a starving boy who becomes heir to a fortune by reconciling the chocolate mogul with his past The music is nice, I liked the design of the scenography and the colors. Photography isn't bad either. A film that in my opinion does not shine very much on the emotional side, and little on the technical side.
rt_name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory - Movie Reviews

review: This is still one of the greatest movies from my childhood! I used to watch this movie everyday when I was a kid, loved it! I recently watched the 1971 film and I honestly think that it was very boring, don't really enjoy the Gene Wilder version. Tim Burton I think did a better job at capturing the story in his style and comedy. I think Johnny Depp was one of the best actors for the role of Willy Wonka hands down. The movie was funny, the candy room scene looks amazing and I really enjoy the different songs that the Oompa Loompas sang. This movie is more memorable than the Gene Wilder version, in my opinion.

review: Would you chew a piece of gum that was the best thing you have ever had, but you ultimately turn violet and disformed for life? After this movie certainly not. This cinematic remake that is supposed to closely follow that of the original Roald Dahl story, will leave you speechless‚Ä¶or covered in trash. It is every child's dream to tour a candy factory where everything is edible. Then there being a special prize at the end for a child who makes it. Let your inner child run free as well as your imagination during this film. Imagine drinking from a chocolate river or tasting a full course meal in a single piece of gum. This bright, sugar-coated, twisted movie hides teaching moments behind a candy land. It shows the right and wrong way to act, and ultimately how parents have failed. The music in the movie is upbeat but the words have an ominous undertone. The camera work certainly captures all the angles which draws you in. The scenes make the child inside of you want to be in the movie yourself. The overview shot of the factory is a child's dream come true. The catchy songs will get stuck in your head, but the words are thought provoking. "Augustus Gloop, Augustus Gloop, a great big greedy nincompoop" this line personally shows why he meet this fate. He was greedy and possibly not smart enough to think of the consequences of his actions. I personally love this movie because of the way the children's manners relate to their ending. The way the child who chews gum competitively chews her last piece and turns into a blueberry. Another being a glutton and almost drowning in chocolate because he can't stop his urge. Suddenly the children all start meeting their demise, but in ways almost expected my Willy Wonka himself. How did he know that only four goggles would be needed in the tv room? How can he not know which key unlocks a gate in his own factory? The plot along with the movie all bring together the twisted story of Charlie Bucket. Enjoy watching Jonny Depp be a chocolatier and Deep Roy be Oompa Loompas and realize the twisted intentions with every scene. Would you survive the factory?

review: A fun way to conclude this trilogy, "The Last Crusade" introduces Connery into the blend of amazing actors, and he ends up carrying this movie. The comedy is done extremely well, and the action is still pleasing to watch. The story is fun and goofy, yet it never gets too goofy in its tone. About the only real issue I can even make is that it still doesn't feel that original, but that is easily overshadowed by the stellar performances and the delightful banter between both Jones. Almost as good as "Raiders of the Lost Ark," and is in some ways even better.

review: One of the greatest sequels ever made [Temple of Doom is a prequel] has the same sense of high-stakes adventure as the original and is just thematically and structurally distinct enough to not feel repetitive. A fitting send-off for a beloved character ... which they ruined by making the lousy fourth one.
mojo_name: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade
rt_name: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade - Movie Reviews

review: While this isn't as perfectly cathartic as Raiders or as intense and daring as Temple of Doom, Last Crusade is probably the most thoroughly plotted and well-plotted of the trilogy, ending this near-perfect trilogy on a worthy note. It looks and sounds just as great as the first two movies, has the same blend of action, worldbuilding and humor, and in some ways it surpasses the other two in these respects. Additionally, the introduction of Sean Connery as Indiana Jones' father was a brilliant move, and the fact that he's a well-realized and immensely flawed character, yet likable nonetheless, only serves to add to the movie's strengths. Throw in a more versatile change of landscapes from Act to Act, some fantastic adrenaline rush moments and a surprisingly thoughtful and emotional climax, and you've got a movie that is a genuinely excellent work of cinema on its own merits, even without taking the first two into account. It works as both a popcorn-munching Blockbuster level, and it works as more of a "thinking man's" movie as well, and it works brilliantly as both.

review: Basically this is a remake of "Raiders Of The Lost Ark": Indiana Jones must beat the Nazis to obtaining the holy relic. The main differences are a lack of strong villains, and the inclusion of Indy's father in the story. Unfortunately Sean Connery and Harrison Ford are not convincing as father and son. The original film was an exciting roller-coaster ride, a remake of 1930's- style exotic adventures. This is the same without the excitement, or any good characters. Even the sword fight which takes place here to make up for the lack of one in the original (because rumor has it that Harrison Ford was too ill at the time to perform it) is tired and unexciting, as is the rest of the movie. The only good thing I can say about it is that it was better than the hideous "Temple Of Doom"-but that is a weak compliment indeed.

review: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade was directed by Steven Spielberg. It stars charismatic Harrison Ford and Sean Connery. It's the sequel about Dr. Jones. This film was nominated for 3 Oscars in 1990 and they won one Oscar for the best sound mixing. The film is set in Venice, Egypt and probably Greece. It was shot on location. The location with its mountains and forests is really unforgettable. The story describes the search for Holy Grail which archaeologist Indiana Jones and the Nazis both found. There are some interesting small historical facts which mix with journey, fantasy and adventure. I strongly recommend this sequel for people who love movies like western and amazing action films. I love scenes with chasing the most.

review: This is absolutely my favourite Indiana Jones film of them all. The journey 'Junior' undergoes is extensive, and the chemistry between Sean Connery and Harrison Fords' chemistry leads to some of the best back and forth I've ever seen in such an interesting adventure film. The plot itself is fascinating and the film can be re watched multiple times, whilst never getting old. This is a definite must-watch and for the people who loved Raiders, I am sure you won't regret the sweet taste of Indy fighting off Nazis, and plundering holy artifacts.

review: What I love about Last Crusade is it's a much more emotional and personal movie, diving deeper into Indy's personal past and relationship with his father and the natural chemistry between Ford and Connery is even better. It's really wholesome and well-developed. The actiom sequences are remarkable (especially the ending) and out of the 3 80s movies, this easily has the most interesting and fun concept for a story and it mostly executes it well and I love the European setting for this movie. As a fan of the fast pace and dark tone of Temple of Doom, I was partly disappointed with the lighter and slower pace of the movie (Damn you critics!) and I think the central conflict gets lost with the stuff with Indy and his dad but it's still an excellent movie

review: Review: While I personally hate Temple of Doom (due to the fact that it disturbed me when I was younger), all was forgiven by its follow-up Last Crusade, a tightly paced, heartfelt, action-packed and incredibly entertaining. But the real reason this film works so amazingly well is the chemistry between Sean Connery and Harrison Ford - a perfect combination of wit and heartwarmth. Some moments don't work quite as well, but the Third Act is top action movie stuff, and the Holy Grail makes for the best maguffin in any of the Indy films. I would go a far to say this is a lot better than Raiders, and John Williams delivers, as always, an excellent score. | Rating: A-

The second part of this tale is not a patch on the first chapter and, to be honest, I was rooting for the evil clown rather than the insufferable adults that return to the small American town that the Pennywise has been terrorising.
Unfortunately doesn't hold up to it's predecessor

People who say "bigger is not equals scary" missed the point of the film. Pennywise, being bigger (his true self) does not signify him scaring the Losers Club. Although Pennywise WAS scaring them away at the start of the film, if you truly watched the movie or read the book, the Losers fought back by facing their demons and eventually facing Pennywise without fear. This made Pennywise become small and vulnerable. This 2nd movie's aim was not to be scary per se, but to be anxious and uneasy about the Losers' arrival back in Derry. Being scary is not only shown in the physical aspect, but the story it represents.
It was boring. I only see to finish the saga
Even dumber than the first one! Don't waste your time!
Fantastic conclusion that fixed a lot of problems from the book. The cg was a little weird but good.

It nullifies everyone's character arcs from Chapter 1 and takes the protagonists back to where they started; now they're adults facing an adversary they already defeated as children so there's little sense of novelty or danger. It's excessively long but incomplete, with several plot threads unresolved. On the plus side the cast is good and there are a couple memorably creepy moments.
The only thing you get by watching this movie is roughly 3 hours closer to death.

You need to be Stephen King levels of coked up to enjoy this movie or find it scary. It Chapter 2 is pure boredom. Don't bother, because thats 3 hours of your life you are not getting back.

Another problematic end, just like Chapter 1 (book and movie). The Horror - 5 stars: "It" can take the form of everyone's greatest fear so the horror here is about as horrific as can be. The Hook/Pace - ZERO stars: I found the opening scene (gay-bashing) just ugly as it had nothing to do with anything, was never resolved, and I almost turned this one off. And the run time is almost three hours. There is a reason the best comedies and best horror films run under two hours: that's usually the limit of genre premises. The Jumps/Scares - 3 stars: Very effective jump-out-of your seat blindsides for the first half, maybe a dozen good to great ones. But after a while they become numbing and repetitive. The Film - 2: Some very nice humanity/friendships here but the movie is much too long and some plot lines are unresolved. Final special effects laughable. The End - Zero Stars: All through this movie there is a running joke about bad endings ("Chapter 1" end laughably absurd). But we get the same stupid ending!!!... only magnified and bloodier. Summary - 2.2. I can only hope Chapter 3 finally ends as it should. I know what it should be, I know Stephen King knows, so I think it's coming. But this film is WAY too meandering and did I mention the terrible opening scene?
Obviously worse than the first part, it feels just like your usual "jump-scary" mainstream horror flick.

A movie that seems to exist mostly in the negative cultural space of IMDB reviewers and genre websites explaining how much they hated it; for unknown reasons 2 of the successful original movie's writers failed to return, the characters are unengaging and feel utterly divorced from their kooky, flawed original players and for unknown reasons Andi Muzccheti wants the film to go for twice it's actual running time. Stuffed with CGI scene elements, features unconvincing de-aging digital effects also. Practically everything they could do wrong, they did on "IT 2", and if you care to look, Gary Dauberman has a list of disposable trash horror already on his CV. Because IT was a lovable cast ensemble film with some genuine scares, this movie is all the worse for it. Certainly does NOT deserve the box office sales generated, so here's hoping this is the last we hear from the writer and director chiefly responsible for (sh)IT: Chapter 2.

After watching this movie, it made me realize how good the first movie is. I mean, this second part is not bad, but it fails in some parts and even repeats mistakes from the first film, such as using the same fright formula, where it ends up being predictable when the film intends to scare us. However he still manages sometimes. Another problem is that the character development, which was done so well in chapter 1, is not equally good in this one, as the film invests in the characters revisiting the past, and the problem is that we've already been introduced to their younger versions. .. I saw a review video (channel "super 8") and in it the guy says that "It chapter two" looks like an extended version of "It chapter one", and I agree, the movie might fall into a feeling that it has to match height of what was the success of the first and is lost a little. But, I'm not just critical of the movie. He, like the first one, is a solid film and manages to employ a good atmosphere, especially when investing in a psychological horror. The cast is also really good, making it really feel like we're really watching an older version of those youngsters from the first movie. It is worth mentioning the performance of James McAvoy, who indulges in the role, and the duo Bill Hader and James Ransone, who serve very well as a comedic relief (something that is well done in the film). In short, despite some bad choices of direction, I liked the movie and it was good entertainment, offering enough for anyone who liked the first one or looking for a horror movie to watch.

Jaws is as much of a great adventure film as it is a great horror film. Steven Spielberg burst onto the scene with this spectacular theatrical debut, and despite countless production problems, he managed to pull out an all-time masterpiece on his first try. Jaws remains one of Spielberg's best, if not the absolute pinnacle of his brilliant resume.

A timeless tale of building up that terrifying thriller. I remember watching this when I was way too little to be watching this lol. It scared me then and still makes me a bit nervous to swim too deep in the ocean. My favorite moment of the entire movie is hands down Robert Shaw's speech about the U.S.S. Indianapolis. Gives me chills everytime and I can't look away from the screen. And given that Robert Shaw kept drinking during shooting and was still able to give such a gripping performance speaks volumes.

Jaws Movie Review Did you know sharks kill an average of 10 people a year, worldwide? Now, imagine eight shark kills in a single week! Yesterday, I watched a Steven Spielberg classic, Jaws. Jaws is about a killer Great White Shark that is attacking swimmers off the coast of a fictional island called Amity, which is off the coast of New England. The acting is great, with many award winning actors, including Roy Scheider, Richard Dreyfuss, and Robert Shaw. Roy Sheider plays Martin Brody, the star of the movie, and the local sheriff of Amity. Martin is from New York, but moves to Amity with his family because he feels that in a small town, he has more of an impact on preventing crime. "'I'm tellin' ya, the crime rate in New York will kill ya. There's so many problems, you never feel like you're accomplishing anything. Violence, rip-offs, muggings. The kids can't leave the house. You gotta walk 'em to school. But in Amity, one man can make a difference. In twenty-five years, there's never been a shooting or a murder in this town." Quote from Martin Brody. An ironic detail about Martin Brody is that he is afraid of the water, even though he is the one (spoiler alert!) who kills the shark in the end. Richard Dreyfuss plays a leading role as an oceanographer named Matt Hooper, who specializes in sharks, and helps track down the shark. Robert Shaw plays Quint, a professional shark hunter, who is strange but entertaining. He has a leading role in helping to kill the shark. The special effects in Jaws were not entirely accurate, but are still exceptionally impressive for a 1975 movie, and can even hold up to today's standards, as well as the rest of the movie. The suspense in Jaws is incredible, and the ominous, trademark, Jaws soundtrack plays every time the shark goes in for the kill. In my opinion, Jaws is an absolute masterpiece, because of it's great suspense, colorful characters, and awesomely gory kills. It has an excellent plot, nail biting suspense, and most importantly, never has a dull moment. Jaws is surprisingly scary for such an old movie, and ages like fine wine. Why should you trust me? I have been watching movies since I was 3, starting with Disney, all the way up to movies like Scream and The Bourne Identity. I have always loved raving, complaining, and watching movies. My family and I have had a Friday night movie night, and I have watched upwards of 350 movies.

Easily in my Top Ten movies of all time, and definitely the movie I've rewatched more than any other in my lifetime (and that's saying something!). The music in the film is exceptional. This movie's score might be the most recognizable of all time (even for John Williams, who's written probably every memorable movie score ever). The acting by Scheider, Dreyfuss, and Shaw is fantastic. This movie is decades old and still packs a cinematic punch despite (or arguably because of) the lack of modern-day special effects. This is the film that made me simultaneously terrified to swim in the ocean and completely fascinated by sharks. This movie remains one of the few examples in cinematic history where the movie is actually FAR better than the book. Spielberg and team made GENIUS changes for the movie version that make Jaws infinitely rewatchable more than 45 years after its release.

The first 70 minutes of Jaws are outstanding filled with incredible camerwork and cinematography, great editing, acting, it's great seeing everyone's different reaction to this shark attack like Brody, who just wants to ensure the safety of people, the mayor, who's just interested in managing the island's economy, and the fisherman, who are interested only in money. John Williams's score is fantastic and the use of the Jaws theme to alert the presnece of the shark was really effective and the shark attacks are absolutely frightening and really well filmed and edited. Just hearing the hopelessness of the people is a great idea. Then the next 50 minutes comes along and it's not bad. The actors have good chemistry, seeing Quint go mad and Quint and Hooper exchanging stories and scars was cool and the way the shark was defeated was really satisfying. But it's just not interesting. There just isn't much going on and did this movie forget about an aftermath. Where is everyone's reaction to the shark getting killed and Quint is so unlikeable. I get it's the point but having to sit through him being a jerk for 50 minutes is painful. Still a great movie overall but it's kind of overrated.

A video game villain, named Wreck-It Ralph, has hero envy and decides to abandon his game to become a hero in another. The brilliance of this film is the easter eggs and cameos of other video game characters that make this movie very rewatchable. Beyond that there is a great story with some interesting characters that were made specifically for this film. The animation is terrific and the attention to detail, like making an old 8-bit character move like one all the time, is astounding. Props to John C. Reilly, Sarah Silverman, Jane Lynch, Jack McBrayer and Alan Tudyk for their voice work. It also helps that they were perfectly cast for these characters. A highly recommended and entertaining film, especially if you are a gamer!
Wreck-It Ralph implements the traditional Disney "magic" in a fresh, modern, and smart way that delivers incredibly well, and is sure to delight audiences of all ages.
Gene was a exceptional and a very likeable character!

Pixar's delightful world building is at its peak here, as the audience are taken inside the mechanics of a children's arcade game. Ralph, the 'bad guy' in the game 'Fix-it Felix Jr', is treated as such even when the arcade shuts down for the day, and the characters inside the arcade are brought to life in their own environment. It's a clever spin on the original Toy Story idea of toys coming to life, but choosing to shift the location to the inner world of a video arcade leads to some glorious cameos from characters you will recognise, and some you will be thrilled to meet for the first time. Although the initial thrill of exploring the world and its characters in the first half of the film does fade as the adventure fully gets going, Wreck-It Ralph is certainly one of Pixar's better films, and considering they've made very few that aren't excellent, that's high praise indeed.
Wreck It Ralph and Ralph Breaks The Internet is the literal meaning of pain and suffering.

This is one of the few movies I rewatched over and over again because it was always on TV. And, guess what? Every time I watched it, it got better. It highlighted the story's perfect pace, how every little piece of the movie is enjoyable and everything comes together at the end. Underrated.

Here's that contrary unique opinion no one wanted. This film's worth is an illusion. Disney does not mean it actually means something. And I know this is supposed to be for the children who are unable to raise their intelligence but that doesn't mean that the concept actually makes sense. In fact, no one's ever questioned the logic of why the arcade games plugged into the server are basically complete and different universes with everything being interactive for no reason at all, why code can directly infect another game after parting from its own, and why the game characters are separate code. And the message isn't conveyed logically because of that, since they're GAME CHARACTERS, they're programmed to play a role and shouldn't deviate from it because they can't, they were made for what they do. The basic "Be yourself" moral could not be conveyed in a worse way than this film. And never mind that, the soundtrack is faux-retro than actual retro. It's basically pop-retro over and over with the occasional Disney orchestral that has little weight because THE PREMISE IS ARCADE GAME CHARACTERS! If they're experiencing a misfortune, recall that they don't actually exist as people, were written for a string of events, and can't even leave the universe of technology itself because they would die trying to. Wreck-It Ralph is just gamer fan service for Disney and they know it, but they audience sure doesn't, and it's the only thing it actually succeeds in. Of course, because it is gamer fan service, that's where it has its entertainment value that actually can remain, unlike everything else that makes so little logical sense in hindsight that the audience won't even bother with it.

As a teenager I had once seen the trailer of this movie when I was at the hospital. Afterwards I never got to see this trailer ever again. I didn't know the name of the movie and we didn't have an internet back then, so I could neither ask anyone nor look it up. The trailer showing Bowser and Eggman were just enough to have me sold. Then when the movie released I saw its name in the newspaper, but within the next week it was taken off (probably it didn't earn much here). So ever since then I wanted to watch it. I finally watched it in 2018 and I'm really glad I could. Wreck-It Ralph is the story of a videogame villain who wants to be a hero, but he can't do it because of how much he's used to being the bad guy. After he meets Vanellope, they both embark on an adventure to help Ralph get a medal which Vanellope had otherwise given away as a prize in her own game Sugar Rush. There are many fun characters like Fix-It Felix, Calhoun and King Candy. There is even a cameo appearance of Sonic, which is like a dream come true for a huge Sonic fan like me. The story is great for children, the visuals are phenomenal like all Disney animated movies, the voice actors are decent, the comic timing is hilarious and unexpected (the Oreo march, Felix fixing the prison bars while trying to hammer them, Ralph running around in Calhoun's game etc). I'm pretty sure if I was a kid and I had watched it, I'd have been completely blown away by it and it would have become my favourite movie. I watched it when I was 19, and yet I really enjoyed it (the rating is from that time so I have written this review from that perspective). For the veteran gamers there are a lot of hidden jokes, easter eggs and references scattered around everywhere. I really want this franchise to expand even more. Ralph has come as a playable character in Sonic and SEGA All Star Racing Transformed. I mean, this is a movie about a game character. It would really be injustice if we don't get Sugar Rush in real life, or Fix-It Felix for mobile phones. The movie was pretty good, since it established all the ideas not even the sequel could ruin. Definitely a watch if you're a gamer and have a family.

I love "Wreck it Ralph" because it makes room for the destroyers. Maybe the little game characters who have their tower destroyed over and over again by Ralph don't like him, but, their game can't continue if he's not there to play the bad guy. I can't help but think of this film when people talk about bots on social media. Listen, just because you've had a 10+ year affair with a computer app under the same avatar doesn't make you able to navigate information better, it means you're having an emotional affair with your phone, and now you're blaming the bots for tampering with something you thought was real and it is all fiction. You are yelling into a bot about bots yelling into you, and it is all very funny to me when people choose these virtual interactions. So, invite Ralph to your Disney parties, but don't censor Ralph or any destroyer, it will only be Game Over. From what I can see, everyone wants Fix it Felix to come, but, they aren't giving any attention to lonely hero sitting in the junk yard who keeps their fun wheel spinning, and I like that this film points at him and goes; He's a hero too, y'know...

review: Today I am going to review The Hangover Trilogy. I am reviewing all the three films together because the series has now become quite old and I think no one would read full page reviews of each movie. But, if you request I would write a detailed review for each movie too. The series revolves around 4 friends, Philip(Bradley Cooper), Stu(Ed Helms), Alan ( Zach Galifianakis) and Doug ( Justin Bartha) and one more interesting, a recurring character, Chow (Ken Jeong), who is an international criminal but besides that, he is very funky. The third and final part of the trilogy revolves around Alan, who after the untimely demise of his father decides to change his ways and start living with some new standards to renovate his life. But all things don't go as planned and the four again land into trouble when Chow's enemies abduct Doug. This film too is very entertaining but what I found is that it lost its very own essence of the hangover. In the film, you see only Chow enjoying the hangover, while the four are always in trouble. The film is very humourous and good comedy too but still I would highly recommend the previous parts over this especially the first one. But still, I would give this film a positive rating.

review: THIS MOVIE IS SO, SO, SO, SO, STUPID!!! Such a horrendous movie. It's completely unfunny and purely lazily written. This movie has some of the laziest writing I have ever seen in film history. All of the gags fall flat and the story is stupid. Not to mention a severely horrible misuse of the song "Hurt". The movie begins with some drunken bastard recklessly driving a car with a giraffe in the back and accidentally causes the giraffe to get decapitated by a highway sign. Oh, and the giraffe's blood from its head splattered on a family's car with two young children inside the car which made them freak out. Did the writers and director seriously think that was funny? I did not even laugh one bit during this stupid, horrible, unfunny, lazily written movie. The acting in this movie is so horrible that it's not even one bit amusing. This movie was so painful to watch. Easily one of the worst comedies of all time. This movie isn't even remotely entertaining. I didn't even make it to the end of the movie, that's how god-awful it was. Rating: 0.8/10

review: After how great The Lego Movie was, I expected a lot from its sequel, more when at the end of the film we were left with an open ending, The Lego Movie 2 is a somewhat strange sequel but I'm not saying it's bad either, I really liked the The theme that was given to us in the Mad Max style was very epic and implies that the audiences who saw the first one have already matured but that at the same time rarely makes the film want to move to a more childish plane, the theme of Time travel is one of the topics that I like to see the most in Movies and I really liked that in this film they took it to comedy and referred to many franchises that have used this theme, the space theme also makes me another Very good theme but as I said it because at the beginning of the film we have this not so childish environment and moving to a childish environment becomes strange, the references in the magical world made me good to have the cameo of Bruce Willis it was made me very funny, the revelation ending is very good and lets again that the topic of time travel is one of my favorite topics to know that Rex is the real villain and that he is Emmet from an alternate future was a good idea, unfortunately Warner lost the rights of the Lego maeca and the theme of time travel will no longer be used in this franchise, in conclusion The Lego Movie 2 is a good movie with great references and a great story that sometimes is not so squashed

review: The vast majority was disappointingly bland, I was looking at the clock after only 15 minutes of watching. The movie starts without a proper build-up, and the story is a jumbled mess of siblings randomly forcing their own story progression. Not until the movie has nearly ended does it come together and did I feel somewhat entertained. The jokes aren't clever enough to keep your attention, except for maybe 2, and the songs feel unnecessary. The one that claims it'll get stuck in your head was ironically not that catchy, while those performed by the villain were the most fun. The previous movie's "Everything is Awesome" is painfully overused in the form of renditions and quotes. I think the sad version should've been the only reference, and the record album Emmet was gifted an Easter egg. The twist was a lazy attempt at making the villains misunderstood, it didn't add up, but the worst offender was the Rex character. I must've missed some dialogue, because I have no idea why he's so Hell-bent on making Emmet become like him and thus ensuring his own suffering. Wouldn't you rather make sure the past never happened the way it did? Anyway. That's it, that's my review, goodbye.

review: Story/Screenplay: (3/5) Not nearly as interesting as its prequel. The storyline wasn't as clear as the original, nor was it as fun or funny. The base concept was good as a sequel and it had potential, but it didn't deliver. Duration/Tempo: (3/5) At 1 hour and 47 minutes, it's an average length movie that felt about the same. Too long. Would have liked to see 15 minutes trimmed from the film's length. Cast & Crew: (3/5) Chris Pratt and Elizabeth Banks were OK, but not as good as in the original. The cast in general were solid, but their performance suffered due to the weak story. Summary: (3/5) The story and cast were middling, and the film didn't move as quickly as I would have liked. A thumbs down.

review: The main problems for the ‚ÄòThe Lego Movie 2' is that it lacks the originality and freshness of the first film and doesn't do a great job of weaving an emotional thread throughout, instead focusing mostly on big, flashy visuals. Best live action transformers movie in my opinion.

A heartfelt and simple film with a familiar story and new directions that clearly shows how much the source material has been handled well for fans to from the previous and new generations to enjoy. The same innocence from the 2007 film was brought back which was missing from the previous installments that were convoluted mess. Who knew that the blocky designs from the G1 series will look good in CGI. This was the Transformers film that we should have gotten a long time ago.

Horribly directed movie that didn't coincide with the original storyline of the original Bumblebee character. Poor representation of the autobot character; which was shown being constantly thrown around and beat up the entire movie by known less powerful transformer characters. The movie made Bumblebee seem incredibly weak. The subpar acting by the chosen cast was at times embarrassing to watch and the low rate action scenes did not live up to the hype of the other movies in the Transformer Franchise.

Not a fan of the Transformers films, I've seen a couple of them and didn't bother with the couple before this one. Right from the start it looks better than all of the other movies as the Transformers actually look like THE TRANSFORMERS. The ‚Äò80's nostalgia was a nice touch too and makes sense since the 90's is when Transformers were introduced to the masses. It's likely the most entertaining and fun of the Transformers films, and probably the best of them but it raises a big question... why didn't they just start with this? Nevertheless, it actually made me interested in seeing another Transformers movie if this is how they are going to be.
I loved this movie. They did a great job of fleshing out the characters ad making them feel real

A new angle on the transformers franchise...and for me it works...this film lightens the story a bit in a way that befits bumblebees persona...a great 80s soundtrack accompanies...overall a success

Suppose you have to make a movie on Barbie. So, what do we know about her? She's beautiful, she's the symbol of feminine, she goes on adventures. Now suppose if these characteristics were taken and Barbie was turned into a porn film series, how would it feel? Wrong, right? Toys are supposed to be the emotions of children. So they have to be given characteristics and emotions, and not just mash them together and throw in a joke after every two lines. This is exactly the problem with the Transformers franchise, and that's what this movie has fixed. One really good thing about this movie is that unlike many character-driven movies like Sonic the Hedgehog or Cars, Bumblebee has not only ben about his relationship with other people. It is a major plot point, yes, but other than that there's also Cybertron, where the Autobots are fighting a lost cause. So this gives a sense of time constraint to the movie. If it wastes too much time the Decepticons will come on Earth and attack the humans. There are occasional warnings like that guy's pickup truck being smashed. Because of this the humans have been properly intertwined with the consequences. While Bumblebee is spending time with Charlie, he also has to learn the ways in which he must behave if he needs the humans to trust him. Charlie knows about the Cybertron attack but she can't let Bumblebee run in the open otherwise the military will take him away. The military thinks that Bumblebee is a bad guy because the Decepticons told them. There is also Charlie's friend Memo who helps her in the adventure. Overall everyone has an important part to play in this movie. And this is how it should be since the humans are in the movies for the majority of the runtime so they shouldn't be cringy to watch. The only thing this movie was lacking was Michael Bay's action scenes. I'd have preferred if they allowed Bay to stay for the fight scenes, but let Travis Knight do the rest. The action scenes and their choreography were given a nod every time Cybertron was shown. In fact, the movie begins on Cybertron itself. The fight between Bumblebee and Shatter and Dropkick clearly made it seem like how Bumblebee is struggling to keep up with them as the military is also intervening their fight. The character development of not just Bumblebee, but Charlie is also seen in the movie. In all the previous five Transformers movies, there was little to no character development, which is what made us stop caring about them. We already knew Optimus Prime will always be the good guy who will fight everyone and win (remember the Martha scene from the Last Knight where Bumblebee suddenly starts speaking and Optimus suddenly becomes a good guy?) and Megatron will be the generic bad guy. Here we have Bumblebee trying to cope with his new life, Charlie trying to get over her fear, Memo trying to impress her and Agent Burns who learns to trust the aliens. We just need a few more movies like Bumblebee and the Transformers franchise will come back on track. We have seen the character development of one Autobot, now Optimus Prime should be the next one and then possibly Megatron to give his point of view. Finally we have gone over Sam Witwicky and Cade, who had the most one dimensional personalities. Now it's all about Charlie.
A Transformers movie that pretty much the whole family can watch. And the 1980's nostalgia is timeless.
Beautiful story, more kid friendly that the previous films.
Despite having a lot of movie-like resemblances, Bumblebee is a very friendly adventure to see on a family afternoon, and it still gives hope to the Transformers Saga after The Last Knight. (9/10)

Bumblebee is a mess of a film that had a talented director who's background in animation allowed them to makes visuals and character designs that were far more interesting than previous films while being a lower budget spinoff but is held down by with terrible writing, music, characters(with the exception of Charlie), acting, and humor likely as a result of the studio not bothering to get people who are talented besides the director.

Just a really fun time honestly. The best part of the movie is Bumblebee and Charlie's friendship. It's surprisingly well developed and you can really tell they care for each other and having Bumblebee not being able to speak makes it a lot better honeslty as the film relies on visuals to show the friendship and it's really sweet and Hailee Steinfield delivers an excellent and heartfelt performance. Charlie alone is a sweet character and they do a pretty good job of showing her grief after her father's death. Her interactions with Memo are also sweet and it's nice they didn't actually become a couple at the end. The action itself is incredibly exciting and the CGI effects are pretty great overall. Script is a bit weak in areas. Tina and her boyfriend are just forgotten in the movie despite their impact on Charlie's character and the decepticond also disappear for periods. Honestly, this movie itslef sometimes forget it's about Bumbleebe and the other autobuts saving their planet from the deceptivons but regardless, a fun time (B+)

This movie has lots of familiar tropes and if you grew up in the 80s, I'm sure you'll be reminded of a few of your favorite old movies (E.T. anyone?) but I think that was the intention. This movie punches the nostalgia button and then has some heartfelt fun with you.

This movie is an absolute delight, I can watch this and The Transformers: The Movie (1986) over and over without getting tired of them. I am a lifelong Transformers super-fan (ask me about my collection ).For me, this is an amazing step in the right direction from the previous 5 films. I look forward to next year's Transformers: Rise of the Beasts to prove that this was not a fluke and show the world how amazing Transformers can be.

Hands down the best Transformers movie. Bumblebee is what Transformers movie should have been right from the start.

Fashion was meh. It's the 80s we want to see big hair and big shoulder pads. Here's some advice for up and coming fashion designers: Try looking up old highschool, college and university yearbooks. You'll notice that hardly any of the hairstyles we see in this movie match what was popular at the time and instead the movie just has stereotypical 80s and not historically accurate BUT they actually tried UNLIKE MANY movies set in the 80s.

Bumblebee is a masterpiece of a movie, taking everything that the Michael Bay Transformers movies were known for and tossing them out the window. This movie in the franchise doesn't focus on action that much, aside from the opening scene and the last 20 minutes. But since there's not that much action, we get to focus on the main characters great personality's. Charlie works as a protagonist because we get to see her basically being bullied by her parents because she can't get over the passing of her father, as well as her relatability factor. That is until Bumblebee shows up and makes the whole experience even better. Bumblebee is the most wholesome character in this movie, he's just so innocent and curios through out the movie, he's just adorable. Shatter and Dropkick to work well as the main antagonist's of the film. Having them trying to track down Bumblebee and all. Dropkick is actually pretty funny and cocky, while Shatter is there to balance out his attitude with a more serious personality. The supporting characters do their part in Charlies journey, with the bullies picking on her, John Cena helping the Decepticons hunt down Bee. Memo helps Charlie throughout the movie too, while also acting as the human comic relief. Bumblebee is a masterpiece of a film, and i highly recommend it to anyone, wether you're a teen who can relate to Charlie, parents who may relate to Charlie's parents, someone who's into action movies, and most importantly, a transformers fan like me.

The relationship between Bee and Charlie is almost platonic, I love it. I've been getting into Transformers recently, and I can't get enough. Theres plenty of action, comedy and a bit of blossoming romance. Just my type.
Finally a transformers movie with a lot of character and a great amount of character that exceeds the expectations of the Bay movies.

first Godzilla movie was good. This one was overhyped, the acting was garbage, and the story was ridiculous. If you like CGI explosions and video game fight scenes, then this movie is up your alley. Godzilla vs. Kong features dazzling visual effects and action sequences which just about make up for the thin story and characters, if you temper your expectations.

Though the action sequences are enjoyable enough to watch, the actual story is terrible, the human characters are not interesting, and the 'twists' are so predictable and generic. About the only good things I can really think of to say about this are that the worldbuilding is still fantastic, the CGI (though overdone) looks good, and the fights between the two leads are epic, making this yet another entertaining crossover in that regard. However, almost anything else you can think of is done so horribly. The surprise villain(s) are not necessary to have thrown in, and the whole "enemy of my enemy is my friend" mentality at the end is the same for every other versus movie that we've seen in the past. Not to mention a boring plot, story, and characters. In the end, I was extremely disappointed in this film as it turned out to just be another generic versus movie like all the others we've gotten, just with worse characters and a somehow worse story.

Ok, I really liked this version! Some spoilers here. I was a kid when the original King Kong vs Godzilla was shown to me. But it's like Star Trek...there is Orig and Next Gen. you have to separate the two. Have them be their own. The fight scenes here were fun and done great! C'mon everyone...this is for entertainment so ENJOY it! I'm Team Godzilla, but loved they way they portrayed Kong here. The little girl aspect and her relationship with Kong was touching and they did a great spin on what you heard or didnt when it was from her perspective. loved that! I did miss the Godzilla roars that he made (from the original movies) but feel they did a Homage a couple of times as I heard the "real" Godzilla roar! lol and there was one shot in one of the fights when Kong shoved the axe in Godzilla's mouth and THAT to me was a definite nod to the original-which that scene always made me laugh. It made me laugh, even got a little teary a couple times. Overall a good, fun time watching the action, the great graphics. Give it a shot!

Ok, it seems off to complain about the physics/science/logic of a movie that is pretty much an upgrade of a man in a rubber suit movie mixed with a comic book type plot/heroes, but I am going to anyway, and here is why.... If you are going to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on a film to have brilliant cg, a decent cast of actors, a neverending marketing budget, and the coming together of two huge IPs all to make what is not a deep thinking movie, but just pure summer entertainment spectacle, than would it really hurt to spend just a tiny bit more on a script, and shot boarding that can save physics from being completely lost for the duration of the film. I love spectacle movies like this, and I don't care that they are bashed for being 'low-brow', or 'ruining the film industry(along with super hero movies, etc), but when I sit down to watch what should be a total suspension of disbelief, I mean you have me at go, I'm ready to not care that from the start we have two creatures that literally could not exist without pretty much magic, all that I can just put aside, and get into this movie. And then one moment after another of seeing something like kong literally jump from one barge ship onto a destroyer and then onto an aircraft carrier. If you were to have about an equal example, imagine someone puts there toy electric speed boat, about 5 feet away from the dock and then have another model about 2 feet long another 5 feet away, now imagine leaping off that dock and using that middle toy electric boat as a stepping stone to the next. What is going to happen? Everyone knows, everyone knows what is going to happen if you do that, your foot will go right through that boat, and your head will be underwater in seconds. There won't be any graceful leap across the gap landing perfectly on the second, which even bigger would also just split in multiple pieces and sink instantly if anyone were to try to use it to hold up their weight in an ocean. I don't mind questions pseudo science that anyone with a decent amount of physics will for a second cringe in regards, but when the physics is so bloody bad that it literally pulls you immediately out of the movie going(W...T...[]) Then they have honestly screwed up. Because from the fx guys, to the directory, all the way back the writer(who I should just say might never have put something like that in the script and was just added by a producer who thinks that 'we need more explosions and crazy stuff', and thinks that it is his job to contribute to the movie with ideas that his 3 year old son gave him, et. Litearlly some of the craziest thing I have seen be added into a movie was all at the demands of producers who literally have no concept of reality, but have managed to get into the position where they are the money's representation on so then they basically get what they want, to the chagrine of the entire crew, most of all the director and writer. Anyway, but somewhere someone put ideas like that on paper, and someone literally should have said 'we can do better for a move that makes 9 figures to make', we can at least get basic, the most basics of physics. Like the earth is round, and water doesn't flow up unless magic is involved, or my favorite people will not tumble into space if they jump up higher enough and the earth's spin makes them get throw out into space like a peanut on a spinning basketball. Basic physics, like you can't get such basics things down, ie like travelling uphill takes more energy then traveling downhill, and the King of the apes that likely weighs more then the Golden Gate Bridge, cannot walk on water, heck normal gorillas cannot walk on water... Please please don't ruin such amazing IPs with such garbage scenes that can't even hold up to the scrutiny of a 3 year old...

What I loved most about the Star Trek film reboot was the implementation of the Kelvin timeline. It was a well conceived idea that opened unlimited paths of ideas for future Star Trek stories. Then came Into Darkness. The principal characters(Kirk, Spock, etc) were cast perfectly. They are believable as those characters. They are the reason I loved the 2009 Star Trek reboot so much. But I can not buy Benedict Cumberbatch as Khan. As actor of his talent deserved to portray an original advesary all his own. I don't understand how or if they thought they could improve on the best film in the Star Trek series. Into Darkness certainly isn't an homage to The Wrath of Khan. It's an unnecessary remake.

review: I have never seen a movie nose-dive in such an epic way as Star Trek: Into Darkness. I saw it a solid year after release, having heard many mixed things about it, in chunks. Specifically, I recall having to stop watching after the first hour, and at that point I had nothing but positives to say about it. By the time the movie ended, however, I had only contempt for it. Once in a while a movie will choose to sacrifice all goodwill it receives, but this movie pushed at this harder than I have ever witnessed via three things taking place all in a short amount of time. First it performs insanely obtuse plot gymnastics to end up to a particular dramatic moment - Then it milks it out as long and aggressively as possible - And then it pulls a: "Oh, hey - nevermind" twist. And this twist is via a brutally cheap Cheat that makes no sense whatsoever, and would have massive consequences far beyond what are implied in the film itself (like, imagine if a time traveler gave gunpowder to the Roman Empire and then the story said "Otherwise, History was completely the same" when you know that this is impossible. In the end I felt cheated by this film, and the ways that it cheats are the type that even children would likely find cheap as well. It's not the worst, but not at all recommended beyond the audio and visual spectacle. It certainly looks and sounds great, not just in terms of post-production but the lighting and cinematography are solid as well, even if it was of the semi-monochromatic blockbusters, made shortly before that fad (fortunately) died.

Aside from a few dull scenes that slowed down the film as well as some minor elements that didn't make a ton of sense, this film was an enjoyable time for both my eyes and ears! Hans Zimmer's score along with much of the cinematography and directing of action scenes, plus for sure Joaquin Phoenix's incredible acting, made this film what it is. This is the first sword and sandals film that I have seen and I can see why some might consider it the best one!

Gladiator is the epic story of a general who is enslaved and forced to fight in the Coliseum in a low fantasy world loosely based on the Roman Empire. Jokes about the complete lack of historical accuracy aside, Gladiator has some strong points - Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) makes for a decent villain, the camerawork is strong, and the action, while occasionally spoiled by the dated slow-motion effects, is satisfying. Unfortunately, the screenplay is entirely unbefitting a Best Picture winner. It is full of pseudo-profundities and is unnecessarily depressing, fridging the main character's family almost immediately in the most horrific way possible. Worse, the awful events Maximus experiences provoke little character development beyond making him a bit bitter. He is not the only one with vague characterization: the screenplay provides little in the way of coherent character motivations for the actors (save perhaps Phoenix) to work with, and perhaps consequently, almost every line is delivered like a speech or soliloquy even when this is inappropriate for the context. Gladiator is an alright film if you want to turn your brain off and enjoy the sights, but critics often present the film as intellectually-engaging art, a modern Spartacus, which it most definitely is not.
Visceral action and a great story make Gladiator one to watch and re-watch again and again.

I'm a big ole sucker for self-serious political philosophizing, and the line Rome straddles between continued tyranny under the sole hands of an emperor or a renewed republic with power restored to the senate provides ample opportunity for this. I'm also a sucker for Russel Crowe scowling on a revenge quest. I'm also a sucker for the performer-audience relationship within combat sports, and this film actively plays on that with "the Spaniard" becoming a renown fan-favorite of the Coliseum-going populace. Effective in many more ways that not.

You can never go wrong with this movie. Whether you are a history fan and love the Romans, or you love raw action movies. This movie has it all. Personally, I love both, and my name is Maximilian, so hearing my name be chanted during the movie gives me my own dopamine boost. This movie will never get old. A truly classic movie. And for you history lovers, it is one of the most accurate "Hollywood" depictions of Rome.
Mildly entertaining but nothing unexpected.

I've heard about this movie many times. I've seen bits and pieces of it on television. To watch it all the way through from start to finish, well, let's just say that I'm amazed for what they have crafted. GLADIATOR is an amazing spectacle full of action, drama, and suspense.

Looking back, it's been a pretty violent week in terms of film watching for me. I hadn't seen Gladiator for seventeen years, and I've wondered for a long time whether I would hold it in the same high regard I did as a fourteen year old. Especially as the last Ridley Scott film I saw was another of his historical epics, the directors cut of Kingdom Of Heaven (2005), which was boring bordering on insulting. Orlando Bloom sank the film like one of the many boulders falling to the ground in the films' action sequences, which served as a far too infrequent alarm clock for me throughout its seeming three day run time. Gladiator, thankfully, is every bit as impressive the second time round. Ridley Scott has always been a fabulous world builder, (that includes Kingdom Of Heaven) and his vision of Rome is staggering. Russell Crowe can be a figure of ridicule at times, but is on mellowed, low key, Oscar winning form here, and he is terrific. It's not often that a film with so many action fight sequences can hold you on the edge of your seat for all of them, but Gladiator achieves this in spades, and is genuinely thrilling. Joaquin Phoenix is pitifully creepy and superbly effective as the villainous Commodus, and Connie Nielsen provides excellent support, alongside the late Richard Harris in a small role. Apart from perhaps The Martian (2015), it's a long time since Scott has been on top form, and Gladiator reminds you of how good he can be.
