The romantic comedy genre has often drifted into dark territory what with the brilliance of The Apartment (1960) and A Touch of Class (1973) but this 1990 mega hit attempts to dress up the shallow materialism and prostitution it deals with as though a woman being bought really is a fairytale. Many will argue that the film gets by on the charm of the two leads, a very young Julia Roberts and supposed ‚Äòsilver fox' Richard Gere, but I found their performances rather dull and never particularly engaging. When compared to the superlative When Harry Met Sally‚Ä¶ (1989) it becomes clear just how lacking this film is in both romance and comedy and even Marshall's trashterpiece Beaches (1988) shows up all of the flaws of this movie as it lacks even the campy charm of that Bette Midler classic. Prostitute Vivian Ward, Julia Roberts, helps corporate raider Edward Lewis, Richard Gere, drive his manual car from Hollywood Boulevard to his upmarket hotel and he agrees to employ her services for one week. She is paid $3000 and he gives her money to purchase an expensive new wardrobe so that she will be able to impress his clients. The two begin to fall in love much to her chagrin and she softens him as he struggles to dismantle the company of a man who wants to continue operating it. With her new outfits and relationship with Lewis Ward begins to gain confidence and is able to charm Lewis's associates with her straightforward style of speaking and beauty. They face challenges when Lewis is forced to reveal to others that Ward is a prostitute and they begin to question the nature of their relationship. After Ward departs for fear of simply being an object to Lewis she is won back by him as he performs a routine in which he imitates one of the ‚Äòknights in shining armor' she had imagined as a child. This is one of those films that pretends to be about how money is not worth as much as genuine love and affection but negates that idea constantly with how obsessed the characters are with status symbols and the creepy nature of the relationship. Ward is essentially bought by her love interest and their connection seems to be based on the fact that she is physically attractive and he can buy her pretty clothing. Even when we are meant to believe that they are ‚Äòreally' falling for one another we hear Ward ask Lewis how much the necklace he bought her costs and while her leaving the money he offers her on the bed is meant to be symbolic she is still departing with expensive clothing and the $300 he paid for her services. A film that portrays the power imbalance in this sort of relationship for what it actually is can be found in Klute (1971) which explores the psychological impact that actually falling in love with a man can have on a prostitute. While this clearly does not aspire to be as gritty or honest as Klute it would have been nice to see this film be less disgusting in the way that it equates a man owning a woman as him loving her. There is also hypocrisy in the film's message about big business as we are meant to believe that Lewis is ‚Äòcruel' in dismantling an old man's business but this is what he does for a job and if he were not doing this he would not have the money to pay for Ward's clothing and ‚Äòservices'. This is what makes it so objectionable when she urges him not to go ahead with his plans. We are meant to believe that this woman, who is surely familiar with using people for money, is so innocent that she believes Lewis can go on losing money because a few businessman won't let their businesses go. We are also meant to believe that she is ‚Äòhelping' him by encouraging him to make these decisions and her final line "She rescued him right back" is supposed to ensure us that she can hold control over their relationship. This is not true as if they are to remain together, living the way they do, he will have to continue his corporate raiding and she will have to turn a blind eye so that she can continue going to the opera. The lead performances are where the film really lost me as usually even the most average screenplay, this one is quite awful, can be lifted by two charismatic leads a la Falling in Love (1984). Roberts is meant to be so darn cute and charming but is never convincing either as the country bumpkin with the knowledge of cars or the sophisticate who loves opera. She seems too highly strung and calculating, qualities used well in My Best Friend's Wedding (1997), to be the guileless little hooker we are meant to fall for in this film. Gere on the other hand doesn't register at all as he is a bland, uninspiring romantic lead with none of the manic intensity he brought to Unfaithful (2002) or Arbitrage (2016). The two together lack chemistry and you never feel as though they are anything more than friends even when naked in a bathtub together. This is definitely one to miss as there are many wonderful romantic comedies out there, even ones concerning prostitutes, that are funnier and more romantic than this one.

Not your typical animated movie ending, "Cars" is an inventive story with colorful characters and really slick (pun partially intended) animation. Lots of positive messages in the plot as we observe the moral transformation of the protagonist.

A Pixar release that is a coming of age story about a race car who gets stranded in an old route 66 town in the southwest. Once again PIxar ups the game in computer animation. Noticeable improvements include the backgrounds, lighting and dust/smoke effects. If you don't think too hard about how this world filled with talking cars works, this movie has an entertaining story. Larry the Cable Guy works as a comedic side character, the love story is believable, and Paul Newman plays a great mentor character. For a franchise intended to sell toys, this movie works and I'd recommend checking it out.

Cars is an animation movie, made by Disney Pixar in 2006, in the cast there's names such as Owen Wilson as Lightning MacQueen and Paul Newman as Doc Hudson. The movie is about a selfish race car who gets lost in a small town called "Radiator Springs". There he meets Mater, a winch car who will become his best friend by the end of the movie. It's completely awesome and surprising to see the evolution of Lightning MacQueen along the movie. The people (or the cars) he met there changes him to a very kind and generous person (or car), and you can literally feel the connection and the friendship they made there. Also, a great aspect of the movie is the quality of it. For a movie made in 2006 it is just incredible. As far as I'm concerned they used a technology called ray tracing. Its function is to calculate the trajectory of the light based on shadows and light points. And believe me, it does its job. The movie is just impeccable! Another surprising and completely original aspect of the movie is the soundtrack, which fits just perfectly the ambience of the movie.

Cars gets a pretty bad press, as far as I can gather it seems to suffer from being the first Pixar vehicle (whay) that dipped below excellent. Cars, following the story of racer Lightning McQueen on his road to redemption after getting lost in the wilderness, is far too long at an almost inexplicable 2 hours, and it really meanders in the middle section. It's baffling considering the subject matter would obviously appeal to an even younger audience than normal. But, the first half an hour is up there with the best and most exciting segments in Pixars' back catalogue, the opening race sequence and surrounding inventiveness are superb, and there are laughs a plenty. It's certainly in a different league to Cars 3 (2017) which is very dull, but in perhaps being overconfident in it's length, Cars falls short of Pixar's previous outings.

Ok‚Ä¶why do people hate this movie again? This movie is fine, really good at some points even, but people act like this is the worse Pixar movie ever made, and it just isn't. Not even close to it. One, the voice acting is really good in this movie, especially Owen Wilson and weirdly Larry the Cable Guy. Secondly, the animation, like in almost every Pixar movie, is great. All the racing scenes are fast and smooth, which you need for this kind of movie. Wow, I'm praising this movie, but it still has major problems! For example, there isn't really a huge emotional moment in this movie, and unlike the incredibles, you can't get away with that here. But the biggest thing is the concept and the plot. It's a fish out of water story about a big city kid going into a small town and learning humility. We've seen that a bunch of times, and this doesn't change the formula up at all, except for them being cars. Speaking of which, there is no reason why the characters should be cars, like I can't give you a good reason for it. With all of that said‚Ä¶.I like this movie. Is it a top 10 Pixar movie? No, far from it actually. But is it the animated movie that everyone thinks is the worse Pixar movie ever? No, again far from it. There were 3 Pixar movies in the 2010s alone that I hated more than this, and I could argue that they made a Pixar movie worse than this even before Cars was made. Ever heard of that boring movie called A Bugs Life? Yeah, I'm not bored by Cars unlike that movie. So‚Ä¶.do you agree or disagree with me on this? Go to Disney+ and see it for yourself!
Not amongst the top notch Pixar entries but still more than good enough to hold it's own.

Cars was the one franchise that really got me into Pixar. I honestly didn't know much about Pixar until I saw this movie, I used to love this movie as a kid, and I probably would've gave it a 10/10 if you were to ask me. However that was back then. Now that I am older now what do I think of the movie now? Actually the movie is still pretty good. Not one of Pixar's best but at the very least it's still is good. One of the highlights of this movie is actually the message that it teaches. In this one a hot shot rookie named Lightning McQueen gets in and over his head about winning the Piston Cup. However after his three way tie between Chick Hits and The King he's in a hurry to get to his last chance of winning the Piston Cup he has to get to California in time before the big race, however all of his plans change and then he ends up in a small town called Radiator Springs. This is actually we're the movie shines the best. The movie's entire message is about taking a break from you normal routine and just enjoy life for once. Yes you can get back to your normally but it is also important to take it easy and just look at life around you. Honestly I like the message that the film was trying to teach but by far the best thing about this movie is the relationship between Lightning McQueen and Doc Hudson. Their relationship is actually the most heartwarming of the movie. However the movie is not perfect though in fact it's far from it while it is actually a nice message to have for kids the movie does feel a bit too long and it can feel like some thing could be cut out however even with that though it still make sense because of the film's message of enjoying life and the people or in this case cars around you also there are some scenes that do kinda feel like it's filler and the animation, while good, it can get boring to look at considering the fact that they are cars and they don't have a lot of range to make it entertaining. All in all Cars was a pretty good movie. With a good message, and likable characters, it might not be a fun ride but it is a smooth one. 7.8/10

This movie is about the first major battle from imperial japanese against China in 1937, when the war didn't even started yet in Europe (world war 2 started in europe in 1939, almost 2 years later). First of all in a cinematographic standpoint, this was a masterpiece. Second of all, how can people dare to say this is propaganda, when there are actual historic footages from that time still in historic archives depicting that event, recorded by journalists. And the movie didn't even portrayed the chinese soldiers having a victory, but it was a bloody retreat, as was described in history that is even recorded and known in western history books. And the soldiers weren't even communists, they were from NRA from Chiang Kaisheks army. Also the West, as in The League of Nations didn't lay a finger to help the chinese to fight fascism. It's a shame and disgrace of western cinemas not putting this movie in mainstream theaters and telling the story about the brave sacrifice these chinese soldiers have made in trying to defend their dignity and country.

Great war movie. Japan invades Shanghai in 1937, and after 3 months of intense fighting, the Chinese Nationalist army decides to retreat. To cover their retreat, they leave behind a regiment of 400 soldiers (exaggerated to be 800) in a warehouse, located strategically near a river, across from the foreign "concessions." What transpires over the next 4 days is a heroic stand against the Japanese invaders. Even though there isn't one main "character," I feel like the main character of the movie was the entire regiment. The movie is a little long, but it hits all the right emotional notes. Definitely recommended.

I was born in Taiwan (Republic of China) and I was very surprised to see a movie made in mainland China that depicts the flag and sung the national anthem of the Republic of China. My own grandparents weren't those veteran soldiers who retreated to Taiwan with Chang Kei Shek but the story of the 800 still resonated with me. I think it is very nice to see a world war 2 movie that is not western centric, because after all it was a world war and so throughout the entire world there were many unsung heroes who gave their lives to defend their own countries from foreign invasion. THe production value of this movie was top notch and it was on par with big Hollywood war movies like Dunkirk and 1917. However I thought the actors over-acted a little and the performance didn't feel "natural". The actions in the movie were superb but the pacing of the storytelling felt a bit odd at places. So while I think the production value, the visuals and the action scenes were excellent but the acting and the storytelling were a little weak. There are also numerous Chinese cultural references and most western audience will not be able to appreciate the significance unless they are versed in classics of the Chinese literature. For example, the white horse and the medieval warrior riding the white horse in the "dream sequence" was a reference to a character (and a historical figure) from the historical fiction novel The Romance of Three Kingdoms. Since this movie is an international release so perhaps the director should have included a footnote in the movie or something to help the western audience understand it. Anyway, The Eight Hundred is a pretty good war movie, and I am glad to have seen it.
The Anti-Japanese War is a history of blood and tears for the Chinese people.

review: Oof, let's remember that every film has positives and negative's. The fact that Fox retconned so many decisions made in this film alone let's you know they screwed the pooch on this film. The bad, a story like Dark Phoenix needs every detail from the source material to make it right, Simon Kinberg clearly thought otherwise (so much so that he basically did the same story adaption for the latest Dark Phoenix attempt, ugh!). While going the "easier" route by making the Phoenix a dual personality within Jean Grey would hold more general audiences attention then going full out space bound like in the comics; this diversion from said source material handicaps the film, leaving true X-Men fans with a sour taste in their mouth. The good, I always believe that if you're struggling to find something redeemable in a bad movie, always consider the score! The music composition in Last Stand will give you chills thanks to John Powell's amazing foresight into a scenes emotional state. Despite the horrible decision to kill off Professor X & Cyclops in the first act of the film, both moments are heightened to a 10 thanks to Powell (I get frisson every. time Dark Phoenix takes full control of Jean)! The acting throughout is exceptionally well with the main cast despite cringe worthy one liners and the mass injustice done to Rogues character and Anna Paquins acting ability. Famke Jansen and Hugh's chemistry in the film alone makes this an easier pill to swallow and really sales the final confrontation! Overall, a Dark Phoenix storyline done right will need heavy development, and it'll probably be a good while before another attempt at this iconic storyline. Although, now that X-Men is in the hands of Kevin Feige I have no doubt the next time we have to take this journey with Jean and the X-Men it will be a glory to behold.

review: The action was the best of the trilogy, but the plot was terrible. It appears that the producers cut crucial scenes from the film, showing how characters individually decided which side they were on. It was almost like people chose sides solely based on whether they were allies of Xavier or allies of Magneto. The story started out with members of the X-Men, like Dr. Hank McCoy vehemently denouncing the cure. Hank was so opposed to it that he resigned from his position on the cabinet. However, later on, the X-Men ended up defending the cure, almost as if the only reason they cared was that they needed to be against anything Magneto wanted. The resolution to the film was equally disappointing. Did societies efforts to develop a cure just magically stop? Also, if the film already demonstrated that Dr. Hank McCoy's position on the cabinet meant nothing when it came to policy, why would his being appointed to the UN mean anything either? Most egregiously, because the movie removed any ethical depth, it argued that anything more than waving a sign in disagreement with something was wrong. Most mutants regarded the cure like someone would regard trying to "cure" someone who's gay. Instead of the movie arguing that mutants should fight for their rights, while still trying to respect non-mutant's rights, the movie advocated for mutants to be push-overs, hoping that non-mutants would magically become enlightened. More broadly, since most viewers have drawn parallels between mutants and other marginalized groups, the message of the movie is that marginalized groups in the real world should just let their oppressors step all over them.

review: I'm surprised to see a big drop in average rating for this. I enjoyed 'X-Men: The Last Stand' to be honest. Taking a quick look at some other reviews and it seems to main gripe is how it treats certain characters from the comics, which is fair enough for sure but that doesn't come into play for me as I'm not a comic reader. I can only judge it as a film and as one I found it suitably entertaining. Hugh Jackman remains the top dog, though at the beginning the way Wolverine acts felt off to me - though that quickly went away. I would've liked if they found a spot for Nightcrawler (Alan Cumming), though one of his replacements in Beast (Kelsey Grammer) went down well with me. From what I read I can understand other people's complaints with this, especially with the aforementioned iffy character treatment, but I gotta be honest and say that I found it to be a good enough watch - even if it is comparatively the weakest entry of the original trilogy. /copied directly from my Letterboxd review\

review: All punch and unfortunately, not enough time for the depth and substance the 3rd entry to the franchise deserved. The effects and action were good for its era, but it was waay too short and it felt so very rushed. Why?! This had always boggled my mind. In order to do justice to the Phoenix Saga you really need at the very least, one trilogy to tell the tale. Instead, not only did they do a Phoenix movie in a lottle over 90 minutes, but that in addition, they actually attempted to cram another story about mutants and the political/philosophical debate about accepting one's self of who you are or take a "cure" for it and remove it permanently to fit in, be normal and protect those around you ftom an unexpected mutant power going off and hurting an innocent person in that process. These two things should definetly be two seperate films. Big mistake. Over-all a disappointment with average dialogue and a very cool and good 2nd chapter in Jean Gray's home. That scene for me was the highlight. The first half of the movie was pretty good and the last half was a big, big disappointment.

review: Not even nearly as bad as the superfans make it out to be. Is it perfect? No. But it doesn't really need to be. Kelsey Grammar's Beast is a huge highlight, the CG has aged pretty well and Wolverine is always a delight when he's hanging out with his X-Men buddies. Magneto gets a huge wow moment when he lifts the entire Golden Gate Bridge and Famke Jannssen's Dark Phonenix while a little too 'The Exorcist' is believable and well done. If you put the nitpicking aside there is an enjoyable ride to be had. If you still think the movie is bad, go watch Simon Kinberg's Dark Phoenix (2019) and I'm sure you'll change your mind. The mid credits scene is disappointing, so I try to forget about it. It's really just bad writing. If you're brave, watch it. If not, just stop watching as soon as it's over.

review: X-Men: The Last Stand was the first X-Men movie I had ever watched. The house fight scene where Wolverine, Storm and Xavier get beaten was the first scene I saw of an X-Men movie. So you can understand how heavy of an impact this movie left on me. My hero, my man, all 3 of them, getting beaten to pulp. But I thought probably that's just one scene and they may get their comeuppance later. And so I stopped watching this movie. I watched it many years later when I began watching every movie from this franchise. So this movie suffers from something I like to call "replacement disruption". It means when someone replaces the director of the movie and then the director makes the movie as if he has never seen the franchise before. Like Joss Whedon for Justice League, Chris Miller in Shrek the Third, Richard Lester for Superman III, Joel Schumacher for Batman Forever etc. This movie throws away all the concepts established previously. Wolverine no longer cares about Rogue, Scott dies as soon as the movie begins, Xavier is killed off, Magneto discards Mystique once she's of no use to him and Wolverine KILLS Phoenix! I really hate what this movie did to my favourite heroes, but I like the fact that this movie has some really good CGI. It shows the concept of mutants being shamed into thinking that they are bad because of their superpowers, and that they should give them up and live like humans. This was actually a really interesting storyline, and it should have been the one which should have been given more emphasis instead of whatever Jean was doing. Warren Worthington III was also a very interesting character and should have been given more screen time. The visual appeal, the score and the acting are all perfect, but the terrible storyline and lack of understanding the concept is what ruins it. Batman v Superman also had the same problem, but at least that was supposed to be the tone of the franchise. Here the tone of the franchise was very different, and this movie is the one which completely changed it and made X-Men the diverse franchise which it is. It is the reason why we got Deadpool and Logan, so I guess that's one good thing that came out of this movie.

review: It really isn't that bad. The idea of a cure and Magneto and other mutants trying to destroy it is actually a really great idea for a finale of the trilogy and continues the themes established in the first really well and that plotline is developed really well with Ian McKellen's excellent performance as well as enough screentime. The action is super well-handled especially the final battle, Storm and Wolverine gets some cool moments and UNPOPULAR OPINION, I kind of like how Xavier died and the movie did a good job exploring the impact of his death. The Phoenix Storyline also had good potential. On the other hand, there are so many characters in this movie that serve no purpose to the plot like Angel despite some nice scenes, it feels convoluted and lacks a singular storyline, the Phoenix storyline felt forced, the ending felt rushed and it lacks the style of the first 2 movies and what they did to Cyclops was unacceptable (although X-2 also treated him poorly). Overall, it's a decent enough ending but could have been a lot better but I'd much rather watch this over Dark Phoenix and Origins Wolverine

If anything, it has the same flaws and strengths as the first film. The plot is stupid and improbable yet the adventure and camaraderie between actors are a lot of fun and there is some education to be had but, like Indiana Jones, it's in a fun way. review_date: A good easy to watch movie. Plenty to like about it, keeps you interested till the end. i like it as much if not more than the first film. Yes it's improbable and a little far fetched, but what movie isn't. So grab some snacks, sit back and enjoy
